description: Trenton

title: Valerie Witoshkin, Charles Fox
description: Valerie Witoshkin and Charles Garrett Fox were married yesterday by the Right Rev. Vincent Saverino at St. Michael the Archangel Russian Orthodox Church in Philadelphia.

title: A Question of Debris as Drivers Voice Doubts
description: DOVER, Del., June 2  Stock cars are wondrous contraptions, built to run for hundreds of miles on hot summer afternoons, often while banging into other stock cars. But they are, after all, still pieces of machinery. They can, and often do, fall apart.

title: Innocents Lost
description: Who is this Nathan Englander, at 37 so young in novelist years, but already possessed of an old masters voice? Well, its not his voice exactly; one senses that Bernard Malamud and Isaac Bashevis Singer are living under the name Nathan Englander in a witness protection program for Jewish fabulists. But the mans apparent lack of vanity is impressive.

title: In the Wee Small Hours
description: Should the aliens ever descend in their sleek ships and train their great scanners on our population centers, capturing our deeds and dreams for transmission back to cosmic headquarters, lets hope they show us the patient tenderness of Haruki Murakami, the Japanese novelist, who himself is not wholly of this world. In a dozen books on our existence here  not in Japan or any special nation but as children of gravity, as earthlings  Murakami has done as good a job as any contemporary writer of pleading humanitys poignant case before the court of whoever may be out there. Have mercy, oh interstellar lords. Were lonesome and small and we know not what we do, only that were obliged by God or nature to bathe, dress, eat and keep on doing it.

title: Patricia Murphy, Todd Stein
description: Patricia Marie Murphy and Todd Matthew Stein were married yesterday at Great Meadow, an equestrian center in The Plains, Va. Norman E. Cartwright-Brown, a Virginia civil marriage celebrant, officiated.

title: Making Accidents Less Likely to Happen
description: ALMOST every home or apartment has at least a few accidents waiting to happen, and if they do occur, they can cause thousands of dollars in damage.

title: Vive le Tour? Bien Sur!
description: Since Lance Armstrong pedaled triumphantly into the sunset in 2005, his sport seems to have embarked on a sincere and surprisingly efficient effort to destroy itself, most notably by a theatrical series of drug scandals. Though were shocked  shocked!  that anybody in this toughest of endurance races would illicitly boost his octane, its hard not to be impressed by the magnitude of the bamboozlement. Exhibit A: Operation Puerto, a Spanish investigation that began in May 2006 and that uncovered, among other violations, a freezer brimming with 223 bags of blood from over 100 top riders, plus coded notes tracking their treatments. Say what you will about the seriousness of Balco: until the day when a sizable chunk of Major League Baseball stars are storing doped blood at the clinic for stretch-run transfusions, American sports still have some catching up to do. All of which leaves us in a dilemma: do we pass grim judgment (a pox on les cheaters!), or sit back on July 7 with a cold sauvignon blanc and toast the worlds most grueling, beautiful, unbelievable race? Weve made our choice.  votre sant!

title: A Battle With Depression and Suicidal Tendencies
description: Susan Endersbe, a schizophrenic who lived in Minneapolis, battled depression all her life. When her illness worsened, she usually checked into a hospital, which she did for the last time on May 7, 1994. On that occasion, doctors gave her an antidepressant, and three weeks later she said she felt ready to leave soon, according to nurses notes.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 8 P.M. (MTV) 2007 MTV MOVIE AWARDS Sarah Silverman, left, is host of this years ceremony, with duties ranging from frisking patrons at the door to serving popcorn  the Golden Bucket variety. Awards, presented live at the Gibson Amphitheater in Universal City, include breakthrough performance and best in categories like villain, performance, comedic performance, kiss, fight and summer movie you havent seen yet. Jessica Alba, Victoria Beckham, Jessica Biel, Cameron Diaz, Zac Efron, Ioan Gruffudd, Samuel L. Jackson Mandy Moore and Bruce Willis are among the presenters. Amy Winehouse, Rihanna and Jay-Z will perform. Viewers will choose best movie spoof from among hundreds of amateur film clips at mtvmovieawards.yahoo.com.

title: In a Busy Season, a Return Engagement?
description: How likely is it that a major hurricane will strike Miami this year? Or Galveston, Tex.? Or the Outer Banks of North Carolina?

title: Our Green Bubble
description: Surely the most glaring contrast in American political life today is the amount of words, speeches and magazine covers devoted to the necessity of going green, combating climate change and gaining energy security, and the actual solutions being offered by our leaders to do any of these things. You could very comfortably drive a Hummer through the gap between our words and deeds.

description: Ashley Elizabeth True, the daughter of Thea True and T. Craig True of Amelia Island Fla., is to be married today to Aaron Charles Lang, the son of Dr. Enid A. Lang and Norton D. Lang of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Cathy Barksdale, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Ribault Club on Fort George Island in Jacksonville, Fla.

description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 2  A militant group in Nigerias oil-producing Niger Delta said Saturday that it would temporarily cease its campaign of pipeline attacks, bombings and kidnappings to allow for a negotiated settlement of its grievances with the newly elected government.

title: Demand for School Chiefs Pushes Salaries Up
description: SALARIES for school superintendents rose at a rate well above inflation in Westchester last year, according to new state figures. School board officials attribute the increase to the difficulty of finding candidates capable of meeting the high expectations of suburban parents and homeowners.

description: BOGOT, Colombia, May 30  His name is Emmanuel.

title: Women of the Revolution
description: In 1791, Olympe de Gouges, a radical pamphleteer, published a response to the Declaration of the Rights of Man and the Citizen, which proclaimed France a constitutional monarchy and gave all men of property the right to vote. Woman is born free and lives equal to man in her rights, reads the first article of her Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen, which demanded full political rights and responsibilities for women. Since woman has the right to mount the scaffold, Gouges noted, she must equally have the right to mount the rostrum.

title: A New Outpost in the Civilian World

title: Freelancers Inc.
description: THE smallest of small businesses  the self-employed and freelancers  rarely get their voices heard in the halls of government. And when small-business concerns are publicly debated, all too often they are simply a mask for proposals that are really intended to benefit corporate interests  farm subsidies and the estate tax cut come to mind.

title: North American Songbird
description: PICTURE Lucille Ball and Tinkerbell engaged in a duet and you have an apt metaphor for the neo-folk singer Becky Stark, who suggests an impish fairy from a faraway land. Her eyes are wide, and her madcap stories full of exclamation points. She seems perpetually atwitter, at once ditzy and all knowing.

title: Comings and Goings
description: JetBlue and Expedia.com have announced a deal in which the online travel agency will list JetBlue flights for the next five years. Last August, JetBlue, known for its independence within the travel industry, began selling flights through Sabre Holdings, which owns Travelocity.com, another online travel agency that has been offering JetBlue flights on a testing basis since last September. ... Travelers spending the night near Chicagos OHare airport can now do it in style. The Hyatt Regency OHare has undergone a $60 million renovation, which includes a new restaurant, a private lounge with leather walls, a 24-hour gym and a business center. Nightly rates start at $219 (www.ohare.hyatt.com). ... The Courtauld Institute of Art Gallery in London (www.courtauld.ac.uk) will play host to Englands first exhibition devoted exclusively to the works of the German Renaissance painter, Lucas Cranach the Elder (1472-1553). The highlight of the exhibition, from June 21 through Sept. 23, will be Cranachs Adam and Eve (1526), above. Gallery admission is 5 euros; free for those under 18 and students and for all on Mondays from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. ... Blue Man Group, the extremely popular multimedia theatrical experience, will begin performances at Universal Orlando Resorts Sharp Aquos Theater this Wednesday. The theater, which features a hard-to-miss 30-foot-tall Blue Man facade, is accessible from both the Universal CityWalk and the Universal Studios theme park. Tickets start at $59, and $49 for ages 3 to 9 (www.universalorlando.com).

title: Jennifer Openshaw and Randy Schwimmer
description: JENNIFER OPENSHAW had been walking for hours before she settled into a cafe on a side street in Florence. Her hair was pulled back in a ponytail, she wore no makeup and she had on sweat pants, a T-shirt and sneakers. Though weary from the walking, she contentedly began eating a mocha gelato.

title: Sweet Franaise
description: The tricky thing about writing historical novels isnt getting the details right. Its knowing which details to leave out  even if that means keeping most of your painstaking research to yourself. You want a novel to read like a novel, not a pageant with elaborate stage sets and showy costumes. This is a skill that suspense novelists like Joseph Kanon and Alan Furst have mastered. And so, for the most part, has the author of April in Paris, the German screenwriter Michael Wallner. But where Kanon and Furst create worlds peopled by complex characters who breathe a rich atmosphere, Wallner has produced somewhat lighter fare.

title: Do You Believe in Magic?
description: My friends here in western Massachusetts usually dont let me down. Kris, the truck-stop waitress, referred me to Michelle, a bartender at the gentlemens club down the road, who directed me to Kim, the red-haired dancer with an ankh-tattoo armband, who referred me to an ex-boyfriends wifes girlfriend, another redhead, who met me outside an American Legion hall in Chicopee (Nipmuck for land of violent pee) and informed me that magic mushrooms were out of season, but she could get me LSD instead. Acid  same deal as mushrooms, she said. Besides, she wondered why a guy in his 60s wanted to experiment with shrooms. The answer was obvious. I had a review to write.

title: The Not-So-Tell-Tale Heart
description: Sue Cox says that her 17-year-old son, Tim, started playing sports practically in the womb. A standout on junior-league basketball and Pop Warner football teams in Hudson, N.H., he was, by high school, among the top basketball players in the state as well as a starting safety on the football team. I lived for sports, you could say, Tim says.

title: Malicious Boycotts
description: The University and College Union, a newly formed British union of college teachers, shamefully called last week for a boycott on contacts and exchanges with Israeli academic institutions. That follows on the shameful call in April by the National Union of Journalists in Britain to boycott Israeli goods.

title: Silent Running
description: HICKSVILLE

title: Comics
description: Few underground cartoonists deserve that subterranean title so fully as Kim Deitch. He was there at the beginning of the movement, drawing for The East Village Other in 1967, and his work retains much of that psychedelic, R. Crumb-like earthiness.

title: Fighting Worsens as Lebanese Army Surrounds Militants
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 2  Heavy shelling and gunfire continued for the second day at the Nahr al Bared refugee camp, as the Lebanese Army intensified its offensive against the Fatah al Islam militia.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Heinrich Heine Memorial in the Bronx, misstated its location on the Grand Concourse. It is 161st Street, not 164th Street. (It was moved from 164th Street in 1999.)

title: Thompson Makes Strong Pitch to Conservative Republicans
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 2  In a preview of the themes he is likely to emphasize in a presidential campaign, Fred D. Thompson tossed some red meat to Republicans here Saturday night, assailing the immigration bill in Congress and warning of a mushroom cloud he said radicals around the world were waiting to see rise over the United States.

title: A Wall Talks, but What Does It Say?
description: MICHAEL NAMER had for years heard rumors that something beautiful was hidden behind the walls at 151 Wooster Street, a building he owns in SoHo, near Houston Street.

title: Plot Was Unlikely to Work, Experts Say, Citing Safeguards and Pipeline Structure
description: Federal authorities said that four men were hoping to blow up Kennedy International Airport and a large swath of Queens by detonating a fuel pipeline and storage tanks, but oil industry executives and local officials said yesterday that such a plot was probably not feasible.

title: Gay Inmates to Be Granted Conjugal Visits in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1  Gay and lesbian prisoners in California will be allowed overnight visits with their partners under a new prison policy, believed to be the first time a state has allowed same-sex conjugal stays.

title: Parallel Paths
description: The protagonist of Javier Cercass 2001 novel, Soldiers of Salamis, self-deprecatingly claims he cant give up writing because his writing never amounted to anything to begin with. Cercas could say the same for his own career as a Spanish novelist  until that book, a stealthily brilliant semifictional account of the Spanish Civil War, became an unexpected best seller in Spain and abroad. Now Cercas has written another novel about the aftermath of war  this time the Vietnam War  and art has caught up with life: his writer protagonist is wildly, cravenly successful, and Cercas-the-author embarks on a dual reckoning with the nature of war and the writing life.

title: Thousands Wait to Hear Ousted Pakistani Justice
description: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan, Sunday, June 3  Pakistans suspended chief justice led a cavalcade of about 100 cars jammed with lawyers and political supporters on a 75-mile trip from Islamabad on Saturday, continuing to protest his dismissal by Gen. Pervez Musharraf two months ago.

title: Whose Katonah Is It, Anyway?
description: The familiar and the fancy are combined to splendid effect in the Katonah Collection, the people at Martha Stewarts empire tell us, pitching a $12 catalogue of furniture and home furnishings that sell for a lot more than that. The line showcases classic American style, accented with a touch of formal refinement, which presumably is how they do things in Katonah, where Ms. Stewart owns a 153-acre estate.

title: Shattered
description: On the one hand, its bad timing: who would want their 9/11 novel to be published so soon after Don DeLillos 9/11 novel? DeLillo, its fair to say, began circling this material long ago. (The cover of Underworld, to name one uncanny example, had a planelike bird flying toward the twin towers.) On the other hand, if your novel happens to be as finely wrought, deeply felt and mercifully funny as Helen Schulmans Day at the Beach, then this timing turns out to be an affirming coincidence, allowing us to see how another talented writer can alchemize that same terrible day.

title: A Defeat Feels Like Yet Another Body Blow for Yankees
description: BOSTON, June 2  There have been so many days like this, so many games when the bad news piles so high for the Yankees that the loss on the field seems secondary, and almost inevitable.

title: Serena Hoy, James Reilly
description: Serena Jeanine Hoy and James Dalton Reilly were married last evening at St. Johns College in Annapolis, Md. Judge Merrick B. Garland of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser
description: To the Editor:

title: King or Queen for a Day? Have We Got a Castle for You
description: VERONA

title: When Its Time to Pay the Piper
description: ASSESSMENTS come in all sizes, none of them custom-tailored. Though apartment owners in straitened financial circumstances or on fixed incomes may be tempted to throw themselves on the mercy of the board, they shouldnt expect much.

title: Boomtown
description: How do you keep suspense alive when you open a story with an atomic blast? Its something that addicts of the high-tension television series 24 asked themselves earlier this year when, on the second night of the new season, a suitcase nuke exploded in California, releasing a mushroom cloud over Valencia. As the next episodes unfolded, the audience wrestled with an uneasy concept: a nuclear strike isnt the end of the world  that is, not for its survivors. For the purposes of dramatic fiction, at least, the bomb was just a starting shot that set off a mad dash for security and compromise, a race no human would want to run, given the choice.

title: A Grand Opening for BMWs Quick-Tanning Machine
description: DRIVING a BMW 3 Series after some time away is like being reunited with a favorite band. The in-line 6 sounds its opening notes and you think, Hey, I remember that song.

title: Modernist Times
description: The recent death of Arthur Schlesinger Jr. was a sad reminder of how the public intellectual is passing from our midst. That is to say, the individual still bold enough to put his mind and his knowledge to use in analyzing the world around us, in language that most of us can understand, and with an eye toward effecting practical improvements. This is apparently a rarer skill set than most of us might once have imagined.

title: Leading Men Lead the Field: Five Riveting Performances Make for a Stiff Competition
description: A WALL of smoke separates Barry Champlain from anyone who might get close to him. The wall is erected eight times a week by Liev Schreiber, whose brilliant, chain-smoking performance as Barry, the antagonistic shock jock in the Broadway revival of Eric Bogosians Talk Radio, is the best argument going for the continued existence of cigarettes.

title: A Moscow Winter Tableau
description: As the second act opened of Voyage, the beginning of Tom Stoppards trilogy, The Coast of Utopia, the seasons most visually sublime moment came into full view. We were in Moscow now, in March of 1834, having left the idyll of Premukhino, the Bakunin family estate, a place of long meals, pastoral languor.

title: Olivia Cowley, Julian Wassenaar
description: Olivia Lorillard Cowley, a daughter of Edith L. Cowley and Robert W. Cowley of Newport, R.I., was married there last evening to Julian Smith Wassenaar, a son of Christine A. Smith of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Paul R. Wassenaar of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Mark J. Pruitt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church.

title: A Jazzman So Cool You Want Him Frozen at His Peak
description: AT the very end of Bruce Webers seductive, unsettling Lets Get Lost, the movies subject, the semi-legendary cool-jazz trumpeter and singer Chet Baker, looks back on the shooting of the film and says, in a quavery, almost tearful voice, It was a dream. Although in the preceding two hours Mr. Baker has delivered a fair number of dubiously reliable utterances, youre inclined to believe him on this one because thats what the movie feels like to the viewer too. Its nominally a documentary (Oscar-nominated in that category in 1989), but it documents something that only faintly resembles waking reality. And Mr. Baker, who wanders through Lets Get Lost with the eerie deliberateness of a somnambulist, appears to be a man who knows a thing or two about dreams.

title: Directions: Hug, Smile, Schmooze, Repeat
description: GENTLEMEN, the photographer said, hug each other.

title: Eternal Sunshine
description: What accounts for the stupefying popular success of Doris Day? Like Elvis, she was generally underserved by her motion pictures, though her charisma and forthright personality always carried her through. She is the No. 1 female box-office star of all time, setting the record over three seismic decades  the 1940s, 50s and 60s. Did she embody McCarthyism or transcend it? As John Updike once said, Im always looking for insights into the real Doris Day because Im stuck with this infatuation and need to explain it to myself.

title: It Takes Money
description: FROM the stacks of allergy medicine at Duane Reade to the students doing homework at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, its clear that spring has overtaken New York. Which means its time for apartment owners to come together in their annual meetings and debate what to do to the spaces they have the fortune, or misfortune, to share.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Palestinian Militant Is Killed as the Air Fire Over Gaza Declines
description: JERUSALEM, June 2  A field commander from the Palestinian militant faction Islamic Jihad was killed in an Israeli air attack on his vehicle in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Friday night, army officials and Islamic Jihad said.

title: Stephanie J. Blocks Cold
description: Stephanie J. Block was sick, bad. She had such a nasty bug that she missed a few previews of The Pirate Queen, a show that sits squarely on her shoulders (she plays the title character) and that she even had to leave in the middle of a critics night performance.

title: The Musicians of the Orchestra Pit
description: As anyone who regularly attends musicals can attest, the sound of music on Broadway these days is often about as appealing as the throb of a jackhammer or the blare of a bus horn. Those distracting little microphones crawling like insects out of the hairlines of the performers are a bit of an eyesore, but what really sets the nerves on edge is the tidal wave of mushy, amplified sound that now seems to be the standard for Broadway musicals.

title: A Critique of Obama Doubles as an Invite
description: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company has a question for Senator Barack Obama: Have you driven a Ford lately?

title: Bridgid Curry and Amos Presler
description: Bridgid Theresa Curry, a daughter of Anne B. Curry and Dr. Thomas A. Curry of Pottsville, Pa., was married yesterday to Amos Hargrave Presler, a son of the Rev. Jane Butterfield Presler and the Rev. Dr. Titus L. Presler of New York. The Rev. Michael Stone performed the ceremony at St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church in Schuylkill Haven, Pa., with the bridegrooms father taking part.

title: A League of His Own
description: Sports anniversaries pile up with insidious regularity. Whereas a D-Day comes around only once a war, the Super Bowl adds another Roman numeral every January (or February), and college basketball gives us the Final Four like clockwork every March (or April). This all but guarantees that in 5- or 10-year increments, we will look back in sepia tones with weepy eyes at various athletic accomplishments, replaying their firsts and measuring their importance. Only a few justify such commemoration. Some live on from sheer spontaneous drama, as with Bobby Thomsons 1951 home run. Some gather weight over time, as with the victory of Texas Westerns black starting five against an all-white Kentucky team in the 1966 N.C.A.A. basketball finals. And a handful are heavy with significance both at the moment and long beyond, as with Jackie Robinsons entry into major-league baseball as its first modern-day African-American player, 60 years ago this season  an operatic tale cannily orchestrated by Branch Rickey, the president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, and brilliantly performed by Robinson.

title: For Dallas, New Prosecutor Means an End to the Old Ways
description: DALLAS  Craig Watkins calls himself a different kind of prosecutor.

title: For a Gussied-Up Street, a Song of Simpler Days
description: Of all the whining about gentrification in Brooklyn, this may be the first time the complaints have been set to an energetic beat with a bass line, a violin interlude and backup vocals.

title:
Prom Night During Wartime; Fighting the Curse
of Poor Penmanship (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A French White Under the Radar
description: Chteau Lamothe de Hauxs citric, mouthwatering 2006 Bordeaux blanc could replace entire lists of white wines in the citys seafood restaurants.

title: Childrens Books
description: Nearly a century after Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel opened her first shop on the exclusive Rue Cambon in Paris, the name Chanel remains synonymous with fashion.

title: Mariam and Laila
description: Khaled Hosseinis first book, The Kite Runner (2003), spent more than two years on best-seller lists in the United States. More than four million copies are in print, and a movie adaptation is also in the works. After such success and fame, some writers might have postponed the challenge of a second novel, preferring to collect their royalty checks and not tempt fate or a backlash. Some might have rushed into print with something, anything, to cash in on their newfound visibility. And some might not have had anything more to say. Hosseini doesnt fit any of these categories.

title: The Other Machu Picchu
description: DAWN had just broken, and the lost city of the Incas lay empty  not a tourist in sight. From the priests district, the high point of the ruins, the bright green central plaza stretched along the narrow summit of a high ridge and dropped precipitously on both sides to a turquoise river thousands of feet below.

title: If Wanderlust Strikes, Their House Goes, Too
description: FOR most people, a home is an anchor. It secures you to a particular spot and dampens the occasional impulse to set off in pursuit of a crazy dream.

title: Fervently French, Ptanque Draws All Ages
description: Yorktown Heights

title: James Lowers His Profile and Raises Cavaliers to Finals
description: CLEVELAND, June 2  LeBron James hurled the ball with all his rippling strength high into the rafters, and the confetti  like everything and everyone else here  soon followed on cue in Cleveland.

title: Reviving a Birthplace of Civil Rights
description: J. W. ROBINSON, 80, remembers when the Sweet Auburn neighborhood in Atlanta was a mecca for aspiring African-American professionals like himself. Just out of college in the early 1950s, Mr. Robinson, a fledgling architect, used to frequent the stylish establishments along the 1.5-mile-long stretch of Auburn Avenue  among them the Royal Peacock, a nightclub that featured Ray Charles and well-known jazz performers of the day.

title: Techno-Touches
description: In The Merchant of Venice, when Tubal learned the whereabouts of his friend Shylocks runaway daughter, Jessica, Shylock didnt have to wait long for the news in the Theater for a New Audience production this year. He got a call from Tubal on his cellphone.

title: 6 Billion Bits of Data About Me, Me, Me!
description: JAMES D. WATSON, who helped crack the DNA code half a century ago, last week became the first person handed the full text of his own DNA on a small computer disk. But he wont be the last.

title: Shes All a Blur
description: If you saw Lauryn Williams on the street, you wouldnt think she was the reigning world champion in the 100-meter sprint. But the 5-foot-3, 127-pound Williams has always been faster than bigger, taller athletes; in elementary school, she outran boys five and six years her senior. Thats when I started to know I had talent, the 23-year-old Williams says. At 20, she won the silver medal in the 100-meter dash at the 2004 Athens Olympics. The next year she earned gold at the World Championships, a title shell defend this August in Osaka, Japan. So how is it that someone so small can run so fast?

title: In Police Hiring Crisis, Clouds of Contention
description: Any hope for a quick end to the long-running contract dispute between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the citys main police union seemed to vanish last week when the union appealed a state officials order for arbitration to move forward.

title: Everybody Into the Pool!
description: Founders Park pool in Islamorada, Fla., is a 50-meter oasis of fresh water flanked by the turquoise Gulf of Mexico, a rocks throw to the west, and the white-capped Atlantic, a quarter-mile to the east.

title: Correction: Lamonts Message to Students: Stay Involved
description: A column last Sunday on a teach-in at Weston High School featuring Ned Lamont misspelled the writers name. It is Gerri Hirshey, not Hershey.

title: Mindy Feinberg, Stefan Gutow
description: Mindy Rebecca Feinberg and Dr. Stefan Harris Gutow were married yesterday evening at the American Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore. Rabbi William Kuhn officiated.

title: Catherine Bennett, Sophien Bennaceur
description: Catherine Gilbert Bennett, a daughter of Ellen and Robert S. Bennett of Washington, was married there last evening to Sophien Lazhar Bennaceur, a son of Dalila and Taieb L. Bennaceur of Nabeul, Tunisia. Judge Paul L. Friedman of the Federal District Court officiated at Evermay, a Federal-era house.

title: Alice, Lets Eat
description: On Aug. 28, 1971, Chez Panisse opened for business. The evening light was streaming across Shattuck Avenue in Berkeley. In the kitchen, a complicated sauce for canard aux olives was being attempted. No one there thought American cooking was about to be sent off in a new direction. The question was whether the restaurant could make it through the evening. True to the kind of well-intentioned venture it was, it almost didnt.

title: Dick Cheney Rules
description: Americans are accustomed to Vice President Dick Cheneys waiting out a terrorist threat in a secure undisclosed location. Now it seems that Mr. Cheney wears the cloak of invisibility in secure disclosed locations.

title: Crash-Test Kudos for 2 Convertibles
description: IN the first crash tests of convertibles by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, the Saab 9-3 and Volvo C70 earned the top rating, good, for protection in front, side and rear collisions.

title: Soviet-Style Torture Becomes Interrogation
description: HOW did the United States, in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, come to adopt interrogation techniques copied from the Soviet Union and other cold war adversaries?

title: Schools Deep-Pocketed Partners
description: Greenwich, Conn.

title: Correction: The Alchemists Moment: The Reclusive Mr. Polke
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the artist Sigmar Polke misidentified the country that took control of his birthplace, Oels, Silesia, in 1945. It was Poland, not East Germany. (Mr. Polkes family moved from Silesia to East Germany at the end of World War II.)

title: Google Keeps Tweaking Its Search Engine
description: Mountain View, Calif.

title: Why They Booed Her in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY

title: Kathleen Rubenstein, Hays Golden
description: Kathleen Bassi Rubenstein, a daughter of Laurie J. Bassi and Herbert R. Rubenstein of Golden, Colo., is to be married today to Hays Nathaniel Golden, the son of Trudy Anna Legge Golden and Arthur Golden of Brookline, Mass. The ceremony, at Saltmeadows, the summer home of the bridegrooms parents in South Dartmouth, Mass., will be led by Jason B. Rubenstein, the brides brother, who has permission to officiate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: Walk to All
description: LIVINGSTON

title: The Week on Long Island
description: Village Wants Restaurant Wastewater Degreased

title: Temple Draws New Life From a Deal With a Caterer
description: Lawrence

title: Breakdown
description: Rosa Lane, a successful journalist living a cautious, insulated life in London, finds herself suddenly aware that she has been stuck in a holding pattern: Sitting at her desk that day, sweating into her shirt, she thought, If they told me I would never do anything more than this, would I want to live or die on the spot? Then she thought, What is the reason for it all, what is it for?

title: Howl
description: Mention the term doggie lit to most winners of Englands T. S. Eliot Prize for poetry and theyll probably think youre referring to a graduate course on classical representations of Cerberus  or maybe to something Hollywood starlets give their Chihuahuas to browse while getting doggie pedicures. But Mark Doty, the only American to have won the prize (for his 1993 collection My Alexandria), is that rare thing: a serious poet with what seems to be a keen eye for trends. At a time when John Grogans Marley & Me has revealed a public appetite for the gushing reveries of a dog owner, and Joan Didions Year of Magical Thinking proved that readers can handle articulate narratives of grief, Doty has delivered a memoir that is both at once.

title: Current Thinking
description: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg recently announced his vision of development in New York City over the next 25 years, he highlighted a plan to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions by 30 percent. To anyone who has studied the history of power consumption in the United States, his proposal sounded a curious echo. New York, after all, was home to one of the countrys first central power stations, built by Thomas Edison in 1882. No individual deserves more credit, or blame, for Americas voracious electricity consumption than Edison, who conceived not only that generating station but also the notoriously inefficient incandescent bulb and a slew of volt-thirsty devices.

title: Just Like Us  Only Better
description: Was there ever a golf moment at once more horrific and more riveting than Phil Mickelsons meltdown on the final hole of last years United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club? You couldnt watch, and at the same time you couldnt not watch.

title: Seeing More in a Marina
description: BAY SHORE

title: Downtown, Meet Waterfront
description: JODI CUNNINGHAM, a 48-year-old single mother from Jericho, spent two years shopping for a house she could afford, scouring the market in Plainview, Syosset and Jericho for a half-million-dollar home that didnt need extensive repairs.

title: An Around-the-World Ticket for Your Portfolio
description: FOREIGN stocks can add some ballast to your portfolio, despite the effects of globalization.

title: Free Your Mind, and Your Spine Will Follow
description: ELEVEN hyper-alert dancers stood stock still in a line, fighting the irresistible rhythms of the pulsing Arabic music. Suddenly one erupted in movement, ducking and twisting with astonishing liquid quickness. Then she froze. Down the line a second dancer burst into motion: another spineless creature from the same strange planet. Abruptly the whole line turned sideways and pounded the air with sinuous arms and hard fists, then froze.

title: Joan Rappoport, Steven Rosenfeld
description: Joan Rappoport and Steven Bruce Rosenfeld are to be married today. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant in New York.

title: Familiarity Is Breeding Fraternity for Coaches
description: CLEVELAND, June 2  Earlier in the playoffs, Cavaliers Coach Mike Brown got a telephone call before a game.

title: Judith Kelman, Peter Scardino
description: Judith Ann Kelman and Dr. Peter Thomas Scardino were married yesterday at the GlenArbor Golf Club in Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. William McD. Tully, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with Rabbi Uri D. Herscher taking part.

title: A Hot-Selling Weapon, an Inviting Target
description: LAST February, Jim Zumbo, a burly, 66-year-old outdoors writer, got a phone call at his home near Cody, Wyo., from the rock star  and outspoken Second Amendment champion  Ted Nugent. You messed up, man, Mr. Zumbo says Mr. Nugent told him. Big time.

title: Albany Discovers Obesity
description: Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up very bad eating habits, habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls competitive foods. Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt  the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease.

title: Dow and S.& P. End the Week at Record Highs
description: It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poors 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs.

title: U.S. Strikes Inside Somalia, Bombing Suspected Militant Hide-Out
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 2  American forces struck inside Somalia on Friday, bombarding a mountainous area where suspected militants were hiding out, Somali officials said Saturday. It was the third known American strike on Somali soil this year.

title: Water World
description: Theres something about ocean diving that inspires deep thinking  or at least thoughts that are apparently profound. Once while wreck diving for a television documentary, I unexpectedly found myself surrounded by several pregnant tiger sharks. Euphorically succumbing to nitrogen narcosis, I was drawn to the sharks, dopily fixated on the commingling of species, wondering why we couldnt all just get along, until my dive master dragged me to safety. (Perhaps I should have been more concerned about the food chain.) In any case, I initially wrote off my ill-timed reverie on interdependence as the reaction of a stoned neophyte diver. But Ive since read enough about diving to realize that insight comes from unlikely places under those refracted waters.

title: LaTasha White and Leland Richards Jr.
description: LaTasha White and Leland Richards Jr. were married last evening at Belle Voir Manor in Bensalem, Pa. The Rev. William Lee, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Failed Presidents Aint What They Used to Be
description: A few weeks ago I did something I never expected to do in my life. I shed a tear for Richard Milhous Nixon.

title: Kara Visconti, Frank Blanco
description: Kara Visconti and Frank Blanco were married yesterday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Dog Years: A Memoir
description: No dog has ever said a word, but that doesn't mean they live outside the world of speech. They listen acutely. They wait to hear a term-biscuit, walk-and an inflection they know. What a stream of incomprehensible signs passes over them as they wait, patiently, for one of a few familiar words! Because they do not speak, except in the most limited fashion, we are always trying to figure them out. The expression is telling: to "figure out" is to make figures of speech, to invent metaphors to help us understand the world. To choose to live with a dog is to agree to participate in a long process of interpretation-a mutual agreement, though the human being holds most of the cards.

title: After Dark
Spy Wars
description: When the door opened in front of him, my visitor knew he was being led into a secret CIA apartment. But which of us was really being led? As he took my welcoming hand I had no idea that it was to drag me and my service into a labyrinth so complex that even today, more than forty years later, my successors have still not found their way through its twists and turns.

title: Redemption Song: The Ballad of Joe Strummer
description: This is how I heard about Joe's death: Don Letts, the Rastafarian film director who had made all the Clash videos, called me at around 9:30 on the evening of December 22, 2002.

title: Rickles Book
description: Jackson Heights, Queens, was no special place, but my dad, Max, was a special guy. Here's the kind of guy he was: If he was your friend and came over to your house and your wife was in a housecoat, he could hug her and you wouldn't think twice. There was nothing distasteful about Max S. Rickles. (I never knew what the "S." stood for, and neither did he.) Everyone loved my dad. The man was all heart.

title: Josephine Baker in Art and Life
description: Josephine Baker's cultural legacy is still alive beyond the hundredth anniversary of her birth in 1906. It exists in live performances, art, photography, fashion, film, literature, and social activism. Baker mesmerized audiences during her lifetime and continues to attract and mystify biographers. Much recent scholarship on Baker has placed her in a pantheon of black feminist heroines, which often has produced a larger-than-life, one-dimensional image. Regardless of the reasons for such depictions, there is a need to remove Baker from reductive stereotypes and to humanize her legacy. This book explores the complex construction of Baker's multiple images in art and life. It is concerned with how art transforms social life, and how life imitates art. Although it presents and evaluates carefully researched biographical facts, it is not a biography. Rather, it offers critical reflections on the symbolic Baker and the images that she and her collaborators constructed during the era of modernity and for the postmodern future.

title: From a Cause to a Style
description: In the 1980s, the Prince of Wales, who has adopted a number of surprising causes for a prince in the course of his life, became for a time the most influential critic of architecture, urban design, and planning in Great Britain. Both modernist architecture and modernist city planning had been very successful in Britain-as indeed they have been almost everywhere-in shaping new towns and rebuilding the centers of old cities and towns. But ordinary people often looked on the results with dismay. The prince's interventions and criticisms received wide publicity, and were effective in derailing some high-profile projects by modernist architects.

title: Liberty

She invited a catholic assortment of liberal, anglophile nobles, their glamorous wives and mistresses, and ambitious young men of middling rank. 'Go hence to Mme de Stal's,' wrote Gouverneur Morris, the one-legged American envoy to Paris, in his apple-green journal in January 1791. 'I meet here the world.'

title: The Fragile Edge

Now, in the final hour of daylight, scores of them coalesce into banners of yellow-and-blue fins, flowing gaudily over the contours of the coral toward the edge of Tiputa Pass. Bunched into agitated crowds of hundreds, they rise above the reefs, swarming and butting each other in a chaos of seeming cross purposes.

title: Contested Waters
description: Philadelphia opened one of the earliest municipal pools in America on June 21, 1884, at the intersection of Twelfth and Wharton Streets. The "swimming bath," as it was commonly called, was so popular with the boys and young men of this immigrant, working-class neighborhood that they regularly waited an hour in line to enter. During the first few days, the crowd outside the pool often became unruly. The youths argued, fought, and tried to sneak ahead of one another in line. On the night of June 24, the usual ruckus escalated into a small riot. It started when the superintendent informed the expectant swimmers that they would not be admitted that evening because the pool was already filled to capacity. As the crowd grew incensed, the superintendent retreated inside the building and bolted the door. According to a local newspaper, the fifty or so young men who had been turned away "concluded to override his authority by the superiority of their numbers." They tore the door from its hinges and knocked down the fence that surrounded the pool. The city had stationed a police detail at the pool in anticipation of disorderly behavior, but the four officers were no match for the angry crowd. They were "tossed about like little bits of driftwood in rough water." Police reinforcements eventually restored order "with a liberal application of their clubs," but not before the pool and the reputation of the bathers had been severely damaged. The Philadelphia Evening Bulletin editorialized that "the good [the pool] has accomplished amongst the unwashed down-town youths has been more than counterbalanced by the harm a certain gang of roughs has seen fit in their ignorant and brutal natures to inflict." Commissioner of City Property William Dixey, whose department administered the pool, promised that "if such conduct is kept up," he would "close the house and keep it closed."

title: On Chesil Beach
description: They were young, educated, and both virgins on this, their wedding night, and they lived in a time when a conversation about sexual difficulties was plainly impossible. But it is never easy. They had just sat down to supper in a tiny sitting room on the first floor of a Georgian inn. In the next room, visible through the open door, was a four-poster bed, rather narrow, whose bedcover was pure white and stretched startlingly smooth, as though by no human hand. Edward did not mention that he had never stayed in a hotel before, whereas Florence, after many trips as a child with her father, was an old hand. Superficially, they were in fine spirits. Their wedding, at St. Mary's, Oxford, had gone well; the service was decorous, the reception jolly, the send-off from school and college friends raucous and uplifting. Her parents had not condescended to his, as they had feared, and his mother had not significantly misbehaved, or completely forgotten the purpose of the occasion. The couple had driven away in a small car belonging to Florence's mother and arrived in the early evening at their hotel on the Dorset coast in weather that was not perfect for mid-July or the circumstances, but entirely adequate: it was not raining, but nor was it quite warm enough, according to Florence, to eat outside on the terrace as they had hoped. Edward thought it was, but, polite to a fault, he would not think of contradicting her on such an evening.

title: The Sack of Panama
description: 'Land ahead on the starboard bow!' It was noon on 25 May 1666 when the ageing privateer, Captain Edward Mansfield, heard the lookout's cry. He clambered up into the rigging to check his position. One quick look through his perspective glass and he could relax. There was no mistaking the rugged hills, over a thousand feet high, of the lonely island which the English called Providence and the Spaniards called Santa Catalina. The old captain glanced back at the rest of his squadron. All four ships were still in sight, spread out across the otherwise empty sea. They all looked as though they had been a long time out of port, weather-beaten, paint faded, sails patched, but still moving well through the water, their bottoms clean after a recent careening. Three of them were very small, lateen-rigged sloops with no deck or cabin to protect their cramped crews from sun and sea and rain; and even the fourth was only about fifty tons, a small, square-rigged, half-decked frigate which, like Mansfield's own similar ship, had been recently captured from the Spaniards off the Central American coast. None of them carried many cannon, but no one who saw them would have been in any doubt that they were best to be avoided. Small, fast ships like these, crammed with men who knew from experience that four muskets could do as much execution as one cannon, had terrorized the waters and coastal settlements of the Caribbean for decades. Mansfield signalled the frigate to furl her topsails to reduce visibility and crept forward towards his goal. By late afternoon he was only twelve miles from the southernmost point of the island, and the squadron hove to until nightfall. Tomorrow, with any luck, the island would be his.

title: Paperback Row
description: MAYFLOWER: A Story of Courage, Community, and War, by Nathaniel Philbrick. (Penguin, $16.) This absorbing history recreates the Pilgrims perilous 1620 voyage, the founding of the Plymouth Colony and its first contacts with the native inhabitants of Massachusetts. Philbrick, the author of the National Book Award-winning In the Heart of the Sea, finds striking parallels between past and present, particularly the way Plymouths leaders, including Miles Standish, rejected diplomatic overtures toward the Indians and instead pursued a policy of violent aggression that led to the needless bloodshed of King Philips War. The Book Review named Mayflower one of the 10 best books of 2006; our reviewer, Russell Shorto, called it a vivid and remarkably fresh retelling.

Orchestra. I had already been mightily impressed with its work in two operas, the Brecht-Weill Aufstieg und Fall der Stadt Mahagonny and Glucks Ile de Merlin. And I became even more impressed on Saturday, hearing the group rehearse Strausss Till Eulenspiegel in the afternoon for an orchestral concert on June 5, then hearing it in the pit in the evening for Pascal Dusapins demanding opera Faustus, the Last Night.

The House has voted to include restrictions on rail transport of deadly chemicals, but the Senate has not.

title: Ed Yost, 87, Father of Modern Hot-Air Ballooning, Dies
description: Ed Yost, who fastened two propane tanks to what essentially looked like a lawn chair, attached that contraption to a 40-foot-diameter white nylon balloon and sailed above the Nebraska plain on a brisk fall day in 1960, becoming the father of modern hot-air ballooning, died May 27 at his home in Vadito, N.M. He was 87.

title: Show Us the Money
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Shake-Up at JWT in Chicago After Loss of Kraft Foods
description: JWT is shaking up the leadership of its Chicago office after the office lost a large part of its important Kraft Foods account.

title: Mr. Murdoch Comes Round for Tea
description: The meeting later today between Rupert Murdoch and the Bancroft family that could determine the fate of Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, would seem to be a very modern media moment.

title: A Theme Song for Clinton: Im a Believer vs. Cold as Ice
description: When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she certainly got the attention she wanted  and a whole lot of jokes at her expense.

title: Dinner Disappears, and African Penguins Pay the Price
description: ROBBEN ISLAND, South Africa, May 28  Striding across a barren patch of this windswept isle, Les Underhill paused, then bent down for a closer look at his discovery: one adult African penguin and two three-week-old chicks, huddled in an earthy depression about as big as the average bathroom basin.

title: Canadiens of the 1950s Are Still the Kings of the Cup
description: Dynasties dont exist in the N.H.L. anymore, and they are seldom seen in any other sport. Not since the Detroit Red Wings won the Stanley Cup in 1997 and 1998 has the same N.H.L. franchise reigned in consecutive seasons. All the more reason hockeys most dynamic dynasty, the Montreal Canadiens of Maurice Richard and Jean Bliveau, who won the Cup a record five years in a row half a century ago, was honored in Ottawa over the weekend.

title: Fever Builds for iPhone (Anxiety Too)
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 3  During an onscreen demonstration of the iPhone in Apples sprawling retail store here recently, an employee, clad in a black T-shirt, of course, surprised a potential customer.

title: At-Home Fertility Screening Available for Men
description: Many men, faced with the prospect of going to the doctor for a fertility evaluation, will tell you: they would rather just stay home.

title: Chinese Stocks Fall After Government Increases Taxes
description: SHANGHAI, June 4  Chinas stock market tumbled again today in one of the biggest sell-offs in years. It followed the governments move last week to impose higher taxes on stock trades.

title: Papers Portray Plot as More Talk Than Action
description: The plot as painted by law enforcement officials was cataclysmic: A home-grown Islamic terrorist had in mind detonating fuel storage tanks and pipelines and setting fire to Kennedy International Airport, not to mention a substantial swath of Queens.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about Reading to Rover, a program at the Westport Public Library in Connecticut in which children read to dogs as a form of therapy, misspelled the given name of the childrens librarian. She is Lynne Perrigo, not Lynn.

title: Bruno Inquiry Scrutinizes Thoroughbred Transactions
description: Federal authorities investigating the business dealings of Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, have been examining records related to his purchases and sales of thoroughbred horses.

title: In Video, Insurgents Claim 2 Missing G.I.s Are Dead
description: BAGHDAD, June 4  A Sunni Arab insurgent group released a video on Monday that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers abducted in an ambush south of Baghdad last month, and the group claimed the two had been killed along with one other soldier.

title: Congress Hobbles the AIDS Fight
description: Washington, D.C., is one of Americas AIDS hot spots. A significant proportion of infections can be traced back to intravenous drug users who shared contaminated needles and then passed on the infection to spouses, lovers or unborn children.

title: Inspired by Nicklaus, Choi Wins Memorial
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, June 3  When K. J. Choi was 16 and living in Wando, South Korea, his physical education teacher gave him a copy of an instructional book by Jack Nicklaus.

title: Wake Up, Princess, the Movies Are Calling
description: In the land of Ballet Ever After, two heroines meet. Odette mimes (as she does in the traditional Swan Lake), That lake is made of my mothers tears. Whereupon Aurora (as refashioned in American Ballet Theaters new production of The Sleeping Beauty) replies: Lake! My mother cried me a river (remember the song?) when I pricked my finger and they thought I was dead. But my prince drank from the rivers waters and sailed up it to find me. ...

title: Bill Whitman, 92, Is Dead; Scoured the Earth for Rare Fruit
description: William F. Whitman Jr., a self-taught horticulturist who became renowned for collecting rare tropical fruits from around the world and popularizing them in the United States, died Wednesday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 92.

title: Bush Goes to Europe in Wake of Putins Threat
description: BERLIN, June 4  President Bush flew to Europe today for talks with world leaders later this week, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in the wake of a threat by Mr. Putin to point Russian missiles at Europe if the United States builds its missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic.

title: You Hear Those People? Theyre Animals!
description: Creature Comforts, a new stop-motion animation series on CBS, is from the British outfit that has given us the characters of Wallace and Gromit and the clever film Chicken Run. In the new show, clay animals with human voices make various observations about attraction, doctors  life. It may seem an odd thing to say, but Creature Comforts reminds me in some tiny way of The Sopranos because just as it is always unfailingly funny when mob men and their coterie speak of Moby-Dick and the human condition, it makes you laugh when a fake pig, speaking as a middle-aged woman, talks about losing weight.

title: Harvard Is Licensing More Than 50 Patents to a Nanotechnology Start-Up
description: George M. Whitesides, a Harvard University chemist, is a renowned specialist in nanotechnology, a field built on the behavior of materials as small as one molecule thick. But there is nothing tiny about the patent portfolio that Harvard has amassed over the last 25 years based on work in his lab.

title: Escape From North Korea
description: CHINESE-NORTH KOREAN BORDER

title: Bloomberg Cast as Enemy No. 1 of Gun Rights
description: In New York, Michael R. Bloomberg is known as the billionaire media mogul who became mayor. But in many parts of the country, he is the man who would take away your guns.

title: With Mientkiewicz Out, Yankees Fill in Missing Pieces
description: BOSTON, June 3  Doug Mientkiewicz was driven home by his wife on Sunday. He was a wounded passenger, having sustained a concussion, a neck sprain and a fractured bone in his right wrist on Saturday in a collision at Fenway Park. From a baseball standpoint, the wrist injury is the most serious, and it will keep him out a minimum of six weeks.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: On Upper East Side, Two Seek Vacated Assembly Seat
description: The Upper East Side was once the reliable foothold of the liberal Republican politician. It was the home of John V. Lindsay and, most recently, State Senator Roy M. Goodman. But in the last decade, the neighborhood has become increasingly Democratic, and Republican officeholders have become fixtures of the past.

title: Palm Is Said to Sell Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
description: Palm Inc., the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal yesterday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: For Red Sox, the Relief Is Almost Beyond Belief
description: Boston

title: Fighting in Lebanese Refugee Camp Rages, and Spreads
description: SIDON, Lebanon, Monday, June 4  The deadly volley of shelling and sniper fire at a refugee camp in northern Lebanon intensified Sunday, and fighting broke out between militants and the army in another camp in the south, increasing fears that the two-week battle between the Lebanese Army and Islamist militants could spread to other parts of the country.

title: Rock on, but Hang on to Your Literary Gigs
description: What kind of rock band gets up before noon? For that matter, what kind of band reads and writes? The Rock Bottom Remainders do both, and have also been known, while on tour, to tune in to The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer. At a little after 6 on Thursday morning they turned up at the studio of Good Morning America to do a promotional spot for a Friday-night benefit coinciding with BookExpo America, the big publishing fair that took place in New York over the weekend. The green-room spread included, instead of greenies and quarts of Jack, platters of fresh fruit and, at the request of Roy Blount Jr., one of the bands founding members, a big pan of grits.

title: China Releases Climate Change Plan
description: BEIJING, June 4  China today released its first comprehensive strategy on addressing climate change, a plan that calls for improving energy efficiency and controlling greenhouse gas emissions but that rejects mandatory caps on emissions that could harm the countrys sizzling economy.

title: All Over but the Shouting
description: CHICAGO, June 3 Bobby Cox remained one ejection shy Sunday of tying John McGraw for a dubious distinction and unofficial baseball record. But Lou Piniella showed again Saturday that he has no current equal for flamboyant temper tantrums that often bring banishment by umpires.

title: A Great Horse, but Who Takes the Winnings?
description: When Curlin chased down the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense to capture the Preakness Stakes, his owners bounded to the winners circle at Pimlico Race Course. They were an eclectic bunch that included a winemaker, a computer magnate, an investment banker and two lawyers.

title: Freezing Out East on the Way to Second Place
description: The Long Island Spring Regional starts in Smithtown tomorrow. The tournament chairman, Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., played on Memorial Day weekend in the Easterns Regional in New York City. He and his teammates, Diana Schuld of Glen Head, N.Y., Ruth Stober of Great Neck, N.Y., and Michael Abramson of Montclair, N.J., finished second in the Open Swiss Teams behind Steven Petersell, Qiang Wang and Sam Wang of New York and Jian Wang of New Milford, N.J. They might have been third but for the diagramed deal.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Way to Give Authors a Lucrative Second Platform
description: Even before Lawrence Wright, a staff writer for The New Yorker, won a Pulitzer Prize for his book The Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11, he was one of the busiest lecturing authors published by Alfred A. Knopf. For April and May, he had been booked to speak at Princeton and Wesleyan Universities, at a public relations seminar in Santa Barbara, Calif., and at a lunch in Chicago sponsored by the Northern Trust Bank.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
National Editor Suzanne Daley
description: Suzanne Daley, The Times's national editor, answered reader questions June 4 through 8, 2007.

title: Romneys Fortunes Tied to Business Riches
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  Mitt Romney owes his nearly $350 million fortune and his political career to a delicate negotiation with his boss in the summer of 1983.

title: Compete With China (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Oddity in Picking Jurors Opens Door to Racial Bias
description: Allen Snyder, a black man, is on death row in Louisiana. An all-white jury in Jefferson Parish, in the New Orleans suburbs, sentenced him to death in 1996 for the fatal stabbing of a man his wife was seeing.

title: 14 More American Servicemen Are Killed in Iraq, Most of Them by Makeshift Bombs
description: BAGHDAD, June 3  The pace of American troop deaths increased this weekend as 14 more servicemen were reported killed in Iraq, all but one from makeshift bombs that insurgents have been employing with greater lethality against American soldiers and armored vehicles. Twenty-one soldiers and an Iraqi interpreter were wounded.

title: Love and Debt: The Game of Life Now Takes Plastic
description: If lifes a game, I can only hope its not a game like the Game of Life. Thats the one where you drive a plastic car along a winding path, going to work or college and picking up pink and blue pegs for children until you end up at a McMansion and get to count your money. I played it with my young daughter a couple of times and found it excruciating, probably because of how effectively it boiled life down to its plodding essence, a march to suburban retirement. It made me long for the solace of death, but that is not an option in this game.

title: Opposition in Senegal Boycotts Vote
description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 3  Voters in Senegal on Sunday largely stayed home from an election to choose a new national assembly amid widespread apathy and after a call for a boycott by the main opposition parties.

title: The Man Behind the Curtain: Political Strategy and Spin
description: Among the many stirring words written by Robert Shrum are these: Since I was very young, I have had a profound reverence for this office I hold. Ive been honored that you, the people, have entrusted it to me. I am proud of what we have accomplished together. And about wife and daughter, Hillary and Chelsea: Their forgiveness and love, expressed so often as we sat alone together this weekend, means far more than I can ever say.

title: Qiagen to Buy Digene, Maker of Tests for Cancer-Causing Virus
description: Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy the Digene Corporation for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Rodriguez Lifts Weight With Homer in 9th
description: BOSTON, Monday, June 4  He was down to his last strike with two outs in the ninth inning of Sunday nights game, at the end of what might be the longest week of his life. Alex Rodriguez  bad boy of the tabloids, violator of baseball etiquette, object of ridicule and scorn at Fenway Park  was fighting.

title: Walls of Art for Everyone, but Made by Not Just Anyone
description: The sticky-sweet smell of spray paint hung in the hot air as members of Tats Cru covered a rooftop wall with crazy kinetic letters. They were far from prying eyes, though not because they were doing anything illegal. In fact, the man whose business occupied the football-field-size building was their patron, allowing them and other graffiti artists to use the roof as their own open-air atelier. Here among the drab warehouses of the Hunts Point Cooperative Market, they had the privacy to try out new designs, repainting and refining until they were pleased with the results.

title: Waxing Philosophical, Booksellers Face the Digital
description: John Updike would not be pleased.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about charges being brought in Brazil against two American pilots, whose corporate jet was involved in a midair collision last year over the Amazon with a Brazilian airliner that went down with 154 people aboard, misstated a Brazilian judges position on the case. He said in a statement issued in Portuguese on Friday that the two pilots, Joseph Lepore and Jan Paul Paladino, should be charged with exposing an aircraft to danger; he did not say they were guilty of having done so. (Go to Article)

title: Immigration Sabotage
description: The Senate plans to resume debate today on its proposed immigration overhaul, which has withstood more than a week of bombardment from critics right and left. More than 100 amendments are circling, many designed to make the tortuously drafted compromise meaner, narrower and nastier.

title: William Silver, 59, Early Gay Applicant for Ministry, Is Dead
description: William Silver, whose 1975 application for ordination in the United Presbyterian Church  the first by an openly gay man  set off a continuing debate in the church over admitting homosexuals into the ministry, died on May 26. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Romney Is Central Target of McCain Counterattack
description: Senator John McCain, facing increasing anger from fellow Republicans over his support of the immigration bill in Congress, is ramping up his counterattack against a main rival in the presidential campaign, Mitt Romney, by accusing him of pandering for votes in opposing the measure.

title: Hamas Fires Mortars After Palestinian Is Killed
description: JERUSALEM, June 3  The military wing of Hamas claimed responsibility for firing mortar shells at the Erez crossing on the Gaza-Israel border on Sunday, slightly wounding four Israeli soldiers, hours after Israeli forces shot and killed a Palestinian man in the West Bank city of Jenin.

title: NBC Names Program Executive to Head TV Studio
description: NBC Universal took another step in revamping its television entertainment operations yesterday, appointing Katherine Pope as president of its television production studio, NBC Universal Television.

title: Rain Postpones Nascar Race
description: The 400-mile Nascar Nextel Cup race scheduled for yesterday afternoon at Dover International Speedway in Delaware was postponed until noon today because of heavy rain. The race is the sixth of the year using the new Car of Tomorrow. Ryan Newman will start from the pole position, and Dale Earnhardt Jr. will start second, his best starting position in 13 races this season.Although skies over the racetrack were still leaden, rain stopped long enough for workers to attempt to dry the track so the race could start just after its scheduled time of 1:45 p.m. But it began to rain again, and the race was postponed a half-hour later.It was the third time in the past four Nextel Cup races, including those at Richmond and Darlington, that a race has been pushed back one day because of poor weather. There is a 60 percent chance of showers today.

title: Liberian Boycotts Trial at The Hague
description: THE HAGUE, June 4  On the first day of his trial, Charles G. Taylor, one of Africas most tyrannical warlords and the former president of Liberia, refused to appear in court today, and he sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to obstruct proceedings that aim to cover a decade of bloody warfare and extraordinary cruelties.

title: Netflix Prize Still Awaits a Movie Seer
description: Sometimes a good idea becomes a great one after it is set loose.

title: Flirting, but Serious, Kicking Off With a Hit
description: RIHANNA

title: Commanders Say Push in Baghdad Is Short of Goal
description: BAGHDAD, June 3  Three months after the start of the Baghdad security plan that has added thousands of American and Iraqi troops to the capital, they control fewer than one-third of the citys neighborhoods, far short of the initial goal for the operation, according to some commanders and an internal military assessment.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, two picture captions on Tuesday with an article in Science Times about private rooms in neonatal intensive care units misspelled the surname of a woman whose son was born prematurely in St. Paul. She is Robyn Frandrup, not Frandrep. Also, the article misstated the month that Amillia Taylor, who was born at just over 21 weeks gestation, was released from a Miami hospital. It was February, not April.

title: Tiny Bit of Hardware With Marley Software
description: When reggae singer Bob Marley released Exodus in 1977, fans most likely bought it as a vinyl record, then over the decades went on to purchase it on CD or to download it. But those same boomers now can buy the album in a format that will impress even their computer-using children: on a U.S.B. flash drive.

title: Publishers Creating Their Own In-House Ad Agencies
description: Like executives at advertising agencies, Richard D. Beckman and his team talk to managers at consumer brand companies about the customers they want to reach. Four to six weeks later, they present a marketing and advertising plan.

title: Judge Throws Out Charges in Guantnamo Prisoner Case
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, June 4  A military judge here dismissed the war crimes charges against a Canadian detainee today, saying there was a flaw in the procedure the military has used to file such charges against Guantnamo detainees.

title: Cancer Experts Threatened After Opposing Drug
description: CHICAGO, June 3  Two prominent prostate cancer experts have been threatened for opposing approval of a controversial new drug and are being protected by bodyguards as they attend the nations largest cancer conference here.

title: In Lawmakers Eyes, All Power Plants Are Not Created Equal
description: ALBANY  Are there more coal-fired and nuclear power plants in New Yorks future?

title: Sharapova Fends Off Jeers and Schnyders Two Match Points
description: PARIS, June 3  Her long blond ponytail soaked with sweat, Maria Sharapova stood at midcourt Sunday, smiling and blowing kisses to the crowd booing her.

title: Fighting in Lebanese Camp Worsens
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 4Two Lebanese soldiers and two militants were killed in fighting in Ain al Hilwe refugee camp in southern Lebanon early today, capping a night of violence in both northern and southern Lebanon.
