title: Pettitte Hurts His Back
description: Remember that great catch by Melky Cabrera Sunday night, the one in the third inning where he ran forever to track down Wily Mo Penas drive on the distant center field warning track? Great moment for the Yankees, right?

title: After Three Playoffs, Candidates Finals Are Set
description: Alexei Shirov, Boris Gelfand and Levon Aronian advanced to the final round of the candidates after winning their tiebreak contests. They join Gata Kamsky, Alexander Grischuk, Evgeny Bareev, Peter Leko and Sergei Rublevsky in the candidates final to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. All the matches, preliminary and final, are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: Experiencing Brad Cloepfil's Vision
description: Images from Brad Cloepfil's reworking of Edward Durell Stone's "lollipop" building at Columbus Circle.

title: A way to bike the dolce vita
description: OK, Lets start with the reality: Central Rome is not made-for-cycling. There are no bike lanes and the streets are narrow. The drivers are nuts. Scooters swarm like bees. It is hilly. Most Italians consider bicycles the lowest form of transportation. If you want a taste what it is like to cycle in the center of Rome, check out this video by Austrian performance artist, Rainer Ganahl, who cycled in the center here with a camera on his helmet. (OK, he was cycling against traffic.) As he noted, he didnt see a single other cyclist during his 16 minute terror ride. On the other hand, the Italian police didnt seem to mind that he was cycling in the middle of the street into oncoming traffic.

title: Phones Add New Photo Features
description: Phone cameras have become more sophisticated, but most still need to focus more on image quality and ease of use.

title: $4 Million Homes
description: Tour five-bedroom homes in Boca Raton, Fla., and Boulder, Colo., and a Napa Valley estate with five structures, a pool, a pond and a tennis court.

title: Magnificent Miami Beach
description: Pool

title: Earbud Upgrade
description: Better headphones equal better sound for portable music players.

title: S.E.C. Sides Against Banks in Enron Suit, Report Says
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to support shareholders suing Wall Street banks for damages over Enrons collapse in a seminal case before the Supreme Court, according to The Washington Post.

title: Tribute to a Senate Role Model
description: Warren M. Anderson, who served as Senate majority leader from 1973 to 1988, died last week at age 91.

title: Jazz I.P.O. Closed Down in Debut
description: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, after pricing below its expected range, closed down in its first day on the Nasdaq. The initial public offering of the biotechnology firm, backed by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, hit a sour note as a negative press report and skeptical investors depressed demand for its $108 million initial public offering.

title: NanoH2 Ceans Up With $5 Million in Fresh Funding
description: NanoH2O, a desalination company that grew out of research at UCLA, has raised $5 million. The company is trying to commercialize a membrane that consists of a matrix of porous polymer sheets embedded with specially designed nanoparticles that purify water. Investors include Khosla Ventures.

title: Cadence Said to Be in Buyout Talks
description: Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company, The New York Times reported.

title: Merc Chief Tub-Thumps C.B.O.T. Bid
description: The war of words in the battle for control of the Chicago Board of Trade continued Friday, as the top executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said that he remains convinced the C.B.O.T. will accept his exchanges bid over a rival bid from the Intercontinental Exchange.

title: British Property Firm Unloads U.S. Life Sciences Portfolio
description: A British property firm, Segro, has agreed to sell its life sciences real-estate business in the United States to Health Care Property Investors for $2.9 billion as it moves to focus on Britain and continental Europe. Segro, formerly Slough Estates, said on Monday it would return 250 million pounds ($495 million) of the proceeds from the sale of Slough Estates USA to shareholders via a special dividend.

title: Xstrata Wont Raise LionOre Bid
description: Xstrata  said Friday it would not match the 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.4 billion), bid by the Russian mining titan Norilsk Nickel for LionOre Mining International. Xstrata, which negotiated a break-up fee of 305 million with LionOre, has extended its offer of 25 Canadian dollars a share to June 15.

title: IAC to Open a Venture Capital Unit
description: IAC/InterActive, the New York-based media and e-commerce conglomerate run by the former Hollywood mogul Barry Diller, is starting a venture investing arm called Primal Ventures, The San Jose Mercury News reported.

title: AXA Sells Insurance Assets to Dutch Financial Firm
description: A Dutch financial group, SNS Reaal, is to buy the Dutch insurance operations of Frances AXA for 1.75 billion euros ($2.35 billion) to double its domestic market share and cut costs.

title: Blackstone Opens Wallet for Alliant
description: The Blackstone Group struck a deal to buy its first insurance broker, saying Sunday it would purchase the privately held Alliant Insurance Services. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Reuters said the price tag comes to $1.2 billion.

title: Bloombergs Slow-Moving Plan
description: The Real Estate Board of New York will start running television commercials today in support of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs long-range environmental plan, which includes a proposal to charge fees to drive below 86th Street during peak hours.

title: Digital Photos on the Mantelpiece
description: There is an elegant way to free snapshots from computer hard drives: the digital picture frame.

title: Anadarko Sells Assets to Atlas for $1.85 Billion
description: the oil and natural gas producer Anadarko Petroleum said late Sunday it is selling natural gas gathering systems and associated processing plants to Atlas Pipeline Partners for $1.85 billion.

title: Spains Realia Aims for $1.34 Billion I.P.O.
description: Realia, jointly owned by the savings bank Caja Madrid and a construction group, FCC, hopes to confound skeptics of the Spanish property sector by raising more than 1 billion euros ($1.34 billion) in an initial public offering on Wednesday, The Financial Times reported.

title: Kinds of Vulgarity
description: The Empire Zone continues its efforts to create a full historical record of the March 14 dust-up between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, amid tense budget negotiations. As previously reported, words were exchanged and voices were raised in the governors office, according to several people present or close by. And after Mr. Bruno made a lewd reference to the close political relationship of the governor and the Senate minority leader, Malcolm A. Smith, Mr. Spitzer stormed out of his office, saying, Im not going to abide that kind of vulgarity.

title: Ferox Capital Names Former Morgan Stanley Banker as C.E.O.
description: Ferox Capital Management has hired a longtime Morgan Stanley banker, Jack Inglis, as chief executive officer. Mr. Inglis, who left Morgan Stanley in January after 15 years there, will take over the day-to-day operations at the $2 billion British hedge fund so that its founder, Jeremy Herrmann, can concentrate on his role as chief investment officer.

title: Highbridge Taps Goldman Alumnus for Buyout Fund
description: In yet another example of hedge funds, investment banks and private equity shops blurring the lines of their respective businesses, Highbridge Capital Management, the hedge fund company with $34 billion of assets, has hired a former Goldman Sachs executive, Scott Kapnick, to start a private-equity business, Bloomberg News reported.

title: TXU Bidders May Have to Sweeten Offer, Analysts Say
description: The buyout shops that want to buy the energy firm TXU may have to raise their offer to persuade shareholders to accept, analysts said. The $45 billion offer by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group to buy the Dallas power company just survived a contentious legislative session unharmed.

title: Google Brings in Big Guns for DoubleClick Review
description: As it awaits the green light from federal antitrust regulators, Google disclosed last week in a government filing that it is putting new lobbying muscle, including a former high-ranking Justice Department antitrust lawyer, behind its proposed $3.1 billion acquisition of the online advertising firm DoubleClick.

title: The Myth of (the Original) Cerberus
description: It has forged a historic deal to buy Chrysler for $7.4 billion, one of most audacious deals in private equitys history. It has taken stakes in 50 companies around the world, often after bare-knuckled negotiations. It has even purchased Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, two of the top makers of so-called black rifles, styled after the assault weapons used by the military.

title: Tribune Reaches $350 Million Settlement with I.R.S.
description: Tribune announced Friday that it had reached a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service that would return to the company as much as $350 million of a disputed $1 billion tax payment it made in late 2005.

title: Carlyles Deal for PQ Reaps Big Windfall for JPMorgan
description: PQ, a specialty chemical manufacturer, is being sold for the second time in less than three years, bringing its owner a huge profit. The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for the company, making it a home run for the private-equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, which bought PQ for $626 million in February 2005.

title: Hey Buddy, Need Tickets?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed a law late last week that legalized ticket scalping.

title: Qiagen to Buy Digene, Maker of H.P.V. Diagnostic Tests
description: Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy Digene for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Immigration Bill Takes Center Stage
description: The Senate returns today for what could be the decisive week for immigration legislation. Many lawmakers will no doubt prefer debating the bill rather than discussing it with voters back home.

title: Amex Close to Private Banking Sale, Report Says
description: American Express is expected to sell its private banking business within weeks, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the matter. The buyer wasnt identified, but the source told Reuters that the private banking unit would likely be acquired by a global institution.

title: Avaya May Be Sold to Silver Lake and Texas Pacific

title: Food Fight!
description: Back to the farm? Several writers  notably Barbara Kingsolver and Michael Pollan  have written best-sellers urging us eat local and organic, but Ronald Bailey at Reason has some qualms:Kingsolver adopts absolutely every one the modern urban fables with regard to food production, starting with the claim that organic is more nutritious. There is very little scientific evidence for that claim. In addition, organic is not necessarily better for nature since yields are generally lower than conventional farming, which means that more land must be used to produce food. Reading Kingsolver, one could also conclude that pesticides were created by giant chemical companies whose sole aim was to cause cancer. But even the American Cancer Society agrees that there is no evidence that residues of pesticides and herbicides at the low doses found in foods increase the risk of cancer. Studies also show that eliminating pesticides could cut corn yields by 30 percent, rice by 57 percent, soybeans by 37 percent, and wheat by 24 percent. Again, that would mean that a lot more of nature would have to be plowed up to maintain the food supply at current levels.

description: HONG KONG, June 5  Share prices in China plunged another 7 percent this morning, only to turn around in the afternoon to finish with gains after the government authorized four large funds to raise money for the purchase of stocks.

title: Memo Pad
description: AIRLINE REPORT CARD: OUCH! The airline industry may be back in the black, but passengers are still seeing red, according to a Consumer Reports survey that will be published in its July issue. Over all, the industrys average score for satisfaction is lower than the scores for hotels and rental car companies and better only than such perennials of frustration as wireless carriers, cable TV operators and computer tech support, the magazine reports. Here is how the top 18 major domestic airlines stacked up in customer satisfaction. JetBlue was rated best. Consumer Reports said the carriers numerous flight delays in mid-February seem to have had little effect on the survey. In descending order, the others are Midwest, Southwest, Frontier, Hawaiian, Aloha, Alaska, Spirit, Continental, AirTran, Delta, American, ATA, Northwest, American Eagle, United, and America West and US Air, which merged in 2005 and recently combined all operations. In the Consumer Reports survey on hotels, Ritz-Carlton, a Marriott luxury brand, was chosen as top in overall satisfaction, while Homewood Suites from Hilton and SpringHill Suites from Marriott were cited as excellent values. Ritz-Carlton was also ranked at the top of the Market Metrix hospitality index survey taken in the first quarter of 2007.

description: PRAGUE, June 5  President Bush delivered a double-barreled message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today, two days before the leaders are to meet in Germany, by assuring Mr. Putin that he has nothing to fear from a missile defense system but also chiding him for derailing democratic reforms.

title: Prevention: Soy Nuts Seem to Help Womens Blood Pressure
description: Substituting a half-cup of soy nuts  baked soybeans  for other types of protein in a healthy diet may help lower a postmenopausal womans blood pressure, a small study has found.

title: A Point System for Immigrants Incites Passions
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Ekaterina D. Atanasova, a civil engineer from Bulgaria who lives in southern Maine, wants to bring her husband to the United States. Under the Senate immigration bill, he would get high marks  at least 74 points  because he too is a civil engineer, has a masters degree and is fluent in English.

title: Asset Manager to Oppose Biomet Takeover Offer
description: At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction over buyouts.

title: Under a Divided City, Evidence of a Once United One
description: JERUSALEM, June 4  Dig nearly anywhere in this city, and you hit the remains of an earlier civilization. One of the latest such finds is a narrow strip of antiquity that runs down the middle of a main road through what is now Shuafat, a Palestinian neighborhood in north Jerusalem.

title: Libby Receives 30 Months in Prison in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to the vice president and one of the principal architects of President Bushs foreign policy, was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq.

title: And Jerry Mathers as ... Tracy Turnblads Father?
description: It shouldnt have seemed weird, but it did: Jerry Mathers, also known as TVs Beaver, having just polished off a 16-ounce steak at the Palm, picked up his cellphone and called his girlfriend, asking her to come over for dessert.

title: Forgetting May Be Part of the Process of Remembering
description: Whether drawing a mental blank on a new A.T.M. password, a favorite recipe or an old boyfriend, people have ample opportunity every day to curse their own forgetfulness. But forgetting is also a blessing, and researchers reported on Sunday that the ability to block certain memories reduces the demands on the brain when it is trying to recall something important.

title: Hong Kongs Tiananmen Vigil Draws Crowd After Officials Denial
description: HONG KONG, June 4  A candlelight vigil here on Monday evening to observe the 18th anniversary of the military crackdown on the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in Beijing drew an unusually large crowd, apparently in response to the recent assertion by the leader of Hong Kongs pro-China party that no massacre took place.

title: Musharraf Issues Decree Cracking Down on News Media
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 4  In an apparent move to curb news media coverage of the continuing political crisis over his suspension of the countrys chief justice, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the president of Pakistan, issued a decree on Monday that gives the government more powers to shut down independent television channels.

title: Dr. Kevorkians Wrong Way
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian  a k a Doctor Death for helping chronically ill and terminally ill patients commit suicide  has emerged from prison as deluded and unrepentant as ever. Brushing aside criticism by other supporters of medically assisted suicide that his tactics were reckless and harmful to their cause, Dr. Kevorkian asserted: I did it right. I didnt care what they did or didnt do. When Im going to do it, Im going to do it right.

title: Palm Sells 25% Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
description: Palm Inc., the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, has reached a deal to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company.

description: CHICAGO, June 4  The way this season has gone, the Yankees have learned not to expect too much from their fragile pitchers. But they seem optimistic that Andy Pettitte and Roger Clemens will start the first two games of this weekends home series against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Protests Mark Six-Day Wars Anniversary
description: HEBRON, West Bank, June 5  Conflicting ideologies and internal divisions came to the forefront today as Israelis and Palestinians marked the 40th anniversary of the start of the Six-Day War in June 1967.

description: A headline on Friday about a growing movement in Britain to boycott Israel economically and culturally referred incorrectly in some copies to a decision reached by the union of public service employees, the largest British labor union. The union said a resolution that would call for a boycott of Israel would be considered at its upcoming annual meeting. The union did not call for such a boycott.

It was Philip L. Barlow, who will lead a Mormon studies program at Utah State University  not Jeff Ricks, executive manager of the Post-Mormon Community  who made the points that the family role is in-built into the theology and that because the family is conceived of as eternal, a wayward Mormon is threatening to that family unit for all eternity.

title: 4th Suspect Surrenders in Airport Plot
description: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, June 5  The fourth suspect in a terrorist plot to ignite jet fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport in Queens surrendered this morning, police officials in Trinidad said today.

description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., June 1  Practice was just under way for the Detroit Shock, defending champion of the Womens National Basketball Association, and Coach Bill Laimbeer was not entirely happy with the conditioning drills. Few people will talk back to a man who is 6 feet 11 inches and always considers himself the smartest person in the room. This does not include Laimbeers assistant, Rick Mahorn, who is only an inch shorter and is often the funniest person in the room.

title: Safe Harbor for Exploited Children
description: The New York State Legislature is rightly pleased with itself for passing a new law that offers tougher penalties for sex traffickers, as well as help for their victims who are often smuggled in from abroad and forced to work as sex slaves. As important as it is, the trafficking law fails to deal with the serious and growing problem of American children, some as young as 13 years old, who are dragooned into prostitution by brutal pimps.

title: Manhattan: New York Remains Safest Big City
description: Crime fell 5.3 percent in New York City last year, and New York is still the safest big city in the United States, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday in releasing statistics from the F.B.I.s preliminary crime report for 2006. Violent crime in New York dropped 4.6 percent, and the city reported the fewest crimes per 100,000 residents among the nations largest cities, the mayor said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said crime had fallen an additional 8.5 percent in the first several months of this year. Nationwide, crime increased 1.3 percent last year, according to the F.B.I. report.

title: Japan: Popular Support for Abe Falls Again
description: Support for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped to its lowest since he took office in September, hovering at 30 percent in a poll by the national daily Asahi Shimbun. Other polls indicated a similar slide in Mr. Abes approval ratings, which have suffered from the recent suicide of his scandal-tainted agricultural minister and from the governments mishandling of pension records. The fall increased the possibility that his governing Liberal Democratic Party might lose seats in Julys upper house election; an outright defeat could spur calls for him to step down as party leader and prime minister.

title: China: 180,000 Displaced After Strong Quake
description: Rescue efforts continued in southwestern Yunnan Province as roughly 180,000 people were evacuated from their homes after a Sunday morning earthquake that registered a magnitude 6.4 killed at least three people and injured more than 300, according to state news media. More than 1,000 aftershocks have rattled the nerves of residents in the city of Puer, in a mountainous region of Yunnan. Roughly 2,000 soldiers and rescue workers are at the scene, and evacuees are living in tents or public buildings.

title: Putin Supports Longer Term for Successor to Presidency
description: MOSCOW, June 4  President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia could benefit from longer presidential terms, though he again ruled out the possibility that he would remain in office after the expiration of his second term next year, according to remarks published Monday.

title: Military Judges Dismiss Charges for 2 Detainees
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, June 4  The governments new system for trying Guantnamo detainees was thrown into turmoil Monday, when military judges in separate decisions dismissed war crimes charges against two of the detainees.

description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Representative Jos E. Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx, objects to a recent bipartisan proposal on immigration policy because, he says, it would create an underclass of immigrant workers with few rights.

A colonnaded temple to both commerce and the automobile, the store, in the classical revival style, had a lot with parking spaces for about 600 cars.

description: Two equity firms, Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, agreed last night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion.

It was Cesare Fassari, a spokesman for the ministry, who told a reporter that Dr. Maria Grazia Pompa, the head of its tuberculosis surveillance program, contacted the C.D.C. and said, Werent you supposed to contact us?  Mr. Fassari also said, At that time, the disease centers confirmed that there was a case but did not provide details. The comments were not made to the reporter by Dr. Pompa.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bushs new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency. (Go to Article)

title: Nassau Tax Relief System Faces Pressure
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 1  Every year, droves of Nassau County homeowners seek tax relief by challenging their property assessments, generating a deluge of cases seen nowhere else in the state.

description: Tank Johnson of the Chicago Bears has been suspended without pay for the first eight games of the 2007 regular season for violating the National Football Leagues personal-conduct policy. Commissioner Roger Goodell said yesterday that the suspension could be reduced to six games if Johnson avoided legal trouble and attended counseling.

description: PARIS, June 4  In his first formal encounter with foreign journalists since assuming office last month, President Nicolas Sarkozy worked hard to be informal.

title: Rhode Island Bishop Condemns Giulianis Position on Abortion
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has come under fire from the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence, R.I., who has criticized Mr. Giulianis support of abortion rights, calling the position pathetic, confusing and hypocritical.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 3  Every summer the radio station Hot 97 organizes Summer Jam, New Yorks foremost hip-hop concert. (Though its held across the river.) Titans clash, stars show up unannounced, fans render their ruthless judgment. It seems that every year Summer Jam proves a point.

title: 4 Die in Fighting at Camp in Southern Lebanon
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 4  Two soldiers and two militants were killed in fighting in the southern Lebanese refugee camp of Ain al Hilwe early Monday. The deaths sealed a night of violence in northern and southern Lebanon that caused fears that the 16-day siege of a refugee camp on the outskirts of this northern Lebanese town may have spread.

title: Clete Boyer, 70, a Yankee Known for His Slick Fielding, Dies
description: Clete Boyer, the sharp-fielding third baseman who played on Yankees teams that won five consecutive pennants in the 1960s, died yesterday in Atlanta. He was 70.

title: Queens: President Appointed for L.I.R.R.
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday appointed a former Nassau County official as the new president of the Long Island Rail Road. The appointee, Helena E. Williams, a lawyer, served as a deputy county executive in Nassau County from late 2002 until February. She had previously worked at the authority and had run its Long Island Bus division from 1993 to 1998. Ms. Williams, who is to begin work on June 18, will be the first woman to run the Long Island Rail Road, the countrys busiest commuter railroad, with 82 million riders each year. The previous president, James J. Dermody, retired in September. Raymond P. Kenny has been serving as acting president. Ms. Williams, a resident of Nassau County since 1985, lives in Garden City. As head of the railroad, she will receive a yearly compensation package worth $272,000.

title: When a Picture Is So Good It Deserves a Frame
description: THE time is right for buying digital picture frames. More than 30 million digital cameras were sold in the United States last year alone, yet millions of snapshots taken with them are never printed. Instead, they remain stuck on computer hard drives, brought up only by an occasional slide show or screensaver.

title: Heart Health: Women Who Drink a Little May Lower Heart-Attack Risk
description: Women who drink moderate amounts of alcohol may reduce their risk for nonfatal heart attack, provided that they do not become drunk, according to a recent study.

title: Warner Group in Deal to Offer Free Music via Internet Site
description: Major labels have fought several legal battles to try to keep fans from listening to music without paying for it. Now one label, the Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales.

title: Tribunal System, Newly Righted, Stumbles Again
description: The Bush administrations attempt to create an alternative justice system for terrorism suspects, in the works for more than five years, has yet to complete a single trial.

title: TV Reporter to Run for a Senate Seat
description: ATLANTA, June 4  A former television investigative reporter announced Monday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, in a campaign that will most likely pit him against a frequent subject of his news reports.

title: Phone Cameras May Have Extras, but Dont Toss Your Point-and-Shoot
description: AT one time, a cellphone with a built-in camera seemed as unlikely a pairing as a double major in organic chemistry and costume design, but many people now regard camera phones as de rigueur for spontaneous photo-ops. Yet continuous improvements in the camera portions of these devices raise a question for gift-givers: do people even need a regular camera anymore?

title: Schumer Calls for Energy Efficiency
description: Looking to create national energy-saving standards and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he was introducing a measure that would require cities and states to increase energy efficiency in new buildings by 30 percent in the next five years and by 50 percent before 2022. Under the measure, to be introduced next week as an amendment to the Senate energy bill, cities and states would face penalties unless they adopted a standard nationwide code or their own codes requiring energy-efficient systems and designs. Cities that met the standards would be exempt from the penalties even if their states failed to do so, Mr. Schumer said. The amendment, he said, is meant to bring the country in line with the standards in California and New York City, which recently overhauled its building code to require so-called green-building practices.

description: Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming, who combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in Cheyenne and Washington, died Monday evening in Bethesda, Md. He was 74.

title: Sudden Growth
description: Seven years ago, I planted a pair of white spruces  Picea glauca. They came by mail in slender tubes from a nursery in Oregon, mere wisps of vegetation. I wasnt sure where I wanted to put them, so I stuck them in an improvised nursery bed, beside the sweet corn and the pole beans. A year later I moved them just inside the fence along the gravel road that runs past our place. It has been to their liking. Those trees are now well over 10 feet tall  lone emissaries from the great forest of white spruces that reaches across Canada.

title: Albany: Monitoring for Acid Rain
description: Officials with the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, are lobbying to reverse planned reductions in the federal budget that would severely limit or eliminate several acid rain monitoring programs. The proposed budget would cut $1 million, about 25 percent, from one program that measures atmospheric gases. Two other programs that sample lakes and streams in the Adirondacks and other areas of the Northeast on an annual combined budget of less than $1 million would also be eliminated. Acid rain remains a serious problem in many parts of the country, but nowhere has it been more damaging than in the Adirondacks, where vast forests have been decimated and more than 500 lakes and ponds have been left unable to support many species of native fish. Closing down, even for a few months, will wipe out 21 years of continuously collected scientific data, Brian L. Houseal, the councils executive director, said in a statement.

title: China Issues Plan on Global Warming
description: BEIJING, June 4  With global warming high on the agenda for the worlds industrial powers gathering later this week in Germany, China staked out its position on Monday by releasing its first national strategy on climate change, a plan that promises to improve energy efficiency but rejects any mandatory caps on greenhouse gas emissions.

description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is investigating what role, if any, a staff scientist played in the international health scare set off by the odyssey of his son-in-law, who has extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis.

description: NEW DELHI, June 4  They burned buses during the morning rush hour. They threw stones at trains packed with passengers and at the police. title: Giuliani Makes 9/11 His Brand
description: The Republican candidates for president will go at it again tonight, debating in New Hampshire. Terrorism and national security are bound to figure as topics, and we all know what that means: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will have another chance to assert proprietary rights to Sept. 11 and how we should understand that day.

title: Dozens Killed in Violence Around Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, June 5  Up to 18 people were killed south of Falluja today when a suicide bomber driving a truck packed with high explosives plowed into a busy commercial district. The attack also wounded at least 15 people, according to a local Iraqi police official.

title: Contract for Advanced Smallpox Vaccine
description: The federal government announced the award of a $500 million contract to a European pharmaceutical company to deliver 20 million doses of an advanced smallpox vaccine. The government already has a stockpile of vaccine that could be used to immunize every American in the event of a smallpox attack by terrorists. But because the existing vaccine sometimes causes serious side effects, the Department of Health and Human Services is asking the company, Bavarian Nordic A/S, of Denmark, to make enough of its vaccine to immunize about 10 million Americans like patients on chemotherapy or people with H.I.V./AIDS. The company said the contract could be worth $1.6 billion.

description: Federal authorities have expanded an investigation into allegations that Jackson Hewitt offices helped prepare fraudulent income-tax returns that allowed customers to obtain refunds illegally.

title: Albany: New Internet Consumer Protection Law
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed legislation yesterday that will broaden consumer protections for New Yorkers who shop online. The law will bring the protections for online shoppers in line with those for consumers who buy goods over the phone or by mail. Among other provisions, it will prohibit online retailers from accepting an order they cannot ship within 30 days and require advertising and promotional materials to include the retailers legal name, address and the conditions under which refunds will be issued. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, who said that his offices Internet Bureau received 1,000 consumer complaints last year and that the bill, passed by the Legislature in May, would put businesses on notice that the Internet is no longer the Wild West of commerce.

title: The Questions Are Big, but the Devils in the Details
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 3  There are operas of action and operas of stasis. But while Pascal Dusapins Faustus, the Last Night certainly qualifies as static, it might more accurately be called an opera of suspension. It seems to float, a quality borne out in the staging here at the Sottile Theater as part of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A.

description: BAGHDAD, June 4  A Sunni insurgent group released a videotape on Monday that showed the military identification cards of two missing American soldiers who were captured last month south of Baghdad, and a narrator said they had been killed.

title: Cars and Bikes Can Mix, When the Rules of the Road Are Clear
description: A journalist who regularly bicycled to work in Washington was killed when he rode headlong into the door of a truck as the driver opened it.

title: Bargain-Basement Acquisitions Help Mets Reach the Top
description: At 12:01 a.m. on Dec. 21, 2005, the office of Commissioner Bud Selig sent an e-mail message to every team in baseball listing 50 players who had become free agents because their teams had not offered them contracts for the next season.

title: Samuel A. Garrison, 65, Lawyer Who Fought Nixon Impeachment, Dies
description: Samuel A. Garrison III, who as chief Republican counsel to the House Judiciary Committee in its Watergate investigation in 1974 argued against the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon, died on May 27 near his home in Roanoke, Va. He was 65.

title: Outcomes: Lycopene Does Not Fight Off Prostate Cancer, Study Shows
description: Some recent studies have suggested that lycopene, a chemical in tomatoes and other red fruits, is protective against prostate cancer, but a large prospective study has found that it has no effect.

title: Ruling Helps Prosecutors in Death Penalty Cases
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  The Supreme Court on Monday strengthened the hand of prosecutors in death penalty cases by making it easier to remove potential jurors who express ambivalence about the death penalty or confusion about how it should be applied.

title: Wading Through Formats: JPEG, TIFF and Friends
description: A DIGITAL camera can save photos in a file format called JPEG, and sometimes in other formats like TIFF or RAW. A computers photo software offers even more choices. While the options can seem bewildering, it pays to know something about them. Format choice can make a big difference, depending on what you want to do with your pictures.

title: Liberian Ex-Leader Boycotts War Crimes Trial as It Opens
description: THE HAGUE, June 4  On the first day of his trial, former President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia, one of Africas most tyrannical warlords, refused to appear in court on Monday and sent word that he was firing his lawyer, apparently wanting to deflect attention from proceedings that aim to cover a decade of warfare and extraordinary cruelties.

title: NATO Sinks Second Boat Full of Taliban Fighters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 5  The Afghan defense ministry said that NATO helicopters attacked and sank a second boat full of Taliban fighters trying to escape across the Helmand River in southern Afghanistan. All of the 20 to 30 Taliban fighters on board were drowned, according to the spokesman, Gen. Zaher Azimi.

title: Shining a Halogen Light on a Senators Dark Corners
description: Two new biographies of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the New York Democrat who is a leading contender for her partys presidential nomination, will put readers in mind of Edward Gibbons observation that history is essentially the recounting of the crimes, follies and misfortunes of mankind. Mrs. Clintons Senate spokesman, Philippe Reines, has complained that these biographies are nothing more than cash for rehash, containing nothing new and largely focusing on the details of the suspected corruption that never produced indictments, despite the considerable efforts of a special prosecutor.

title: Stormy Weather, Brought to You By ...
description: For years, Ace promoted itself as the place with the helpful hardware man. Now, Ace wants to be the helpful place when it comes to coping with hurricanes.

title: An Unacceptable Nominee
description: President Bushs latest appeals court nominee, Leslie Southwick, has a disturbing history of insensitivity to blacks and other minority groups. The Senate should reject this nomination and make clear to the White House that it will reject all future nominees who do not meet the high standards of fairness that are essential for such important posts.

title: Letters
description: Care For the Earliest Newborns

title: A Perennial Search for Perfect Wheat
description: PULLMAN, Wash.  It is a gleaming prize for wheat farmers, and environmentally correct, to boot: a perennial food plant that requires plowing only once every three to five years and prevents dust storms, stems soil erosion and even absorbs carbon to help mitigate climate change.

title: Dominating Dover, Truex Earns First Cup Victory
description: DOVER, Del., June 4  Martin Truex Jr., the often overlooked teammate of Dale Earnhardt Jr., won his first Nascar Nextel Cup race Monday before half-filled grandstands, just hours after the former Nascar president Bill France Jr. died.

title: Republicans Face Off in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., June 5  The Republican presidential candidates waged verbal combat tonight in the Congressional battle over a proposed immigration overhaul, with Senator John McCain, an author of a pending compromise plan, defending the controversial proposals in a Republican debate and demanding that his competitors offer a better idea.

title: France: Rare White Lion Cubs Die at Zoo
description: Four white lion cubs, three females and a male, whose birth last month at the zoo in Jurques, in western France, added to the roughly 30 white lions in captivity worldwide, have died, zoo officials said. The cubs were vulnerable to infection because they had been bottle fed after being rejected by their mother.

title: Untangling the Choices and Finding Headphones
description: THE headphone cords that tether ears to portable music players can carry subtle messages. They may declare, Im hip, or, Im above your world  Im not part of it.

title: Renovation Slowly Adds Some Light to Lollipops
description: The controversial white block of a building is still shrouded in dark netting. The hard-hatted men perched on the surrounding scaffolding wont wrap up their work until the middle of next year. But behind the scrim, the lollipop building at 2 Columbus Circle is steadily changing into a new home for the Museum of Arts and Design.

title: The Passion of Al Gore
description: Al Gore is earnestly talking about the long-term implications of the energy and climate crises, and how the Arctic ice cap is receding much faster than computer models had predicted, and how difficult and delicate a task it will be to try and set things straight in Iraq.

title: An Evening Full of Trios, Combining Bach and Ballet
description: In life there can never be too much Bach. If only the same could be said for New York City Ballets latest compilation program, Three by Bach, an evening of dances by George Balanchine, Christopher dAmboise and Jerome Robbins, whose portion was a revival of his sparkling 1997 Brandenburg. For a program to fulfill an artistic craving, variety is crucial.

title: Terror Arrests Puzzle Many in Guyanese Enclave in Queens
description: Over the course of 30 years, the sober-sided houses of Richmond Hill, Queens, have been transformed into an echo of the Caribbean, with candy-colored paint jobs, fanciful ironwork and beds of vivid flowers. Immigrants in this neighborhood care passionately about their houses, as well as their cricket teams and Bollywood musicals. Terrorism does not seem to fit here.

title: A New Way to Clean Up
description: When people talk about their career transitions, they often become natural storytellers, skipping over the dull bits and zooming in on the moments of high drama and epiphany. Stan Halperns career shift always takes him back to the heart attack he suffered in 1997.

title: What if Israel Had Turned Back?
description: Jerusalem

title: Yankees Revival Takes a Wrong Turn
description: CHICAGO, June 4  Roger Clemens was supposed to rumble into the Yankees clubhouse Monday and make everything better. He would have received his pregame rubdown  analgesic ointment smothered over his legs, back and shoulders, a pitchers war paint  and strode to the mound, an old sheriff back in town.

title: Third G.O.P. Debate
description: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Republican presidential candidates debate hosted by CNN, WMUR-TV and The New Hampshire Union Leader. The participants were Senator Sam Brownback, the former Virginia Gov. James Gilmore, the former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani, Rep. Duncan Hunter, the former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, Sen. John McCain, Rep. Ron Paul, the former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney, Rep. Tom Tancredo, and the former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson and the moderator was Wolf Blitzer.

title: Wyoming Senator in Serious Condition
description: Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, is in serious condition at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., as he battles leukemia and an infection, according to a statement from his office. Mr. Thomas learned that he had leukemia in 2006, before he was elected to his third Senate term.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article and picture caption on Friday about President Bushs new proposal for setting a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions misstated the location of his speech announcing the plan. Mr. Bush spoke in an auditorium in the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, which also houses the offices of the United States Agency for International Development. He did not speak at the agency.

title: Cheated of Future, Iraqi Graduates Want to Flee
description: BAGHDAD, June 4  They started college just before or after the American invasion with dreams of new friends and parties, brilliant teachers and advanced degrees that would lead to stellar jobs, marriage and children. Success seemed well within their grasp.

title: Both Parties Expect Corzines Choice for Chief Justice to Be a Fair and Moderate Voice
description: TRENTON, June 4  When Gov. Jon S. Corzine officially nominated Attorney General Stuart Rabner on Monday as the next chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, he said he expected Mr. Rabner, 46, to shape our history long, long after this administrations service under the golden dome has long since passed.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Wallace Seawell, a Hollywood photographer, misspelled the given name of one of the celebrities he photographed. She was Ava Gardner, not Eva.

title: Bush to Seek a Bit of Unity With Putin
description: PRAGUE, June 4  At a moment of rising tensions between Washington and Moscow, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appear likely to use a meeting in Germany this week to focus on the one area where they appear to share a common interest: slowing Irans ability to produce nuclear fuel.

title: No Clemens, No Chance Against White Sox
description: Not much to say about this one here in rainy Chicago tonight. The Yankees scored three in the ninth but it wasnt enough in a 6-4 loss. Matt DeSalvo pitched an inning and a third, gave up three runs, and that was about it. Jim Thome and Paul Konerko homered to put the game out of reach.

title: Flying with Air France
description: Years ago, two old stock-car racers were in Nascars Daytona Beach, Fla., headquarters, reminiscing about how fast they used to drive from various racetracks to Daytona. It was the record, as they called it. Who had it?

title: F.C.C. Rebuffed by Court on Indecency Fines
description: A federal appeals panel struck down the government policy that allows stations and networks to be fined if they broadcast shows containing obscene language.

title: Comparing the Photo-Sharing Sites
Still keen on Spain?
description: The good news about the Spanish property market slowdown is that there are good deals to be had for those still interested in buying a home there. One city that continues to lure buyers is Alicante, one of the most well-known towns on the Costa Blanca. In Alicante  popular for its university, beautiful beaches, and quality properties  the average home price is now $341,000.

title: Views of the Museum
description:
Additional images of the Steven Holl expansion of the
Nelson-Atkins Museum in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Theater Briefs
description: Recent rains have washed out the first preview of the Public Theater's presentation of Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

title: An Election Day, for Some
description: There is a special election today on the East Side of Manhattan in the 65th Assembly District. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. For details, voters can call the New York City Board of Elections toll free at 1 (866) VOTENYC (868-3692).

title: Former Enron Official Sentenced to 2 Years
description: The former chief operating officer of Enrons broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison and fined $125,000 for his role in the fraud that led to the companys collapse, a court official said on Monday. Mr. Hannon was sentenced by Judge Vanessa Gilmore of United States District Court in Houston.

title: Eschewing Trump, Blacks Defense Tries to Contain the Circus
description: In Canada, at least, the criminal fraud case of Conrad M. Black was billed as the trial of the century as it began more than two months ago. Accusations that Mr. Black and three colleagues had looted more than $60 million from the international newspaper conglomerate that he built promised to put not just Mr. Blacks oversize ego and life on display, but also a frothy brew of high finance, high society and high intrigue.

title: Inside Murdochs Meeting With the Bancrofts
description: In their first face-to-face meeting, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company told Rupert Murdoch on Monday that it would sell him the company only if its jewel, The Wall Street Journal, could be shielded from editorial interference from him, according to a report in The New York Times.

title: I.C.E., Waiting on CBOT, Buys Commodity Trader
description: The IntercontinentalExchange, the Atlanta commmodities exchange that is currently pressing an unsolicited $11 billion buyout bid for Chicago Board of Trade parent CBOT Holdings, disclosed Monday that it had agreed to acquire the commodity trading business of ChemConnect of Houston.

title: American Express Is Said to Be Near a Sale of Private Bank
description: American Express is expected to sell its private banking business within a matter of weeks, according to Reuters, in a sale that could fetch between $1 billion to $2 billion for the credit card and travel services company.

title: Uranium One Stakes Claim for Energy Metals
description: Fast-growing Uranium One extended its aggressive acquisition spree offering 1.8 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion) in stock for Vancouvers Energy Metals. The takeover would give Toronto-based Uranium One a slate of American assets including near-term production from projects in Texas, Wyoming, New Mexico and Utah.

title: Chicago Bank Tries to Break Up Bears Bid for Doral
description: FBOP, a privately held Chicago bank holding company, is trying to muscle in on Bear Stearnss deal for a controlling stake in cash-strapped Doral Financial of Puerto Rico.

title: Doctor in your town?
description: I spent much of last week covering the story of the American lawyer with tuberculosis who flew around Europe potentially exposing others, afraid (he said) of being put in quarantine here in Rome. I was thinking that one of the problems was this: When youre in a strange city, where you may not know the language, it is often hard to get medical advice or care you can trust. To that end, Ive asked all our Globespotters reporters to recommend a good English speaking medical practice where they live. Well put it up in the travel basics box for each city. But if you have recommendations, please write in

title: Joost Names Former Cisco Executive as C.E.O.
description: The high-profile Internet start-up Joost announced Tuesday that it had hired Michelangelo Volpi, a veteran executive of Cisco Systems, as its new chief executive. Joost, which is based in London, is building a global television network of full-length TV shows and movies and sending it to viewers over the Internet.

title: Indian Bank Seeks $2.5 Billion in Overseas Share Sale, Report Says
description: The ICICI Bank may raise $2.5 billion in the biggest overseas share sale by an Indian company, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Asset Manager to Oppose Biomet Takeover Offer
description: At least one significant investor in Biomet, an artificial joint maker, plans to vote against a proposed $10.9 billion deal for the company, in the latest instance of shareholder dissatisfaction over buyouts.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Says Earnings Will Beat Estimates
description: the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, the British bank leading a takeover bid for ABN Amro, said first-half earnings will rise more than 8.1 percent, beating analysts estimates, as bad consumer loans declined in Britain.

title: Prosecutors May Add Charges in Squawk Box Retrial
description: Three ex-brokers at Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers  face a November retrial on charges they conspired to commit fraud by letting day traders eavesdrop on the firms internal squawk boxes.

title: Software Deals Set Torrid Pace in 2007
description: Big-ticket acquisitions by Cisco Systems, Oracle and a variety of buyout firms helped drive software mergers and acquisitions to record levels so far this year. An analyst firm, The 451 Group, takes a look at the nearly $28 billion in software deal activity in the first five months of 2007.

title: Venture Fund to Seek Out Cost Cutters in Health Care
description: Venture investment in the health business typically chases miracle cures and high-technology gadgets, like bioengineered drugs and new medical devices. They promise much but cost a lot.

title: Top Tokyo Banker at Merill to Start His Own Investment Firm
description: Jesper Koll, one of the best known foreign commentators on Japans economy, resigned from Merrill Lynch in Tokyo to form an investment company. The move is the latest in a string of departures of investment banking executives looking to start their own firms.

title: Chinas Citic Eyes $2.4 Billion Offering
description: Chinese stocks may be slumping now, but Citic Securities, Chinas most profitable securities house, believes there will still be an appetite for its shares. The company indicated Tuesday that it plans to sell up to 350 million new A shares on the Shanghai market, which could raise some $2.4 billion to back its expansion plan to become a first-class investment bank.

title: With $2 Billion War Chest, Pershing Is Said to Target an Icon
description: Pershing Square Capital Management, a New York hedge fund with a gift for shaking up corporate boardrooms, has raised $2 billion that will be dedicated to an activist assault on just one specific, iconic American company, The New York Post reported.

title: Activist Hedge Funds Targets J-Power in Japan Test
description: The Childrens Investment Fund, the activist hedge fund whose demands put Dutch bank ABN Amro in play, is scouring Japan for deals but sees its struggle to raise the dividend at Japanese electric power wholesaler J-Power as a test case for further investment in the country.

title: Commerzbank Jumps on Rumors of a Citigroup Deal
description: Shares in Germanys Commerzbank, which has been persistently cited as a possible takeover target, jumped more than 3 percent on Tuesday to near a seven-year peak on market talk that Citigroup was likely to bid about 45 euros ($61) per share for the bank, traders said.

title: IceBreaker Warms Up With $7.2 Million Round
description: The start-up behind the mobile matchmaking service Crush or Flush is feeling the love from venture investors, who agreed to put $7.2 million into the company. IceBreaker, which markets a cellphone-based dating service, said Tuesday that Frazier Technology Ventures and Lightspeed Venture Partners led its latest financing round. Crush or Flush, which works a bit like the once-popular Hot or Not Web site, is not yet generating revenue, according to the Seattle Post-Intelligencers Venture Blog. An IceBreaker marketing executive told the blog that his business was considering adding advertising or selling subscriptions.

title: A Look Back
description: The six-day Arab-Israeli conflict in 1967 ended in a military victory for Israel, a sober defeat for the Arab armies, and began Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: GE to Buy Canadian Assets from Dundee REIT
description: General Electrics real estate unit agreed to buy office and industrial buildings in Canada from Dundee Real Estate Investment Trust for about 2.4 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) and will purchase an 18 percent stake in the company. The purchase, which gives G.E. a toehold in faster-growing markets to tap global demand, includes 180 properties located primarily in Ontario, Quebec and Newfoundland.

title: Analysts Divided on Possible Cadence Deal
description: A New York Times report that Cadence Design Systems, a software maker, was in talks with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Blackstone Group about a possible buyout had analysts divided on whether such a deal would materialize.

title: New Palm Investor Sees Hand-Held Free-for-All
description: The private equity investment in Palm, announced Monday, is just the latest indication of the intense new competition that will increasingly blur the lines between telecommunications, computing and entertainment during the next several years. The stakes are so high that none of the major players in any of those three industries can afford to be left out.

title: As Private Equity Hunts, Its Prey May Be Adapting
description: As private equity firms continue to gobble up assets at unprecedented rate for unprecedented sums, their deal-frenzy is causing a chain reaction among firms who are eager to escape the clutches of these cash-rich hunters.

title: Venture Backers Tune Into Video-Sharing Site Blip.tv
description: Blip.tv, a two-year-old video-sharing Web site, said Tuesday it raised its first round of venture capital funding. The round was led by Ambient Sound Investments, a fund created by founding engineers from Internet-telephone company Skype, Blip.tv said. The amount of the funding wasnt disclosed. Jeffrey Sechrest, co-head of media and entertainment at investment bank Lazard, also participated in the round, Blip.tv said.

title: Warner Group in Deal to Offer Free Music via Internet Site
description: Major labels have fought several legal battles to try to keep fans from listening to music without paying for it. Now one label, the Warner Music Group, has made a deal with an Internet start-up, Lala.com, that will allow anyone to listen to its music free, with the idea that doing so will drive music sales.

title: Buyout Firms Reach Deal to Buy Avaya
description: Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group agreed Monday night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion. The deal, priced at $17.50 a share, puts the two private equity firms in control of the worlds biggest maker of corporate phone equipment, letting them go head to head with Cisco Systems in the $5 billion market for Web-based gear. Mondays agreement calls for Avaya to seek out other potential buyers over the next 50 days.

title: When in Bangkok, go Italian
description: Anyone who lives in Bangkok is constantly asked for restaurant recommendations by friends flying in for a few good meals. Often my answer is, How about Italian food? There are superb Italian restaurants in Bangkok. Within a 15-minute walk of my apartment in the Langsuan area I can count more than a half-dozen. Thais have long had an affinity for Italian food and at some point over the past decade the number of high-end Italian restaurants reached a critical mass. It became profitable to fly in a whole range of meats and ingredients as varied as fresh mozzarella di bufala and Sorrento lemons (one chef insists that only lemons from southern Italy will do the trick for his Tagliatelle al Limone). This week a group of Italian chefs has banded together to put on what they are calling, The Splendor of Italian Cuisine. I certainly agree with the concept. The festival, which is being held at 11 top Italian restaurants in the capital through June 10, has the faint whiff of a marketing gimmick. But Im a sucker for gimmicks that involve risotto and prosciutto crudo. Biscotti, the Italian restaurant at the Four Seasons (Tel: +66 2 255 5443), offers a 6-course menu for 1,500 baht ($44). Other restaurants involved in the festival include La Scala at the Sukhothai hotel (Tel: +66 2 344 8888) Spasso at the Grande Hyatt Erawan (Tel: +66 2 254 12340) and Giannis on Soi Tonson, near Central Chidlom department store (Tel: +66 2 252 1619).

title: Kiss, Kiss: The CFDA Awards
description: Oscar de la Renta looked mildly stunned last night when Steven Kolb, the executive director of the CFDA, hurried toward the podium to inform the mistress of ceremonies Ellen Barkin that there were TWO winners of the Womens Designer of the Year award. Everyone seemed surprised, not least Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough of Proenza Schouler, the other winner, who got up from their table (with Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen) and joined de la Renta. He made a special point of acknowledging his wife, Annette de la Renta, who was sitting next to Patrick McCarthy of WWD, and noting, not insignificantly, that he had been making clothes for more than 40 years.

title: Creation Differences
description: Robert T. Miller, an assistant professor at the Villanova University School of Law, says that part of Sam Brownbacks New York Times op-ed on evolution is obviously wrong. But Miller does not object to Brownbacks evaluation of the science. Instead, he opposes the Kansas senators general observations on the relationship between faith and reason, which Miller believes are worrying. Miller writes at On the Square, the First Things blog:

title: Smashing a Hot Dog Record
description: One quick way to demonstrate Takeru Kobayashis stature in the world of competitive eating is to refer to a fan-turned-peer named Crazy Legs Conti. To compare Kobayashi to Michael Jordan or Tiger Woods is to slight Kobayashi, he claimed.

title: Families and Newspapers: A Volatile Mix
description: A prominent family late Monday cut its longstanding ties with the newspaper business. No, not the Bancrofts  the Chandlers.

title: Diving in Punta del Este, Uruguay
description: Do you know if there are any diving centers and diving places in Punta del Este? I hope you can give me a good answer soon. Please give me a link to a diving center site if you know one.

title: In Which I Become Indiana Jones
description: The Harvard Crimson has a fun profile of me, based on digging up old college roommates and bosses. I love Jeff Toobins reference to me as the Indiana Jones of our generation of journalists. Thats better than many of the things I get called.

title: Debunking the Higher Bit Rate Myth
description: So last week, Apple began its experiment of selling non-protected, higher-quality songs on the iTunes Store for a 30-cent premium.

title: Focus on Immigration
description: With the Republican debate tonight in New Hampshire, the differences among the candidates on the compromise immigration legislation now under consideration in the Senate are likely to be enunciated. While some of the Democratic candidates talked about the bill at their debate on Sunday night, the disagreements among them were minor in comparison to the spectrum of views among the G.O.P. field.

title: Parsing Clintons Views on Gay Marriage
description: Is Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton preparing to endorse gay marriage?

title: Libbys Sentence: 30 Months and a $250,000 Fine
description: I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney known since childhood as Scooter, was sentenced this morning to 30 months in prison for lying to investigators checking into the unmasking of a C.I.A. operative whose husband helped fuel a fierce public debate over the administrations case for going to war in Iraq.

title: Op-Ed: Five Questions About Murdow
description: By Anant K. Sundaram

title: Burkle to Team with Dow Jones Union
description: Is Dow Jones becoming a case of deja vu all over again?

title: Ready for Pricier Emissions?
description: For years European industry has fought off the idea that companies should buy permits to pollute under the EUs program for complying with the Kyoto Protocol. Industry seemed to have a strong argument: The European economy was lagging the United States while China and India were shooting ahead. More regulation, said worried industrialists, was the last thing the regions power, pulp, cement and steel factories needed if they were to keep factories open and workers employed.

title: AIDS  Outpaces Treatment
description: For each sub-Saharan African who was placed on anti-AIDS drugs last year, five more were infected.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Alison Smale, managing editor of The International Herald Tribune, discusses the Group of 8 summit in Germany.

title: For Law Firm, Giulianis Halo Becomes a Glare
description: When he joined the Texas law firm Bracewell & Patterson in 2005 (and put his name on the door), Rudolph Giuliani said the move had nothing to do with a presidential run. Since then, the former mayor of New York has declared his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, collected more campaign contributions in Texas than any other Republican candidate and named the firms managing partner, Patrick Oxford, as his campaign chairman.

title: A Powerful Cyclone Hits Oman
description: Tropical Cyclone Gonu, the strongest storm to hit the strategic sultanate of Oman since the 1970s, has prompted the shutdown of important energy distribution centers, a rush inland, the proclamation of a national holiday until Sunday, concern for turtles  and a surfer alert about 40-foot waves.

title: Thompson Favors Libby Pardon
description: The 30-month sentence handed down today for I. Lewis Scooter Libby could become a rallying cry for Fred D. Thompson, the all-but declared Republican presidential candidate.

title: Make It Snappy, but Not Too Snappy
description: When asparagus are in season and on the menu, I always order them. To me they are a total indulgence and it must have something to do with their scarcity in my childhood: they were not available year round.

title: Could Alcatel-Lucent Consider an Avaya Reunion?
description: Avaya has agreed to be acquired by two private equity firms for $8.2 billion, but its not a done deal yet. As with many recent buyout agreements, terms call for a go-shop period during which the target company can solicit better offers. Although go-shops havent tended to smoke out rival bidders (Triad Hospitals is an exception), an analyst at Prudential says he thinks other parties remain interested. Among those that might peer through the go-shop window, according to Prudentials Inder Singh, is Alcatel-Lucent. Avaya, which sells telecommunications gear, was spun off from Lucent in 2000, so a deal between the two would be reunion of sorts.

title: Bikinis  la Mode
description: Some years ago, when Jean Paul Gaultier was really sinking teeth into couture, he held a show in the former home of Marie Laure de Noailles, an enormous house in the Place des tats Unis. I have a memory of rounding the corner  a wet January day  and seeing the bronze statue of Myron T. Herrick. Now theres a name a girl cant forget. Herrick was the American ambassador to France when Lindbergh landed in Paris, in May 1927. I knew this because I happened to be reading Scott Bergs biography of Lindbergh. A trip to a fashion show helped square a minor figure in history. A few nights later I was at a cocktail party at the American Embassy, and Felix Rohatyn, then ambassador, told me he loathed Lingbergh because of his Nazi sympathies. I was glad I had read Bergs great biography, which spelled out the sources of Lingberghs self-absorbed, self-reliant character.

title: A $112-a-Month MetroCard?
description: Well, maybe not that much. But not all is well in the land of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Solectron Takeover Sparks Guessing Game
description: This weeks deal in which Flextronics International will acquire Solectron for $3.6 billion has analysts wondering whether more consolidation is coming in the electronics manufacturing services sector  the business of making electronics on contract for other companies. There are plenty of potential targets out there, but some analysts warn against overexuberance, largely because buyers seem scarce. Investors seem to be unsure. After gaining on Monday, when the Solectron deal was announced, shares of many of the industrys players fell on Tuesday.

title: F.T.C. Seeks to Block Whole Foods-Wild Oats Deal
description: Concerned that one company might corner the market on organic broccoli and all kinds of other natural fare, federal regulators are suing to block Whole Foods Markets $565 million acquisition of a rival grocery chain, Wild Oats Markets, the two companies said Tuesday. The companies added that they will file a challenge in court.

title: Gaming With Googles Help
description: Alex Trebek offers no lifelines to contestants with the audacity to hit their buzzer. Just silence, and then a little needling. And if your brain doesnt bail you out, thats it. You failed.

title: I Now Pronounce You, Economic Benefit
description: Of all the arguments brought to bear in support of legalizing same-sex marriage, this one appears to be rather original: New York City, according to a new analysis by the city comptroller, could reap $142 million in economic benefits over three years, primarily from a surge in spending by residents and visitors on weddings and by their out-of-town guests.

title: Avandia Commercial
description: GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Jane Seymour(Fall 2001).

title: Avandia Commercial
description: GlaxoSmithKline Avandia advertisement with Della Reese (June 2004 - Dec. 2004).

title: "Avandia Montage"
description: An advertisement for GlaxoSmithKline's Avandia Type 2 diabetes medication.

title: Senator Craig Lyle Thomas, 74
description: Senators took to the floor today to pay tribute to Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming, who died last night after a short battle with acute myeloid leukemia.

title: Bear Dips Its Toe in the Sand with Saudi Joint Venture
description: In the latest move by American investment banks into the Middle East, Bear Stearns will join with a group of Saudi executives to form a joint venture to provide financial products compliant with Islamic law, MarketWatch reported Tuesday.

title: 2008: Democrats on Their Faith
description: While the religious views of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and former Senator John Edwards received wide coverage at Mondays forum organized by the evangelical group, Sojourners, four other Democratic presidential hopefuls also had a chance to weigh in during the second hour. Senators Joe Biden and Chris Dodd, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson and Representative Dennis Kucinich  all Catholics  candidly spoke with CNNs Paula Zahn about faith and politics.

title: Klobuchar Gets D.S.C.C. Leadership Spot
description: Just five months into her first term, Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, has been given a leadership position within the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

title: Starrett City Tenants Go to Albany
description: Nearly 150 Starrett City residents rallied outside the office of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, this afternoon, clamoring for him to appear. The residents want the Senate to pass a bill that would ensure their rents would not soar if a potential sale of Starrett, the massive Brooklyn apartment complex, goes through.

title: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Indiana
description: Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to Indiana. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

title: Will the Libby Case Enter the G.O.P. Debate?
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H., _ As the 10 candidates for the Republican nomination for president prepare for tonights debate, the matter of I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Cheneys former chief of staff, has suddenly moved to the front burner. A federal judge sentenced Mr. Libby this morning to 30 months in prison after he was convicted of obstructing justice in the case involving Valeria Plame Wilson.

title: More Useless Knowledge
description: When army ants are sweeping across the forest on one of their massive predatory raids, potholes tend to slow them down. And just the other day, British researchers revealed how these hard-charging creatures deal with the impediment: Individual ants fling themselves down and bridge the potholes with their bodies. In fact, the volunteers seem to size-match themselves to the holes they choose to plug. And when the army has tramped across their backs, they get up, dust themselves off, and head home to join the communal feast.

title: Site of Virginia Tech Massacre to Reopen
description: Norris Hall, where a student killed 30 students in nine minutes on April 16, is reopening, but not for classes, Virginia Tech announced today.

title: Hillarys Iowa Problem
description: Is Iowa a more sexist place than the rest of America? Linda Lantor Fandel, the deputy editorial page editor of The Des Moines Register, fears that it is, and that Hillary Clintons presidential campaign is suffering because of it.

title: Michigan Wins, and Jeter Rubs It In
description: Ive known Derek Jeter for six years, and we have a cordial relationship, like he seems to have with every writer. But hes never used my name. Today he sees me and pipes up, loud enough for the other writers to hear, Hey Tyler, whered you go to college?

title: Ships Passing in the Morning
description: On Wednesday morning, some Staten Island ferry riders are in for a brush with grayness.

title: Live-Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
description: GOFFSTOWN, N.H.

title: Beltrans Back
description: Hard-luck pitchers often say they are a victim of poor run support. Over his last two starts, Tom Glavine has gotten literally nothing. The Mets did not score against either John Smoltz or Barry Zito while losing, 2-1 and 3-0. Perhaps with Carlos Beltran, who missed the last three games with a bruised right knee, back in the lineup tonight against Philadelphia, Glavines luck may change.

title: How I Learned to Relax
Mets Dodging Draft
description: For the first time in history, MLBs first-year player draft will be televised. Or at least the first round. The fun begins at 2 p.m. Thursday on ESPN2, but unless youre a Mets fan who has special interest in local players like the New Jersey high school pitcher Rick Porcello or Rutgers shortstop Todd Frazier, you could probably find better things to do with your time.

title: The War in Present Tense
description: Ive been reorganizing the garage all morning. Rearranging journals and notebooks written years ago, weeding through boxes marked miscellaneous for any seemingly useful item, throwing out a broken warming plate that never worked to begin with, trash-bagging old clothes for the goodwill bin at the local grocery store  basically sloughing away the material things that seem to accumulate so easily in my life, packrat that I am. But for some reason when I get to my Army duffel bags I dont leave them closed. I undo their snap-links, grab each green bag with my name and unit numbers still stenciled on them, and flip them upside down to dump everything out onto the concrete floor.

title: A Taxi Ride to Remember
description: Until recently, my craziest taxi ride occurred a few years ago in Newark, N.J. That escapade involved a shared taxi, a rear window being kicked out, me diving into the passenger footwell, and the cabbie attempting to run over the guy whod just skipped paying fare. It turns out that I had to go to Hockenheim, Germany, to top this wild tale.

title: F. Thompson on Fox
description: While Fred Thompson, the former senator from Tennessee, wasnt among the Republican candidates on stage at the G.O.P. debate, he appeared just afterward on Fox News Channels Hannity & Colmes.

title: Ready for the N.B.A. Throne, but Not Like Mike
description: The National Basketball Association has been in search of a transcendent star with staying power since Michael Jordan retired in 1998; television viewership of the finals is down 55 percent since that year. The league may have found its savior in LeBron James, who can sometimes score like Jordan or Kobe Bryant but who can also pass like Magic Johnson.

title: NBC Universal Signs Head of Studio to a Five-Year Agreement
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5  A week after a messy shake-up of the management of its television unit, NBC Universal has signed Ron Meyer, the president and chief operating officer of Universal Studios, to a new five-year contract. He will oversee movie production, theme parks and studio operations through at least 2012, the company said.

title: Looking Beyond L. L. Bean
description: FREEPORT, Me.  Downtown Freeport hardly looks like a place that needs to reinvent itself. Perhaps best known as the home of L. L. Beans three large retail outposts, it also offers luxury names like Burberry, Cole Haan and Polo Ralph Lauren and dozens of well-appointed outlets.

title: Red Hook Vendors Pressed to Get New Permit
description: PUPUSAS, sunburns, soccer: could this be the last summer to get them all at the same place?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft and Apple to develop their next operating systems misspelled the surname of a technology executive who commented on the migration of computer functions to the Web. He is Nova Spivack, not Spivak.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Bill France Jr., the former president of Nascar, rendered incorrectly the name of the organization. It is the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, not the National Association of Stock Car Racing.

title: Can He Unleash the Force?
description: In mythic tales from Superman to Star Wars to Spider-Man, there comes a moment when the young superhero has to learn to harness his powers. Thats the challenge Barack Obama faces now.

title: Glavine Does His Part, but the Mets Dont Help Him Out
description: If Tom Glavine were granted three wishes, he might consider bypassing the rigmarole of the first two and get right down to business. He would like to have won his 300th career game three weeks ago  as soon as possible, in other words  so that life can return to normal.

title: Wall Collapses on Staten Island in Concrete Avalanche
description: A 50-foot-high retaining wall behind a large hilltop house owned by a high-profile Staten Island lawyer collapsed late Monday night, unleashing an avalanche of concrete blocks weighing hundreds of pounds each into the yards of smaller homes below.

title: South Korea: Hanwhas Chairman Indicted
description: South Korean prosecutors indicted Kim Seung Yun, the chairman of an industrial company, the Hanwha Group, on six charges in connection with what the authorities say was a revenge attack on employees of a bar in Seoul.
