Prosecutors charged Mr. Kim and a bodyguard, both arrested on May 11, with confinement and causing bodily harm with a weapon, the Seoul Central District Prosecutors Office said. A Hanwha Group spokesman, Ju Cheol Beom, declined to comment.

title: What You Get for... $4 Million
description: Oakville, Calif.

title: Protestors Keep Tensions High at Summit
description: KHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 6  They lurked in the woods, fifty strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal given by one of their number, they sprang forward and threw their debris across a road here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a screeching halt.

title: Afghanistan Exhibition Provokes Questions
description: The National Geographic Society has struck a $1 million deal with the Afghan government to bring a rare cache of gold artifacts to the United States in a traveling exhibition. But some cultural experts who have followed the negotiations are questioning whether Afghanistan is being properly compensated.

title: Riders of the World, Unite! Skateboarding Sprouts as Team Sport
description: After months of wooing sponsors, and drafting bylaws and articles of incorporation, all Jeff Stern needed to create the first high school skateboard league was teenage skaters to get onboard and compete.

title: Dining Briefs
description: REVISITS

title: Long-Drawn-Out and Ready to Eat: Fresh Pastas on Essex Street
description: Vadim Ponorovsky, the owner of Paradou, a bistro in the meatpacking district, and Paradou March, a crepe and sandwich counter in the Essex Street Market, has opened Casa Tua in the market, specializing in freshly made ravioli and other pastas, and sauces. David Shemesh, the chef, may encourage you to try his beet and goat cheese ravioli  hes making it at right  or his seven-herb fettuccine. And in a spirit of adventure, you might consider his earthy sumac fettuccine, flavored Middle Eastern style, and toss it with olives, olive oil, lemon zest and chilies. Pasta with sauce at cafe tables is $8 to $10, from 11:30 a.m. until the market closes (at 6 p.m. Monday to Wednesday, and 7 p.m. Thursday to Saturday). Pasta for two, to take home, is $6.50 to $14, and sauces are $3.50: 120 Essex Street (Delancey Street), (212) 477-4177.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan.

title: Seventeen Hits and a Sigh of Relief for the Yankees
description: CHICAGO, June 5  To Johnny Damon, explaining the Yankees troubles has been simple. When only three everyday players are hitting the way they should, he has said, that leaves six others dragging down the team.

title: Mob Case Defendant Is Shot in Brooklyn
description: A reputed mobster associated with the Gambino crime family was shot at least three times while sitting in his car on a Brooklyn street yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Gehry to Design Battery Park Playground
description: Frank Gehry, the architect known for his buildings adorned with undulating banners of titanium, is set make his first foray into the world of monkey bars and swing sets with a new playground at Battery Park, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today.

title: Stock Market Falters as Bond Yields Rise
description: The stock market posted its first decline in a week after bond yields surged to a nine-month high amid signs that the economy might be gaining momentum.

title: Coal-to-Liquid Fuels (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet and Sour Sit Down to Dessert
description: RHUBARB is an alarmingly sour vegetable passed off as a fruit, but requiring a huge mound of sugar to effect the transformation.

title: Getting Into College, Strumming His Own Tune
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa.

title: Iraqs Brain Drain (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eternal Vaudeville of the Spiritual Mind
description: God is in the curriculum in the lively lecture hall that has been made of the New York Theater Workshop, where Rinde Eckerts Horizon opened last night. But even the fiercest secularist should find pleasure in this engaging performance piece, which is set in the seminary-without-walls of one mans mind.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chefs on the Move

title: American Trade Specialist Resigns
description: Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, announced his resignation yesterday. Mr. Lavin plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post. He is joining the Washington office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company. He led negotiations for the United States at the World Trade Organization over how to rework trade laws.

title: Recipe: Zucchini Carpaccio With Avocado
description: Adapted from Vegetable Harvest (Morrow, 2007)

title: From Turkey Waste, a New Fuel and a New Fight
description: BENSON, Minn.  For anyone curious about what thousands of tons of turkey litter looks like, piled high into an indoor olfactory-assaulting mountain of manure, this old railroad stop on the extreme edge of alternative energy production is the place to be.

title: Albany: Nominees for SUNY Board
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer yesterday announced three nominees to fill coming vacancies on the State University of New York board. Besides Carl T. Hayden, whom Mr. Spitzer had identified as his choice as SUNYs chairman, the governor yesterday named H. Carl McCall, a former state comptroller and a former president of New York Citys Board of Education, and Linda S. Sanford, a senior vice president at I.B.M. The governor appoints 15 of SUNYs 16 board members, subject to State Senate approval. The other seat is held by a student.

title: Clinton Backs Change to Marriage Law
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has told a gay rights organization that she supports the repeal of one provision of the federal Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law signed by her husband that says states and the federal government do not have to recognize gay marriages and unions from other states. On the questionnaire for the Human Rights Campaign, Mrs. Clinton said she opposed the part of the law that would prohibit the federal government from recognizing same-sex relationships. Her advisers said that she continued to oppose gay marriage. Her response on the questionnaire puts her in line with her rivals for her partys nomination.

title: Keeping a Watch on Winter
description: Yesterday brought an end to another public comment period on another winter use plan for Yellowstone National Park, a plan that would raise the number of snowmobiles allowed into the park from 250 to 720 per day. The National Park Service has now spent some $10 million over the past decade examining over and over again the effects of snowmobiles on Yellowstone. The scientific results have been consistent. The best alternative, environmentally speaking, is to do away with snowmobiles altogether. There have also been more than 700,000 public comments on this question. The public has been consistent, too  consistently against snowmobiles.

title: Transplant Team Dies in Jet Crash; Mechanical Problems Suspected
description: DETROIT, June 5  What was meant to be a mission to save the life of a man in desperate need of a lung transplant ended instead on Monday in the deaths of four members of a medical team and two pilots of a plane that crashed while racing to fly the organs from Milwaukee to Michigan.

title: Fed Chief Dims Hopes for a Rate Cut
description: The stock market stumbled yesterday as Wall Street seemed to grasp that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates.

title: A Vestige of British Rule Is About to Vanish, Unmourned
description: HONG KONG, June 5  Queens Pier is a simple building, a few short columns and a low roof next to Hong Kongs harbor, designed and built after World War II for official events like the arrival and departure of colonial governors.

title: The Expanding Meatball Universe, From Mamas Table to Esca
description: IF youve ever suspected that meatballs were a dead end for a restaurants leftovers, you no longer have reason to fear. These days, chefs are free associating with well-sourced ingredients, clever substitutions and dazzling techniques. Others are refining more authentic variations that highlight the meatballs global appeal (see also: kofte, nem nuong, frikadell, kottbuller, albndigas, keftedes, tsukune).

title: New AIDS Cases in Africa Outpace Treatment Gains
description: BEIRA, Mozambique  Four years ago, the region surrounding this somnolent seaport, Mozambiques second largest city, offered hardly any AIDS-prevention advice to pregnant women. Today, two dozen health clinics give mothers-to-be H.I.V. counseling, tests and medicine to protect their newborns from catching the virus.

title: Panel Asks Official About Politics in Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  A senior Justice Department official acknowledged to Senate investigators Tuesday that he once bragged about his success in hiring conservative Republican lawyers onto his staff that handled civil rights cases.

title: Case of the Deadbeat Dad Is Closed but Unsolved
description: As the official letter began with the inspiring words, You are hereby summoned, Mike Shaieb took a minute to digest the contents. Well, several minutes.

title: Recipe: Creamy Lemon-Chive Dressing
description: Adapted from Vegetable Harvest (Morrow, 2007)

title: Automakers Push to Head Off Tighter Fuel Standards
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Automobile executives are making progress in their resistance to tougher fuel economy requirements, an issue that sharply pits powerful Congressional Democrats from Michigan against party leaders who want to pass energy legislation by the end of this month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Return of Tap Water

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,476 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Mickelson Will Rest His Injured Wrist
description: Phil Mickelson has decided to skip the St. Jude Championship in Memphis this week as he tries to recuperate from an injured left wrist in time for the United States Open, which begins June 14 at Oakmont Country Club near Pittsburgh.

title: Major Claims Are Settled in 2005 Collapse
description: Shortly after 3 p.m., on May 12, 2005, a 150-foot section of a nearly century-old retaining wall high above the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan gave way in a thundering and frightening avalanche.

title: Ready for N.B.A. Throne, but Not Like Mike
description: CLEVELAND, June 5  LeBron James was still a teenager when he was cast as a basketball messiah in television commercials and labeled The Chosen One on magazine covers. Now at the age of 22, James may soon fulfill all of the hyperbolic promise  if the viewing public can adapt to a new kind of superstar.

title: Cyclone Nears Iran and Oman
description: Oman and Iran girded for heavy flooding and winds today as the strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea began to hit coastlines that have little experience with such powerful storms.

title: The Best of the Bad Cops Keeps Walking a Hard Line
description: When Michael Chikliss agent first read the script for The Shield in 2001, he advised the actor not to audition. If Mr. Chiklis wanted the lead role in the cops-and-gangs drama  and he did  he shouldnt have to abase himself with a tryout, his agent argued. Mr. Chiklis, after all, had already starred in The Commish on ABC and Daddio on NBC. He was almost a household name.

title: Reader Responses
description: Here are excerpts from reader responses to my June 6 column on health care:

title: To the Envelope Pushers, Cheers!
description: THEY go by many names. Most familiarly and perhaps most unkindly, theyre called wine geeks. Theyre also known as zealots, extremists and even the wine counterculture.

title: A Translucent and Radiant Partner With the Past
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 31  Working on theoretical proposals and the occasional house commission, Steven Holl emerged as a rare, original talent in the 1980s. The strength of his vision was rooted in a desire to reconnect architecture to the physical world  the shifting nature of light, the reflective surfaces of water, the texture of materials  and an atavistic love of craft.

title: Charges Filed Against 6 Men in Plot to Attack Base
description: A federal grand jury in New Jersey has charged five men in a plot to kill American soldiers at the Fort Dix military base, and charged a sixth with illegally helping some of the others to obtain weapons, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Charles Evans, 81, a Founder of Fashion Line, Dies
description: Charles Evans, a founder of the fashion house Evan-Picone and who was also executive producer of the film Tootsie, died Saturday in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Gitmo: A National Disgrace
description: Ever since President Bush rammed the Military Commissions Act of 2006 through Congress to lend a pretense of legality to his detention camp at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, we have urged Congress to amend the law to restore basic human rights and judicial process. Rulings by military judges this week suggest that the special detention system is so fundamentally corrupt that the only solution is to tear it down and start again.

title: Service Industries Expansion Picked Up Pace Last Month
description: Service industry expansion unexpectedly accelerated last month to the highest level in more than a year, a sign the economy is strengthening.

title: Filly Rags to Riches Will Take on the Boys at Belmont
description: What had been shaping up as a ho-hum Belmont Stakes received some star power yesterday when the filly Rags to Riches was confirmed as a starter for the 139th running of the race Saturday.

title: Abbas Pulls Out of  Talks With Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 6  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has pulled out of planned talks this week with Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, after the two sides could not agree on an agenda.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about C. C. Myers, a contractor whose company finished repairs well ahead of deadline for a highway ramp that linked parts of the East Bay to San Francisco, incorrectly described the type of cowboy boots he favors. They are ostrich, not peacock.

title: Talking the Dream, Growing the Brand
description: ATLANTA  What looks from the outside like roughly 70,000 square feet of warehouse space near the King Center is the home of Tyler Perry Studios, where Mr. Perry is living his dream of running a media empire. On this day in late May, the dream meant talking and talking, so he really wanted something for his chapped lips.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on May 3 about an I.B.M. advance in chip-making referred imprecisely to recent developments in the field. I.B.M. and Intel  not Intel alone  announced in January that they would take advantage of a new insulating material for their chips. (It is I.B.M.s more recent work, involving a manufacturing process that creates insulating vacuum channels in chips, that sets it apart from Intels approach.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 4; this correction was delayed for research.

title: Chastising Putin, Bush Says Russia Derails Reform
description: PRAGUE, June 5  President Bush delivered a two-pronged message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday, two days before their scheduled meeting in Germany, chiding Mr. Putin for derailing democratic reforms while assuring the Russian leader that he had nothing to fear from a missile defense system in Europe.

title: Libya: Equity Firm Buys Stake in Oil Refiner
description: The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said. Tamoil, based in Switzerland and owned by the Libyan government under the name Oilinvest B.V., owns three refineries  in Germany, Italy and Switzerland  and 2,500 gas stations in Italy.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Putin Honors Solzhenitsyn

title: Manhattan: Man Sought in Hotel Robberies
description: The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who recently robbed guests at two hotels in Manhattan. In the first robbery, on April 13 at the Millenium Hilton downtown, the man followed a couple and a 9-year-old girl to their room, held them at gunpoint, then bound and robbed them of cash, jewelry and electronics, the police said. In the second robbery, on Thursday night at the Roosevelt Hotel on East 45th Street, the man forced himself into a womans room as she was entering, assaulted her and took her handbag, the police said. The robber is described as a white man, about 5 foot 7 and about 25 years old, with a stocky build, wearing a blue baseball cap and a black pea coat. Anyone with information should call 1-800-577-TIPS, the police said.

title: Manhattan: Economic Benefits of Same-Sex Marriage
description: Legalizing gay marriage would bring New York City $142 million in economic benefits over the first three years, according to an economic analysis released yesterday by William C. Thompson, the comptroller. Mr. Thompson, a likely candidate for mayor in 2009, wrote in the report that the benefits would come mainly from increased spending of residents and visitors on their weddings, including items like hotel stays.

title: Erratic Week for China Stocks as Policies Seem to Shift
description: HONG KONG, June 5  The Chinese government is learning the dangers of intervening in stock markets, as policy shifts by the government and even speculation of policy shifts have led to sharp swings in share prices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets over the last week.

title: Charles Maynes, 68, Statesman, Is Dead
description: Charles William Maynes, a longtime editor of Foreign Policy magazine who was also a former assistant secretary of state, died on Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 68.

title: U.S. Set to Defend Gold Cup
description: Before the United States played Guatemala in a friendly match in March, the North Americans were flying high. They had won three straight games under their new coach Bob Bradley, including a 2-0 victory over archrivals Mexico and a masterful 3-1 dismantling of World Cup darlings Ecuador. But the Guatemalans werent intimidated. Playing a defensive style, they completely stymied the U.S. attack, and held the superpower to a scoreless draw.

title: Senate Rejects Immigration Stricture
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The proposed immigration-overhaul bill survived a crucial test this afternoon as the Senate rejected a measure that would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to eventually achieve legal status. By a vote of 51 to 46, the senators defeated a proposal to bar legal status for aliens who disobey deportation orders or who engage in identity fraud. The proposal was made in the form of an amendment, offered by Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, to an overall immigration bill that is being debated.

title: Arrest of 30 Leads Youths to Organize in Brooklyn
description: The hue and cry over the arrests of about 30 students on the way to a friends wake in Bushwick, Brooklyn, last month has spurred a growing youth movement against racial profiling.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 5, 2007

title: Manhattan: Man Charged With Posing as a Lawyer
description: A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer at a major New York law firm for four years  even though, prosecutors said, he had never gone to law school  pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to charges of impersonating a lawyer and stealing at least $284,350 in salary from his firm. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, was promoted from paralegal to lawyer at the firm, Anderson Kill & Olick, in 2002, and was earning $155,000 plus bonuses when he was fired in October 2006, prosecutors said. His lawyer, Joseph R. Conway, said Mr. Valery, who is now unemployed, faced related charges in Connecticut and expected to have charges brought against him in Brooklyn.

title: Libby Given 30 Months for Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bushs foreign policy, was sentenced Tuesday to 30 months in prison for lying during a C.I.A. leak investigation that became part of a fierce debate over the war in Iraq.

title: G.M. Chief Tells Shareholders to Take Long View
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 5  The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, faced more than two hours of criticism from shareholders at the annual meeting here Tuesday, but he countered that the company had made major progress in turning around its fortunes last year. And he urged patience for the long term.

title: Interrogation Abuses (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: On Avandia, a Niche Strategy Now Under Stress
description: Could a widely praised approach to drug marketing now be at risk of backfiring? That is a question confronting GlaxoSmithKline and its diabetes treatment Avandia, which is now clouded by concerns over the drugs safety.

title: Stocks Drop on Fed Comment on Interest Rates
description: The stock market stumbled today as Wall Street seemed to grasp that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates.

title: Red Bulls Import a Little Excellence
description: Gone are the shoulder-length hair and the wide headband, and the disdain for the generally miserable weather of the English midlands.

title: Expletive Policy Deleted
description: At the Billboard Music Awards in 2002, Cher had a salty rejoinder to critics who have been telling me Im on the way out every year. At the same event in 2003, Nicole Richie had some earthy reflections on the difficulties of cleaning a Prada purse. Its hard to believe these comments threaten the nations well-being, but the Federal Communications Commission found them indecent and profane. That threatened Fox Broadcasting, which televised the awards show, with major fines. This week, in a very welcome decision, a federal appeals court overturned the F.C.C.s indecency policy.

title: The Constant Comfort of an Old Friend
description: THERE are restaurants with more shimmer, and there are certainly restaurants with more spark. There are restaurants that take bigger chances and stake bolder claims to your attention.

title: Democrats Hope to Expand Rights at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  A day after two military judges ruled against the Bush administrations system for trying terrorism detainees, Democrats seized on the rulings on Tuesday as evidence that Congress should restore the right of those held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to challenge their detentions.

title: Farnsworth Sees No Need to Clear the Air With Clemens
description: CHICAGO, June 5  Kyle Farnsworth first met Roger Clemens at one of the lowest points of his career. Farnsworth, then the closer for the Atlanta Braves, had blown the save in the final game of a division series against Clemenss Houston Astros in 2005.

title: Is U.S. Safer Since 9/11? Clinton and Rivals Spar
description: The Bush administrations efforts to thwart terrorism at home have created a fissure among the three leading Democratic presidential candidates, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton coming under attack for saying that America is safer now than before 9/11  contrary to a popular line of argument among some Democratic officials.

title: Manhattan: Hotelier Buys 1951 House
description: The hotelier Andr Balazs bought Maison Tropicale, a small 1951 aluminum-paneled house by the French designer Jean Prouv, for $4.97 million yesterday, Christies auction house said. Christies had estimated that the house would go for $4 million to $6 million. (The final price includes Christies commission: 20 percent of the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest.) The house had been on view since mid-May in Long Island City. Prouv designed it as a prototype for prefabricated homes for French colonial officials stationed in Africa. The seller, Eric Touchaleaume, a French antiques dealer, has said he plans to use the proceeds to finance a Prouv museum that will travel in another Maison Tropicale.

title: Victory Is in View for Team New Zealand
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 5  Emirates Team New Zealand was in front for good again Tuesday, and as usual in this one-sided Louis Vuitton Cup finals, which the Kiwis now lead, 4-0, the crew member with the best view was Adam Beashel.

title: Sea Lions Hit by High Levels of Acid Poison in California
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5  A distressed, possibly pregnant sea lion was wheeled recently into the Marine Mammal Care Center here, just as two other lions were herded into cages in preparation for their return to the ocean.

title: Recipe: Rhubarb Big Crumb Coffeecake
description: Time: 1 1/2 hours, plus cooling

title: Asbury Park: Sewage Spill Closes Beaches
description: About two miles of beaches, from Deal south to Bradley Beach, were closed yesterday after a pipe broke at the Asbury Park sewage treatment plant, Monmouth County officials said. Beaches in Allenhurst, Loch Arbour, Asbury Park and Ocean Grove were also closed. The pipe, which has since been repaired, released about half a million gallons of partly treated sewage into the Atlantic Ocean between 3:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m. yesterday, said William Simmons, the countys environmental health coordinator. Results from water quality tests, expected this afternoon, will determine whether the beaches can reopen. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Steps on the Road to Energy Reform (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: On Kentuckys Bourbon Trail
description: GRADUALLY the hills and pastures of Tennessee, which for hours had rolled on like a sinuous green wave, came to an end. The stands of hilltop trees, once so bulbous and neat, like broccoli tops, grew wilder and chaotic. And instead of flowing up, over and around the swells in the earth, U.S. Route 31E now cut right through them, exposing the white limestone below the topsoil. It was the only Welcome to Kentucky sign I needed.

title: Cuomo Broadens Student Loan Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans exposed secret ties between universities and lenders, said today that he was broadening his investigation to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans and whether they violated civil rights statutes.

title: Jail Time for Scooter Libby
description: The jail sentence and fine imposed on Scooter Libby, the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, are an appropriate  indeed necessary  punishment for his repeated lies to a grand jury and to F.B.I. agents investigating a possible smear campaign orchestrated by the White House. Although Mr. Libby plans to appeal, as he has every legal right to, the judge ought to send him to jail now as a lesson that such efforts to frustrate justice will not be tolerated.

title: Gates Urges Stronger U.S. Ties With Europe
description: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France, June 6  Beside a churning sea and an ocean of white marble crosses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said today that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance they died defending.

title: F.T.C. to Sue in Bid to Halt Food Merger
description: Wild Oats Markets may not become part of the natural foods empire of Whole Foods Market, after all.

title: A Middle-Class Hamptons Is Vacated on Towns Orders
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 4  Up and down a sandy road here, hard to find even with a map, residents were emptying their weekend homes as fast as they could on Friday to beat the tide. Cars have been scarce on this scruffy peninsula since the bridge to the mainland burned in 1996. But suddenly, moving trucks, having arrived by boat, were as plentiful as rose hip bushes.

title: Recipe: Couscous Salad With Spinach
description: Adapted from Vegetable Harvest (Morrow, 2007)

title: Baghdad Gallery Owner Hopes Culture Can Dispel Hate
description: BAGHDAD, June 1  He may be the last hopeful man in Iraq.

title: Unleashing the Dogs That Abhor
description: The N.F.L. scene has become the puppy mill for pit-bull lore.

title: Pakistan Questions 2 in Daniel Pearl Killing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 5  Pakistani officials said they were investigating two people arrested Monday in Kashmor, a remote town in the southern province of Sindh, for any links to the killing of the American journalist Daniel Pearl in 2002.

title: What a Mess
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank

title: To Keep Its Parakeets Wild, San Francisco Bans Handouts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5  In what may be a legislative first for San Francisco, the citys Board of Supervisors on Tuesday banned the feeding of a tourist attraction.

title: Diabetes Drug Still Has Heart Risks, Doctors Warn
description: A medical study intended to demonstrate the heart safety of a well-known diabetes treatment seems, instead, to have added to the controversy over the drug.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about William F. Whitman Jr., a horticulturist and collector of rare fruit, referred incorrectly to an underwater camera he built with his brother Dudley earlier in his career. It was a film camera, not a video camera.

title: The Partition That Divided a City and a Civilization
description: After the Berlin Wall came down in 1989, the government of the soon-to-be-former German Democratic Republic pulled off a breathtakingly cynical stunt. It auctioned the thing off, one piece at a time. Adding a special piquancy to the event, at the Hotel Parc Pallas in Monte Carlo, was the official responsible for transporting the wall from Germany.

title: D. Nelson Adams, 97, Tax Law Specialist, Dies
description: D. Nelson Adams, a former managing partner of Davis Polk & Wardwell, one of the nations most prominent law firms, died on Thursday at his home in Barneveld, N.Y. He was 97 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Suicide Attack Near Falluja Kills 18 in Commercial Area
description: BAGHDAD, June 5  Eighteen people were killed south of Falluja on Tuesday when a suicide bomber driving a truck packed with explosives plowed into a busy commercial district, the local Iraqi police said. Fifteen others were wounded.

title: Vigorous and Rebellious, a Master Composer in His Youth
description: Summer at Mannes College the New School for Music is a seamless succession of mini-festivals and institutes that cover everything from music theory and analysis to keyboard virtuosity, contemporary music and the guitar and vocal repertory. The main purpose is to instruct the conservatorys students, but the programs also give the school a public presence by way of open master classes, lectures, panel discussions and performances. The Mannes Beethoven Institute, which began its weeklong run on Sunday, is now in its seventh year and has been directed from the start by the pianist Thomas Sauer.

title: Ethics Panel to Investigate Congressman on Conduct
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  Under pressure from Republicans, the House ethics committee announced Tuesday it would open an inquiry into the conduct of Representative William J. Jefferson, who relinquished his sole committee assignment in the wake of his indictment on corruption charges.

title: Vignettes That Wind Lusciously in and Out of the Music
description: Olu Dara and Dianne McIntyre seldom perform together anymore, and that is a great pity. Their sensibilities fit hand in glove; their complementary sly humor and sweetness create vignettes of everyday people who somehow manage to rise above simply getting along in life.

title: A Hands-On Hotel Owner Who Values Independence
description: CHICAGO  Arriving at the InterContinental Hotel on North Michigan Avenue on a warm afternoon, Laurence S. Geller notices that the doorman, Hussain al-Mosawy, is wearing a new addition to his summer uniform: a white safari hat.

title: The Dog Who Breathed a New Business
description: WHO would have thought that a middle-age couple who held government jobs and were a tad unsure what an entrepreneur was would make a small fortune from their beloved dogs bad breath?

title: In Paris, Bringing Vegetables Out to Play
description: ON Sunday mornings, theres an organic market on Boulevard Raspail in Paris where everything screams Eat me.

title: Radio Time to Join List of eBay Items Up for Auction
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5  The auction giant eBay said it would begin selling radio airtime to advertisers starting Wednesday, expanding into a business that Google entered last year

title: The Six-Day War, Plus 40 Years (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Symbolism Takes a Back Seat to the Worlds Abrasive Realities
description: Within the first few minutes of her show at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, Keren Ann charted a complex constellation of feelings: wistfulness, disdain, self-pity, indignation, whimsy. She was singing a breakup song, naturally  In Your Back, from her self-titled fifth album  but making it sound more momentous than most.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a private equity investment in Palm Inc. gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a research analyst at Gartner, who discussed the market for cellphones and other hand-held devices. He is Todd Kort, not Cort.

title: Serena Williams Falters and Henin Capitalizes
description: PARIS, June 5  The most anticipated and potentially heated match at the French Open so far  Serena Williams against Justine Henin  fizzled nearly from the start Tuesday.

title: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
description: The Bush administration wants to reform the nations patent system by requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the director of the governments patent office.

title: Health Care as if Costs Didnt Matter
description: In a saner world, the place where you live wouldnt have much effect on how doctors treated your back problems. In our world, it can make all the difference.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column on Friday, about Fred D. Thompson, the former senator and actor on Law & Order, who has taken steps to run for president, misstated the year of the Senate Watergate hearings, when he was named minority counsel for the committee investigating the scandal. It was 1973, not 1974.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Saturday about high-powered public policy debates held by Robert Rosenkranz, a New York investor and philanthropist, used an outdated title in some copies for one participant, Bob Barr. He is now a consultant on public policy; he is no longer a United States representative.

title: A Romanian Town Slouches Toward Revolution and Beyond
description: At the beginning of The 18th Brumaire of Louis Napoleon, Karl Marx famously observes that history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. He forgot to add that the commemoration of history can raise farce to a whole new level of absurdity. This, at any rate, is among the insights offered by the Romanian director Corneliu Porumboius acutely funny first feature, 12:08 East of Bucharest.

title: Albany: Crime Dropped Statewide Last Year
description: State officials yesterday released preliminary crime statistics for 2006, reporting a modest decrease in the crime rate over 2005. Violent crime decreased by 4.6 percent in New York City and 2.3 percent in the rest of the state; nationwide, according to federal statistics released this week, the rate of violent crime increased slightly. There were roughly 476,000 reported crimes in the state last year, the lowest volume since statewide reporting began nearly 40 years ago, officials said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A timeline in some copies on Sunday about the events leading up to charges against four men in what the authorities said was a plot to blow up terminals and fuel lines at Kennedy International Airport misspelled the given name of one suspect in some copies. He is Russell Defreitas, not Russel.

title: Recipe: Almond and Buttermilk Sorbet
description: Adapted fromVegetable Harvest (Morrow, 2007)

title: Proposal for New Jail Rules Draws Fire From Inmate Advocates
description: The board that oversees the citys Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates  the most significant changes since 1978  following an outcry by the City Bar Association, the Legal Aid Society and other groups that have called the changes draconian and inhumane.

title: Martnez Is Taking Awhile to Find His Comfort Zone
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., June 5  In an obscure warm-up area at the Mets minor league camp Tuesday, Pedro Martnez pitched off a mound for the first time in more than eight months. He came away feeling he had passed a basic first test toward rebuilding his career.

title: Nets and Knicks Show Togetherness in Working Out Draft Prospects
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 5  There is nothing unusual about the Knicks working out draft prospects at this time of year. There is nothing unusual about the Nets doing the same. But the Knicks and Nets working out their players together? Now thats unheard of. Until now.

title: Craig Thomas, 74, G.O.P Senator From Wyoming, Dies
description: Senator Craig Thomas, a Wyoming Republican who combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in his home state and Washington, died Monday evening in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 and had homes in Casper, Wyo., and Arlington, Va.

title: Canada: Lowes Is Planning to Open Six Stores
description: The Lowes Companies, the home-improvement retailer, will open up to six stores in Canada by the end of January 2008. At least four stores will be in southwestern Ontario, including Toronto, said Doug Robinson, Lowes president of Canadian operations.

title: New Study Finds Gains Since No Child Left Behind
description: Student achievement has increased and test score gaps between white students and black and Hispanic students have narrowed in many states since President Bush signed the No Child Left Behind law in 2002, according to a new survey of state scores in reading and math.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page picture caption on Thursday and a related article in sports about Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys who participated in a health study of retired athletes, misstated part of the name of the shrine in Ohio that honors football greats like him. It is the Pro Football Hall of Fame, not the National Football Leagues Hall of Fame.

title: Manhattan: Special Trains Planned for Football Games
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it planned to run special trains from the Metro-North Railroads New Haven line to Secaucus, N.J., for Giants and Jets football games at the Meadowlands, beginning in the second half of 2009. The trains would switch in New Rochelle from Metro-North tracks to Amtrak tracks and then run through Pennsylvania Station to New Jersey. Riders could take a shuttle train from Secaucus to the Meadowlands. The pilot program would also make it possible for subway or bus riders or riders on other commuter railroads to buy a single ticket allowing them to transfer at Penn Station to the Metro-North football trains or to New Jersey Transit trains bound for the Secaucus-Meadowlands shuttle.

title: Vioxx Damage Award
description: A judge who threw out a $51 million damage award against Merck last year over its Vioxx painkiller reversed himself and awarded $1.6 million to the plaintiff, a former F.B.I. agent who blamed the drug for his heart attack.

title: Dinner at the Foodies: Purslane and Anxiety
description: RICHARD FAULK still recalls, with a twinge of shame, the day he and his girlfriend, Jeanine Villalobos, served store-bought tortillas to guests.

title: South Africa: Health Minister Snubs Aids Meeting
description: The health minister, long known for questioning the scientific tenets of the AIDS epidemic, has turned down an invitation to address the nations third annual conference on the disease because she was not given a conspicuous spot on the conference agenda, Vice President Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka said. The minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, was excluded from opening ceremonies at the conference, in Durban, but had been scheduled to speak today at a gathering of AIDS experts and activists. Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka, who did speak at the opening session, criticized the events organizers for relegating Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang to a lesser spot on the program. The health ministers speech was to mark her return to public life after a long illness culminating early this year in a liver transplant.

title: Former Brooklyn Officials Surrender for Prison Terms
description: One man helped lead the State Assembly and controlled the Brooklyn Democratic Party, the largest such organization east of Chicago. The other presided over matrimonial cases in the borough, deciding hundreds of child custody or family finance disputes. Both left court in handcuffs yesterday to begin serving prison sentences for corruption.

title: Home Depot Meeting (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: China: Optimism on Pollution
description: China has reached a turning point in reversing its runaway pollution problems and expects to see reductions in air and water pollution in the coming months, according to Zhang Lijun, a top official with the State Environmental Protection Administration. Mr. Zhang, left, used a news conference to predict that emissions of sulfur dioxide in the air and levels of water pollution measured by a process known as chemical oxygen demand would fall this year. Cutting those areas of pollution are the main indicators in Chinas nationwide plan for a 10 percent reduction in pollution by 2010. Last year, China failed to meet its goal of two percent reductions in each category and instead registered small increases. But Mr. Zhang said improvements had become evident after government programs to install pollution technology on coal-fired power plants, as well as the installation of new wastewater treatment equipment. He acknowledged that other pollutants, including ammonia, continued to rise. And greenhouse gas emissions like carbon dioxide are increasing rapidly.

title: Rifts on Russia and Climate Seen at G-8 Summit
description: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 6  On the eve of a meeting of the leaders of the Group of 8 wealthy industrial nations, the United States remained deeply at odds with many of its international partners on climate change, and work still needed to be done before an agreement could be reached on cutting greenhouse gas emissions, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said today.

title: A Routine Traffic Stop Leads to Gunshots and Questions
description: CLIFTON, N.J., June 5  John Kubasta has spent much of his life defying the notion that being permanently disabled means being permanently dependent on others.

title: Traditional Korean Marriage Meets Match on the Internet
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 5  Sitting in his office crammed with files and boxes, Lee Woong-jin, a 42-year-old entrepreneur, talks enthusiastically about his latest moneymaking plan: merging the age-old Korean matchmaking tradition with the vibrant South Korean Internet culture.

title: Strong Cyclone Heading for Southern Iran
description: The strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea churned up the coast of Oman today and was on track to hit land in southern Iran, sending high winds and waves through a region that is used for oil exports and civilian and military shipping traffic.

title: Run, Gobble, Gobble, Run: Vying for Pac-Man Acclaim
description: Wakka wakka wakka.

title: Steven Gilliard Jr., 42, Dies; Founder of Liberal Political Blog
description: Steven Gilliard Jr., a political journalist who found his calling as a combative and influential blogger on the left, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 42.

title: Why Wait for the G-8?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Guide to Americas Cheese Trail
description: A FEW years ago, I spent a week traveling the byways of New England in search of the best cheesemakers. As the rest of the world hurries on, remote farms are quietly turning milk into everything from charming little goat pyramids to big bold wheels of aged cows milk cheese. Down many dirt roads there was marvelous cheese to taste from the animals grazing in the nearby fields.

title: Restitution Deal Made
description: A former sales chief at CA Inc., the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the companys quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

title: HBO Moves to Fill Executive Void
description: HBO announced a new lineup of four top corporate officers yesterday to succeed Chris Albrecht, the chief executive who resigned last month. The group will be led by Bill Nelson as the chairman and chief executive.

title: Recipe: Veal and Ricotta Meatballs
description: Adapted from Marco Canora

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A map of Central Asia with an article on Saturday about the construction of a bridge linking Tajikistan and Afghanistan misidentified the country shown in the lower left. It is Iran, not Azerbaijan. (Go to Article)

title: Recipe: Tuna Meatballs
description: Adapted from The Young Man and the Sea, by David Pasternack and Ed Levine (Artisan, 2007)

title: Straphangers Warning: Fares May Have to Rise
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have to raise revenues significantly to stave off looming deficits in the next several years, increasing pressure on the authority to increase transit fares and bridge and tunnel tolls, according to a study by the citys Independent Budget Office.

title: A Mastery in Swing Time That Endures for All Time
description: There was a time in American music when Ella Fitzgerald seemed to be an eternal constant, an irresistible force and immovable object rolled into one mighty voice. At once girlish, wise and all-forgiving, Fitzgeralds singing transcended age, race, sex and genre.

title: New Jersey Court Voids Death Penalty Conviction
description: TRENTON, June 5  The New Jersey Supreme Court on Tuesday vacated the murder conviction and death sentence of a Pennsylvania man imprisoned since 1994. The court ruled that the trial judge and two lawyers who represented the man had failed to pursue the potential bias of a juror.

title: To an Equine Athlete Dying Young
description: Caution: Tears will flow from watching Barbaro, the HBO Sports documentary that tells the life story of a horse Hemingway would have loved, one who exhibited grace under great pressure. Like the other innocent animals we love, horses trust us, live alongside us, honoring our many commands, the narrator, Liev Schreiber, says. And when we ask them to  they run.

title: Donald Johanos, 79, a Conductor of Symphony Orchestras, Is Dead
description: Donald Johanos, a former music director of the Dallas and Honolulu Symphonies and a prominent member of the generation of American conductors who emerged after World War II, died in Naples, Fla., on May 29. He was 79.

title: Mexican Courts Media Ruling Shows Support for Competition
description: MEXICO CITY, June 5  In a defeat for Mexicos television duopoly, the Supreme Court struck down crucial provisions of a media law on Tuesday, sending a clear message in favor of greater economic competition.

title: Newark: County Must Change Jail Health Contract
description: A State Superior Court judge yesterday ordered Essex County to reject the winning bidder for the health contract at the county jail and give it to a company that challenged the award, county officials said. The award, made in December to Correctional Health Services, which has held the contract for 15 years, was challenged by a rival company, CFG Health Systems, said Joyce Wilson Harley, the county administrator. Judge Rachel Davidson found that the county had improperly awarded the contract and ordered that CFG be declared the winner. Lori E. Grifa, a lawyer for Correctional Health Services, said it had filed for a stay of the judges order.

title: Mets Lineup Gets a Boost as Beltrn Returns
description: The Mets struggling offense received a boost last night against Philadelphia when Carlos Beltrn rejoined the lineup after missing three games because of a bruised right knee.

title: The Wounded Return Home, and Another Battle Begins
description: The broadcast tonight of War Wounds: Home and Still Fighting on TLC is early enough that some people might tune it in while eating dinner. That would be a mistake.

title: Dow Jones Union Seeks Billionaires Help in Finding Alternative Bidder to Murdoch
description: Hoping to head off a takeover by Rupert Murdoch, the main union of the Dow Jones & Company employees is shopping around for another bidder and has begun talks with aides to Ronald W. Burkle, a California billionaire, union officials and others said yesterday.

title: 30 Taliban Reported Drowned as NATO Sinks Boat
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 5  The Afghan Defense Ministry said Tuesday that a boat full of fleeing Taliban fighters had been fired upon by NATO helicopters and sunk in the Helmand River, in southern Afghanistan. All on board, between 20 and 30 guerrillas, drowned, said Gen. Zaher Azimi, a ministry spokesman.

title: Comptrollers Aide Wins Upper East Side Assembly Seat
description: Micah Z. Kellner, an aide to the New York City comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., won a special election yesterday for an Assembly seat representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Investing in Prague
description: Since Edward Barner moved to Prague from Los Angeles in 1993 he has bought and sold more than 20 apartments, with an average return of 500 percent on each one. But now Mr. Barner has just two apartments, and even though he is living in one of them, he plans to sell them both.

title: G.O.P. Candidates at Odds Over Immigration Overhaul
description: The Republican presidential candidates waged verbal combat last night in the Congressional battle over a proposed immigration overhaul, with Senator John McCain, an author of a pending compromise plan, defending the controversial proposals in a Republican debate in Goffstown, N.H., and demanding that his competitors offer a better idea.

title: Study May Fuel Debate Over Title IXs Effect on Mens Sports
description: As Title IX commemorates its 35th anniversary this month, a study released yesterday will further agitate the debate over whether it has damaged mens college athletics and caused the elimination of dozens of mens teams.

title: Doll Web Sites Drive Girls to Stay Home and Play
description: Presleigh Montemayor often gets home after a long day and spends some time with her family. Then she logs onto the Internet, leaving the real world and joining a virtual one. But the digital utopia of Second Life is not for her. Presleigh, who is 9 years old, prefers a Web site called Cartoon Doll Emporium.

title: Irate Fairy Is at the Door; Double-Check the Guest List
description: Gelsey Kirkland did not kill the infant Aurora, as she laughingly threatened to do in a recent interview, when American Ballet Theater performed The Sleeping Beauty on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. She didnt need to. Dancing Carabosse for the first time in this new production, staged by the companys director, Kevin McKenzie, and Ms. Kirkland, she made the vengeful fairy believably capable of any evil.

title: Coptic Christian Fights Deportation to Egypt, Fearing Torture
description: An Egyptian Coptic Christian who was permitted to stay in the United States because of the probable threat of torture back home is now fighting deportation on a murder charge in Egypt.

title: Agency Warns of Surge in Drug-Resistant TB
description: Tuberculosis may reach the point where most new cases in some countries are resistant to many drugs unless far greater efforts are made now to stop the spread of the infection, World Health Organization officials said yesterday.

title: Georgia: Goldman Sachs Endows King Chair
description: Goldman Sachs Group donated $2 million to endow a chair at Morehouse College in Atlanta that will oversee the collected writings of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The chair will supervise the compilation of 10,000 pieces of Dr. Kings writings and manuscripts, Goldman Sachs said. Dr. King was a 1948 graduate of the all-male, historically black college. A group of civic leaders, businesses and philanthropists based in Atlanta bought the collection, which includes a draft of Dr. Kings 1963 I Have a Dream speech, last year after it was to be auctioned by Sothebys for more than $30 million.

title: Food Calendar
description: Free Caffeine Downtown

title: Anniversary of 1967 War Shows Lasting Divisions
description: JERUSALEM, June 5  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Tuesday that the Palestinians were on the brink of civil war and that their internal battles were as dangerous to their welfare as Israeli occupation has been, if not more so.

title: Changing Views on Gays in the Military
description: Bill Clintons promise to lift the ban on gays in the military provoked one of the most wrenching fights of his first year in office. It roiled his relationships with Congress and the military, consumed huge amounts of political capital, and ultimately ended in an uneasy compromise: Dont ask, dont tell.

title: Scientists Turn to the Internet and Venture Capitalists for Backing
description: Before the coming of the Internet and venture capital, the discoveries of many scientists came to the attention  and the benefit  of the public only after years or decades. But times have changed.

title: Praise at U.N. for a New U.S. Envoys Inclusive Tactics and Convivial Style
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 5  One by one, the ambassadors at an unusually jolly diplomatic dinner last month rose to pay tribute to the new American ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad.

title: Police Arrest Fourth Suspect in J.F.K. Case
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, June 5  The fourth suspect in what the authorities have described as a terrorist plot to ignite jet fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport in Queens surrendered to the police Tuesday morning, and angrily told reporters after a court hearing that the case against him was a setup.

title: Russia: Putin Wants Moscow Mayor to Stay
description: President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that he would reappoint Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow, who had previously said that he would leave office after his term expired in December. The leaders of Russias 86 regions, which include Moscow, have served at the presidents behest since constitutional changes passed after the Beslan terrorist attack in 2004. A power broker in his own right, Mr. Luzhkov, above with Mr. Putin, has used his popularity to win two popular elections since his appointment in 1992. At a tour of an experimental affordable housing project in Moscow, Mr. Putin asked the mayor to remain in office, ostensibly to address several outstanding housing problems in the capital. The Kremlin will likely seek to wield Mr. Luzhkovs influence for its benefit in the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections.

title: Campaign Finance Overhaul Would Rein in Major Donors
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council leaders have agreed on a major overhaul of the citys campaign finance laws intended to enhance the power of small donors and reduce the influence of those who do business with the city, including real estate developers.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about sensory integration disorder in children misspelled the surname of a therapist and researcher who first argued that sensory problems were more than symptoms of other disorders. She is A. Jean Ayres, not Ayers. The article also misspelled the given name of a father whose son received therapy for sensory problems. He is Antony Pougnet, not Anthony.

title: Whats on Wednesday night
description: 8 P.M. (13) WE LOVE ELLA! A TRIBUTE TO THE FIRST LADY OF SONG Great Performances salutes Ella Fitzgerald, left, in honor of what would have been her 90th birthday (April 25) in this concert special taped at the Galen Center of the University of Southern California. Patti Austin, Natalie Cole, K. D. Lang, Nancy Wilson, Wynonna Judd, Stevie Wonder and Ruben Studdard, among others, perform Fitzgerald favorites. Quincy Jones and Ms. Cole are hosts of this 90-minute special, which includes interviews, a slide show and never-before-released vocal tracks.

title: Voters Send Mixed Signals to Democratic Organization in New Jersey Primaries
description: JERSEY CITY, June 5  Democratic voters in urban New Jersey delivered a mixed message to traditional machine politics in Tuesdays legislative primaries.

title: Recipe: Pork Meatballs With Yogurt Dressing
description: Adapted from Akhtar Nawab

title: Reid Says He Will Seek to End Debate on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said Tuesday that he would try to force an end to debate on a comprehensive immigration bill, leaving the fate of the legislation in question.

title: Commuter Ticket to Hades: A Ghost Haunts the Railroad
description: In Takeshi Furusawas Ghost Train, a group of high school students tries to unravel a mystery that leads the teenagers into the bowels of their city, and into a nest of elements familiar from other Japanese supernatural horror movies.

title: Pressel Handles Stress of Success
description: Morgan Pressel turned heads for playing through adolescence, becoming the youngest player to qualify for the United States Womens Open when she was 12 and the youngest to win an L.P.G.A. Tour major, at 18.

title: British Grocer Set to Dip Toe in U.S. Market
description: LONDON  Britains largest retailer, Tesco, is finally ready for its American debut.

title: Biologists Make Skin Cells Work Like Stem Cells
description: In a surprising advance that could sidestep the ethical debates surrounding stem cell biology, researchers have come much closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patients cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease.

title: The Many Lives of a Dancer, Explored Upon the Stage
description: Over the weekend, it was possible at Lincoln Center to see all the generations of a School of American Ballet dancers life onstage. On Saturday afternoon, the curtain rose at the New York State Theater to reveal, at the start of Balanchines Mozartiana, Kyra Nichols, in her farewell season with New York City Ballet, framed by four tiny girls from the school, who danced the opening Preghiera with her. Ms. Nicholss way of including the children in her dance of prayer while gently opening herself to the light, to the stage space and to the music made this a sublime image.

title: Man Dies in Shootout With Police Officers in New Brunswick
description: A 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer wounded in a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., last night, the Middlesex County prosecutor said.

title: Extra Virgin Anti-Inflammatories
description: FOR a newcomer to the world of olive oil connoisseurship, the sound effects from the 20 or so tasters at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds in Pomona, Calif., were startling. The low murmurs of discussion were punctuated by loud, sharp slurps, and loud, sharp coughs. Slurps and coughs, hour after hour. On the second day I made two notes to myself: reread The Magic Mountain; check in with Dr. Beauchamp.

title: Silence = Despotism
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Basque Separatists Call Off Cease-Fire in Spain
description: MADRID, June 5  Spain was bracing for fresh attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA on Tuesday after the group called off a 15-month-old cease-fire and vowed to resume its battle for an independent Basque nation.

title: Demonstrations at the Group of 8 Summit
description: Several thousand anti-globalization protesters blocked roads and railway lines leading to the Heiligendamm resort.

title: Gorgeous Gleneagles
description: Glenmor

title: Preserving the Music
description: Guitar makers are rethinking the notion that there is an inexhaustible supply of wood to make their instruments.

title: U. S.-Mexico Rivalry Headlines Gold Cup
description: The Concacaf Gold Cup tournament, which began Wednesday, has never carried a great deal of prestige in the wider world of soccer. But among the teams competing for the championship of North and Central America and the Caribbean, the importance of the tournament has grown steadily since the first tournament was staged in 1991.

title: Scenes of Milford, Pa.
description: This carefully-updated old town is located on the Delaware River about 80 miles from Manhattan.

title: Frugal Traveler: Nashville
description: The Frugal Traveler finds himself drawn to the older and grittier aspects of Nashville, the heart of the country music world.

title: Traditional Fishermen in Laos
description: Despite threats to the local fish population, the Mekong River remains one of the largest fishing resources in the world.

title: Alan Ayckbourn Eases Up
description: The prolific English playwright Alan Ayckbourn, 68, whose plays include "Absurd Person Singular," "The Norman Conquests" and the Tony Award-winning "Bedroom Farce," will step down in 2008 after 37 years as the artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, the BBC reported. He will continue to direct his plays at the theater and any new work by him will have its premiere there.

title: Theater Briefs
description: "The Pirate Queen," the $16 million musical by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schnberg, is giving up the ship on June 17, when it will have played only 85 performances and 32 previews.

title: Finding Room for an Actor Fit for the Stage
description: When Christian McKay appears on stage in Rosebud: The Lives of Orson Welles, one wonders if the casting session took any longer than the time it would to drink a glass of ice water on a hot day. What nature hasnt already bestowed on him in Wellesian aura and appearance, he meticulously affects. The jowls, the quizzical eyes and sonorous baritone: Mr. McKay is Welles to the soles of his feet, annunciating every word as if the future of proper diction depended on him. There are no girdles here. Mr. McKay lets out his gut (or a quite good facsimile of one), stretching the buttonholes on the fly of his trousers to maximum capacity.

title: Irony and Other Theatrical Hazards
description: If this review was written in the style of I.E., in Other Words, the tedious new satire by the Bats, the resident acting company of the Flea Theater, it might begin something like this: insert snappy introduction putting play in context, followed by short plot description with some dismissive adjectives.

title: Burritos for Sophocles
description: Vengeance has always been one of the most passionate of human Pursuits and Sophocles Electra is one of dramatic literatures most compelling studies of the extremes to which it can lead. Unfortunately, an adaptation of the play by Alfred Preisser being staged by the Classical Theater of Harlem is more of a spoof of a Greek tragedy than a serious attempt to revive one.

title: From the Lips of a Pop Icon
description: How much you enjoy All Her Faces: A Portrait of Dusty Springfield will depend on two things: what sort of activity youve engaged in before the performance, and how strong an affection you harbor for the White Lady of Soul.

title: Colony Captures Libyas Tamoil in $5.4 Billion Deal
description: The private equity firm Colony Capital agreed to acquire control of Tamoil of Libya for 4 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The Libyan government will retain 35 percent of the company, which operates refineries and gas stations, Colony said.

title: Commerce Undersecretary to Join Cushman & Wakefield
description: Franklin L. Lavin, under secretary of commerce for international trade, said on Tuesday that he will resign to join the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Lavin, who prodded China to reduce trade barriers by backing new tariffs on Chinese goods, plans to leave on July 13, less than two years after taking the post.

title: Former CA Executive Makes Restitution
description: A former sales chief at CA, the software maker, has agreed to pay $29.7 million in restitution after pleading guilty last year to criminal charges in a scheme to raise the companys quarterly revenue artificially through backdated sales contracts.

title: I.B.M. Settles Suit Over Stock Expenses
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005.

title: V.C.s Have a Crush on IceBreaker
description: IceBreaker has landed $7.2 million in new financing, money that the Bellevue, Wash. startup will use to continue marketing its mobile dating service, Crush or Flush. It also plans to use funds to bolster a research and development center in Beijing, where the company employs more than 20 people and is looking to add more.

title: Third Avenue Adds Managing Director
description: Third Avenue Management, an investment firm led by Martin J. Whitman, said it hired Erik Kleinbeck as a managing director in its client services and business development group. Mr. Kleinbeck, previously a managing director at Sparx Investment & Research, will focus on Third Avenues alternative investment vehicles, Third Avenue said.

title: Firm Launches Synthetic Fund Amid Fee Debate
description: Jerome Abernathy, former head of research at the hedge fund giant Moore Capital Management, opened a new fund on Tuesday that tries to replicate returns generated by the industry, but with lower fees.

title: Ousted RadioShack Chief Goes it Alone With New Venture
description: After a very public fall from grace, the ousted chief executive of RadioShack, Dave Edmondson, is gearing up for his second-act as an entrepreneur.

title: Starent Networks Raises $126 Million in I.P.O.
description: Starent Networks, which provides hardware and software for mobile telephone services, raised $126.4 million in an initial public offering Tuesday, above a forecast range. The offering of 10.5 million shares sold for $12 a share, compared with a forecast range of $9 to $11, Reuters reported.

title: The Private-Equity Approach to Executive Pay
description: With scrutiny of executive pay practices heating up in the United States, the private equity industry may have something to add to the debate.

title: AstraZeneca C.F.O. Leaves for Goldman Post
description: The British drugmaker AstraZeneca on Wednesday said its chief financial officer, Jon Symonds, is quitting after 10 years, opting for an investment-banking post instead. Mr. Symonds is leaving AstraZeneca in July, and in September he will become a managing director at Goldman Sachs.

title: Iverness Gets Big Dog Status as Buying Binge Continues
description: Inverness Medical Innovations may not be a household name, but the Massachusetts medical-testing company is becoming a force to be reckoned with as it continues one of the biggest shopping sprees in the healthcare industry.

title: Shareholders Approve Outback Buyout
description: Shareholders of the owner of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant brand on Tuesday approved a $3.2 billion takeover offer from a private investor group. The consortium, which includes Bain Capital Partners and investment funds affiliated with Catterton Management offered $41.15 a share in cash for OSI Restaurant Partners.

title: Are Investment Banks Running Too Lean?
description: Top investment banks are struggling to cope with the record volume of deals, and their overworked staffs are in danger of making costly mistakes, The Financial Times reports. Many banks are reluctant to bulk up their staff and the shortages are especially keen in financial hubs in continental Europe and Asia, the article says. One headhunter tells the newspaper that vice presidents are very stretched with many junior staff working beyond their experience.

title: 2 Ex-Putnam Managers Settle Market-Timing Charges
description: Two former fund managers for Putnam Investments of Boston agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle allegations they inappropriately traded mutual fund shares and potentially harmed other fund investors, federal and state regulators said on Tuesday.

title: Debitel Dials Up Deal for Talkline
description: Debitel, the largest German reseller of mobile phone services, agreed on Tuesday to buy Talkline from TDC of Denmark for 560 million euros ($756 million), adding 3.8 million customers to its rolls.

title: Hedge Funds and Private Equity: An Uneasy Alliance?
description: Hedge funds and private equity funds seem to have a good routine going, with activist funds goading many companies into buyout deals and then buying the debt used to fund them. But Thorold Barker of The Financial Times cautions that this symbiosis could unravel if and when many of these big buyout deals start to go bad.

title: Teachers Pension and Providence Join Bid for BCE
description: Another bidder for BCE, the parent of Canadas largest telecommunications company, has officially entered the race.

title: Tudor Investment Shutters Small-Stock Fund
description: Tudor Investment, the hedge-fund firm run by Paul Tudor Jones, is shutting its $550 million small-company stock fund after returns failed to meet expectations.

title: Google Forges Deal for PeakStream
description: Google said it has purchased closely held PeakStream, a start-up that sells tools for programming chips with multiple processing units.

title: Indian Miner to Raise $1.65 Billion in U.S. and Japan Offerings
description: A copper and zinc miner, Vedanta Resources, is raising $1.65 billion through a share offering in the United States and Japan by its main subsidiary, Sterlite Industries. The proceeds of the offer will be used to fund a move into power generation and to buy back a minority shareholding in its zinc business from the Indian government.

title: G.M. Chief Seeks to Assuage Buyout Fears
description: The chairman and chief executive of General Motors, Rick Wagoner, sought to reassure shareholders at the auto makers annual meeting that the company was not headed for a private equity buyout like its rival, Chrysler, but he shied away from categorical refusal on the subject.

title: Enel Pays Big for Stake in Russian Power Company
description: Italys Enel , which is poised to take over Spains biggest utility, will expand its presence in Russia after it beat rivals to buy a one-quarter stake in the Russian wholesale generation company OAO OGK-5 for about $1.52 billion.

title: Private Equitys Technology Buying Spree
description: With Elevation Partners investment in Palm, the buyout deal for telecom-equipment firm Avaya and reports of private equity interest in Cadence Design Systems, private equity firms seem to be leaping with open checkbooks into areas where they once feared to tread: technology and telecommunications.

title: French Regulators Examine Deutsche Bank on Hedge Fund Trades
description: French regulators are examining whether Deutsche Bank enabled hedge funds to trade on inside information, destroying tapes and failing to keep written records of phone conversations when lining up buyers for a 2002 Vivendi Universal securities sale, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Lenders Strike Cautious Note on Private Equity Lending
description: Alarm bells were sounded on Tuesday by two major lenders to buyout shops about the way loans are being handed out to fund the booming private equity sector. Meanwhile, a deal by the Texas Pacific Group for the Japanese electronics maker JVC might also be jeopardized by banks looking to tighten their belts.

title: Funds Press TD Ameritrade to Make a Deal
description: Steven Cohen seems intent on burnishing his nascent image as a swashbuckling activist shareholder. On Tuesday, TD Ameritrade, owner of Ameritrade, the nations largest online broker, said in a regulatory filing that its board has received a letter from SAC Capital and Jana Partners urging the company to find a merger partner, and quickly.

title: Blackstones Accounting Switch to Cut Earnings
description: The Blackstone Group, which is preparing for an initial public offering, dropped plans to adopt a new accounting standard that would have let it book profits at the time of a buyout. The change greatly reduced its pro forma earnings and could make it more difficult for the private equity giant to justify a $34 billion valuation, Breakingviews said.

title: Getting the Most Out of Your Wi-Fi Menu
description: Whoa, did I learn my lesson!

title: Prudential to Close Equity Research Unit
description: The analysts at Prudential Equity Group have issued their last buys, holds and sells (or, to be more exact, their last overweights, neutral weights and underweights).

title: Hands Off the Popemobile!
description: A man apparently attempted to board the Popemobile without permission today as it carried Benedict XVI to his customary weekly audience in St. Peters Square.

title: Dawn of the B-List Republicans
description: Blitzed again? The Republicans debated last night, and Wolf Blitzer won again, suggests another Talk Clock infographic from Chris Dodds campaign.

title: Fred Thompson on Fox News Channel
description: While the ten Republican presidential candidates participated in a televised debate this evening, former Senator Fred Thompson appeared on FOX News Channel's "Hannity & Colmes" following the debate. Below is the full rushed transcript.

title: A Republican Bastion No More?
description: Republican hopes to regain a foothold on the Upper East Side were dashed last night. For years, moderate Republicans held a number of elected positions on the Upper East Side, once home to Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: Buzz Over Mayors Get a Life Remark
description: On Monday, the day before a fourth man in a suspected plot to bomb jet fuel tankers at Kennedy International Airport turned himself in to the authorities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg waded once again into the emotional discussions of how ordinary residents can conduct themselves in a post-9/11 world.

title: Wines With a Difference
description: In my column in Wednesdays paper I pay tribute to that under-recognized group on the margins of wine culture known as wine geeks. I try to make the case that these people play a vital role, not only insuring that we have a wonderful diversity of wine selections now but also in being among the first to discover tomorrows must-have bottles.

title: Debate Outtakes
description: Last nights debate among the Republican candidates for the G.O.P. presidential nomination gave the top contenders ample time to explain some of their core beliefs. Among the more memorable moments were Senator John McCains ardent defense of his belief in the current Iraq war strategy and impassioned defense of his support for the immigration legislation; former Mayor Rudy Giulianis succinct responses to questions about the Iraq invasion, terrorism and his humorous comeback to the sound glitches caused by lightning from a storm; and former Gov. Mitt Romneys elaborative explanation and embrace of his Mormon faith.

title: Grayz Anatomy
description: In todays Dining Briefs column, youll notice that one of the three briefs talks about dishes being rehearsed, in a sense, for the new sort-of-restaurant Grayz, which is scheduled to open in September in midtown.

title: NASA Chief Regrets Warming Comments
description: The NASA chief regrets but apparently does not retract global warming comments that caused an uproar with climate scientists, The Associated Press reported.

title: Venice Biennale: Tottering on the Tarmac
description: The slogan of the 52nd annual Venice Biennales international art exhibition can be seen everywhere in this city, even in red-and-green advertisements atop the baggage carousels at Marco Polo airport: Think With the Senses, Feel With the Mind. When I got here early the other morning, I was feeling with my mind  quite strongly  that my bags had to be coming down that ramp sometime soon. But they kept not coming  15 minutes, 20, half an hour. The clock on the wall said 11:30 a.m. My body told me it was 5:30 a.m. (as it was back in New York.) The bright sunshine outside seemed like a cruel joke. If art has any power these days, I hope it is the power of making jet lag go away.

title: A Hybrid of Nonsensical Thinking
description: The Honda Accord Hybrid was killed on Monday. Honda will not have an Accord Hybrid in its line when the next-generation Accord arrives this fall.

title: Venice Biennale: Scoping Out the Crowds
description: If you arrive in Venice a few days before the Biennale parties and unofficial, really-early, almost-secret, Im-extremely-important openings, one of the games you can play is: Art Person or Not Art Person. Biennale or not, the city is already packed with tourists by this time of year. On Sunday, few of them looked like they were here to see the latest in contemporary art. But by Tuesday, you could begin to sense the coming invasion. That bald guy with the Grizzly Adams beard and the neck tattoo? Probably an art person. The three British women who boarded my vaporetto all wearing gray peasant dresses that screamed expensive independent designer? No question. Funky glasses and fanny pack? Sneaky, hard to tell. I spotted a woman on the same boat with khaki cigarette pants, expensive hairdo and lime-green ballet flats. I was convinced. But my wife pointed out, Maybe shes just Italian.

title: Rethinking Not Asking and Not Telling
Challenge to Grocery Deal Leaves Many Asking Why
description: The Federal Trade Commissions decision to try to block the merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets is getting some shocked reactions from Web commentators  and even the technology-focused blog TechDirt blog is weighing in on the newly troubled supermarket deal.

title: 2 Degrees of Separation Between Bush & Merkel
