description: A Greenpeace banner on the Eiffel Tower, Paris. Christophe Ena/AP

title: Pulling a Lou
description: Guest Post by DAN SALTZSTEIN

title: Giuliani to Skip Iowa Straw Poll
description: In a move that bucks years of tradition, Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided not to compete in the earliest indicator of where Republican primary voters stand, the Ames Iowa straw poll.

title: Venice Biennale: Some Very Familiar Faces
description: One of the earliest parties of the rolling Biennale opening week here was held on the roof and grounds of the Peggy Guggenheim Collection on the Grand Canal, to mark the opening of All in the Present Must Be Transformed: Matthew Barney and Joseph Beuys, a show examining affinities between the work of the two groundbreaking artists, one of whom (Beuys) gravitated toward molten fat as a sculptural material and the other (Barney) toward petroleum jelly. While not officially part of the Biennale, the show was timed to coincide with it, moving from the Deutsche Guggenheim in Berlin, where it originated.

title: Baseballs Fantasy World
description: In this months issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesnt depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment. At PLAY were wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?

title: Merrill Lures Co-Head of Morgans Power Group
description: Jonathan Grundy has resigned from Morgan Stanley to join Merrill Lynch as head of energy, power, and infrastructure origination for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Mr. Grundy had been co-head of Morgan Stanleys power and utilities group.

title: Venice Biennale: Revenge of the Raptors
description: One of the artists who seems to be getting a lot of attention is also among the youngest, David Altmejd, 32, representing Canada. He has been known mostly for his recurrent werewolf motif: heads of fanged changelings sprouting crystals and mirrors and chains, as if decaying or exploding. Its partly about our fear of our animal instincts, Andrea Rosen, Mr. Altmejds dealer, says, but transformed into things that are beautiful.

title: Activists Deal Push Boosts Brokers Shares
description: In an otherwise dismal day for the stock market, investors in TD Ameritrade have something to celebrate. Shares in the nations largest online broker rose 4.75 percent Wednesday, after the company disclosed that two hedge funds are calling for it to explore a sale. And the stock of one of their preferred merger partners shot up even more.

title: A More Friendly Facade?
description: Dear Betsy, Richard, Julien, Johan, Jay  and other readers who commented that the facade is too imposing and formal, and reminiscent of a McMansion:

title: Clinton Book Review: First You See It
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign operation includes a website called HillaryHub.com   a campaign newsroom of sorts, with links to articles and blog items that are flattering to Mrs. Clinton.

title: Matching All Those Billions
description: Want to win elected office? First, become a billionaire.

title: An Idea From Down Under: Law Firm I.P.O.s
description: Given that its not legal, American law firms are unlikely to be holding initial public offerings any time soon. But it has already happened in Australia, and, according to American Lawyer, it is apt to happen in Britain within a few years.

title: Saving the Spacesuit for History
description: The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter if NASA doesnt change its plans.

title: Candidates Finals Begin and It Was a Good Day to Play White
description: Levon Aronian, Peter Leko and Alexander Grischuk, all playing White, took the lead in their final candidates matches with victories in the first games. The matches are to determine qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. They are being played in Elista, Kalmykia. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: Notes on the News
description: Some news items that turned up in our dolphin-safe Web nets.

title: CBOT Executives Warn of Dangers in ICE Bid
description: The war of words over the Chicago Board of Trade grew more hostile on Wednesday as its parent company warned of catastrophe if the IntercontinentalExchange took over the exchange.

title: Movie Minutes: '12:08 East'
description: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "1208 East of Bucharest," a bittersweet look back at the 1989 Romanian revolution.

title: Down by the Dumpster
description: Drew Cline, the editorial page editor of New Hampshires Union Leader, files an on-the-scene report from the activists corral outside last nights Republican presidential debate, where the turnout by Brownback supporters was, to put it politely, unimpressive. Cline writes on his Union Leader blog:

title: Blogtalk: The Debate From the Right
description: Conservative bloggers and pundits have been weighing in with their thoughts on last nights Republican debate in New Hampshire, and while the reviews are somewhat mixed, many gave high marks to former mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: The Ultimate Computer Challenge?
description: A six-game match between two computer programs billed as the Ultimate Computer Challenge kicked off today in Elista, Kalmykia. The match, between versions of commercially available software programs, is running concurrently with the final candidates matches to select human qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. In fact, the computer match is taking place on the same playing stage as the candidates finals.

title: Movie Minutes: 'La Vie en Rose'
description: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "La Vie en Rose," about the legendary French singer Edith Piaf.

title: Do a Little, Talk a Lot
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met for their latest public meeting this afternoon  their fifth such session in the last five weeks.

title: McCain to Skip Ames Poll, Too
description: Strike Two for the Ames Iowa Straw Poll. Senator John McCain has decided to follow his Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and not take part in the summer event.

title: Watersports at Aquafest in Shek O
description: Addendum: This event, cancelled because of rain, is now on June 23. Updated info at www.d2adrenaline.com.

title: Fund-Raisers, Belly-Busters
description: We get even hungrier than usual on Wednesdays, when the newspapers run their mouth-watering food features. Apparently, the campaigns are responding to the same Pavlovian pages with their food-themed fund-raising gimmicks.

title: Serbias on a Hot Streak
description: Sure, Kosovo still wants out and grim reminders of war keep emerging, but Serbians are feeling the love lately in European centers of politics, sport and culture.

title: The News From Shea Hospital
description: Most of the injury news coming out of the Mets clubhouse recently has revolved around their banged-up outfield. Not surprisingly, Moises Alous left quadriceps and Shawn Greens broken right foot were again on the tip of Willie Randolphs tongue, although a few more injuries emerged, too.

title: Sopranos Grief
description: I welcome any advice anyone has about a certain problem: How is a person supposed to live without The Sopranos?

title: Willie Seinfeld?
description: Willie Randolph will never be confused with, say, Dave Chappelle or Jerry Seinfeld or Insert Your Favorite Comedian Here, but for some reason during his pregame interview session with reporters (perhaps because the ESPN announcers were listening in) he was in a particularly good mood. I even laughed out loud a few times.

title: Talkin Baseball With the Yankees
description: Alex Rodriguez is at his best when hes stripped away from the politics of being A-Rod and he just talks about baseball. There are few players Ive ever covered who can get as in-depth on the game when they want to.

title: Then and Now
description: I spent almost a year in the Sunni Triangle. I somehow avoided the hundreds of mortar attacks on my base, the I.E.D.s on some of the most dangerous roads in Iraq, the R.P.G. fired at my convoy. Its the path of the ages I feel Ive traveled, where able bodied Americans go to war for their country, either by choice or not, and the best way to illustrate my journey is with a simple then and now. It is a desert full of memories I can conjure up, and every grain of sand is in ultra-sharp focus like a 7-megapixel photo.

title: Your Comments on my China-Guantanamo Column
description: In Thursdays column, my last from the China trip, I write about human rights abuses in China  and the way our own American policies undermine our moral authority and ability to raise these concerns. Please post your comments on it here.

title: Synthetic v. Natural Pesticides
description: Ive been getting questions about the biochemist Bruce Ames work, which I briefly cite in the Findings column as evidence that synthetic pesticides in our diet are a minuscule risk for cancer. So let me elaborate on the work done by him and his colleague, Lois Swirsky Gold, the director of the Carcinogenic Potency Project at Berkeley.

title: Furor Over Proposed Jail Rules
description: Sewell Chan reports from City Council hearings on the Board of Corrections' proposed rules on the treatment of prisoners.

title: Despite the Dumb Jokes, Stereotypes May Reflect Some Smart Choices
description: A quick Web search identifies thousands of jokes about dumb blondes, this one among them: A married couple were awakened by a call at 2 a.m. The wife, a blonde, picked up the phone, listened a moment and said, How should I know, thats 200 miles from here! and hung up. Her husband asked, Who was that? She replied, I dont know; some woman wanting to know if the coast is clear.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo.

title: Wang Shows Effectiveness Good Pitching Can Have
description: CHICAGO, June 6  The signs of life are hard to miss now. The Yankees have won five of their last seven games, with dormant bats stirring and a defense that is starting to make a difference.

title: Away From the Set but Not Away From HDTV
description: Its summertime, and catching your favorite TV shows is not so easy when you are on vacation or a weekend outing. A cheap, portable TV is one option, but what if youve developed a taste for high definition? Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptops U.S.B. port. The receiver, which sells for $99 and is available at www.plextor.com, has an external antenna and software that scans for over-the-air HD signals.

title: Through Erik Saties Music, a Trip Back in Time to the Soundless and the Surreal
description: Its so intense I cant stand it, the pianist Bruce Levingston said laughingly after playing Erik Saties Sarabande No. 2, Gnossienne No. 4 and Gymnopdie No. 1 to open his concert at the French Institute Alliance Franaises Florence Gould Hall on Tuesday.

title: Chinese Auto Parts Enter the Global Market
description: JINZHOU, China  Zhao Qingjies favorite book, he says, is a Chinese translation of Lee A. Iacoccas autobiography.

description: ITunes and Vista,

title: As Cellphones Multiply, Phone Books Get Slimmer
description: Parents have used them as booster chairs for children. Marksmen have fired at them for target practice. And musclemen have ripped them in half as a show of strength.

title: Judge Rejects Main Argument of Effort to Stop Atlantic Yards Project in Brooklyn
description: A federal judge yesterday dismissed the most significant lawsuit against the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents of the $4 billion project.

title: Tough Art With a Candy Center
description: VENICE, June 6  The artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres, who died of AIDS in 1996 at 38, did not exactly fit the profile of a secret agent, an infiltrator foiling lines of defense. He was a generous man with a handsome, cherubic face and wicked sense of humor. He loved cats. And some of his best-known art is made of candy, mounds of it, free for the taking and endlessly replenished, a Willy Wonka vision of Post-Minimalism.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about GlaxoSmithKlines efforts to market its diabetes treatment Avandia to African-Americans, misstated the name of a television network that is typically used when marketers want to reach black audiences. It is Black Entertainment Television, or BET  not the Black Entertainment Network.

title: Decisively, One Womens Team Earns Itself a Trip to Shanghai
description: The first team has qualified for the world championships from the trials taking place in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Loving New Orleans, With a Ready Escape
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Droopy Dahlias

title: Tough Shot for Mickelson
description: Phil Mickelson, profiled as "Mr. Unpredictable by Charles McGrath in this months PLAY, has opted for a cortisone shot in his injured left wrist and a week of rest, adding another level of uncertainty to his effort to win his first United States Open next week (as if the specter of last years 18th-hole meltdown at Winged Foot wasnt enough). Mickelson is skipping this weeks Stanford St. Jude Championship and says hell be fine for the Open, at the Oakmont Country Club in Pittsburgh, but ailing wrists and deep rough dont make an ideal golf pairing. After all, Mickelson injured the wrist during a recent practice round at Oakmont. Pros who are practicing there this week are saying the course is tougher than Winged Foot, where the winning score was 5 over. Theres already enough preying on a golfers mind at a U.S. Open  it features the harshest conditions and the most grueling mental challenge. Wondering whether your wrist can hold up is the last thing you need. Looks like Mickelson is already down a few strokes.

title: Out From the Ethical Deep Freeze
description: Just as House Democrats fervid promises of ethics reform are running out of steam comes the bribery indictment of one of their own, William Jefferson, the Louisiana representative accused of stashing $90,000 in marked bills in his home freezer. Surely the image of Mr. Jefferson allegedly using the Congressional dining room to transact quid-pro-quo corruption schemes is the strongest possible wake-up call for foot-dragging members to face up to the need for aggressive ethics enforcement. The existing ethics committee produced cobwebs, not early-warning alerts, as recent scandals were launching several lawmakers, staffers and lobbyists on prison careers.

title: Smooth Lips for Men (Yes, Men!)
description: HE carries one in his pocket, said Landon Yeager, an auditor from Dallas. One in my gym bag, one in my briefcase, one in my desk and one in my car.

title: The Virtually Untrammeled Power of Presidential Pardons
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  When it comes to high-profile presidential pardons, the big one, of course, was President Gerald R. Fords pardon of Richard M. Nixon.

title: Duncan Has Parker. James Has Himself.
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 6  The Cleveland Cavaliers bumped into their first logistical challenge here Wednesday, on the eve of their first N.B.A. finals: Who takes the microphone at the league-mandated news conference?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on May 11 about the arrest of a New York police officer on charges of killing his estranged girlfriend misspelled the name of a Queens restaurant where they had met in an effort to reconcile. It is the Kaieteur Restaurant & Sports Bar  not Kiteur.

title: At Group of 8 Meeting, Bush Rebuffs Germany on Cutting Emissions
description: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 6  As leaders of wealthy nations converged Wednesday on a Baltic Sea resort for their annual meeting, the White House effectively derailed a climate change initiative backed by one of President Bushs strongest European allies, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.

title: Where Is the Yankees Real First Baseman?
description: While the Yankees hold their breath waiting for Roger Clemens to rescue their rotation, they continue to suffer from the absence of a real Yankee first baseman.

title: Traveling Ever Lighter
description: ONE effortless way for hikers to pick up the pace is to carry lighter gear.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report by the BBC in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday, about the intention of the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn to retire next year from his post as artistic director of the Stephen Joseph Theater in Scarborough, England, misstated the year he was knighted. It was 1997, not this year.

title: A Long, Uncertain Path for New Cell Technique
description: While intriguing, a new approach for producing embryonic stem cells faces considerable hurdles before it can be used to develop medical treatments, executives from stem cell and other biotechnology companies said yesterday.

title: Arnold Lappert, 86, Who Heard Corregidor Fall, Is Dead
description: Arnold Lappert, the Army radio technician in Hawaii who received the last messages from the island of Corregidor before its surrender to the Japanese in May 1942, and nearly four years later realized a quest to find the fellow New Yorker who sent those final desperate words, died Friday in Dania, Fla. He was 86.

title: Bracing for the Demise of the Big Guy
description: CLIFTON, N.J.

title: Sharapova Loses in French Open Semis
description: PARIS, June 7  On her way to beating Maria Sharapova today to make it to the French Open final, Ana Ivanovic hardly said a word.

title: Warning: Dont Swat That Fly, She May Be One of the Stars
description: David Ivess Time Flies & Others by Ives is popular among acting students, and its not just because the amusing collection of compact one-acts features comic roles perfect for performers who love to show off. Receiving a spirited production by the director Jordana Kritzer, this show also speaks quite sympathetically to people struggling to make a way for themselves. They are comedies that embrace the little guy  or, in the case of the first playlet, the little fly.

title: Defeats Killing Fields
description: SOME opponents of the Iraq war are toying with the idea of American defeat. A number of them are simply predicting it, while others advocate measures that would make it more likely. Lending intellectual respectability to all this is an argument that takes a strange comfort from the outcome of the Vietnam War. The defeat of the American enterprise in Indochina, it is said, turned out not to be as bad as expected. The United States recovered, and no lasting price was paid.

title: A Voice for Small Business
description: Steven C. Preston, 46, a former executive vice president at ServiceMaster, became administrator of the Small Business Administration in July 2006. He sat down recently in his Washington office to discuss his efforts and those of Congress to overhaul the agency, which has been hit with budget and staff cuts. Following are excerpts:

title: Partisan Battles Mark End of Regular Hartford Session
description: HARTFORD, June 7  As the state legislature prepared to end its regular lawmaking session on Wednesday, there were times when the political leaders could not even agree to disagree.

title: Pull Over, You With the Lead Foot: Your TV Career Awaits
description: True-crime reality shows can be named after the enforcers (Dog the Bounty Hunter), the miscreants (Americas Most Wanted) or both (Bandits vs. Smokies). The creators of Speeders, which makes its debut tonight on Court TV, went with the bad guys  perhaps because the natural alternative, Traffic Cops, would have made it just a little too obvious where they got their ideas.

title: Bombs Hit Shiites in Baghdad; Turkish Threats Grow Acute
description: BAGHDAD, June 6  A pair of car bombs struck one of the most heavily protected Shiite areas on Wednesday, the Kadhimiya district of Baghdad, killing three people and wounding 25, the Iraqi police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on May 26, about Home Depot, referred incorrectly to protesters at the companys 2006 annual meeting for shareholders. A number of workers protested the compensation of Bob Nardelli, the chief executive at the time, but only one employee who attended  not several  wore a chicken suit as part of the demonstration.

title: Jack Valentis Memoir Suffers Without a Key Salesman
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  Jack Valentis death has created a marketing problem that would have challenged even him.

title: For Student Play About Iraq War, Banned in School, Curtains Finally Go Up in Connecticut
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 6  Three months after their principal canceled a school production they had prepared on the war in Iraq, a group of Wilton High School students staged a dramatic reading of the play Wednesday night to a packed house at a nearby theater.

title: Moss Expects to Produce for Patriots
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., June 6  Randy Moss smiled at the suggestion that joining the New England Patriots marked a new beginning.

title: State School Standards Vary Widely in Study
description: What students must learn to be deemed academically proficient varies drastically from state to state, the United States Department of Education said today in a report that, for the first time, showed the specific extent of the differences.

title: Doctor Says He Was Assailed for Challenging Drugs Safety
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The business of developing and selling new drugs is fraught with peril and setbacks. Billions of dollars are at stake. Nerves are on edge. Tempers flare.

title: Cuomo Plans to Broaden Student-Lending Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans has exposed ties between universities and lenders, said Wednesday that he was broadening his inquiry to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans, and whether they violate civil rights statutes.

title: Can the Americans Right the Ship?
description: What will a reported $200 million get you en route to the Americas Cup? For BMW Oracle, the American team owned by Larry Ellison, it got them thumped by Luna Rossa, the Italian team with more shallow pockets, says John Tayman, who wrote about the Americas Cup for this months issue of PLAY.

title: Heartthrob Swooning and Concert T-Shirts
description: WANTAGH, N.Y., June 5  It was a breezy Tuesday night here at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater, and the stands were filled with screaming teenagers and a few nonscreaming parents. Early on, Pete Wentz, the bassist and lead celebrity  but not lead singer  of Fall Out Boy, took a moment to reassure the nonscreamers.

title: Brooklyn: Universities Pledge Emissions Cuts
description: The presidents of nine universities in New York City promised yesterday to cut greenhouse gas emissions from their campuses by 30 percent over the next 10 years. The pledges, made during a news conference at Pratt Institute, came in response to a challenge by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has set the same objectives for all city-owned buildings as part of his environmental sustainability plan for the city. According to a city study, buildings account for nearly 80 percent of the citys greenhouse gas emissions, which have been linked to global warming. The participating schools are Barnard, Columbia, Cooper Union, all 23 campuses of the City University of New York, Fordham, New York University, Pratt, St. Johns University and the New School. Asked if the retrofits might require tuition increases, the president of one university said it was a possibility; others said they would seek other financing.

title: Kiwis Earn Cup Rematch Against Their Top Rival
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 6  Bring it home, read the T-shirts of the New Zealanders who have turned this distant harbor into a sunny enclave of their cloudier land.

title: A Dark, Rock n Roll Oasis in the Shine of the Hamptons
description: IF you are not acquainted with the oeuvre of John Varvatos, the first things you need to know are the following: he invented the boxer brief for Calvin Klein and, in partnership with Converse, the laceless Chuck Taylor.

title: Brooklyn: Hearing for Airport Defendant Postponed
description: A detention hearing in Federal District Court for one of four men charged in a plot to blow up fuel lines at Kennedy Airport was postponed yesterday after the defendant, Russell Defreitas, 63, decided not to seek bail at this time, prosecutors said. A new hearing date was not set yesterday afternoon.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Close Tax Shelter Shortly After I.B.M. Uses It to Save $1.6 Billion
description: For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

title: Calmer Talk From U.S. and Russia
description: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 6  Russia and the United States on Wednesday appeared to step back from their confrontation over American plans for installations in Europe relating to a missile shield, as President Bush said Russia was not a threat to Europe and the Russian foreign minister withdrew a threat to pull out of a conventional arms treaty.

title: Curlin Gets His Chance to Become a Big Star
description: As good as he is, Curlin has never been the big star. There were 20 horses in the Kentucky Derby, too many for any one to stand out as the one to watch. In the Preakness Stakes, it was all about Street Sense, which was no surprise considering he was dominant two weeks earlier in the Derby.

title: To Appeal to Women, Too, Gadgets Go Beyond Cute and Pink
description: Nancy Duarte professes no affection or affinity for consumer electronics. Despite being a founder of a presentation technology company in Silicon Valley, she does not go gaga for gigabytes. Im not typically wired and connected, Ms. Duarte said without apology. I dont have a belt with all things electronic hanging off of it. Im not a BlackBerry person.

title: Repression by China, and by Us
description: BEIJING

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,485 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Sameh Khouzam, a man accused of murder who says he will be tortured if he is deported back to Egypt, misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Immigration and Customs Enforcement who said there were extensive deliberations within the government about deporting Mr. Khouzam. He is Marc Raimondi, not Raimondo. (Go to Article)

title: India Has Fewer AIDS Victims Than Thought
description: NEW DELHI, June 7  India, which has repeatedly been accused of denying the size of its AIDS epidemic, probably has millions fewer victims than has been widely believed, according to a new household survey that has not yet been released.

title: Ducks Bring Cup to the West Coast
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 6  The Anaheim Ducks got their Disney ending after all.

title: Pennsylvania Republican, Convicted in 80s Bribery, Backs Giuliani
description: In a recent letter to donors, Robert B. Asher, a prominent Pennsylvania Republican and prolific fund-raiser, wrote, I am proud to say that I have agreed to be the state political chairman for Mayor Rudy Giuliani.

title: From Database to Crime Scene: Network Is Potent Police Weapon
description: By the time a police van pulled up outside a Morningside Heights apartment on April 14 where a 23-year-old Columbia University graduate student had been tortured for 19 hours, her assailant was long gone. But inside the van, laptop computers were humming with a wireless link to a high-tech nerve center in Police Headquarters, next to the Manhattan approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: When a High-Definition Picture Is Too Good to Believe, See How It Handles This Test Disc
description: With the specially produced videos that play in electronics stores, those HDTVs and DVD players produce pictures so astounding you can scarcely believe your eyes.

title: From Pucker and Pout to Hip-Hop Hit
description: RUN-D.M.C. had its Adidas, Busta Rhymes had his Courvoisier and Lil Kim, the fashion plate turned convicted perjurer, has used her couplets to praise the work of everyone from Marc Jacobs to Jacob the Jeweler.

title: TB Patient Gives His Account to Congress
description: In a Senate hearing, Andrew Speaker yesterday contradicted some accounts by government officials about the timing of who knew what and when about his plans to travel abroad after being told that he had extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis.

title: Brooklyn: Sentence for Practicing Law Without a License
description: A woman who represented clients in Family Court without a license to practice law was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years probation. Law enforcement officials said that the woman, Natasha Riley, 44, represented at least seven clients, including minors seeking disposition of criminal charges and parents seeking child custody, charging $300 to $900 per court appearance. At one hearing, law enforcement officials said, Ms. Riley offered an objection couched in a barnyard epithet, raising the suspicions of the judge. Ms. Riley, who pleaded guilty to filing a false instrument, was also ordered to repay her clients $3,267.

title: Biologists Make Skin Cells Work Like Stem Cells
description: In a surprising advance that could sidestep the ethical debates surrounding stem cell biology, researchers have come much closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patients cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease.

title: This Gehry Work to Revolve Around Play, as in Ground
description: Frank Gehry, the architect known for buildings adorned with undulating banners of titanium, is set to make his first foray into the world of monkey bars and swings with a new playground at Battery Park, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Ballot Boxes? Yes. Actual Democracy? Tough Question.
description: CAIRO, June 6  This is election season in the Middle East. Syria just held presidential and parliamentary elections. Algeria held parliamentary elections. Egyptians will be asked to vote next week on a new upper house of Parliament. There will soon be elections in Jordan, Morocco and Oman, followed by elections in Qatar. So is democracy suddenly taking root in the strongmans last regional stronghold?

title: Stocks Decline on Inflation Fears
description: For the second straight day, Wall Street recoiled today at the prospect that inflation would not settle down enough to suit the Federal Reserve. And investors appeared to worry not only that interest rates will stay where they are, but that the Fed could raise them even higher.

title: Pakistan Arrests 300 Workers From Opposition
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 6  The police have arrested more than 300 political party workers over the past few days in a crackdown before a protest planned this week against new government curbs on the news media, a government official acknowledged Wednesday.

title: Clemens Appears Set to Return on Saturday
description: CHICAGO, June 6  Roger Clemens threw batting practice Wednesday in Tampa, Fla., and he seemed to have passed the final test before he rejoins the Yankees on Saturday against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Libby and the Scales of Justice (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
description: The Bush administration wants to revamp the nations patent system, requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the patent offices chief.

title: F.D.A. Issues Strictest Warning on Diabetes Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs, Avandia and Actos, whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern.

title: Vote on New Rules for Jail Inmates Is Delayed
description: The board that oversees the citys Department of Correction has put off a final vote on changes to the rules governing the daily lives of city inmates  the most significant changes since 1978  after an outcry by the City Bar Association, the Legal Aid Society and other groups that have called the changes draconian and inhumane.

title: China Reminds Hong Kong Whos Boss
description: Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National Peoples Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve a high degree of autonomy for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kongs mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territorys laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kongs return to China.

title: Independence Still the Issue at Dow Jones
description: In 1981, Rupert Murdoch and a division of his News Corporation made extraordinary promises about not meddling in the news pages of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, which they were about to take over. But in short order, no one doubted who was firmly in control of the newsrooms.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Jersey
description: THE prospect of rocking to Lil Anne and Hot Cayenne and savoring boiled crayfish and grilled alligator sausage sent visitors in streams last week to Michael Arnones Crawfish Festival, where they peeled off their shirts  and their citified ways. The crowd at the Sussex County Fairgrounds in Augusta, N.J., swapped a buttoned-down style for one best described as country-festive, showing off straw hats, riotously colorful bandanas and meadow-sweeping patchwork skirts.

title: It Takes a Rule Breaker to Create Dance for Rebels
description: At the premiere of Bill T. Jones and Arnie Zanes dance piece Secret Pastures in 1985, Mr. Zanes parents noticed Madonna and Andy Warhol two rows behind them. Still skeptical about their sons involvement with Mr. Jones on and off stage and the couples confrontational, self-revealing dances, they were nonetheless impressed. Now you guys are beginning to get somewhere, Mr. Zanes father told them. If you dont blow it, maybe youll get to Broadway.

title: Saudi Said to Receive Money for British Arms Deal
description: LONDON, June 7  Confronted today with fresh allegations of impropriety in a major British arms deal with Saudi Arabia, Prime Minister Tony Blair once again defended his decision to cancel an official inquiry into the multi-billion-dollar agreement.

title: For Hikers in a Hurry to Get Fit Fast
description: SO many trails, so little time. With summer around the corner in the Pacific Northwest, Dan Lauren, 48, faces this frustrating state of affairs every weekend.

title: More Fears on Inflation Hit Stocks
description: After rising almost uninterruptedly for three months, the stock market tumbled for a second day yesterday over fears that inflation is not settling down enough to satisfy the Federal Reserve.

title: Manhattan: City Worker Charged Over Water Tests
description: A city employee who was supposed to check the purity of New York Citys drinking water was charged in Federal District Court yesterday with making false entries in official water-monitoring records. The man, Nicholas Miritello, 44, of Wappingers Falls, is charged with four instances of recording test results in 2005 on the cloudiness of water that he had not actually tested, federal prosecutors said. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison. The Department of Environmental Protection, which runs the water system, has been under federal oversight since 2001 because of similar record-keeping irregularities and other violations of federal law.

title: Stealing the Scene Along With the Store
description: ON Monday night, the 33-year-old designer Phillip Lim, who worked quietly behind the scenes in other designers studios for a decade before putting his name on a label that is now sold at Neiman Marcus, won the fashion industrys highest award for emerging talent. Yet his obvious pleasure at being recognized by the Council of Fashion Designers of America at its annual ceremony must have been tempered by the fact that he was handed his statuette by two women who also call themselves young designers  Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen.

title: Before Punishing Giambi, Selig Wants His Help
description: After Jason Giambi of the Yankees tacitly admitted last month to using steroids, Commissioner Bud Selig was placed in an awkward position. Selig wants to show that he is tough on steroid users, but punishing Giambi is problematic because if he used steroids, it occurred before Major League Baseball punished players for using performance-enhancing substances.

title: Tentative Deal Reached for Darfur Peacekeeping Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 6  The United Nations and the African Union struck a tentative deal on Wednesday to end disagreement over the command of a 23,000-soldier joint peacekeeping force proposed for Darfur.

title: Next Week
description: Charles McGrath looks at the United States Open at Oakmont Country Club in Pittsburgh and whether Phil Mickelson, if hes recovered from a minor wrist injury, can recover in a larger sense from his meltdown on the final hole of last years Open at Winged Foot. Plus, Gretchen Reynolds on one of the risks of summer activity: heat illness.

title: A Room of Sound From Golf Ball-Size Speakers (Plus Subwoofer)
description: When the wee home audio gremlins invade your home at night to change your wireless settings and turn up your TV, they will be quite enamored with the Sony DAV-IS10 audio system and its five tiny speakers. The system also includes a larger subwoofer, a DVD/CD player and a radio receiver.

title: Baseballs Fantasy World
description: In this months issue of PLAY, Bryan Curtis argues that fans who play fantasy baseball are part of an intellectual revolution, having devised a way to interact with the game that doesnt depend on watching the actual games for enjoyment. At PLAY were wondering: How has fantasy baseball changed the relationship between fans and the game?

title: On a Corner, a Shutter Clicks as Poets and Punks Pass in Review
description: It was getting close to midnight when a man who goes by the name Swami taped a hand-lettered placard reading Pearls Before Swine to a phone booth on the west side of Avenue A in Lower Manhattan.

title: A Lifetime Spent Fleeing the Savagery That Follows
description: Born in filth on a ship full of German refugees in New York harbor in 1936, Rebecca Schwart, like so many of Joyce Carol Oatess heroines, will live a life touched by enough violence to supply a slasher movie. At 13 she is cornered by her shotgun-wielding father, the eponymous gravedigger, who has killed a man and blown his wife into a headless heap inside their hovel near the cemetery gates. Instead of murdering his daughter too, he sends himself into oblivion, showering her with gore. Shed wiped that face off her own damn face! Ms. Oates writes of Rebecca. Shed picked that face out of her hair.

title: Researchers Detect Variations in DNA That Underlie Seven Common Diseases
description: Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Rock Bottom Remainders, a rock band of popular authors, misspelled the given name of a singer who performed with the band at Webster Hall on Friday night. She is Lesley Gore, not Leslie.

title: Shirley: Boy Drowns in Pool
description: A Long Island toddler drowned in a neighbors pool yesterday after wandering away from home, the Suffolk County police said. The boy, Anthony Muniz, 3, was reported missing by his mother, Denise Morrisette of Auborn Avenue, shortly after 9 a.m., the police said. After searching the neighborhood and knocking on doors, neighbors and Ms. Morrisette found the boy in a neighbors pool. The police said the in-ground pool had been properly fenced. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a plan to return straying bison to Yellowstone National Park referred incorrectly in some copies to the type of animals from a herd north of the park that were found infected with brucellosis last month. They were cattle, not bison.

title: 2012 Olympic Logo: Sparks Precede the Flame
description: LONDON, June 6  It was said to provoke epileptic seizures. Someone compared it to a broken swastika or some sort of comical sex act between The Simpsons.  The mayor was not amused.

title: CBS, Bowing to Protests, Brings Back Jericho
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  Three weeks after CBSs cancellation of the apocalyptic drama Jericho set off a sustained and creative protest by fans of the first-season series, the network reversed course and announced on Wednesday that it had ordered seven additional episodes to be broadcast late this year or early in 2008.

title: One Saloon Singer to Another, Encompassing Two Universes
description: Now that James Brown is gone, the designation Hardest-Working Man in Show Business is up for grabs. One candidate for the title would have to be Michael Feinstein, the multitasking singer, pianist, all-around entertainer, intrepid archivist and strict watchdog of old-guard pop traditions.

title: High-Jumper Learns Fast and Thrives
description: SACRAMENTO, June 6  A little more than a year ago, Donald Thomas was a shooting guard at Lindenwood University, an N.A.I.A. school in St. Charles, Mo. He had played

title: A Small Strategy for Selling Concerts
description: The music industry may seem like a broken record of bad news these days, with plunging album sales and confusion over the digital future. But in the concert business at least one corner is booming: clubs.

title: Auto Chiefs Make Headway Against a Mileage Increase
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Automobile companies seem to be making progress in tamping down Democratic proposals for tougher fuel economy requirements, an issue that pits powerful Democrats from Michigan against some national leaders of their own party.

title: Behind the Glass Wall
description: WHEN Philip Johnsons Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., officially opens to the public on June 21, paying visitors will have a chance to explore one of the worlds most celebrated works of Modernism for the first time since its completion in 1949. The diminutive glass-and-steel building and its uncluttered interior, which have barely changed in 58 years, are so spare that it is hard to imagine that anyone ever lived there. But for nearly all that time, it was the constantly used country retreat of its round-spectacled creator, who shared it after 1960 with David Whitney.

title: House Passes Stem Cell Bill Despite Veto Threat
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation intended to ease restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, sending a bipartisan measure to the White House that President Bush has pledged to veto.

title: China to Revise Rules on Food and Drug Safety
description: SHANGHAI, June 6  Responding to growing international concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs, China said late Tuesday that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections.

title: China: Car Sales Rise 34% in May
description: Chinas car sales rose 23 percent in May, as price cuts and new models attracted more people to showrooms. Customers bought 488,500 passenger cars, multipurpose vehicles and sport-utility vehicles in May, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 6, 2007

title: Afghans Seek Men Who Killed Broadcaster as She Slept
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 6  An Afghan journalist was shot dead by unknown gunmen in her home north of Kabul on Tuesday night as she slept beside her 10-month-old baby, Afghan officials said Wednesday.

title: Travelers Face Frustrations With Passport Rule Changes
description: HOUSTON, June 6  With government phone lines jammed by record numbers of passport-seekers, Veronica Alvarez and three anxious friends hoping to travel to Cancun next week showed up at the federal building here on Wednesday at 3 a.m.

title: Immigration Bill Fails to Win Crucial Vote in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  A bill that would overhaul immigration law suffered a crippling defeat this evening in the Senate, casting grave doubt on the prospects for changing the system any time soon.

title: Hes 9 Years Old  and a Video-Game Circuit Star
description: HOLBROOK, N.Y., June 5  Victor M. De Leon III has been playing video games on the professional circuit for five years now, racking up thousands of dollars in prizes and endorsements at tournaments around the country. He has a national corporate sponsor, a publicist and a Web site, with 531 photos chronicling his career. A documentary filmmaker has been following him for months.

title: Saving Trees Is Music to Guitar Makers Ears
description: Christian F. Martin IV is the sixth generation to run his familys renowned guitar-making business, C. F. Martin & Company. But he is surely the first to worry about the availability of the distinctive woods needed to build Martin guitars, the choice of musicians like Sting, Paul Simon, Jimmy Buffett and John Mayer.

title: Yonkers Agency Approves Controversial Development
description: YONKERS, June 6  After three years of divisive debate marred by suspicions of back-room deals and political favoritism, a proposal to build houses, offices and shops on an 81-acre site off the Sprain Brook Parkway cleared its last hurdle here on Wednesday. The Industrial Development Agency, a quasi-governmental body, approved $22 million in mortgage and sales tax exemptions for the developer.

title: The Candidates Faith (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a contest for YouTube viewers to choose a theme song for Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign referred incorrectly to a Billy Joel song. The song, New York State of Mind, was on the album Turnstiles; the album is not named for the song.

title: Prudential Financial to Close Research Unit
description: Prudential Financial has been trying for years to figure out what to do with its small, struggling equity research and sales business. Yesterday, the company said it had decided to shut the operation.

title: Colorado: Report on Mauling
description: The police have closed an inquiry into the mauling death of a zookeeper at the Denver Zoo, clearing the zoo of criminal wrongdoing. The zookeeper, Ashlee Pfaff, 27, was killed by a 140-pound male jaguar Feb. 24. According to the police report, the results of which were published yesterday in The Rocky Mountain News, armed zoo personnel rushed to Ms. Pfaffs aid, fending off the jaguar with a fire extinguisher and eventually shooting and wounding the animal after it approached them. A veterinarian euthanized the jaguar after the attack. It is unclear why a door to the jaguars enclosure was ajar, allowing the animal to pounce on Ms. Pfaff.

title: An Immigration Compromise Divides Republican Senators
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Senator Jeff Sessions, a conservative former federal prosecutor from Alabama, says he is anything but anti-immigration. But he is dead set against what he says is a misguided and flawed immigration proposal he says will not secure the nations borders while rewarding those who have sneaked across them.

title: Citigroup and NASD Settle BellSouth Case
description: NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said yesterday that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of the BellSouth Corporation into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.

title: Looking for Leadership
description: If there is a point to gathering the leaders of eight of the worlds richest and most powerful nations each year, it is to thrash out policies for tackling the most pressing and contentious problems.

title: F.D.A. Calls for New Warnings on Diabetes Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The governments top drug regulator told a packed House hearing today that the agency had recently decided to put the agencys most serious safety warning on two diabetes drugs  Avandia and Actos  whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern.

title: Rights Groups Call for End to Secret Detentions
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Six human rights groups on Wednesday released a list of 39 people they believe have been secretly imprisoned by the United States and whose whereabouts are unknown, calling on the Bush administration to abandon such detentions.

title: Thousands of Protesters Foil Some German Security Measures and Clash With the Police
description: KHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 6  They lurked in the woods, 50 strong, wearing black hoods and bandannas, and wielding tree limbs. At a signal, they sprang forward and threw their debris across one of the bigger roads here, creating a barricade that brought traffic to a halt.

title: Beethovens Fraternity of Friends and Peers
description: The Emerson String Quartet knows how to give itself a party, and how to turn a composers quartet cycle into a high-concept marathon. Its Perspectives series at Carnegie Hall  an expansive look at the Beethoven quartets, juxtaposed with works by composers who influenced him and felt his influence  is part of the groups celebration of its 30th anniversary.

title: General Tells Senate U.S. Must Prevail in Iraq
description: The Army officer named to be the Bush administrations war-coordination czar told a Senate panel today that America continues to have vital interests in the Middle East, and that it must prevail in the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Feud Over Land Parcel Shadows Plans for a Permanent Memorial to United Flight 93
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa., June 6  Two employees of the National Park Service used a garbage bag and duct tape on Wednesday to cover an unauthorized box erected to receive donations at a temporary memorial where visitors pay homage daily to the 40 victims of United Flight 93.

title: The Inadequacy of Civil Unions
description: A potentially groundbreaking legal battle over Connecticuts exclusion of gay people from the states marriage law has catapulted the debate over same-sex marriage to a new level.

title: Sorenstam Strives to Become What She Was
description: At times, Annika Sorenstam broke into the kind of giddy smile that would rarely be coaxed from her in the middle of a competitive round. This occasion, she said, was worth letting a little joy break through her usual focused facade.

title: Accord to Protect Wine Names
description: Australia agreed to stop using names like champagne and port as part of an accord with the European Union that helps protect the unions wine industry by preserving traditional production methods and names. The agreement safeguards the E.U.s wine-labeling regime, gives full protection to E.U. geographical indications, including for wines intended to be exported, and includes a clear Australian commitment to protect E.U. traditional expressions, the European Commission said. The agreement replaces an existing accord that dates from 1994 and provides for Australia to phase out the use of a number of important E.U. names within a year.

title: Where a Screen Isnt an Option, a Hand-Held Uses Audio
description: The Icon mobile manager has just about everything you would expect in a hand-held organizer, including a calendar, address book, clock, word processor, calculator, voice recorder, and Wi-Fi and Bluetooth connectivity. What it does not have is a screen, because this pocket-size device from LevelStar was designed for visually impaired users.

title: A Confident But Close Victory Over Guatemala
description: Even playing the last 18 minutes with 10 men didnt stop the United States from opening up its Gold Cup defense with a comfortable 1-0 victory over Guatemala, in theory the toughest opponent in its group.

title: CBS Bringing Jericho Back After Protests From Fans
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6  Three weeks after CBSs cancellation of the apocalyptic drama Jericho set off a sustained and creative protest by fans of the first-season series, the network reversed course and announced on Wednesday that it had ordered seven new episodes for broadcast late this year or early in 2008.

title: A Beloved Brooklyn Pizzeria Is Closed, Again, by the Health Dept.
description: It was about lunchtime yesterday when Eugene Kaplun stood in front of a pizzeria in Brooklyn, not believing what he was seeing. He read the yellow sign. He read the brown sign. Neither was a menu.

title: Giuliani and McCain to Skip Straw Poll in Iowa
description: NEW CASTLE, N.H., June 6  Bucking a ritual for Republican presidential candidates, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain announced Wednesday that they would skip participation in what has been a significant early test of candidate strength, the straw poll in Ames, Iowa, this summer.

title: Easier Connections for the Networked Family
description: Connecting printers and hard drives for use over a network has been a daunting task for even the most knowledgeable. With the Belkin Network U.S.B. Hub, all that is needed is to put a plug into a socket.

title: Europes Central Bank Raises Interest Rates
description: FRANKFURT, June 6  The European Central Bank on Wednesday raised borrowing costs to their highest level in nearly six years, pointing to a humming economy that, while welcome, raised the risk of higher inflation. It also hinted at additional increases, prompting a slide in European stock markets.

title: Arguments Over Removal of Schoolbook on Cuba
description: MIAMI, June 6  A three-judge panel heard arguments on Wednesday over the Miami-Dade County school boards decision to remove a childrens book about Cuba from elementary school libraries. Board members said the book painted too rosy a picture of life in Cuba.

title: Britain: Muhammad Ranks No. 2 in Boys Names
description: Muhammad is now the second most popular name for baby boys in Britain, outstripped only by Jack, The Times of London reported. It said it based its conclusion on an analysis of 3,000 names provided by the Office for National Statistics for births in 2006 and had taken into account 14 different spellings for the name. Using the spelling Muhammad in its article, the newspaper said that the popularity of the name came from the growing number of young Muslim couples having families. Many of these parents chose the name of the prophet in order to show a solidarity with their religion, the newspaper said. According to the Times analysis, Muhammad (5,991) could outscore Jack (6,928) by the end of this year if the names current rate of popularity continued. The names Thomas and Joshua followed Muhammad closely in third and fourth places. No other Muslim names showed up in the list of 20 names published by the newspaper.

title: Manhattan: Police Request Denied in Surveillance Case
description: Lawyers representing protesters who have sued the city, claiming they were improperly arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention, do not have to reveal whether they provided confidential information about the case to the news media, a federal judge has ruled. On Tuesday, Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV of Federal District Court denied a motion by the Police Department to compel statements from the protesters lawyers, saying that the police first had to establish that the information, reported in The New York Times, did not come from sources within the department. The judge said that the information  documents that detail police intelligence gathering  were nonconfidential. Lawyers for the city said yesterday that they were reviewing the decision.

title: Britain: Hedge Fund Creates Research Institute
description: The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, said it would pay 13.8 million ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship. The initiative is a way for Man, which uses mathematical models to make investments, to find mathematicians, who have become increasingly scarce as students planning careers in hedge funds study business instead.

title: Martin Meyerson, 84, Leader at 3 Universities, Dies
description: Martin Meyerson, a former president of the University of Pennsylvania and the State University of New York at Buffalo, died on Saturday near his home in Philadelphia. In 1965, he helped calm tensions as acting chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, in the demonstrations of the Free Speech Movement. He was 84.

title: Connecticut Girl Missing Nearly a Year Is Found in a Closet
description: When the police showed up with search warrants yesterday morning at a scruffy house on a busy street corner in West Hartford, Conn., they assumed they were looking for evidence in the possible killing of a 15-year-old girl, missing for almost a year.

title: Master Stroke
description: While he continues to struggle in the pool with the new kicking technique that he learned at the Race Club Swim Camp, Jim Thornton says hes found that the skill seems natural in open water. On Saturday, he will test that kick in competition for the first time during a two-mile open water swim in western Pennsylvania. As he wrote in this months issue of PLAY, his instructor at the camp in Islamorada, Fla., Jon Olsen, a four-time Olympic gold medalist, focused on five flaws in his freestyle stroke, providing some simple solutions like keeping his head down and back flat. Its amazing how often you have to remind yourself to do these things, he says. Three weeks after the camp, and while fighting a nasty cold, Thornton, 54, swam his fastest 100-yard race in five years, a performance he called a triumph over infirmity and petulance. Thornton recommends the intensive instruction that specialized schools and camps provide. Even those new to the sport, he says, will benefit from learning the right techniques before theyve spent years practicing the wrong thing.

title: Manhattan: Man Charged in Subway Robberies
description: A Bronx man has been arrested and charged with six counts of robbery in connection with a series of robberies on subway trains, the police said yesterday. The man, Miguel Ortiz, 27, of Morris Avenue, was arrested about 7:30 p.m. on Tuesday after a woman exited a No. 2 train at the Wall Street Station and told a police officer that a man on the train had just stolen her necklace and pocketbook. When officers stopped the train at 14th Street, another woman told them that a man had just robbed her. After his arrest, the police said, Mr. Ortiz was also charged with robbing women on other trains and at 109th Street in Manhattan.

title: After the Fight, Bookers Top Antagonist Is Still Standing
description: NEWARK, June 6  It was the kind of triumph that would fill any up-and-coming political force with glee. Mayor Cory A. Booker, who took City Hall in a landslide here last year, threw his newfound heft behind six legislative candidates in Tuesdays Democratic primary and found himself celebrating victory with five of them.

title: Promoting a Thirst for Sprite in Teenage Cellphone Users
description: The Coca-Cola Company is hoping its new mobile site for social networking, Sprite Yard, will become the MySpace of the cellphone world.

title: Switzerland: How tzi the Iceman Died
description: tzi, the Neolithic iceman whose well-preserved body was found in the Alps in 1991, bled to death after being hit in the back by an arrow, Swiss scientists said. The arrowhead itself had already been found, but new CAT scans show that it cut an artery, causing internal bleeding, according to Frank J. Rhli of the Anatomy Institute of Zurich University. A lesion of an artery close to the shoulder has been found, thanks to a CAT scan, he said.

title: Wheres EuroArnold?
description: As long as President Bush does not give German Chancellor Angela Merkel another one of those surprise neck rubs, the Group of 8 meetings should settle into cautious choreography on how to bring down the planets fever and reduce global inequities.

title: Pro Scouts Go Diamond Mining at Los Angeles-Area Powerhouse
description: CHATSWORTH, Calif., June 6  The Chatsworth High School baseball team walked single file through the campus quad Wednesday, one future millionaire after another.

title: Above Midtown, a Lilliputian Universe
description: IVE never really loved miniature worlds because the real thing always seemed so much more compelling. Why put little teacups around a tiny table, when you can have a tea party with real cake? Why stick moss and ferns in a glass box, when you can go wading in the stream where they grow wild along the banks?

title: Congestion Pricing Proposal Races Ahead
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan got a boost today from the governor and the United States secretary of transportation, who announced that New York City was one of nine finalists for a share of $1.1 billion in federal money intended to fight traffic in major urban areas.

title: Injured Alou Is Running; Running Out of Patience
description: Moises Alou is running out of patience. Desperate for a remedy for his ailing left quadriceps, Alou even tried rubbing the muscle with an ointment that he gives to his horses. It did not work.

title: Abbas and Olmert Delay Meeting; Withheld Funds at Issue
description: JERUSALEM, June 6  A meeting scheduled for Thursday between the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, and the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, has been postponed, largely over what appeared to be the issue of the conditions under which Israel would turn over tax revenues it collects for the Palestinians.

title: A 17-Year-Old Turns Pro and Looks to Be the Man
description: There is a touch of Paul Bunyan in the story of Tony Finau, a 17-year-old golfer who stands 6 feet 4 inches, weighs 205 pounds and carries only one wood, 12 irons and a putter in his bag.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) CLASS OF 3000 Andr Benjamin, a k a Andr 3000 of the hip-hop group OutKast, lends his voice to Sunny Bridges in the second season of this vaguely autobiographical animated series about a star who gives up everything to teach a group of musical prodigies in Atlanta. In tonights episode the students decide to replace all their teachers with celebrities, since things are going so well with Sunny.

title: Mets Stumble as Outfield Absorbs Another Hit
description: The Mets night got off on the wrong foot, so to speak, when Damion Easley took himself out of the lineup with an injured right knee. David Newhan, like Easley a natural second baseman, replaced him in left field, and if he had not been available, General Manager Omar Minaya and his staff may have started combing the streets of Flushing for anyone with outfield experience.

title: With Buyout, the Isles Have Finally Seen the Back of Yashin
description: The quirky Islanders conceded perhaps their biggest business blunder in franchise history yesterday when they gave up on Alexei Yashin, buying out the last four years of his weighty 10-year contract.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. I envy my neighbors elegant backyard waterfall. How can I install one?

title: Trading Brews for Bags? High Five!
description: WHILE many city dwellers are escaping to the beach this weekend, the irreverent owners of two Crumpler bag shops in Manhattan are planning a promotion seemingly devised by Homer Simpson: Bring them beer, and in exchange they will give you one of their practical carryalls.

title: Administration Seeks Overhaul of Patent System
description: The Bush administration wants to reform the nations patent system by requiring better information from inventors and allowing public scrutiny of applications, according to the director of the governments patent office.

title: North Korea Fires Missiles Off Coast
description: SEOUL, June 7  North Korea test-fired short-range missiles off its west coast today, drawing an annoyed reaction from the United States and a dismissive one from South Korea.

title: Agreed: We All Love Narciso
description: ON Tuesday evening at Il Cantinori, the Greenwich Village restaurant, Jerry and Jessica Seinfeld were waiting for guests to arrive at a dinner they were giving for their friend Narciso Rodriguez. Mr. Seinfeld had decided to wait at his place at one of the front tables, and though he didnt quite have fork and knife in hand, he looked like any number of American husbands at the dinner hour. Im just here to eat, he said in his mock sensible tone.

title: Louisiana: Public Housing Opens
description: Four public housing duplexes are opening in the devastated Upper Ninth Ward of New Orleans, the secretary of the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development announced at a news conference. The secretary, Alphonso R. Jackson, said that more than 100 housing units would be rebuilt in the neighborhood before the end of the year at the New Desire development, on the site of a city housing project that before Hurricane Katrina was being turned into a mixed-income development. Protesters at the news conference said they were representing thousands of former public-housing residents who have been unable to return to the city because, they said, the federal government refuses to reopen even projects that suffered little damage in the storm.

title: Sudanese Lawyers Receive Guidance for Possible Trials Over Darfur
description: LONDON, June 6  As international pressure increases over the situation in Darfur, Sudanese lawyers are looking ahead to the day when victims of mass rape and torture seek justice in tribunals like the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

title: Nadal Extends His Perfect Record at the French Open
description: PARIS, June 6  For more than two hours, Rafael Nadal played his quarterfinal match at the French Open as if he had never seen the man on the opposite side of the net.

title: Spain: A Madrid Terror Defendant Is Freed
description: One of the 29 defendants in the Madrid train bombings trial has been cleared of all charges and is a free man, CNN reported on its Web site, citing his lawyer and a court spokeswoman. It said prosecutors had dropped all charges against the Moroccan-born defendant, Brahim Moussaten, 23, for lack of evidence. He was accused of having helped two suspects escape after the 2004 attacks, one who is now a defendant in the trial and another who is believed to have died in Iraq as a suicide bomber. Mr. Moussatens brother and an uncle remain on trial.

title: Deranged Man Hurls Himself at Pope, Who Seems Unfazed
description: ROME, June 6  A man the Vatican described as clearly deranged sprang over a barricade on Wednesday and landed a yard or so behind a waving Pope Benedict XVI as he rode in an uncovered popemobile through crowds at St. Peters Square.

title: Brooklyn: Couple Found Dead, With Gun Nearby
description: A man and woman were found dead in their apartment in East New York last night in what investigators are calling a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The couple, identified as Veldora Dixon, 39, and Tito Jemmoot, 35, each had a gunshot wound in the head when they were found in the apartment at 712 Pennsylvania Avenue. Their bodies were found in their bed, and a 9-millimeter gun was found near Mr. Jemmoots body, the police said. The police were alerted to the body about 7:30 p.m. by a friend of the family, who wondered why the couple had missed an appointment.

title: Conrad Black Loses Bid to Recall a Witness
description: CHICAGO, June 6 (Bloomberg News)  The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Blacks co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

title: Handbag Suit Settled
description: Fendi, the Italian maker of luxury products, settled a lawsuit yesterday against Wal-Mart Stores that contended the retailer had sold counterfeit handbags and wallets in its Sams Club stores.

title: omg my mom joined facebook!!
description: I HAVE reached a curious point in life. Although I feel like the same precocious know-it-all cynic I always was, I suddenly am surrounded by younger precocious know-it-all cynics whose main purpose appears to be to remind me that Ive lost my edge.

title: Pennsylvania: Stay Is Extended
description: A federal judge has extended a stay of deportation for Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt. Mr. Khouzam, 38, of Lancaster, Pa., was to be deported June 7, but deportation has been stayed until June 18, court documents show. Mr. Khouzam fled to the United States nine years ago, claiming that he had been detained and tortured because he refused to convert to Islam. He denies the murder accusation. In 2004, a federal appeals court allowed Mr. Khouzam to remain in the United States because it determined that he would quite likely face torture if he returned to Egypt. After being freed from detention in 2006, Mr. Khouzam was detained again May 29, after the Egyptian government provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be tortured.

title: If Only ...the Drama of the Single Child (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Listen Up, Everybody: Im in Menopause
description: IT was 8 a.m. on a Friday and Deb Caruana, 51, a personal trainer in Manhattan, had just finished working out with two of her clients, Jackie Greenberg, an interior designer in her 30s, and her father, Ronald Greenberg, 59, an art dealer.

title: Europe and U.S. Move Toward Climate Deal
description: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 7  The United States agreed today to seriously consider a European proposal to combat global warming by halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, breaking a trans-Atlantic deadlock at a meeting here of the worlds richest industrial nations.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: City Settles Art Dispute

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Mark Harris, who wrote the baseball novel Bang the Drum Slowly and other books, gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the actor who played catcher Bruce Pearson in a 1956 television adaptation of that novel. He was Albert Salmi  not George Peppard, who played another ballplayer, Piney Woods, in the production. The obituary also misidentified a university at which Mr. Harris taught. It was Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

title: Senate Rejects Most Efforts to Change Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The Senate signaled support for major provisions of a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday by rejecting many proposed amendments, including one that would have made it much harder for many illegal immigrants to achieve legal status.

title: Silent Amnesty: Where the Hard Right Goes Soft on Immigration
description: All right, seal the border. Then what?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The listing of lottery results on Monday misstated the dates the winning numbers were drawn. They were from June 3 and June 2, not May 3 and May 2.

title: Campaign Funds for Alaskan; Road Aid to Florida
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  It is no secret that campaign contributions sometimes lead to lucrative official favors. Rarely, though, are the tradeoffs quite as obvious as in the twisted case of Coconut Road.

title: Calendar
description: Design and Technology in Japan

title: When Pardons Turn Political
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  President Bush has pardoned 113 people during his presidency, including a Tennessee bootlegger and a Mississippi odometer cheat.

title: Japan: Executive Leaves Citigroup
description: Citigroup, which recently acquired a majority stake in the Nikko Cordial Corporation, said Brandon Ginsberg had resigned as co-head of equities at its Japanese investment bank. Mr. Ginsberg has already left, said Masufumi Yoshino, head of corporate communications at Nikko Citigroup in Tokyo. No further details were available. The departure is the second change of senior managers at the unit since Citigroup bought 61 percent in April.

title: Romantic Side of Brahms: So Dark, So Brooding
description: An orchestra festival can aspire to cast new light on a particular composer or period, dust off the familiar and uncover the less known. Or it can be a way to keep its musicians busy.

title: Converters Signal a New Era for TVs
description: At midnight on Feb. 17, 2009, the rabbit ears and the rooftop antennas that still guide television signals into nearly 1 of every 5 American homes will be rendered useless  unless they are tethered to a new device, including two versions unveiled yesterday, that the government will spend as much as $80 a household to help families buy.

title: Jim Clark, Sheriff Who Enforced Segregation, Dies at 84
description: Jim Clark, the former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed, however inadvertently, to the success of the voting rights movement, died Monday in Elba, Ala. He was 84 and had been living in a nursing home there.

title: Free Judges Pay
description: SINCE Gov. Eliot Spitzer reappointed me chief judge three months ago, fair pay for our judges has been the consuming issue. In these critical, final days before the Legislature adjourns, New Yorkers deserve a frank explanation of why raising judicial pay and replacing New Yorks broken system of compensation matter  and why so much is at stake if Albany fails to act now.

title: Early Advice on Successor for Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  Five days after senior Justice Department officials gave the White House the first official list of possible United States attorneys to be dismissed, an executive of a conservative legal group offered the Bush administration a recommendation for one replacement candidate, documents released Wednesday show.

title: Italy: 5 Acquitted in Bankers 1982 Death
description: A court in Rome acquitted five people accused of conspiring to murder Roberto Calvi, who was president of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Italys largest private banks, and a financial adviser to the Vatican when he was found hanged under Blackfriars Bridge in London in 1982, his pockets stuffed with rocks, bricks and cash. The presiding judge cited a lack of evidence. The defendants included Giuseppe Cal, known as the Mafias treasurer. Prosecutors argued that Mr. Calvi, known as Gods banker because of his Vatican connections, was killed for stealing Mafia money he was supposed to launder. His death was at first ruled a suicide, but the case was reopened in 2003 as a murder inquiry. With yesterdays court ruling, it remains unsolved.

title: Brazil: Bank Cuts Benchmark Rate
description: The countrys central bank cut the benchmark lending rate to a record low as a rally in Brazils currency holds inflation at an eight-year low. Policy makers, led by the banks president, Henrique Meirelles, 61, lowered the overnight lending rate by half a percentage point, to 12 percent.

title: In a Virtual Universe, the Politics Turn Real
description: The kingdom is in crisis. After pledging to treat its citizens equally, the government stands accused of unfairly favoring one powerful, well-connected political faction. Many citizens have taken to open dissent, even revolt, and some are threatening to emigrate permanently.

title: City Nonprofit Group Gets Money for Merit Pay at Charter Schools
description: The United States Department of Education has awarded a $10.5 million grant to a New York City nonprofit group to create merit pay systems in 10 local charter schools, local and federal education officials announced yesterday.

title: Why Give Away the Airwaves? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Not-So-High- Definition Camcorders
description: Uh-oh, its started. The electronics industry has begun diluting the term high-definition.

title: Goals Are Both Met and Missed in Clinton Fund-Raising
description: As the Clinton presidential campaign raises money this spring, Hillary and Bill Clinton have had many ups and a few downs. Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey is delivering at least $1 million, and their friend Warren Buffett an additional $500,000. And Mrs. Clintons brother Tony kept the peace in the family by coming through with $175,000 at a Pennsylvania fund-raiser  right after his daughters baptism.

title: Bombings Near Iraqi Police Station Kill at Least 9
description: BAGHDAD, June 7  A suicide bomber and bus bomb exploded near a police station in northern Iraq today, killing at least nine people and wounding 22, the authorities said.

title: Brooklyn: Mayor Promotes Congestion Pricing
description: Congestion pricing could help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority avoid fare increases, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Mr. Bloomberg made his comments at a news conference at Pratt Institute the day after an analysis by the citys Independent Budget Office showed that transit fares could go as high as $3 over the next three years. Maybe congestion pricing would generate enough to help them for a long time and postpone a fare increase, said Mr. Bloomberg, who has been pressuring Albany to approve his plan. If you dont give them another source of revenue, then the likelihood of less mass transit and higher fares is clearly there.

title: Fashion Paper Joins Bottom-of-the-Front-Page Club
