description: With todays issue, Womens Wear Daily, the longtime chronicler of the fashion world, becomes the latest newspaper to sell a piece of valuable real estate: advertising space on its front page.

title: Brazilian Numbers Game Ties Officials to Mobsters
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The illegal lottery known as the animal game is as visible a part of the urban landscape here as Ipanema beach or Sugarloaf mountain. On thousands of street corners, vendors sit all day at little wooden booths, pads of paper in hand, taking money from bettors, who return later to check results posted on lampposts or walls.

title: Putin Presents Bush With Plan on Missile Shield
description: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 7  After months of angrily rejecting a White House plan for missile defense in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised President Bush to day with an offer to build a joint system in the former Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

title: Recalling D-Day, Gates Urges a Stronger Alliance
description: COLLEVILLE-SUR-MER, France, June 6  Beside a churning sea and an ocean of white marble crosses, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance that they died defending.

title: AstraZeneca Loses C.F.O. to Goldman Sachs
description: LONDON, June 6  AstraZeneca, Britains second-largest drug maker after GlaxoSmithKline, said on Wednesday that its chief financial officer was leaving to join to Goldman Sachs just months after it paid $15.2 billion to buy MedImmune.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on May 29 about Fallujah, a play in London about the American attack in 2004 on the Iraqi city of that name, misidentified the nationality of a journalist whose account was one of those used for the script. The journalist, Dahr Jamail, is American, not Canadian. The article also referred incorrectly to another documentary play, with which Fallujah was contrasted. That play, Guantnamo: Honor Bound to Defend Freedom,  was a full production; the actors did not sit on the stage and read scripts.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on May 26 about Coca-Colas acquisition of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, misstated a financial result for Glaceau that is considered a crucial indicator of market value. The company had an estimated $350 million in sales, not earnings, in 2006.

title: 60 Products
description: With inspiration from "60 Minutes," gadgets too good to pass up in this summer rerun.

title: omg my mom joined facebook!!
description: In her Cyberfamilias column today in Thursday Styles, Michelle Slatalla writes about how she joined Facebook, the social networking site that recently expanded its membership beyond students, to keep up with her daughter. The teenager viewed it as super creepy.

title: Ducks Capture First Title
Go Team!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Making Waves
description: Images from the movie "Surf's Up."

title: China's Pork Crisis
description: Rising prices is causing Chinese companies to raise prices for exports, particularly on one critical commodity: pork.

title: Thrill of the Heist
description: Images from "Ocean's Thirteen."

title: The Venice Biennale in Pictures
description: Additional images from the 2007 international art exhibition.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Horizon" and "Crazy Mary."

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Bike Racks
description: Josh Simonds, cycling coach, tests bike racks.

title: Inside the Torture Factory
description: Benefiting from a higher budget, Eli Roths follow-up to his generally odious Hostel may sport glossier production values, but its driving motivation  to push the boundaries of exploitative nastiness  remains just as low.

title: Genstar Closes $1.55 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Genstar Capital, a private equity firm focused on midsize companies, said it closed its fifth private equity fund at $1.55 billion. That amount far exceeded the funds initial target of $1 billion. Genstars latest fund was also more than three times the size of the one it raised in 2004.

title: UBS Agrees to $115 Million Enron Payment
description: The Enron Creditors Recovery Corporation, formerly known as Enron, announced on Wednesday that UBS had agreed to pay $115 million to settle litigation over the collapse of Enron.

title: The Brutal Struggle for Survival
description: The events recounted in Miriam are horrific, and the story behind it is moving. Matt Cimber made this World War II drama after his friend Max Guefen told him about his cousin Miriams struggle to survive in German-occupied Lithuania, where her family was robbed, brutalized and eventually shipped to a concentration camp. Unfortunately, the finished product feels like a 1970s exploitation movie in prestige-picture drag.

title: Birds on Boards
description: Ever since Luc Jacquet's endearing documentary "March of the Penguins" persuaded Hollywood that penguins are the new Bambis, we have endured singing, wisecracking and even tap-dancing versions. Now, treading eagerly on the flippers of last year's "Happy Feet," comes "Surf's Up," a computer-animated comedy featuring birds on boards.

title: A Rockers Climb From Despair
description: Early in the documentary "You're Gonna Miss Me," the film's subject, the psychedelic rocker and drug-damaged schizophrenic Roky Erickson, ambles through his Austin, Tex., home, clutching a Mr. Potato Head doll. It's a potent image that's all the more effective for being tossed off: Mr. Erickson, the lead singer of the 13th Floor Elevators and maybe the most influential 1960s pop star that most folks haven't heard of, has had so little control over his life and image for so many years that he's become a goofy blank slate.

title: Conrad Black Loses Bid to Recall a Witness
description: The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Blacks co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

title: Citigroup and NASD Settle BellSouth Case
description: NASD, a regulator of brokerage firms, said on Wednesday that Citigroup will pay $15.2 million to settle claims that its brokers had coaxed employees of BellSouth into retiring early on exaggerated projections for investment returns.

title: I.B.M.s $1.6 Billion Tax Shelter Now an I.R.S. Target
description: For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

title: Criticism Mounts Over Yahoo Chiefs Pay Package
description: Yahoos Terry Semel may be heading for a pay cut. As the Internet giant lags behind Google and with its much ballyhooed Panama project  the nickname for the firms overhaul of its search advertising system  yet to materialize, investors and industry observers are casting a critical eye on the chief executives $71 million compensation package.

title: V.C.s Just Cant Get Enough Clean Tech
description: Recently published research confirms what any venture capital investor would tell you: clean tech is hot.

title: Canadas Stelco Likely to Be Sold Whole, C.E.O. Says
description: Stelco, the Canadian steel company that announced last week that it is exploring the possibility of sale, is likely to be sold whole rather than in parts, its chief executive said Wednesday.

title: British Hotel Group Drops $3.4 Billion I.P.O.
description: A British hotel group, Vector pulled the plug on its planned 1.7 billion pound ($3.4 billion) initial public offering Wednesday night after investors failed to support what would have been the biggest share sale in London this year.

title: Cerberus Affiliates Seek to Raise $11 Billion
description: Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that recently agreed to buy Chrysler, has created affiliates that plan to raise more than $11 billion for investments, Reuters reported, citing regulatory filings. The six affiliates have already raised about $10.5 billion, Reuters said.

title: Spain Orders Search and Capture of Odysseys Ships
description: The story of the discovery of a disputed undersea trove of gold and silver valued at $500 million by an American company continues to unfold like a pirate adventure.

title: Man Group Goes Back to School
description: The Man Group, the largest publicly traded hedge fund in the world, is sending future hedge fund managers back to school. Man said on Wednesday that it would pay 13.8 million pounds ($27 million) to set up a research institute at Oxford University. The funds, to be paid over five years, will create the Oxford-Man Institute of Quantitative Finance and endow a professorship.

title: Buyout Shops Sue Aeroflex Over Break-Up Fee
description: Two private equity firms whose takeover offer for Aeroflex was scuttled last month in favor of a competing bid are suing the company over the size of a break-up fee that was part of their original purchase agreement.

title: Alcoa Files for Antitrust Approval for Possible Alcan Deal
description: The aluminum giant Alcoa, taking the next step in trying to take over its reluctant acquisition target Alcan, said Wednesday it had filed with antitrust authorities in the United States to gain approval for the $27 billion hostile deal.

title: New Sun Nutrition Swallows $25 Million
description: New Sun Nutrition, a maker of energy drinks, has swallowed $25 million in a first round of funding from Oak Investment Partners. Oak invested alongside Radar Partners and Thomas Weisel, the chairman and chief executive of Thomas Weisel Partners, the San Francisco boutique investment bank.

title: Amgen Doubles Down on Future Products
description: The Biotech giant Amgen said Wednesday it would buy Alantos Pharmaceuticals for $300 million, marking its second acquisition of a private biotech company this week. Alantos lead drug is a small-molecule treatment for Type 2 diabetes.

title: Hedge Funds Put the Squeeze on Tribune Buyout
description: Sam Zells agreement to buy Tribune, the publisher of the Los Angeles Times and owner of the Chicago Cubs, prompted three hedge funds to seek profits in the fine print of $1.26 billion of bonds, Bloomberg News said.

title: Redstone: No Viacom or CBS Buyout on the Horizon
description: Sumner Redstone, who controls both CBS and Viacom, said Wednesday that, despite rampant speculation on Wall Street, he has no plans to take either of those media giants private. That has been suggested to me and Philippe and to Les, Mr. Redstone said during an interview on CNBC, referring to the chiefs of Viacom and CBS, respectively.

title: British Regulators Approve Verint Deal
description: British antitrust regulators have cleared the acquisition last month of Witness Systems by a software provider in the United States, Verint Systems, for $950 million. In a report released Wednesday, the British Office of Free Trade wrote that the purchase is not expected to result in less competition in Britain.

title: Venice Biennale: Intimations of Mortality
description: The weather here keeps threatening to take a Thomas-Mannish turn, that hateful sultriness in the narrow streets that hangs low, like exhalations, not dissipating. But aside from a little rain, the thousands of art patrons, collectors, dealers, artists and writers streaming along the water toward the exhibitions at the Giardini and the Arsenale have been lucky.

title: Monster C.F.O.s Resignation Reignites Buyout Rumors
description: Shares of Monster Worldwide, parent of the jobs Web site Monster.com, fell more than 2 percent on Wednesday after it said its chief financial officer, Larry Baker, was resigning in a management shake-up. Timothy Yates will succeed Mr. Baker, who was leaving to pursue other interests, the company said.

title: Columnist Seeks to Decode Wall Streets Deal-Speak
description: Wall Street has its own language that requires some insider knowledge to speak fluently, according to MarketWatchs David Weidner. So, in his latest, column, Mr. Weidner has put some of the most recent headlines through his decoder.

title: Hedge Funds Accuse Bear of Loan Market Manipulation
description: Hedge fund managers are accusing Bear Stearns of trying to manipulate the market in securities based on subprime mortgages, according to press reports.

title: British Billionaire to Buy Newcastle United
description: Newcastle United, the English Premier League soccer club, will be sold to a British sportswear tycoon, Mike Ashley, in a cash deal valuing it at about 134 million pounds ($267 million). The deal comes after Newcastles chairman, Freddy Shepherd, and his family agreed to sell their 28 percent stake in the club to Mr. Ashley.

title: This Judge Is No Longer Rated
description: Gerald P. Garson, the disgraced former State Supreme Court judge, has been sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison for bribery and official misconduct, as Michael Brick reported yesterday.

title: Activist Shareholders Demand A Vodafone Shake-Up
description: John Mayo, the former deputy chief executive of Marconi, is backing a group of investors who are seeking to restructure Vodafone and unlock up to 38 billion ($76 billion) in value from the mobile phone group.

title: At Home in a Pristine Box
description: Memories of life and death in an architectural masterwork.

title: Gardening in the heart of Paris
description: For a few weeks, urban dwellers can revel in a vast, verdant garden that has sprouted outside Paris City Hall. Alongside a giant, gurgling water can and an oversized armchair, upholstered in natural vines, are thousands of plants, trees and micro gardens grouped by categories to tickle the senses or attract butterflies.

title: Under Pressure, Biomet Agrees to Higher Takeover Bid
description: Biomet, the orthopedic device maker, accepted a sweetened takeover bid of $11.4 billion on Thursday from a group of private equity firms after an influential shareholder advisory firm urged the companys shareholders to reject a previous $10.9 billion offer.

title: Evercore Names New Finance Chief
description: Evercore Partners, the investment banking boutique, said its chief financial officer, David Wezdenko, was leaving the firm, to be succeeded by Robert Walsh, a senior partner at Deloitte & Touche.

title: Two Views on How the Buyout Boom Might End
description: Much of Wall Street has been trying to figure out what factors could bring an end to the recent run of big buyout deals. Wilbur Ross, the billionaire financier, has his own view, and it sounds pretty grim.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Owner Casts Eye on Dow Jones
description: Another investor has expressed interest in the idea of putting together a rival bid for Dow Jones, the family-controlled publishing company that is fielding a $5 billion takeover offer from Rupert Murdochs News Corporation.

title: Currents
description: Frank Gehry's sculptural style comes to the table and more.

title: Monaco Grand Prix retrospective
description: There is probably no other Formula One event that invites a photographer to go quite so mad as at Monaco. I have just completed a day-by-day photo retrospective of the Monaco Grand Prix from the Wednesday to the Sunday, with explanatory descriptions. It seems that it is now or never to take a look at this before we become involved in the Canadian Grand Prix, for which practice starts tomorrow.

title: The Unpardonable
description: Free Scooter! But dont pardon him. William Otis, special counsel for President George H.W. Bush and a former federal prosecutor, thinks Scooter Libbys lies were too damaging to the fundamental rule of law that the grand jury is entitled to every mans evidence for Libby to merit a full pardon from the current President Bush.

title: Paris Hilton Leaves Prison for House Arrest
description: After a four night stay in jail, Paris Hilton was released early this morning and put under house arrest, The Los Angeles Sheriffs Department announced today.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Porcelain, recycled plastic and a bronze stump adorn the lawn.

title: AIDS Awareness in India
description: If the results of a survey are correct, India is no longer the worlds supposed leader of people infected with AIDS.

title: Congestion Pricing Racing Forward
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal got a huge boost this morning.

title: Wachovia to Hire 300 Private Bankers
description: Wachovia said on Thursday it would hire nearly 300 private bankers to cater to affluent customers as it revamps its wealth management unit. Over the next three years, the Charlotte bank plans to more than double the 240 relationship managers in its private banking unit aimed at clients with investable assets between $250,000 and $5 million. The bankers will target high-growth markets such as Florida, Texas, California and New York.

title: 2008: Campaign Calculations
description: Were not even into the middle of June and the fund-raising expectations game for the second quarter ending this month is already in high gear, as is the decision-making by some campaigns looking ahead to spending in the third quarter this summer.

title: Edwards Tackles Are We Safer Now?
description: Former North Carolina Senator John Edwards is set to hold a news conference in New York today to detail his own national security plan.Excerpts of his speech show that he will continue the riff off of whether the nation is safer now, a theme produced heated exchanges during the Democratic debate on Sunday, as he criticized the views of his rivals, especially Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Venice Biennale: Prankster at Work
description: If there is a court jester for this far-flung kingdom of art called the Venice Biennale, it is a Romanian artist named Dan Perjovschi, who has been making spontaneous, hilarious and scathing drawings on the walls of museums and other art spaces for a decade.

title: PNC Financial Acquires a New Jersey Bank for $403 Million
description: The PNC Financial Services Group said Thursday it would pay $403 million to acquire the Yardville National Bancorp a central New Jersey bank that has struggled with regulatory problems and complaints from its largest shareholder.

title: The Best Croissant in Paris
description: One of the great pleasures of returning to France on an overnight flight from North America or Asia is arriving in the worlds most beautiful city as it wakes.

title: Time Inc. Chief Imagines Marriage With Scripps
description: Ann Moores dream house would apparently include parts of E.W. Scripps.

title: Clintons Block Party
description: Although the Clinton event last night in a downtown D.C. parking lot was billed as Club 44, the thousands of women who streamed in and out didnt quite fit the clubbing demographic.

title: Breaking Down the Walls Between Mac OS X and Windows
description: I'm a bi-platform kinda guy. Not just because I need to be conversant in both Mac OS X and Windows for my job, but also because my life revolves around certain Mac programs and certain Windows programs.

title: Senate Barbs Fly on Immigration
description: The intense Senate debate over immigration has produced some memorable exchanges with political overtones.

description: Today we do a little follow-up on some Screens fairy tales:

title: Affordable Hotels in Moscow and St. Petersburg
description: I am traveling with a friend to St. Petersburg and Moscow mid-July, and Im looking for affordable hotels near the city center or main tourist attractions. Any suggestions?

title: Housing With Higher Rates
description: Wall Street wizards have been expecting higher long-term interest rates for a couple of years, but some now seem surprised they are arriving. The yield on the 10-year United States Treasury note climbed above 5 percent today, and there have been rises in most other countries as well. Maybe China is less willing to buy American and European bonds. Maybe there is something else.

title: Breaking Down the Walls Between Mac OS X and Windows
description: Im a bi-platform kinda guy. Not just because I need to be conversant in both Mac OS X and Windows for my job, but also because my life revolves around certain Mac programs and certain Windows programs.

description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

description: The rule of unintended consequences strikes again.

title: Time Warner Plans AOL Decision This Year
description: Heres a reason to look forward to 2008: By then, the nonstop speculation about the fate of AOL should finally be over. Richard Parsons, the chief executive of Time Warner, said Thursday that the media conglomerate would make a decision on AOLs future by the end of this year.

title: The Forgotten 90s Classic
description: Reading the Rob Sass article on TVR last weekend, I was sad to see it end with TVRs 1987 departure from America, which meant no mention of the Peter Wheeler-era Griffith, possibly the most important TVR of my lifetime.

title: On Second Day of Finals, All Games Are Drawn
description: Levon Aronian, Alexander Grischuk and Peter Leko preserved their leads in the candidates finals by drawing the second games of their matches. The other match between Gata Kamsky of the United States and Boris Gelfand of Isreal remained tied after their second draw. The matches are being held in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers to the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

title: Amaranth to Pension Fund: You Knew the Risks
description: Amaranth Advisors has a response for managers of San Diego Countys pension fund, who are smarting over big losses they took when the hedge fund collapsed. It goes something like this: We warned you.

title: A Paris arrival
description: 81 Victor Hugo

title: In Dow Jones Bidding, (Vague) New Names Surface
description: A Los Angeles billionaire and the owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer have already acknowledged that they are interested in a potential counteroffer for Dow Jones & Company. Now it appears that YouTubes Chad Hurley or the folks behind Lonelygirl15 may want in as well.

title: What About Paris?
description: At a press conference today in New York City, John Edwards tackled some of the more weighty topics in the race for the White House. After reminding reporters that terrorism is still alive, and ongoing, and a serious threat to America and to the rest of the world and outlining his plan for a 10,000 member Marshal Corps to win back the hearts and minds of people around the world, one intrepid member of the press corps attempted to hold the feet of Mr. Edwards to the fire on what is surely the issue on the minds of most Americans.

title: Jimmy Buffetts first show in Paris
description: Jimmy Buffett has romanticized Paris in a number of his songs, and the singer, a self-described Francophile, has even owned an apartment in the city. But he has waited until now to play his first-ever Paris concert.

title: Win Recognition
description: E.M. Rose Builders, Branford, CT - Owner Eric Rose has a goal to be the best and his industry has awarded him for his achievement.

title: Do  What Works
description: Done Galleries, Sydney, Australia - Painter and entrepreneur Ken Done explains that the market will tell you what to make and how to price it.

title: Listen to Customers
description: Record Technology, Camarillo, CA - Owner Don MacInnis tells how his top-selling product was invented by customers.

title: Acquire the Competition
description: Caf Pilon, Miami, Florida - Enrique Souto and his brothers have grown the business their father started by buying their competitors.

title: Choose A Powerful Name
description: Bridgecreek, Huntington Beach, CA - Founder Frank Jao's vision was to build bridges between his country of origin and his new home in America.

title: Lashing Out at Hiltons Release
description: The best of the deluge of Lede comments and reactions from around the Web on the end of Paris Hiltons prison term:

title: Borrowing Less
description: The Federal Reserves flow of funds data came out today, and one interesting thing is how rapidly mortgage borrowing is falling. Americans borrowed (on a net basis) $127.6 billion in the first quarter of this year, a figure that is only 40 percent of the borrowing in the peak quarter, the third quarter of 2005.

title: PlaNYC Bill Introduced in State Senate
description: Just in, courtesy of Aaron Naparstek, the guru of Streetsblog: the 154-page bill [pdf] introducing Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs comprehensive PlaNYC program to make New York City environmentally sustainable. Expect policy analysts, lobbyists and legislative aides to be poring over this legislation with a magnifying glass over the next few days and weeks.

title: You Win-Lose Some
Venice Biennale: The Event in Pictures
description: A slide show of additional images from the Biennale.

title: NYSE Euronext Strives to Go Global, but What to Call It?
description: Less than a year has passed since the New York Stock Exchange merged with Euronext, forming NYSE Euronext and a major player in the global exchange market. Now, it seems, the firm is hungry for even more partners.

title: Biden Gets a Brief Iraq Moment
description: Although Senator Joe Biden took the lead weeks ago in calling for a 90-minute debate on Iraq among the presidential candidates, his plans to take part in a forum last night on that very topic were all but derailed by the Senates deliberation on the immigration bill.

title: Signs: The Seed Is Planted
description: A strange feeling came over me as the C-130 landed at Fort Bragg, N.C. After 11 months in Iraq, I wasnt scared any more, but it felt like the rest of America was.

title: Yanks Reel In College Righty
description: On the day he would be drafted into professional baseball, Andrew Brackman went fishing on the Ohio River with his family. Brackman, who lives in Cincinnati, said he fishes a lot but never catches anything.

title: End of (School) Year Frenzy
description: That time of year thou mayst in me beholdWhen sitters to their far-off homes hath fled,When camp and health forms make my blood run coldAnd all I want to do is lie in bed.In me thou seest the frenzied wide-eyed stareOf one whose work time has been cut in twoAnd yet cannot resist the year-end snareOf read-a-louds, teacher gifts, and hot glue.In me thou seest the envy, vile and greenOf those who smile while Spring turns into heatSuiting up for tennis, Pilates, tooAnd sporting perfectly manicured feet.This thou perceivst, all around me I hearOthers expressing their equal ill cheer.

title: Blairs Accord With Libya Worries Kin From Lockerbie
description: LONDON, June 7  Alex Salmond, the newly elected first minister of Scotland, expressed concern Thursday that the British government had struck a deal that might permit the only person convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing to return to Libya to complete his sentence.

title: For Dont Ask, Dont Tell, Split on Party Lines
Argentine Visitor Arrives With Armloads of Rhythm
description: The Argentine pianist and composer Guillermo Klein brought his big band to the Village Vanguard for the first time last summer, and New York reacted as it should. Word got around, and an artist whose music was easy to follow even if its referents were hard to determine  having crafted his individual, worldly, not-quite-jazz in various basements in New York, Buenos Aires and Barcelona  became a little less obscure that week.

title: Brooklyn: DNA Evidence in Bouncers Murder Case
description: Prosecutors have disclosed DNA evidence in a triple-murder case against a bar bouncer connected to the Sweet Cherry strip parlor in Sunset Park. Months after the killings, the defendant, Stephen Sakai, was arrested carrying a washcloth with what appeared to be a bloodstain, his lawyer, Kleon C. Andreadis, said yesterday after a pretrial hearing in State Supreme Court. The Brooklyn district attorneys office is expected to try to link the DNA to Mr. Sakai. Mr. Sakai and two of the victims in the case, both of whom were killed in 2005, worked or spent time at the Sweet Cherry, which the authorities finally shut down last year after nearly a decade of trying. In a separate case in Manhattan, Mr. Sakai is charged with shooting four patrons outside a dance club in Chelsea in May 2006, killing one.

title: Brooklyn: Drug Arrests Near Childrens Museum
description: The authorities yesterday interrupted a sophisticated drug organization operating in Crown Heights, said Charles J. Hynes, the district attorney. Raiding several safe houses around the Brooklyn Childrens Museum, the police arrested 11 people, ranging in age from 23 to 67, on conspiracy, drug and weapons charges. Investigators secretly videotaped suspects weighing and measuring drugs, then bought or seized 2.8 pounds of cocaine and 8 pounds of marijuana, Mr. Hynes said. They also seized binoculars and radio equipment used for countersurveillance of the police.

title: Part Coach, Part Motivator and 100 Percent Welcomed
description: CHICAGO, June 7  Tyler Clippard had just earned his first major league victory when a call came for him on the cellphone of a Yankees staff member. Clippard, 22, was in the visitors clubhouse at Shea Stadium, and the pitcher with more victories than anyone alive wanted to talk to him. Roger Clemens was on the line.

title: House Votes to Expand Stem Cell Research
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  The House gave final Congressional approval on Thursday to legislation aimed at easing restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research, but Democratic leaders in both chambers conceded they were short of the votes needed to override a veto threatened by President Bush.

title: Manhattan: Police Department Starts Video Podcasts
description: The Police Department has begun a monthly series of video podcasts offering an inside look at the department, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. The videos will be available for download through the iTunes service to iPod users and can also be viewed online at the Police Departments Web site, nyc.gov/html/nypd/home.html. The first episode features a six-minute look at the departments harbor and scuba units.

title: Manhattan: Two Fatally Shot
description: Two young men were fatally shot on a street in East Harlem early yesterday, the police said. The victims, Manuel Sabatera, 27, and Joshua Agard, 17, were each shot several times about 4:30 a.m. as they gathered with others who were listening to music and playing dice in front of 404 East 105th Street, an investigator said. A separate group approached Mr. Sabatera and Mr. Agard, with at least one of them firing a .40-caliber handgun, the investigator said. The investigator said Mr. Agard appeared to be the target. Mr. Sabatera was pronounced dead at Metropolitan Hospital Center; Mr. Agard was pronounced dead at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday, the police said. Among detectives leading theories was that drugs played a role, the police said.

title: Edwards Answers His Critics With Attack on Terror Doctrine
description: Former Senator John Edwards struck back yesterday at Republican critics who have called him soft on the war on terrorism, saying the partys candidates seem intent on trying to one-up each other in trying to be a bigger, badder, George Bush.

title: Paying the Price on Both Ends of a Hangmans Rope
description: Timothy Spall is the quintessential blundering bloke in English movies. Youve seen him in several Mike Leigh films, playing a portly working-class oaf with a sloping chin and chipmunk teeth, wearing a look of wide-eyed bafflement as he lumbers through life. Usually his characters convey a profound reticence. But when the stored-up indignities visited upon them become too much to bear, they can explode with apoplectic outrage.

title: Getting a Deal on Some Pricey Political Real Estate
description: DES MOINES  Eight years ago this weekend, a campaign plane with the name Great Expectations landed in Iowa. George W. Bush was at the top of the manifest, making his maiden voyage to a state that would launch his candidacy for the White House.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 7, 2007

title: In a Connecticut River, Fatter Fish and Happier Fishermen
description: THE Housatonic River, which flows through western Connecticut to Long Island Sound, made local headlines earlier this spring for flooding that uprooted trees and damaged homes. The bigger story, though, at least in the eyes of fishermen, is the river's improved health.

title: A TB Patient Turns to His Inner Lawyer
description: ATLANTA, June 7  Until last week, Theodore and Andrew Speaker had devoted their legal skills to the workaday custody disputes and personal injury claims that clients brought to their small father-son practice here.

title: The Season for Sea Turtles
description: BARELY an hour into a beach excursion one May morning last year, Lisa Ellington had, as she describes it, the experience of a lifetime. A longtime lover of marine life, Ms. Ellington, who lives in San Antonio, had dreamed of seeing a sea turtle emerge from the surf to lay its eggs on the beach. Despite knowing that her chances were slim, she drove two hours to Padre Island National Seashore on the Texas coast, where rare Kemps ridley sea turtles were known to nest.

title: Agency Sides With Ford in Parts Case
description: The Ford Motor Company won a ruling yesterday that barred the import of copycat grilles, headlamps and other parts for its top-selling F-150 truck.

title: Former Killing Ground Becomes Shrine to Stalins Victims
description: BUTOVO, Russia  Barbed wire still lines the perimeter of the secret police compound here on the southern edge of Moscow where more, perhaps far more, than 20,000 people were shot and buried from August 1937 through October 1938, at the height of Stalins purges.

title: Paraiso del Mar
description: WHAT Oceanfront residential resort.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column on Tuesday, about a decision by the London office of Saatchi & Saatchi to feature images of Kurt Cobain and other dead rock stars in ads for Dr. Martens footwear, included an outdated reference to an agency that arranges licensing deals involving deceased celebrities. The agency, Roger Richman, has been incorporated into Corbis; it is no longer a stand-alone agency.

title: Spitzer Has a New Plan for Racing Franchise
description: ALBANY, June 7  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has a proposal that would keep horse racing in the hands of the New York Racing Association, but would give one of the three private groups bidding on the states horse racing franchise control over future casino gambling operations.

title: A Snake Around Her Neck and a Tragedy in Her Past
description: Bindi Irwin is 8 years old, she has straight bangs and crimped pigtails, and she has already appeared on both Larry King Live and The Ellen DeGeneres Show. The daughter of the celebrity naturalist Steve Irwin, who was killed by a stingray in his native Australia last year, Miss Irwin has become a kind of Shirley Temple of the wildlife conservation movement. Im trying to get across the message that dont be afraid of animals, People magazine quoted her as saying after her fathers death. Theyre just put on this earth to help the environment and everything like that.

title: To Gain Among Muslims, Indonesia Offers to Mediate Middle East Disputes
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  In April, Indonesia held a gathering of Sunni and Shiite clerics and scholars in an effort to contribute to reconciliation in Iraq, where the death toll is overwhelmingly the result of Muslims killing Muslims.

title: The Yankees Draft a 6-Foot-10 Pitcher, Elating at Least One of Their Players
description: CHICAGO, June 7  Before the 2006 season, Alex Rodriguez visited his neighbor Ramon Corona at North Carolina State. Corona is the Wolfpacks second baseman, and Rodriguez attended a weekend series. He watched from behind the catcher as a 6-foot-10 right-hander warmed up.

title: Mother Awarded $10 Million Asks Reopening of Police Case
description: The mother of an unarmed man killed by an undercover police officer seven years ago called on the Bronx district attorneys office yesterday to reopen a criminal investigation after a jury awarded her $10.45 million for the wrongful death of her son.

description: People

title: Lies, Sighs and Politics
description: In Tuesdays Republican presidential debate, Mitt Romney completely misrepresented how we ended up in Iraq. Later, Mike Huckabee mistakenly claimed that it was Ronald Reagans birthday.

title: Dow Jones Enhances the Severance Packages for Senior Managers
description: Dow Jones & Company may or may not be close to a sale, but yesterday it sweetened the pot for managers in case of a takeover.

title: Some Small Law Firms Find Strength in Numbers
description: Steven Spielvogel, a lanky 40-year-old lawyer who, with his angular looks and jet black hair, resembles Ric Ocasek of the 1980s band the Cars, has been on something of a tour of his own.

title: Fire at Motel in Georgia Kills 5 People and Injures 6
description: ATLANTA, June 7  Five people died and six were injured after a fast-moving fire engulfed a motel in Riverdale, Ga., on Thursday morning.

description: AROUND TOWN

title: U.S. Planning to Ease Rules on Passports, Official Says
description: HOUSTON, June 7  Responding to anguished travelers at risk of being grounded by a broken passport system, the government is expected to announce on Friday that it will ease its rules for summer travel in the Western Hemisphere, a Bush administration official said Thursday.

title: Italy: Terrorism Suspects Held in Italy and Britain
description: The authorities in Milan issued arrest warrants for nine men suspected of providing logistical and financial support to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, North Africas most active terrorist group. By evening, at least two of the suspects were in Italian custody. British authorities made a separate arrest in North London as part of the sweep. The North African group, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, claimed responsibility for the suicide bombings in Algiers in April that killed 33 people.

title: The Shame of the Cherokee Nation
description: Many members of Congress were rightly outraged by the Cherokee Nations decision earlier this year to revoke the tribal citizenship of about 2,800 descendants of slaves once owned by the tribe. The tribes leaders have since tried to avoid any punishment by restoring partial rights to some black members. Congress should disregard that ruse and move ahead with legislation that would force the Cherokee to comply with their treaty obligations and court decisions that guarantee black members full citizenship rights, including the right to vote and hold tribal office.

title: Britain: Cadbury Acquires Gum Maker in Turkey
description: Cadbury Schweppes said it had agreed to buy Intergum of Turkey for $450 million to gain almost half of the countrys chewing gum market. Intergum, which has a 46 percent market share in Turkey, will be acquired from the Amram family, Cadbury said. Cadbury, which is based in London, is in the process of selling or spinning off its North American soft drinks unit, which makes Dr Pepper and 7Up.

description: To the Editor:

title: Vodafone Investors Seek Verizon Wireless Spinoff
description: LONDON, June 7  The Vodafone Group, the worlds largest cellphone company, said on Thursday that it had received a letter from a group of shareholders asking it to return as much as 38 billion ($75 billion) to investors in part by spinning off its stake in Verizon Wireless.

title: Rise in Chinas Pork Prices Signals End to Cheap Output
description: GAOYAO, China, June 1  Few things are as essential to the Chinese as their pigs.

title: Once More, Cows Attract a Visitor to New York City
description: Many things draw visitors to New York: Broadway musicals, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, games at Yankee Stadium.

title: Hartford: Commission Has Authority Over Sculpture
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the Historic District Commission of Fairfield has the authority to rule on whether an 80-foot-long sculpture may be installed in front of a house in the towns Southport Historic District. The homeowner, Andrew J. Hall, had argued that the artwork, by the German sculptor Anselm Kiefer, was not subject to commission approval because it could not legally be considered a structure. The Supreme Court affirmed a lower courts decision, saying the six-ton concrete and steel work fit within the commissions jurisdiction. Mr. Hall said the decision meant the town forfeits a major sculpture by one of the worlds greatest artists. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Trading One Beach Retreat for Another
description: PROVINCETOWN was good to Mark Doty and his partner, Paul Lisicky, who shared an 18th-century Cape-style house there for the first 10 years of their 12-year relationship. Mr. Doty had gone there first, to seek solace with a former partner who was dying of AIDS, and wound up staying on for years with Mr. Lisicky. It was the ideal place for the pair of writers  rich with both literary and gay history, and home to an inspiring mix of dreamy landscapes and thrumming resort-town life.

title: Strolling Within the Strange World of Blue Velvet
description: What would it be like to step inside a movie?

title: Flights in Northeast Face Delays
description: Thunderstorms and computer failure combined to produce extensive air traffic delays in the Northeast this afternoon, with airports reporting departure delays of two hours or longer.

title: New Jersey Senate Panel Supports Penalty for Smoking in Cars With Children Aboard
description: TRENTON, June 7  Smoking in New Jersey has been banned from the workplace, public buildings, bars, restaurants and even large swaths of the casino floors in Atlantic City. The next frontier is the family car with children aboard.

title: Singing His Heart Out for the City of New Orleans
description: Im not going to dwell on it; Im tired of talking about it, the singer John Boutt said at Joes Pub on Wednesday night. He was referring to the state of affairs in New Orleans, where he was born and reared and where he still resides. And while the second part of his statement seemed true enough, the first part quickly proved otherwise.

title: Bork v. Yale Club: Jurist Seeks Redress Over a Fall
description: In his days as a legal scholar, Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, engaged, as many scholars do, in high-minded debates about the august issues of the law. He wrote widely  sometimes controversially  about antitrust issues, the right to privacy and the limitations of the First Amendment.

title: Pennsylvania Tries to Sell Itself as Backup for Wall Street During a Disaster
description: Hoping to capitalize on fears of the chaos another terrorist attack might cause in New Yorks financial industry, Pennsylvania officials are promoting a corner of their state as Wall Street West.

title: Quirks and Attitude to Burn
description: New York galleries are in the habit of saving their best  their newest, boldest, oddest  for last, for the annual blitz of end-of-season group shows that give exposure to underseen artists and freelance gigs to promising curators, while the commercial heat is down.

title: Mexicos Court Limits Reach of Big Media
description: MEXICO CITY, June 7  The Mexican Supreme Court overwhelmingly voted Thursday to declare parts of a new media law unconstitutional, a blow to the countrys two main broadcasters who had hoped to extend their dominance in television to the Internet and telephone service.

title: Greys Star Said to Be Off the Show
description: Isaiah Washington, a star of the hit ABC television series Greys Anatomy, who became embroiled in a furor after he twice used an anti-gay slur against a co-star, will not return in the fall, an executive informed of the decision said last night.

title: Its Subpoena Time
description: For months, senators have listened to a parade of well-coached Justice Department witnesses claiming to know nothing about how nine prosecutors were chosen for firing. This week, it was the turn of Bradley Schlozman, a former federal attorney in Missouri, to be uninformative and not credible. It is time for Senator Patrick Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, to deliver subpoenas that have been approved for Karl Rove, former White House counsel Harriet Miers and their top aides, and to make them testify in public and under oath.

title: Spurs Show That James Has Much to Learn
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 7  The education of LeBron James, rising N.B.A. star, took on a decidedly rougher edge Thursday night, right around the time that he at last encountered the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Selanne Takes Road Less Traveled on Way to the Stanley Cup Title
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 7  Even when their logo was a cartoon, when their arena was a pond, when their name was a punch line, Teemu Selanne took them seriously.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday in the special Circuits section about the trend for consumers to have two or more models of some digital devices misstated the storage capacity of one model of Apples iPhone, which will be on the market at the end of the month. The model, which is to cost $599, has eight gigabytes of storage, not five.

title: Gaza: One Dead in Factional Firefight
description: A Palestinian man was killed and at least nine other people were wounded in factional fighting in the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah. Each of the rival factions, Hamas and Fatah, blamed the other for starting the shooting. The dead man belonged to Fatah. A report this week by the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens Rights said 616 Palestinians had been killed in internal fighting since the beginning of 2006. In the first half of May, fierce factional clashes left about 50 dead in Gaza. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, warned this week that the Palestinians were on the verge of civil war.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page News Analysis article yesterday about the possibility of a presidential pardon for I. Lewis Libby Jr., who was convicted of lying to investigators in the C.I.A. leak case, referred incorrectly to Terence Hunt, a reporter for The Associated Press, in describing a scene in which President Bush cut off one reporters follow-up question about a pardon by moving on to another reporter who asked about Russia. Mr. Hunt was the reporter who tried to ask the follow-up question about the pardon; he was not the reporter who changed the subject to the new tensions about Russia. And it was an unidentified reporter  not Mr. Bush  who said, Nice going, Terry.

title: Biomet Accepts Sweetened Takeover Offer
description: A group of private equity firms bidding for Biomet, a maker of artificial joints, sweetened its offer to $11.4 billion after a prominent shareholder adviser criticized its previous bid as too low.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on May 15 about the International Atomic Energy Agencys latest assessment of Irans nuclear program referred imprecisely to information found in a design document that the agencys inspectors have seen in Iran but that the Iranian authorities have declined to explain. The information shows how to make uranium into hemispheres, not spheres. (Depending on their precise design, some types of hemispheres of highly enriched uranium can be suitable for manufacturing a nuclear weapon.) (Go to Article)

title: Congressman Pleads Not Guilty to Bribery
description: Representative William Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat, pleaded not guilty today to federal charges that he solicited hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes while trying to arrange business deals in Africa.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on May 21, about veganism, mischaracterized an aspect of traditional vegetarian Indian diets. Generally, these diets are lacto-vegetarian; they do not include eggs.

title: Biased Drug Research (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Compromise on Global Warming Plan Averts Impasse at Group of 8 Meeting
description: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 7  The United States agreed Thursday to consider seriously a European plan to combat global warming by cutting in half worldwide greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, averting a trans-Atlantic deadlock at a meeting here of the worlds richest industrial nations.

title: Tee Time Anytime
description: WHO Kevin Hoyle, 55, owner of a wealth management firm, from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: G-8 Summit Winds Down With Africa Aid Pledge
description: HEILIGENDAMM, Germany, June 8  As the Group of 8 summit meeting moved toward a conclusion, leaders reaffirmed a 2005 pledge of $60 billion to counter HIV and other illnesses in Africa, but did not set any new deadlines for delivering the aid.

title: Child Rape Trial Relies on Confession, True or False
description: When the videotape began to play in a Queens courtroom this week, the jurors sat spellbound. For nearly half an hour, they watched as a day care worker named Khemwatie Bedessie described the sequence of events that she said led her to have sexual intercourse with a 4-year-old boy.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

description: To the Editor:

title: When Home Was Where the Art Was
description: One of the continuing rhetorical questions of our artistic era, asked in a 1971 essay by the art historian Linda Nochlin, is Why have there been no great women artists? One answer was already at large, thanks to Virginia Woolf, who put it this way in 1929 in A Room of Ones Own: For most of history, Anonymous was a woman.

title: Somethings Up, and Its Not the Surf
description: None of the music in David Milchs new surfing series on HBO is by the Beach Boys. The surfing scenes are few and fleeting.

title: Web Site Editor at BusinessWeek
description: John A. Byrne, executive editor of BusinessWeek, was named yesterday to lead the magazines Web site.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sculpture Sale Is a Record

title: A Reputed Mob Figure Is Found Shot to Death in His Bed
description: The reputed mobster was found face up in his white striped pajamas, his mouth agape, half hanging off his bed in his Brooklyn home. He had been shot once near his ear, in the back of his head, and late last night investigators were still searching for a motive.

title: States Found to Vary Widely on Education
description: Academic standards vary so drastically from state to state that a fourth grader judged proficient in reading in Mississippi or Tennessee would fall far short of that mark in Massachusetts and South Carolina, the United States Department of Education said yesterday in a report that, for the first time, measured the extent of the differences.

title: Philip K. Dick: A Sage of the Future Whose Time Has Finally Come
description: Philip K. Dick was still an obscure pulp novelist known mainly to teenage boys when a friend predicted that he would one day have more impact on the world than celebrated writers like William Faulkner, Norman Mailer and Kurt Vonnegut. The prediction seemed almost delusional in the 1960s, when Dick was popping pills around the clock and churning out novels in a science fiction ghetto from which he seemed destined never to escape.

title: Arrests of 31 in U.S. Sweep Bring Fear in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, June 7  Over the last several years, this city has gone to great lengths to turn itself into a kind of haven, quite literally, for illegal immigrants. It was not that new immigrants were pouring in, but that there were thousands already living here, and the officials who have long run the city wanted to bring them out of the shadows.

title: As the Local Economy Prospers, So Does the Lobbying Industry
description: The strong local economy that is driving record city surpluses is also helping the lobbying industry.

title: For a Cinematic Object of Desire, a Second Act
description: Released in 1967 to outrage and condemnation, Luis Buuels sublime Belle de Jour stars a frosty, breathtakingly young Catherine Deneuve as a proper bourgeois wife who, by becoming a whore, liberates herself, ruins her husband and possibly goes mad. That, at least, is one way to read the films perverse and intentionally ambiguous finale, with its frozen teardrop, ringing bells, beatific smiles and the startling image of the paralyzed, catatonic husband rising like Lazarus from his wheelchair, as if suddenly, miraculously healed.

title: At G-8 Meeting, a Familiar Song (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Haditha Hearing, Dueling Views of a Battalion Commander
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 7  Through three combat deployments in Iraq, a Bronze Star and numerous combat ribbons, Lt. Col. Jeffrey R. Chessanis Marine Corps career has been defined, it seems, by terrorist bombs.

title: Lets Twist Again, Dude, as the Screws Turn
description: Rehab as a spectator sport has become such a girlie affair, thanks to the pink-tinged public meltdowns of Britney, Lindsay, et al., that its kind of gratifying to watch Neil LaBute grease the road to recovery with his patented brand of testosterone.

title: Brooklyn: Judge Questions Murder Charges
description: Prosecutors and the police failed to ask important questions about the killing of a witness to a Mafia murder, a judge said yesterday at a pretrial hearing. The judge, Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, said he would decide on Monday whether to dismiss murder charges against the defendant, John Sinagra. Mr. Sinagra is charged with the 1990 killing of the witness, Patrick Porco, 18. Prosecutors brought murder charges against Mr. Sinagra last year as part of their case against a former F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, who has been accused of helping a Mafia informer commit several killings. Justice Reichbach called a series of hearings compelling prosecutors to show good cause for their delay in bringing charges. Prosecutors have disclosed documents showing that Mr. Sinagra was named as a suspect as early as 1995, but that the police later closed the case, attributing the Porco killing to a man who had since died.

title: They Always Come Out Ahead; Bet on It
description: Ah, bliss, the gangs all here, well, the guys anyway, looking fighting trim and Hollywood beautiful, at your disposable pleasure as well as mine. Theres George, of course, as in Mr. Clooney, lovely and lean and a touch more gray, smiling and gliding his way through the shimmer and gleam. Brad, henceforth known as Pitt the Elder, looks a wee tired around the eyes, like a baby-bottle warmer on 3 a.m. call, while Matt Damon looks handsomer, somehow more adult, now that he has a lucrative action franchise to call his own. The third time really is a charm.

description: POP

title: Built for Stargazing
description: IN an astronomy village, a hush falls at night as the sky turns dark and the stars appear. Roofs roll back and telescopes aim for the heavens. All the neighbors are stargazing, and nobody turns on the lights.
