description: ART

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Pace to Retire as Joint Chiefs Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  Gen. Peter Pace is being replaced as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a move that reflects a feeling among top civilian officials at the Pentagon and in the White House that the American military needs new leadership after years of being strained by the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: A One-Light Town Grows Into a Second-Home Hotspot
description: A decade ago, an average visit to Milford, Pa., might have lasted about 20 seconds, which is how long it takes for the one traffic light in this small northeastern Pennsylvania town to turn from yellow to red to green.

title: Immigration Bill Sponsors Vow to Press On
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  The authors of a comprehensive immigration bill said today that they would try to resuscitate the measure, which stalled Thursday when the Senate refused to cut off debate, as President Bush urged senators from both parties to bring the bill back to the floor.

title: State Lawmakers Give Bloomberg Traffic Plan a Cool Reception
description: State lawmakers gave a cordial but cool reception today to the congestion pricing plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, asking whether it amounted to a regressive tax on middle-class drivers and whether its costs were worth the promised benefits.

title: After Key Arrest by Serbia, European Union Is to Reopen Talks
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, June 7  The European Union said Thursday that it would resume negotiations with Serbia next week on an agreement that is the first step toward possible membership in the bloc.

title: Reading the Body Language at the Summit
description: HEILIGENDAMM, German, June 8 -- Body language is everything when world leaders gather  especially when one of those leaders is President Bush.

title: Demands for Loan Information
description: The Senate Banking Committee and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York sent joint letters to the nations 20 largest student lenders, demanding information on how they set rates and fees on student loans, as part of a growing investigation into possible discrimination in student lending. The letter gives lenders until the end of next week to say which criteria they use, including college, college location, graduation rate, historic default rate, gender, age, parental income, credit history and any other factors used or considered in underwriting determinations. Separately, the House Education Committee made a similar request of the five top student lenders, to help determine whether the lenders offer less favorable terms to students at predominately minority colleges.

title: Handicapping the Tonys (I Got the Plays Right Here)
description: Lets get one thing out of the way first: That 800-pound mobster in the room. Remember TiVo, people? The theater industry is counting on you to use it.

title: New War Czar Wins Praise, but White House Is Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Senate Democrats praised the three-star Army general picked by President Bush as the new Iraq coordinator but sought to bury elements of that Iraq policy, saying the need to appoint an Iraq czar four years after the invasion proved the White House had lost control of the war effort.

title: Reviving the Hamilton Agenda
description: These days there seem to be four schools of political economic thought. First, there are the limited government conservatives, who think taxes should be low and the state should be as small as possible. Second, there are the Hamiltonians, who believe in free market capitalism but think government should help people get the tools they need to compete in it.

title: Waiting for Al Gore (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Wednesday about a shootout in New Brunswick, N.J., in which a 21-year-old man was killed and a police officer was wounded gave an erroneous surname from the police for the dead man. He was Sixto Martinez, not Hernandez. The article also misspelled the surname of a neighbor of Mr. Martinezs who said she heard shots fired but thought they were firecrackers. She is Daniela Tamarez, not Taniarez.

title: Phillies Rally Against Wagner, and Sweep Mets
description: A fan seated behind the Mets dugout held up a bright orange sign with black lettering during the top of the sixth inning yesterday that read, We believe.

title: China: Students Riot
description: Hundreds of angry students rioted on Wednesday night in the central city of Zhengzhou after a city inspector beat a female student, according to a Hong Kong-based rights group, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. It reported that students from three universities poured into the streets, overturning cars and destroying property for more than four hours. The rampage apparently erupted after an inspector knocked out the front teeth of the female student, who was running an illegal street vending stall. The police later detained a handful of students. A local newspaper also reported that several inspectors were later fired or reprimanded.

title: Artificial Sweetener Rivals Renew a Heated Court Fight
description: The sugar wars have a sour new chapter.

title: The Chorus Is Dancing, and the Mothers Grim
description: Death pervades The House of Bernarda Alba, not only the two that are knelled at the beginning and end of Federico Garca Lorcas last play but also the suffocating atmosphere that permeates life for the inhabitants inside. The National Asian American Theater Company has mounted a first-rate revival in an adaptation by Chay Yew that is somewhat abbreviated but maintains Garca Lorcas tragic claustrophobia.

title: A New Danger in Iraq
description: Absolutely the last thing Iraq needs right now is to have thousands of Turkish troops pour across the border into the countrys one relatively peaceful region  the Kurdish-administered northeast. Turkeys government needs to know that it will reap nothing but disaster if that happens.

title: Shakespeare, Naturally
description: ALL the worlds a stage, sure, but what might Shakespeare have made of the dramatic possibilities of a Lower East Side parking lot, with cars backing out right into the Capulets masked ball? Or Loves Labours Lost on a stroll through Central Park, as helmeted bicyclists whiz by?

title: Protests Rage Against Musharraf; Aides Criticize Justice He Ousted
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 7  In protests around the country, thousands of lawyers and members of opposition parties demonstrated Thursday against new government curbs on the news media, as senior military and intelligence officials presented affidavits to the Supreme Court in the case against the suspended chief justice.

title: Happening Upon a Look at an Optimistic Lincoln
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  It was a historians dream: alone in dimly lighted stacks, leafing through hundreds of yellowed papers and stumbling across a document that clarifies a pivotal moment in United States history.

title: Turkey Rattles Its Sabers at Militant Kurds in Iraq
description: CIZRE, Turkey, June 7  Turkey is stepping up its presence along its border with Iraq to levels not seen in years in an effort to root out Kurdish separatist guerrillas who take refuge in northern Iraq.

title: Immigrant Bill, Short 15 Votes, Stalls in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 The sweeping immigration overhaul endorsed by President Bush crumbled in the Senate on Thursday night, leaving the future of one of the administrations chief domestic priorities in serious doubt.

title: Secret Prisons in 2 Countries Held Qaeda Suspects, Report Says
description: LONDON, June 7  Investigators have confirmed the existence of clandestine C.I.A. prisons in Romania and Poland housing leading members of Al Qaeda, contends a new report from the Council of Europe, the European human rights monitoring agency.

title: A French Songbirds Life, in Chronological Disorder
description: As if acknowledging the challenges it faces in finding an American audience, La Vie en Rose, Olivier Dahans long, feverish film biography of dith Piaf, notes that its heroine, an incomparably bright star in the French cultural firmament, never quite caught on over here. After a less than rapturous stateside reception, the films Piaf (played by Marion Cotillard) observes that Americans just dont get her, and though she seems to have a good time in New York and California, the incomprehension appears to have been mutual. She wont even try a corned beef sandwich at a Manhattan delicatessen.

title: War Notions: Victory, Defeat, Reality (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports headline and an article in some copies yesterday about the Anaheim Ducks defeat of the Ottawa Senators to capture the Stanley Cup referred incorrectly to the accomplishment. Anaheim is the first West Coast team to win the Cup since the National Hockey League took control starting with the 1927 playoffs; it is not the first West Coast team ever to win the championship. That distinction is held by the Vancouver Millionaires, who took the Cup in 1915. (The Seattle Metropolitans won in 1917, and the Victoria Cougars in 1925.)

title: One Citys Home Sellers Do Better on Their Own
description: It sounds like the setup for a dull economists joke. Who gets the better deal: the cautious economist who sells his house through a real estate agent, or his risk-taking colleague who finds a buyer on his own?

title: After Setbacks, Shuttle Is Ready for Launching
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 7  Three months after its external fuel tank took thousands of dings and pockmarks from the golf-ball-size hailstones of a freakish winter storm, the space shuttle Atlantis is ready to fly.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The David Pogue column in the special Circuits section on Tuesday, about Web sites for sharing and printing photos, incorrectly described a feature of one site, Kodak Gallery. While a user with a free or paid account can upload photos to the site (kodakgallery.com) and allow others to view them, the site does not allow others to download them. But it has a Print@Home feature that lets others print photos without downloading them.

title: Pitchers Dominate First Round of the Draft
description: It helped to be a left-handed pitcher yesterday during the first round of Major League Baseballs first-year player draft, or a pitcher of any kind.

title: Paris Hilton Is Ordered Back to Jail
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8  The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice on Friday, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released for an unspecified medical problem.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: New Hampshire to Repeal Parental Notification Law
description: BOSTON, June 7  New Hampshire will become the first state to repeal a law requiring teenage girls to notify their parents before having an abortion, under a bill that won final passage in the State Senate on Thursday.

title: Bronx: Bones Found in Sinkhole
description: City officials inspecting a sinkhole yesterday discovered what may be human remains underground, the police said. The sinkhole, near Wilson Avenue and East 214th Street in Williamsbridge, developed several weeks ago and grew to about 3 feet square, neighbors said. Residents had complained to the Department of Environmental Protection, which sent workers yesterday. Department employees found several bones, including what appeared to be a femur and a jaw bone. The remains will be passed to the medical examiners office, the police said.

title: Democrats May Subpoena N.S.A. Documents
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  Senior House Democrats threatened Thursday to issue subpoenas to obtain secret legal opinions and other documents from the Justice Department related to the National Security Agencys domestic wiretapping program.

title: Yields on Treasuries Climb; Shares Tumble Again
description: Not long ago, Wall Street trembled when it looked as if the slowing American economy might be getting worse. But now, anxiety over the potential for higher inflation, driven by a strong global economy, is preoccupying investors.

title: Art in Review
description: NICK Z. AND KAI ALTHOFF

title: 96 Winner of the Tour Loses Title for Doping
description: The organizer of the Tour de France declared yesterday that the 1996 version of cyclings most important race no longer had a winner.

title: Putin Surprises Bush With Plan on Missile Shield
description: ROSTOCK, Germany, June 7  After months of angrily rejecting a White House plan for missile defense in Europe, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia surprised President Bush on Thursday with an offer to build a joint system in the former Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan.

title: Afghanistan: Hostages Swapped for Taliban Body
description: The Taliban released four members of an Afghan medical team kidnapped and held hostage since March after the government handed over the body of the senior Taliban commander Mullah Dadullah, said Qayum Pukhla, the director of the health department in Kandahar. The four, a doctor, two nurses and a driver described as thin and frail, were quickly reunited with their families. Members of the Taliban said that the Afghan government handed over the body of Mullah Dadullah, killed in fighting last month, on Wednesday evening and that was why they released the four hostages. They said they had killed the fifth member of the team, a pharmacist, because the government did not hand over the commanders body within the ultimatum set earlier this week.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review on Wednesday about We Love Ella! A Tribute to the First Lady of Song, a PBS Great Performances concert, misidentified the site of the concert. It was Los Angeles, not San Diego.

title: Thrust Into Spotlight, Trainer Is Unable to Shake Past
description: Until the third Saturday in May, Steve Asmussen was mostly known in thoroughbred racing circles as a driven and ambitious second-generation horseman. He trains 200 horses in a half-dozen sites from Texas to New York. Some are relatively cheap claiming horses, others are of a much higher caliber. They help him win a lot of races.

title: Americas Cup Gets Interesting
description: VALENCIA, Spain -- Now the Americas Cup gets really interesting, even if the sailing is not guaranteed to do the same.

title: Wie Endures a Rough Week and First Round
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 7  It was obvious from the start, when Michelle Wie took aim at her first fairway of this L.P.G.A. Championship with a 3-wood in her hands, that she was not the same golfer who contended for the title here last year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,487 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Manhattan: Money to Support Parents in Schools
description: Robert Jackson, the chairman of the City Council Education Committee, yesterday proposed a $3.2 million budget outlay to support programs that encourage parent involvement in public schools. We want parents to be empowered for themselves and for their children, Mr. Jackson, said at a news conference on the steps of City Hall, echoing a common complaint by parents that the Department of Education fails to seek their input before making decisions. If approved, the money would help pay for educational outreach, a parents hot line for resolving school issues and other support services.

title: Bombs and Gunmen in Iraq Kill at Least 22 and Wound 55
description: BAGHDAD, June 7  A suicide bomber detonated his explosives and a bus bomb exploded minutes apart near a police station in northern Iraq on Thursday, killing at least nine people and wounding 22, the authorities said.

title: A Girl Recovers at a Hospital, but Answers and a Happy Ending Remain Elusive
description: Unable to hold back tears, the mother of a 15-year-old Connecticut girl who was discovered in a locked crawl space at the home of three adults said yesterday that she was impatient to get her daughter back.

title: In Napa, Wilderness Above the Wineries
description: AFTER hours of tromping through the hills of Napa County, beneath towering redwoods, over mountain creeks, past ruins of 19th-century homesteads, there still wasn't a single grape to be seen.

title: Veterans Benefits System Needs Overhaul, Panel Says
description: A panel of medical experts called yesterday for a sweeping overhaul of the way veterans disability claims are judged, saying the current system is riddled with obsolete medical definitions and ignores the impact of injuries on veterans quality of life.

title: Larry Leon Hamlin, 58, Dies; Promoted Black Theaters
description: Larry Leon Hamlin, the founder and executive director of the National Black Theater Festival, a gathering for theater professionals and an influential showcase for artists, died Wednesday at his home in Pfafftown, N.C. He was 58.

title: Movers Come to Times Sq., but the Name Stays
description: Lets say that a company moves out of a New York neighborhood that has borne its name for more than a century. Lets also say that we are talking about the place where the ball drops every New Years Eve. In this age of naming rights and branding strategies, some people might be eager for a change.

title: Janet S. Sainer, 88, Leader of New York Office for Elderly, Dies
description: Janet S. Sainer, who as commissioner of New York Citys Department for the Aging in the 1980s created programs to keep older people active, educate them on health issues, provide them with meals on weekends and help their caregivers, died Monday while attending a training conference on the elderly in Denver. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Inflation Fears Again Chill the Markets
description: Anxiety over high inflation, which has preoccupied investors all week, sent bond prices falling today and pushed the interest rate on the benchmark United States Treasury note above 5 percent for the first time since last summer.

title: Good Form Once, but Now a Dark Horse
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., June 7  How does a presidential candidate, consigned to the lower tier, distinguish himself in a field of 10 Republican hopefuls whose debates are a diorama of white male politicians in dark suits?

title: Italy Braces for Legal Fight Over Secret C.I.A. Program
description: ROME, June 7  There is no dispute over the central event of Feb. 17, 2003, on Via Guerzoni in Milan: an imam, known as Abu Omar and eyed as a terrorism suspect, vanished while walking to his mosque.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (Disney) JOHNNY KAPAHALA: BACK ON BOARD (2007) In this sequel to Johnny Tsunami, the 1999 Disney movie, Johnny Kapahala (Brandon Baker, left), now a 17-year-old Vermont snowboarder, returns to his hometown in Hawaii for the wedding of his surfer grandfather (Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa)  and meets 12-year-old Chris, who is soon to be his uncle. Turns out that Uncle Chris (Jake T. Austin) is a budding rebel with a passion for mountain boarding and a surly attitude. When Chris joins the Dirt Devils, a tough boarding crew, Johnny tries his hand at the sport in an attempt at family bonding. Beware: rocky patches ahead!

title: Brooklyn: Fire Kills Infant and Injures Others
description: A fire swept through a home in East New York last night, killing a baby and injuring three other people, including two children, the Fire Department said. The fire at 182 Atkins Avenue was reported at 9:48 p.m. and was under control within 20 minutes, department officials said. The conditions of the injured people were not known, and investigators were still trying to determine the cause last night.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Public Lives profile on May 25, about Martin Garbus, a Manhattan lawyer representing the fired radio host Don Imus in his pending lawsuit against CBS, misidentified the mentor to Mr. Garbus who won all nine cases he argued before the United States Supreme Court. It was Ephraim London  not Emile Zola Berman, who represented Sirhan B. Sirhan, Robert F. Kennedys assassin.

title: Putin Offers Alternatives on Missile Defense
description: MOSCOW, June 8 President Vladimir V. Putin today offered new suggestions for alternatives to a missile defense system in Europe, suggesting that Russia would not object to American interceptor missiles in Iraq, Turkey or at sea, and proposing that Russian and the West study emerging missile threats together.

title: Putting the We Back in Wii
description: TOKYO, June 7  If there is a secret to the smash success of Nintendos Wii video game console, it may be this: even the creative loner can benefit from having friends.

title: The Joys of Teaching? Get Lost, Mr. Chips
description: The gawky, overweight high school students in the fictional documentary Chalk are the antithesis of the sleek mean girls and buff junior studs of the typical Hollywood high school melodrama. Slouched glumly in their seats, they regard a new teacher with the blank gazes of bored, sullen prisoners serving out their sentences.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the Reebok Grand Prix track and field event on Randalls Island referred incorrectly in some copies to the wind speed during the 100-meter dash. It was recorded at 2.2 meters a second, not miles an hour. The allowable wind speed for a world record to count in the event is 2.0 meters a second, not miles an hour.

title: As Money Pours in, Hedge Funds Come to Look More Like the Markets
description: We are somewhere between the third and fifth inning in the growth of assets invested in alternative strategies, said Todd Builione, a managing partner at Highbridge Capital Management, a $34 billion hedge fund that is majority owned by JPMorgan Chase.

title: Steroid Investigators Requested Giambis Cooperation
description: Before Commissioner Bud Selig requested that Jason Giambi of the Yankees meet with George J. Mitchell for Mitchells investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in Major League Baseball, Mitchell had already sent Giambi a letter seeking his cooperation.

title: New York in All Its Nuts-and-Bolts Glory
description: The exhibition New York Rises makes a case for adding Eugene de Salignac, the official photographer for the New York City Department of Bridges, Plant and Structures from 1903 to 1934, to the canon of American photographers whose images are forever linked with the city. If he is not the equal of Berenice Abbott, Margaret Bourke-White, Walker Evans and Alfred Stieglitz, his work now on view at the Museum of the City of New York demonstrates that he is at least their kin.

title: Curators Under the Sea
description: Chicago

title: A Vigilant Eye on Threats to the Capital of the World
description: MARK J. MERSHON, the assistant director in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigations New York City headquarters, is not quite sure he wants it known that he considers the bluish fabric of the office furniture he inherited just horrible. Slippery. Shiny. Not particularly masculine. Has to be offensive, he notes, for him to even notice it.

title: Do You Want to Be a Music Critic This Summer?
description: The old saying Everyones a critic has taken on added meaning in the age of blogging. Millions of people are now able to share their opinions with the public, a privilege formerly limited to professionals with mainstream bully pulpits.

title: A Hail of Shots Kills 3 Young Men in Brooklyn
description: A placid evening of socializing by a group of friends on a stoop in Brownsville, Brooklyn, turned bloody Wednesday night when a gunman walked up and opened fire, killing three young men, the police and neighbors said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A VIOLENT SPECTACLES LAST GASP

title: British Contractor Paid Saudi, Reports Say
description: LONDON, June 7  A major British arms contractor paid more than $2 billion clandestinely into bank accounts in Washington controlled by Prince Bandar bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia, two British news organizations reported Thursday. Prince Bandar denied accepting improper secret commissions.

title: Bronx: Man Shot to Death
description: A 26-year-old man was fatally shot about 5:30 p.m. yesterday on Fulton Avenue near East 172nd Street, the police said. The man, who was shot several times, including once in the head, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital in critical condition and later pronounced dead. The police did not release his identity. No arrests had been made.

title: The Diana Chronicles
description: Like any writer examining the life and death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Tina Brown must peer into the world of British royalty with nose pressed to the glass. Unlike almost all of the others, Ms. Brown does not fog the windowpanes. In The Diana Chronicles  which is her maiden foray into long-form nonfiction, or first book  this celebrated editor, mover and shaker brings her own sort of privilege to the realm of aristocratic fairy tales. She knows this world much better than many who inhabit it.

title: City Traffic Pricing Wins U.S. and Spitzers Favor
description: ALBANY, June 7  Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to reduce traffic by charging people who drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan received significant support on Thursday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer endorsed the idea and the Bush administration indicated that New York stood to gain hundreds of millions of dollars if the plan were enacted.

title: Ivanovic Reaches the French Open Final With a Smile
description: PARIS, June 7  With eyes wide and eyebrows raised, Ana Ivanovic watched Maria Sharapovas final forehand sail past the baseline to end their semifinal match at the French Open.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on May 15 about the International Atomic Energy Agencys latest assessment of Irans nuclear program referred imprecisely to information found in a design document that the agencys inspectors have seen in Iran but that the Iranian authorities have declined to explain. The information shows how to make uranium into hemispheres, not spheres. (Depending on their precise design, some types of hemispheres of highly enriched uranium can be suitable for manufacturing a nuclear weapon.)

title: Hamas Leader Calls for End to Clashes
description: JERUSALEM, June 8  The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya of Hamas, today called for warring factions to muster the political will to stop the continuing intra-Palestinian clashes between his own faction and Fatah, who sit together in a unity government.

title: Mexico: Cemex Gains Control of Rinker
description: Cemex, the Mexican cement maker, gained a controlling stake in the Rinker Group of Australia, completing its largest acquisition and increasing its share of the United States market with the $14.2 billion deal. In a filing to the Australian stock exchange, Cemex said it had received acceptances from investors holding 50.34 percent of Rinker. The offer for all of Rinkers shares expires June 22. Cemex, based in Monterrey, Mexico, had to sweeten its six-month-old unsolicited offer by 22 percent in April to win management approval. Rinker, which is based in Sydney, receives about 80 percent of sales from the United States, where Cemex is already the largest cement company.

title: Candidates Tax Plans Are a Mystery
description: Opportunities for real tax reform are rare. But when they do come along, something good can happen only if political leaders are prepared with a plan they can sell to a populace that knows the shortcomings of the present system but is suspicious of changes that may cost them money.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Savannah, a City Close to Its Ghosts
description: WHEN it comes to finding child-friendly haunts in the South, Savannah might not be the first city that comes to mind. After all, endless tours of historic mansions and myriad distinctive, though largely grown-up, galleries and stores would be enough to bore any energetic youngster. But it turns out that this vibrant 18th-century port city  and nearby Tybee Island, with its lovely, expansive beach  can be equal fun for young and old.

title: Sprinter From Queens Tries to Go the Distance
description: SACRAMENTO, June 7  Natasha Hastings craved running success so badly that three times during the week of Christmas she drove more than 200 miles from her familys new home south of Atlanta to Columbia, S.C., for a day of training with Curtis Frye, her coach at South Carolina.

title: For the Adventurous, an Earthbound Ride on the Shuttle
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 7  Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes to the lucky few only after a long selection process and arduous training. But the Kennedy Space Center visitor complex has worked with current and former astronauts to develop a ride that just may be the next best thing.

title: Defense Team for Bondss Trainer Is Set to Argue for His Release
description: Since the investigation of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative began five years ago, one man has spent more time behind bars than anyone in the federal drug case: Greg Anderson, the former personal trainer of Barry Bonds.

title: Good Day for Torre, but Not Everyones Happy
description: CHICAGO, June 7  Joe Torre needed six victories to reach 2,000 for his managerial career, and it seemed as if he might not make it. The Yankees were going nowhere last Wednesday, with five losses in a row, so Torre canceled batting practice and benched Bobby Abreu.

title: Baby Dies in East New York Fire
description: An infant girl was killed in a Brooklyn fire last night when her mother left three children at home by themselves to get Chinese food, the police and neighbors said. Two neighbors who dashed into the apartment to save one of the older children were initially unaware of the baby, who was in a stroller in a bedroom.

title: India, Said to Play Down AIDS, Has Many Fewer With Virus Than Thought, Study Finds
description: NEW DELHI, June 7  India, which has been repeatedly accused of denying the size of its AIDS epidemic, probably has millions fewer victims than has been widely believed, according to a new but still unreleased household survey.

title: Harvey R. Colten, 68, a Pediatric Immunologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Harvey R. Colten, a pediatric immunologist and a leading medical educator at Columbia University whose research helped isolate a gene tied to respiratory failure in infants, died on May 24 in Manhattan. He was 68.

title: Florida: Recordings for Jurys Ears First
description: A federal judge in Miami ruled that the government does not have to provide reporters covering the terrorism trial of Jose Padilla with recordings of wiretapped phone calls until a day after the jury hears them. The judge, Marcia G. Cooke of Federal District Court, did order the government to give reporters transcripts of the recordings the same day they are played in court, but as late as 10 p.m. That could make it difficult or impossible for news outlets to report on the proceedings as they happen. The Associated Press, joined by CNN, The New York Times and The Washington Post, filed a motion last week requesting the transcripts and tapes on the same day they are presented to the jury.

title: Owner Is Accused of Looting His Car Service to Seek Office in Africa
description: The president of a Brooklyn-based car service business not only looted his own company but also used the money to finance his campaign for elective office in his native Ghana, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: U.S. Border Passport Rules Suspended
description: Responding to anguished travelers at risk of being grounded by a broken passport system, the government announced today that it is easing its rules for summer travel in the Western Hemisphere.

title: The Parks the Thing
description: A selection of summer Shakespeare presentations in New York. Schedule and ticket information is available from the companies.

title: Bribery Investigation Looks at Senator Stevens
description: GIRDWOOD, Alaska  The neighbors of Senator Ted Stevens occasionally catch a glimpse of him at his house in this ski resort outside Anchorage.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Translate
description: Atlanta

title: Mets Activate Valentn and Put Chvez on Disabled List
description: As expected, the Mets placed outfielder Endy Chvez on the 15-day disabled list yesterday and activated second baseman Jos Valentn. The move reflected the way the Mets season has been going: Just when one player is healthy enough to return, another is injured.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a sports article about the Mets 4-2 extra-innings loss to the Phillies carried an incorrect credit. The photograph of a play at home plate involving the Mets David Wright and the Philliles Carlos Ruiz was by Ray Stubblebine of Reuters, not Barton Silverman of The New York Times.

title: Setback Aside, James Transcends His Generation
description: San Antonio

title: Patent Ruling Strikes a Blow at Qualcomm
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 7  Millions of new mobile phones containing certain Qualcomm semiconductors could be barred from import into the United States under a ruling issued Thursday by a federal government agency in a patent dispute.

title: G-8 Summit Winds Down With Africa Aid Pledge
description: KUHLUNGSBORN, Germany, June 8  Adjourning a meeting marked by some surprises and a less contentious tone than many expected, the leaders of the worlds richest industrial nations pledged today to commit $60 billion for treatment of AIDS and other diseases in the developing world.

title: At a London Fair, a Helping Hand, a Discerning Eye
description: Because some people find the process of acquiring antiques intimidating, Clarion Arts, the organizer of the Summer Fair Olympia in London, has sought out an impartial team of experts to accompany visitors around that arts and antiques fair this week.

title: A Venetian Customs House for Contemporary Art
description: Venice, June 7  Franois Pinault, the luxury-goods magnate and art collector who owns Christies, arrived here this week not simply to peruse the hundreds of art installations that make up this years Venice Biennale, but also for the formal signing of an agreement on Friday between the City of Venice and his Palazzo Grassi to create a contemporary-art center in an unused customs house called Punta della Dogana, at the entrance to the Grand Canal.

title: In One City, Home Sellers Find It Pays to Cut Out Middleman
description: A study to be released today based on home-sales data from 1998 to 2004 in Madison, Wis., says that people in that city who sold their homes through real estate agents typically did not get a higher sale price than people who sold their homes themselves. When the agents commission is factored in, the for-sale-by-owner people came out ahead financially.

title: A New Era: United States 1, Guatemala 0
description: This was the United Statess first competitive match under Coach Bob Bradley and without the retired veterans Brian McBride, Claudio Reyna and Eddie Pope. How does the future of the U.S. team look to you?

title: No Moose Call to Schilling on the Near Miss
description: Until Bostons Curt Schilling lost a no-hitter Thursday with two outs in the ninth inning at Oakland, the Yankees Mike Mussina had the dubious distinction of being the last pitcher to come so close to a no-hitter without getting it.

title: Can a Subtenant Collect an Overcharge?
description: Q I am subletting a rent-stabilized apartment. I recently found out that the original tenant is charging me about $400 more than his rent and that in our contract he states that I am his roommate rather than subtenant. Can I get back what he has overcharged?

title: For sale: Rupert Murdochs former home
description: Exterior

title: Getting in Tune
description: Additional images from the restoration of the Wanamaker Organ in Philadelphia.

title: Teach Your Parents Well
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pulse
description: Whos your daddy?  Heres his gift.

title: Theater Briefs
description: With the sinking of "The Pirate Queen" it's now official: The new musical "Young Frankenstein"  excuse us, "The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein"  will open at the Hilton Theater on Broadway on Nov. 8, with previews set to begin on Oct. 11.

title: U.S. Commitment-Phobia
description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and U.S. President George Bush during the second working meeting at the G8 Summit. Guido Bergmann/ Bundesregierung/AP

title: The Artists Take Over
description: Additional images from Swedish artists' unofficial annexation of the Isola San Michele.

title: Where Off Off Took Off
description: Last fall the theater company Peculiar Works Project took audiences back in time by way of a tour that meandered through Greenwich Village, stopping at Off Off Broadways earliest locales. Along the way actors performed excerpts from seminal works of downtown theater. But the company was only telling half the story.

title: Ravaged Beauty
description: Bridesmaids have had a hostile relationship with their dresses for years. Now, brides are acting the same way.

title: Cemex Gains Control of Rinker
description: Cemex, the Mexican cement maker, gained a controlling stake in the Rinker Group of Australia, completing its largest acquisition and increasing its share of the United States market with the $14.2 billion deal. In a filing with the Australian stock exchange, Cemex said it had received acceptances from investors holding 50.34 percent of Rinker.

title: Mexicos Court Limits Reach of Big Media
description: The Mexican Supreme Court overwhelmingly voted Thursday to declare parts of a new media law unconstitutional, a blow to the countrys two main broadcasters who had hoped to extend their dominance in television to the Internet and telephone service.

title: Pennsylvania Pitches Wall Street West
description: Hoping to capitalize on fears of the chaos another terrorist attack might cause in New Yorks financial industry, Pennsylvania officials are promoting a corner of their state as Wall Street West. So far, however, the real Wall Street hasnt shown any serious interest in putting data backup centers in that part of Pennsylvania.

title: Hedge Funds Are Looking More Like the Markets
description: Alternative investments continue to be the rage among wealth managers for a number of reasons, including the low correlations that hedge funds have historically had with major equity and bond markets. (In other words, when those markets tank, hedge funds, in general, do not.)

title: 2 Executives at Center of Dow Chemical Scandal File Suit
description: Two former Dow Chemical executives have sued the company, seeking payment of their legal fees for lawsuits and a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry. Ex-Chief Financial Officer J. Pedro Reinhard and former Executive Vice President Romeo Kreinberg, were fired April 12 after being accused of holding unauthorized talks to sell the largest U.S. chemical maker.

title: Some Small Law Firms Find Strength in Numbers
description: The International Network of Boutique Law Firms, founded by lawyer Steven Spielvogel in 2004, aims to provide options to those lawyers who have decided against spending their days grinding out billable hours on a large firms time sheet.

title: London Journal: Spring Ends With a Flourish
description: During June in New York the concert season typically winds down. Not so in London, it would seem, where big things are happening this week, more than enough to entice me to visit.

title: Infinera Captures Big First-Day Gains
description: Share of Infinera, a maker of optical computer chips, rose as much as 63 percent in their market opening on Thursday, a day after the company raised $182 million in an initial public offering.

title: Small Shareholders Band Together Against Genzyme Bid
description: Angry at what they say is an unfairly priced takeover attempt by Genzyme, more than three dozen small shareholders of the biotechnology firm Bioenvision are trying to band together to block Genzymes deal to buy the company.

title: Tyco Board Approves Split
description: Tyco International, the industrial conglomerate, said Thursday that its board had formally approved its separation into three publicly traded companies.

title: Calpers Puts $400 Million in Private Equity Funds Coffers
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest public pension fund in the United States, put $400 million in a Pacific Corporate Group investment unit focused on developing countries. The unit, PCG International, will invest the money in private equity funds in international markets including Japan, China, India, Central Europe, Latin America and Africa, the company said.

title: Microsoft Picks Up Data Management Firm
description: Microsoft said Thursday it had acquired Stratature, a privately held company that specializes in so-called master data management software. Through the acquisition, Microsoft will build master data management tools into its Office System line.

title: Cash in Hand, AstraZeneca Remains on the Prowl
description: AstraZeneca, the British drugmaker, plans to continue making acquisitions to fill its product pipeline, its chief executive, David Brennan, told Bloomberg News.

title: Another Management Shake-Up at Revver
description: Revver, a video-sharing Web site, said Thursday that its chief executive, Steven Starr, has stepped down in the struggling venture-backed companys second executive shakeup in the past six months.

title: For Activist Fund Manager, PNC Deal May Be A Double-Edge Sword
description: After campaigning for three years to force Yardville National Bancorp of New Jersey to put itself up for sale, Larry Seidman, the hedge fund manager, might mark the companys sale to the PNC Financial Services Group for $403 million as a sweet success.

title: China Properties Raises $299 Million in London Offering
description: China Central Properties, an investor in distressed real estate assets, said it had raised 151.2 million pounds ($299 million) in a London share sale as it seeks funds to buy incomplete developments in the country. China Central sold 151.23 million new shares at a price of 1 pound each, the company said in a statement. China Central shares will trade on the AIM Market of the London Stock exchange.

title: May Merger Continues to Drag on Macys
description: Macys reported further evidence Thursday that stores it acquired through a merger with the May Department Stores continue to be a drag on sales. For the month of May, Macys saw sales at stores open at least a year drop 3.3 percent, more than the 1.4 percent that analysts were expecting.

title: New Zealand Regulators Block Warehouse Group Bid
description: Woolworths and Foodstuffs NZ, New Zealands biggest grocers, were barred by antitrust regulators from buying the Warehouse Group, the largest non-food retailer in the nation. Warehouse shares fell 8 percent.

title: Discover Gets Ready to Go It Alone
description: Discover Financial Services is scheduled to split from Morgan Stanley on July 2, trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol DFS. But The Chicago Tribune says the credit-card issuer will face a number of challenges on its own.

title: Bank of America Said to Appeal Ruling on LaSalle Deal
description: Bank of America, seeking to overturn a decision that halted its $21 billion acquisition of the LaSalle Bank, is expected to claim that a Dutch commercial court acted in a shocking and unlawful manner in freezing the transaction, The Financial Times reported, citing a copy of the appeal filing the newspaper obtained. The sale of LaSalle has emerged as a key element in the larger takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro.

title: Venice Biennale: Lining Up for Britains Bad Girl
description: The Biennale is now under full steam, with lines to get into some of the more popular exhibitions in the Giardini, like the British pavilion, with the my-most-intimate-thoughts-up-in-neon work of Tracey Emin.

title: Societe Generale Said to Explore BNP Merger
description: In a deal that could create a French banking giant, Societe Generale is exploring possible merger options with its larger domestic rival, BNP Paribas, the French economic newspaper Les Echos reported.

title: Merrill Names New Investment Banking Executives
description: Merrill Lynchs Andrea Orcel, who took over investment banking and capital markets two weeks ago, named his deputies, Bloomberg News reported, citing a company memorandum.

title: Soul Searching on the Sell Side
description: Prudential Financials recent decision to close its equity research group is just the latest change in an industry that is trying to find its way in a shifting Wall Street landscape. BusinessWeek examines some of the pressures on sell-side analysis, including restrictions on soft dollars, as well as the new business models that are being developed.

title: Dow Jones Sews More Golden Parachutes
description: Dow Jones & Company may or may not be close to a sale, but on Thursday, it sweetened the pot for managers in case of a takeover.

title: 2008: Immigration Fallout
description: Immigration issues rocked the Republican field at Tuesday nights debate, with all but Senator John McCain finding serious flaws with various parts of the legislation. The mounting opposition, from many quarters including Democrats, put a lot of pressure on the compromise bill. It failed last night in the Senate, and The Timess Carl Hulse and Robert Pear give us the play by play of how the bills sponsors came up short and what it means:

title: Longing For a Third Way on Stem Cells
description: The last two days have brought two important headlines related to stem-cell research: that the Congress is once more trying to ease restrictions on federal financing for embryonic stem cells, and that researchers have made important progress on ways to turn ordinary cells into stem cells.

title: A Smooth Liftoff
description: The shuttle Atlantis thundered off the launching pad on a mission to continue building the International Space Station.

title: Paris and Scooter on the Scales of Justice
description: The Liberation of Paris: George Washington University professor Orin Kerr adapts the rhetoric of the Free Scooter crowd to the cause of another celebrity crook, Paris Hilton. Kerr writes at The Volokh Conspiracy, a legal group blog:

title: Outside the Blast Zone
description: The other day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told people who worry about terrorist threats to get a life  and got some positive feedback. Now comes the news that Pennsylvania officials hope to capitalize on fears of chaos should another terrorist attack hit New Yorks financial district. Call it Wall Street West.Gov. Edward G. Rendells administration maintains that since the region is about 100 miles west of Manhattan, it is outside New York Citys theoretical nuclear blast zone. It is ideally situated, they say, to be a safe retreat from the metropolis, but close enough to be linked directly to the computers that run the banking and trading systems.

title: Deutsche Rejoins Hertzs Underwriting Caravan
description: It looks as if Deutsche Bank has put an embarrassing e-mail episode behind it.

title: Venice Biennale: A Watery Stillness (Sometimes)
description: One of the best things about Venice (in contrast to another great city on the water like, say, New York) is that you will never hear the sound of a car (or a car alarm) or a bus or a screeching, screaming taxi or an early-morning garbage truck that sounds as if it is hoisting entire brownstones and emptying their contents.

title: For Online Brokers, Another Deal Option
description: Steven Cohen of the hedge fund SAC Capital may want TD Ameritrade to strike a deal with Charles Schwab or E*Trade Financial, but an analyst at Banc of America Securities has other ideas.

title: In Bloom
description: Dozens of private gardens in New Jersey and on Long Island are opened to the public each year, with some drawing thousands of visitors.

title: For More Buyouts, Tender Is the Offer
description: When Biomet announced Thursday that it had accepted an increased takeover offer from a group of private equity firms, the agreement was remarkable for a few reasons.

title: Sharing a Virtual Canvas
description: In a world where Web sites can be spreadsheets, word processors, movie theaters and matchmaking databases, it took something as simple as DoodleNow.com to freak me out.

title: Jefferson Vows to Fight Charges
description: Shortly after pleading not guilty to 16 fraud/corruption charges and being released on $100,000 bail, Representative William Jefferson defended himself before the media outside of a federal courthouse in Alexandria, Va.

title: Rugs Reconsidered
description: Images from The Great Cover-Up at the American Folk Art Museum.

title: A backwards glance
description: The Thursday press conference was not so kind to two drivers who started their first full seasons in Formula One as teammates 10 years ago. Giancarlo Fisichella had already done several races the year before at Minardi, but when he joined Jordan in 1997 as Ralf Schumachers teammate, it made for quite an explosive couple.

title: Frieden Interview: The Politics of Opposition
description: The citys health commissioner, Dr. Thomas Frieden, gave a frank interview to Christopher Murray of The Gay City News on a wide range of his agencys policies that have drawn opposition from some groups that represent gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgendered people.

title: Two Days of ChaosA President visits Rome
description: courtesy of AP

title: The Selling of Congestion Pricing
description: There was a time, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told an audience today at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, when he, too, was skeptical of congestion pricing.

title: Audra McDonald
description: Ahead of Sunday's Tony Awards ceremony, the actress, who is nominated for her role in "110 in the Shade," answered readers' questions.

title: Campaign Cash: $3,417,030
description: Thats the total amount of commitments from fundraisers that former President Bill Clinton is headlining this spring for his wifes presidential campaign, according to an internal Clinton finance document provided to The Times.

title: Funds Demand Ameritrades Records of Merger Talks
description: SAC Capital and Jana Partners have raised the stakes in their proxy fight for TD Ameritrade.

title: Taking Questions: A Traffic Expert on Congestion Pricing
description: This afternoon, we arranged for Michael Horodniceanu, one of the foremost experts on traffic in New York City, to take questions from readers on the subject of congestion pricing. Dr. Horodniceanu was the citys traffic commissioner from 1986 to 1990. He is currently chairman and chief executive of Urbitran, an engineering, architectural and planning company based in Manhattan. This Q&A is now closed, but readers are invited to continue the discussion in the comments below.

title: Down by the Shake Shack
description: I think we should all make a pact to gather in 10 years to chew on the Tom Ford empire. Ford put out a statement this morning about a plan to have 100 free-standing Tom Ford boutiques over the next decade. In three years, he says hell open shops in L.A., Hawaii, London and Milan. Other cities down the road will include Moscow and Hong Kong, and hell have in-store deals with Neimans and Villa Moda. Oh, and Daslu in Brazil. Maybe in his spare time he could design Valentino. just a thought.

title: C.E.O.s and Mergers: Nothing to Lose?
description: Heres a coin-flipping game anybody would love to play. Heads: you get pots of money. Tails: you get smaller pots of money.

title: From Our DUI for Famous People Dept.
description: So heres something new: A celebrity whose fame stemmed at least as much from good looks and sex appeal as from actual work product is nabbed for driving while blotto again, but nonetheless manages to avoid jail time.

title: Weekend Reading: Letters from Robert Chapman
description: Shareholder activism has proven especially popular  and lucrative  for hedge funds over the past year, but few practitioners show the epistolary flair of, say, Third Points Daniel Loeb, known for his eloquently barbed letters to companies that he thinks need to change their ways. Another expert in this art is Robert Chapman, who is at it again  with the kid gloves firmly off.

title: Google Map Bites Founder
description: The privacy concerns over Google Maps bouncing around Web may have just bounced back  into the co-founders office. Valleywag has located the home of Larry Page.

title: Chiang Mai, the mini Bangkok
description: Chiang Mai is a popular get-away from Bangkok, as its only about an hours flight away and is relatively cooler in the hot, rainy months. Id never gone before, but I knew what I was expecting: a small city with ancient temples, old buildings, sprawling markets, outlying villages, cute cafes and homey guest houses.All those things were there, but the whole was bigger and more commercial than I had thought; the main road along one side of the river was packed with cars, scooters, pick-up trucks and some seriously assertive tuk-tuk drivers.There some nice little streets, shops and pubs in the area along the river, but there was also a Starbucks, 7-Eleven, Subway, McDonalds, etc. Further up, somewhat desperate looking, scantily clad women milled around al fresco pool halls where nobody was playing pool. The night bazaar is impressively large, but touristy. Not that Im going to go on a PC rant against U.S. coffee chains or thinly veiled girlie bars; it just felt too much like a mini-Bangkok to be a peaceful getaway, especially in the evening.

title: Skipping the Straw Poll
The Second Floor Redux
description: You get to judge, too, but when I saw the latest drawings our architect, Greg, sent, I thought we were a lot closer.

title: Out of Their Shells
description: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a fast and tasty salad of fresh crab and peas.

title: A Hill of Beans
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a variety of bean salads.

title: London Journal: Casing the Neighborhood
description: While Im in London this week there are also some enticing concerts at the elegant and intimate Wigmore Hall, including a recital of Beethoven sonatas by the fine British pianist Paul Lewis. Alas, Im otherwise booked, with events to cover every night. This is additionally frustrating, because Im staying with good friends about a block away on enchanting Wigmore Street.

title: To Break a Tsunami Alarm
description: Angry villagers in Aceh, Indonesia, have done the last thing one would expect: break a Tsunami alarm by hurling stones at it until it went on the fritz. Have they gone absolutely mad?

title: All Things Steak
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, shows how to grill steaks.

title: Your Turn: Traffic Questions for Readers
description: It seems to be congestion pricing day. Our expert on the subject had to return to his life, but thanks to all who posed questions.

title: The Shape of Things That Came

description: 9 P.M. (ABC) RUFFIAN  (2007) Right on the heels of the Belmont Stakes (5:30 p.m. on ABC), and with the memory of Barbaro still fresh, comes this drama about the horse heralded as the greatest thoroughbred filly of all time. After winning the Filly Triple Crown early in 1975, the undefeated Ruffian went on to run a battle of the sexes match against the Kentucky Derby winner Foolish Pleasure on July 6 at Belmont Park. The race ended in sorrow when, with Ruffian leading Foolish Pleasure by half a length, two bones in her right front leg snapped. After a 12-hour surgery, Ruffian caused further damage to herself when she thrashed around on the floor of her padded stall, and she was euthanized shortly after. The film, directed by Yves Simoneau (HBOs Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee), stars Sam Shepard, above, as Frank Whiteley, the trainer who guided Ruffians ascent, and Frank Whaley as the sportswriter Bill Nack, who wrote the book the movie is based on.

Its hard to say which of the three couples on stage is more mismatched and miserable: Andrea, a tightly wound Martha Stewart wannabe, and Greg, who cant stop tossing verbal darts; Charlotte, the slinky fiance of buttoned-up Lenny, Gregs brother; or Laura and Richard, both way too downtown  in different ways  for their own good.

title: Strange Land
description: In Naeem Murrs first two novels, set in London and its environs, social workers administered to demonic child prostitutes and bardic welfare cheats while tackling their own severe personal problems. In The Perfect Man, his third novel, Murr, who was born and raised in London and now lives in the United States, brings his slightly gothic sensibility to bear on the heart of America. The book takes place chiefly in Pisgah, Mo., the small town where Rajiv Travers, a half-Indian, half-English boy, comes of age in the 1950s. This Our Town-ish locale is an ideal showcase for Murrs impressive talents, previously deployed on a widely divergent cast of British characters. Here, Murr weaves an elaborate plot, shifting perspective between small-town characters  adults, outcasts and the handful of teenagers who form the novels core.

title: 36 Hours in New York

As a subject, photographers have been endlessly attracted to its streets (Lee Friedlander), night life (Weegee), world-famous skyline (Berenice Abbott) and all the refracted angles in between. As a place to view great works, it offers possibilities that are endless, from museums and galleries devoted to the art form, to restaurants and bars that hang rarified works. The city is the world's media capital, so photography not only attracts artists and shutterbugs alike, but it's also a big business, fueling everything from advertising and modeling agencies to retouching labs and frame shops. With so much to see, the trick is to edit out the visual distractions  just as with any good photograph.

According to a trailer from Lionsgate, which last fall packaged some of these DVD releases as an After Dark HorrorFest: Eight Movies to Die For, this is because the content of certain movies is considered too graphic, too disturbing and too shocking for general audiences. title: Proximity to Darkness
description: Larky, fitfully brilliant, as profane as they are aphoristic, Leonard Michaelss stories stand alongside those of his best Jewish contemporaries  Grace Paley and Philip Roth. Like theirs, Michaelss vernacular achieves the level of song. And yet, though much celebrated during his lifetime  Michaels died at 70 in 2003  his sexually kinetic work is little read today. But perhaps now it will be, with the republication of his work in two new volumes that should bring Michaels to a new generation of readers and remind us of his lasting achievement. The Collected Stories includes the full contents of his acclaimed first two volumes, Going Places (1969) and I Would Have Saved Them if I Could (1975), as well as selections from his later writing, including all the existing Nachman stories. Sylvia is a fictionalized memoir, first published in 1992, about Michaelss first wife, Sylvia Bloch, who committed suicide.

title: The Mind of the South
description: I had to stop reading this book in public. I laughed out loud too often and too uproariously for the company in a bus or plane or cafe. What was worse, if I tried to explain myself my Southern accent, usually kept in check when Im traveling in the North or abroad (where I live), came back like kudzu after a summer rain. Yall got to read this, I heard myself saying to an older couple staring at me on a flight to Rome last month. (They were Americans, as I knew by their Bermuda shorts.) I dont normally say yall except when Im making my annual pilgrimage to South Carolina, and then only for a couple of weeks  although I always do, it is true, feel better about myself when Im drawing out my vowels.

title: Shop Stewards on Fantasy Island?
description: One thing that can be said about the war for Fisher Island is that everyone involved wants only whats best for the place. This 216-acre property with 34 sprawling Mediterranean-style luxury condominium buildings sits conveniently surrounded by Miami Beach, the city of Miami, Biscayne Bay and the Atlantic Ocean. It is an island paradise containing every possible indulgence that someone with a great deal of money and an enormous need to be coddled might desire. Fisher Islands fortunate 1,400, fewer than one-third of them full-time residents, can play on the golf course created by P. B. Dye, of the famed course-design family, or on one of 18 tennis courts  clay, grass and hard court surfaces. There are two marinas  one for large yachts and one for larger yachts  and a state-of-the-art gym, complete with a Roman waterfall for aching backs and, along with yoga and Pilates, classes with names like Waves of Steel and Esto Es Tango! The sand on the beach is imported from the Bahamas and cleared daily of seaweed, so it is always soft and white. There are swimming pools, not just at the health spa, but also in each condo complex. Perpetually blooming tropical flowers perfume the air; caged toucans twitter in banyan trees, flamingos wade lazily in their own private pond. Kids attend a special island private school where cameras, wired into the condos, allow anxious parents to monitor their offspring from home; the playground, naturally, is gently padded.

title: Service Compris

title: The Office
description: The Pentagon is not generally considered a significant work of architecture, but perhaps it should be. In a period when every new art museum and luxury condo tower is touted as iconic, the Pentagon is the real thing: a globally recognized symbol. This concrete behemoth  the largest office building in the world  is also the product of considerable human ingenuity and resourcefulness, as Steve Vogel amply demonstrates in his interesting account. The Library of Congress categorizes The Pentagon as history and architecture, but it is really biography  the biography of a building.

title: Theater Listings
description: SKETCHFEST NYC Since the first SketchFest in Seattle eight years ago, sketch comedy festivals have been popping up in cities from Los Angeles to Toronto. New York has plenty of cutups too, and it joined the fun two years ago with Sketchfest NYC, an annual event taking place this weekend. The goal is to make people realize what sketch comedy is, said Alexander Zalben, a producer of Sketchfest NYC. Its not just people in their fraternities putting on funny skits about their professors. Unlike improvisation or standup comedy, sketch consists of short written scenes rehearsed in advance. (Think of Saturday Night Live.) The content may be funny, but Mr. Zalben and his co-producers, Keith Michel, Becky Poole and Elizabeth Ellis, are serious about this type of humor. We werent going to aim for being the biggest, Mr. Zalben said. Its more important to aim for a consistent level of quality. Instead of opening the festival to all performers, the producers watched more than 100 live-performance tapes, and chose 21 groups for the festival.

title: Warsaw Underground
description: The Poles, probably more than any other Europeans, must feel they deserve a little peace, freedom and prosperity. Sandwiched between the neighbors from hell (Germany, Russia), they were at the back of the line when the late 20th century dispensed its favors. But now here are democracy, economic growth and membership in the European Union; Polands future, on the surface, appears rosier than ever.

title: Tabloid Princess
description: Admittedly, Im biased. On July 29, 1981, when Lady Diana Spencer married Prince Charles, I was in London with my family. I was 11, and like millions of people, I couldnt get enough of the Shy Di fairy tale: ugly (O.K., gangly) duckling meets handsome (O.K., gangly) prince and becomes luminous royal swan. In the new couples honor, I spent a months allowance on wedding memorabilia. My prize purchase was a Diana coffee mug with a wide-brimmed ceramic hat. Only the girls are going in for this lot, the sales clerk grumbled. He might have been talking about the fairy princess myth itself. Sometimes against their better judgment, women the world over were entranced by the prospect of untold leisure, unequaled glamour and redemptive metamorphosis that this particular myth promised. Ladies, lets be honest: who really among us hasnt dreamed of becoming a princess?

title: Chinese Leave Guantnamo for Albanian Limbo
description: TIRANA, Albania  Ahktar Qassim Basit says he is not angry about the four years he spent as an American prisoner at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, before his captors mumbled a brief apology and flew him to this drab Balkan capital to begin a new life as a refugee.

Sadly, right now, thats the world people are aspiring to. You have Harvard-educated medical doctors who would rather work at an investment bank than try to cure cancer, and thats the wish-fulfillment lifestyle that I play into.

The joke is, the more banal the information or sweeping the generalization, the more complex the graphics. Its a comment on fans short attention spans, he said. title: Larry Summerss Evolution

They must have made for an entertaining sight, one of them bearish and the other less than five feet tall, debating each other in a dark Harvard Square dive. The argument, in a nutshell, came to this. The smaller man  Robert Reich, a future secretary of labor  argued for something that he called industrial policy. Since the government couldnt avoid having a big influence on the economy, he said, it should at least do so in a way that promoted fast-growing industries and invested in worthy public projects.

title: The Poverty Platform
description: In April 1964, when Lyndon Johnson sought to rally public support for his new War on Poverty, he did it while sitting on a pile of two-by-fours on a front porch in Inez, Ky.  an appearance that helped establish the Appalachian South as a national symbol of economic deprivation. And so it was fitting that John Edwards, announcing his candidacy for president at the end of last year, chose as his setting not his hometown, Robbins, N.C., where he unveiled his first presidential campaign four years earlier, but the front yard of a mangled brick house in New Orleanss Upper Ninth Ward. New Orleans is the new national shorthand for neglect, and it is, not coincidentally, the spiritual center of Edwardss campaign. After Hurricane Katrina washed away, with brutal efficiency, some of Americas most impoverished neighborhoods, Edwards took more than 700 students to the submerged city to help rebuild homes and schools, and in the months since then, he has never stayed away for long. I can always tell when hes been to New Orleans, says Bruce Raynor, a co-president of the hotel and garment workers union, who is close to the former senator. His passions are stirred. It angers him.

title: The Class-Consciousness Raiser
description: By the time Ruby Payne sat down for lunch, she had been at it for three hours straight, standing alone behind a lectern on a wide stage in a cavernous convention hall, parked between two American flags, instructing an audience of 1,400 Georgians in the hidden rules of class. No notes, no warm-up act, just Ruby, with her Midwestern-by-way-of-East-Texas drawl and her crisp white shirt, her pinstriped business suit and bright red lipstick and blow-dried blond hair, a wireless microphone hooked around her right ear. She had already explained why rich people dont eat casseroles, why poor people hang their pictures high up on the wall, why middle-class people pretend to like people they cant stand. She had gone through the difference between generational poverty and situational poverty and the difference between new money and old money, and she had done a riff on how middle-class people are so self-satisfied that they think everyone wants to be middle class.

The Nepal Family Adventure, for example, an 11-day trip that includes white-water rafting, a visit to a crocodile breeding center, elephant rides and camping in the Himalayas, costs $830 a person (www.intrepidtravel.com). ... description: The Arniko Highway climbs out of Kathmandu in long wending loops that pay twin tribute to the impassability of Himalayan terrain and the implausibility of its development. Outside Africa, no country is poorer than Nepal. Its per capita income looks like a misprint: $270 a year. Sudans is more than twice as high. Nearly two-thirds of Nepalis lack electricity. Half the preschoolers are malnourished. To the list of recent woes add regicide  10 royals slaughtered in 2001 by a suicidal prince  and a Maoist insurgency.

title: Monaco Recalls Princess Grace With Exhibit
description: Grace Kelly, the movie star who became a real-life princess when she married Prince Rainier in 1956, and the tragic victim of a car crash in 1982, revisits the French Riviera this summer when the Grimaldi Forum Monaco (www.grimaldiforum.com) pays tribute to her in an exhibition from July 12 through Sept. 23.

title: Barcelona Warning: Trains Coming. Church at Risk.
description: BARCELONA, Spain  With its soaring but impossibly slender columns and masonry that resembles heavy frosting, Antonio Gauds unfinished masterwork La Sagrada Familia seems as if it might suddenly collapse on itself, like a surreal cake.

title: Tudor Charm Loses Ground to McMansion Space
description: JAMAICA ESTATES, in east-central Queens, hugs a ridge whose steepness discouraged early settlement. Even after that changed, in the early 20th century, and the neighborhood became a car-friendly suburb, residents tended to preserve the trees, which by that point were old and numerous.

title: The Great Midtown Cover-Up
description: ANYONE strolling down a nine-block stretch of Broadway in Midtown at noon on a sunny day this spring could be forgiven for thinking that it was either nighttime or unexpectedly gloomy. Nine sidewalk sheds, some up to a full block long, could be found between Times Square and Herald Square. All had been erected around existing buildings, not at sites where construction was taking place.

title: On the Road With Historys Father
description: Ryszard Kapuscinski disappeared in the dead of winter, January 2007, half as well known as his influence would lead one to expect. He went into the beyond Nobel-less, like Joyce and Proust and Nabokov, but to many who read him he was as exalted: deity was used, more than once, in his assorted funeral songs. While such desperate formulations as world literature conjure up bongos, beads and sitting Indian-style, the books Kapuscinski wrote may actually qualify, as evocative and singular in English as they are in their native (and what is said to be austerely fine) Polish. For many of us, the day of his death was a dark, cold day.

title: Using Alliance Partner Airlines For Miles and Upgrades
description: My husband and I are planning to celebrate our 10th anniversary exploring New Zealand. Since this isnt until 2010, do you have any suggestions for ways to earn points while we wait that would enable us to upgrade to first class for the long flight? We arent frequent fliers, but we do have credit cards.  Nancy Timper, Prescott, Ariz.

title: Raw
description: When I first tried sushi in Tokyo in the fall of 1977, I thought of myself as an intrepid culinary adventurer who, if he survived the experience, would return to America to tell the incredible, unbelievable tale of the day he ate raw fish on rice balls. Someday, perhaps, I would tell my children. By the time I returned to the States two years later, I found sushi bars in Midtown Manhattan; within a few years, nigiri sushi became the signature forage of the Young Urban Professional. As for my children, they eat sushi three or four times a week. They developed a taste for it when they were living in Nashville, Tenn., which, though it lacks any convincing French or Italian restaurants, has several fine sushi bars. From very different perspectives, The Zen of Fish, by Trevor Corson, and The Sushi Economy, by Sasha Issenberg, attempt to account for the transformation of sushi from a provincial street snack to the international luxury cuisine of the 21st century.

title: North Korea Misspent Funds From U.N., Diplomats Say
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Senior American diplomats at the United Nations have compiled new information indicating that several million dollars in United Nations development money had been paid to a North Korean entity closely associated with that nations programs to develop unconventional weapons and sell missiles abroad.

title: Between Skid Row and Starbucks
description: THE dive bars, pawnshops and flophouses for the misanthropic, misbegotten and mostly down-and-out have disappeared. The rock club CBGB closed in October, Whole Foods opened in March and at least 20 Starbucks outlets are entrenched within a mile radius. The Bowerys gritty glory days may well be over, pushed out by surging rents and the ever-rising tide of gentrification.

title: Does the G Stand for Ghost?
description: In theory, the G train, the lime green line that never enters Manhattan, runs for about 14 miles, from Red Hook, Brooklyn, all the way to Forest Hills, Queens. For residents of Jackson Heights who enjoy the cuisines of Carroll Gardens, for example, or for Greenpointers who shop at the Queens Center mall in Elmhurst, the G can be a straight shot, no train changes needed.

It is also an unsteady business, erected not on our material need to visit Florence or the Grand Tetons but on the illusions that lead us there, or anywhere beyond the horizon of home.

So when financial aid and low-interest government loans did not stretch far enough, Ms. DiPoi applied for $49,000 in private loans, too. How bad could it be? she recalls thinking.

title: Knowing Not
description: Decline-and-fall books, like E. D. Hirsch Jr.s Cultural Literacy and Allan Blooms Closing of the American Mind, can leave the reader torn between depression and elation: by detailing how stupid everyone else is, the authors leave us feeling better about ourselves. (I know which has more members, the Supreme Court or the Supremes!) So it was with smug anticipation that I opened Religious Literacy, Stephen Protheros jeremiad about declining religious knowledge. Most Americans cannot name one of the four Gospels, Prothero writes, and many high school seniors think that Sodom and Gomorrah were husband and wife. Religious illiteracy cuts across generations, and the devout scarcely know more than the secular do. In one survey of high school students, most evangelicals did not recognize that Blessed are the poor in spirit is from the Sermon on the Mount.

title: Safaris Where the Hunt Is for the Perfect Picture

He tried steadying the camera by kneeling on the sand, to no avail. Then he tried fidgeting with the autofocus mode, but wasnt sure how  the manual was back at the hotel.

description: Dan Freed, a 36-year-old journalist and a new Brooklyn resident, has long had a knack for finding places to swim. In Chicago, where he grew up, it was Lake Michigan, and during the eight years he lived in East Harlem, he walked to Central Park, to the Lasker Rink and Pool, an unusual hybrid designed for swimming in warm weather and ice skating in the cold.

title: Adjusted Income
description: Lets start by saying I have a lot of money. Ive acquired it by writing childrens books about terrible things happening to orphans, and this seems like such a crazy and possibly monstrous way of acquiring money that I give a lot of it away. I mean, I guess its a lot. Let me put it like this: My wife and I recently became obsessed with a Web site where you plug in the amount of money you made in a year and find out where you stand. If your salary equaled the amount of money my wife and I gave Planned Parenthood one year, youd be in the richest 1 percent in the world, which is pretty great. Still, there would be 60 million people richer than you, and thats a lot. They wouldnt fit in your home, for example, even though youd have the sort of home that only the top 1 percent of people in the world can afford.

title: Sweet Teens

title: The Age of Abundance
description: On July 24, 1959, in the depths of the Cold War, Vice President Richard Nixon and Soviet premier Nikita Khrushchev stood face-to-face, close enough to smell each other's breath. Dozens of journalists and dignitaries crowded around them in increasingly nervous silence as the two argued heatedly. Khrushchev, the bald, brash son of Ukrainian peasants, raised his booming voice and waved his stubby hands in the air. Nixon, nearly a head taller, hovered over him, struggling to maintain his composure but then jabbing a finger into his adversary's chest. Precipitating this superpower showdown was a disagreement over ... washing machines.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE POSSIBILITY OF AN ISLAND, by Michel Houellebecq. Translated by Gavin Bowd. (Vintage International, $14.95.) In this ingenious novel by a French author and provocateur, Daniel, a middle-aged film producer and emotional failure, joins a cult of sexually promiscuous health fanatics who achieve immortality through cloning. The narrative alternates between Daniel and one of his clones, Daniel24, who picks up the story of Daniel  and the story of human history  thousands of years in the future, when Daniel24 and his fellow neohumans live in a world ravaged by environmental disaster and almost completely devoid of human interaction. In the Book Review, Stephen Metcalf called this novel brilliant and searing and Houellebecqs antihero delightfully lubricious.

There are more than a dozen music festivals spanning the next two months. And most of the events are held outside, in relatively small parks or venues, under beautiful breezy summer sunsets. Tickets are cheap and the music ranges from mainstream to classical to Italian opera to wonderfully eclectic ethnic bands. Last summer I saw Senegalese superstar Youssou NDour, with his crystalline voice, a Portugese jazz flutist and Eric Burden (yes, that Eric Burden  of the Animals and House of the Rising Sun fame).

SERE stands for Survival, Evasion, Resistance, and Escape  not Survival, Evasion, Reconnaissance and Escape.
