title: London Journal: Remembering an Aldeburgh Regular
description: ALDEBURGH, England  Understandably, the memory of Mstislav Rostropovich, who died in April, is permeating the festival here. The master cellist, impassioned conductor and courageous global citizen was a devoted friend of Benjamin Britten and Peter Pears. He and Britten first met in 1960 in Moscow at a concert, when Mr. Rostropovich played Shostakovichs First Cello Concerto. He soon became a regular at the festival and a frequent guest at Red House, the home of Britten and Pears here, now a library.

title: Politics and Cyberspace

A few of the e-advisers to the campaigns, namely those with the Clinton, Obama and McCain operations, also attended. They didnt give away many trade secrets, but offered some insights into what works and what doesnt at this stage of the election cycle.

title: Sunday Sampler Platter

The former secretary of state also said that he had met twice with Senator Barack Obama as the young Democratic presidential candidate sought foreign-policy advice. And the retired general and Bush administration veteran left open the distinct possibility of endorsing a non-Republicancandidate.

title: Two massive F1 stories in Canada
description: Between now and the U.S. Grand Prix in one week, there will be so much to talk about that I have decided to put up only two photographs of the two biggest stories in a Canadian Grand Prix that was just overflowing with stories. Below, the one massive story is that of Lewis Hamiltons victory, and its obvious repercussions, and the other of the accident from which Robert Kubica miraculously came out alive and with only a sprained ankle and a slight concussion. (In the confusion after the accidents, early reports said he had a broken right leg or a broken foot.)

title: The Three Atheists
description: Writings against God and religion have been around as long as God and religion have been around. But every so often an epidemic of the genre breaks out and a spate of such writings achieves the status of notoriety (which is what their authors had been aiming for). This has now happened to three books published in the last three years: Sam Harriss The End of Faith: Religion, Terror and The Future of Reason (2004, 2005), Richard Dawkinss The God Delusion (2006) and Christopher Hitchenss God is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything (2007). (Were this the kind of analysis performed in Lancelot Andrewess sermons, I would note the fact that the names of all three authors end in s, signifying, no doubt, the presence of Sin and Satan.)

description: For years, Johnny Five lived not on the streets but below them, in the dark underworld beneath an abandoned train station in the Bronx.

title: Warning: Trains Coming. A Masterpiece Is at Risk.
description: BARCELONA, Spain  With its soaring but impossibly slender columns and masonry that resembles heavy frosting, Antonio Gauds unfinished masterwork La Sagrada Familia seems as if it might suddenly collapse on itself, like a surreal cake.

title: John McGovern, 85, Allergist, Investor and Philanthropist, Dies
description: Dr. John P. McGovern, a Houston allergist and real-estate investor whose philanthropy helped endow medical facilities at Duke University, the Texas Medical Center and other institutions, died on May 31 in Galveston, Tex. He was 85.

title: Awaiting Real Sales From Virtual Shoppers
description: THE seven million or so inhabitants of Second Life, the three-dimensional online world, have spent millions of dollars on digital makeovers, clothing and other goods and services for their avatars.

title: Factional Violence Continues in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, June 11  Factional violence raged in Gaza today between the rival Palestinian factions, Hamas and Fatah, despite a new cease-fire that was supposed to have come into effect at 11 a.m.

title: Missing a Sweep, but Little Else
description: Todd Pletcher confessed that it had yet to become real to him. How he had led Rags to Riches to the paddock for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, then met the filly in the winners circle, where both were toasted for a rare racing feat. She had broken his 0-for-28 streak of futility in Triple Crown races; she had become the third filly to win in the 139 years of the Belmont, known as the Test of the Champion, and the first since Tanya in 1905.

title: Press Boxes Become an Afterthought, After the Thought of Luxury Seats
description: CHICAGO, June 6  The original press box at the 16-year-old U.S. Cellular Field was a fine place to cover a White Sox game. From their nest behind home plate, reporters could easily discern the spin of a curveball or hear the thwack of bat on ball.

title: The Night Christopher Wheeldon Met Oscar Wilde
description: Christopher Wheeldons new work, The Nightingale and the Rose, is mysterious, unwieldy and haunting. It is also one of his most beautiful and daringly imaginative works. But be warned: Nightingale may break your heart.

title: Economic Life After College
description: Commencement is a time for idealism.

description: To the Editor:

title: Marijuana Law in Connecticut Gains Ground
description: HARTFORD, June 10  Seventeen years ago, Mark Braunstein dived 60 feet off a footbridge into a river, landed wrong and became a paraplegic. A librarian at Connecticut College, Mr. Braunstein, 55, walks with the aid of crutches and leg braces. He smokes marijuana every three days or so to control the pain and spasms in his feet that would otherwise immobilize him.

title: Sonys Other Games Division Makes Push in New Direction
description: Sony has a long and colorful history of failure on the Internet. But there has been a bright spot, one Sony operation  Sony Online Entertainment, based in San Diego  has built a legitimately innovative and successful Internet business.

title: Looking Ahead
description: READING REPORTS Signals on inflation will come from reports on the Consumer Price Index (Friday), the Producer Price Index (Thursday) and the Feds beige book on regional economic conditions (Wednesday).

description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Finds Subtle Ways to Cast Herself as a Trailblazer
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is not much of a gambler, in politics or life: She refers to herself as part of the sensible center in the Senate, and only occasionally has she laid money on the table (blackjack is her game).

title: Sporadic Fighting Continues in Lebanon Refugee Camp
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 10  As the conflict between Lebanese soldiers and militants inspired by Al Qaeda entered its fourth week on Sunday, there was sporadic fighting at the Nahr al Bared Palestinian refugee camp where most of the earlier battles had taken place.

title: Bush Vows to Get Immigration Bill Passed
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 11  As he heads home from an eight-day European swing to face a hostile Congress, President Bush lashed out today at Democrats for scheduling a vote of no confidence on his attorney general, and vowed to get his stalled immigration legislation passed, saying, Ill see you at the bill signing.

title: Building a Mini Metropolis Known as the U.S. Open
description: When the United States Open begins this week at Oakmont Country Club outside Pittsburgh, a challenging, manicured golf course will be only part of the scene.

title: No Prize Money (This Time) for 9-Year-Old Star of Video Game Circuit
description: Victor M. De Leon III, a 9-year-old Long Island boy believed to be the worlds youngest professional video game player, finished out of the prize money in his latest tournament, the Major League Gaming Pro Circuit Event, which ended yesterday at the Meadowlands in New Jersey.

title: When Lots of Money Makes You Feel Rich
description: Anyone who has ever thrown around a stack of liras or rupees knows that people are sometimes more extravagant with currencies that have high face values. A paper recently published in The Journal of Consumer Research explored that effect.

title: Pinning Down the Money Value of a Persons Life
description: HOW much is your life worth? How about a year of life? How much is your vision worth? What about being pain-free? Able to walk unassisted? Have sex?

title: As Legislative Session Wanes, So Does Leaders Momentum
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer would have preferred more progress by now, with two weeks left in the legislative session.

title: Rolling Stone Finding Out Green Isnt Green Enough
description: Just about every major magazine has made some sort of nod to global warming, and Rolling Stone plans to do so in its June 28 issue: on top of the requisite interview with former Vice President Al Gore and an essay by the environmentalist Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the magazine will start printing on paper that is said to have less of a negative impact on the environment.

title: Onetime Mob Stronghold Hears Echo of the Old Days
description: On Bath Avenue, in a part of Brooklyn once dominated by gangsters and wiseguys, times have changed.

title: Path to 300 Wins Gets Rocky for Glavine
description: DETROIT, June 10  Tom Glavine lay on the Comerica Park grass, his body contorted in a position as uncomfortable as his afternoon. He had just flipped a ball to the backstop, giving Detroit yet another run, and his momentum caused him to tumble forward so that his knees touched his nose. He stayed there for a few seconds, stuck in a moment he could not escape, then rose to one knee and gazed toward the outfield.

title: Health Costs Push Companies to Set Targets for Workers
description: WATCH your cholesterol and triglycerides. Your boss and fellow workers are counting on it. As the nations employers aim to get their moneys worth from ever more expensive medical insurance, many are playing a bigger role in managing and monitoring their workers health.

title: Homer J. Stewart, 91, Aerospace Engineer, Dies
description: Homer J. Stewart, an aerospace engineer and rocket propulsion expert who in 1958 helped launch the first successful American satellite, Explorer 1, while he kept tabs on rival efforts by the Russians, died on May 26 at his home in Altadena, Calif. He was 91.

title: Newark: Girl Killed by Hit-and-Run Driver
description: A 12-year-old girl was killed by a hit-and-run driver last evening while she was attending the Portuguese Festival, the police said. The girl, identified as Kaitlyn Velez of Pennsylvania, was struck shortly before 6 p.m. near the intersection of Elm and Congress Streets by a blue Econoline van with the word Construction on the side, the police said. The van sped off and the girl was taken to University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital, where she died. The police were looking for the driver last night.

title: New CDs
description: QUEENS OF THE STONE AGE Era Vulgaris (Interscope)

title: A Test of the Senate
description: The Senate has scheduled a no-confidence vote today on Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. No one who has followed the news needs to be told why it is necessary. Mr. Gonzales is the Michael Brown of the Justice Department, smilingly presiding over incompetence, chaos and malfeasance, while President Bush insists that he is doing a heck of a job. Todays vote should get the support not only of Democrats, but of every Republican senator concerned about the American justice system.

title: Takeover Zeal in the News Industry Is Seen Subsiding
description: The McClatchy Company bought Knight Ridder and then sold pieces of it, the Tribune Company took itself private under a plan devised by the real estate developer Samuel Zell, and Rupert Murdoch has mounted a strong run at Dow Jones & Company all in the last year.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: States Finding Fiscal Surprise: A Cash Surplus
description: State lawmakers across the country, their coffers unexpectedly full of cash, have been handing out tax cuts, spending money on fixing roads, schools and public buildings, and socking something away for less fruitful years.

title: Spurs Show No Mercy in Dismantling Cavaliers
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 10  It was understood, even before the N.B.A. finals got going last week, that the San Antonio Spurs were a fearsome force, capable of great and powerful things. It appears they can be a little destructive, too.

title: Putin Plays Down I.M.F. and W.T.O.
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, June 10  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called Sunday for a new global economic framework that would play down the role of institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization and instead emphasize regional alliances.

title: Outspoken Political Scientist Denied Tenure at DePaul
description: Norman Finkelstein, the political scientist whose bid for a permanent position at DePaul University stirred up charges of anti-Semitism, personal vendettas and outside interference in the hiring process, was informed Friday that he had been denied tenure by the university.

title: Blast in Kenya Kills One
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11  A mysterious explosion rocked downtown Nairobi this morning, killing one person, possibly the bomber, and injuring 31 others.

title: Ethics in Medicine (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gordon Gambles on the Weather and Wins at Pocono
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 10  At the moment Jeff Gordon won his fourth Nextel Cup race of the season Sunday night, his blue Chevrolet was covered with a rain-spattered tarpaulin and was parked on pit road, 235 miles from the scheduled finish.

title: Mandatory Coverage Is Easier Said Than Done
description: ITS a seemingly simple solution to a nationwide problem: if people do not have health insurance, just require that they buy it. The idea of making coverage compulsory to help reduce the number of uninsured Americans  currently 45 million  is gaining momentum. With a law passed last year, Massachusetts became the first state to mandate coverage. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California has supported the idea, proposing that his state do the same. In Illinois, mandatory health insurance has become part of a broader discussion of health reform.

title: We Have Always Depended on Strangeness of Families
description: Three HBO tragedies have comedic set-ups. A middle-class mob boss seeks therapy. A groovy Los Angeles family lives in a mortuary. And, most recently, a Utah entrepreneur has three wives.

title: Manhattan: Man Killed in Hit-Run Accident
description: A Brooklyn man was killed when he was struck by a car while crossing East 22nd Street early yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Matthew Hopkins, 26, of Montgomery Street, was crossing near the intersection of Park Avenue South about 4:09 a.m. when he was hit by a 1991 Honda, which continued without stopping, the police said. No arrests had been made yesterday evening.

title: Ousmane Sembne, 84, Dies; Led Cinemas Advance in Africa
description: Ousmane Sembne, the Senegalese filmmaker and writer who was a crucial figure in Africas postcolonial cultural awakening, has died at his home in Dakar, Senegal. His family, which announced his death on Sunday, said Mr. Sembne had been ill since December. He was 84.

title: A TheirSpace for Drug Sales Reps
description: THE drug sales representative was expecting a $12,000 performance bonus. Unfortunately, the reps chance to jump to a better job at another drug company required that the move be made a month before the bonus would be issued. Was it possible to start the new job without the old employer knowing and still collect the bonus?

title: Environmental Bounty Hunters, on Trail of Cash, Are in California Officials Sights
description: In the great traditions of the Old West, California deputizes bounty hunters to help enforce its environmental laws.

title: Who Pays for Efficiency?
description: SAVING money can be expensive.

title: U.S. Arming Sunnis in Iraq to Battle Old Qaeda Allies
description: BAGHDAD, June 10  With the four-month-old increase in American troops showing only modest success in curbing insurgent attacks, American commanders are turning to another strategy that they acknowledge is fraught with risk: arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past.

title: Forget Tickling the Keys, Its All About the Power
description: OJAI, Calif., June 10  Behind the rise of the all-powerful Romantic movement was the piano and its essential paradox: a percussion instrument (hit it, and it makes noise) that would be tamed and stroked until it sang like the human voice. By the 1920s music had had enough of this romance and returned the instrument to its primary nature: hit it, and it sounds like a drum.

title: Bankruptcy Filing May Delay Pornography on Cellphones
description: Ampd Mobiles filing for protection from bankruptcy on June 1 may have one unexpected side effect: a delay in the introduction of sex-oriented programming on cellphones.

title: Treasury Sales Set
description: The Treasurys schedule of financings this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Top Editor Is Leaving Book Post
description: Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group who was hired four years ago for his strong literary credentials, is leaving the company at the end of June.

title: Marketers Are Joining the Varsity
description: Athletes, if they are talented, train hard and get a break or two, can climb the sports ladder from high school to college to the pros. Madison Avenue, sensing a lucrative opportunity, is heading the other way.

title: Longing in England: Death in Venice on Two Stages
description: ALDEBURGH, England, June 10  Many devotees of Benjamin Britten feel that his final opera, Death in Venice, based on the Thomas Mann novella and first presented at the Aldeburgh Festival in 1973, is a profound, piercing and inexplicably neglected masterpiece. At the moment, though, the opera seems anything but neglected, at least in Brittens native land. The Aldeburgh Festival, which Britten helped found, is presenting a grippingly austere production of the opera, its first staging here in nearly 30 years. The first performance, on Friday night, provided a momentous opening for this renowned festivals 60th anniversary.

title: Schumer to Propose New College Loan Rules
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer and Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday announced a plan to change college loan applications. The proposal, which Senator Schumer said he would introduce as federal legislation, would require that lenders detail loan amounts, interest and fees in a table on loan applications. A high school graduate shouldnt need a law degree to pick a loan for college, Mr. Schumer said in a statement.

title: As Fifth Ave. Brims With Pride, Even the Horses Dance
description: As the sidewalks along Fifth Avenue began to fill and the bands took their places behind the police and the politicians for yesterdays Puerto Rican Day Parade, Tony Flores took a deep breath and smiled.

title: Nadal Defeats Federer for French Open Title
description: PARIS, June 10  With clay the color of terra cotta caked on his clothes, Rafael Nadal climbed into the grandstand Sunday at Roland Garros to celebrate his third consecutive French Open victory.

title: Iraqs Parliament Leaders Agree to Remove Speaker
description: BAGHDAD, June 10  Iraqs leading political blocs on Sunday agreed to replace the speaker of Parliament, Mahmoud Mashhadani, a Sunni, after hearing accusations that his bodyguards assaulted a Shiite lawmaker as the speaker cursed him and then dragged him to the speakers office.

title: Take Me Out to the Bling Blineo (I Dont Care if I Ever Get Back)
description: It seemed like a great idea: a reggaetn grudge match in Shea Stadium on the eve of the Puerto Rican Day parade. Daddy Yankee and Don Omar  two of the genres biggest stars, and longtime rivals  were scheduled to be the headliners at El Bling Blineo, a Saturday night concert organized (and tirelessly promoted) by the reggaetn radio station La Kalle, 105.9 FM.

title: Brooklyn: Man Shot and Killed in Street
description: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot shortly after 11 a.m. yesterday in a fight on the street in Bushwick, the authorities said. Acquaintances identified the man as Jose Torres, who they said was in his early 20s. He was pronounced dead at the scene, near the corner of Stanhope Street and Wyckoff Avenue, where, a witness said, he had been shot several times. The witness, who declined to be identified by name, said that Mr. Torres was riding his bicycle when he was approached by the other man. When Mr. Torres got off the bicycle and began fighting, the other man pulled out a gun and fired, the witness said. The police arrested Adrian Aguiliar, 30, of Brooklyn and charged him with murder and criminal possession of a weapon.

title: Citys White Elephant Now Looks Like a Transit Workhorse
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va., June 4  During its troubled years of construction and testing in the early 1970s, the Personal Rapid Transit system that snakes through this hilly college town was derided as a fiasco and a waste of money that perhaps should be dynamited rather than finished.

title: Spring Awakening and Coast of Utopia Rack Up Tony Awards
description: The 61st annual Tony Awards last night were dominated by two shows drawn from the 19th century: Spring Awakening, about sexually frustrated German teenagers in that era, won best musical and most of the other musical awards, while The Coast of Utopia, Tom Stoppards epic period trilogy about Russian intellectuals, set a record for the most awards won by a play in Tony history.

title: A Spectrum of Disputes
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Democrats Say They May Revisit Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Senate Democrats opened the door to reviving the stalled immigration measure on Sunday, calling on Republicans to resolve their internal divisions and produce an agreement on how to move the legislation forward.

title: Pakistans Dictator
description: If Gen. Pervez Musharraf were the democratic leader he indignantly insists he is, he would not be so busy threatening independent news outlets, arresting hundreds of opposition politicians and berating parliamentary leaders and ministers from his own party for insufficient loyalty to his arbitrary and widely unpopular policies.

title: In Biotech Brews, Questions of Consistency
description: VACAVILLE, Calif.

title: Mental Health in Prisons
description: The New York State Legislature set an important national example when it passed a bill that would dramatically improve treatment for mentally ill prison inmates. Gov. Eliot Spitzer seems to regard the bill as unnecessary and tried to head it off by making changes of his own earlier this spring. But Mr. Spitzers tinkering is no substitute for the thoroughgoing reforms in this bill, which would end once and for all the horrific maltreatment and neglect that mentally ill inmates suffer in New York.

title: Box Office for Horror Movies Is Weak, Verging on Horrible
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10  Moviegoers put a nail in the coffin of a dying horror boom this weekend, as Hostel: Part II opened to just $8.8 million in ticket sales, far behind the crime caper Oceans Thirteen in a three-day period of relatively soft box office performance.

title: Station Astronauts Examine Shuttle
description: The crew of the International Space Station welcomed the seven astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis aboard on Sunday, the third day of the shuttles mission.

title: A Dog or a Cat? New Tests to Fool Automated Spammers
description: On the Internet, nobody knows youre a human  until you fill out a captcha.

title: Yankees Keep Smashing Their Way Toward .500
description: The offense was relentless and merciless yesterday, but that has been the case a lot lately. The Yankees are scoring runs in bunches, and they are getting contributions from a player whose season once appeared to be a lost cause. Add pitching that has been effective if not spectacular, and you have a six-game winning streak from a team that no longer resembles the underachieving bunch that stumbled its way through April and May.

title: Call the Doctor
description: When the news broke last month that significant questions had been raised about an increase in the risk of a heart attack for users of Avandia, I followed the reports with a bit more avidity than most.

title: Investing: WebMDs Fever Chart
description: CAPITALIZING on the national preoccupation with things medical, WebMD Health has built the most-visited and fastest-growing health site on the Internet. Should investors click on its stock?

title: Musharraf Rescinds Media Regulations After Public Outcry
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 10  Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has formally withdrawn his decree that imposed new regulations on the news media, government officials said over the weekend. The president made his decision after he met with industry leaders, and after journalists and opposition parties strongly protested the decree, officials said.

title: A Few Details of the iPhone Galvanize the Apple Cadre
description: These days advertisers fret over DVR owners fast-forwarding through their commercials, but that was far from the case with the release by Apple last week of four iPhone commercials, which viewers pored over with Talmudic intensity.

title: Revolution, as in Beatles (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: For LeBron James, Baptism by Finals Fire
description: San Antonio

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Pettersens Putts Seal L.P.G.A. Championship
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 10  All Suzann Pettersen had to do to win her first major championship Sunday was two-putt from 30 feet. As she stood over her uphill putt on her 72nd hole of the L.P.G.A. Championship, the fans surrounding the 18th green grew quiet.

title: No-Confidence Vote on Gonzales Fails in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Senate Democrats fell short this afternoon in their effort to hold a vote of no confidence in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales but still registered a strong, if symbolic, rebuke of the nations chief law enforcement officer.

title: Iraqs Parliament Votes to Remove Speaker
description: BAGHDAD, June 11  Just over two-thirds of the 168 Iraqi parliament members present at todays session voted in favor of a resolution to remove the bodys speaker, Mahmoud Mashhadani, opening the way for the coalition of Sunni political groups who had installed him last year to replace him.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) BIG LOVE The Henricksons, Americas favorite polygamists, return for a new season on a new night, with some damage control in the wake of the familys exposure when wife No. 1, Barb, was being considered for mother of the year. (And with seven children scattered among three homes, why not?) Tonight the patriarch Bill (Bill Paxton, above with Jeanne Tripplehorn) scrambles to find out who betrayed him, and Barb (Ms. Tripplehorn) retreats into her own world, leaving wives No. 2, Nicki (Chlo Sevigny), and No. 3, Margene (Ginnifer Goodwin), to pick up the slack. Meanwhile Roman (Harry Dean Stanton) tries to intimidate Joey (Shawn Doyle) after Joeys wife, Wanda (Melora Waters), poisoned Romans son, Alby (Matt Ross). And back at home, the eldest daughter, Sarah (Amanda Seyfried), catches the eye of Scott (Aaron Paul) at a meeting for ex-Mormons.

title: NBC Studied Dow Jones Bid With Microsoft
description: General Electrics NBC unit and Microsoft explored making a joint bid for Dow Jones but decided against it a week ago, a person close to NBC and Microsoft said yesterday.

title: The Former Queen of Buzz Conjures a Golden Heyday
description: Tina Brown, the once highly conspicuous editor of Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and the short-lived Talk, has just written The Diana Chronicles, about the British princess who, like her, reigned as a golden girl over the transatlantic media world during the 1980s and 90s.

title: Battle for Bermuda Bowl Slot Turns Close With a Late Surge
description: As the final of the trial to select the U.S.A.-2 team for this years Bermuda Bowl headed toward its conclusion late last night in Shaumburg, Ill., what had seemed a runaway suddenly turned close. The 120-board match pitted Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell against Russ Ekeblad, Ron Rubin, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby, with Ekeblad surging late. (The final result is at usbf.org.)

title: The Poets of War
description: Last month I invited readers to send in poems for my second Iraq Poetry Contest.

title: Libbys Supporters Who Wrote to Judge Learn That Letters Take on New Life on the Web
description: In what may be a sign of things to come, the lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. last month invoked the rarely used courtroom tactic: the bloggers can be mean defense.

title: New Passport Rules Bring Worry Over Tourism at Niagara Falls
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 10  Standing at Prospect Point in Niagara Falls State Park, Paul Cranley looked through the mist formed by millions of gallons of water dropping more than 160 feet to the gorge below.

title: Cosmetics Heir to Lead World Jewish Congress
description: Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics magnate, won his bid to become the first elected president of the World Jewish Congress, the tiny nonprofit group that faced down some of the worlds largest banks to win billions for Holocaust victims but is now struggling to recover from scandals resulting from lax financial controls.

title: Israeli Airstrikes, Aiming at Militants, Hit Gaza City
description: JERUSALEM, June 10  The Israeli Air Force struck at least two buildings in Gaza City early Sunday morning in what appeared to be a response to a raid across the Gaza-Israel border by Palestinian militants on Saturday.

title: Cottos Knockout Victory Against Judah Fails to Impress Mayweather Jr.
description: Miguel Cottos dominating victory against Zab Judah on Saturday night has lifted him to a new level of prominence. But he still lacks the leverage to earn the biggest fight out there: against Floyd Mayweather Jr., considered by many to be the best pound-for-pound boxer in the world.

title: Queens Leader Supports Bloombergs Traffic Plan
description: The Bloomberg administrations plan to charge drivers in the busiest parts of Manhattan won support yesterday from Representative Joseph Crowley, the influential chairman of the Queens Democratic Party, whose endorsement could help reshape the fight where resistance to the plan has been among the strongest, in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: What She Wants: Retro, Soul and Hip-Hop (Just a Little Bit)
description: Joss Stone came to Central Park SummerStage on Friday night with a full soul band, complete with horns and backup singers. Shes just 20 years old and English, but she has decided her favorite music was made in the United States years before she was born: soul from about 1964 to 1974.

title: Taliban Fire Rockets During Speech by Karzai
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 10  Militants fired rockets on a district town on Sunday as President Hamid Karzai was giving an address to elders and residents during a visit to Ghazni Province, south of Kabul, officials said.

title: An Editors Untimely Departure Is Captured in Just a Flicker
description: Call it a bit of a video killed the radio star moment, circa 2007: John Curley, who had been a deputy managing editor of The San Francisco Chronicle, announced that he was let go from the newspaper by posting the news on Flickr, the photo-sharing Web site.

title: Need a Knee Replaced? Check Your ZIP Code.
description: WHY does health care for the average Medicare patient cost nearly twice as much a year in New Jersey, at $8,076, as it does in Hawaii, at $4,529?

title: Both Sides Say Project Is Pivotal Issue for Brazil
description: PORTO VELHO, Brazil  The eternal tension between Brazils need for economic growth and the damage that can cause to the environment are nowhere more visible than here in this corner of the western Amazon region.

title: On Rough Day, a Rookie Arrives
description: MONTREAL, June 10 (AP)  Lewis Hamilton, the first black driver in Formula One history, added his first series victory to an already remarkable rsum by winning the Canadian Grand Prix on Sunday.

title: Queens: Three Men Stabbed in Fight
description: Three men were stabbed, one of whom was critically injured, in a fight in Astoria early yesterday, the police said. The men, whom the police did not identify, were arguing with another group near Club Fashion, on Steinway Street, about 3 a.m. when someone in the other group stabbed them, the police said. One man, who was stabbed in the neck and chest, was in critical condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center, the police said. The other two men suffered minor cuts. No arrests had been made.

title: Colt Versus Filly: Whats All the Fuss?
description: During the stretch run of the Preakness Stakes, American racing fans screamed as Street Sense and Curlin battled to the wire. Spectacular, heart-pounding and remarkable were the adjectives that appeared in the papers the next day.

title: Market Owner Is Cited in Fire Where 5 Men Were Trapped
description: The owner of a Queens supermarket was accused yesterday of violating city codes after a blaze on Friday night in which firefighters rescued five workers who had been locked inside the store and were found in the basement, huddled, crying and blackened by smoke.

title: Sarkozys Party Heads Toward Huge Legislative Majority in France
description: PARIS, Monday, June 11  President Nicolas Sarkozys center-right party was on course to win an overwhelming parliamentary majority after the first round of French legislative elections on Sunday, cementing his power to enact changes that he says are needed to rescue France from economic and social malaise.

title: At Creative Artists, a Bit of Blushing After a Corporate Kiss-Off
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10  For the powers at the Creative Artists Agency, Hollywoods pre-eminent talent representative, the coming blockbuster Transformers has already brought a lesson in the cold-hearted ways of corporate entertainment.

title: Thousands Hail Bush in Visit to Albania
description: TIRANA, Albania, June 10  His poll numbers may be in the basement, but when he zipped through this small, relentlessly pro-American nation on Sunday, President Bush was treated like a rock star.

title: For Snow, Beating Expectations Is Part of Game
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 10  The Cleveland Cavaliers finals fate will probably not turn on an Eric Snow jump shot, pass or hand check of Tony Parker. But if Snow somehow saves the series, it may not even qualify as the most unlikely development of his N.B.A. career.

title: Judge Throws Out Sentence in Teen Sex Case
description: ATLANTA, June 11  A Georgia Superior Court judge today ordered the release of Genarlow Wilson, who has served two years of 10-year prison sentence for having consensual oral sex with another teenager at a party when he was 17. Prosecutors said they would appeal the order.

title: In Pursuing Vick, Government Bares Its Teeth
description: Michael Vick may or may not have played a role in an apparent dog fighting ring. But Vick, the Atlanta Falcons besieged quarterback. has already been indicted in the court of public opinion and by the news media, which increasingly embrace the presumption of guilt as vital to entertainment value.

title: Nonorganic Exceptions Ruffle Enthusiasts of Organic Food
description: The latest battle over what can be called organic involves beer and gelatin, food colorings and casings for sausage. The Department of Agriculture, the final arbiter of all things organic, is poised to approve a list of nonorganic ingredients that can be used in food stamped with its green-and-white organic seal.

title: Whats the Flavor of the Month? Medical Devices.
description: LUKE EVNIN contends there is money to be made giving people with fading vision a poke in the eye.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,494 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

title: Will I Ever Be O.K. Again?
description: Like I said before, I was at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda. Md., when I first returned. This was an interesting time; I was on enough pain medicine to tranquilize a small militia. I had some very creative hallucinations. When I was still in bad shape my nurse left on Univision while I was sleeping. The next morning I woke up speaking Spanish. One night the N.B.A. draft was left on T.V. for the evening. When I awoke the next morning, I hired my brother J.P. as my agent. When you are drafted in the second round by the Dallas Mavericks you need an agent. My first instructions to him were to get me a Rolex. I had to fire him, as it has been almost three years and he has not gotten me signed and I still do not have my Rolex.

title: Hopeful Signs From China and India?
description: Fears are growing about the polluting power of India and China. The reason is clear enough: Both countries are industrializing fast and pumping out vast amounts of greenhouse gases to meet global demand for their goods. Yet governments in both countries continue to marshal two powerful arguments to resist calls to cut their greenhouse gas emissions. First, China and India emit less pollution per person than developed-world countries and secondly, Chinese and Indian officials say pollution constraints would impede lifting millions out of poverty.

title: Sherritt Deal Gets Thumbs Up from Dynatec Shareholders

title: Passport Pandemonium
description: PASSPORT PANDEMONIUM The confusion and delays in passport processing are a warning to plan far ahead to renew or obtain a passport, travel industry trade groups say. Since Jan 23, United States citizens as well as those from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean have been required for the first time to present a valid passport when entering the United States by air. A rush for passports has created long processing delays, partly because of confusion among some travelers, who mistakenly thought they needed a passport to return to the United States from Canada or Mexico by car. That requirement will not take effect until next year. Maura Harty, the assistant secretary of state for consular affairs, said that the demand for passports was over and beyond even the enormous demand we had expected, leading to the delays. In response, the State Department adjusted the rules so that through Sept. 30, those who can show proof they have applied for a passport, even if they have not received it, are exempt. The required documents are a government-issued photo ID and a printout showing that they have applied for a passport, which can be downloaded from travel.state.gov.passport.

title: Central African Republic: Aid Worker Shot Dead
description: A French aid worker with the group Doctors Without Borders was killed in a volley of gunfire in an area of this vast and lawless country that had recently suffered through a rebel attack and army reprisals. The worker, a 27-year-old logistics specialist named Elsa Serfass, was part of an assessment mission that was sent to evaluate the medical needs of displaced villagers, the latest victims of an increasingly violent conflict between rebels in the northwest of the country and government troops. Dozens of villages have been set on fire in the last 18 months as the army has tried to flush out the rebels, forcing nearly 300,000 to flee their homes.

title: Battling a Nasty Green Invader From the Deep
description: SCHROON, N.Y.  Nosing into a shallow bay on Schroon Lake, Steve LaMere peered over the side of his pontoon boat. He was on an unusual reconnaissance mission, looking for signs of an aggressive aquatic invader, a stringy herb from Eurasia that once adorned American aquariums but has no business here in the Adirondacks  or anywhere in North America.

title: After the Bomb
description: THE probability of a nuclear weapon one day going off in an American city cannot be calculated, but it is larger than it was five years ago. Potential sources of bombs or the fissile materials to make them have proliferated in North Korea and Iran. Russias arsenal remains incompletely secured 15 years after the end of the Soviet Union. And Pakistans nuclear technology, already put on the market once by Abdul Qadeer Khan, could go to terrorists if the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, cannot control radicals in that country.

title: New Jersey Is Closer to Letting Voters Decide on Property Tax Relief
description: TRENTON, June 11  A standoff over a 1-cent sales tax increase led to a government shutdown last year. But on Monday, the Assembly voted 79 to 1 to allow voters to decide whether they wanted all of the proceeds of that increase to go toward property tax relief for local governments.

title: A Compass That Can Clash With Modern Life
description: CAIRO, June 11  First came the breast-feeding fatwa. It declared that the Islamic restriction on unmarried men and women being together could be lifted at work if the woman breast-fed her male colleagues five times, to establish family ties. Then came the urine fatwa. It said that drinking the urine of the Prophet Muhammad was deemed a blessing.

title: A Filmmaker Who Found Africas Voice
description: Ousmane Sembne, by consensus the father of African cinema, was nearly 40 when he started making films. (He was 84 when he died over the weekend at his home in Dakar). By 1960, the year that Senegal, his native country, won its independence from France, he was already a novelist of some reputation in Francophone African circles.

title: Bush, on European Tour, Perfects the Art of Meet and Run
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 11  Its good to be here in your beautiful country, President Bush told President Georgi Parvanov of Bulgaria on Monday morning. He would be in the beautiful country for roughly 20 hours, half of them spent inside his hotel. In the world of White House travel, that is an eternity.

title: Afghan Forces Found Bomb Like Type Used in Iraq
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 11  Afghan security forces found a sophisticated roadside bomb of the type used in Iraq in the center of Kabul last month, the first time such a device has been discovered in the capital, an Afghan intelligence official said Monday. The bomb was primed to hit a convoy of high-ranking Afghan officials or international forces, the official said.

title: Renewal: Not Just for Library Books Anymore
description: There is the Security Council and the World Council of Churches, the Council of Europe and innumerable city councils. Now, a leading lodging chain is adding to the assembly of assemblages with what it is calling a Renewal Council.

title: State Bar Weighs Law License of Duke Prosecutor
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 12  Michael B. Nifong, the prosecutor who brought rape charges against three Duke University students, found himself in a crowded courtroom today with the tables turned. Mr. Nifongs law license is hanging in the balance of an ethics trial focused on his motives and tactics in pursuing the now-dismissed case.

title: In Mexico, Diabetes Strains Lives and Budgets
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11  Ten years after she learned she had Type 2 diabetes, Teresa Snchez bought her first blood sugar meter, a small, hand-held device that cost $100, a quarter of her monthly pension.

title: The Irresistible Fantasy of the Invisible Man, and Machine
description: Humans have always dreamed of invisibility. Perseus, in Greek mythology, had a cap to make him disappear. Leprechauns and other magical creatures did it on their own.

title: Discovering Good Fun in Mournful Dark Moods
description: A mournful streak runs through the lyrics of Architecture in Helsinki, like these from The Cemetery: I dont wanna fall face down/In the flood of the tears from the years that we loved and we messed up. But those words, like most of the bands set on Friday night at Fillmore New York (the renamed Irving Plaza), arrived with manic glee.

title: Euro RSCG to Create Cracker Ads for Kraft
description: Kraft Foods in Northfield, Ill., has awarded the North American creative assignments for the Ritz and Triscuit lines of crackers to Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas. Spending was estimated at $50 million.

title: Campaigning as Trailblazer, by Proxy and Association
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is not much of a gambler, in politics or life: She refers to herself as part of the sensible center in the Senate, and only occasionally has she laid money on the table (blackjack is her game).

title: Court to Weigh Disparities in Cocaine Laws
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Supreme Court, expanding its review of federal criminal sentencing, agreed Monday to consider the proper judicial response to the sharp disparity in the way the law treats crack cocaine and cocaine powder.

title: Hes Cornering the Market on Misfit TV Heroes
description: Denis Leary would seem an unlikely candidate to become the Dick Wolf of dark, morally muddied TV series about firefighters, cops and lawyers  and perhaps no more so than on a morning last week on an Upper East Side playground.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about commencement speeches at colleges around the country referred imprecisely to comments by Boyd Tinsley, an electric violinist in the Dave Matthews Band, at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. He spoke the day before graduation at the universitys valedictory exercises, not at the commencement. As the roundup of speeches noted, the novelist John Grisham was the commencement speaker.

title: 9 Die in Fierce Palestinian Factional Fighting
description: JERUSALEM, June 11  The worst factional fighting in nearly a month raged among Palestinians on Monday, with gunmen reportedly firing at the prime ministers home and office and violence elsewhere in Gaza leaving at least nine dead.

title: New DVDs
description: LATE OZU

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,499 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: In Parting Shot, Blair Calls Press a Feral Beast
description: LONDON, June 12  In the land that produced Scoop, Evelyn Waughs novel of journalistic ambition and ineptitude, it would seem unsurprising for politicians to criticize reporters on occasion. But was it justified, as Prime Minister Tony Blair did today, to call the press a feral beast?

title: Silver Challenges Health Benefits Promised in Manhattan Toll Plan
description: ALBANY, June 11  Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, in his strongest language yet against Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to charge people who drive into the most congested parts of Manhattan during the day, questioned the health benefits of the proposal yesterday. He also suggested that many of the environmental goals Mr. Bloomberg has outlined could be accomplished without congestion pricing.

title: The Divide in Caring for Our Kids
description: A few weeks ago, Teri Hatcher, one of the stars of the television series Desperate Housewives, was on David Lettermans show, talking very animatedly about a time when her daughter needed emergency dental care.

title: Cancer Drug Representatives Spelled Out the Way to Profit
description: Medicares decision to reform the way it paid for cancer drugs came after a decade in which oncologists collectively made billions of dollars on the drugs they prescribed. Many doctors say those profits did not affect their prescribing patterns.

title: Princeton Track Team to Compete in China
description: Overseas trips were once common for Ivy League track teams. Until a half-century ago, meets frequently involved the combined teams of Oxford and Cambridge against colleges like Yale, Harvard and Princeton.

title: U.S. Warns Iraq That Progress Is Needed Soon
description: BAGHDAD, June 11  The top American military commander for the Middle East has warned Iraqs prime minister in a closed-door conversation that the Iraqi government needs to make tangible political progress by next month to counter the growing tide of opposition to the war in Congress.

title: A Work in a Prism, Offering Varied Points of View
description: How does a ballerina solve a problem like Aurora? Its no easy task, especially when she is held captive by a production as muddled as American Ballet Theaters busy, dramaturge-heavy version of The Sleeping Beauty. Still, just as the frequent predicament of ballet in New York has become a variation on the theme of bad show, good dancers, five cast changes last week at the Metropolitan Opera House offered new interpretations  and glimmers of hope for the works future.

title: A Planet Is Too Hot for Life, but Another May Be Just Right
description: So much for the Goldilocks planet.

title: Dissident Challenges U.N. Role on Kosovo
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, June 11  Like countless ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Albin Kurti spent the weekend glued to his television set, watching President Bushs visit to Albania. He was eager to see what Mr. Bush would say from just across the border about Kosovos efforts to gain its independence from Serbia.

title: Mocking an Olympics Logo, but Loving the Attention
description: LONDON, June 11  Has any marketer ever gotten more for its money than the London Olympics organizers when they introduced a new logo for the 2012 Games?

title: Cricket Coach Not Murdered, Jamaican Police Say
description: MEXICO CITY, June 12  Jamaica police said today that Bob Woolmer, the Pakistani cricket coach who was found unconscious in his hotel room in March after his team lost in an upset in the Cricket World Cup, was not murdered as they had previously thought, but died of unspecified natural causes.

title: Over an Open Mike, Young Voices Speak in Verse
description: IT was 30 minutes before the open microphone part of the show was to begin, and one poet was already nervous.

title: Male Depression Is Linked to Poor Sibling Relations
description: Men who had poor relationships with siblings during childhood are at significantly greater risk for depression in adulthood than those who got along better, a new study has found.

title: A Chance of Yankee Thunder at Fenway
description: Projections in baseball are overused and meaningless. Its just plain foolish to say or think that because Alex Rodriguez hit 14 home runs in the Yankees first 18 games that hes going to hit 126 home runs this season. Not even Barry Bonds, in his body-boggling prime, could have done that.

title: Rising Rapper Is Fatally Shot Outside His Home in Queens
description: A 24-year-old Queens rapper whose career appeared to be on the rise was fatally shot as he was heading into his apartment building at 5 a.m. yesterday in Far Rockaway, the police said.

title: Manhattan: Six Charged With Trafficking in Stolen Cars
description: Six men were charged yesterday with altering identifying marks on hundreds of stolen cars and reselling them over the past eight years, federal prosecutors said. Operating from New York City, the men applied for automobile titles from states including New Jersey and Georgia, then altered them to disguise the fact that the cars were stolen, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. They also altered vehicle identification numbers, a practice known as retagging, Mr. Garcia said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies yesterday about Eric Snows role with the Cleveland Cavaliers in this years N.B.A. finals misstated the year of a previous trip to the finals by Snow when he was with Seattle. It was 1996, not 1995.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: ARK Advisors, which helps advertisers search for agencies, was opened by three longtime industry executives, who are all principals in the consulting company. They are Ann Billock, Ken Robinson and Russel Wohlwerth. Ms. Billock and Mr. Wohlwerth were formerly at A/Team Advertising Advisors, New York, and Mr. Robinson was formerly business development director at StrawberryFrog; he previously worked with Ms. Billock at Roth Associates. Ms. Billock and Mr. Robinson are based in New York and Mr. Wohlwerth is based in Los Angeles.

title: Educational Side Effects (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Immigration Bill Stalled (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Exercise: To Encourage Walking, Make It Personal
description: People who want some exercise often need to do little more than get off their, er, couches and go for a walk. Despite numerous studies linking walking to better health, many people cannot seem to bring themselves to do even that.

title: TV Writers Were Also Watching Sopranos
description: After he completed the final episode of The Sopranos, David Chase told publicity executives at HBO that he was leaving for France and would not take any calls asking him to comment about the ending of his classic television series.

title: Day of Split Outcomes in Teenage Sex Case
description: ATLANTA, June 11  A judge on Monday ordered the release of a man who is serving a widely criticized 10-year prison sentence without parole for having consensual oral sex with a 15-year-old girl when he was 17.

title: Qwest Chief Executive to Retire
description: Richard C. Notebaert, who is credited with bringing Qwest Communications back from an accounting scandal and the brink of bankruptcy, surprised investors yesterday by announcing that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman.

title: Peel Off the Layers, and Tiffany Peeks Out
description: Hidden beneath decades of modernization, the physical past often re-emerges to tell its story of old New York.

title: Soloists Run Small Businesses, Too
description: NOT everyone who starts a business wants to have employees.

title: Having a Baby: Home Visits May Reduce Infant Deaths, Findings Show
description: Health workers may be able to reduce the number of infant deaths by making regular visits before and after birth to the homes of pregnant women considered at risk.

title: Delay in Prosecution Brings an End to a Murder Charge
description: The case against John Sinagra was about as serious as they come: Prosecutors charged him with first-degree murder, saying he had acted on orders from a Colombo crime family capo, using information from a Federal Bureau of Investigation supervisor, to forever silence an 18-year-old man, a witness to a Mafia killing.

title: 3 Plead Not Guilty to String of New Jersey Bank Thefts
description: TRENTON, June 11  Three men accused of stealing more than $87,000 in a string of bank robberies in New Jersey, including an attempted robbery in April that led to the death of an F.B.I. agent, pleaded not guilty Monday in federal court here to conspiracy and other charges.

title: For Politicians in Britain, the Post-Blair Era Has Already Begun
description: LONDON, June 11  For the past few weeks, like a wannabe rock band on provincial tour, a clutch of British politicians has been crisscrossing the land, from Glasgow to Cardiff to Oxford.

title: U.N. Monitor Urges Defusing of Stalemate Over Iran
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The director general of the United Nations nuclear inspection agency warned Tehran and Washington for the first time on Monday that their yearlong stalemate over Irans nuclear activities was turning into a brewing confrontation that he said urgently needs to be defused.

title: Shuttle Mission Extended to Fix Insulation Blanket
description: NASA managers said Monday night that they would extend the mission of the space shuttle Atlantis for a spacewalk to repair a problem that could cause heating damage during re-entry.

title: Rare Stamps Fetch $9 Million
description: William H. Gross, the bond investor and chief investment officer of Pimco, confirmed his prowess in another area yesterday when his collection of 19th- and early 20th-century British stamps was auctioned in New York for $9.1 million.

title: Laborers Seek Back Wages in Lawsuits
description: The Asian-American Legal Defense and Education Fund filed four lawsuits yesterday on behalf of six Sikh and Bangladeshi laborers who are seeking to win thousands of dollars in what they claim are unpaid wages from five construction contractors. The suits  one filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, two in Federal District Court in Brooklyn and one in State Supreme Court in Queens  accuse the companies of breach of contract and violations of minimum-wage laws at construction sites, including a veterans hospital in Northport and a residential building in the Bronx.

title: Trade Board Deal Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (Dow Jones)  The Justice Department said on Monday that the proposed merger between Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings and Chicago Board of Trade Holdings would not pose a threat to competition.

title: Pettersen Adds Mind Game to Her Golf Game
description: HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., June 11  The target golf that Suzann Pettersen is playing these days has her taking direct aim at the worlds top-ranked female player, Lorena Ochoa.

title: Bush Lobbies G.O.P. Senators on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  President Bush made a rare trip to the Capitol today, meeting with Senate Republicans over lunch in an attempt to revive the immigration bill and vowing not to give up.

title: Sports Briefing
description: MARATHON

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) HAVE YOU SEEN ANDY? In August 1976 Andy Puglisi, 10 (middle, in turtleneck), disappeared from a public pool in Lawrence, Mass., where he was playing with dozens of children, including Melanie Perkins. In this documentary Ms. Perkins, now a filmmaker, looks for answers through interviews with other neighborhood children, Andys family, police officers and forensics experts, and uncovers new evidence in this still unsolved case.

title: YouTube Sets Tests of Video Blocking
description: Google says it will soon begin testing a long-awaited system that can block unauthorized copyrighted clips from being uploaded to YouTube, the popular video-sharing site it bought last year.

title: Celebrities Are Present; Mets Are Absent
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11  The celebrities came out to Dodger Stadium in droves Monday night. Wearing blue and orange, Jerry Seinfeld and Hilary Swank cheered on the Mets. Hedging his bets, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sported a Brooklyn Dodgers cap. Posh Spice flitted around before the game, receiving tips on how to throw a baseball.

title: Their Season in an Ebb, the Mets Show No Panic
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11  Unlike many 23-year-olds straight out of college, Joe Smith is making $380,000 this year. Enough money, one would think, to splurge for room service on the road and for high-speed Internet service in his Queens apartment. Out of habit, Smith is stuck in his Ramen-for-dinner ways, living the way he did a year ago at this time, when he was an unheralded third-round pick with a common name and an uncommon delivery.

title: Women Behind Bars, Real or Imaginary
description: Susanna Moore writes about women in search of an identity, women who are, more often than not, self-destructive, victimized, conflicted and desperate to escape or transcend an oppressive past. And she writes about these women in two utterly different modes: 1) the lyrical and nostalgic, which she used to enormous effect in her 2003 novel, One Last Look, and her early novels set in Hawaii (My Old Sweetheart, The Whiteness of Bones, Sleeping Beauties); and 2), the transgressive and graphic, which she used jarringly in her 1995 erotic thriller, In the Cut.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the leading movies in ticket sales over the weekend misstated the given name of the vice chairman of Lionsgate, who commented on the recent decline in sales for horror films like Hostel: Part II, which ranked sixth over the weekend. He is Michael Burns, not Mark.

title: Forging His Own Way in the Shadow of an Icon
description: People see the number, the short-cropped hair, the stiff-shouldered swagger, the pretty jump shot, and reach a logical conclusion. Sasha Pavlovic must be mimicking Drazen Petrovic, paying tribute to a former countryman, a linchpin on his favorite basketball team before it was Balkanized out of existence, into history.

title: Big Radio Makes a Grab for Internet Listeners
description: Last week a radio D.J. known as Vibegrrl, who works the midday shift on Hot 99.5, a Washington pop station, offered her listeners the chance to receive tickets to see the rock band Hinder.

title: Yankees Weigh Their Options and Draft a Pitcher With Two
description: As the only ambidextrous pitcher in college baseball, Pat Venditte can choose which arm he throws with. But when it comes to professional baseball, he has only one immediate choice: the Yankees.

title: Explosion Rocks Nairobi; Signs Point to Terrorism
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 11  A mysterious explosion, which witnesses described as a bomb, rocked downtown Nairobi on Monday morning, killing one person, possibly the bomber, and wounding 31 others.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in the special Circuits section on June 5 about ways to restore rich sound to digital music misstated the data rates at which compressed MP3 music files are recorded. The standard rate is 128 kilobits per second, not 128 bits per second. Higher, and better-sounding, rates are 160 and 190 kilobits per second.

title: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry of AIDS Spending
description: Two members of Congress have asked the Government Accountability Office to investigate what they called the H.I.V./AIDS crisis in Puerto Rico and the federal oversight of money provided for care of indigent AIDS patients there. In a letter to Comptroller General David M. Walker, the two lawmakers, Representative Nydia M. Velzquez, Democrat of New York, and Representative Hilda L. Solis, Democrat of California, cited testimony from community and patient groups in Puerto Rico and recent news accounts indicating that the Puerto Rican authorities have mismanaged federal money meant for groups helping AIDS patients, and that many patients have endured waits for lifesaving drug therapies. The letter called on the G.A.O. to scrutinize actions taken by the Health Resources and Services Administration, the federal agency that dispenses money under the Ryan White Care Act, to ensure that that money is better spent. Some $53 million went to Puerto Rico last year.

title: Sudan Surprise
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: When School Is Out, Getting Good Food In
description: No one can dispute that American children are fatter than ever. Much of the blame has been placed on schools  lunch programs high in calories, snack and soda machines in the schools and curtailed or absent physical activities during the school day.

title: That Nice Midwestern Mom, the One Whos Handy With a Knife
description: Its not a good sign when the most exciting moments in a play have to do with cutlery. Center stage in The Butcher of Baraboo, which incidentally is not about a theater critic in Wisconsin, is a humongous meat cleaver, so ominously prominent in this gothic comedy that at one point it even gets its own spotlight.

title: In Sudan, an Animal Migration to Rival Serengeti
description: The first aerial survey of southern Sudan in 25 years has revealed vast migrating herds, rivaling those of the Serengeti plains, that have managed to survive 25 years of civil war, the Wildlife Conservation Society and Southern Sudan will announce today at a news conference in New York.

title: For a Russian Builder of Nuclear Plants, Business Is Booming
description: MOSCOW, June 6  The Russian nuclear power company Atomstroyexport has been roundly criticized for helping Iran build its nuclear program. But neither that project nor the companys mouthful of a name has hurt its business prospects.

title: U.S. Pushes Iraqi Leader to Pursue Changes
description: BAGHDAD, June 12  Deputy Secretary of State John D. Negroponte visited Baghdad on Tuesday to pressure Iraqs Shiite-led government to complete a series of political changes intended to reconcile the countrys warring sects.

title: Fidelity Reports a 10.5% Stake in Delta Air Lines
description: Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund company, said yesterday in a regulatory filing that it held a 10.5 percent stake in Delta Air Lines.

title: Leaders for the Americas Cup Teams Have Different Perspectives
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 11  An edgy Americas Cup competition grew edgier Monday, when the head of Alinghi expressed disappointment with the oppositions plans and suggested that its leaders were ungrateful for the financial support he had provided when they were struggling to create a syndicate.

title: Still Dying in Congo
description: Darfur is not the only place where people are dying in staggering numbers. Conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo has taken more than three million lives in the last nine years. Since damping down a civil war in 2003, the outside world has largely focused on the struggle for power in the capital, Kinshasa, culminating in elections last year that were mostly free and fair.

title: Drug Maker Fined in Plavix Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb pleaded guilty on Monday to making false statements to a federal agency, ending an unusual criminal case involving its blockbuster blood-thinning drug Plavix.

title: Canadian Real Estate Concern Makes Bid for Australian Developer
description: OTTAWA, June 11  The Canadian real estate investor Brookfield Asset Management made a cash offer on Monday worth 4.2 billion Australian dollars ($3.55 billion) for Multiplex, a troubled Australian developer and contractor.

title: In the Company of Women: Pioneers, Mavericks and All
description: According to the American Symphony Orchestra League, works composed by women amounted to 1 percent of the music played by 300 of its member ensembles in the 2004-5 season. That sobering if unsurprising figure was cited in the program for Notable Women, a three-weekend festival the St. Lukes Chamber Ensemble is presenting at the Chelsea Art Museum and Dia:Beacon.

title: Spurs Winning Culture Has Other Teams Wanting the Secret
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 11  Tim Duncans team is halfway to its fourth championship, and in the distance, one can almost hear the commemorative DVDs being pressed and labeled.

title: Manhattan: Man Admits Role in Widespread Spam Campaign
description: A Brooklyn man admitted in Federal District Court yesterday that he had violated federal law by taking part in a widespread effort to send spam e-mail messages to America Online customers, federal prosecutors said. The man, Adam Vitale, 26, was charged with sending junk e-mail messages to 1.2 million subscribers in August 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Garcia said that Mr. Vitale admitted hiding the origin of the mail by using other computers to relay and transmit the spam. He faces up to 11 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

title: Solar Panels, Biofuel and Tidal Turbines in Bloomberg Plans
description: Moving to harness cleaner forms of energy to meet the citys growing power demands, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan yesterday to outfit municipal buildings with solar panels and to begin buying heating oil containing biofuels.

title: Bonos Poverty-Fighting Plan Promoted by Two Ex-Senators
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Two former Senate leaders who were once fierce adversaries, Bill Frist and Tom Daschle, joined together Monday to promote a bipartisan effort to make global poverty a central issue of the 2008 presidential race.

title: Iraqi Parliament Votes to Oust Speaker Who Intimidated Members
description: BAGHDAD, June 11  Parliament approved a resolution on Monday that would force the resignation of the speaker, Mahmoud Mashhadani. The vote underscored the widespread discontent with Mr. Mashhadani, a Sunni Arab politician who has done little to build consensus among Iraqs political blocs.

title: Light Fantastic: Flirting With Invisibility
description: Increasingly, physicists are constructing materials that bend light the wrong way, an optical trick that could lead to sharper-than-ever lenses or maybe even make objects disappear.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map with an article on Friday about a decision by Turkey to step up its military presence along its borders misstated the name of the countrys largest lake. It is Lake Van, not Lake Gl.

title: U.S. Forces Kill Afghan Police Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 12  American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and injured five more in an exchange of fire early this morning that Afghan police officials said was a result of mistaken identity.

title: Shelter Closes, Residents Move on and Fortunes Diverge
description: A few weeks ago, the last resident of what was once New York Citys largest homeless shelter, Camp La Guardia, packed his bags and left.

title: Congress Turns to Energy, and Lobbyists Arrive
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Having tried and failed to overhaul the nations immigration laws last week, Congress begins what some say is an even more divisive project this week: taming Americas thirst for oil.

title: Incentives Limit Any Savings in Treating Cancer
description: When Medicare cracked down two years ago on profits that doctors made on drugs they administered to patients in their offices, it ended a windfall worth hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for each physician.

title: Hearst Sues for Access to Names in Inquiry
description: When the United States attorneys office announced that it had reached a plea agreement with Kirk Radomski, a former Mets clubhouse attendant who said he sold performance-enhancing drugs to major league baseball players, the government said it would provide information from its investigation to baseball for its own inquiry into drug use.

title: Manhattan: New Coordinator for Trade Center Health Issues
description: Nearly six years after the attack on the World Trade Center, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has appointed a public relations specialist to coordinate New York Citys response to the mounting health issues of people who were exposed to dust and smoke from the collapsed towers. The new coordinator, Jeffrey Hon, will advise the mayor on 9/11 health issues and oversee the way municipal pension programs respond to requests from employees who were exposed to the toxic dust. Mr. Hon, 53, was a spokesman for the American Red Cross September 11 Recovery Program, which provides financial assistance for mental and physical health care for those most directly affected by the attack. Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg also named a 15-member panel to review findings on the effects of exposure at ground zero and the adequacy of medical services available to those exposed, The Associated Press reported. The panel includes representatives of Mount Sinai Medical Center and the city Fire Department.

title: Thailand Freezes Former Prime Minister's Bank Accounts
description: BANGKOK, June 12  By freezing bank accounts on Monday holding $1.6 billion, the ruling generals of Thailand have hit Thaksin Shinawatra, the tycoon turned politician, where it hurts. But they also emboldened the former prime ministers supporters and stirred sympathy among what were Mr. Thaksins most ardent detractors.

title: Dancing That Pulls Viewers Right Out of Their Seats
description: At the start of Ohad Naharins Decadance, performed by the Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet on Saturday night, a line of dancers stands immobile in front of the audience. Then a body twitches and bursts into a buckling, convulsive dance, arms and legs lashing and flailing to the rhythms of Habib Alla Jamals music. Each of the dancers is compelled into dance until they all join in a fist-shaking crouch, no longer individuals but part of a tribal crowd.

title: Brooklyn: Nanny Sentenced in Toddlers Death
description: A nanny was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 17 years in prison for the death of a 19-month-old boy. The nanny, Tammy Williams, 43, of East New York, pleaded guilty to manslaughter, admitting that in March 2005 she put duct tape over the mouth of the boy, Jaylen Robinson, to stop his crying. The boy suffocated. Prosecutors have said that Ms. Williams's own daughter was a witness to the killing. In court yesterday, an assistant district attorney, Jacqueline Kagan, said the plea agreement "will save the defendant's own child from having to testify against her." A defense lawyer, Peter J. Guadagnino Jr., said that Ms. Williams was in poor mental health and that "I know she's very sorry for what she did.".

title: Lottery Numbers
Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the American militarys new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris. (Go to Article)

title: Great Architecture Finds a Home in Indiana
description: THE sign said Dining Room, and its red Deco neon shone valiantly against the empty blue sky. Below was a whitewashed country diner, with only a few cars and pickups in the parking lot; by this late afternoon hour, everyone in North Vernon, Ind., had long since lunched.

title: There Are No Timeouts or Substitutes in Golf
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 11  Three years ago, at the lush and leafy K Club near Dublin, Ireland, Thomas Bjorn walked off the course in the middle of his round on the European Tour, saying he was fighting demons in his head. The golf course, with its thick trees and winding rivers, had all but suffocated him, Bjorn said. He did not want to take another swing.

title: Top Democrat Plans Advance List of Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  A top House Democrat delivered a promise  and a threat  on Monday about the disclosure of the pet projects known as earmarks.

title: But the Wrong Coat Was So Much Nicer Than Mine
description: My business travel is fairly uneventful. But a flight this year did force me onto a slippery slope of morality.

title: Tradition Is Renewed at Pocono

title: Misdirected Studies on Avandia
description: Eight years and seven million patients later, we still dont know whether the diabetes drug, Avandia, is safe or effective. This is largely because the manufacturer, GlaxoSmithKline, failed to vigorously pursue questions about cardiac safety and the Food and Drug Administration acquiesced in its feeble efforts. Both either ignored or tried to silence scientists who raised the alarm.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the American militarys new strategy of arming some Sunni Arab groups in Iraq gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the river where the body of a kidnapped American soldier was found last month. It was the Euphrates, not the Tigris.

title: U.S. Close to Deal to Release Frozen North Korean Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The United States appears to be close to reaching a deal to transfer $25 million in frozen funds to North Korea, with Russia and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York acting as intermediaries, in hopes of getting North Korea to begin to dismantle its nuclear arms program, American officials said Monday.

title: New Haven: Mayor Seeks Halt to Immigration Raids
description: Mayor John DeStefano Jr. asked the federal government yesterday to back off from any further raids on illegal immigrants until allegations that agents broke rules in conducting one such raid last Wednesday could be addressed. The mayor said yesterday that another raid was imminent. At the same time, three Connecticut lawmakers  Senators Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman and Representative Rosa L. DeLauro  wrote to Michael Chertoff, left, the homeland security secretary, seeking answers to questions about procedures used during the raid. The lawmakers also asked whether the timing of the raid was tied to a decision by city officials to provide identification cards to all residents, including illegal immigrants.

title: Queens: Storekeeper Shot
description: The owner of an Ozone Park bodega was shot last night in what investigators believe was an attempted robbery of his store, the police said. Three men entered the bodega, at 133-45 135th Street, around 9:30 p.m. and shot the owner in the face, the police said. He was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was in critical condition.

title: California: A.C.L.U. Files Suit Over Missing Man
description: A developmentally disabled man who was born and raised in Los Angeles County and is a United States citizen was illegally deported to Mexico last month by immigration agents screening inmates at a jail, according to a federal lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California. The man, Pedro Guzman, 29, of Lancaster, Calif., has now been reported missing in Tijuana, Mexico, family members said. The lawsuit accuses federal authorities of failing to ascertain his citizenship and refusing to help find him in Mexico. Mr. Guzman, who was serving a sentence for misdemeanor trespassing, said in a brief telephone conversation with a family member after he was removed that he told jailers he was born in California, the lawsuit said. Virginia Kice, a spokeswoman for the federal immigration agency, said it had no reason to believe that it improperly removed Mr. Guzman.

title: At Aldeburgh Festival, Surprise Is the Tradition
description: ALDEBURGH, England, June 10  From its inception, in 1948, the Aldeburgh Festival has been a place where old and new music happily, sometimes provocatively, coexist. In his program book essay for the 60th anniversary of the festival, now under way, the critic Paul Griffiths reminds us that the inaugural festival, which lasted a week, offered new works by young composers, Mozart chamber music, songs by Britten and Schubert, a new small-scale opera, a recital by a great pianist and a dash of Purcell  things that were to be replicated in virtually every festival since.

title: A Ruling for Justice

title: Croatian Serb Convicted of Atrocities
description: PARIS, June 12  The U.N. war crimes court hearing cases from the former Yugoslavia today found a former henchman of president Slobodan Milosevic guilty of multiple crimes while heading a Serbian separatist rebellion and sentenced him to 35 years in prison.
