title: Sleek, Fast and Focused: The Cells That Make Dad Dad
description: We are fast approaching Fathers Day, the festive occasion on which we plague Dad with yet another necktie or collect phone call and just generally strive to remind the big guy of the central verity of paternity  that its a lot more fun to become a father than to be one. I wont lie to you, said the great Homer Simpson. Fatherhood isnt easy like motherhood. Yet in our insistence that men are more than elaborately engineered gamete vectors, we neglect the marvels of their elaborately engineered gametes. As the scientists who study male germ cells will readily attest, sperm are some of the most extraordinary cells of the body, a triumph of efficient packaging, sleek design and superspecialization. Human sperm are extremely compact, and theyve been stripped of a normal cells protein-making machinery; but when cast into the forbidding environment of the female reproductive tract, they will learn on the job and change their search strategies and swim strokes as needed.

title: The Inevitability of Bumps
description: People who fly a lot tend to be nonchalant about the experience  until the plane hits a patch of choppy air. Then, as cups start skidding across tray tables and luggage jostles overhead, even some frequent fliers admit to gripping the armrest with fear.

title: Parents and Health Experts Try to Ease Italys Pollution
description: MILAN  This part of northern Italy is renowned for fashion, food, Fiat. But now it has another, less welcome claim to fame: the cities here have the worst air pollution in Europe.

title: Spain: Parties Find Common Ground on ETA
description: Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, and Mariano Rajoy, the leader of the Popular Party, the conservative opposition, fiercely divided over Mr. Zapateros earlier efforts to broker a peace deal with the violent Basque separatist group ETA, held their first meeting since the group called off a cease-fire last week. Officials from both sides offered an upbeat assessment of the meeting as a step toward healing the leaders bitter rift and forging a united front against ETA.

title: Canada: Onex Joins Group Bidding for Bell
description: The Onex Corporation, Canadas largest investment firm, has joined the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board in its bid for Bell Canada, the countrys largest telephone company. Onex will bring additional capital to the bid and help ensure that the pension funds bid meets Canadian ownership requirements for telecommunications companies. Others in the bidding group include Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Caisse de Dpt et Placement du Qubec, that provinces biggest pension fund. Bell, which changed its name from BCE last week, has formally recognized two other bidding groups, one led by the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Bells largest stockholder with 6.3 percent of its shares, and the other led by Cerberus Capital Management working with unnamed Canadian investors.

title: Milestone Marks What Phillies Fans Already Knew
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11  During the 1920s and 30s, when the Phillies inhabited a park called the Baker Bowl, the fence in right field was adorned by a giant advertisement for soap that read: The Phillies Use Lifebuoy.

title: Venezuela Dances to Devilish Beat to Promote Tourism
description: SAN FRANCISCO DE YARE, Venezuela, June 7  Wearing blood-colored costumes and devilish papier-mch masks that would make a gargoyle grimace, hundreds of worshipers disguised as demons danced through the streets here Thursday in one of Venezuelas most exalted religious rituals.

It is Kearny Avenue in Kearny, not Kearney. title: Correction: For the Record

The salesman, Louis Giuffre, 46, of Lake Grove in Suffolk County, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court on Monday to interstate transportation of stolen property, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Giuffre admitted that while working for the consulting company, Netsoft, last summer, he sent confidential information to a rival company by e-mail, Mr. Garcia said. Prosecutors said the competitor ultimately won a contract that Netsoft had been trying to secure. Mr. Giuffre faces up to 10 years in prison when he is sentenced in September, prosecutors said.

title: Newark: Volunteer Group Official Is Sentenced
description: A former executive vice president of the nonprofit group 100 Black Men of New Jersey was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 21 months in prison for fraudulently obtaining $156,000 from the organization, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Keith DaCosta, 44, of Newark, admitted using bank accounts affiliated with the organization for personal use, including hotel stays, meals and a $374 hat, and entering into leases for office equipment with his personal home health care company, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney.

title: Recipe: Lamb and Bulgur Kibbe With Garlic Yogurt Sauce
description: Time: 40 minutes

title: A Different Sudan
description: To many of us, Sudan means one thing  the ongoing disaster called Darfur. But scientists flying over Southern Sudan  the site of a separate civil war that finally ended in 2005  have discovered vast numbers of migrating animals: herds of antelope and gazelle that may rival the scale of the great migration in Serengeti.

title: Federal Grant for a Medical Mission Goes Awry
description: In theory, it was simple: Congress gave two decommissioned Coast Guard cutters to a faith-based group in California, directing that the ships be used only to provide medical services to islands in the Central and South Pacific.

title: Aprs Vous, Oscar Wilde (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemens Joins Teammates; Johnson Stays in Desert
description: Roger Clemens is not a scheduled starter against the Arizona Diamondbacks this week, yet he was at Yankee Stadium yesterday, roaming the clubhouse and the field like any other teammate. The Yankees have told Clemens he can come and go as he pleases on the days he does not start, but Clemens is here now.

title: Senators Seek to Penalize China for Trade Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  A group of leading Republican and Democratic senators, signaling growing Congressional impatience with Chinese trade practices, proposed legislation today aimed at forcing penalties on China over its policy of suppressing the value of its currency to promote exports.

title: Scrutiny on Tax Rates That Fund Managers Pay
description: The backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength.

title: Seeking a Bank Robber With a Taste for Hats
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J., June 12  You have to tip your hat, literally, to the man who has robbed 17 banks in northern New Jersey since last fall.

title: 7 Afghans Die in Erroneous Exchange of Fire
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 12  American-led forces killed seven Afghan policemen and wounded five more in an exchange of fire early Tuesday that Afghan police officials said was a result of mistaken identity.

title: Orthopedic Surgery (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan misstated the difference in length between this years parade and the one in 1958, which one paradegoer, Tony Flores, took part in as a Boy Scout from Brooklyn. The 1958 parade was eight blocks shorter, not at least a dozen.

title: Vietnamese President to Visit Washington Next Week
description: HANOI, June 13  President Nguyen Minh Triet of Vietnam is bracing himself for criticism over his countrys human rights record when he travels to Washington next week, the first Vietnamese head of state to do so since the Vietnam War ended 32 years ago.

title: Day Care Worker Is Convicted of Raping a 4-Year-Old Boy
description: A Queens jury, forced to render a stark judgment on a videotaped confession, yesterday found a day care worker guilty of raping and sexually abusing a 4-year-old boy in her care.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the shooting death of Rudolph Izzi, a loan shark and reputed mobster, included an erroneous reference in some copies to his place of residence. As noted elsewhere in the article, he lived in Brooklyn, not Staten Island.

title: Left Wrist, Meet Right Wrist
description: He tweaked his wrist last month by muscling practice balls out of a rough as thick and tangled as pompoms on the United States Open course at Oakmont Country Club.

title: Judge Tries Suing Pants Off Dry Cleaners
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  Roy L. Pearson Jr. wanted to dress sharply for his new job as an administrative law judge here. So when his neighborhood dry cleaner misplaced a pair of expensive pants he had planned to wear his first week on the bench, Judge Pearson was annoyed.

title: Hart Was Doyenne of the Arts and Showbiz
description: Frank Sinatras You Make Me Feel So Young might seem a peculiar choice to open a memorial celebration. But if the person being remembered is Kitty Carlisle Hart, the entertainer and culture grande dame who died in April but was singing the standards in cabaret bars and on stages well into her 90s, it makes plenty of sense.

title: Letters
description: Converted by Meatballs

title: Kibbe Raw (Good) and Cooked (Better)
description: MOST of the time, my husband, Daniel, is an eager accomplice when it comes to my more outr culinary cravings. He has gamely sampled braised chicken feet in Chinatown, crispy tripe tacos in Hells Kitchen and even the deep-fried Gummi octopuses I made one afternoon in an oil-ridden frenzy. But when it came to raw lamb kibbe for dinner, he put the kibosh on my plan.

title: Bush Lobbies G.O.P. Senators on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  In an effort to revive a crippled immigration bill, President Bush visited the Capitol on Tuesday to try to assure wary Senate Republicans personally that border security was a driving force behind his push for changes in immigration law.

title: Indonesia Says Militant Is in Custody
description: Indonesian police confirmed today that Abu Dujana, a major southeast Asia terrorist leader, had been arrested and is in custody in Central Java.

title: Shiite Leaders Appeal for Calm After New Shrine Attack
description: BAGHDAD, June 13  One of Iraqs most sacred Shiite shrines, the Imam al-Askari mosque in Samarra, was attacked and severely damaged again today, just over a year after a previous attack on the site unleashed a tide of sectarian bloodletting across the country.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the high number of arrests at this years Puerto Rican Day Parade in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the estimated number of arrests at last years parade. The figure of 50 to 60 arrests last year was taken from an article that ran in The Times in 2006; the estimate did not come from the New York police in the course of reporting yesterdays article. (The 2006 article cited at least 50 arrests, but the Police Department disputes that figure, saying 151 people were arrested.) An article about the reaction to this years arrests appears today.

title: Hamas Forces Seize Control Over Much of Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, June 13  Hamas forces consolidated control over much of Gaza on Wednesday, taking command of the main north-south road and blowing up a Fatah headquarters in Khan Yunis, in the south.

title: For the Mets Captain, the Sea Is Always Calm
description: LOS ANGELES, June 12  It was April 2005, and the sheen of Willie Randolphs first season as the Mets manager was still fresh. The losses piled up  one, two, three, four, five in a row  placing him in danger of returning to Shea Stadium for the home opener without a victory. Pressure? For someone who won two World Series rings by age 24, played for Billy Martin and Lou Piniella and was hired after 12 failed managerial interviews, this, he said, was nothing.

title: Google to Reduce History of Personal Searches
description: PARIS, June 12  Faced with criticism from privacy activists and questions from the European Union, Google announced on Tuesday that it would cut back on how long it keeps the Web search histories of users, to 18 months from 24.

title: Dissident Shareholders Send Message to Yahoo
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 12  Yahoo said on Tuesday that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms who complained about what they described as excessive executive pay.

title: Lehman Profit Climbs 27%
description: Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, reported today that its profit in the second quarter had increased 27 percent, a record for the firm and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports.

title: Searching for the Secret to Attracting the Youth Vote
description: Maybe it started with Howard Dean, or maybe it was Al Gore, or maybe it was as long ago as when Bill Clinton talked about his underwear on MTV, but campaigns are putting a lot of energy into courting the youth vote. Links to the online hangouts of the under-25 set, YouTube, MySpace and Facebook among them, are all over the candidates home pages, especially those of the Democratic candidates. Some campaigns have hired youth vote coordinators to mobilize young voters.

title: Trying to Give Police the Right Answer, Even When Its Wrong
description: Ask him a question. Ozem Goldwire holds onto it across a half-dozen conversational detours, and keeps working on it until he is sure you have gotten precisely what you were looking for.

title: Queens: Doctor Charged With Insurance Fraud
description: A doctor who works at a clinic in Jamaica has been charged with insurance fraud, accused of billing insurance companies for tests that were never performed on victims of motor vehicle accidents, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Alexander Israeli, 53, of Middle Village, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Monday night on charges of grand larceny and insurance fraud, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Dr. Israeli billed insurance companies last year for $21,000 worth of neurological tests that were not performed. He faces loss of his medical license and up to seven years in prison if convicted, prosecutors said.

title: Mickelson Plays in Pain Because Its the Open
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 12  With a black wrap covering his injured left wrist, Phil Mickelson played nine holes at Oakmont Country Club on Tuesday with diminished expectations.

title: Dispute Over Arrest Pattern at the Puerto Rican Parade
description: Details of the complaints by police against the people arrested at the Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday outline a pattern in the way they were arrested, according to documents released yesterday.

title: College Leaders Push for Carbon Neutrality
description: Cape Cod Community College is erecting a wind turbine and will soon install solar panels. The dining halls at Furman University in Greenville, S.C., are offering more fresh produce from local farms. Arizona State University is distributing free bus passes to every student, employee and faculty member.

title: China Inflation Hits 3.4 Percent in May
description: Inflation in China reached a 27-month high of 3.4 percent in May, government statisticians announced today, but the price increases were heavily concentrated in food while separate figures for growth in the money supply and loans suggested that the broader economy was not yet overheating.

title: South Africa Strike Foreshadows Political Contest
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 12  A nationwide strike by South Africas public-service unions lumbered into its 12th day on Tuesday, shuttering schools, crippling hospitals and hamstringing courts  but not moving President Thabo Mbekis government far toward a settlement.

title: Europe Plans a Quieter and Cleaner Passenger Jet
description: BRUSSELS, June 12  Driven by concerns that it is falling behind on airplane development, the European Union is planning a 1.6 billion-euro public-private partnership to help its aviation industry develop a generation of greener and quieter aircraft.

title: Amid Alleluias, Festival Hall Resurrected
description: LONDON, June 12  All four of the resident orchestras at the Royal Festival Hall  the London Philharmonic, the Philharmonia Orchestra, the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment  took part in the grand and substantive gala concert on Monday night to reinaugurate the hall after a major two-year, $234 million renovation. The refurbishment was both keenly and nervously anticipated. When the Festival Hall opened in 1951 on the south bank of the Thames, this formidable concrete building, rising almost literally from the ashes of World War II, was embraced as a symbol of British fortitude and renewal.

title: After Finally Admitting Killing, Man Finally Goes Free
description: Carmine Carini had a decision to make. He was 47 years old. Nearly half that time he had spent in prison for the murder of a Brooklyn record shop owner, a man shot three times to the head and dumped from a car in the watermark style of a Mafia execution.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A listing of results on Monday from the Prefontaine Classic track-and-field meet in Eugene, Ore., reversed the top two finishers in the mens high jump. Tora Harris was first and Jesse Williams second.

title: The Combatant and the Evidence (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place to Go if You Like It Hot
description: MA la, the uppercut combo of chili heat and the peculiar numbing effect of the Sichuan peppercorn, is the flavor profile most associated with Sichuan eating.

title: Defense Rests in Black Trial
description: CHICAGO, June 12 (Bloomberg News)  Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, and three other former company executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges Tuesday without taking the stand. Closing arguments are set for Monday.

title: New Presidential Debate Site? Clearly, YouTube
description: The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A map on Monday with an article about fears that tourism in the Niagara Falls area will suffer when tighter border restrictions take effect mislabeled an island in the Niagara River between New York and Ontario. It is Goat Island, not Duck Island.

title: Before Fourth Season, a Chat With Fifth and Sixth Graders
description: TRENTON, June 12  Eli Manning sat in the principals office Tuesday, waiting to address a group of fifth and sixth graders.

title: A Home Big Enough to House the Cousins
description: The setting of Tyler Perrys House of Payne, a new comedy on TBS, is a tidy ranch with black shutters and neat landscaping. The proprietor, Curtis Payne, known as Pops, is an aging firefighter who has done well enough to own a place to maintain his extended family.

title: Giant Bird-Like Dinosaur Fossil Found in China
description: Scientists have uncovered a huge surprise in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China: the fossil skeleton of an unusually robust bird-like dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago. The animal appeared to be a young adult 25 feet long and weighing 3,000 pounds and, if it had lived longer, would probably have grown even larger.

title: In Mamaroneck, Taking a More Hospitable Approach to Day Laborers
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 12  The placard, about the size of a record cover, was perched on the sidewalk outside a church on Old White Plains Road, so discreet it could have easily escaped the notice of drivers passing by. Steel-blue type on a white background offered a modest invitation to contractors used to trolling the streets here in search of help: Hire Workers!

title: Symptoms Found for Early Check on Ovary Cancer
description: Cancer experts have identified a set of health problems that may be symptoms of ovarian cancer, and they are urging women who have the symptoms for more than a few weeks to see their doctors.

title: Bill Is Delayed by Republicans Over Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  No longer in charge of writing spending bills since they lost their majority, House Republicans are unleashing a previously unseen indignation at the pet projects that individual lawmakers attach to such bills.

title: Earnhardt Will Announce His Decision and May Join Nemesis
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, will announce this morning what team he will race for beginning in 2008 amid indications that he will sign with the powerhouse Hendrick Motorsports.

title: Earnhardt Joins Nascar Powerhouse Hendrick
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., June 13 - Dale Earnhardt Jr. flashed a broad smile as he stood next to car owner Rick Hendrick, the cameras clicking as they captured the moment that will change Nascar forever.

title: Recipe: Confit Byaldi
description: FOR PIPERADE

title: Senate Democrats Propose Loans for Coal-Based Fuel Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  As the Senate began debate Tuesday on a sprawling bill to reduce oil consumption, top Democrats were circulating a proposal to provide $10 billion in loans for plants that make diesel fuel from coal.

title: Subpoena Vote Is Set in Wiretap Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote Thursday on whether to authorize subpoenas to gain access to Justice Department documents related to the National Security Agencys domestic wiretapping program, including a series of secret legal opinions.

title: 2 Ex-Bush Aides Subpoenaed in Attorneys Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Two former White House officials were subpoenaed today as Congressional Democrats intensified pressure on the Bush administration over the dismissals of eight United States attorneys.

title: Cut the Nuclear Arsenal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Las Vegas Caters to Asias High Rollers
description: LAS VEGAS  Without the dreamy postcard views of the neon-pulsing Strip, visitors to the V.I.P. lounge at the top of the Venetian hotel and casino here might think they had taken an elevator to someplace in Hong Kong or Shanghai.

title: Ireland: Greens Close to Coalition Deal With Ahern
description: The Green Party has moved closer to a coalition accord with Fianna Fail, the party of Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, left, after the parties reached agreement on climate change, education and political reform, the Green Party negotiator, Dan Boyle, said in comments on RTE radio in Dublin. Negotiations between the parties resumed yesterday after talks collapsed on June 8. Mr. Ahern, in power since 1997, turned to the Greens after his party failed to win enough seats in the May 24 election to allow it to govern alone. Irelands new Parliament will meet tomorrow, with lawmakers selecting a speaker and prime minister.

title: Lehman Brothers Profit Climbs 27%
description: Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, reported yesterday that its profit in the second quarter rose 27 percent, a record for the firm and potentially auguring a good week for Wall Street earning reports.

title: Giuliani Sets Forth a Dozen Priorities for His Presidency
description: BEDFORD, N.H., June 12  Rudolph W. Giuliani on Tuesday outlined what he said would be the 12 major priorities of his presidency, among them fighting terrorism, cutting taxes, achieving energy independence and, in a new theme for him, overhauling the education system.

title: Cricket Coachs Death Not a Murder, Police Say
description: MEXICO CITY, June 12  Bob Woolmer, the coach of the Pakistani cricket team who was found unconscious in his hotel room in March after his team was ousted from the Cricket World Cup, was not murdered as the police had previously thought but died of unspecified natural causes, the Jamaican police said Tuesday.

title: Sudan Relents on Peacekeepers in Darfur
description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 12  After resisting for months, Sudan has agreed to a joint United Nations and African Union force of nearly 20,000 peacekeepers in Darfur, its western province and the site of one of the worlds worst humanitarian crises, the African Union said Tuesday.

title: Stirring Composers, Musicians and Theater Artists Into a Stew
description: Informal salon concerts are largely a thing of the distant past. But Jed Distler and Clia Cooke, the directors of ComposersCollaborative inc, offer an attractive update of that old model with Serial Underground, the monthly series they organize at the Cornelia Street Caf in the West Village. There, composers, musicians and theater artists mix and mingle, presenting recent pieces and works in progress in an unbuttoned setting.

title: Cornell Medical School to Get $400 Million for Research Centers
description: A group of philanthropists led by Joan and Sanford I. Weill plans to announce today that it has pledged $400 million to build research centers and to recruit senior scientists for Weill Medical College of Cornell University.

title: Glitch Blamed for Fire Alarm on Orbiter
description: Astronauts and mission managers scrambled yesterday when a fire alarm went off on the Russian part of the International Space Station. Within 20 minutes, however, the problem was determined to be a software glitch.

title: Attracting Vacation Home Renters
description: Several years ago, after arriving at her vacation rental on Oneida Lake in upstate New York, Christine Karpinski noticed that the house lacked an essential amenity: a barbecue. I called the owner and he agreed to bring me one, Ms. Karpinski said. How can you rent out a place without a grill? Ms. Karpinski maintains the Web site How to Rent by Owner.

title: Audience Participation Welcome (but Shhh)
description: There are plenty of singers who inspire their fans to sing along. And then there is Feist, the indie-rock chanteuse from Canada. She is a restless polymath with a catalog of great songs and a voice like carved steam. At Town Hall on Monday, during the first of two sold-out shows, she encouraged audience participation, but no one seemed eager to drown her out. When Feist opens her mouth, there is only one reasonable reaction: shut up.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about group shows at New York galleries referred incorrectly to a show at CRG in Chelsea that includes the work of Colby Bird, who has a sculpture in one of the group shows reviewed, In Defense of Ardor, at Bellwether in Chelsea. The show at CRG is a two-man show of work by Mr. Bird and Joshua Fields, not a solo show by Mr. Bird.

title: Answers Sought in Guard Smuggling Case
description: HOUSTON, June 12  A soldier awarded a Purple Heart for service in Iraq and two other Texas National Guardsmen charged with human smuggling remained in jail in Laredo on Tuesday as federal authorities expanded their investigation into how 24 illegal immigrants wound up in a Guard-leased van deep into Texas.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on June 4 about Abdul Kadir and Russell M. Defreitas, two of the four men accused of plotting to blow up Kennedy International Airport, referred imprecisely to Mr. Kadirs role in the Linden Fund, a charity in Guyana, his home country. As a board member and former mayor of Linden, Guyanas second-largest city, he used his contacts to help speed up the distribution of money and supplies sent to Guyana by donors in the United States, but he was not in charge of receiving and disbursing money and supplies.

title: Between Dust and Deliverance
description: Ramallah, West Bank

title: China: Cities Suffer More Pollution
description: Air and water quality in Chinese cities is worsening, according to a report of the Environmental Protection Administration. According to the agencys latest survey, just 38 percent of 585 cities monitored enjoyed air quality that reached minimal national standards, down from 45 percent in a 2005 survey.

title: Guess Whos Back?
description: Every year, it seems, Mariano Rivera struggles for a bit and the fans and the news media wonder if hes finally lost it. Its a legitimate story, because some day, Rivera wont be Rivera anymore. But that day is not upon us.

title: Fat, Glorious Fat, Moves to the Center of the Plate
description: Frank Bruni says that these are times of bold temptation, as well as prompt surrender, for a carnivorous glutton in New York.

title: Its Not All Geek to Me
description: Arrrgh, bad news: evidently, the ratings for Its All Geek to Me (my funny tech show) were low. So Discovery execs have decided NOT to broadcast the final 2 episodes on the Science Channel. Instead, they intend to put those two episodes, complete, here on the Web. (Thats what they SAY. Theyre still not posted.)

title: The Markings on the Wall
description: Additional images from the exhibit "Projects 85: Dan Perjovschi" at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: 36 Hours in Milan
description: Shopping, strolling and eating on a weekend tour of this Italian city.

title: Hitting the Road
Mega Dittos
description: I am a Chicago high school teacher who (unfortunately) rarely travels or writes, on a journey to Africa with an award-winning international correspondent who reports with inspired, accessible, concise language and offers a breadth of knowledge from years of working and living in foreign lands. With so many experienced writers and entertainers sharing stories and reports from Africa, why in the world would you ever want to read my blog? I hope my daily photographs and stories will reach and relate to other uninformed young people who seek a fresh, unlearned and detailed perspective into the daily life and youth culture of sub-Sahara Africa.

title: Visions of Basel
description: Additional images from the international art fair in Switzerland.

title: Expanding the Text
description: A look at productions by the Target Margin Theater company.

title: On the Waterfront
description: Additional images from the Brooklyn waterfront, which the National Trust for Historic Preservation has declared an endangered site.

title: Currents
description: Landlocked goldfish worth their weight in 24-karat and more.

title: Is Green Just About Profits?
description: One of the things that is really bothering me these days is that going green is so often presented as an opportunity for making money. Yesterday we hear the potentially good news that the E.U. is planning a 1.6 billion Euro public project called Clean Sky to develop greener aircraft.

title: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Gloves
description: Katherine Whiteside, the author of The Way We Garden Now, tests gloves while building a raised-bed potager.

title: War Returns to Sri Lanka
description: After a cease-fire that quelled violence for nearly four years, war is again scarring Sri Lankan life.

title: United States Climbs in FIFA Rankings
description: The United States men's soccer team, fresh off three straight first-round shutout victories in the Concacaf Gold Cup, is riding an eight-game unbeaten streak under the team's new coach, Bob Bradley.

title: A Caregiver Not in a Giving Mood
description: Read that a play is about a woman who finds romance while caring for her disabled father, and your treacle meter is likely to start flashing an urgent warning: well-intentioned feel-good mush ahead. That plot description fits The Rules of Charity, but this dark, scalding play by John Belluso is not remotely what youre expecting.

title: Life Lessons, Behind the Wheel
description: The are we there yet? of a family trip is magnified  or condensed  into two acts in Anastasia Trainas play From Riverdale to Riverhead. The title is purely descriptive; it denotes the journey of three achingly stereotyped sisters and their niece to visit the son of one of the sisters, Louise, in jail. Virtually the entire action of the piece, which opened last weekend at Studio Dante, consists of four women riding, talking, bickering and crying in a car.

title: For This Group, the Partys Over
description: Rabbit, a new play by the young British writer Nina Raine, feels a bit like an episode of Friends set in an abbey. It is chatty and high-strung. It is stark and funereal. It is Bella, the central figure, a woman in glittery high heels and an unadorned black dress who embodies a tension that Ms. Raine tries to grab but can never quite clutch  the tension between the enticement of sex and the denial of its most profound implications.

title: Notes on the Losers Lounge
description: The Mint Theater makes other companies look ridiculous by lovingly producing forgotten plays that are much better than many that are repeatedly revived.

title: Blackstone Plans a June I.P.O.
description: The Blackstone Group wants investors to save the date: The buyout shops much-awaited initial public offering is set for the week of June 25, underwriters said.

title: V.C.s High on Botanical Drug Companies
description: Phytomedics, a developer of an arthritis drug based on extracts from the Chinese Thunder God Vine, has nabbed $9 million in Series B funding, an event that the Red Herring suggests could signal new market opportunities for plant-based medicines and a tempering of Big Pharmas suspicion of herbal remedies.

title: Greenberg Files Rebuttal in Lawsuit
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, tried to turn the tables on his accusers on Tuesday. In a court filing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Greenberg said testimony from three A.I.G. employees would discredit recent accusations by the State of New York.

title: Bank to End Deals With Officers Kin
description: Apparently, there has been a little too much family spirit at Commerce Bancorp. The bank, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said it would end contracts with companies owned by executives and their relatives by the end of the year, halting a practice that has drawn the attention of regulators.

title: Defense Rests in Black Trial
description: Conrad M. Black, the former chairman of Hollinger International, and three other former company executives rested their defense on federal fraud charges Tuesday without taking the stand. Closing arguments are set for Monday.

title: Ex-Citi Executives Buyout Shop Makes Investment
description: Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm set up by two former Citigroup executives, has made its first investment, taking a $230 million stake in a Mexican financial services group. Brysam, which was started earlier this year by Robert Willumstad, former president and chief operating officer of Citi, and Marge Magner, former chairman and chief executive of Citis global consumer group, will take a 28 percent stake in Ixe Grupo Financiero.

title: New Century Dismisses 2 Top Executives
description: New Century Financial, the bankrupt housing lender, disclosed on Tuesday that it had fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.

title: Former Executive of CA Will Pay Restitution
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn approved an agreement Tuesday in which the former sales chief of CA, Stephen Richards, who pleaded guilty in an accounting fraud case at the company, will pay more than $29 million in restitution.

title: Morgan Stanley Settles Metals Lawsuit
description: Morgan Stanley will pay $4.4 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with brokerage clients who bought precious metals and paid storage fees, according to a court filing.

title: Openads Gets First Venture Funding
description: Openads, a supplier of open-source online advertising software, has received $5 million in initial venture funding from a group led by Index Ventures. Openads ad-server technology competes with DoubleClick, which Google recently acquired, but at a different end of the market, Reuters reported.

title: Suitor Revises Bid for Chicago Board
description: IntercontinentalExchange resubmitted a proposal Tuesday to acquire Chicago Board of Trade Holdings, with enhancements that included allowing the Chicago boards shareholders to receive cash instead of stock.

title: A Chinese Company Fights Its French Partner
description: A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French multinational company, and a brash Chinese executive has escalated into a battle for control of the countrys largest beverage maker, in what some observers are calling a cautionary tale.

title: Ford Confirms Review of Luxury Brands
description: Ford Motor confirmed Tuesday that it was working with financial advisers to sort out the future of Jaguar and Land Rover, which have been rumored to be up for sale for more than a year.

title: HSBC Executive to Take Top Post at ANZ
description: The head of HSBCs Asian business, Michael Smith, unexpectedly resigned to become chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, signaling that ANZ will continue an aggressive expansion into Asia. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade.

title: Four Banks Ordered to Stand Trial in Parmalat Case
description: A Milan judge has ordered four banks, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank, UBS and Citigroup, to stand trial in connection with the 2003 bankruptcy of the Italian dairy company Parmalat, the banks said. Judge Cesare Tacconi set the date for Jan. 22, the four firms confirmed Wednesday.

title: Frugal Traveler: Columbus, Ind.
description: In Columbus, Ind., the Frugal Traveler saves money on lodging by staying with a family he found through CouchSurfing.com.

title: Santander Considers Real Estate Sale to Fund Bank
description: Santander Central Hispano, Spains biggest bank, may raise 4 billion euros ($5.3 billion) selling real estate assets including the banks headquarters to provide funds for its banking business. The lender hopes to make a 1.4 billion euro gain by selling or signing lease-backs for 44 buildings in Spain, including its new headquarters at Boadilla del Monte outside Madrid, a spokeswoman for the bank told Bloomberg News on Wednesday.

title: An Increasingly Visible D.E. Shaw Hires Its First P.R. Executive
description: As D.E. Shaw continues to ramp up its public persona  increasingly taking an active role in pressuring companies to shape-up  it seems the firm felt it needed someone to take care of its burgeoning new image.

title: Hong Kong Cozies Up to Hedge Funds
description: Hong Kongs Securities and Futures Commission is planning to simplify licensing requirements to make it easy for hedge fund managers to set up shop there, HedgeFund.Net reported. The commission will speed up the licensing process and exempt some staff members of hedge fund firms from having to take exams. Firms that are already licensed or registered in the United States or United Kingdom will benefit from an expedited licensing process, the agency said.

title: Dissident Shareholders Send a Message to Yahoo
description: Yahoo said on Tuesday that about a third of its shareholders had voted against the re-election of one or more company directors. The vote against some directors had been recommended by three Wall Street advisory firms who complained about what they described as excessive executive pay.

title: Ackmans Pershing Opposes Ceridian Sale
description: Ceridians largest shareholder, Pershing Square Capital Management, has opposed the companys sale to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial, saying the offer is too low.

title: ComScore Eyes $80 Million I.P.O.
description: ComScore, an Internet market-research company, plans to raise as much as $80 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing.

title: As Murdoch Looms, a Shake-Up in Newsroom of Journal
description: The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, will announce on Wednesday a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, The New York Times reported.

title: Barclays May Sweeten Cash Portion of ABN Offer
description: Barclays has drawn up contingency plans to restructure its all-share offer for ABN Amro, the Dutch bank, with a significant cash sweetener in case it is forced into a full-blown takeover battle, The Financial Times reported.

title: May Is Banner Month for Venture-Backed I.P.O.s
description: Venture-backed initial public offerings had their best month in years last month as 11 companies raised $1.6 billion from I.P.O.s on American exchanges. That figure represents the most money raised since August 2004 when the debut of Google raised that figure to nearly $1.9 billion, according to statistics released Tuesday by Thomson Financial and the National Venture Capital Association.

title: Banks Try to Distance Themselves from Covenant-Lite Frenzy
description: The debate over whether the less-restrictive loans that banks have been handing out at an unprecedented rate to private equity groups will end in more bankruptcies is far from settled, as DealBook noted on Tuesday.

title: In the Hamptons, a Hedge Row Goes Public
description: With a single e-mail, a hedge fund chief, James Chanos, delivered all the ingredients of a Wall Street gossip item tailor-made for a slow week in mid-June.

title: Jones Apparel in Talks to Sell Barneys to Dubai Fund, Report Says
description: The Jones Apparel Group is nearing a deal to sell its Barneys New York luxury department store chain to a private-equity firm owned by the Dubai government, The New York Post reported, in a deal that may worth about $950 million.

title: Rubin Urges Scrutiny of Private-Equity Tax Treatment
description: The backlash against the tremendous wealth being created by managers of hedge funds and private equity funds may be gaining strength, The New York Times noted. On Tuesday, a former treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, made a case for doubling the tax rate paid by private equity and hedge fund managers.

title: G.O.P. Rivals Gear Up for Thompson
description: While former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson stopped short of officially announcing his candidacy for president on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno last night, he made his intentions clear enough. Though he told the late night audience that he has never craved the presidency, he expressed an interest in the job. Mr. Thompsons supporters will more than likely have to wait until next month for an actual announcement.

title: Group Is Said to Offer Bid for Macquarie Stake in Rome Airports
description: A group of investors based in Italy made an informal offer on Tuesday to buy out Macquaries 45 percent stake in Romes airports for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), The Financial Times reported. The Australian financial firm is considering whether to take the offer or to counter by buying the Italian groups 51 percent stake, the paper said.

title: Mourning Mr. Wizard
description: One of the bigger YouTube sensations so far can be credited to an ingenious combination of a two-liter bottle of Diet Coke and and a few Mentos. But the inspiration behind it stretches all the way back to the 1950s and Don Herbert, who died on Tuesday at 89.

title: Sites on the 2007 list of most-endangered historic places designated by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
description: 1. Brooklyn's Industrial Waterfront. Once a booming 19th-century industrial waterfront supported by generations of immigrants, Brooklyn's heritage is at risk as historic dockyards and factories are being demolished by developers anxious to cash in on the area's newly hip status, the trust says.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by George Saunders
description: On Wednesdays, this blog will be the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the celebrity playlists on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

description: Chinua Achebe has won the Man Booker International Prize [NYT / Guardian], reportedly beating out writers like Salman Rushdie, Philip Roth, Alice Munro, Carlos Fuentes and Michael Ondaatje.

title: Piggy Memories
description: In todays Dining section, I write about the proliferation of restaurants and dishes that promote eating with fatty, meaty abandon. This kind of eating often involves pork, and it often involves offal. The restaurants and dishes in question put a diner in touch with his or her most carnivorous, gluttonous, barbaric self, and they leave a diner with fingers slicked with grease and a belly filled, quite possibly, with belly (pork, lamb).

title: United States Gets Its Groove Back
description: The United States cemented its position Tuesday at the top of Group B with a convincing 4-0 drubbing of El Salvador in the Gold Cup at Gillette Stadium in Foxboro, Mass.

title: Goldman Gets a Spot on Blackstones I.P.O. Team
description: Amid all the fuss over Stephen Schwarzmans $400 million paycheck, another interesting nugget in Blackstone Groups latest I.P.O. prospectus went largely overlooked: Goldman Sachs, which had previously been left out of the club of investment banks underwriting Blackstones $4.7 billion public offering, has been added to the list.

title: Talking Shop With Ciscos Dealmaker
description: Cisco isnt afraid to make surprising deals  even big ones. In March, it announced a $3.2 billion acquisition of WebEx, causing several pundits to wonder why the company, which makes networking gear, would buy a videoconferencing firm. That deal came just after the much smaller acquisition of Tribe.net, a social-networking Web site that had long been eclipsed by MySpace, Facebook, and others.

title: Boutique Hotels Berlin  Q!
description: Berlin, so hip in so many ways, hasnt been on the leading-edge of the trend in designer hotels. Thats either good or bad, depending on whether you find these minimalist places exciting or an excuse to charge five-star prices for closet-size rooms. But now there are a growing number of hotels that are safeguarding Berlins reputation as one of Europes coolest cities.

description: Herbert Muschamp, a former architecture critic for The New York Times, mused last December that the Trevi Fountain had been running for so long that it wouldnt mind being stopped, for its life must be getting tiresome:

description: It may be too early to begin a death watch, but theres more bad news ahead for Detroits once-invincible auto show. Porsche will not have a display at the North American International Auto Show next January. Dont worry, Detroit, youll always have winter.

description: Most readers have asked if the design of the house will be out of place on Anna Maria. For us, the answer is no.

description: Above, President Bushs watch, on his wrist, today. On YouTube, an NBC video showing him pocketing it himself in Albania. After speculation  in varying degrees of caution  stretched across the Web and into The Lede on Tuesday, he deserves the last word on this. Buying, instead, from local farmers looks increasingly appealing: We get fresher produce (and benediction from Alice Waters), while also preserving open space and protecting local jobs.

title: Efforts to Avert Sectarian Reprisals After Shrine Attack
description: BAGHDAD, June 13  Two explosions on Wednesday that appeared to have been set by Sunni extremists with links to Al Qaeda toppled the twin golden minarets that were most of what remained of one of Iraqs most revered Shiite shrines after a devastating bombing by Al Qaeda last year.

title: Security Is Focus of Revised Effort on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The White House and senators from both parties mapped out possible changes in a comprehensive immigration bill on Wednesday, so they could better portray it as a way to bolster national security rather than to grant amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants.

title: Networks Ink Ads Deal for Fall Television Season
description: The upfront market for the 2007-8 television season is getting under way with a large, significant deal between the NBC Universal division of the General Electric Company and the media agencies owned by the WPP Group.

title: Commuters Still Driving Alone
description: Despite high gasoline prices, the share of commuters driving alone has increased slightly since 2000 while the proportion in car pools dropped and those using mass transit remained about the same, according to a Census Bureau analysis released yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Former Chairman of G.O.P. Will Join Bushs Inner Circle
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Ed Gillespie, a prominent Washington lobbyist, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and longtime adviser to President Bush, will join the White House inner circle as the next counselor to the president, Mr. Bush said Wednesday.

title: Planned Parks May Cost City Too Much, Group Warns
description: In a city with few backyards, everyone loves a park  but not many people consider who is going to pay for all that grass.

title: Southeast Asian Terrorist Leader Is Under Arrest
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 13  After several days of uncertainty, the Indonesian police confirmed Wednesday that Abu Dujana, a major Southeast Asian terrorist leader and a most-wanted fugitive in Indonesia, had been arrested and was in custody in central Java.

title: Computer Flaw Could Imperil Space Station
description: The Russian computers that help keep the International Space Station in orbit were out of commission for the second day, a glitch that could imperil the $100 billion orbiting laboratory if it is not corrected.

title: Seeing Manhattan From Sea Level
description: The visibility in some of the waterways surrounding Manhattan is so poor that a swimmer can barely see his own hands. The water is cold, the currents are powerful and debris can include plastic bags and dead fish.

title: A Phone for the Sly Can Record Calls and Store Them on a Computer
description: The Ipevo Free.2 phone is slim, sleek and potentially sneaky. The phone, which makes calls over the Internet, can record your calls and save them on the hard drive of your computer.

title: Skateboarding in Olympics: Rad or Bad?
description: It is definitely not cycling. Some say it is not a sport at all. Still, skateboarding  with creative assistance from cyclings international governing body  appears headed for the Olympics in a bid to make the 111-year-old Games more attractive to a younger audience.

title: North Carolina: Grahams Say They Will Be Buried at New Library
description: The Rev. Billy Graham announced that he and his wife, Ruth Bell Graham, have decided to be buried at the new Billy Graham Library in Charlotte. Mrs. Graham, who has been bedridden for several years, has reportedly slipped into a coma. Disagreements between the Grahams children over the couples burial site became public last year. Mrs. Graham, 86, preferred a long-planned site at the Cove, a retreat center in Asheville that she helped design for the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association. Asheville is nearer to the couples mountain homestead in Montreat.

title: Calendar
description: Drawing With David Macaulay

title: Edwards to Press Insurers on Health Care Premiums
description: DETROIT, June 14  John Edwards pressed his signature issue of universal health care coverage today, saying that he would force insurance companies to spend at least 85 percent of the premiums they collect directly on patient care.

title: F.D.A. Panel Votes Against Weight-Loss Drug
description: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected today by a federal advisory panel, which cited concerns that it increases the risk of neurological and psychiatric problems, including suicide.

title: Pedaling in Their Dreams
description: Forget about Lance and Landis. Lets not talk about the Tour. The worlds toughest bicycle race -- the Race Across America -- kicked off at noon on June 10, and it will go nonstop for the next week straight through to a time cutoff on June 22. The coast-to-coast course follows a 3,043-mile route on highways and county roads from Oceanside, Calif., to Atlantic City, and riders pedal around the clock, some forgoing sleep for days on end. Top solo riders average 350 miles a day and will finish after more than a week of near-constant motion. Relay teams of two, four, or eight racers average 500 miles a day. About 200 competitors -- including soloists and team riders -- are competing this year, the biggest showing ever for a competition now in its 26th year. As of Thursday morning, the leading solo riders -- Jure Robic, Wolfgang Fasching, and last year's winner, Daniel Wyss -- were spinning sleeplessly through the high plains of Kansas.

title: Chase Bank Set to Build Tower by Ground Zero
description: After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, JPMorgan Chase is expected to announce today that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown, according to government officials and real estate executives.

title: House Votes to Bolster Database on Gun Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The House voted Wednesday to close a loophole in gun control laws that allowed the Virginia Tech gunman to buy firearms even though he had been committed to a mental hospital. The Senate is likely to follow suit, marking the first time since 1996 that Congress has approved a measure strengthening gun control.

title: Georgia Aquarium Mourns Another of Its Whale Sharks
description: ATLANTA, June 13  For the second time in five months, the Georgia Aquarium is mourning one of its stars, a young whale shark named Norton who was euthanized by veterinarians early Wednesday morning after he stopped swimming and slipped to the bottom of his tank.

title: An Unexpected Odd Couple: Free Markets and Freedom
description: When President Bush declared last week that political openness naturally accompanied economic openness, his counterparts in Beijing and Moscow were not the only ones to object. Liberal and conservative intellectuals, even once ardent supporters, have backed away from the century-old theory that democracy and capitalism, like Paris Hilton and paparazzi, need each other to survive.

title: Fixing Silent Movies in Windows
description: Fixing Silent Movies In Windows

title: Losing Count
description: THE Holocaust has always been marked by numbers. There was the numbering of arms in death camps and the staggering death toll where the words six million became both a body count and a synonym for an unspeakable crime. After the Holocaust, Germany performed the necessary long division in paying token reparations to survivors. More recently, Swiss banks and European insurance companies have concealed bank account and policy numbers belonging to dead Jews.

title: The Pangs of Family Mealtime Guilt
description: ON a recent weeknight at my house, my 16-year-old gobbled leftover pasta and a protein bar at 5:15, then raced off to baby-sit at 5:30. My 13-year-old left for Hebrew school at 6, where dinner is served in the form of pizza and salad (though I cant swear that he ever eats the salad). My husband, whose usual commute brings him home at about 7, drove directly to pay a condolence call at 7:30, where he snacked on a cookie. I ate low-carb cereal standing at the kitchen sink.

title: Never Mind the Name: Balanchines 60s Hit Seeks to Sparkle Again
description: George Balanchines Jewels was said to have been inspired by a visit to Van Cleef & Arpels, though he made sure to say publicly that the ballet had nothing to do with gems. The supposed theme, the jewel-strewn look of the work and several rave reviews made Jewels the kind of hit that ballet seldom had in the mid-1960s, when the work was first performed.

title: Chase Bank Announces Plan to Build Tower at Ground Zero
description: JPMorgan Chase announced today that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the decline of the South Korean tradition of drinking after work referred incorrectly to Norske Skog, a paper company that acquired a South Korean mill whose hard-drinking culture changed under the new owner. It is Norwegian, not Swedish.

title: Six Men Charged in Fort Dix Plot Plead Not Guilty
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 14  Six men accused of planning to kill soldiers at the Fort Dix military base pleaded not guilty today to the charges against them, accusations that include training with guns, conducting surveillance of military installations and acquiring weapons in preparation for the attack on the base.

title: Power in the Shower: New Zing for the Bathroom
description: IF taking out a home-equity loan to renovate your bathroom seems too daunting, why not try a quick fix? A new rug, a mat for the shower stall or even a wall-mounted cabinet for extra storage can make a bathroom feel fresh and work more efficiently.

title: The Mets Just Love to See Clemens Sweat
description: In the amateur draft in June 1981, the Mets took a college outfielder named Terry Blocker with their first-round pick. Blocker would go on to have one hit for the Mets. With their fifth-round pick, the Mets drafted a high school shortstop named Steve Phillips and signed him for $42,000. Phillips never played in the majors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An illustration with a short article in Science Times on Tuesday about the effect that soot in snow has on warming in the Arctic incorrectly included a penguin. Penguins do not live in the Arctic; the northernmost penguins are those on the Galpagos Islands, around the Equator.

title: 70 Million Years Ago, Birdlike Giant in China
description: Scientists have uncovered a huge surprise in the Inner Mongolia region of northern China: the fossil skeleton of an unusually robust birdlike dinosaur that lived 70 million years ago. The animal appeared to be a young adult 25 feet long and weighing 3,000 pounds and, if it had lived longer, would probably have grown even larger.

title: San Francisco Fights Official Over Residency
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13  For six months or so, Ed Jew, a new member of San Francisco Board of Supervisors, has spoken on all sorts of issues involving this city. He has spoken about San Francisco laws, San Francisco people and even San Francisco animals.

title: N.B.A. Players to Combat Hunger
description: The National Basketball Players Association yesterday announced its initiative to feed one million people in Kenya, through its formal partnership with the organization Feed the Children.

title: As the Rich Get Richer, the Nascar Field Tilts
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., June 13  Dale Earnhardt Jr. flashed a broad smile as he stood next to the race-team owner Rick Hendrick with cameras clicking away, capturing the moment that marked the beginning of a new era in Nascar.

description: As he walked down West 59th Street yesterday, a burly man in a blue hard hat, he looked like thousands of other electricians in the city.

description: Words like modest, moderate and somewhat faster do not typically describe the type of economy that sends Wall Street on a tear.

title: Anti-Syrian Lawmaker Killed in Lebanon Blast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13  A powerful bomb exploded at a popular seaside club here on Wednesday, killing a prominent lawmaker and nine other people. It was the deadliest in a string of recent explosions that have rattled this city and shaken its fragile sense of stability.

title: With Immigration Bill Stalled, Advocates Push Forward
description: LOS ANGELES, June 13  As officials in Washington discussed ways to revive an immigration bill stalled in the Senate, immigrant advocates moved forward on Wednesday with a new round of lobbying that they hope will lead illegal immigrants out of the shadows.

title: 4 in Senate Seek Penalty for China
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Four leading Democratic and Republican senators proposed legislation Wednesday aimed at penalizing China over its export practices and predicted that they would have the votes to pass it in Congress this year even if it was vetoed by President Bush.

title: Battle Over Math in New Jersey Drives Off a New Schools Chief
description: Parents, some involved in a campaign against the math teaching in the highly regarded Ridgewood, N.J., school district, were to have met the new superintendent at a reception last Monday night.

title: Sharing Views of Past, Present and Purgatory
description: One of two things usually happens when something goes on for a long time (long being an outrageously subjective concept in the arts). Either the activity builds in impact, like a Pina Bausch spectacle, or you largely forget its there, like a Norah Jones album.

title: Only Wild Fish Matter in Endangered Count, Judge Rules
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13  A federal district judge in Seattle on Wednesday nullified a Bush administration policy that counts hatchery fish along with wild fish when making decisions about which species should be protected under the Endangered Species Act.

title: Keeper of the Saudi Secrets
description: British Prime Minister Tony Blair seems determined to use his final weeks in office to show how far he has strayed from the pledges of clean government that helped sweep him to power a decade ago. Defending his decision to block a corruption investigation into the sale of fighter jets and other weapons to Saudi Arabia, Mr. Blair said last week that the probe would have led nowhere except to the complete wreckage of a vital strategic relationship.

title: Germany: Anger Over U.S. Lawmakers Remark on Schrder
description: German officials heatedly protested remarks made by Representative Tom Lantos, a Democrat of California who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in which he described former Chancellor Gerhard Schrder as a political prostitute for taking a job with a Russian state gas company. The government spokesman, Ulrich Wilhelm, said the comment, made in a speech at the dedication ceremony for a victims of Communism memorial in Washington on Tuesday, was unseemly. The foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, said it had breached the bounds of decorum and was a discredit to Mr. Lantos. Mr. Schrder has been criticized within Germany for his new job, overseeing a pipeline project.

title: In for a Penny, in for the Pounce
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 13  Is there anything left? Anne Mosseri-Marlio asked as she surveyed the red dots beside many of the paintings in Paula Coopers booth.

title: Mets Try Clubhouse Humor to Offset Their Frustration
description: LOS ANGELES, June 13  Five Mets players sat around a small card table before Tuesdays game playing dominoes. They were shouting, laughing, enjoying themselves. A few hours later, after another disheartening loss, the only sounds coming from the clubhouse were from the attendants banging dirt off cleats. A few coaches sat at their stalls, their heads lowered. From across the room, John Maine, the losing pitcher, threw a half-filled (half-empty?) water bottle into his locker.

title: A Sense of Anxiety a Shirt Wont Cover
description: ON a recent afternoon, Dr. Michelle Copeland, a plastic surgeon whose offices face the Metropolitan Museum of Art, clicked her computers mouse as images of young mens torsos flickered across the screen. Unlike the ancient Greek statues of Herakles or the bronze discus throwers in the newly renovated galleries across the street, the young men in Dr. Copelands digital images were a bit different: Rather than bearing the broad, flat chests of Greek athletes, their pectoral areas assumed a fuller, more feminine shape.

title: Violence Rising in Much of Iraq, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Violence increased throughout much of Iraq in recent months, despite a security crackdown in Baghdad that at least temporarily reduced sectarian killings there, according to a quarterly assessment of security conditions issued Wednesday by the Pentagon.

title: Oscar Rules Regarding Producing Are Relaxed
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 13  Producers take heart: It just got a little easier to put your hands on an Oscar.

title: Losses Are Taking a Toll on the Frustrated Mets
description: LOS ANGELES, June 13  The Mets are not panicking. They are not scared. Yet the losses are stacking up in staggering fashion, five in a row and 9 in 10 games with the 9-1 drubbing by the Los Angeles Dodgers on Wednesday night, and in small but distinct ways this dreadful stretch is starting to wear on them.

title: For Those Who Missed the 60s or Just Cant Remember
description: FASHION, depending on which designer you ask, is currently about futurism, romanticism, athleticism or the revival of 1980s-ism. Funny how no one ever mentions hippies.

title: Who, Me Take Running Class?
description: WHEN Steve Huda began running nearly three decades ago, he gave little thought to putting one foot in front of the other. I did what most people do, said Mr. Huda, 53, a computer specialist from Centennial, Colo. I just went out and ran.

title: China: Automaker Acquires Two Ventures
description: The Shanghai Automotive Company, Chinas largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations. The operations being taken over, the Shanghai Huizhong Automotive Manufacturing Company and the Shanghai Wanzhong Automotive Components Company, will become part of a Shanghai Automotive unit, the SAIC Motor Corporation, Shanghai Automotive said. The automaker already owns half of both ventures. The move is in line with a government plan to combine the countrys automakers.

title: Rudolf Arnheim, 102, Psychologist and Scholar of Art and Ideas, Dies
description: Rudolf Arnheim, a distinguished psychologist, philosopher and critic whose work explored the cognitive basis of art  how we interpret it and, by extension, the world  died on Saturday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 102.

title: Iran May Know of Weapons for Taliban, Gates Contends
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany, June 13  The flow of illicit weapons from Iran to Taliban fighters in Afghanistan has reached such large quantities that it suggests that the shipments are taking place with the knowledge of the government in Tehran, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday.

title: Barneys Could Be Sold to Dubai Firm
description: The Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, people involved in the talks said yesterday.

description: Tokyo

title: Tennessee: University Cannot Sell Artwork, Judge Says
description: A Nashville judge has ruled that Fisk University cannot sell artwork from its Stieglitz Collection, including Georgia OKeeffes signature painting Radiator Building-Night, New York. Tuesdays chancery court ruling came in a legal dispute over the universitys right to sell the OKeeffe and a painting by Marsden Hartley; both were donated by Ms. OKeeffe in 1949. The university announced plans to sell the two paintings in late 2005 to bolster its endowment and pay for campus improvements.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the conviction of a Brooklyn man, Gregory Zalevsky, for the 2004 murder of his girlfriend, Irina Ilyina, misstated their ages. He is 52, not 57, and she was 31 at the time of her death, not 34. (Both errors appeared in an article about his trial on June 2, and the incorrect age for Ms. Ilyina first appeared in an article about Mr. Zalevskys arrest on July 8, 2004.)
