description: The quadrennial ritual of presidential debates has long followed a tried and true format.

title: A Resort Cottage to Go
description: WHEN it became unbearably hot and humid last month in Houston, Jane Moore, a 60-year-old primary school reading consultant, left her house to stay in her park model trailer in South Fork, Colo. Its very cool and beautiful here, she said in a telephone interview, snug in her park model, which looks like an elongated cottage, is surrounded by a white picket fence and overlooks the Rio Grande. She bought the land and the park model in October. People dont understand what park models are, she said. Theyre not tacky.

title: Winning Is Best Change That Els Can Make
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13  There have been small scars and deeper bruises in the career of Ernie Els, whether from a surgeons blade or the heartbreak of 18 holes gone wrong.

title: An Obama Patron and Friend Until an Indictment
description: CHICAGO  Antoin Rezko, an entrepreneur of considerable charm who found riches in fast food and real estate, is known around Chicago as a collector of politicians.

title: Wall St. Journal Will Raise Price to $1.50
description: The Wall Street Journal will raise its weekday newsstand price from $1 to $1.50, starting July 16, the newspapers parent, Dow Jones & Company, said yesterday.

title: Refinery Considered for South Dakota
description: Hyperion Resources, a closely held Dallas investment firm, said it might build an oil refinery in South Dakota to capitalize on record gasoline prices.

title: Battle for Control of Chinas Largest Beverage Maker Escalates
description: SHANGHAI, June 13  The former chairman of the Wahaha Group and many of the companys top executives joined forces Wednesday to denounce their longtime partner, Groupe Danone, the French food and beverage giant, and threatened to form a company that would break away from its joint venture.

title: The Only Thing Missing Is Bananarama
description: AH, cruel summer.

title: For Democratic Leaders, a Fear That the Focus on the War Has Blurred
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Bush had barely left the Capitol after immigration talks there on Tuesday when Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, walked onto the Senate floor to call for a moment of silence. It was time, Mr. Reid said, to pay tribute to American soldiers in Iraq as their death toll reached 3,500.

title: Justice Dept. Reshapes Its Civil Rights Mission
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  In recent years, the Bush administration has recast the federal governments role in civil rights by aggressively pursuing religion-oriented cases while significantly diminishing its involvement in the traditional area of race.

title: At 44, Wells Is the Anti-Clemens
description: SAN DIEGO, June 10  The reunions happened to be scheduled for the same day, one at Yankee Stadium, the other at All Souls Episcopal Church in San Diego.

title: Headphones to Shut Out the World
description: As you may have heard, air travel this summer isnt going to be pretty.

title: MacBook Pros Look Like Older Models, but the Innards Are Different
description: Apple rarely makes sweeping changes to its product line, which is why its new MacBook Pro laptops look identical to older models. Only the innards are different, offering improved wireless networking and processing speed.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I hide my ugly windows without blocking the light?

title: A Classico-Minimalist
description: THERE were no turtle rumps, dormice or sows vulvas in the freezer of Jesse Browners Chelsea kitchen recently, but there was boar meat, and his pantry  a swell pullout number hidden in a cabinet  held a whiffy bottle of garum, a fish-infused oil that smells something like a restaurants Dumpster on a really hot day.

title: Prima Ballerina With Supple Grace and a Will of Steel
description: When Diana Vishneva was 9, she was denied admission to the Vaganova Ballet Academy in Leningrad, the school that has produced generations of stars (Nijinsky, Pavlova, Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov among them). Her spine was malformed and would cause her problems later, the authorities said. And her legs didnt lift high enough.

title: Kurt Waldheim, Former U.N. Chief, Is Dead at 88
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General and President of Austria whose hidden ties to Nazi organizations and war crimes was exposed late in his career, died today at his home in Vienna. He was 88.

title: The Dust Is Thick: Its Time to Vacuum the Elephants
description: The hydraulic lift lurched up, bringing the back of an African elephant into full view. To Mike Peter Smith, who was cleaning the elephant yesterday, its spine took the form of a gently sloping mountain range with peaks behind the head and near the rear legs.

title: What if You Met the Enemy and It Really Was You, and Then It Happened Again
description: It isnt often you walk around a corner and run into yourself, but it happens occasionally in Raw Danger, a survival game in which the player lives through the aftermath of a tsunami as several characters.

title: The Cat With Only Hats
description: A NEW hat shop seems like a strange place to lament the demise of the hat business. But then the very idea of a hat shop is something of an anachronism.

title: Germany: VW Narrows American Loss
description: Volkswagen narrowed its North American first-half loss by reducing discounts and warranty claims and concentrating on sales of the most profitable models, the company said. Volkswagens sales have fallen this year in the United States as the company prepares new models for 2008. The company sold 91,743 vehicles in the United States in the first five months, a 4.4 percent drop from a year earlier. Sales in 2007 will be flat, Mr. Hallmark said.

title: A Retreat in Ulster County, Shipped Partly From Bolivia
description: FOUR years ago Henry Scott, a media consultant living in Manhattan, hired Sergio Guardia to design a weekend house on a wooded site in Kerhonkson, N.Y. Mr. Guardia, an architect who was born in Bolivia and trained at Harvards Graduate School of Design, came up with plans for a futuristic house set on thick steel beams cantilevered over a hillside.

title: Mixing, Matching and Mirth for Oakmonts First 36 Holes
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13  The course at Oakmont Country Club has greens that slope like a funhouse floor and about as much breathing room as polyester knit pants. If the weather this week is hot and dry, the worlds best golfers are liable to stagger through the United States Open with faces longer than the 667-yard 12th hole.

title: A High-Definition Media PC That Evokes Legendary Technology
description: According to urban legend, aliens crash-landed in the desert outside Roswell, N.M., and their remains are hidden in the Air Forces Hangar 18. Inside Alienwares Hangar 18, however, you will find only high-end PC components and high-definition video playback systems.

title: Queens: 20 Years for Killing Father
description: A Queens woman who killed her father by striking him with a hammer in 2004 was sentenced to 20 years in prison yesterday, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, pleaded guilty last month in State Supreme Court to manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin was charged with beating her father, John Martin, 67, with a hammer in their Long Island City home and then going out to buy drugs. She told the police that he had been attacked during a break-in, Mr. Brown said.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) PIRATE MASTER Its never easy at the top  of the mast, that is. Capt. Joe Don, left, is riding high for the moment, but in this reality TV jibe at Pirates of the Caribbean there are plenty of buccaneers who are ready to throw him over. In a high-seas version of a straw poll, half the pirate contestants are backing the captain, while the others are ready for a mutiny. Theyll have to find the $35,000 bounty first.

title: Yes, Kilroy Was Here, Armed With Agitprop
description: Drawing is a verb, according to Richard Serra, and the Romanian artist Dan Perjovschi seems to agree. This spring, as cranes were hoisting Mr. Serras steel sculptures into the Museum of Modern Art for his retrospective, Mr. Perjovschi was scaling the eastern wall of the buildings atrium in a cherry picker.

title: In Health Care, Cost Isnt Proof of High Quality
description: Stark evidence that high medical payments do not necessarily buy high-quality patient care is presented in a hospital study set for release today.

title: Stocks Rise on Upbeat Economic Reports
description: Everything Wall Street has been worried about in the last week  rising bond yields, high inflation, the strength of the economy  seemed to weigh less heavily on investors today, and stocks began to recover.

title: You Can Smooth or Zap but Will the Results Hit Home?
description: IN pursuit of a glowing, smooth, youthful complexion, Ann Runnels, 44, has tried Botox, microdermabrasion, injectable fillers, Fraxel lasers (a treatment said to stimulate cell growth) and the usual array of creams, ointments and $120-a-bottle serums.

title: House Panel Passes Bill to Cut Subsidies to Student Lenders
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The House education committee voted Wednesday to cut subsidies to student lenders and to halve the interest rates on a key student loan program over the next five years.

title: Legislators Grapple Over How to Legalize Medical Marijuana Use
description: ALBANY, June 13  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders said this week that the use of marijuana for medical purposes should be made legal in New York State.

title: Next Week
description: A look at the man behind soccers Gold Cup, the anti-World Cup with the downmarket reputation, as the tournament moves toward a conclusion. Also, the summer hotspot for tennis: Vermont.

title: Panel Says Liberian Ex-Leaders Wealth Hasnt Vanished
description: DAKAR, Senegal, June 13  When Charles G. Taylors long-awaited trial on 11 war crimes and crimes against humanity opened in The Hague on June 4, Mr. Taylor upended the proceedings by refusing to appear, saying he was too poor to afford his own defense and unhappy with the one provided by the court, despite having amassed a personal fortune estimated at half a billion dollars while in power in Liberia.

title: Manhattan: St. Vincent Gets New Chief
description: The chief executive of Catholic Health and Human Services in New Jersey has been selected to become the next president of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, the Manhattan-based hospital and health care network, officials at St. Vincent announced yesterday. The new president, Henry Amoroso, will lead St. Vincent as it works to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy this summer, officials said. In addition to leading the Newark-based hospital and charity system, Mr. Amoroso was principal adviser on urban health care to Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, officials said.

title: Congressional Payback (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Personal (pH) Balance
description: PATRICIA OHARA considers herself a methodical, detail-oriented person.

title: Let Doctors Act (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Several Mosques Attacked, but Iraq Is Mostly Calm
description: BAGHDAD, June 14  A handful of Sunni mosques were attacked today in retaliation for the destruction of two minarets at one of Iraqs most revered Shiite shrines on Wednesday, and there was scattered violence around the country, as has become the norm.

title: Wall Street to Get Guidelines on E-Mail
description: Try to imagine Wall Street getting through one day without cellphones, BlackBerrys or sending messages through Bloomberg terminals. No, really.

title: Nomination of Chief Justice Raises Questions in Trenton
description: TRENTON, June 13  Several African-American lawmakers raised questions on Wednesday about the nomination of New Jerseys attorney general to lead the states Supreme Court, saying that Gov. Jon S. Corzine should have consulted more widely among them and given minority candidates more consideration.

title: Few Good Options for U.S. on Palestinian Violence
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  For two years, the United States has tried to choke off Hamas, the militant Islamic group that has been ascendant in Gaza and the West Bank, while throwing limited aid and support to Fatah, its more moderate Palestinian rival. Now, with Fatah, the party of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on the verge of collapse in Gaza, Washington is facing a shrinking menu of alternatives.

title: Kellogg to Phase Out Some Food Ads to Children
description: Froot Loops days on Saturday morning television may be numbered.

title: The Summer of Love (and Rivalry, Too) (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Throw Out Challenge to Murder Conviction
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that an Ohio prisoners challenge of his murder conviction must be thrown out because he missed a filing deadline by a few days  not through his or his lawyers fault, but because a federal judge made a mistake.

title: Lab Chief Explains DNA Report in Duke Case
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 13  The prosecutor in the Duke lacrosse case had nothing to do with a laboratorys decision to not say in a report that tests had found DNA from at least four unknown men on the body and underwear of a stripper who accused the students of gang rape, the lab director said Wednesday.

title: In a City of Power Brokers, a Young Visitor Who Is Truly Worshipped
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  Even by the standards of the luminaries who sweep through Washington, the little girl in front of Lafayette Elementary School almost six miles north of the White House was special.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about industry lobbying to shape energy legislation gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the group that is running advertisements in favor of expanded use of alternative fuels. It is the Energy Security Leadership Council, not the National Commission on Energy Policy. The article also left an incorrect impression in some copies that John Rowe, the chief executive of the Exelon Corporation, an electric utility company that operates nuclear power plants, was connected to those advertisements. The article noted that Mr. Rowe, coincidentally or not, is a co-founder of the Energy Security Leadership Council. In fact, he is the head of the National Commission on Energy Policy.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed by Robert H. Bork, the onetime Supreme Court nominee, against the Yale Club in Manhattan over injuries he suffered during a fall from a dais incorrectly rendered an account of the incident by Cricket Farnsworth, the office manager for The New Criterion magazine, which had invited Mr. Bork to speak at the club. Ms. Farnsworth said that Mr. Bork went on to deliver his speech after his fall; she did not also say that he managed to make his way back to the dais first.

title: In Shift, Judge Eases Limits on Surveillance by the Police
description: In a startling legal reversal, a federal judge in Manhattan decided yesterday to vacate his own order that had greatly limited the New York police in videotaping people at public gatherings. He said the reversal was based partly on new information.

title: An Economical Alternative to a Higher-End Canon
description: Canons 8-megapixel S5 IS, which just went on sale, is considered a bridge camera  crossing the gap between a pocket point-and-shoot and heftier single-lens reflex models, known as DSLRs. Those high-end cameras have interchangeable lenses, which can be costly and hard to change without dirt finding its way to the charged image sensor. The resulting spots on images can be a real problem.

title: Sex-Positive Feminism and the Single Snail
description: Ariane Anthony is probably the only New York choreographer and performance artist who could get away with portraying, on the same evening, an at least superficially earnest lecturer on global warming and a glamorous gardener who eventually falls in love with the snails she intends to exterminate. Ms. Anthony did both, and more, in Snail and other spirited dances and films on Sunday night at the Construction Company on East 18th Street in Manhattan.

title: Markets Soar on Upbeat Economic Data
description: Stocks surged yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its biggest gain in almost 11 months, after the bond market rallied and a government report on retail sales exceeded economists estimates.

title: Millers Path to Eight Under Went From Tee to Green
description: Oakmont, Pa.

title: Putting Energy Hogs in the Home on a Strict Low-Power Diet
description: I THOUGHT I was pretty good about energy conservation, but it turns out that Ive been a bit of a hypocrite. I drive a reasonably fuel-efficient car, I work at home so I dont use fuel to commute and I am replacing incandescent bulbs in my home with energy-efficient fluorescent bulbs.

title: The River and the Man
description: Two months after completing a 3,278-mile swim down the Amazon River, Martin Strel -- profiled by Ed Zuckerman in the June issue of PLAY -- is back in Slovenia and, according to his son, Borut, profoundly affected by the experience. Martin has told me many times he is dreaming daily about the Amazon swim and just cannot forget it, Borut wrote in an e-mail message. It looks like this swim changed his life. Strel is still drained from the Amazon swim, Borut says, and cannot even train at half power. Nevertheless, Strel is telling people he is reborn. He feels like he did 20 years ago, Borut says.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about higher pork prices in China amid fears of rising inflation referred incorrectly to the time period in which pig prices increased 71.3 percent. It was in April compared with the same month a year earlier; the prices did not increase that much from March to April.

title: Japan: Current-Account Surplus Rises
description: The current-account surplus widened at the fastest rate in three years in April as exports rose and a weaker yen increased the value of investments abroad. The surplus expanded 50.3 percent, to 1.99 trillion yen ($16 billion), from a year earlier, as growth in exports to Asia and Europe helped offset a decline in shipments to the United States, the Ministry of Finance said. The trade balance climbed 34.7 percent. Exports climbed 7.3 percent from a year earlier, and imports advanced 3.2 percent.

title: Woman and Three Children Found Dead Near Chicago
description: CHICAGO, June 14  A mother and her three children were found shot to death early today in a sport utility vehicle parked near an interstate about 50 miles southwest of here, the authorities said.

title: Bronx: Suspect Rescued From Ledge
description: Police officers with the Emergency Services Unit broke through a window and grabbed a suspect who was clinging to a 23rd-story ledge of a building near the Bruckner Expressway early yesterday morning, the police said. The suspect, Francisco Correra Jr., was charged with assault and with violating an order of protection, the police said. Mr. Correra, 33, was charged with hitting his father about 5:30 a.m. at their apartment building at 950 Underhill Avenue, the police said. When officers arrived, Mr. Correra had left the apartment and gone to the buildings roof, the police said.

title: Arrest Uncovers Divide in Hmong-Americans
description: ST. PAUL, June 9  Year after year, Vang Pao, the most recognized leader of Hmong people in the United States, described his dream when he appeared at Hmong New Year celebrations, ceremonies for new refugees, memorial dedications. Someday, he said, he would carry his people home to a free Laos.

title: Town Went Too Far in Trying to Take Land, Court Says
description: In a decision that could affect redevelopment battles across New Jersey, the State Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday that a town had overstepped the State Constitutions definition of blight when it tried to take private property for development.

title: Updating Maps on the Spot and Sharing the Fixes
description: Out-of-date maps can throw a wrench into your driving plans, but TomToms new Map Share software combines cartography with community to allow users to update maps on the go  and later share the results with others.

title: Bid to Ban Gay Marriage Fails in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, June 14  Same-sex marriage will remain legal in Massachusetts, as its proponents today won a pitched months-long battle to defeat a proposed constitutional amendment to define marriage as between a man and a woman.

title: Gaza Turmoil Prompts Abbas to Dissolve Government
description: JERUSALEM, June 14  The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Palestinian president dissolved the three-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.

title: Staten Island: Sentence in Scalding Case
description: A Staten Island man was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for scalding a 3-year-old boy in a bathtub in 2005, prosecutors said. The man, Michael Duhs, 34, of Seaview Avenue, was convicted of assault and child endangerment in State Supreme Court in February, said Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney. Mr. Donovan said Mr. Duhs was charged with scalding his live-in companions son on Sept. 16, 2005, and not seeking medical attention for the child until the mother returned home six hours later. The boy suffered third-degree burns over 10 percent of his body, Mr. Donovan said.

title: The Times Promotes Circulation Official
description: Yasmin Namini, senior vice president for circulation at the New York Times Media Group, has been promoted to senior vice president for marketing and circulation.

title: Queens Bodega Owner Dies After Being Shot in Robbery
description: A Queens bodega owner died yesterday after being shot during a robbery on Monday by three men the police said may have carried out as many as 16 other robberies since March 17.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the National Briefing column on June 7 about the opening of four public housing duplexes in New Orleans misidentified their location. It is the Upper Ninth Ward, not the Lower Ninth Ward.

title: A First for the Cavaliers Still Endures
description: Shortly after the Cleveland Cavaliers closed out an emotional playoff series against Detroit, I met a Cleveland police officer who said he was a friend of a friend who knew the legendary Robert Bingo Smith  the original Cleveland Cavalier.

title: Writer Convicted of Kidnapping Expresses Remorse in Letter to Judge
description: The Womens Wear Daily writer convicted of kidnapping and sexually molesting a former colleague has submitted a long, sometimes flowery, sometimes analytic letter to the judge who is going to sentence him on Monday.

title: Coughlin Wants Less Talk, More Wins
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 13  Tom Coughlin wants to coach a Giants team that does more winning and less bickering.

title: Showcasing His Growth, Parker Quiets His Critics
description: CLEVELAND, June 13  When Tony Parker talked about growing pains with a vindicated grin Wednesday, he was not talking about the agony that has been LeBron Jamess first N.B.A. finals.

title: Manhattan: More on Congestion Plan
description: Trucks that meet tougher emissions standards would pay just $7 rather than the $21 fee charged to other trucks to enter the busiest parts of Manhattan under a new provision of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan, the mayor said yesterday. He made the announcement at Gracie Mansion, surrounded by labor leaders who endorsed his overall environmental program, PlaNYC. Officials said that cleaner, more efficient trucks, as well as those retrofitted to reduce emissions by 85 percent, would qualify for the discounts. Mr. Bloomberg said that there were no plans to reduce the $8 automobile fee for lower-emission cars like hybrids because the program was intended both to reduce traffic and to raise revenue.

title: Above the Store, a Little R&D
description: ROMANA RAFFETTO met her husband, Gino, at a cafe on West Fourth Street just a few weeks after she arrived in New York in 1957; she had come by ship, having traveled from her hometown of Asolo, just outside Venice.

title: New Haven: Yale Buying Research Site
description: Yale University said yesterday that it was acquiring the Bayer HealthCare complex in West Haven and Orange, about seven miles from its main campus in New Haven. Bayer announced in November that it was leaving the 136-acre site, where it conducted research and had its headquarters. When efforts to find another pharmaceutical company to take over the property failed, it was put up for auction. Yale was the winner, but declined to disclose the price. Richard C. Levin, Yales president, said the acquisition would enable the university to accelerate its science research program.

title: The Artists Kitchen, Recycled and Curated
description: SIMONE LEIGH, 39, lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on the second floor of a squat brick building that was once a garage for Ebbets Field. Ms. Leigh is an artist who makes swollen and lovely ceramic objects  eggs, breasts, missiles, plantains  that she assembles into large installations about race, history and gender.

title: Senate Leaders Agree to Revive Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Senate leaders announced an agreement this evening to put a comprehensive immigration bill back on track for further debate and possible passage.

title: Ex-Premier of Israel Takes Helm of Labor Party
description: JERUSALEM, June 13  Ehud Barak, a former prime minister of Israel, returned to the political scene on Wednesday as the new leader of the Labor Party, and the deputy prime minister and elder statesman, Shimon Peres of the ruling Kadima Party, was elected by Parliament to the largely ceremonial post of president.

title: Hartford: Senator Quits Leadership Job
description: Louis C. DeLuca, left, the State Senate minority leader, resigned yesterday from his leadership post, according to a statement from the Senate Republicans. Mr. DeLuca, Republican of Woodbury, pleaded guilty this month to a misdemeanor charge of asking a businessman now facing racketeering charges to have someone threaten a man Senator DeLuca believed was abusing a family member. The businessman, James Galante, a trash hauler, had not been charged at the time; he has since pleaded not guilty. In a statement, Senate Republicans said Senator John McKinney, of Fairfield, would assume the leadership role until the caucus elected a new leader. Senator DeLuca, 73, said he looked forward to continuing to be a productive member of our caucus.

title: Hamas Seizes Broad Control in Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, June 13  Hamas forces consolidated control over much of Gaza on Wednesday, taking command of the main north-south road and blowing up a Fatah headquarters in Khan Yunis, in the south.

title: Big-Name Playwrights, Still Bargain Tickets
description: The Signature Theater Company, the 16-year-old Off Broadway theater that dedicates each season to the work of one American playwright, announced yesterday its next four seasons, which will feature plays by Edward Albee, Charles Mee, Suzan-Lori Parks and Tony Kushner.

title: Multigenerational Cooking
description: TEN years ago, right after the birth of Paulette Mullings-Bradnocks son Reginald, her mother came to visit from Kingston, Jamaica.

title: Kitchen Tales
description: THE American kitchen has been an aspirational space ever since electricity and post-World War I prosperity commingled in a nifty new appliance called the refrigerator. There are scads of ads from the 1920s showing people in tuxedos and evening gowns literally adoring their fridge, said Victoria Matranga, a historian of industrial design and the design programs coordinator at the International Housewares Association near Chicago. Then as now, Ms. Matranga said, owning the right appliance flagged your social status by showing off your understanding of technology and progress, not to mention your prowess as a breadwinner. The kitchen has also long been a very personal space, not just a place where we tell stories about who we are, but a highly functional theater for those stories (even if the stories have nothing to do with the preparation of food).

title: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Drug for Obesity
description: A drug once viewed as a possible magic bullet against obesity was rejected yesterday by a federal advisory panel because of worries that it causes neurological and psychiatric problems and increases the risk of suicide.

title: Teaching Policy Chief Takes Top School Job in Baltimore, and Klein Taps Brooklyn Educator
description: After one year, Andrs Alonso, the senior instructional official in the New York City public schools, is resigning as Chancellor Joel I. Kleins top deputy to become chief executive of the Baltimore public schools.

title: Irish Green Party to Support Deal That May Give It Governing Role
description: DUBLIN, June 13  The leadership of Irelands Green Party agreed Wednesday to support a deal with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern that could make it a part of the government for the first time.

title: Rules of the Road
description: FOR distance running (versus sprinting) most experts agree on the following principles of proper form:

title: The Only Heat Is From Hot Sauce
description: JILL PETTIJOHN, a raw-food cook and advocate, has earned a bit of fame in the fashion world, both as Donna Karans personal chef and as the purveyor of five-day juice fasts, the juices for which are delivered daily to winter-swollen fashion editors from her raw-food restaurant, Jill's, in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. She may have been responsible for a rash of public non-eating this spring, reckoned Kate Betts, editor of Time Style & Design magazine. Ms. Betts and her husband spent a week sipping Ms. Pettijohns juices and then pretending to eat at her many meal-centered business and social functions. I even saw men pushing their food around their plates, she said.

title: Reading the Cards Well Enough to Collect Them All
description: The final of the trial to select the U.S.A.-2 team for this years Bermuda Bowl world championship ended Sunday night in Schaumburg, Ill., with Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell winning the 120-board match. They defeated Russ Ekeblad, Ron Rubin, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby by 271 international match points to 225.

title: Computer Problem on Space Station Persists
description: The Russian computers that help keep the International Space Station in orbit remained largely out of commission today, although Russian engineers appeared to be making some progress in correcting a glitch that could imperil the $100 billion space laboratory.

title: Parade Officials Criticize Police Over Arrest Total
description: The organizers of the Puerto Rican Day Parade criticized the police yesterday for arresting more than 200 people Sunday, many of them on charges of unlawful assembly.

title: You Were Expecting Maybe Tragedy?
description: When Truman Capote became an Oscar-worthy movie character and In Cold Blood bounced back onto bestseller lists, The New Yorker sportingly published yet another Woody Allen instant classic. Titled Above the Law, Below the Box Springs, it mimics the absurd solemnity and keen attention to minutiae that color self-important crime reporting in rural settings, lampooning a style well known to New Yorker readers.

title: Vintage Performance From Mussina
description: Their seats are in the front row of Section 616, in the upper deck behind home plate at Yankee Stadium, a convenient spot for paying homage to the Yankees starting pitcher. Gary DeSpirito and his son, Anthony, from Hawthorne, N.J., attend eight games a year in those seats, and most of the time the pitcher is Mike Mussina.

title: At Oakmont, No Tin Cup; Just a Steel Curtain
description: When I wrote about Phil Mickelson for this months PLAY, I called him a favorite for the United States Open. I hadnt reckoned on the clingy rough at Oakmont wringing out his wrist two weeks before the tournament began. A guy I know, a former club champ who can still knock the ball around, played in an outing there recently, and he came away physically intact but psychically maimed. The championship tees were roped off and the greens had yet to be given their pre-tournament shave. Even so, my friend disappeared into the rough, failed to break 100 and was shell-shocked for days.

title: Arctic Plants Have Adjusted to Climate Changes
description: Many Arctic plant species have readily adjusted to big climate changes, repeatedly re-colonizing the rugged islands of Norways remote Svalbard archipelago through 20,000 years of warm and cool spells since the frigid peak of the last ice age, researchers say.

title: Another Sorry Ascension
description: It apparently wasnt enough for the Bush administration to pack the Department of Justice with political operatives. The White House has now nominated one of the most meddlesome of those partisans, Hans von Spakovsky, to a powerful post on the Federal Election Commission.

title: Baron Guy de Rothschild, Leader of French Arm of Bank Dynasty, Dies at 98
description: Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.

title: Funds Released in North Korea Deal
description: HONG KONG, June 14  The banking authorities in the United States and Macao today began to transfer millions of dollars to North Korea and end a dispute that has stalled an agreement to dismantle the Norths nuclear programs, officials from the Macao government said.

title: Another Spin for Buy American
description: GENERAL MOTORS has clearly been hurt by consumers who simply refuse to buy an American brand of vehicle. But the automaker has decided to use its heritage as a competitive advantage rather than a weakness, since it is one adjective that competitors like Toyota and Honda cannot use.

title: Bork v. Bork
description: There are many versions of the clich that a conservative is a liberal who has been mugged, and Robert Bork has just given rise to another. A tort plaintiff, it turns out, is a critic of tort lawsuits who has slipped and fallen at the Yale Club.

title: S.E.C. Ends Decades-Old Price Limits on Short Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted yesterday to end price restrictions on short selling, meaning that investors seeking to sell a share that they do not own will no longer be barred from doing so because the price of the stock is falling.

title: Bloggers Ejection May Mean Suit for N.C.A.A.
description: The eviction of a newspaper reporter from a baseball press box for blogging about a game while it was in progress has stirred a debate about First Amendment rights, intellectual property rights and contract law.

title: When the Real Estate Market Sizzles, the Oven Stays Cold
description: THE Wolf oven in this open kitchen with cherry wood veneer cabinets still has the plastic wrapping on its shelves, though its owner, Dennis Mangone, 47, has lived here for two years. But the kitchen has uses besides cooking.

title: South Africas City Workers Join Spreading Strike for Higher Wages
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 13  South Africas municipal workers joined provincial and national government employees in a bitter strike on Wednesday, walking off their jobs to march by the thousands in scores of cities and bringing activity in some places to a halt.

title: 2 Greens, Blue Line, a Yellow Golfer
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 13  Bubba Watson was taking a break between shots on the practice range at the Oakmont Country Club on Wednesday when the conversation in his entourage of four turned to the rules about putting on the practice green. Watsons eyes widened when he was told, incorrectly, as it turned out, that golfers would face disqualification if their putts rolled over the blue line separating the practice green from the ninth green.

title: The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
description: Michael S. Dell (of Dell Inc.) sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard University sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

title: Jazz With a Casual Urgency, Played in Support of Peace
description: Since moving to New York in the early 1990s the tenor saxophonist Donny McCaslin has built a reputation for versatility, poise and a vigorous approach to improvisation. Not coincidentally he now holds a sideman post in two of the more prominent ensembles in jazz, the Maria Schneider Orchestra and the Dave Douglas Quintet. And he has been increasingly productive as a bandleader, drawing from the well of similarly broad-minded New York musicians and writing music that suits their worldly ideals.

title: Stormy Weather for Soloists as Battles Rage All Around
description: When a jazz club audience completely rolls over for a band and gives it full license, the band can do extraordinary things  instinctive, daring, almost unreasonable things.

title: Prisoner Killed Kentucky Police Chief, Officials Say
description: CAVE CITY, Ky., June 13  The longtime police chief of a rural town in eastern Kentucky was shot dead Wednesday by a handcuffed prisoner he was driving to the county jail, officials said.

title: And the Oscar-Winning Filmmaker Goes to ...
description: After a flirtation with Senator Barack Obama, and maxing out his contributions to both Mr. Obama and former Senator John Edwards, Steven Spielberg threw his support behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president. Mr. Spielberg cited Mrs. Clintons experience and strength in a statement posted on her campaign Web site. Ive taken the time to familiarize myself with the impressive field of Democratic candidates and am convinced that Hillary Clinton is the most qualified candidate to lead us from her first day in the White House, he said. Hillary is a strong leader and is respected the world over. As president, she will bring America back together, rebuild our prestige abroad and ensure our protection here at home.

title: Unwelcome at Home, Student Play Is a Hit in New York
description: Backstage at the Vineyard Theater, Taylor Telyan, 18, was bent over an ironing board, ironing her hair. A few feet away, her friend and castmate Tara Ross, also 18, was applying makeup; outside their door, a couple of boys were sacked out on a couch, studying notes in binders. They had 35 minutes until their Off Broadway debut.

description: THE RWANDA-BURUNDI BORDER

title: Summer Challenge: Handling the Heat
description: With temperatures for summer activities likely to reach into the 80s and 90s around much of the country, its a good time to reflect on heat illness, which incapacitates thousands of athletes every summer and, in the form of heat stroke, can kill. Last year, the American College of Sports Medicine published new consensus guidelines about avoiding, recognizing and treating heat-related illnesses. (Keep a tub filled with ice near the playing field, for instance.)

title: Explosives Are Found in Lockers in New Jersey School
description: WAYNE, N.J., June 13  A high school was evacuated here during the last full day of classes after a total of 16 gunpowder-filled devices with fuses were found in two lockers on Wednesday morning, officials said.

title: Day of Police Chases, Some Woolly, Some Winged, All Wild
description: The stark, hard-edged and dramatically capitalized words of a police bulletin said it all: A SHEEP RUNNING IN THE STREET. OFFICERS CANVASSED THE AREA AND LOCATED THE SHEEP/LAMB AND REQUESTED ESU.

title: For Mrs. Giuliani, Not the Usual Campaign Trail for a Candidates Wife
description: Three months ago, as Rudolph W. Giuliani was starting his quest for the Republican nomination, his campaign sought to introduce the political world to his third wife, Judith, having her speak at a fund-raiser in New York, while Mr. Giuliani suggested on national television that his wife might someday even sit in on cabinet meetings.

title: 2 Committees Subpoena Ex-Officials on Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The Senate and House Judiciary Committees issued subpoenas on Wednesday to Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel, and Sara M. Taylor, the former political director, ratcheting up the pressure on the White House to cooperate with the Congressional inquiry into last years firings of federal prosecutors.

title: China: Retail Sales Surged in May
description: Retail sales unexpectedly accelerated at the fastest rate in three years, lifted by rising incomes and a stock market that has doubled this year. Sales rose 15.9 percent from a year earlier to 715.8 billion yuan ($94 billion) after gaining 15.5 percent in April, the statistics bureau said. The gain was the biggest since May 2004 after adjusting for distortions caused by Chinas Lunar New Year holidays.

title: Dry Cleaner Calls $54 Million Lawsuit Over Pants a Nightmare
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  A pair of charcoal-colored pants at the center of a $54 million lawsuit was unfurled in a courtroom here on Wednesday, introduced into evidence by a defense lawyer who called the lawsuit a nightmare for his clients.

title: Correction: Listen Up, Everybody: Im in Menopause
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about menopause referred incorrectly to the theater production Menopause: the Musical. It had its premiere in Orlando, Fla., not in New York.

title: N.J. Legislators Pet Spending Projects, Exposed
description: TRENTON, June 12  As part of the effort to bring greater transparency to the states budget process and reduce the potential for corruption, the Legislature on Wednesday released for the first time a list of special projects and other changes to the $33.5 billion budget being requested by individual lawmakers.

title: Google Gives Up on Competing With eBays Big Boston Party
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13  It had all the appearances of a marketing stunt gone awry, the Internet industrys version of a wily playground taunt that quickly escalated into a tense standoff, until the taunter  Google, in this case  blinked.

title: Family Forestry
description: There is a crisis brewing in Americas vast forest lands, but it has little to do with the health of the woods: the acreage is essentially the same as it was a century ago, and there is over 30 percent more wood volume per acre than in 1952.

title: Vietnams Leader Wants U.S. Visit to Be All Business
description: HANOI, Vietnam, June 13  Bracing himself for criticism over Vietnams human rights record, President Nguyen Minh Triet said Wednesday that he would keep his eye firmly on trade and investment when he visited the United States next week.

title: Fighting the Web, Sports Teams Seek to Control Ticket Resales
description: When the N.B.A. finals resume today in Cleveland, Dan Gilbert, the owner of the Cavaliers, will be showing off the youngest, flashiest asset in his portfolio.

title: If You Really Need the Big Price Tag
description: WHEN I walked up to Theorys flagship store in the meatpacking district, I saw a model teetering outside on the uneven cobblestones of Gansevoort Street, getting some last-minute touch-ups for a photo shoot. She was wearing a cream-colored coat that was gathered in the back with clips, like an exoskeletal spine.

title: Brooklyn Waterfront Called Endangered Site
description: The mighty Monitor, the ironclad Civil War ship, was built on Greenpoints gritty waterfront. The Graving Dock at the Todd Shipyards in Red Hook was the terminal for ships traveling from the Erie Canal. The Old Dutch Mustard Company in Williamsburg churned out prepared mustard, vinegars and fruit juice for half a century. The mustard building was torn down last fall, and other sites in Brooklyn are soon to be transformed into apartments and stores in an ambitious neighborhood revitalization effort that is a cornerstone of the Bloomberg administrations economic development initiative. But today the National Trust for Historic Preservation plans to sound the alarm by declaring Brooklyns industrial waterfront one of Americas 11 most endangered historic places.

description: To the Editor:

title: American Held in Torture Case Leaves Prison in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 13 (AP)  An American imprisoned in Afghanistan for running a private jail for terrorism suspects has left the Afghan prison where he was held for almost three years and has departed the country, the warden said Wednesday.

title: Wrong Image? It Depends on Beholder
description: NEW CITY, N.Y.

title: NBC Developing Web Site for Students
description: Imagine Tim Russert introducing a classroom history lesson about the Articles of Confederation, or Brian Williams describing the reverberations of the Stamp Act.

title: Judge Won't Delay Libby Prison Term
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  A federal judge refused today to delay the start of the prison sentence for I. Lewis Libby Jr. in the C.I.A. leak case while he appeals his conviction, meaning he could be ordered to surrender within two months.

title: Upfront TV Market Starts With NBC Universal Deal
description: The upfront market for the 2007-8 television season is getting under way with a large deal between the NBC Universal division of the General Electric Company and the media agencies owned by the WPP Group.

title: Theories About Separatist Group Muddy Terrorism Trial in Madrid
description: MADRID, June 13  For the past three months, more than two dozen defendants have been on trial in Madrid on charges that they orchestrated one of the worst terrorist attacks in Europes recent history  the bombing of four commuter trains on March 11, 2004, which killed 191 people and wounded at least 1,800. But at many points during the trial, the courtroom has been absorbed by a sideshow  the effort by a handful of lawyers for some victims to demonstrate that ETA, the armed Basque separatist group, had a part in the bombings.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,504 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Detox Survivor, Check Your Straitjacket at the Door and Get Ready to Rock
description: The rock musical has become the live-performance equivalent of the road movie: a ubiquitous convention turned rite of passage as one aspirant after another seeks to achieve its perfect fulfillment. If it falters  which it often does  its less often on the rock than on the musical part. That is, a band drapes its songs over an often ambitious, and sometimes squirm-inducing, story.

title: Trial Ordered in Italy for 4 Big Banks in Parmalats Failure
description: MILAN, June 13  An Italian judge on Wednesday ordered Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, Morgan Stanley and UBS, as well as 13 employees of the four banks, to stand trial on charges of market manipulation in the events that led to the multibillion-dollar bankruptcy filing of the Italian dairy company Parmalat in 2003.

title: Where the Goods Are Odd
description: This time of year, Alaska is paradise. King Salmon hustle up to the front porch of Anchorage. Softball games unfold in the buttery glow of the midnight sun. And the woods are full of mega fauna in frisky pursuit.

title: For Cavaliers-Spurs, Where Have All the Viewers Gone?
description: What has become of the N.B.A. finals? Yes, they will continue tonight on ABC with San Antonio leading, 3-0, and yes, there will be hopes that LeBron James can lead Cleveland to a victory or two before his Cavaliers succumb to the Spurs. But if fan aversion to this series continues at its current pace, these finals could be the least-viewed in at least 22 years, if not longer.

title: Mr. Fundamental
description: Tim Duncan has his Spurs within reach of a fourth N.B.A. title, and has won two most valuable player awards, but is considered by some to be a boring player. Should Duncans style of play affect his standing among the leagues all-time great big men?

title: A Failure to Protect Our Troops
description: The Bush administration and military leaders in Washington are always claiming that they will do anything to support American troops fighting in Iraq. That makes it all the more infuriating to learn that, for more than two years, the Pentagon largely ignored urgent requests from field commanders for better armor-protected vehicles that could have saved untold lives and limbs.

title: Kellogg to Curb Marketing of Foods to Children
description: Froot Loops days on Saturday morning television may be numbered.

title: Fun in the Booth as the Yanks Surge Continues
description: The Times seat in the Yankee Stadium press box is located right next to the visiting TV booth. Separated by a panel of glass, Ive sat next to a whole bunch of guys from my old baseball card collection, incluiding Bert Blyleven, Jerry Remy, Ron Fairly, Buck Martinez and the funniest guy in baseball (trust me), The One And Only Rex Hudler.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "In a Dark Dark House" and "The Butcher of Baraboo."

title: Art in the Everyday
description: Images of Venice's readymades, from the city's campos and palazzos.

title: To the Matinee and Back
description: By the millions, day-trippers visit New York every year to see the Saturday or Wednesday matinees on Broadway.

title: Diverging Fortunes
description: A golf resort in Oregon benefits from a variety of subsidies, the kind of indirect favors that influence the flow of money from public to private interests.

title: Glimpses of Hope
description: Today begins with a bad story, and ends with a good one. We had heard about a settlement of recent returnees from Josh Ruxin, our gracious host in Kigali and director of Rwandas Millennium Villages Project. Millions of Rwandans left Rwanda in the decades of instability leading up to the genocide, and many settled permanently in surrounding countries. Some have since been forcibly sent back, including this group of about 2,000 people from Tanzania. The group we encountered had all been settled in Tanzania since the 1980s, and had established sustainable farms and small businesses. Many were even born in Tanzania and had never set foot in Rwanda. Last November, they were stripped of their belongings and chased out of their villages, and told to return to Rwanda. Rwanda has a right of return policy reminiscent of Israel. (Rwanda will never turn away our own people, a Rwandan woman told us, We are one people, and no matter where they come from, they belong with us.) The refugees, or more correctly, the returnees, were welcome into the country.

title: Armageddon Comes Knocking
description: Given that the finest special effects in this crashing bore are Jessica Alba's pillowy lips, which look as if they could save lives in a 175-mile-an-hour car crash, it's no wonder some viewers might find themselves wishing that the promised end of the world might happen a bit sooner. At least there would be some bounce to go along with the big bang. Woe unto the impatient: it takes well over an hour before Armageddon comes knock, knock, knocking on the door to this particular hell, by which time the guy with the director's credit, Tim Story, has shown that he checked out the latest Superman movie before slapping together this amalgam of recycled ideas, dead air, dumb quips, casual sexism and pseudoscientific mumbo jumbo.

title: Under a Big Top
description: Photos of performances at Spiegelworld, a blend of cabaret, circus and burlesque.

title: Down n dirty dim sum
description: Theres a scene in Christopher News novel, A Change of Flag, in which a murderous triad boss invites a down-and-out street thug to an impressive dim sum meal to lure him into switching loyalties. The location was the ultimate in old Hong Kong gangster chic: the Luk Yu Teahouse.

title: Colorful Tributes
description: Images from Neo Rauch's "para" at The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Despite Honors, Misery for Company
description: "Company" may have won the Tony Award for best revival of a musical on Sunday night, but that accolade, along with honors from the Drama Desk, the Outer Critics Circle and the Drama League, won't prevent the final curtain from falling on it on July 1.

title: Who Said Break a Leg?
description: James Carpinello, who is playing the lead male role, Sonny, in the Douglas Carter Beane musical "Xanadu," currently in previews at the Helen Hayes Theater, badly injured his foot during a rehearsal on Tuesday. (This kind of thing happens when much of a show takes place on roller skates.)

title: The Best Coffee in Rome or Take that Paris!
description: If  as my colleague in Paris notes  Parisians are serious about their croissants, then Romans can be equally discriminating about coffee, in particular, their early morning cappuccino.

title: Shanghai Automotive Absorbs Venture
description: Shanghai Automotive, Chinas largest carmaker, agreed to buy out its partners in a truck maker and an auto-parts venture for 1.48 billion yuan ($194 million) to combine and expand its commercial-vehicle operations.

title: News Corporation to Sell 9 TV Stations
description: Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, which is making a $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said on Wednesday that it planned to sell nine of its Fox-affiliated TV stations. The stations are generally in the smallest markets served by the News Corporations 35-station television group.

title: A.I.G. Sues Ex-Officers Over Deals and Earnings
description: The American International Group sued its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and its former chief financial officer, Howard I. Smith, on Wednesday, becoming the sole plaintiff in a case seeking more than $1 billion in damages.

title: Lehman to Merge Two Residential Mortgage Units
description: Lehman Brothers said Wednesday it would merge two residential mortgage units, cutting 400 jobs.

title: Todays Teens, Todays Entrepreneurs
description: Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

title: Logical Therapuetics Gets $30 Million Injection
description: A drug developer, Logical Therapeutics, has raised $30 million in Series B funding, as venture capitalists eye an opportunity created by the spectacular fall of anti-inflammatory drug Vioxx three years back.

title: Zell Lobbies Washington on Tribune Deal
description: Chicago financier Sam Zell made the rounds on Capitol Hill this week, drumming up support for a buyout of Tribune in an effort to pressure federal regulators to grant waivers necessary to own both newspapers and TV stations in Los Angeles and four other cities.

title: Your City, Your Room
All in the Genes
description: There is an in-joke smothered under the wooden dialogue of "And Then Came Love," an inept romantic comedy that for reasons known only to God drew Vanessa Williams, Eartha Kitt, Ben Vereen and Stephen Spinella into its swamp of clichs. Ms. Kitt's character, Mona, is a scowling termagant as fearsomely strait-laced as Lady Bracknell in "The Importance of Being Earnest"  a play that figures prominently (and ludicrously) in the story. It's a hoot to watch Ms. Kitt, pop music's original vamp, look down her nose and pester her daughter, Julie (Ms. Williams), a single mother and successful magazine reporter, to marry and be respectable.

title: The Comedy of Capitalism
description: Maybe you have to have been brought up in a formerly Communist country to recognize and fully appreciate what might be called capitalist propaganda. What does it mean? It entails promoting a starry-eyed shop-till-you-drop ethos in a population accustomed to deprivation. How easy that appetite is to stimulate is demonstrated in the cheeky documentary "Czech Dream," whose creators, Vit Klusak and Filip Remunda, two students at the Prague Film Academy, used state money to stage an elaborate hoax.

title: Battle for Chinas Largest Beverage Maker Escalates
description: The former chairman of the Wahaha Group and many of the companys top executives joined forces Wednesday to denounce their longtime partner, Groupe Danone, the French food and beverage giant, and threatened to form a company that would break away from its joint venture.

title: A Family Struggling to Heal
description: Beyond Hatred, a documentary about a murder victims family struggling to heal, is an example of a film whose style doesnt merely suit its story but amplifies its meanings.

title: Fighting Words
description: Any attempt to elucidate the most vitriolic turf dispute of our time in just 73 minutes may seem insanely ambitious, but Isidore Rosmarin, the documentary filmmaker and producer, was not deterred. In Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict, he methodically traces the battle from its biblical origins to the fragile present through the eyes of everyone from fundamentalist Muslims to committed Zionists.

title: A Difficult Subject and a Delicate Balance
description: The documentary "Unborn in the USA" is billed as a rigorously objective look at the anti-abortion movement, and that's accurate  but only to a point. The people who are the filmmakers' subjects are passionate, sometimes intemperate and often in-your-face aggressive, and the movie's topic is a powder keg regardless.

title: Baron Guy de Rothschild Dies at 98
description: Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.

title: Entrepreneur Muscles In on Tescos Garden Deal
description: Shares in Britains Dobbies Garden Centres soared more than 17 percent after the Scottish entrepreneur Tom Hunter doubled his stake and said that he was considering launching a bid to rival that of the British supermarket chain Tesco.

title: Britain Explores Options for Venture Capital Fund
description: CDC, the government-owned fund that pioneered venture capital investment in Britains former colonies, has hired Morgan Stanley to advise it on a possible initial public offering or sale, The Times of London reported.

title: V.C.s Tune into PermissionTV
description: Web video platform provider PermissionTV has closed a $9 million Series C round of funding led by new investors Castile Ventures and Point Judith Capital.

title: Citi Raises $2.2 Billion in Landmark Japanese Bond Sale
description: Citigroup raised 270 billion yen ($2.2 billion) in Japans biggest bond sale by a foreign firm, tapping demand for higher returns than investors can receive from the nations companies.

title: An Epic Dodgeball Battle in Silicon Valley
description: As the dog days of summer approach, some Silicon Valley venture capitalists and entrepreneurs decided to take their deal-making to the dodgeball court.

title: Three Mid-Market Buyout Shops Sew Up Funds
description: Blackstone Group dominated the news with its upcoming initial public offering, but it was a busy week for some smaller private equity shops as well. Three buyout firms, Avista Capital Partners, VMG Equity Partners and Sterling Capital Partners, announced that each has closed a new private equity fund to invest in the middle market.

title: Hedge Funds Warn S.E.C. of Sub-Prime Manipulation
description: A group of hedge funds has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to be on the lookout for manipulation of bonds backed by sub-prime mortgages.

title: Goldman Seeks Stake in Indian Asset Manager
description: Goldman Sachs offered to invest in ICICI Financial Services to profit from increasing demand for Indias asset-management and insurance businesses.

title: Noise-Canceling Headphones
description: David Pogue puts to the test headphones that aim to reduce background noise.

title: Wesfarmers Seeks $10 Billion from Banks for Coles Bid
description: A buyout group led by Wesfarmers, Australias biggest home improvement retailer, is seeking to raise about 12 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to pay for an offer for Coles Group, according to Bloomberg News. The group met with 11 international and domestic banks in Melbourne Wednesday about loans and a possible bond sale, Bloomberg reported.

title: Whos Who at City Room
description: Updated, March 2010 | City Room, a live-news blog about the five boroughs of New York City, is a collaborative effort by reporters and editors of The Times. Listed below are some of the staff members involved:

title: Will IHOP Serve Up an Offer for Applebees?
description: A report on Wednesday that the pancake chain IHOP might be about to toss Applebees International onto its menu in a $2 billion deal, left analysts skeptical that such a deal was really in the offing.

title: Could Blackstone Regret Going Public?
description: The Blackstone Group is set to go public during a golden age of private equity investing. But what could happen if the environment gets tarnished by inflation, unfavorable regulation and other unpleasantness?

title: Wall Street to Get Guidelines on Electronic Messages
description: Try to imagine Wall Street getting through one day without cellphones, BlackBerrys or sending messages through Bloomberg terminals. No, really.

title: J.P. Morgan Set to Build Tower by Ground Zero
description: After months of sharp bargaining and threats to relocate, J.P. Morgan Chase is expected to announce Thursday that it has struck a deal to build a skyscraper near ground zero and move its investment banking headquarters from Midtown, according to The New York Times.

title: Barneys Deal Is Boon for Jones Chief
description: Following a report that the Jones Apparel Group is close to an agreement to sell Barneys New York, the fashionable clothing retailer, for $950 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, The New York Times put the price tag closer to $825 million.

title: S.E.C. Ends Decades-Old Price Limits on Short Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted Wednesday to end price restrictions on short selling, meaning that investors seeking to sell a share that they do not own will no longer be barred from doing so because the price of the stock is falling.

title: Concerns Grow Over Equity Bridges
description: The recent popularity of equity bridge loans, used to finance private equity deals, is worrying some analysts, regulators and even the investment bankers who arrange them. Goldman Sachs has told its mergers and acquisitions staff to avoid them, an unnamed banker who works there told Reuters. Another banker who arranges buyouts called equity bridges really bad business.

title: Hertz Prices Offering
description: Hertz Global Holdings said Wednesday that the offering by certain of its stockholders of 51.8 million shares of its common stock was priced at $22.25 a share. The shares are being sold by the private equity funds Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity. Hertz raised $1.32 billion from its initial stock offering, most of which paid for a dividend for owners Clayton Dubilier, Carlyle and Merrill Lynch.

title: Subprime Woes Sting Bear Stearns 2nd-Quarter Profit
description: The subprime mortgage market took a toll on Bear Stearnss second-quarter earnings, as the investment banks profits fell 33 percent from the same period a year ago despite record revenue for the quarter, the firm said on Thursday.

title: Paris Hiltons Jail Term, Taken Seriously
description: Who wouldve guessed that Paris Hilton would help underscore the profound effect of the Sheriffs Departments early-release program in Los Angeles?

title: John From Cincinnati
description: Is there a support group for John Updike obsessives? (Maybe its here, at The Centaurian, a Web site I admire but find so spectacularly hideous, in terms of design, that I half-expect to learn it causes epilectic fits in some readers, like that 2012 British Olympics logo.) If one exists, sign me up.

title: N.Y.P.D. Sirens
description: When New York City police officers have to use their sirens, they have the option to mix and match a series of screeches and wails. Below are the sounds at their disposal as well and one more -- the Rumbler -- which may soon be added to their repertoire.

title: Goldmans Profits Rise, But Just Barely
description: Goldman Sachs, the worlds most-profitable investment bank, reported earnings of $2.33 billion in the second quarter, a modest increase from last years second-quarter profit of $2.31 billion.

description: Comments on NYTimes.com are moderated. For details, see the answers to frequently asked questions about comment policies.We encourage readers to use their real names or initials. City Room values civil, thoughtful comments representing a range of views about news and issues in the five boroughs of New York City.

Their man appeared on television last week, emerging like a biblical apparition. The Coen Brothers film of No Country for Old Men will be in theaters soon. McCarthys The Road won a Pulitzer Prize two months back.

On The Market
No Jeans Left (Below) Behind

Researchers have long thought they saw the remnant of an ancient seabed on its surface, but they had a hard time explaining what happened to the oceanfront property. title: Bonnaroo: The Warm-up
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.For one weekend a year, 700 acres of green Tennessee farmland turns into the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, which gets started modestly tonight and runs through Sunday on six main stages. The main headliners are Tool on Friday, the Police on Saturday and, in a jam band finale, Widespread Panic on Sunday. The festival sold out to capacity today: 80,000 tickets at about $200 each.

title: Whos for Hillary. And Who Isnt.
description: According to a Washington Post  ABC News poll published earlier this week, Hillary Rodham Clintons most consistent and enthusiastic female support is now coming from high school graduates with incomes of less than $50,000 a year. Young women like her best. Over age 45, college-educated, higher-earning women like her least. In fact, asked who they found most honest, trustworthy and inspiring, these women  Clintons peers  expressed more of a kinship with Barack Obama.

title: Bonnaroo: A Portable Jazz Club
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Bonnaroo has a new feature this year: a fulltime jazz stage, sponsored by Blue Note Records. Its a smart marketing move for the label. Bonnaroo brings out listeners who care about instrumental music, and some of them are bound to appreciate unhyphenated jazz. (Since Bonnaroos stages have names like Which Stage, That Tent and The Other Tent, the jazz one is called Somethin Else, after a Cannonball Adderley album on Blue Note.) Its a tent tucked away at the edge of the field, set up like a jazz club with tables and waitress servicean odd apparition in rural Tennessee. Unfortunately, its not ideal acoustically; its ventilation fan can be as loud as a quiet jazz passage.

title: Japanese Show Seeks a Berth in Basel
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 14  Takashi Murakami, the Japanese artist and curator, arrived here on Tuesday, not just to peruse the thousands of artworks on view at Art Basel, the annual contemporary art fair, but also to scout possible sites for his Geisai show, which Mr. Murakami has been running twice a year in the Big Sight Exhibition Center in Tokyo since 2002.

The article also misstated the name of the Connecticut town where he and his wife, Dr. Irene Kitzman, have their primary residence. It is Hamden, not New Hamden.

title: Congress and the Caregivers
description: A retired home health aide who sued her employer for unpaid overtime lost big this week in the Supreme Court  and so did fairness and the health care system. A regulation that was ill-conceived and is cruelly applied is depriving an increasingly important group of health care providers of a decent living.

title: Hard to Find Good Help? Not in This Little Town
description: Much like zombies, zombie movies show no sign of rolling over and staying dead, really, truly, most sincerely dead. In recent years, they have run speedily amok in Danny Boyles spine-tingler 28 Days Later and its sequel, 28 Weeks Later (where the virus-stricken creatures are more zomboid than true zombies), as well as in the remake of George A. Romeros Dawn of the Dead. Ever the classicist, Mr. Romero keeps his zombies moving slow but steady in his rollicking Land of the Dead, the 2005 chapter in the zombie epic that shuddered into existence with his 1968 masterwork, Night of the Living Dead.

title: Britain: Tool Rental Company Buys a Rival
description: Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning Internationals Hewden Tools business for 115 million ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators. Speedy, based in Newton-le-Willows, northwest England, will pay cash for the operation, part of the Hewden Stuart subsidiary of Finning, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The purchase will increase Speedy Hires annual revenue by at least 20 percent, to more than 400 million, the chief executive, Steve J. Corcoran, said on a conference call.

title: Manhattan: Aid for Congestion Plan Disputed
description: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit yesterday said the Bush administration was exceeding its authority by offering New York City up to $500 million for Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposed congestion pricing plan. Representative Peter DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, said he had serious doubts that the mayors plan qualified for federal financing under the funds the federal Department of Transportation is proposing to use. But Jeffrey N. Shane, the transportation undersecretary for policy, said the department had ample statutory and regulatory authority to authorize the money under several different programs. The federal money has been a major selling point in Mr. Bloombergs efforts to win approval for the program in the State Assembly.

title: Brooklyn: Youth Accused of Bias Killing
description: A Brooklyn teenager was indicted yesterday on charges that he had fatally stabbed a 20-year-old man because he was gay, prosecutors said. Omar Willock, 17, was charged with murder in the second degree as a hate crime, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Willock is charged with stabbing Roberto Duncanson, 20, after shouting antigay remarks. Mr. Hynes said Mr. Duncanson tried to walk away, but Mr. Willock stabbed him four times.

title: Gasoline Pushed Up Producer Prices in May
description: A double-digit jump in the price of gasoline pushed inflation at the wholesale level up in May, but tame increases for most other goods suggested that price increases were largely contained and businesses would not react by raising prices.

There is the  hi-lo, dubbed the European siren by some, because it evokes the police chases seen  and heard  in French and Italian films.

Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox.

description: RALEIGH, N.C. June 15  Durham County district attorney Michael B. Nifong said today he plans to resign his job, after admitting that he had crossed the line of ethical standards in some of the public statements he made about the Duke University lacrosse players he charged with rape.

title: Kentucky: Indictment Issued in Fen-Phen Settlement
description: Three Lexington lawyers illegally kept $65 million in settlement money that should have been distributed to their clients, according to an indictment for wire fraud issued by a federal grand jury in Covington. The money was part of $200 million settlement of a civil suit claiming that about 440 people had been injured by the diet drug fen-phen. The lawyers, William J. Gallion, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and Melbourne Mills Jr., were entitled to about a third of the settlement but took twice that, the indictment said. The lawyers have denied criminal wrongdoing.

title: Bronx: Man Seeks Permission to Stay in U.S.
description: The West African man who lost his wife and four children in a Bronx fire in March that claimed 10 lives in all asked immigration officials yesterday to allow him to stay in the United States now that he has returned from burying his family in his homeland of Mali. The man, Mamadou Soumare, 48, is an illegal immigrant, and he received temporary travel permission for the trip. One of Mr. Soumares lawyers asked the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to grant his case deferred action status, which removes the threat of deportation. A spokesman for Citizenship and Immigration Services said the request is being reviewed.

description: THERE is a spot on the Zippety trail, a sinewy, 10-inch-wide track of hard-packed dirt near Fruita, Colo., where the sides drop away so steeply its like biking down the tip of a knife blade. Its the kind of trail that demands a pause before you commit yourself, so I gazed out over the broad Grand Valley to the snaking Colorado River and the red sandstone towers of the Colorado National Monument beyond.

Garcia, the United States attorney.

title: China: Strong Rate of Growth Persists
description: Chinas government reported industrial production growth unexpectedly accelerated in May, hours after Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, left, said further steps were needed to cool the countrys economy. Output rose 18.1 percent in May from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said, after gaining 17.4 percent in April. Mr. Wen said Wednesday that monetary policy needed moderate tightening, underscoring the failure of two interest rate increases this year to slow the economy. Record trade surpluses have pumped money into the financial system, stoking investment, inflation and a stock market boom. For the first five months, industrial production climbed 18.1 percent from the period last year, up from 16.6 percent growth for all of 2006.

title: When Good Weeds Go Bad
description: One of the basic parables of our time  and a staple of science fiction  is the tale of an alien organism that escapes into a new world and, because it has few natural enemies there, takes it over. We like the story best when it comes from outer space, preys on humans and is obviously the invention of a heated imagination. True invasives, the ones among us now, are more modest, and that helps explain their success  and their danger.

description: SALINAS, Calif.  Jose Martnez left Mexico around 1988 and toiled for years in a patchwork of fields here, harvesting berries and lettuce and barely making ends meet.

title: South Africa: New Post for Annan
description: Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, said he would serve as chairman of the Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa, a $150 million undertaking financed by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation. Mr. Annan made the announcement while speaking at the World Economic Forum in Cape Town. The alliances aim is to increase the productivity of millions of small scale farmers in Africa, where per capita food production lags behind population growth and a third of the population suffers from chronic hunger.

title: Songs About a Wanderlust That Always Leads Her Home
description: The jazz singer Sarah Partridge has a promising theme for her new show, Ive Gotta Roam, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel: songs about wanderlust in which all roads eventually lead back home. From Gypsy in My Soul, her set takes a circuitous route with visits to Paris, Key Largo and Beyond the Sea before ending Back in Your Own Backyard.

description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 14  The team of Stanford University engineers that won $2 million in a Pentagon-sponsored robot car contest in 2005 unveiled its next-generation vehicle that will maneuver in traffic without a human driver.
