description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 14  Maybe Sergio Garca should have genuflected at Oakmont Country Clubs Church Pews instead of joking about them.

title: British Court Names Terror Case Escapee
description: LONDON, June 14  A British court lifted restrictions Thursday on identifying a terrorism suspect who was said to have absconded last year by clambering through a window at a mental hospital. He is still at large.

title: The New Zealand Invasion: Digi-Folk Now!
description: It sometimes seems as if there is only one joke, and its innocence. From Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton to Jerry Lewis, Will Ferrell and Steve Carell, a comedian is as funny as he is unknowing.

title: Mapping the Causes of Corruption
description: It seems counterintuitive that a House Democrat responsible for winning elections thinks Congressional races need to be made more competitive.

title: Eating the Environment: A Literary Kitchen Cornucopia
description: Marks & Spencer, the British department-store chain, recently started putting a new symbol on its packaged foods. The store already labels its food with the country of origin and often the name of the farmer. But shoppers who buy strawberries and beans, for example, now see a white airplane on a black circle with the words air-freighted. This means that the food in question was transported by airplane, leaving a big carbon footprint in the sky. In other words, go ahead and eat the beans, but you have been warned.

title: People
description: People

title: 2 Lawyers Sued by S.E.C. in Penny Stock Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit yesterday against two lawyers, one a former enforcement official for the commission, charging that they had played important roles in a penny stock fraud that cost investors at least $160,000 in 2005.

title: Apples, Pears and Flow in World of Sensual Sparks
description: Jody Oberfelders new piece, The Title Comes Last, establishes her as one of the funniest modern-dance choreographers in New York. Performed on Wednesday night at the Flea Theater, this trio is essentially an unspooling skein of pure movement, much of it acrobatic. The dance tells no story. But fleeting bits of mime  a fist tapping upward on another dancers chest, a bite into a pear  work together to suggest much about everyday encounters and the sensual impulses that lurk among them.

title: Newark: Authorities Announce Gang Arrests
description: Law enforcement officials yesterday announced the arrests of 27 people accused of membership in the Bloods street gang. In two separate operations, state and federal authorities charged groups operating in Newark and Paterson. Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in Newark, said 13 people were charged with running a gun and drug business from two Newark housing projects. The state police also announced the arrest of 14 men they said were members of another branch of the Bloods, the Sex Money Murder set. They said three state leaders of the group were among those arrested.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Correction: A One-Light Town Grows Into a Second-Home Hotspot
description: The Havens column on June 8 about Milford, Pa., misstated the occupation of the first owner of Grey Towers, an estate open to the public for part of the year. James Pinchot was a wallpaper merchant whose family was in the lumber business; he was not a local timber baron. (The estate was later used primarily as a summer home by his son Gifford.)

title: In Trentons Culling of Pet Projects, Legislators Feel a Bit Left Out
description: TRENTON, June 14  If last years budget process in New Jersey ended with a bang  as in a costly seven-day shutdown of the state government  then this years is ending with a whimper and a measure of whining.

description: DANCE

description: Strauss Operas Yield Court Drama

title: Chinese in Talks to Send Pickups to Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, June 14  A small Chinese automaker and its New Jersey partner are negotiating with Mexican officials to import Chinese-made pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, the first step toward establishing a beachhead in North America.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,507 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: The National Pastime
description: At this very moment thousands of people are surfing the Web looking for genetic material so their children will be nothing like me. They are looking through files at sperm bank sites with Jetson-like names such as Xytex, which have become the new eBays for offspring.

title: Finally, on a Sunny Hill in Ukraine, Respect for Victims of the Nazis
description: Yesterday in Gvozdavka, Ukraine, Rabbi Shlomo Baksht removed a small cache of human bones from a cardboard box and placed them in a shallow grave, a hole once dug as a trench by villagers trying to thwart the advance of Nazi tanks in the early 1940s.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report by Agence France-Presse in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about the Rolling Stones performance at the Isle of Wight Festival on Sunday night referred incorrectly at one point to the history of their appearances in Britain. As the report noted elsewhere, their performance at the Isle of Wight was their first at a British music festival since 1976. It was not their first in Britain since then.

title: Rising Rates Squeeze Consumers and Companies
description: The unusually low interest rates of the last three years have been an enormous boon to almost every corner of the American economy.

title: On Mt. Shasta, Winters Wrath Knows No Calendar
description: ABOVE the timberline on Mount Shasta, somewhere near 10,500 feet, my tent decided to take flight. Grab that corner, grab an ice ax! I yelled over wind roaring down in gusts like waves. Dont let go!

title: Hong Kong: North Korean Funds Transferred
description: Banking authorities in the United States and Macao began transferring millions of dollars to North Korea to end a dispute that has stalled an agreement to dismantle the Norths nuclear programs, Macao government officials said. The money was transferred from Banco Delta Asia, a small family-owned bank in Macao, in the first step to return the money to the original account holders, the officials said. Under pressure from the United States, the Macao government in September 2005 ordered that about $25 million belonging to either North Korean state agencies or businesses with links to North Korea be frozen in the Macao bank. Diplomats working on putting into effect the agreement reached in February among North Korea, the United States, China, Japan, Russia and South Korea hope the transfer will at last revive stalled attempts to get the North to shut its nuclear facilities.

title: Sri Lankas Scars Trace Lines of War Without End
description: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka  The nights here are once again broken by artillery fire across the black lagoon. The road out of this peninsula has been closed since last August, making the area nearly inaccessible. Though food and fuel manage to arrive, shopkeepers are reluctant to keep stocks, not knowing when they may have to close up and run.

title: A Deal Too Far: Interviewers Balk at Jolies Terms
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14  The pen is mightier than the sword, they say. But not, apparently, when celebrity gossip is part of the equation. Then the pen has to deal with a lawyer.

title: More Trouble in Subprime Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first quarter, particularly in California, Florida and other formerly hot real estate markets, according to an industry report released on Thursday.

title: Forensic Experts Testify That 4 Iraqis Killed by Marines Were Shot From a Few Feet Away
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 14  Government forensic experts testified at a military hearing here Thursday that four Iraqi men killed by marines in Haditha in 2005 appeared to have been shot in the head from at least a few feet away, undercutting prosecutors argument that the men had been executed by two Marine infantrymen.

title: From Supernatural Tales to Storybook Endings
description: In an effort to engage the public further, New York City Ballet might consider allowing people to create their own thematic evenings next season. How about a What on Earth?! night (like anybody would miss that) anchored by Dybbuk?

title: A Trans-Atlantic Deal for Plays From London
description: Another piece of the London theater market has just been claimed by the same producer whose partnership already has a deal with the National Theater in Britain that gives it the first option to transfer shows to Broadway.

title: Report Details Deals in Student Loan Industry
description: Gifts and payoffs to universities and their officials by student lenders were far more pervasive than had been disclosed and in some cases were demanded by university officials themselves in exchange for promoting lenders to students, according to a Senate report on the student loan industry issued yesterday.

title: Junior Sleuth Finds Her Way to the Screen, With Knee-Socks Pulled Up High
description: In Nancy Drew, the titular girl sleuth, a literary role model and crush object for generations of young readers, is decked out with air quotes and the full complement of knowing pop-culture accessories. At one point in the film a Southern California real estate agent appraises Nancys penny-loafer-and-knee-socks look and says, With a little tweaking, you could be adorable. Later a semi-reformed Mean Girl from Nancys school notes that Nancys retro appearance has become a fashion sensation called the new sincerity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Season for Sea Turtles (June 8) brought back the treasured memory of a rare experience I shared with my then 5-year-old son and my parents 17 years ago.

title: Romney Faces Another Flip-Flop Question: Has He Changed on Stem Cells?
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Mitt Romney, who as a presidential candidate has already drawn criticism for changes in his positions on other social issues, is now facing questions on whether he has shifted his stand on expanded federal support for embryonic stem cell research.

title: White House Seems Ready to Let Hamas Seize Gaza
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Bush administration officials said Thursday that they had been discussing the idea of largely acquiescing in the takeover of Gaza by the militant Islamic group Hamas and trying instead to help the Fatah party of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, retain its stronghold in the West Bank.

title: And if You Pay Too Much, Its a Shame
description: This weekends Subway Series between the Mets and the Yankees  beginning tonight at Yankee Stadium  has long been sold out. But inexpensive tickets are still available for many of both teams remaining home games.

title: A Feisty Philanthropist at 100, With a Five-Year Plan
description: Tarrytown

title: A Gallery of Characters, a Galaxy of Possible Outcomes
description: Who wants to eat just one potato chip? Nobody, I trust. Similarly, dedicated theater lovers will not be content to sample just one of the eight plays that constitute Intimate Exchanges, the abundant buffet of domestic comedy by Alan Ayckbourn that opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters. To see a single play in this cycle, all about disappointing marriages and promising love affairs in a sleepy London suburb, is to be left with wistful, tantalizing thoughts about other possible fates that might befall its characters.

title: Austrians Cast Doubt on Russian Arrests in Murder Case
description: MOSCOW, June 12  It was among the more shocking contract murders in recent years in Moscow, a city that has seen more than its share of such crimes.

title: Four Women Are Sentenced in Attack on Man in Village
description: A judge sentenced four young women to prison yesterday  one for 11 years  for beating and stabbing an independent filmmaker in Greenwich Village last year who they claimed had taunted them because they were lesbians.

title: Home Foreclosures and Delinquencies Higher
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first three months of the year, particularly in California, Florida and other formerly hot real estate markets, according to an industry report released here today.

title: Often Accused, Never Charged, Newarks Ex-Mayor Faces U.S.
description: When federal prosecutors found in 1995 that Sharpe James, then the mayor of Newark, could not account for hundreds of thousands of dollars in donations from political patrons, his only penalty was a $44,000 fine from the state election commission.

title: Four Countries, Five Bands, One Coast-to-Coast Party
description: As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature Gypsy Caravan could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement. Shot on film and what looks like consumer-grade video by almost a dozen camera operators, including the veteran documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles, the movie tracks five very different Gypsy bands from four countries  India, Macedonia, Romania and Spain  that toured North America in 2001, delighting audiences from Florida to Oregon with ragalike melodies, furious flamenco and much brassy oompah-oompah amid bottles of booze and clouds of cigarette smoke.

title: Senator Blocks Vote on Subpoenas Over Eavesdropping
description: A Republican senator blocked a vote in the Judiciary Committee on whether to authorize subpoenas to the Justice Department to obtain secret legal opinions and other documents related to the National Security Agencys program of domestic eavesdropping. The action by Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona will block the vote for a week. After the vote next Thursday, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the committee, can decide whether to issue the subpoenas or use them as leverage in negotiations with the Bush administration over access to the documents.

title: Family Seeks Assurances on Protecting Dow Integrity
description: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company has rejected a proposed plan prepared by its lawyers, asking them instead to seek stronger guarantees of editorial independence as a condition of selling the company to Rupert Murdochs News Corporation.

title: Autism on the Rise: Just Look Around (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny Bones Unearthed at Facility in India
description: NEW DELHI, June 14  Health officials discovered 35 tiny bones and at least eight skulls at an illegal nursing home run by an unqualified doctor in a suburb south of New Delhi, investigators said Thursday.

title: Judge Promises Speedy Trial in Fort Dix Case
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 14  The federal judge presiding over the case of six men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at the Fort Dix military base compared the investigation on Thursday to an undercover drug operation and promised a speedy trial by years end that he expected to last three or four weeks.

title: With Sweep of Cavs, Spurs Are Champions Again
description: CLEVELAND, June 14  The San Antonio Spurs raced to the center of Clevelands court, jumping together in a tight circle of jubilation.

title: Suitor for Midwest Air Wins Board Seats
description: Shareholders of the Midwest Air Group elected three directors backed by a hostile suitor, AirTran Holdings, increasing pressure on Midwests board to consider AirTrans $389 million takeover offer for the airline.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Yankees notebook on Wednesday about catcher Jorge Posadas 7-year-old son, Jorge Jr., misspelled the name of a condition that the boy was born with in which the bones in the skull fuse prematurely. It is craniosynostosis, not craniosynostis.

title: Russia: Economy Expanded in Quarter
description: Russias economy expanded in the first quarter at the fastest pace in six years as production of building materials increased to keep pace with a construction boom and consumer demand remained strong. Gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 7.9 percent in the period, compared with 5 percent in the first quarter of 2006, the Federal Statistics Service said. The figure is not seasonally adjusted. Industrial output increased 7.9 percent in the first quarter of the year, compared with 4.1 percent in the period last year, according to the Federal Statistics Service.

title: Climbing to the Upper Decks (Before Theyre Torn Down)
description: UP in the distant, thin-air seats of Shea Stadium, where the sky-splitting peal of airplanes taking off from La Guardia seems even more terrifying than on the field level below, I had a clear view across the park to the forest of cranes in the neighboring lot. The Mets $600 million new stadium has been under construction since last summer, and though it is still only a concrete skeleton, I couldnt help but think as I clutched my $9 nosebleed ticket: It looks awfully expensive out there.

title: To Avoid Conflicts, Clintons Liquidate Holdings
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Concerned that their personal finances might become a political liability once again, Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in April sold the millions of dollars of stocks held by their blind trust after learning that those investments included oil and pharmaceutical companies, military contractors and Wal-Mart, their aides said Thursday.

title: Meadow Birds in Precipitous Decline, Audubon Says
description: Spreading suburbs and large-scale farming are contributing to a precipitous decline in once common meadow birds like the Northern bobwhite, the Eastern meadowlark, the loggerhead shrike and the field sparrow, a report released yesterday by the Audubon Society said.

title: Mountains, Woods and Noisy Waters That Dig Deep
description: IN June 1808, so the story goes, a 93-year-old woman known to history as Aunt Jess Guernsey set out on foot from her familys log house at the base of Mount Pemigewasset in New Hampshire to look for a new place to fish. Led by the sound of water, she wandered into a gorge that, although shed lived close to it for years, shed never seen before. She found herself at the bottom of a chasm of lush natural beauty, a roaring stream at its base, carved deep into the granite of the rugged White Mountains, yet so narrow as to be easily missed from the top.

title: Experts Call for More Research and More Vigilance Against TB
description: ATLANTA, June 14  In the wake of a worldwide scare caused by an American who traveled abroad with a highly dangerous strain of tuberculosis, the countrys top experts on the disease called Thursday for a vast increase in federal research dollars. They also asked for expanded authority to restrict travel by infected persons and a heightened explicitness in counseling patients on the risks of infecting others.

title: Senate Leader Criticizes Performance of Joint Chiefs Leader
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, delivered a critical assessment on Thursday of Gen. Peter Paces performance as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and demanded that Congress be given a fair, honest and frank report about conditions in Iraq when it receives a progress report in September.

title: Annette Bening Set to Revisit Broadway After Two Decades
description: After nearly 20 years away, Annette Bening is returning to Broadway next spring in a new play by the Australian writer Joanna Murray-Smith. The six-character play, The Female of the Species, about a feminist author with an extreme case of writers block, is set to begin performances on April 11 and open on April 28 at a theater to be named, according to the producers David Richenthal and Mary Beth OConnor. Michael Mayer, who just won a Tony for his direction of Spring Awakening, is slated to direct.

title: That Unruly, Serendipitous Show in Venice
description: VENICE, June 13  After the artists, dealers, critics and hedge-fund guys jetted off last weekend to shop in Basel and check out Documenta in Germany, it became easier to tell whether the 52nd version of the Venice Biennale was as much of a bore as it seemed.

title: Justices, 5-4, Accept No Excuses From Inmate for Mistaken Late Filing of an Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  A narrow Supreme Court majority on Thursday agreed that a lower court properly dismissed the appeal of a man who missed a federal filing deadline by three days because of a federal district judges erroneous instructions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: Federal Officials Must Testify
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that senior federal officials would have to answer questions under oath in a lawsuit accusing them of personally conspiring to violate the rights of Muslim immigrants held in a federal detention center in Brooklyn after 9/11. The ruling, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, upholds most of an earlier decision by a federal judge in Brooklyn. The officials, including former Attorney General John Ashcroft and Robert Mueller, the head of the F.B.I., had asked for dismissal of the lawsuit, by Javaid Iqbal, a Pakistani immigrant, arguing in part that the government was entitled to take actions that might not have been lawful before 9/11. Although acknowledging some forms of government action in emergencies may exceed normal constitutional limits, Judge Jon O. Newman rejected the officials contention, saying some protections against some of the violations claimed, such as needlessly harsh confinement and ethnic discrimination, do not vary with surrounding circumstances. The strength of our system of constitutional rights derives from the steadfast protection of those rights in both normal and unusual times, he wrote.

title: Writer Expresses Remorse for Sex Attack, but Still Claims He Is Ill
description: A former Womens Wear Daily writer convicted of kidnapping and sexually molesting a former colleague has expressed remorse for his actions, while insisting he is mentally ill.

title: Curfews and Pleas for Unity Keep Sectarian Retaliation at Bay in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, June 14  With curfews imposed in Baghdad and several other Iraqi cities and with heightened security across Iraq, Thursday passed with few violent incidents despite the destruction on Wednesday of the minarets of a holy shrine in Samarra sacred to Shiites.

title: Manhattan: Four Laws Are Enacted
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed four bills into law yesterday, including a bill renaming numerous streets that caused controversy when the City Council removed the name of a radical black activist, Sonny Carson, from the list. The mayor also signed the Safe Housing Act, giving the city broad new powers to go after slumlords and improve housing conditions. The act requires the Department of Housing Preservation and Development to identify 200 buildings each year with the worst histories of emergency repairs and uncorrected code violations and force their landlords to make repairs, or else the city will do it for them and bill the owners. If the landlord refuses to pay, the city can seize the property.

title: Cleared to Tee Off or Take Off
description: THE Hohokams were probably the first to turn the foothills of North Tucson into a second home. Two millenniums ago, they spent their summers gathering cactus pears and mesquite beans, anthropologists say, just north of the basin where the city of Tucson was founded in 1775.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Supports New York Citys Effort to Collect Taxes on Some U.N. Missions
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  New York City can go forward with its effort to collect unpaid property taxes from foreign governments that use part of their United Nations missions for housing, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.

title: Winners of Series May Meet in Travers
description: After a thrilling Triple Crown series, the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense, the Preakness winner Curlin and the Belmont heroine Rags to Riches will soon begin to gear up for summer campaigns that could, for all three, include a stop in Saratoga for the Travers Stakes on Aug. 25.

title: Oxnard, the Un-Malibu
description: OXNARD isnt the first place that comes to mind when the conversation turns to fabulous beach resorts on the California coast.

title: Britain Sentences 7 in Terror Plot
description: LONDON, June 15  A British court sentenced seven men to a total 136 years in prison today who had been convicted or admitted to acting as accomplices to an Al-Qaeda terrorist planning spectacular attacks in the United States and Britain.

title: If Its June, This Must Be Jazz
description: Every year in New York, toward the end of June, jazz suddenly becomes easier to understand. Not that the music empties out its tough ideas and becomes more glossy or simple-minded. Rather, the picture of what jazz is around the world grows sharper, as the possibilities of what to hear grow finer and deeper.

title: The Laptop Is Mightier Than the Sword
description: WHILE waiting to see if the Iraq surge strategy pays off, President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert Gates have shown Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the door and brought in Lt. Gen. Douglas Lute as the new White House war czar. Well, they can shift senior leadership all they want, but unless they give our troops patrolling the streets the tools they need, our leaders are going to see this strategy fizzle.

title: A Rakish Sabbatini Yuks It Up
description: OAKMONT, Pa.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Wednesday about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the surname of an attorney for Mark S. Kipnis, a co-defendant. He is Michael Schwartz, not Schwarz.

title: Indias Economic Boom Transforms Stock Trading Into a National Pastime
description: NEW DELHI, June 14  Devender Singh invested in Indias volatile stock markets for the first time last year after watching a friend make a mint. The markets promptly fell 30 percent.

title: Going to Court Over Fiction by a Fictitious Writer
description: Cloaking ones identity while writing  to hide, in other words, in order to reveal  is an old literary tradition. Mary Ann Evans used the gender-crossing pseudonym George Eliot to publish Adam Bede in 1859, when female authors still struggled to be taken seriously. Charlotte Bronte released Jane Eyre in 1847 under the name Currer Bell.

title: I.R.S. Seeks More Charity Transparency
description: The Internal Revenue Service yesterday proposed a vast overhaul of the main tax form for charities, an effort to make it easier for the I.R.S. and the public to tell how much nonprofit groups are paying their executives and how much of their money goes toward fund-raising.

title: Justice Dept. Expands Inquiry of Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  A Justice Department internal inquiry will examine whether Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales improperly tried to influence the testimony of a senior adviser in a private meeting in March in which the two discussed the dismissal of federal prosecutors, department officials said on Thursday.

title: What Do a Guy and a Gal Do in a Truck? They Sing
description: Every major road trip, at least from my experience, is a mixture of tedium and serendipity: long stretches of empty, eye-glazing highway interrupted by the awakening punctuation of the unexpected oddity or beauty spot.

title: Landis Uses New Book to Address Charges
description: A new book by Floyd Landis, the American cyclist who is facing charges that he used a performance-enhancing drug en route to winning the Tour de France last year, sheds new light on Landiss actions during a hearing over the doping charges last month as well as during last years Tour.

title: Remembering French Hero of the American Revolution
description: THOR-LA-ROCHETTE, France  Michel de Rochambeau likes to think that the life span of a tree separates him from his most illustrious ancestor.

title: At Ethics Hearing, Duke Prosecutor Is Called Unprofessional
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 14  The state bars expert witness on prosecutorial conduct testified Thursday that Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, repeatedly violated professional standards in his handling of evidence in the case of the stripper who accused Duke lacrosse players of sexual assault, and in many of his public statements related to that case.

title: Crew Chiefs Strategy Gives Gordon an Edge
description: Steve Letarte is Jeff Gordons crew chief, which means that Letarte spends race days perched on a portable cart next to Gordons pit stall. Letarte pulls on a headset and, like an offensive coordinator in football, becomes a tactician.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a house fire that killed five children in Pittsburgh incorrectly described the building. It was wood and shingles, not brick.

description: Mikki Hidalgos moment of clarity came on Memorial Day weekend in 1993, as she sat on her girlfriend and threw punches at her.

title: Paul McCartney Plays a Secret Show
description: I love you, Paul, someone shouted, halfway through Paul McCartneys secret set at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Well, more than one: A lot of people were shouting that. They couldnt help themselves. He was right in front of them.

title: Now Americana, Pac-Man and Its Ilk May Gobble Auction Bids
description: In the near future video games may attain the exalted levels of cultural respect now reserved for pop jingles and situation comedies. When that happens, consumers and collectors alike may discover a reverence for artifacts from gamings misty past (also known as the 1970s and 80s).

title: Good News on Math
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the teachers of New York are rightly proud of the citys performance on this years state math tests. New York City students showed gains in every grade tested, outpaced students in most other of the states big cities and edged closer to the state performance average. Thats significant, given that big city systems typically lag far behind rural and suburban districts.

title: Sunni Mosque Is Destroyed in Retaliation
description: BAGHDAD, June 15  A powerful explosion that reduced a large Sunni Arab mosque to rubble in the southern city of Basra this morning signaled that the cycle of revenge violence following the destruction of the Shiite shrine in Samarra has not entirely unfolded.

title: Energy Measure Blocked by Republicans in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Senate Democrats, facing their first significant battle over a wide-ranging bill intended to reduce oil consumption, found themselves blocked by Republicans on Thursday and postponed all significant votes until next week.

title: Hepatitis Cases Linked to M.D.
description: The citys Health Department said late last night that it was urgently contacting 4,500 patients treated by a Manhattan doctor after the discovery that three of them were found to have hepatitis C, a virus that can damage or destroy the liver.

title: Toy Building Sets Are Up for Auction
description: Its architecture in miniature, said Paul Neuman, explaining his attraction to antique building toys. Its about construction, assembly and materials. These toys are nothing until you build them. They require imagination and dexterity. And, unlike models, they can be taken apart and put back together.

title: The Father Figures, Though Not as Much
description: This is about as scientifically rigorous as alchemy. But the sense here, as we head toward another Fathers Day, is that married men and women could not be more different when it comes to displaying family photographs at work. It says something about relationships.

title: Boom Times for Banks in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In marathon speeches peppered with quotes from Marx and accolades to Che Guevara, President Hugo Chvez repeatedly vows to do away with capitalism in Venezuela. But it turns out that Mr. Chvezs economic policies have been generating a boom for those most capitalist of institutions  Venezuelas banks.

title: A Reversal of Fortunes for the Yankees and the Mets
description: Reggie Jackson was in the first class of free agents and began playing for the Yankees in 1977. That was 20 years before the onset of interleague play, so Reggie missed that revolutionary development in Major League Baseball.

title: Nigeria: Militant Released From Jail
description: A court freed a leading Niger Delta militant who has been jailed on treason charges for nearly two years, raising hopes that a deal to end a spell of violence in the oil-rich region may soon be at hand. The militant, Mujahid Asari-Dokubu, was jailed after he declared war against the government over corrupt practices that stripped the Niger Delta of its oil wealth but failed to develop it, making the Niger Delta one of the poorest regions in Africas top oil producer. The release of Mr. Asari-Dokubu, a member of the influential Ijaw tribe, has been a top priority of militants in the Niger Delta, who have carried out a campaign of bombings and kidnappings that have crippled Nigerias oil industry, slashing output by 25 percent.

title: Buoyed by Some Spiritual Guidance, Its Smooth Sailing
description: Three stout red ships muscled north along the East River. They seemed to grow larger against the backdrop of Governors Island as they approached Pier 17.

title: Senate Leaders Agree to Revive Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  President Bush and Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, pledged today to work for passage of the suddenly revived immigration bill, with Mr. Reid saying Senate Democrats would sacrifice their Fourth of July break, if necessary.

title: Mitchell-Giambi Meeting Under Discussion as Deadline Nears
description: With five days left before the Yankees Jason Giambi must decide if he will meet with investigators about steroid use in baseball, lawyers from the players union and Arn Tellem, Giambis agent, are in deep discussions with lawyers from Major League Baseball.

title: Haitian Teammates Turn Up After a Detour
description: Two days after 13 members of the Haitian national junior soccer team disappeared during a stopover at Kennedy International Airport, all but one had returned voluntarily, a Haitian diplomat said last night. The last boy was being held by the police and was waiting to be picked up, the diplomat said, but did not disclose the location.

title: Palestinians Split Deepens Even as Gaza Is Calmer
description: GAZA, June 15  The Palestinians divide, at once geographic, political and religious, deepened today: Hamas supporters marked their new control over Gaza by looting the symbols of fallen power as the routed Fatah party named a new prime minister likely to hold sway only in the West Bank.

title: Assisting the Good Life
description: BANDON, Ore.  Mike Keiser, who made a fortune selling greeting cards on recycled paper, turned this remote spot on the southern Oregon coast into a golfing mecca that attracts wealthy people in private jets from around the world.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a federal court ruling that overturned a Bush administration policy of counting hatchery fish when deciding whether federal protections are warranted for certain fish species misstated the location of the court. It is in Seattle, not Spokane, Wash.

title: Curious Time Travel Through Art History
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is not doing the German painter Neo Rauch any favors. It has invited him to mount a show, but in such an infelicitous, low-ceilinged gallery that he has had to abandon his usual proscenium proportions and walk-in scale. In the canvas called Para, one of his characteristically large, heavy-limbed men wears a red riding jacket and holds a hunting horn; he is bent over, bumping his head against the top edge of the painting.

title: Trying to Save, New Jersey Drove Up Pension Costs
description: In 2002, struggling to close a huge budget gap, the New Jersey Legislature hurriedly passed a bill offering thousands of state employees generous early retirement packages. Unions applauded because layoffs had been averted. Gov. James E. McGreevey claimed the state would save millions by cutting its payroll.

title: Many Arctic Plants Have Adjusted to Big Climate Changes, Study Finds
description: Many Arctic plant species have readily adjusted to big climate changes, repeatedly recolonizing the rugged islands of the remote Svalbard archipelago off Norways coast through 20,000 years of warm and cool spells since the frigid peak of the last ice age, researchers report in todays issue of the journal Science.

title: Art in Review
description: PETER FISCHLI

title: Eating Beyond Sichuan
description: TWENTY years ago, American perceptions of Asian food could be summed up in one word: Chinese. Since then, we have developed appetites for Korean, Japanese, Thai and Vietnamese fare. Yet while the quality of the restaurants that serve these cuisines, particularly Japanese, has soared in America, Chinese restaurants have stalled. For American diners, the Chinese restaurant experience is the same tired routine  unimaginative dishes served amid dated, pseudo-imperial dcor  that weve known for years.

title: Part Owners of Curlin Charged With Defrauding Clients
description: Two of the owners of the Preakness champion Curlin were indicted yesterday by a federal grand jury on a charge that they conspired to defraud their clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: In the Venture Capital World, a Helping Hand for Women and Minorities
description: THE chief executive of the Center for Venture Education offers a dismal assessment when it comes to the organizations track record for developing and training minorities and women as venture capitalists.

title: Giuliani Cites Reagan, Not Bush, as Model for Strong Leadership
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has largely steered clear of criticizing President Bush as he campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination, took an indirect swipe at the president on Thursday, suggesting that Mr. Bush was failing to provide strong leadership.

title: Anglican Demand for Change Is Rebuffed by Episcopalians
description: The executive council of the Episcopal Church announced yesterday that it would not comply with demands from leaders of the global Anglican Communion to retract the churchs liberal position on homosexuality and create alternative supervision for disaffected conservative Episcopalians.

title: Thomas the Tank Engine Toys Recalled Because of Lead Paint
description: The toy maker RC2 Corporation pulled a number of its Thomas & Friends trains and accessory parts off the shelves yesterday after learning that the red and yellow paint used to decorate more than 1.5 million of the toys contained lead.

title: Ireland: Prime Minister Wins Third Term
description: Bertie Ahern secured his re-election as prime minister for a third term, winning parliamentary support for a broadly based coalition that he said would ensure stable government for the next five years. The re-election, analysts say, was a personal and political triumph for Mr. Ahern, who, in deal-making since national elections on May 24, allied his centrist Fianna Fail party with legislators from both the left-leaning Green Party and the right-of-center Progressive Democrats. For the first time, the Green Party will get cabinet posts in an Irish government. The Progressive Democrats, who governed with Fianna Fail for the last 10 years, will have a much reduced role in the new coalition, having lost seats in the national election.

title: Giants Jacobs Hopes Barbers Shoes Are a Comfortable Fit
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 14  Brandon Jacobs is eager to fill the large void left by Tiki Barbers retirement.

title: McCartney, Almost Within Touching Distance
description: I love you, Paul, someone shouted, halfway through Paul McCartneys unadvertised set at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. Well, more than one: A lot of people were shouting that. They couldnt help themselves. He was right in front of them.

title: Subprime Problems Hit Both Goldman and Bear Stearns
description: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market took its toll on two Wall Street investment banks today, as second-quarter profit at Bear Stearns dropped 33 percent and Goldman Sachs squeezed out a modest 1 percent rise in profit.

title: Delay Denied, Libby Is Seen as Weeks From Prison
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  I. Lewis Libby Jr., once one of the most powerful men in government, was escorted by federal marshals out a side door in a federal courtroom here Thursday for processing after a judge issued a final ruling that he would have to begin serving his 30-month prison sentence shortly, even before his appeals were exhausted.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) NANCY DREW, DETECTIVE (1938) The latest version of the famous girl detective may be released in theaters today, but Emma Roberts wont be the first to play the young crime solver. Turner Classic Movies runs a minimarathon tonight of films starring Bonita Granville, above at center, as Nancy Drew. In the first installment theres a whole lot of kidnapping going on when an elderly woman who was supposed to deliver a check to Nancys father disappears. Nancy solves the campy caper, but only after she and her best friend are, of course, kidnapped themselves. The tribute continues at 9:15 p.m. with Nancy Drew ... Reporter (1939). At 10:30 Nancy comes to the aid of a family friend who is accused of murder in Nancy Drew ... Trouble Shooter (1939), followed at 11:45 by Nancy Drew and the Hidden Staircase (1939).

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: A Man Would Lose His Land While Another Would Benefit
description: BANDON, Ore.  Many here praise Mike Keiser because his Bandon Dunes Golf Resort created 325 full-time jobs in an area where work has been scarce since 1980. But Scott Cook says Mr. Keiser is going too far.

title: Lawsuit Seeks to Break Deal Over Use of Randalls I.
description: East Harlem residents are trying to block a deal that gives a group of 20 Manhattan private schools exclusive rights to use two-thirds of the sports fields on Randalls Island during after-school hours, according to a lawsuit filed yesterday.

title: A Hit Shows Big Interest in Racy Material  and Obama
description: An amateur video now circulating on the Web, I Got a Crush on Obama, has drawn considerable interest, with more than 55,000 hits on YouTube. It was originally posted on www.barelypolitical.com

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The State of the Art column in Business Day yesterday, about noise-cancellation headphones, referred incorrectly to the audio cord of the Bose QuietComfort 2 headphones. It can indeed be detached, with a sharp tug. The column also misstated the name of a set of headphones from Able Planet. They are called Clear Harmony with Linx Audio, not Solitude with Linx Audio.

title: Oakmont Is Rough, and Mickelson Feels Pain
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 14  On a century-old golf course carved among rusted bridges and a roaring turnpike, Phil Mickelson stood atop one of the highest points at Oakmont Country Club and prepared for his first swing in the 107th United States Open. He tugged at the black sleeve covering his balky left wrist, and all eyes seemed trained on him. He balanced his golf ball on a white, wooden tee, and a gallery waited for impact.

title: If You Dare to Sing of Truth, You Cant Avoid Some Pain
description: Julie Wilson gave what amounted to a master class in stage presence at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening. Like Martha Graham late in her career, Ms. Wilson, 82, uses her wiry body as a lightning rod.

title: Are You Tough Enough? An Adventurers Guide to Surviving the Wilds
description: The plain metal rowboats at the Central Park Boathouse are surprisingly similar to the skiff that Bear Grylls commandeered in Alaska during an episode of Man vs. Wild, his hit series on the Discovery Channel. Except that his leaked, lacked oars and eventually sank among a pack of ice floes, forcing him to strip down to a T-shirt and swim to shore. The water was so frigid that he started hyperventilating as his pulse raced to the heart-attack zone.

title: Arrests in Egypt Point Toward a Crackdown
description: CAIRO, June 14  Heavily armed police officers woke the Said family at 2 a.m. with pounding on the front door. The parents dressed quickly as their two children drifted between sleep and fear. The police seized books, documents and computer equipment. They blindfolded the father, Abdellatif Muhammad Said, 40, and took him away.

title: Deal Updates Contracting Law, but No Progress on Campaign Finance
description: ALBANY, June 14  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders agreed on Thursday to overhaul a 1921 law that forces municipalities to hire multiple contractors on public works projects, finding consensus where two previous governors could not.

title: Who Must Pay a Co-op Assessment?
description: Q I recently bought a co-op from a sponsor who stated in writing at the closing that there were no known assessments. A few weeks later, I learned that there was, in fact, a $2,500 assessment levied a month before my closing. Since the seller is a board member, there is no way for him not to have known this. What is my recourse?

description: Players of interactive online games and the avatars, gear, spells, skills and identities they forge to represent themselves.

description: What I'm wearing now, when the invite says "island," antidote to itsy-bitsy and more.

title: Settlement Sought With Interpublic
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said Thursday that it had received a letter from federal regulators in a continuing investigation into earnings restatements by the company. The so-called Wells notice from lawyers at the Securities and Exchange Commission signals that its staff is likely to recommend civil action regarding possible S.E.C. violations.

title: Panama Leads the Rise of the Minnows
description: The United States men's soccer team did not look overly impressive in winning its first two games at the Gold Cup tournament. But the Americans rounded into form by dismantling El Salvador by 4-0 in its final group stage match on Tuesday -- a thrashing so thorough it has sown fear in distant Argentina, whose national team will face the Yanks at the Copa America tournament on June 28.

title: Suitor for Midwest Air Wins Board Seats
description: Shareholders of the Midwest Air Group elected three directors backed by a hostile suitor, AirTran Holdings, increasing pressure on Midwests board to consider AirTrans $389 million takeover offer for the airline.

title: Speedy Hire Tools Off With Finning Unit
description: Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning Internationals Hewden Tools business for 115 million pounds ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators.

title: Guilty Plea Entered in Tax Shelter Case
description: A former employee of the accounting firm Ernst & Young pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit tax fraud Thursday, a month after similar charges were filed against four current and former employees of the firm.

title: British Game Developer Signs 2 Deals
description: The founding family behind British video game developer Codemasters Software has sold its ownership stake to Balderton Capital, while Goldman Sachs has invested 50 million pounds ($100 million) in the company.

title: V.C. Firm Closes New Life Sciences Fund
description: PTV Sciences, an Austin-based venture capital firm, says it has raised $190 million for a second fund that will invest in life and materials science companies.

title: 2 Lawyers Sued by S.E.C. In Penny Stock Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit Thursday against two lawyers, one a former enforcement official for the commission, charging that they had played important roles in a penny stock fraud that cost investors at least $160,000 in 2005. It appears to be the first time the commission has sought damages from lawyers who performed legal work in such cases but did not sell stock.

title: In the Venture Capital World, a Helping Hand for Women and Minorities
description: The chief executive of the Center for Venture Education offers a dismal assessment when it comes to the organizations track record for developing and training minorities and women as venture capitalists. Our numbers are awful, the centers chief executive, Patrick Von Bargen, told The New York Times Matt Richtel. But theyre better than in the industry as a whole.

title: A New Twist on an Old Idea Gets V.C.s on Board
description: The solar thermal engine is heating up, again. Infinia, which makes a Stirling engine that can generate electricity or household heat by harvesting heat from the sun, has raised $9.5 million, the company said Thursday.

title: For His Next Act, Indian Tycoon Considers Buying Airline Stake
description: An Indian tycoon, Vijay Mallya, is pursuing another takeover deal, soon after buying a stake in a rival airline, as well as a Scottish liquor company.

title: Sebastian Vettel in, Robert Kubica out
description: Robert Kubica feels perfectly fine after that accident he had at the Canadian Grand Prix last week. But the Formula One doctors decided he should not race, for fear of the possible negative consequences to his head of another accident. He had suffered a minor concussion.

title: Universal Music Gets Britains Sanctuary
description: Troubled music group Sanctuary has accepted a takeover offer from Universal Music Group. The firm, which manages James Blunt and Sir Elton John, announced this morning that Centenary, a division of Universal, has offered to pay 20 pence a share, valuing the company at 44.5 million pounds ($87.7 million).

title: New Law Give Foreigners a Taste of Samsung I.P.O.
description: Samsung Card, a leading Korean credit card issuer and the consumer finance unit of the Samsung Group, will raise 576 billion won ($619 million) from its initial public offering after fixing the price 6.7 percent above the top of the earlier indicated range.

title: Bag Borrow or Steal Pockets $15 Million
description: Bag Borrow or Steal, which rents high-end handbags and jewelry to consumers, has bagged a $15 million venture capital round that it will use to expand into new product categories.

title: Indias Economic Boom Turns Stocks into a National Pastime
description: While Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, has offered warnings about Chinas market, Indian indexes have hit new highs, drawing in foreign investors and Wall Street banks.

title: Kicking Around the Eternal City
description: Turns out its been a pretty weird week for Rome, or at least the Rome of popular imagination. First a construction mishap cut off the water supply to a number of the citys captivating fountains, including the famous Trevi. Then, in the wee hours of Thursday, a man evidently captivated by something or other drove his Toyota Celica down the Spanish Steps.

title: Microsoft and Yahoo Deals to Come Under Scrutiny, Report Says
description: The Federal Trade Commission reportedly wants to take a look at a few online advertising acquisitions, not just Googles planned deal to acquire DoubleClick.

title: Family Seeks Assurances on Protecting Dow Integrity
description: The family that controls Dow Jones & Company has rejected a proposed plan prepared by its lawyers, asking them instead to seek stronger guarantees of editorial independence as a condition of selling the company to Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, The New York Times reported.

title: Hedge Fund Targets Sunrise Senior Living
description: A hedge fund has called for the sale of Sunrise Senior Living, citing problems with management and accounting at the large U.S. owner of assisted-living and nursing homes.

title: In Sickness and in Health
description: Two former undercover detectives, both suffering from devastating sickness, now rely on each other more than ever.

title: Space Shuttle Supplier Denies Sales Rumors
description: MacDonald Dettwiler, a Canadian firm that makes components for the Space Shuttle, has denied reports that it is in talks to sell its surveillance and space business, but that hasnt seemed to quash analysts speculation.

title: Qatar Fund Raises Sainsburys Stake to 25%
description: Delta (Two), a Qatar-backed property investment fund, raised its stake in British supermarket chain J Sainsbury to 25 percent by purchasing 732 million pounds ($1.4 billion) of stock.

title: Blackstone Bid and Lost for Archstone
description: The Blackstone Group had also bid for U.S. apartment owner Archstone-Smith Trust in the weeks before Archstone agreed to acquired by affiliates of Lehman Brothers Holdings and Tishman Speyer for more than $15 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Nymex In Talks to Sell to Larger Rivals, Report Says
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange, the worlds largest energy market, is exploring a sale to NYSE Euronext, Deutsche Borseor Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Goldman Shows Its Vulnerable to Subprime Woes
description: Goldman Sachss shares fell 3.4 percent Thursday after the giant securities firm reported that second-quarter profits were flat from a year ago. Despite the effects of the subprime mortgage slump, however, The Financial Timess Lex argued that Goldman remains the best-positioned investment bank.

title: Home Depot Unit to Get Bids from 2 Buyout Groups, Report Says
description: The auction for Home Depots supply unit may finally be heating up. Two private equity consortiums are planning to table offers of about $10 billion each for the contractor-supplies unit of the worlds largest home-improvement retailer, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Bank of America Holds Off on ABN Amro Lawsuit
description: Bank of America has postponed plans to take ABN Amro to court, preferring to wait until the Dutch Supreme Court rules on the Dutch banks sale of LaSalle Bank, its American unit, a Bank of America spokesman said on Friday.

title: Wanderlust, or a Break for Freedom?
description: Most of the local papers this morning covered the case of the 13 members of Haitis national junior soccer team who bolted during a stopover at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday evening. The case has the authorities and many in the Haitian community scratching their heads. By yesterday, all but one of the boys had returned voluntarily, and the last one, held by the authorities, was waiting to be picked up.

title: Germany Will Block Cerberus Deal for RAG
description: Germany will not let Cerberus Capital Management buy RAG, a major industrials group, even though the private equity firm is ready to pay up to 8 billion euros ($10.65 billion) for the conglomerate, a government official told Reuters on Friday.

title: Tom Hicks Wants a $400 Million Blank Check
description: Thomas O. Hicks, the owner of the Texas Rangers and a veteran of the leveraged buyout business, is seeking to raise $400 million for his blank check company, Hicks Acquisition. He is jumping into a crowded field: Nearly 100 blank check companies have held initial public offerings since August 2003, creating a small army of shell companies, each prowling for an acquisition target.

title: G.M. to Help Delphi Exit Bankruptcy, Report Says
description: General Motors and bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi are very close to a deal with the United Auto Workers union that would help the supplier emerge from bankruptcy, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

title: Blackstone Bill Could Chill Buyout Firm I.P.O.s
description: Lawmakers are throwing some rain on Blackstone Groups parade, and it is bound to worry other buyout firms that were thinking of marching after it.

title: Blackstone to Sell Atlanta Asset to Macquarie
description: The Blackstone Group agreed to sell 50 percent of an Atlanta building to Australias Macquarie Office Trust, as the buyout firm offloads assets acquired in its $39 billion takeover of Equity Office Properties Trust.

description: I may as well admit it: This item was submitted by a PR guy on behalf of his client. And since Ive admitted that, I may as well just copy and paste his note.

title: A Translucent Wire in the Sky
description: The Jewish Sabbath that begins at sundown tonight will be a particularly significant one for thousands of observant Jews in a wide swath of Manhattan. Today marks a major, southward expansion of an eruv  a symbolic boundary that allows certain actions, like carrying things or pushing a stroller, which would otherwise be forbidden under Jewish law.

title: 2008: Clintons Stock Sell-Off
description: In an attempt to clear Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons path toward the Democratic partys presidential nomination of any potential conflicts of interest, Bill and Hillary Clinton have dissolved a blind trust that once held millions of dollars of the couples assets. title: Buyout Firms Ante Up $6.1 Billion for Penn National
description: Less than a year ago, few private equity firms were willing to step up to the table and acquire casino companies, in large part because of the extra regulatory hassle that came with owning a gaming operation. But since last years deal for Harrahs Entertainment, casino buyouts are on a roll. Friday brought the latest deal: Penn National Gaming agreed Friday to be bought by Fortress Investment Group and Centerbridge Partners for about $6.1 billion in cash.

title: The Backstory on Obama-Clinton Attack Memos
description: There was an interesting behind-the-scenes drama playing out yesterday as the Clinton campaign announced that Bill and Hillary Clinton were liquidating their blind trust, converting stocks into cash.

title: American Justice, Not a Moment Too Soon
description: It seems to The Lede this morning that while there is a strong streak of procrastination in the American soul, it is generally not born of cynicism or shiftless avoidance but of a quintessential American what-me-worry optimism  that there will always be a chance to catch up again, that whenever we get to it, it wont be too late. As a people, we hate the words too late, and tend to get worked up about unfinished business and irretrievable loss  perhaps accounting for two of our national appetites these days, for historic preservation and for increasingly grandiose memorials.

title: News Ewes Can Use
description: The 7-month-old lamb that was found loose on the tough streets of the Bronx on Wednesday is on her way to a better life.

title: Patriotic Gore
description: Heres something to see. The advertisement at left, for Sister Carrie, Theodore Dreisers first novel, ran in The Times exactly 100 years ago today: June 15, 1907. The book had first been published in 1900, of course, but it was barely promoted. This later edition, issued by B.W. Dodge & Company, is the one that really took off, putting Dreiser on the map.

title: Packing Up
description: In what has very suddenly become the old New York Times building, on West 43rd Street in Manhattan, the Book Review office is on the eighth floor, worlds away from the humming, adrenalized newsrooms that occupied floors three and four. You have to look to find it. No signs guide you into the narrow hallway that leads inside. Nothing says: You are here.

title: Fortresss Shareholders Take Tax Threat in Stride
description: Is Thursdays tax bill the beginning of the end for publicly traded private equity? Judging from the action in shares of Fortress Investment Group on Friday, probably not.

title: London Journal: At Fidelio, the News Was on the Podium
description: With so much enticing music to take in here, going to the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden to see the director Jrgen Flimms production of Beethovens Fidelio, created for the Met and introduced there in 2000, did not seem a top priority. What drew me on Thursday night, though, was the chance to hear the conductor Antonio Pappano, 47, the music director of Covent Garden since 2002, who increasingly seems one of the most significant musicians of his generation.

title: Tokyo Uncovered
description: A younger, postwar creative class is reviving a culture of small, hidden counter bars  with a decidedly modern spin.

title: Inflation Soars  But Wall Steet Ignores It
description: Wall Street is relieved that inflation is under control. Consumers know it isnt.

title: Bonnaroo: Beery Blues-rock and Jazz Anarchy
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Things got bluesy, and twisted in two different ways, at two midnight Bonnaroo sets on Thursday night. One was by Clutch, a long-running, hard-touring band that has been around since 1991. Clutch played beefy, beery blues-rock, with vintage guitar riffs and growly vocals upholstered in harmonica and organ. Its the kind of band that reminds a Yankee that Bonnaroo takes place in Southern rock territory. But its not that simple. Clutchs lyrics dont leer and swagger as the sound might suggest. They are convoluted and philosophical, closer to Pearl Jam than to Ten Years After. They ponder ethics, politics, faith and the devil as the music steams along: Yes, Ill be a responsible member/of this great and blessd society./Ive come to understand the wrongful nature/of gun ownership in the age of monarchy.

title: Energy Hearing Garners Less Oomph
description: There are fewer fireworks today at Round 2 of the State Assemblys look at the citys sustainability proposal. Round 1, you may recall, could have been called Congestion Pricing and Its Discontents.

title: Bonnaroo: Destroying the Ozone?
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Part of Bonnaroos hippie aura is its nods to environmentalism. There are separate trash barrels for composting and recycling; biodiesel generators supply some power; theres a Planet Roo area with a solar-powered stage and booths for organic products and environmental groups. Leave it to a comedian to inject some realism. John Bowman, at the comedy tent, reminded his audience of the giant traffic jam that inevitably precedes the festival: cars, trucks and RVs going nowhere, idling with air conditioners on full blast. His audience roared as he declared that Bonnaroo had made its own hole in the ozone layer.

title: Dennis Publishing Is Said to Sell U.S. Titles to Quadrangle
description: The world of American laddie magazines  the publications featuring scantily clad starlets and frat-boy humor  may have a new publisher in the game. Dennis Publishing has sold its American titles to the Quadrange Group in a deal worth between $240 million and $250 million, according to The New York Posts Keith Kelly.

title: Long Island City Gets a New Library
description: Long Island City, on the waterfront at the western edge of Queens, is widely seen as the next frontier in the citys plan to remake the waterfront, with new housing developments within walking distance of the areas many transit stations. The area is still home to some of the citys largest public housing developments, and for many years, residents of the area had little access to public libraries. There were two makeshift branches of the Queens Library, shoehorned into uncomfortable spaces in the Ravenswood and Queensbridge housing projects. They were apartment-sized, the director of the Queens Library, Thomas W. Galante, told me this morning.

title: Signs of Investor Burnout in Ethanol I.P.O.s
description: The initial public offering Thursday of BioFuel Energy was described in the Red Herring as lackluster. But worse adjectives might be applied to the public debut of the ethanol maker. It cut its offering price several times in the weeks leading up to the I.P.O. It had filed to sell 9.5 million shares for between $16 and $18. It ended up selling 5.25 million shares at $10.50 each. After a bumpy first day of trading, the stock closed up a penny. And at midday Friday, they were trading at $10.37.
