title: Buried Car Unearthed in Oklahoma
description: Hundreds of onlookers gathered to watch the raising of a gold and white Plymouth Belvedere to celebrate Oklahoma's 50 years of statehood.

title: In F.T.C. Fight, Whole Foods Turns to the Web
description: As it attempts to fight an antitrust suit by the Federal Trade Commission over its proposed deal for Wild Oats Markets, Whole Foods Market has turned from the legal arena to the court of public opinion.

title: Traffic Fees and the Plains of Hesitation
description: Add yet another strange wrinkle to the imbroglio over Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit urged Albanys Big Three to carefully consider the expectation that the $500 million in federal funds promised by the mayor will actually come through. Turns out the Department of Transportation may not have the proper authority to give up the goods.

title: Hesitation, Bleached Bones and Traffic Fees
description: Add yet another strange wrinkle to the imbroglio over Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan. In a letter sent yesterday, the chairman of the House Subcommittee on Highways and Transit urged Albanys Big Three to carefully consider the expectation that the $500 million in federal funds promised by the mayor will actually come through. Turns out the Department of Transportation may not have the proper authority to give up the goods.

title: Farewell to a Vintage Home
description: This is my last working day in the old New York Times building, at 229 West 43rd Street, and since Ive spent quite a bit of time here over the last 23 years, permit me a brief departure from our usual subjects.

title: A Question of Scale
description: The Upper West Side north of 96th Street is experiencing a period of profound physical change. New luxury residential towers are rising 30 stories or more, twice the height of the 14- and 16-story buildings that have defined the neighborhood for a century. Small businesses are giving way to blocklong retail development.

title: Easy Riders (and With a Brand, Too)
description: First there was the official New York City memorabilia. Then there was the official New York City condom. Now theres the official New York City bike helmet.

title: Environmentalmania? (Part Deux)
description: An abundance of Fisking  described by Wikipedia as a detailed point-by-point criticism that highlights errors, disputes the analysis of presented facts, or highlights other problems in a statement, article or essay  was one of the original glories of the blogosphere, but the practice has fallen into disuse as an emphasis on briefer, pithier comments has blossomed. Marlo Lewis of Planet Gore is a throwback, however, and her current, very lengthy takedown of a speech by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid on energy policy is, whether one agrees with her or not, a masterpiece of the form. For those too hurried to take it all in, heres her point in a nutshell:

title: Easy Riders (and With a Brand, Too)
description: First there was the official New York City memorabilia. Then there was the official New York City condom. Now theres the official New York City bike helmet.

title: Albany Spelling Check: Marihuana?
description: When the Assembly passed a bill last week that legalized the medical use of marihuana, copy editors across the state did a double-take. Shouldnt that be spelled with a J?

title: Toasting Blackstones Billion-Dollar Grandpa
description: Though the big news for the Blackstone Group on Thursday was a Senate bill that seemed to take aim at the private equity firms initial public offering, Stephen A. Schwarzman had other things on his mind. Chief among them: He had just become a first-time grandfather  two times over.

title: Rain Doesnt Soak Spirits at Le Mans
description: Packed train stations and gridlock on every street are proof enough that were less than one day away from the worlds greatest 24 hour auto race.

title: Rwanda, Past and Present
description: In 1994, Rwanda was the scene of killings at a rate of 10,000 people per day, and bludgeoned bodies literally lined the streets. When the Rwandan Patriotic Front (the current government of Rwanda) took over, they found dead people, moribund services, crumbled houses, and decimated hospitals. Latrines and lakes were stuffed with bodies, and churches were filled by the bodies of thousands of parishioners whose killings were facilitated by their own ministers. There was no government to speak of.

title: War at Home: The Battleground of Summer
description: A coalition of antiwar groups is looking to make it a long, uncomfortable summer for 40 Republican members of Congress who are opposed to setting a timeline to end the war in Iraq.

title: The Big Move
description: After 94 years on West 43rd Street, The Times moved south to its new home on Eighth Avenue.

title: A Note to Readers
description: Byron Calames tenure as the public editor ended on May 6 with the publication of his final column.

title: Paging Carl Pavano, Please Move Your Car
description: One of the things Im sure will be different about the new Yankee Stadium is the media parking. Right now, were in the same lot as the players, and the beat writers park in the next row. Its a sweet deal, and it probably wont last.

title: London Journal: An Americans View of a British View of America
description: I am writing this on my laptop, on a sunny, nicely breezy morning in London, sitting on a bench in Russell Square in the Bloomsbury section of town. My nifty guidebook tells me that this is where T.S. Eliot, dubbed the Pope of Russell Square, used to come to escape his emotionally troubled first wife when he was an editor and, later, the director of the Faber & Faber publishing house. There are students from the nearby University of London sitting on the lawn, reading and writing.

title: Bill Clinton on Congestion Pricing
description: Is there anyone at this point who hasnt weighed in on Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to impose weekday traffic fees in Manhattan? Former President Bill Clinton mentioned Mr. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal today during the annual luncheon of the National Partnership for Women and Families in Washington. Mr. Clinton did not explicitly endorse or criticize the plan, but he suggested that traffic fees would be slightly regressive for lower-income working people that have no option but to drive. He focused on the potential for creating jobs by making buildings more environmentally friendly.

title: Bill Clinton on Congestion Pricing
description: Is there anyone at this point who hasnt weighed in on Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to impose weekday traffic fees in Manhattan?

title: A Changing Metropolis
description: Times reporter Sewell Chan introduces his new project, City Room, a blog about the New York City experience.

title: Learning Spanish With Jose Reyes (Yankee Stadium Edition)
description: One of my favorite things about Shea Stadium, and admittedly there arent that many, is that 30-second segment featuring Jose Reyes and his Spanish Academy. With the Mets on a 10-game road trip, I havent gotten my fix recently, so I asked Reyes for a Spanish word today.

title: Win a Trip: Meeting Great Leaders
description: Leana Wen, who's traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, reports on her visits with Rwanda's president and Dr. Paul Farmer.

title: The Handwriting on the Road
description: The artist Eve S. Mosher, who is drawing a chalk line along 70 miles of New York coastal neighborhoods, at work. Videography by Justin Lange.

title: Turning On the Faucet of Emotion
description: Here I stand, weighted down in the sand again, about to enter another foreign territory. Im marching into a world I have never seen, a world where I am the intruder. Instead of carrying a 40-pound rucksack, I wear a 40-pound aluminum tank. Rather than a crooked Kevlar, I wear a tight neoprene hood. My desert uniform is buried; on this journey I wear a 14-millimeter wetsuit. On my feet I wear booties and soon will don fins. My hands are gloved. Here, a regulator allows me to survive, rather than a protective gas mask. The temperature is 52 degrees, not 118. I carry a Riffe spear gun instead of an M16. I have a compass, a watch, and a plan in case I lose my buddy. My stomach is in knots, but from excitement instead of fear. We are on an underwater hunt.

title: Bonnaroo: Two Well-Traveled Guitarists
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Early Friday afternoon at Bonnaroo brought two well-traveled guitarists playing to grab nonbelievers. James (Blood) Ulmer led a jazz-rock power trio in a set that fell into a pattern: he sang blues songs alternating with instrumentals. The blues were political and personal complaints, including denunciations of the war, a song about Hurricane Katrina and a song about money troubles that announced, I aint broke but Im badly bent. And the instrumentals veered toward the harmolodic zigzags of Ornette Coleman: setting out melodies at willful, shifty speeds, improvising over a vamp. In both blues and instrumentals, he loosed a new idea at each break: searing sustained lines, phrases that scurried into different keys, bent and wah-wahed notes, crunched funk chords. Each idea could have been the seed of a whole solo, but Mr. Ulmer kept coming up with more.

title: Bonnaroo: Restless, Free and Easy
description: He managed to make make his standard stage patter work with a very different audience, which means its either universal or downright generic: Bonnaroo is all about being free and easy, he announced, leading into his twangy, restless Free and Easy (Down the Road I Go).

title: Spark From Reyes Overcomes Heat From Clemens
description: Their symbolic subway cars were headed in opposite directions. The Yankees were the hottest team in the majors, the Mets the coldest. The Bronx was up, Queens was down and, last night, both batteries were on.

title: Broad Effort to Resurrect Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  At 4:30 p.m. on June 7, the Roman Catholic Church defied the sponsors of a comprehensive immigration bill and urged the Senate not to move toward final passage of the measure without significant changes.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report on theater news in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday included incorrect information from the Godlight Theater Company about its plans to present a stage adaptation of Kurt Vonneguts Slaughterhouse-Five at 59E59 Theaters. It might be presented there this winter or next spring; it is not scheduled for September.

title: Work Done on Space Station Computers
description: Russian astronauts and engineers may have corrected a problem yesterday that caused computers aboard the International Space Station to crash and raised the possibility that the station might have to be evacuated.

title: An Advocate Lends a Hand as Social Justice Goals Unify Faiths
description: CHICAGO

title: Ritual Fence Set for Jews in Manhattan Is Extended
description: Jews living in a large area of Manhattan who regularly observe the Sabbath will have a much easier time of it today. An eruv, a line that delineates the concept of domestic space for Orthodox Jews and dictates where they may carry items on the day of rest, has been extended from Midtown to Houston Street.

title: Jeter Lets Chance to Know Whats Coming Sail On By
description: Derek Jeter had a chance for some authentic, inside information about how another major league team planned to pitch him. But Jeter, the Yankees shortstop, refused to listen yesterday.

title: Canada: Report Critical of Broken Mounties
description: The head of an investigation into the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, David A. Brown, said in a report that the forces management and operations structure was horribly broken. Mr. Brown, the former head of the Ontario Securities Commission, was asked by the government to examine how the force had handled allegations that money was misspent by administrators of the pension and insurance fund. He concluded that officers who raised questions had been punished, that those responsible were not held to account and that an ostensibly independent investigation by Ottawas municipal police force, which found no wrongdoing, was effectively guided by the Mounties. He was particularly critical of the autocratic leadership style of the Mounties former commissioner, Giuliano Zaccardelli. Mr. Zaccardelli resigned this year after retracting some of his parliamentary testimony about the case of Maher Arar, the Canadian citizen deported to Syria by the United States after the Mounties provided erroneous information suggesting that he was a terrorism suspect.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Clarkson Cancels Tour

title: R. F. Dial, 62, Dies; Convict Fled With Wardens Wife
description: Randolph F. Dial, an artist and confessed hit man who fled a life sentence for murder to spend nearly 11 years on the run with a deputy wardens wife, died Wednesday in the infirmary of the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in McAlester. He was 62.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about Accordionology, a festival this weekend at Barbs in Park Slope, Brooklyn, misidentified the bass player shown in the accompanying picture. He is Trevor Dunn, not Drew Gress. The entry also misidentified the title of the new album by Will Holshouser, who is playing in the festival. It is Singing to a Bee, not Reed Song, which was an earlier recording.

title: China: Workers Told to Wear T-Shirts to Save Energy
description: In an effort to conserve energy, the government has urged office workers to abandon business suits in favor of T-shirts and other informal wear. The message was delivered in a week when air-conditioning in many government offices was turned off and inspectors sent to hotels and office buildings in Beijing to enforce new temperature guidelines.

title: Tax Gap Puts Private Equity Firms on Hot Seat
description: This week, Goldman Sachs, Wall Streets most profitable firm, reported that it earned about $3.4 billion for the second quarter. As always, it set aside a big chunk of money  $1.1 billion, or about 32 percent  to pay corporate income taxes on its healthy profits.

title: N.B.A. Finals Have Lowest Viewership
description: The San Antonio Spurs sweep of the Cleveland Cavaliers produced the N.B.A.s least-viewed championship, with an average of 9.2 million viewers, as measured by Nielsen Media Research. The previous low, almost 9.9 million, was in 2003 when the Spurs defeated the Nets.

title: Pearson Is Said to Seek a Partner for a Takeover of Dow Jones
description: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, is exploring a rival takeover offer for Dow Jones & Company, and has discussed a joint bid with General Electric and the Hearst Corporation, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: Out Amid the Cold Night Air the Devil Dares to Tread
description: Wednesday evening was so unseasonably cold that it felt as if hell had frozen over Central Park during the Metropolitan Operas concert performance of Gounods Faust, which opened its annual free summer series.

title: Spurs Give Cavaliers, and Others, a Look at How Its Done
description: The marketing slogans that accompanied LeBron James and the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first N.B.A. finals lay like discarded signposts the day after the Cavaliers quick capitulation to the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Pakistani Judges Lawyers Are Confident of Winning His Reinstatement
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 14  Lawyers representing the suspended chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, in Supreme Court hearings said in an interview this week that they were confident that they could win the case and secure his reinstatement by the end of the month.

title: The Matriarch of Penticton Against the World
description: The World Wide Bridge Contest, in which the same deals are played at bridge clubs around the world, began 21 years ago. This years events were played on June 1 and 2, with players in Nepal participating for the first time.

title: In the Classroom, a New Focus on Quieting the Mind
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 12  The lesson began with the striking of a Tibetan singing bowl to induce mindful awareness.

title: Building a TV Station and a Platform for Leftists
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: Video Game Arrives in the Flesh (Lots of It)
description: There was a time when movies like DOA: Dead or Alive lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses. But the multiplex is a beast that needs constant feeding, and sometimes the meal has to be cheese.

title: Home on the Rainforest
description: DEEP within Madagascar, more than 1,300 square miles of rainforest continue to breathe in carbon dioxide and breathe out oxygen every day, helping to keep the planet cool. That may not seem like a big achievement for a bunch of trees, but elsewhere around the world tropical forests like this one are being felled to make way for timber and mining operations, cattle ranches and, increasingly, sugar and palm oil plantations to fuel the worlds growing thirst for ethanol.

title: Gileads Drug Is Approved to Treat a Rare Disease
description: Gilead Sciences won approval yesterday for a new drug to treat a life-threatening lung disease, stealing a march on another company, Encysive Pharmaceuticals, which learned yesterday that its similar drug would not be approved yet.

title: On His First Visit to Fenway, Bonds Has Some Kind Words
description: BOSTON, June 15  Shortly before Barry Bonds of the Giants played his first game at Fenway Park on Friday night, he answered many questions with platitudes. But he responded to one directly and forcefully.

title: A Fixture in the Heart of Harlem Faces Another Fight
description: The sounds of jazz in the 1970s slowly gave way to the hip-hop that now blasts from cars rolling down 125th Street in Harlem. The street itself has been transformed, as chain stores have moved into the area they long shunned. Through it all, Sikhulu Shange, 65, has been a constant, a looming presence behind the register of his music store, the Record Shack.

title: At Camp, Conquering Fears and Hearing Cheers
description: CLARYVILLE, N.Y., June 13  As her classmates pulled on a rope to raise her above the forest floor in the giant swing, Tanisha Polanco, 15, announced that she needed a hug. And that she wanted to get down. And that she was going to cry.

title: Spiritual Guidance and Smooth Sailing for the Fire Dept.
description: Three stout red ships muscled north along the East River. They seemed to grow larger against the backdrop of Governors Island as they approached Pier 17.

title: Singing! Dancing! Tragedy! Comedy! Resurrecting a 1600s Operatic Spectacle
description: BOSTON, June 14  Baroque opera was the Busby Berkeley extravaganza of its day. It focused on spectacle and pageantry, and with composers like Jean-Baptiste Lully cranking out an opera a year, it was eminently disposable.

title: Publisher of Mens Magazines Is Sold to Private Equity Fund
description: Dennis Publishing, the magazine company behind three of the most successful publications aimed at young men in the United States  Maxim, Stuff and Blender  was acquired for an undisclosed price by the private equity fund, Quadrangle Capital Partners II, Quadrangle said yesterday.

title: An Artists Look Back at Her Life, Now Ended
description: It has become almost obligatory among those attending memorial services to comment that the departed one seems somehow so present, as if he or she were there looking on, enjoying, even participating. But this observation rarely has the lapel-grabbing force it acquires in Behind the Lid, a remarkable environmental theater piece by the performance artist Lee Nagrin and the puppeteer Basil Twist.

title: How Great Leaders Juggle Ideas
description: WHEN we look for ways to improve our life at work, how we can make better decisions, for example, or try to figure out the next step in our career, invariably one thing we do is look at what great leaders have done. This is why books like Straight From the Gut, by John F. Welch Jr., and those by Lee A. Iacocca sell so well.

title: As Lower Manhattan Recovers, Many Question Use of Subsidies
description: JPMorgan Chases announcement on Thursday that it would build a $2 billion investment banking headquarters downtown and move 7,000 employees there was only the latest illustration of how far Lower Manhattan has come since the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Not Everyone Is in the Red on Trade With China
description: The great Chinese export machine is producing rising trade surpluses with the United States and soaring surpluses with Europe. But when it comes to the rest of the world, it is running a trade deficit.

title: Hazardous Teenage Years (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Slashing and Warming
description: Buried in the final communiqu issued at the recent Group of 8 summit in Germany was an important and overdue pledge to help poorer nations reduce the global warming emissions caused by the slashing and burning of their tropical forests.

title: In Iraq, Gates Says Progress Toward Peace Is Lagging
description: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq, June 15  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived here late on Friday bluntly expressing disappointment with the pace of political reconciliation under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, even as the final units of the American troop increase were moving into position and bombings threatened to inspire more sectarian violence.

title: On West Bank, a Show of Force by Fatah
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 15  The preacher at the main mosque here in the Palestinian Authoritys administrative capital in the West Bank called for reconciliation during Friday Prayer, a day after Hamas violently seized control of Gaza.

title: Facing Sanction, Duke Prosecutor Plans to Resign
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 15 Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, announced Friday that he would resign, as he faces disciplinary charges for his handling of a sexual assault prosecution against three former Duke University lacrosse players who were later declared innocent.

title: Russia Says It Opened Criminal Inquiry Into British Espionage
description: MOSCOW, June 15  Russias intelligence service said Friday that it had opened a criminal investigation into British espionage here in Russia, based on statements and undisclosed evidence provided by a businessman who is accused of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer and a Kremlin critic.

title: Injured Mickelsons Chances of Making Cut Were Fat or Slim
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15  The caddie Jim Mackay, who is known as Bones, is paid to feed numbers into the golfing machine that is Phil Mickelson. Yards to the green, feet to the pin; those are the figures that Mackay is used to calculating.

title: Martin J. Weber, 102, Dies; Innovator in Graphic Techniques
description: Martin J. Weber, a graphic artist, typographer and art director who invented a widely adopted technique that gave two-dimensional images the illusion of appearing in three dimensions, died last Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 102.

title: A 50-Year-Old Time Capsule Sees Daylight, but Will It Start?
description: A muddy, rusty 1957 Plymouth Belvedere was lifted out of the Oklahoma earth yesterday, 50 years after the citizens of Tulsa deposited the coupe in an underground vault near the county courthouse to commemorate the states 50th anniversary.

title: Against Former Teammate, Delgado Again Struggles to Produce for Mets
description: Carlos Delgado of the Mets patiently listened to the statistics, heard that he had a .324 average against Roger Clemens, then pushed the numbers aside and called them meaningless.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about the philosopher Richard Rorty misidentified the source of the quotation, There is no basis for deciding what counts as knowledge and truth other than what ones peers will let one get away with in the open exchange of claims, counterclaims and reasons. It was from Charles Guignon and David R. Hiley in the introduction to the book Richard Rorty, which they edited; it was not from Mr. Rorty.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on May 25 about the influence of the war in Iraq on this years graduating class at the United States Military Academy referred incorrectly to Brig. Gen. William B. Kunzig Jr. of Minneapolis, an alumnus who was on campus for the annual alumni review. General Kunzig, 97, class of 1932, was the oldest living graduate at the ceremony, not the oldest living graduate of West Point. (According to the academy, that title belongs to Benjamin Whitehouse, 104, a retired colonel from Brewster, Mass., who graduated in 1927.)

title: Prosecutor in Duke Case Is Disbarred for Ethics Breaches
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 16  In a case that has brought one surprise after another, a disciplinary hearing panel found Michael B. Nifong, the Durham County district attorney, guilty today of ethical violations while pressing a false accusation of sexual assault against three former Duke University lacrosse players. The panel then ruled that Mr. Nifong should be disbarred.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Amy Sullivan, a former executive director of the Eugene ONeill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misstated the history of the National Theater Institute, a program of the center, and referred incorrectly to it. The institute was founded in 1970, more than 30 years before Ms. Sullivan became executive director at the center. She did not create it, and it is not a summer program. She added a summer session.

title: A Program to Match the Personality of Its Conductor
description: About to Be would have made a good title for the New York Philharmonic concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday. Rossinis Overture to Semiramide finds an Italian local-boy-made-good at the beginning of his wider European career. Schuberts Third Symphony places a Viennese teenager somewhere between his already prolific boyhood and a short but even more prolific adult life. Dvoraks Fifth Symphony marks the onset of the Czech composers career-making publishing deal with the Simrock company and the support of Brahms that made it possible.

title: Indonesia Reports the Arrest of a 2nd Top Terrorism Suspect
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15  The leader of the Southeast Asia terrorist network Jemaah Islamiyah was seized last weekend during raids by Indonesias antiterrorism force, the police said at a news conference on Friday.

title: Another Justice Dept. Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Another Justice Department official involved in last years dismissals of federal prosecutors is resigning, department officials said on Friday.

title: Flip Side of the Dream
description: Camden, N.J.

title: Father and Son Try Sparing the Rod
description: The sun had begun to set as I stood at the edge of my favorite golf course pond. The slanting rays were warming the northern shore, giving the bass a comfortable place to bask. A foursome was teeing off in the distance, but we were well out of sight, and this was a good thing. Im sure my party of two would have provided quite a distraction to any unsuspecting golfer. Its odd enough to see someone fishing a water hazard. But instead of fly rods, we wielded what looked like car-vacs with stubby plastic poles attached.

title: Sleuth Expands the Case File
description: FOR nearly a year until this week, Sharesleuth, the investigative business Web site financed by the billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban, had published articles about just two companies. But in what may signal a departure, Sharesleuth has published an article about a third company: the Orthopedic Development Corporation, which is marketing a new spinal implant procedure (sharesleuth.com).

title: Second Sunni Mosque Is Blown Up in Basra
description: BAGHDAD, June 16  Hooded gunmen clad in black blew up another Sunni mosque in the southern city of Basra today after ordering the police officers at the mosque to flee, and despite a curfew imposed by Iraqs central government, witnesses and security officials said.

title: Pests That Bite and Slither? Call Snake Wranglers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14  For Sam the Weimaraner, things had been quite grave. A rattlesnake bite to the snout  the unhappy result of flower bed pursuit  had left him unconscious, lying in his owners garage in Topanga Canyon, an IV dangling from his paw.

title: Blast Destroys Sunni Mosque in Iraq, Raising Fears of Reprisals
description: BAGHDAD, June 15  A powerful explosion that reduced a large Sunni Arab mosque to rubble near the southern city of Basra on Friday morning appeared to signal that the cycle of revenge violence, following the bombing of a sacred Shiite shrine in Samarra on Wednesday, has not entirely unfolded.

title: House Passes Security Bill That President Opposes
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The House on Friday approved the spending of $37.4 billion next year by the Department of Homeland Security, calling for significantly more spending than proposed by the Bush administration, including hundreds of millions in extra state and local antiterrorism grants.

title: Fatah Seizes Public Buildings in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, June 16  The Fatah faction, crushed in Gaza, moved to consolidate control over the West Bank today, seizing public buildings, including the Parliament, and preparing to swear in a new government that did not include its rival, Hamas.

title: An End to Pants-Grabbing Armrests: 2010, Railroads Say
description: Come 2010, the Long Island Rail Road will be safe for trousers again.

title: Course Is Hard, No Matter How You Cut It
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15  It was the closest thing to a day of misspent golf, a day when the players waded through weeds and crept behind bunkers that looked like benches.

title: In Aftermath of Gaza Battle, Grim Realities
description: GAZA, June 15  This packed, impoverished coastal strip had a postrevolutionary feel on Friday: the green flag of Hamas, victor over Fatah in what amounted to a five-day civil war, flew over public buildings where once the multicolored Palestinian one had been.

title: Mother Charged After Sons 4 A.M. Walk
description: FAIRVIEW, N.J., June 15  Al Carbone, a Bergen County cabdriver, was nearing the end of his shift about 4 a.m. Friday when a man approached him in the parking lot of the A.&P. here and told him that two children were wandering in front of the supermarket.

title: Of London and Paris (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 7:15 P.M. (HBO) THE MUSIC IN ME: A FAMILY SPECIAL A bevy of young musicians from around the country, two of whom are pictured above, demonstrate the various cultural traditions theyre carrying on. The six featured in this special include an 11-year-old tin-whistle player, a 10-year-old mariachi singer and guitar player, and an 11-year-old classical composer. And two young girls discuss how playing the piano helped them survive cancer.

title: Fuel Prices Aside, Inflation Is Tame
description: A leap in gasoline prices pushed the overall rate of inflation higher last month, government data showed today, but consumer prices nationwide generally appear to be increasing at a consistently slower rate.

title: Hoofers in Search of Heroes
description: The DancemOpolitan dance cabaret series at Joes Pub at the Public Theater are essentially gatherings of the downtown dance clan, performers and their friends.

title: Man Is Guilty of Manslaughter in 06 Stabbing of Neighbor
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 15  A Connecticut man pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter here on Friday in the stabbing death last summer of his Fairfield neighbor who he mistakenly believed had molested his 2-year-old daughter.

title: The Scarlet Letter
description: By this time next week, the left-for-dead Senate immigration bill should be up off the slab, lurching toward a final vote. It almost died when Republicans tried to weigh it down with too many harsh amendments. But now its coming back, thanks to some late attention from President Bush, a rush to repackage it as a super-heavy-duty enforcement measure  with $4.4 billion to be thrown at the border right away, as a good-faith gesture to the anti-amnesty crowd  and a deal to limit the amendments from both parties to only a couple dozen.

title: Shunned by Bloomberg, Newsman Is a Gadfly in Exile
description: As the publisher of a small independent newspaper, Rafael Martnez Alequin has tormented generations of politicians, raising hackles with pointed  some say pointless  questions, often about the interplay of race and class in the city.

title: Considering the Crime, Not the Suspect
description: Because of the wiring of his brain, Ozem Goldwire must account for every minute in an hour. Asked what happened on the day he came home from work in January 2006 and found his sister dead in bed, Mr. Goldwire reports that his alarm went off at 5 a.m., and he took the B-20 bus at 6:18. I got to work at 7:04, he says, and so his narrative spools, one precise moment after the next, until he gets off the bus at night and opens the door to his house in Brooklyn.

title: Switzerland: Big Rail Tunnel Opens
description: Switzerland opened the 21.5-mile Ltschberg Tunnel beneath the Alps, the worlds longest railway land tunnel and part of the countrys plan to shift freight traffic off the roads and speed up passenger transportation. It joins Frutigen near the capital, Bern, in the north with Raron in the Rhne Valley to the south, cutting travel time for trains crossing from Germany to Italy by about 90 minutes and bringing skiers to resorts like Zermatt more quickly.

title: Colonial Roots Have Spread Worldwide
description: Few names are as evocative of American history as that of Ethan Allen and his Green Mountain Boys. But today Ethan Allen, the furniture and home furnishings company based in Danbury, Conn., is thoroughly international. Its chief executive is Farooq Kathwari, 62, who was born in Kashmir. Its manufacturing base is increasingly international as are its design motifs. Mr. Kathwari recently discussed the international influence. Following are excerpts:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about two lawyers indicted in Kentucky on federal charges of conspiring to defraud clients in a $200 million lawsuit settlement with the maker of the diet drug fen-phen omitted the name of a third lawyer who was indicted. Melbourne Mills Jr. was also charged  but unlike the other two, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr. and William J. Gallion, he was not a part-owner of the Preakness champion Curlin. (Unaware of the sports article, the editors of the National Briefing column ran another one that omitted the lawyers horse-owning backgrounds.)

title: In the Underworld, Looking for Beams of Blessed Light
description: In her latest program Neta Pulvermacher reveals not just a trilogy of dances, but also three sides of the choreographer herself, linked by madcap visions of heaven and hell. In a sense her dancers, performing on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam, embody spirits, somberly or comically trapped in underworld landscapes, where even Elvis Presley makes an appearance. But it is the concluding Air, in which she drops the veneer of storytelling, that is the most stirring.

title: Slumping Confidence in Bonds Tied to Subprime Mortgages
description: A series of indexes that gauge investor confidence in subprime mortgage bonds dropped sharply this week and neared the pessimistic levels that they last sank to in late February when several large lenders collapsed.

title: Homeless in New York (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Nomination Feud Redraws Battle Lines in Trenton
description: TRENTON, June 15  Even considering the odd manner in which politics are played in New Jersey, where feuding party colleagues shut down state government and Senate candidates avoid unpopular vice presidents, this weeks dispute over Gov. Jon S. Corzines nominee for chief justice of the State Supreme Court was especially curious.

title: Speedy Reyes and Gomz Help Fuel a Stellar Outing by Prez
description: In the old days, players did not get their own rooms on road trips. They shared them, leading one to wonder what sort of high jinks would ensue if three of the Mets most high-strung players  Jos Reyes, Carlos Gmez and Oliver Prez  were roommates.

title: For the Mets, C Is for Cold Bats and L Is for Lineup Change
description: Manager Willie Randolph opened his pregame interview session with a response straight out of Sesame Street. Asked why Carlos Beltrn was moved up to hit second last night, Randolph said, His name starts with a B and its the second letter in the alphabet. How do you like that?

title: Prescription for Pain
description: A dozen states are already bucking the federal government and giving the chronically ill access to medical marijuana. Now residents of New York and Connecticut who are ill or dying may soon have that chance to find relief from their pain or nausea.

title: With a Few Exceptions, the Advice Remains: Dont Touch That Nest Egg
description: Conventional wisdom says not to pull money out of retirement accounts except for actual retirement. Most Americans have enough difficulty building up a nest egg, and cracking it prematurely could mean living on cat food (slang for Social Security) later.

title: It Might Pay to Follow Your Bliss
description: REMEMBER the fable about the ant and the grasshopper? The ant works hard all summer, socking away provisions for the winter; the grasshopper frolics away each day. The ant warns the grasshopper that hes being hedonistic and short-sighted. The grasshopper ignores the ant, and continues on his merry way  only to perish when winter sets in.

title: The Suicide Anarchists (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: He Wants to Make It Here, Again
description: Roger Clemens could have been in Boston, in a matchup for the aged, going after Barry Bonds and the Giants with his best friend of his athletic old age, the pitch he calls Mr. Splitty. He could have had a pleasant, commuter-friendly night in Houston after facing the Mariners. But who more than Clemens knows that there is no fiercer and famous interleague baseball than the version played in New York, New York?

title: Sifting the Palestinian Rubble (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans Online Sift for Clues in the Sopranos Finale
description: Nearly a week after the HBO series The Sopranos itself went to black forever, the debate about what its final scene  in which the screen goes black for 10 seconds as Tony Soprano and members of his family eat in a diner  might really mean has raged on, especially on blogs. Online, fans have either been railing about the cop-out of the ending or trying to fill in the blanks of the final episode themselves (or, often, both).

title: Polished and Upbeat, Romney Tries to Connect
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  Mitt Romney loves the word great. As in, Have a great day, Things are going great, Im feeling great. Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, also looks great, sounds great and smells great, like shaving cream. Everyone who asks him something gets a Thanks, great question.

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about Justin Strzelczyk, a former National Football League player who was found post-mortem to have had early signs of brain damage that experts said was most likely caused by football concussions, misidentified the medical institution where Bennet Omalu, the doctor who made the diagnosis, is a clinical instructor of neuropathology. It is the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, not the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.

title: The Handwriting on the Road: An Artist Draws the Flood Line
description: In landscape drawing, lines are usually representations of the contours of the observed world: a horizon, a mountain ridge, a tendril. But a line that the artist Eve S. Mosher began drawing last month is striving for a different kind of effect. To begin with, it is not of the landscape, exactly. It is on it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on June 9 about preparations for President Bushs visit to Albania misstated the position of Bernard Kouchner, the new foreign minister of France, before the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003. Although he advocated removing Saddam Hussein from power with pressure from Europe, the United States and other countries through the United Nations, backed by a continuing military buildup, he did not support the war.

title: A New Kind of Politics Closely Resembles the Old
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Senator Barack Obama often offers a crisp sales pitch to voters, imploring them to be part of something new, different and hopeful. If you want a new kind of politics, he says, its time to turn the page.

title: Cost of Gas and Food Rose Sharply Last Month
description: Americans felt the pinch of higher gas prices and eroding wages last month, even as an important gauge of inflation drifted lower, government figures showed yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Eyes Antiterror Rules for Small Jets and Boats
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Acknowledging that the nation remains too vulnerable to terrorist attack by small planes and recreational boats, the Department of Homeland Security is considering new requirements to allow authorities to identify operators and passengers in millions of these vehicles as they ply the coasts and skies.

title: Podiums of London Welcome Newcomers
description: LONDON, June 15  The three leading orchestras of this major music capital are now going through changes in artistic leadership. All the newcomers have been in action this week. Its as if London had deliberately planned a showcase of the new guard for the benefit of those here for the reopening of the Royal Festival Hall.

title: Insurers Suspend the Marketing of Some Medicare Plans
description: The UnitedHealth Group, Humana and five other insurers are suspending the marketing of some federal government health plans after complaints that unscrupulous agents were duping elderly Americans into buying the coverage.

title: Globalization in Every Loaf
description: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.  In a glassed-off area in the headquarters of Sara Lee, a handful of specialists study computer screens and flat-screen televisions beaming the latest weather reports and commodity prices. They are sourcing ingredients from all over the world to make Sara Lees assortment of breads, deli meats and microwaveable desserts.

title: Well, He Did Get an A on the Eating Part
description: I HUNKERED over a six-burner commercial stove, my pulse pounding and my hands dripping with extra virgin olive oil. It was half past noon on an otherwise auspicious Sunday inside a 12th-floor teaching kitchen at the Institute of Culinary Education in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. Eight chicken breasts marinated in fresh garlic and herbs were sizzling on a cast iron grill pan atop the stove  and I was feeling the heat.

title: Discovering New Truths in Themes Developed Long Ago
description: In its Beethoven Quartets in Context concerts at Carnegie Hall, the Emerson String Quartet has raised the bar for ensembles interested in thematic programming by taking a commonplace idea  presenting the Beethoven quartets with works by other composers  and turning it into a revelatory series. To say that the other composers influenced Beethoven or were influenced by him isnt saying much when the earlier composers are Bach, Mozart and Haydn, and the successors are anyone who composed after him. But the Emerson has thought deeply about its juxtapositions.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 Bystanders in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 16  A suicide bomber driving a taxi set off his explosives near a convoy of American civilian contractors and accompanying soldiers here this morning, killing himself and four bystanders but only wounding one of his intended targets, the Kabul police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about complications surrounding David Beckhams arrival in the United States to play with the Los Angeles Galaxy, misstated the location of a game scheduled for Oct. 18 between the Galaxy and the Red Bulls that Beckham might miss. It will be in Los Angeles, not at Giants Stadium. (The teams will play on Aug. 18 at Giants Stadium.)

title: Government Financial Crisis May Claim Jerusalem Symphony
description: TEL AVIV, June 15  On the eve of its 70th anniversary, sharp budget cuts threaten the existence of the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra.

title: Former Bush Aide Fights Nickname: Gov. Privatize
description: INDIANAPOLIS  At this rate, critics of Gov. Mitch Daniels grouse, all of Indiana will be run by private corporations.

title: 7 Men Sentenced in Qaeda Bomb Plot in the U.S. and Britain
description: LONDON, June 15  A British court handed down lengthy prison sentences on Friday to seven men who served as accomplices to a Qaeda terrorist planning spectacular attacks in the United States and Britain.

title: Disease Prevention (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Curbs Put on the Appetites for Debt and Sugar
description: Consumers cast a worried eye on the bond market as mortgage rates rose, while investors rode a bullish wave to end the week. Blackstones founders were poised for a big payoff as they prepared for an initial offering.

title: Specialist in Tough (to) Love
description: Hype and hokiness aside, some reality shows are appealing because they seem real. Buffalo is the setting for Confessions of a Matchmaker, tonight on A&E. Nobody will confuse that town with Hollywood, Manhattan or the castle on The Bachelor. Establishing shots show us a gritty, snowy industrial city in the unforgiving north, with a heroine to match.

title: One Word for Airplane Makers: Plastics
description: PARIS, June 15  In the 1999 comedy Pushing Tin, John Cusack and Billy Bob Thornton portray rival air traffic controllers who spend their workday guiding planes in and out of New Yorks airports.

title: Cherokee Freedmen (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona-Mexico Discussion Focuses on Border Violence
description: TUCSON, June 15  For more than 50 years the governments of Arizona and its Mexican neighboring state, Sonora, have gathered regularly to strike agreements, pledge cooperation and bask in border bonhomie.

title: Adult-Only Froot Loops
description: Childhood obesity too often starts at home  in front of the television set. Children are defenseless against the wiles of Madison Avenue, and studies show most cannot understand the difference between an advertisement and the rest of their television fare. Even worse, these snappy ads directed at the young help create bad eating habits for life.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,509 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Washingtons Secret Gun Files
description: A NARROWLY divided Congress will vote in the coming days on whether to renew legislation that stops the federal government from sharing with local police departments and prosecutors crucial information about guns used in crimes. The Tiahrt amendment, first passed in 2003, prohibits Washington from releasing crime data about guns that used to be provided to state and local law enforcement. If House members reauthorize the measure, they will harm efforts to curtail gun violence in this country.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on June 8 gave the wrong date in some copies for the start of audio podcasts on the New York Police Departments Web site. The podcasts began in September 2005, not last November.

title: A Criminal in the Suburbs, but With a British Accent
description: Until the dawn of the 23rd century  at the very earliest, you suppose  any new family drama on television seeking to dissect class and criminality will exist in the penumbra of another. The arrival of such a series will call to mind what legendarily came before: its moral inquiries, its occasionally bewildering points of plot. I speak here, of course, of Knots Landing, the pioneer of subdivision gothic, a genre whose spigots have leaked ever more ghoulishly since.

title: Iran Strategy Stirs Debate at White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  A year after President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced a new strategy toward Iran, a behind-the-scenes debate has broken out within the administration over whether the approach has any hope of reining in Irans nuclear program, according to senior administration officials.

title: Russia: A Surprise Putin Successor Is Hinted
description: A senior adviser to President Vladimir V. Putin, Igor I. Shuvalov, added new intrigue to the question of who might succeed Mr. Putin when he steps down next year. Mr. Shuvalov, in remarks widely reported in Russia, told a conference at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington on Thursday that Mr. Putin might yet turn to someone other than one of the two aides routinely touted as his most likely successor: Sergei B. Ivanov and Dmitri A. Medvedev. People talk about two candidates, possible candidates, he said, according to the center, but, you know, my president could trade another surprise, and maybe even late during this year you will know about another possible figure. His remarks revived speculation in Russia about other political figures close to Mr. Putin who might yet emerge. Mr. Shuvalov emphasized that Mr. Putin intended to step down, saying he did not want Russia to follow other post-Soviet states, like Belarus and Turkmenistan, whose leaders changed their constitutions to retain authoritarian power.

title: Speedy Reyes and Gmez Help Fuel a Stellar Outing by Prez
description: In the old days, players did not get their own rooms on road trips. They shared them, leading one to wonder what sort of high jinks would ensue if three of the Mets most high-strung players  Jos Reyes, Carlos Gmez and Oliver Prez  were roommates.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reports of Forced Labor Unsettle China
description: SHANGHAI, June 15  Su Jinduo and Su Jinpeng, brother and sister, were traveling home by bus from a vacation visit to Qingdao during the Chinese New Year when they disappeared.

title: Streisand Tours, and New York Musicians Cheer
description: Thank you, Barbra.

title: U.S.G.A.s Urban Drive Is Well Short
description: Oakmont, Pa.

title: Bill for Direct Vote to Elect President Is Blocked in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, June 15  President Ahmet Necdet Sezer refused Friday to approve a bill that would allow for direct presidential elections, a move that will result in a national referendum on the measure.

title: Leonard Pickell Jr., 53, Is Dead; Ex-Leader Who Stole From Beard Foundation
description: Leonard F. Pickell Jr., the former president of the James Beard Foundation who was imprisoned for stealing from it after years of promoting it as one of the nations top culinary institutions, died on Wednesday at his home in Howell, N.J. He was 53.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a decision by the National Trust for Historic Preservation to declare Brooklyns industrial waterfront one of the countrys most endangered historic places misstated the nature of the roofing at the Domino Sugar Refinery in Williamsburg, which is within the area. None of the buildings are topped by a dome; the Revere Sugar Factory in Red Hook, which has been mostly demolished, had a dome.

title: In Writers Trial, Testimony of Life as Strange as Fiction
description: The life of a writer bears about the same relation to the work as everyday reality does to a dream. In both cases, a glancing transformation takes place.

title: A 66 on a Tough Course Wows a Tough Audience
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 15  When the Englishman Paul Casey holed an 18-inch birdie putt at the ninth hole to complete his round of four-under-par 66, the golfers who were putting on the portion of the ninth green that is set aside for practice stopped what they were doing to applaud his effort.

title: Claudia Cohen, 56, Socialite and a Reporter of Gossip, Is Dead
description: Claudia Cohen, a high-profile gossip reporter for television and newspapers who was a frequent subject of the gossip columns herself, partly because of her marriage to, and remunerative divorce from, the billionaire businessman Ronald O. Perelman, died yesterday in Manhattan. She was 56 and had homes in Manhattan and Easthampton, N.Y.

title: Penn National Gaming Accepts Takeover Bid
description: The gambling world is dominated by a few high-profile names like MGM Mirage, Wynn Resorts, Harrahs Entertainment  the same few corporations that, not coincidentally, dominate Las Vegas.

title: Europe Backs Abbas in Fight for Control of West Bank
description: BRUSSELS, June 15  The European Union extended firm support to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Friday and said it would continue humanitarian and financial aid in the Palestinian territories despite Hamass seizure of control in Gaza.

title: Julie Thoma Wright, 49, Who Helped Create Market for Modern Design, Is Dead
description: Julie Thoma Wright, a founder and co-owner of Wright, the Chicago auction house that helped create the market for 20th-century modern design, died on Monday in Chicago. She was 49.

title: Clerk Accused of Fixing Tickets for Suspect in Ft. Dix Terror Plot
description: A court clerk in southern New Jersey was dragged into the outer orbit of the Fort Dix terror case this week after she was charged with altering traffic tickets issued to one of the six suspects who have been indicted, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: Bollywood Goes to Europe and Finds Love
description: If Bollywood has a credo, it might be that everything is possible. The corollary is just as important: Nothing is too big or too obvious. A character is in Paris? Fine. He must dance with his love in front of the Louvre, the Eiffel Tower, the Arc de Triomphe and the Obelisk of Luxor. The song they sing? Ticket to Hollywood, of course.

title: Can a Vision Save All of Africa?
description: It was Malaria in Africa Week here in New York. Not officially, of course. But by coincidence, two big malaria-related events took place that were by turns moving, inspiring and invigorating.

title: Hints of New Kosovo Talks
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, June 15  The United States envoy to Kosovo said Friday that Western nations could put off plans to make the province independent of Serbia, if doing so might bring Russia on board.

title: Web Help for Getting Mortgage the Criminal Way
description: Want to buy a home, but hampered by bad credit, an empty bank account or no job? No problem!

title: Contractor Is Shot Twice in Queens
description: A contractor was shot and critically wounded early yesterday as he walked out of his house in the Whitestone section of Queens, the police said.

title: William C. Mercer, 88, Former Phone Executive, Dies
description: William C. Mercer, the former president and chairman of the New England Telephone Company, died on June 6 in Westwood, Mass. He was 88.

title: The First Domed City
description: PHOENIX

title: Juanita Swedenburg, 82, Dies; Won Suit on Wine Shipping
description: Juanita Swedenburg, a Virginia winery and vineyard owner who in 2005 won a battle in the United States Supreme Court to tear down protectionist barriers that kept wineries from shipping directly to consumers in other states, died June 9 at her home in Middleburg, Va. She was 82.

title: The Dental Needs of Our Children (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Budget Is Adopted, With Members Pet Projects Identified
description: There were the usual earmarks for things like Boy Scouts and churches, Greek-American radio and day care, even some money sprinkled in for fireworks. Only this time, there was a little more explanation of who was responsible for the money.

title: Bonnaroo: Hot Chip Seduction
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.A little Bonnaroo music education: I wandered from the tent where Gillian Welch (and her partner David Rawlings) had just finished two bluegrass-tinged songs with John Paul Jones from Led Zeppelin joining them on mandolin. (Unfortunately, neither one was Led Zeppelins Battle of Evermore.) I was headed for Hot Chip, the band that matches pumping electronica to plaintive songs, and as I got closer I thought I was misguided: the minor-key tune and steady beat drifting across the field made me think I was heading toward a band playing some mountain hoedown. No, it was Hot Chip, and the steady 16th-note pulse wasnt old-timey music; it was electronic, but I was seduced by the segue.

title: Buddies After All
description: Two former undercover detectives in their early 40s look to one another as they confront serious illness in the wake of 9/11.

title: Gorgeous in Grenada
description: Exterior

title: Comparing AMGs
Luang Prabang, a city even a cynic can love
description: Theres a lovely thing one can still do in parts of Buddhist Asia. You get up before dawn to buy food at the market. Then you line up with the villagers at the side of the road, taking care to remove your shoes. As the sun rises, a procession of monks in their brilliant orange robes emerges silently from around a corner. Each carries as a tub which the villagers and you, if you wish  fill with handfuls of fruit, sweets or rice as offerings.

title: Poor U.S. Finishing Makes Hard Work of Panama
description: Two goals in two minutes from a Landon Donovan penalty and a fine glancing header by Carlos Bocanegra gave the United States a 2-1 victory over Panama in the quarterfinals of the Concacaf Gold Cup in Foxborough, Mass., Saturday. The win sets up a semifinal matchup with Canada Thursday at Soldier Field in Chicago.

title: Wedding Bells in Queens
description: Couples line up at Queens Borough Hall every Friday   to tie the knot.

title: Bloomsday!
description: I was just sitting down and reading for the first time in a while in the calm before the storm, and suddenly began to wonder just which way I should be attacking this momentous weekend, wondering which end of the string to pull first, as it were. After all, its the U.S. Grand Prix at Indianapolis, but in France, its the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Adrian Newey, the all important technical director of Red Bull (and more or less of Toro Rosso), is not over there at Indy this weekend with his F1 teams, Newey is in France at Le Mans with a sports car racing team. No, not as a technical director, Newey is racing as an amateur driver in the 24 hour race!

title: Bonnaroo: Tools Ache and Bombast
description: MANCHESTER, TENN. I smell patchouli, Maynard James Keenan of Tool wisecracked when the band arrived onstage to headline Fridays Bonnaroo festival lineup. When it was announced, Tool seemed like an odd booking choice for Bonnaroo. The festivals core of jam bands and grinning fans in tie-dye doesnt fit Tools baleful image. But musically, Tool isnt that much of a stretch from Bonnaroos Saturday headliner, the Police. Both bands are paragons of intricacy, concocting guitar-bass-drum patterns that demand quick fingers and easily slip into odd meters. Both bands have singers who are generally melodic crooners, not shouters or barkers; both Mr. Keenan and Sting have a wistful ache in their voices.

title: We Come to Bury Him
description: Its looking more and more like that 10-second blackout at the end of The Sopranos was the dark silence inside Tonys capo.

title: London Journal: No Standing Please. Were British.
description: For 10 days in London and Aldeburgh I have been among audiences that certainly seemed to appreciate what they were hearing every bit as much as I did. But one thing Ive noticed: No matter how excited audiences here get, standing ovations never happen.

title: 2008: Not-So-New Politics, New Fallout
description: We begin our news summary this morning with an issue that has definitely exercised Caucus readers. Adam Nagourney posted on the backstory of a memo, released without attribution by Senator Barack Obamas campaign but ultimately procured and re-released by Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign, which included critical analyses of her finances. Today, The Timess Jeff Zeleny steps back to examine how this and other wrinkles affect the sheen on Mr. Obamas new kind of politics.

title: Under the Senate Leaders Tent
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer once memorably declared at a public meeting with top lawmakers that they were convening in my room with my rules. Last Monday, Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno invited the governor to his lavish annual picnic for Senate Republicans at his upstate farm. This is my tent, the majority leader was said to have quipped, my farm. The Legislative session ends next Thursday, and the outcome of several issues will depend on how well the states top Democrat and Republican are getting along. By the end of this week, they were skirmishing again at a public negotiating session, where Mr. Bruno called the governors campaign finance proposals nuts and nonsense.

title: Posada at First, Celebs on the Field, and More
description: Some tidbits before the start of Saturdays Subway Series game

title: Bonnaroo: Late Night Led Zep Medleys and Passed-out Fans
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Bonnaroos late nights are bewildering. After the headline set, the mid-level jam bands vamp into the night. The same fields where Ive been wandering all day are now unevenly lighted and populated by more or less vertical dancers, seated groups and sacked-out people who peaked too early to get back to their campgrounds. Its a tribute to the courtesy of Bonnaroos audience that more people dont wake up with footprints on them.

title: Pre-Race Celebrity
description: While I was walking through the back of pit lane at the 24 Hours of Le Mans, only minutes before the drop of the green flag at 3:00 p.m. (9:00 a.m. E.S.T.), a teenage boy came running toward me. In his right hand he had a racing helmet, in his left a black magic marker. Oh no, I thought, this kid thinks Im a one of the race car drivers! Dressed in a Corvette Racing team jumpsuit and still fresh-faced from the pre-race excitement, maybe I did have an aura of self-confidence and that bouncy walk that racecar drivers have perfected. Still, I couldnt lie.

title: A Wild Afternoon in the Bronx
description: In case you hadnt heard, Omar Minaya is featured in a lengthy cover article in this weeks Sports Illustrated, written by the excellent Gary Smith. Minaya said that he was initially reluctant to open up so much about his private life and family history, but that he felt it was important to perpetuate the memory of his parents, who are deceased. His children, Teddy and Justin, never met them.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 17
description: Iraq takes front and center in this Sundays morning talk show lineup, with top Defense and State Department officials monopolizing some programs.

title: Blogger Wants His Press Pass Back
description: What does it take for a blogger to get a press credential in this town?

title: Are Traffic Fees a Senate Election Issue?
description: Could congestion pricing become the next big campaign issue in the state?

title: A Novelist Reads. Dogs Listen.
description: May I say, Ive never known such a well-behaved group of dogs at a literary reading, Adam Gopnik, the author and New Yorker writer, said this afternoon after the novelist Cathleen Schine read from her latest book, The New Yorkers.

title: Young people of a Rwandan pygmy village
Where Is the U.S. Soccer Teams Killer Instinct?
description: Another win, but a whole host of missed opportunities. The United States reached the semifinals of the CONCACAF Gold Cup with a 2-1 win over Panama Saturday, but where is the Americans killer instinct? What does U.S. coach Bob Bradley need to do to get his team to stop misfiring and to start scoring goals early and often?

title: Win a Trip: Pygmy Village
description: Will Okun, who's traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, reports on his visit to the home of pygmy villagers in Rwanda.

title: The Union Street Hall of Fame
description: NO one who walks by Santo Matarazzos neatly kept brownstone on Union Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, is likely to guess at the personalities gathered inside.

title: And Still the Champion
description: Although the dining scene in Park Slope has spread around the neighborhood in the past few years, with a blossoming restaurant row on Seventh Avenue and promising newcomers on Sixth Avenue, Fifth Avenue has held firm as the center, with star players like these.

title: Roommates Who Almost Werent
description: AS soon as Chris Roan and Justin Fluck become colleagues  as advertising salesmen at the satirical newspaper The Onion  they became friends. Later, they became roommates. The first was effortless. The second, not so much.

title: Miles to Go Before They Sleep
description: In politics, reaching consensus is more difficult in good times than in bad. Both Republicans and Democrats had big ideas about how to spend a large surplus that now approaches $1 billion. But endless debate and discussion over six months never helped them find common ground. Now the General Assembly needs a special session to complete the most basic task of government: passing a budget.

title: The New Lady Chatterley: Sober, Sensual, French
description: THE years have not been kind to Lady Chatterley. Nor for that matter have the movies. Scandalous in her day, the sexual adventuress of D. H. Lawrences best-known novel has matured into something of a pop-culture joke, remembered less as a symbol of erotic liberation than a soft-core staple of late-night cable.

description: JERSEY CITY

title: Elizabeth Hall, Pamela Palumbo
description: The Rev. Dr. Elizabeth Sidar Hall, a Presbyterian minister, and Pamela Mary Palumbo were joined in a civil union ceremony yesterday. The Rev. Jean A. F. Holmes, a Presbyterian minister, officiated in Califon, N.J., at the home of Rev. Jean Johnston and Dr. Edward Johnston, who are friends of the couple.

title: Nascar Watches as Team Blends Oil and Water
description: Beer cans rained down on Jeff Gordons No. 24 Chevrolet back on April 29, when he accomplished the unthinkable, winning at Talladega Superspeedway to surpass the beloved Dale Earnhardt and move into sixth place on the career Nascar victory list. It was messy and mean, and perfectly in keeping with fans that are maniacally devoted to all things Earnhardt.

title: For Questions and Complaints
description: WHAT can you do if youre concerned  or simply curious  about a building project in your neighborhood? To learn whats happening at any construction site in the city, consult the online Buildings Department information system www.nyc.gov/buildings.

title: An Elegy for Three Sisters. Chekhov? No, Wasserstein.
description: Theres a moment in Act II of Wendy Wassersteins Sisters Rosensweig in which Geoffrey Duncan, the bisexual theater director, mourns all the friends he has lost to AIDS: Ive seen too many lights that never had their chance to glow burn out overnight. Ive tried for years to make sense of all this, and all I know is life is random. Today, those lines stand as a lament for Ms. Wasserstein herself, whose inimitable voice was prematurely stilled last year, when she died of lymphoma at 55.

title: World View Podcast
description: GREG WINTER. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: CAUTIONS ON MOSCOW

title: Lindsey LaBoon, Samuel Rothenberg

Cameos will include Elizabeth Taylor as the former wife of the anti-wind-farm Senator John Warner; Warners former mother-in-law Bunny Mellon, the nonagenarian Listerine heiress who decorated the Kennedy White House (behind the scenes) and helped establish the Oyster Harbors Club; and Walter Cronkite, who, as the co-authors Wendy Williams and Robert Whitcomb have it, starts out on the side of darkness only to turn toward the light, or in this case, the wind. The setting is Horseshoe Shoal, about five miles off the coast of Cape Cod, where, in 2001, an energy developer named Jim Gordon proposed what he still hopes will be Americas first offshore wind farm, an array of 130 turbines, 440 feet tall, that would create 468 megawatts of electrical energy, the only dangerous fumes being those emanating from the mad-as-hell multimillion-dollar homeowners on the Cape, Marthas Vineyard and Nantucket.

title: A Father Never Stops Counting

title: Water Shed
description: The French know a thing or two about symmetry. In the late 19th century, the picturesque banks of the Seine west of Paris were a favorite subject of the Impressionists; Renoir painted his famous Luncheon of the Boating Party on the balcony of the Maison Fournaise, on an island (now called Lle des Impressionnistes) at Chatou. Today, floating just next door to the Maison Fournaise (restored as a restaurant), there is an artistic enterprise that is as modern now as the Impressionists were then. The Centre National de lEstampe et de lArt Imprim, or Cneai  a contemporary art center devoted to prints, multiples and artist publications  commissioned the Paris-based designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, who are brothers, to design a dwelling for its artist-in-residence program. But instead of a house, Cneai asked for a houseboat  a reference to the bateaux-lavoirs, or laundry boats, that dotted the river until the early 20th century. The new structure, however, needed a contemporary form.

title: When Is a Pain Doctor a Drug Pusher?
description: Ronald McIver is a prisoner in a medium-security federal compound in Butner, N.C. He is 63 years old, of medium height and overweight, with a white Santa Claus beard, white hair and a calm, direct and intelligent manner. He is serving 30 years for drug trafficking, and so will likely live there the rest of his life. McIver (pronounced mi-KEE-ver) has not been convicted of drug trafficking in the classic sense. He is a doctor who for years treated patients suffering from chronic pain. At the Pain Therapy Center, his small storefront office not far from Main Street in Greenwood, S.C., he cracked backs, gave trigger-point injections and put patients through physical therapy. He administered ultrasound and gravity-inversion therapy and devised exercise regimens. And he wrote prescriptions for high doses of opioid drugs like OxyContin.

But step outside the central shopping district and you'll find a growing number of stores that showcase young fashion and furniture designers. There's also an exploding restaurant scene. Sri Lankan food may be as easy to find as anything cooked alla Milanese (battered and fried). In fact, the only meal that may elude you is The Last Supper.

title: The Year of the Goat

First stop: margaritas at the Cadillac Bar (oh, how they flowed), and then we taxied to a restaurant famous for tender, smoky, spit-roasted goat. The next morning, I embraced two new truths: I had accepted a life-changing job in rural isolation and a favorite new meat to barbecue.

title: A Little Night Music

An Englishman in his mid-40s, he readies himself, his aluminum music stand holding a complete score of Sergei Prokofievs Romeo and Juliet, not the standard subway saxophonists fare. Mr. Jennings, who is tall and dark-haired, wears a red velvet jacket; he keeps time on the tenor sax with the tap of a black Oxford.

Instead, the chief operating officer of the Starwood Capital Group plotted  with the help of Homebase Abroad, a luxury villa company that specializes in Italy  to arrange a week in Tuscany last year as a surprise for his wife, Cathy, to be shared with more than two dozen friends and family members.

The court took away Mr. Bowless right to challenge his murder conviction in a ruling that was so wrong and mean-spirited that it seemed like an outtake from MTVs practical joke show Punkd.

title: Into the Wood
description: A biography of a late-18th-century English artist whose medium was the woodblock? I confess to having been bewildered by the assignment. Why would anyone care? I thumbed through the book, which is filled with illustrations of country scenes, each about two inches across. Charming enough, at first glance, the kind of sentimental drawings found on packages of soap or seeds, meant to suggest old-time value. Then I got to the beasts  the foumart, the cur fox, the baboon, the Chillingham bull  and suddenly, gazing at a handsome illustration of a lion, I remembered, as a child, pulling down an impossibly heavy old leatherbound book of fables, full of magical drawings of wolves and crows and bears, intense in their detail while managing to leave much to the imagination. A few days later, a friend sent me Donald Halls book about Eagle Pond, his home in New Hampshire, and there were more woodcuts: of skaters on the ice, a dog curled at his masters feet, clouds billowing over mountains, clapboard houses and placid streams. Apart from slicing my palm open with an X-Acto knife while cutting a picture into a block of linoleum during seventh-grade art class, I havent spent five seconds thinking about woodcuts. Yet theyre everywhere you look.

title: Presidential Stone Walls
description: The template for the Bush administrations mania for secrecy was signed by the president six years ago  Executive Order 13233, reversing the presumption of right of public access to presidential papers. This basic right of taxpayers and historians alike was embedded in the 1978 laws enacted after the Nixon administration. The reforms established a reasonable 12-year waiting period for access. But Mr. Bushs reversal lets presidents or vice presidents (guess who?) keep their records sealed in perpetuity unless they or their heirs approve access.

title: Bookshelf
description: EVERY FRIDAY. By Dan Yaccarino. Henry Holt. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 7) Friday is my favorite day, a small boy tells us, because every Friday he and his dad go for breakfast together at the local diner. In cheerful gouache illustrations, they wave to passersby, watch shops open and buildings going up; everyone is rushing, but were taking our time. A note from the author tells us the book is based on his weekly ritual with his own son. It is also a valentine to good dads and neighborhood diners, and a reminder on Fathers Day that the little traditions are sometimes the best ones.

title: Curb Job
description: Taxi drivers are the most enduring oppressed minority in New York City history. Race, ethnicity and religion are not sources of the oppression. It lies entirely in the nature of the work. Trapped for about 12 hours each day in the worst traffic in the United States, taxi drivers must suffer the savage frustrations of jammed streets, double-parked cars, immense trucks, drivers from New Jersey  and they cant succumb to the explosive therapy of road rage. Their living depends on self-control.

title: Take It Slow, Dont Have Many Kids and Enjoy Cold Water
description: ESKIMO hunters killed a bowhead whale off the coast of Alaska last month and began to chainsaw their way into its blubber. They stopped when the saw hit the tip of an old harpoon lodged deep inside the whale. Historians identified it last week as part of a bomb lance, a harpoon manufactured for only a few years in the late 1800s in New Bedford, Mass. Whalers probably fired it at the bowhead around 1890, when the whale was probably a teenager, and it carried the harpoon for the next 115 years before finally being killed by a modern one.

The other is an infusion of cash to put new streetlights and trash cans on Franklin Avenue as it enters Hempstead from Garden City, prettifying one of the most jarring boundaries between rich and poor, white and nonwhite, leafy streets and mean ones that you will see in any part of staunchly segregated Long Island.

To believe that auto expressionists will run out of gas at some point is to underestimate their ability to create previously unimaginable novelty. Picture, for instance, a 1976 Impala improbably perched on 26-inch wheels and painted in colors inspired by a variety of Hawaiian Punch. This is whats called a donk.

The classic school story is set in elementary or middle school, and the characters are people whom readers can identify with. Most of these stories take place in Middle America, but they can also be set in an urban environment. The kids are not seriously troubled, their parents arent dead, missing or on drugs. title: Returning to Broadway on Celestial Roller Skates
description: Douglas Carter Beane is having a Broadway moment. His play The Little Dog Laughed, a Faustian tale about a closeted actor navigating the demands of Hollywood hustlers, was nominated for a Tony Award for best play. (It lost to The Coast of Utopia.) Julie White, the shows caustically funny leading lady, won the Tony for her performance as the actors conniving agent. Mr. Beane, whose other plays included As Bees in Honey Drown, has also written the book for the new stage adaptation of the 1980 movie musical Xanadu, which starred Olivia Newton-John as a beautiful, breathy muse named Kira (Kerry Butler plays her on Broadway) who comes to earth to help an artist open his dream roller disco and had songs by the Electric Light Orchestra. The show is scheduled to open soon at the Helen Hayes Theater.

As he unveiled them, a gasp was heard throughout the room. People shrieked, recalls Sheldon Fine, chairman of Community Board 7.

title: Oh, to Be 19 and an Entrepreneur

For most relatively normal guys like me, life at 19 is a joyously ephemeral state of being in between. Your adolescence is not quite behind you; your adulthood is not quite at hand. You can appropriate the privileges of a grownup without facing the responsibilities. And if youre lucky, you can still put it all on your parents tab.
