This is all black, said Ms. Wang, dismissively. Black is very 90s.

title: Amita Mahajan and Deepak Vadada
description: Dr. Amita Mahajan and Dr. Deepak Vadada were married yesterday at the Sheraton Parsippany Hotel in New Jersey. Pandit Venugopal G. Devdhar, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Correction: The Geisha-and-Houseboy-Liberation Theater
description: An article on May 20 about the Pan Asian Repertory Theater referred incorrectly in two references to Daniel Dae Kim, who has acted with the troupe. He is Mr. Kim, not Mr. Dae Kim.

title: Vivian Thomson, Patrick Roach
description: Vivian Elizabeth Thomson and Patrick Joseph Roach were married yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Alane Cameron Miles, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated at Pavilion VII on the University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville.

title: Doors Open
description: It occurred to Allan Cruikshank that the reason he made a good banker was that he was intrinsically boring. He had never taken a risk in his life. This meant he was cautious and prudent, and therefore good at not losing his clients money. But banking had also made him cynical. It was a truism that those who already had money would find it easy to increase their wealth, and they never seemed very grateful for Allans work on their (often unmerited) behalf. Some of the High Net Worth individuals on his books owned three or four homes, yachts, racehorses, private islands and numerous works of art. Yet they seemed to appreciate very little, being too busy amassing yet more. He found them dull and blinkered, and wondered if they thought of him the same way. Then there were his fellow account executives at First Caledonian Bank, some of whom hardly registered his existence. The chief executive had met him a dozen times, yet never seemed to remember him. With a drink in one hand and a canap in the other, he would regale Allan time and again with the same anecdote, while Allan smiled and tried to sound interested throughout and surprised by the predictable punch line.

title: Woman Warriors
description: To appreciate the delicious irony of the title of Throw Like a Girl, Jean Thompsons boldly unconventional new story collection, you need to consider it in context: in the title story, two college friends have reunited in New York, where one of them is living with her dyspeptic boyfriend, known to the reader as Whats-his-name. One night, after Whats-his-name has been especially pillish, the young women begin picking up chunks of broken sidewalk and hurling them at him. He couldnt ignore us any longer when we hit him, pretty hard, once between his shoulder blades and then beneath his ear, Thompson writes. Whats-his-names shrill response before running away  Youre crazy, you know that? Besides, you throw like a girl!  prompts hilarity from the women. Youre so much smarter than me, says Whats-his-names girlfriend. I dont see you with a jerk.

title: When Demagogues Play the Leprosy Card, Watch Out
description: People who want to reform immigration by putting America in lockdown have not been shy about using fear and revulsion to get their point across. Illegal immigrants, they say, are invading the country to reconquer it, to erode our Anglo-Saxon culture and to make us all sick.

title: With a Bow to Springsteen, a Band Plays On
description: UP close, Mark Salore doesnt look much like Bruce Springsteen. Except, perhaps, for the stud in his left ear and a wispy bit of beard. Mr. Salore is shorter than the Boss, his complexion darker, his nose slightly bigger. An astonishing transformation takes place, though, when he gets onstage with his tribute band, Tramps Like Us. He punches out the opening riff to Cadillac Ranch, the group kicks in behind him, the crowd erupts in war cries and air guitar riffs, and it suddenly seems as if Bruce and the E Street Band have commandeered the Vintage Bar in White Plains.

title: New Homes Confront Old Burial Grounds
description: DAC ENTERPRISES, a small, mostly residential developer in Georgia, bought about 118 acres in Hall County, just south of the city of Lula, with the idea of selling lots to builders to put up single-family houses. The transaction, completed in 2004, seemed routine for the fast-growing exurb, 50 miles northeast of Atlanta.

title: Reagan on Reagan
description: Not since the 19th century has a United States president kept a diary through his entire White House tenure, and this volume tells us more about Ronald Reagan than many of his biographies. Besides which, not a few interpretive bits of gold are sprinkled amid the grit and gravel of diplomatic niceties, Congressional consultations and after-dinner entertainments.

title: Cellphone Exposes Flaw in 911 System
description: ON a drizzling Sunday morning last month, Adrienne Pincus hit the brakes on her bicycle as two riders  one a close friend  crashed on a rain-slicked road in Norwalk, Conn., near the start of the Bloomin Metric, one of regions most popular cycling events.

title: Willkommen! Life Is a Spiegeltent, Old Chum
description: VALLEJO GANTNER is a devotee of spiegeltents: those 1920s European traveling pavilions of teak and leaded glass, velvet and brocade, banquettes and beveled mirrors. He knows the handful of owners in Belgium and the Netherlands who rent the last surviving spiegeltents to a lucky few cities each year. And in his native Melbourne and in his former job as director of the Dublin Fringe Festival, he produced shows in spiegeltents that drew throngs.

title: Making Musical History
description: Massapequa Park

title: Potter Fans Are on Board, Eagerly Awaiting the Finale
description: NEWARK

title: Correction: Remembering the Royal Wedding of 1947
description: A photograph with the In Transit column on June 3, about an exhibition at Buckingham Palace on Queen Elizabeths 1947 wedding, was published in error. It depicted a bridesmaids dress, not the brides.

title: Young Beyond Its Years
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Tall, Gangly and Not So Hidden in Plain Sight
description: Marine Park, a leafy neighborhood of detached houses in southern Brooklyn, is a quiet place where neighbors are proud to say they know one another. The kind of place, as the president of the Marine Park Civic Association, Greg Borruso, says, where if you dont water your lawn on Tuesday, a neighbor will water it for you on Wednesday.

title: Among Firefighters in New York, Mixed Views on Giuliani
description: Their images are permanently etched in photographs after the fall of the World Trade Center towers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and firefighters cloaked in the same gray dust. For months afterward, they stood together at funerals. Mr. Giuliani, in his eulogy, always asked for a round of applause to celebrate the dead firefighters life.

title: Alice Stagg, Thor Mann
description: Alice Miriam Stagg and Thor Tembeya Mann, management consultants, were married yesterday by Rabbi Dennis Shulman at the Grounds for Sculpture, a museum and park in Hamilton, N.J.

title: Inside the List
description: MARGINALIA:  Reviews of Michael Ondaatjes new novel, Divisadero, have been mixed to positive. But even critics whove admired it  see Erica Wagners review this week  have found it to be, at times, a slog. (In The Los Angeles Times, Thomas Meaney wrote about the novels narrator: Ondaatje has left us in the hands of an English Ph.D., one whose literary pretensions are on full display.)

title: Correction: Income Inequality, Writ Larger
description: The Economic View column last Sunday, about income inequality in the United States, misstated the top marginal rate for federal income taxes. It is 35 percent, not 36 percent.

title: Slow Track This Nominee
description: New Jersey Attorney General Stuart Rabner, who is Gov. Jon Corzines choice for chief justice of the states Supreme Court, is viewed as a nonpolitical straight arrow with no tolerance for ethical shortcomings. That is an essential character trait in New Jersey, given the states record of corruption. But it is not the only quality the states top judge must have.

title: Homes for an Overlooked Market
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: Design Meets Dance, and Rules Are Broken
description: SUPPOSE your daughter is getting married, and her wedding dress wont be ready until the morning of the wedding, but its by Dior, the composer Morton Feldman said to a friend in 1958. He was explaining how Merce Cunningham could be choreographing Summerspace in one part of the country while Robert Rauschenberg was designing it in another and he, Feldman, was composing the music in a third. By that time this wait-till-the-wedding compositional formula for Cunningham dance theater had already been established. According to its rules the choreography, design and music are created separately and may be brought together as late as opening night, with the artists knowing little if anything about one anothers plans save the dimensions of the stage, the number and physical details of the dancers, and the works duration in time.

title: Crackpot Legislation
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Downtown, an Amenities Rivalry
description: WITH a thud, 75 Wall Street, a huge hotel-and-luxury-condominium building, has landed in the financial district  another residential offering typical of the area, where it seems a weekends-worth of amenities can be experienced in the course of an elevator ride.

title: Up North, Looking for Direction
description: SCOURING the tundra for the source of the next big boom is the Alaskan way.

title: We Cant Just Duck and Cover (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Turning Down the Volume in the Next Cubicle
description: Q. Your co-workers sometimes have loud conversations near you, and they dont seem to realize that the noise is keeping you from concentrating. What should you do?

title: As Close to Mexico as the County Gets
description: THE first thing youll notice about Sunset Grille in White Plains is the tortilla chips automatically placed at each table. Thicker and darker than the usual fare, they have a richer, nuttier taste as well. The green and red salsas that accompany them are different, too. They lack the electric color and processed taste of most Mexican restaurants offerings.

title: Where the Arts Were Too Liberal
description: London

title: Habitat for Humanitys Homes Faulted in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  When Habitat for Humanity built the Fairway Oaks development here seven years ago, Mary Zeigler thought, This is a blessing. In just 17 days, an army of 10,000 volunteers, including former President Jimmy Carter and first lady Rosalynn Carter, built 85 low-cost houses, one of the nonprofit groups biggest blitz build projects.

title: Shirley Lasker and Stephen Fox
description: POLITICALLY, Dr. Stephen Fox and Shirley Lasker are a close match  both wear their activism on their sleeve. Youd think, then, that romance between the two would be smooth sailing.

title: Can He Crush Hillary?
description: WASHINGTON

title: An Unpleasant Trudge Toward Baseballs Record Books
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Comments of Disciplinary Panels Chairman
description: Following is a transcript of the comments of F. Lane Williamson, chairman of the disciplinary panel that voted unanimously to disbar Michael Nifong, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Port Authority Needs More Openness, Governors Say, and They Have a Plan
description: The governors of New York and New Jersey are seeking an end to most secret meetings and want greater disclosure on how contracts are awarded at the powerful agency that operates the two states major bridges, tunnels and airports in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Covering the Bases
description: Milestone Tracker

title: Stricker May Be Fashioning Another Comeback Story at U.S. Open
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 16  Tiger Woods is not the only golfer on the leader board who will be stalking his third United States Open title Sunday. Lee Janzen, the champion in 1993 and 1998, was seven strokes back Saturday after his third consecutive three-over-par 73.

title: Venice. Art. Ubiquitous.
description: The mere use of ones eyes in Venice is happiness enough.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A message to those who have applied for  and are eagerly awaiting  passports: relax. The Departments of State and Homeland Security announced on June 8 that through Sept. 30, United States citizens traveling to Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and Bermuda may enter and depart the United States by air as long as they have a government-issued photo identification and proof that they have applied for a passport. The Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, which has required passports for all air travel outside of United States territories since Jan. 23, has created a record demand for passports, meaning longer processing and turnaround times. Details are at www.travel.state.gov. ... Want more Pirates of the Caribbean? Hotels on Dominica, which provided some locations for the movies starring Johnny Depp (below), have created packages for pirate-crazy travelers. A seven-night experience offered by Calibishie Lodges (www.calibishie-lodges.com) includes visits to eight spots used in the movies; it is available for $599 a person, double occupancy, if reserved by June 30. A seven-day package offered by the Tamarind Tree Hotel and Restaurant (www.tamarindtreedominica.com) includes tours led by the driver for Gore Verbinski, the movies director, starting at $1,615 a person, double, with all meals. Other pirate-themed packages are being offered by the Anchorage Hotel (www.anchoragehotel.dm), the Hummingbird Inn (www.find-us.net/hummingbird)  ask at these two when you reserve  and the Fort Young Hotel (www.fortyounghotel.com). ... American Airlines (www.aa.com) recently announced that all AAdvantage members must redeem or accrue miles at least once every 18 months to keep their accounts active. Starting Dec. 15, mileage accounts that have not changed in the previous year and a half will expire.

title: The Light Stuff
description: Capriccio Cafe is the kind of place where going out for a bite is really about being outside. Sure, this Italian eatery has indoor seating, but a vast majority of the chairs  more than 80  are on Stamfords restaurant row, flanked attractively by a leafy cottonwood on one side and two crabapple trees on the other.

title: Wheres the Melody? Its Everywhere You Look
description: HIS old report cards read Shaffer Chimere Smith, but to the rest of us hes known by two syllables: Ne-Yo. Ne-Yo, a 24-year-old Grammy-nominated R&B singer-songwriter, was back home in Atlanta after a trip to Japan to publicize his sophomore album, Because of You (Def Jam). He was in town temporarily to celebrate the opening of his recording studio  with kitchens!  and to announce a talent contest. (The winner scored a record deal with Ne-Yos label, Compound Entertainment.) Seemingly the victim of a jampacked schedule, he was getting dressed while on the phone with Winter Miller. A thoughtful sentence about melody was punctuated with a request for socks. Nearing the end of his list and finally dressed, though still shirtless, he spoke from the car on the way to greet the press and fans at the new studio. The next day he was off again for his national tour.

title: Correction: Detroits Sticker Shock on Fuel Efficiency
description: An article last Sunday on the resistance of American automakers to proposals that would significantly increase gasoline mileage misspelled the name of the chief executive of the Ford Motor company. He is Alan R. Mulally, not Mullaly.

title: A Basketball Prospect Yearning for Peace and Quiet
description: ALIQUIPPA, Pa.  Herb Pope rises early each morning and dribbles a basketball to a nearby park. Along the way, he passes trash-filled yards and abandoned homes with boarded-up windows.

title: Manhattan House Divided
description: BREAKING up is hard to do, particularly for the developers of one of the most ambitious and expensive condominium conversions ever: the redevelopment of the Manhattan House, a complex with 582 apartments on a full square block on East 66th Street and Third Avenue.

title: Picking Up the Pieces
description: I come from Divisadero Street, Anna tells us in Michael Ondaatjes fifth novel. Divisadero, from the Spanish word for division, the street that at one time was the dividing line between San Francisco and the fields of the Presidio. Or it might derive from the word divisar, meaning to gaze at something from a distance.

title: Unleashed Joy
description: Q. Just after I crossed the footbridge into the Ramble of Central Park the other day, I saw a woman receiving a citation for having her dogs off their leashes by the lake. Dont the city parks have areas outside dog runs where dog owners are allowed to let their pets run free?

title: The Cranes Are Back, and So Are the Tenants
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.

title: Childrens Books | Young Adults
description: Beowulf, a 3,000-line epic poem composed early in the eighth century, is the first significant text written in English, or in what eventually became English. What interests scholars about the story is its place in our linguistic development, and also the way it blends both Christian and pagan details. But what recommends Beowulf to children  and to older readers who havent lost a childs delight in stories that are both scary and gory  is that its also a first-rate horror yarn, featuring slaughter, dismemberment and underwater sword fights.

title: Charles Lee Remington, Butterfly Expert, Dies at 85
description: Charles Lee Remington, the intellectual patriarch of modern American lepidopterology, the scientific study of butterflies and moths, died on May 31 in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.

title: The Best Hotel in Town May Now Be at the Airport
description: If youve passed through one of several major United States airports recently, you might have noticed something that has actually made you want to miss your connection: a luxury hotel linked right to the terminal, no shuttle ride needed.

title: Despite Calls for Restraint, Sunni Mosque Is Bombed in Southern Iraq City
description: BAGHDAD, June 16  Hooded gunmen clad in black blew up another Sunni mosque in the southern city of Basra on Saturday after ordering the police at the mosque to flee, and despite a curfew imposed by Iraqs central government, witnesses and security officials said.

title: Campbells Opportunity
description: Ever since 1869, when the fruit merchant Joseph Campbell shook hands on a deal that would establish one of the nations food giants, the Campbell Soup Company has been a mainstay in Camden, a southern New Jersey city that has long since fallen on hard times.

title: Aronian-Carlsen Was Liveliest of the Candidates Matches
description: There were no real surprises at the candidates matches, held May 27 to June 13 in Elista, Kalmykia, a Russian republic, to select four qualifiers for the World Championship Tournament in Mexico City in September and October.

title: The Life of the Chinese Gold Farmer
description: It was an hour before midnight, three hours into the night shift with nine more to go. At his workstation in a small, fluorescent-lighted office space in Nanjing, China, Li Qiwen sat shirtless and chain-smoking, gazing purposefully at the online computer game in front of him. The screen showed a lightly wooded mountain terrain, studded with castle ruins and grazing deer, in which warrior monks milled about. Li, or rather his staff-wielding wizard character, had been slaying the enemy monks since 8 p.m., mouse-clicking on one corpse after another, each time gathering a few dozen virtual coins  and maybe a magic weapon or two  into an increasingly laden backpack.

title: To the Rumble of Trucks, Add the Roar of Buses
description: Dieter Kist, a contractor with a graying beard, has lived on truck-laden Cooper Avenue in Glendale, Queens, for three years. In that time, his parked car has been hit three times by other vehicles, and at night he is lulled to sleep by the rumble of 18-wheelers hauling cargo.

title: Unlikely Problem: Anchor of Rotation Drags Mets Down
description: If Tom Glavine doesnt get to 300 this season, the Mets arent going anywhere  not to the World Series, not to the National League Championship Series, not to the playoffs period.

title: Thomas Agonistes
description: After all the twisted racial history of the United States Supreme Court, Clarence Thomas was confirmed by the Senate with the smallest margin of victory in more than 100 years, with little professional scrutiny and with a level of manipulative political rancor that diminished everyone directly involved. The effect on Thomas, we learn from this impeccably researched and probing biography, was to reinforce the chronic contradictions with which he has long lived.

title: Going Nose-to-Nose With a Great White
description: IT was not the most comfortable position in which I had ever found myself. Encased inside a ten-foot-long aluminum cage that dangled off the side of the dive boat, submerged up to my neck in 57-degree sea water, I peered with difficulty through a fogged-in scuba mask at the placid Indian Ocean. My feet rested on a thick metal bar about three feet below the surface; my knees were propped up against my chest. Though a wet suit kept my body reasonably well insulated, my exposed hands were freezing and turning numb.

title: Michelle Norkus, Scott Kreitz
description: Michelle Norkus and Scott F. Kreitz were married yesterday at St. Catharine Church in Spring Lake, N.J. Msgr. Thomas A. Luebking, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Pure Gilbert and Sullivan? No. But Still a Glorious Thing.
description: Unbuckle your swashbuckle, channel your inner Johnny Depp and prepare to have a blast at Pirates!  a delightful new adaptation of Gilbert and Sullivans classic Pirates of Penzance at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: Anika Proskurowski and Kenneth Natori
description: Anika Yael Proskurowski, a daughter of Maxine and Andrzej Proskurowski of Eugene, Ore., was married last evening to Kenneth Cruz Natori, the son of Josie Cruz Natori and Kenneth Natori of New York. The Rev. Carleton Jones officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, and the Most Rev. Leonardo Z. Legaspi, the archbishop of the diocese of Caceres in the Philippines and a friend of the bridegrooms family, participated in the ceremony.

title: Mets Said to Be Looking Into an M.L.S. Franchise
description: Mr. Met, the mascot of New Yorks National League baseball team, may not speak fluent Spanish yet, but the club has recast itself with a strong Hispanic flavor and may soon expand beyond Americas pastime and embrace the worlds game: soccer.

title: A Kids Invention That Rocks (and Scoops)
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK

title: A Boycott Built on Bias
description: Two weeks ago I took part in commencement for this years doctoral candidates at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. The ceremony was held in the amphitheater on Mount Scopus, which faces out onto the Dead Sea and the Mountains of Moab. The setting sun framed the graduate students in a reddish-orange glow against a spectacular biblical backdrop.

title: Lana Taradash, Adam Scheiner
description: Lana Faye Taradash, a daughter of Anita and Howard M. Taradash of Nashville, was married on Friday to Adam David Scheiner, a son of Elayne Scheiner of North Brunswick, N.J., and Seth M. Scheiner of Kendall Park, N.J. Cantor Judith Steel officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: To These Preservationists, Ordinariness Is the Charm
description: The six-story brick apartment houses of Pelham Parkway in the Bronx have little in common with the cast-iron emblems of SoHo, the opulent town houses of Gramercy Park or the palatial apartment buildings of Central Park West.

title: Mirth, in Honor of Dad
description: Fathers Day is here, and Im still getting used to not having my father around.

title: Posada May Start at First Base on Interleague Trip
description: Mike Mussinas spot in the rotation comes up twice on the Yankees trip to National League parks at Colorado and San Francisco. That presents Manager Joe Torre with a problem.

title: Israel Shenker, 82, a Reporter With the Instincts of a Scholar, Dies
description: Israel Shenker, a scholar trapped in a newsmans body who was known to readers of The New York Times for his vast erudition and sly, subversive wit, died on June 9 at Kibbutz Shoval in southern Israel. He was 82.

title: Partners Bound by the Ties of 9/11
description: FOR two former undercover detectives in their early 40s who cheated death time and again, no day is ordinary, not anymore, and certainly not a day like this one on the shore of Long Island  a day showered with sea spray and salt air; with clam bellies in a bucket at their sides and jigs tempting stripers in the surf; with sand and sky, wind and waves, straight talk about life and mocking chatter about death.

title: A Chance to Focus on Earnings
description: A light economic calendar this week should give traders a chance to look ahead to second-quarter earnings announcements. It might also provide a respite from their fixation on the bond market.

title: Prenatal Scare
description: Clare Clarks first novel, published in 2005, was inauspiciously  but accurately  titled. The Great Stink offered a richly imagined re-creation of Victorian Londons sewers, a murky labyrinth in which a mildly crazy ex-soldier, newly employed as an engineer, discovers a corpse and finds himself suspected of murder. Praised for the ingenuity of its plotting, this accomplished book also won plaudits for the authenticity of its detail and its almost queasily intense exuberance. Clark, who paid generous acknowledgment to the inspiration of Peter Ackroyds pyrotechnic style, joined him as a highflier, soaring through a dreamscape of her own imagining, yet grounding it in the bricks, mortar and mud of a well-researched past. Her strikingly well-written book was also huge fun to read.

title: Correction: Between a Mother and a Daughter
description: An article on June 3 about Christine Ebersole misstated the location of the high school she attended. New Trier Township High School was and is in Winnetka, Ill., but she attended classes at a different campus in Northfield.

title: Here to Take Your Order (and Biting Their Tongues)
description: THE groans were increasing.

title: A Rattletrap East German Icon Has Its Day Again
description: ZWICKAU, Germany, June 15  East German flags fluttered proudly in the brisk wind. A cheerful young man showed off his black and red T-shirt, stamped with the name of the once feared spy agency, the Stasi. Lurking behind a souvenir table was a portrait of the Communist boss Erich Honecker.

title: Stars Check In, Stars Check Out
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Hidden Tokyo
description: IT was the middle of the night as a Japanese skateboarder and concert promoter named Chris led me through Tokyo's Shibuya district  a sort of futuristic Times Square  with its hyper-commercial vertical sprawl of glass office towers and flashing neon billboards advertising the latest cellphones and pop stars. We threaded past the sleeping shopping malls and shiny multiplexes, down a series of winding streets and through a stone pedestrian tunnel, until we emerged beneath raised train tracks.

title: On the Fence, War Protest Signs
description: Branford

title: Next in Child Prodigies  the Gamer
description: LIKE a lot of parents, Ive always thought the phrase child prodigy had a nice ring to it.

title: Small Detours for Sweet Rewards
description: VISITORS to New York City rightfully expect everything here to be unique, or at least different: quirky characters, well-known sights, special subway grime and state-of-the-art price gouging by bottled-water vendors, to name a few.

title: Teamsters Official Is Expected to Succeed Indicted President of Central Labor Council
description: Gary La Barbera, who helped lead efforts to clean up a Teamsters local once controlled by the Gambino crime family, has been tapped to become the next president of the New York City Central Labor Council.

title: Dont Expect a Surprise Winner at Oakmont
description: Oakmont, Pa.

title: A Japanese Club Maker Forges a Reputation for Craftsmanship
description: A world away from the United States Open, a man hunches over a grinding wheel, quietly aiding some of the games top players.

title: Up Front
description: In a 1991 Op-Ed article for The New York Times, Orlando Patterson  then, as now, a professor of sociology at Harvard  said of the Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill uproar, The hearings ... brought to light the fact that the American public is way ahead of its journalistic and social-science commentators with respect to race relations. Patterson, who reviews Supreme Discomfort, a biography of Thomas, on the cover of this issue, elaborated in an e-mail message: The American public has in recent decades adopted far more nuanced and progressive views than its political and intellectual leaders on both right and left. We are currently living through a good example of this in the immigration debate. As for race relations today, he thinks extremism on both sides is flatly rejected. The great majority of black Americans, including the black poor, do not blame their problems on race, as the academic army of social scientists insists on telling them they should, and getting lifetime tenure for it.

title: In Tense Time, Prank Is Read as Bomb Scare
description: MONTROSE, N.Y.

title: Christine Whelan, Peter Moyers
description: Christine B. Whelan, the daughter of Elizabeth M. Whelan and Stephen T. Whelan of New York, and Peter Rowe Moyers, the son of Katherine M. Moyers and John R. Moyers of Iowa City, were married yesterday at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Bike Path in Jeopardy as Power Company Balks
description: GARY WLADYKA often rides a bicycle from his home in Miller Place to his shop, Rocky Point Cycle, two towns east. He pedals along the shoulder of busy Route 25A, where many cyclists are afraid to ride.

title: The Dispossessed
description: If Peter Godwins new book about Zimbabwe is part family memoir and part bulletin from the barricades, then these two streams converge at a portent so ominous it takes your breath away: A white in Africa is like a Jew everywhere  on sufferance, watching warily, waiting for the next great tidal swell of hostility.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: A record number of trees are expected to fall victim to gypsy moth caterpillars this year, according to the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, which predicts that 200,000 to 300,000 acres of trees will be defoliated by the pesky creatures.

title: A Guru for Achieving and Enjoying the Good Life
description: Madison

title: Erasing Tattoos, Out of Regret or for a New Canvas
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Kelly Brannigan was suffering from a case of tattoo remorse.

title: Pennington Gives the Jets an Arm Up on This Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., June 15  When Jets quarterback Chad Pennington fired a long pass to Justin McCareins for a touchdown late in Fridays minicamp practice, receiver Laveranues Coles helped him celebrate with a mock touchdown dance while Pennington watched and laughed.

title: Prosecutor in Duke Case Disbarred by Ethics Panel
description: RALEIGH, N.C., June 16  A state ethics panel on Saturday disbarred Michael B. Nifong, the Durham district attorney who pursued a false accusation of sexual assault against three Duke University lacrosse players, shortly after Mr. Nifong said through his lawyer that he thought disbarment was appropriate.

title: In the Prime of Their Time
description: BOTOX and plastic surgery allow actresses to look younger. Television is permitting them to act their age.

title: Endings Without Endings
description: HUH? The black screen at the end of the series-concluding episode of The Sopranos last Sunday caused thousands of viewers to leap from the couch and smack the cable box, suspecting a loose connection. So many sent e-mail messages to HBO that the companys Web site was temporarily jammed, and debate over the meaning and worthiness of this particular ending has continued on the blogs and next to the water cooler.

title: Matsuzaka Blanks Bonds and the Giants
description: BOSTON, June 16  Start with one of Americas most hitter-friendly stadiums, Fenway Park, and add Barry Bonds, one of baseballs most productive sluggers. What do you get?

title: Amanda McCormick, Matthew Bacal
description: Amanda Attilia McCormick, the daughter of Suzanne C. McCormick and Dr. James B. McCormick of Chicago, was married yesterday afternoon to Matthew Jack Bacal, the only son of Gail S. Bacal of Fairfield, Conn., and Jules M. Bacal of New York. The Rev. Wayne F. Prist, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Queen of All Saints Basilica in Chicago.

title: Tiers in My Eyes
description: How would you feel if you were running for president, knocking yourself out on the campaign trail, wheedling money out of people who dont owe you a favor, pressing whatever flesh that deigns to come to hand, answering gotcha! questions from choleric bloggers with a circulation of two and still  despite having the most cogent views on urgent issues and seized with an inspiring vision of America  find yourself consigned to the demeaning dungeon of politics, the second tier?

title: The Inner Lives of Men
description: Since academic novels usually focus on the nasty rivalries and inflated egos of their characters, they have served as vehicles for broad satire, not serious themes. One great exception is Willa Cathers 1925 novel, The Professors House. Cather used the traditional calling of a scholar and the atrophy of his marriage to convey her own growing alienation from the modern world. Her novel has only one successor, another book that invokes the life of learning as a rebuke to the wasteful wars and cheap compromises of the wider world. John Williamss Stoner is something rarer than a great novel  it is a perfect novel, so well told and beautifully written, so deeply moving, that it takes your breath away. Ignored on publication in 1965, a clamorous year, it has been kept alive by enthusiasts who go into print every decade to rediscover it, including Irving Howe in The New Republic in 1966, C. P. Snow in The Financial Times in 1973, Dan Wakefield in Ploughshares in 1981 and Steve Almond in Tin House in 2003. They invariably wonder why no one has heard of the book. Why isnt this book famous? Snow kept asking. Now, along with Williamss earlier novel, Butchers Crossing (1960), Stoner is available in a handsome reprint by New York Review Books. Both books deserve to be widely read, but their dark, comfortless vision raises the question of whether this can be expected.

title: Natures Engraver: A Life of Thomas Bewick
description: Printing from woodblocks is the oldest way of all. Before Gutenberg invented moveable type around 1450, books and broadsheets were produced by writing the text on wood in reverse, as in a mirror, and then cutting painstakingly round the letters, dabbing the block with ink and pressing paper on top. With the new metal type, printers still used the blocks for illustrations and a single block could be used over and over again, on different pages, in different books. The early cutters worked on the 'side-grain' of the wood, a plank cut along the trunk, often of a fruitwood such as pear or cherry, using carpenters' tools - knives, chisels and gouges. When designed by masters like Drer or Holbein these woodcuts could attain an astounding delicacy, but increasingly book publishers preferred to use copper engravings which gave a finer effect, and the crude woodcuts were banished to broadsides and chapbooks. Slowly, however, craftsmen tried using the dense end-grain of wood, sliced across the trunk or branch rather than along it like a plank. Boxwood proved the best, because box grows so slowly that the growth-lines are very close and on its hard surface the engravers could use the fine tools employed on silver or copper.

He and his wife were fugitive slaves from Kentucky who had settled in Toronto in 1834 and had gone on to become wealthy and successful businesspeople. The Thornton and Lucie Blackburn Site became the first archaeological dig on an Underground Railroad site in Canada.

(Harvest/Harcourt, $14. ) A presiding figure in the literature of the American West, Doig sets his latest novel, like most of his books, in rural Montana. His narrator, a school superintendent named Paul Milliron, looks back to the fall of 1909, when he was 13 and his recently widowed father answered a newspaper ad from a woman seeking employment. The housekeeper, Rose Llewellyn, is as feisty and willful as she is charming, and she brings with her a surprise guest  her scholarly brother, who, after the elopement of the communitys only teacher, takes over the one-room schoolhouse. The land and its people  the family, the neighbors  are laid out before us with a fresh, natural openness, Sven Birkerts wrote in the Book Review.

Brake dust is on my face, in my hair, in my ears, and under my nails. Whether I like it or not, Ill be bringing home a pound or two of Corvette brake dust as a souvenir.

description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Back in the 1960s, the hippie counterculture briefly looked like a political opposition to a protracted war. At Bonnaroo this year, hippie fashion statements also go with protest songs and anti-Bush pronouncements. Perhaps thats no suprise at a festival that includes longtime politically inclined rappers like the Roots, Michael Franti and El-P, who tour to the same collegiate audience that comes to Bonnaroo. Fridays lineup also included Manu Chao, the globe-trotting, mostly Spanish-speaking songwriter whose hopped-up reggae and ska songs decry violence and poverty, support human rights (especially for immigrants and displaced people) and savor romance and marijuana.

For me, that would be the set by the guitarist Keller Williams and his group WMDs, with both Mr. Williams and a second guitarist trading Garcias bluegrass-like picking and chromatic slides while the band picked up a Dead-style lilt. The homage was obvious; it was also a pretty good one.

title: Dr. McIvers Pain; Richard Paeys Hope

If youve read Tina Rosenbergs excellent article on Dr. Ronald McIver, you know the answer to that question posed on the cover of the Times Magazine: When a prosecutor and a few jurors think they know more about medicine than he does. It didnt matter that there was no evidence Dr. McIver intentionally dealt drugs  hes serving a 30-year sentence for not meeting the jurors standards of pain treatment.

title: Bonnaroo: The Police  Vital and Experimental
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.  Of course the reunited Police belonged at Bonnaroo, the festival built on jam bands. What disappeared when the band broke up in 1983 was a chance to hear the interaction of three musicians whose blend and friction forged one of rocks most original ensemble sounds. They left behind terse, neatly arranged studio albums and a few live recordings. Now, on tour again, they are jamming the alternatives. Their Bonnaroo set interspersed familiar arrangements with new ones, often within the same song. There were sparks, teases, intriguing excursions and a few misfires, but the Police sounded vital, still fascinated by Stings songs and ready to tear into them anew.

Valentino will have a 45th blow-out in Rome. Theres a sense, however, that couture is again in some kind of transit phase. The Valentino company has a new owner and theres a question of what will happen to couture when Valentino retires. This past Thursday, in Paris, I sat down with Alber Elbaz to ask what couture means to a younger generation of design innovators. What would induce a designer like Elbaz, or Marc Jacobs, or Nicolas Ghesquiere, to want to be part of an old-school couture house? Are theyand fashionmissing something?

To mollify people just outside the zone who feared their streets would turn into parking lots, the Senate bill would allow the city to issue permits so that most parking spots would be restricted to neighborhood residents.

title: The Death of an Italian Innovator
description: Wire services in Italy and France report this evening in Italy that Gianfranco Ferre has died at the age of 62. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Friday in Milan and was hospitalized. Ferre was for many years a leading designer in Milan, beginning his career in the mid 1970s after receiving a degree in architecture. There was always something over-the-top about Ferres clothesthe white shirt collars always high and sculptural, the leather often laced and assertive, the coats swinging. I once began a review of a Ferre show, in the early 90s, with: Diva, can you dig it? His clothes had a great sexual energy, if you got your head into them, and I loved that he didnt seem to care a jot about trends and skinny models and so forth. His Dior period was not especially memorable, at least for me, and perhaps thats because he never seemed very happy there (living in the Plaza Athenee), and of course Dior in the early 90s was in transition, not the old style but not quite yet the new era of Galliano and Bernard Arnault.

The first, heard in the months before the war, when Israelis feared a second Holocaust at the hands of their Arab neighbors, is of a sign hanging near the boarding gate at the national airport, asking the last one out of the country to turn off the lights. The second, told after the six days in which Israel defeated the armies of Egypt, Syria and Jordan and quadrupled the territory under its control, involves two officers talking about how to spend their day.  Lets conquer Cairo, one proposes. The other replies, But what will we do after lunch?

The accident occurred at 3:20 p.m. on the northbound side of Flatbush at East 29th Street. One teenager, 15, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in extremely critical condition, the police said. A man with him, whose age was unknown, was in critical condition at the same hospital, while a 16-year-old was in critical condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. Alcohol was not a factor in the accident, and the driver was not charged yesterday afternoon, the police said. Neither the driver nor a passenger in the car was seriously injured.

title: Operas Inner Soap Dishes the Divas
description: An opera wife I know used to describe the atmosphere backstage as  Peyton Place with classical music in the background. In The Second Tosca, which opened June 13 at the 45th Street Theater, the playwright Tom Rowan taps the comic potential of this promising environment. The aging diva trying for one more triumph? The ambitious, coldhearted conductor? Sex, jealousy and the ghosts of the past? They are all here, drawn in enough detail to transcend mere caricature, brought to life by an excellent cast and enlivened with a lot of humor. The piece is not without its flaws; still, even nonopera lovers should enjoy themselves.

title: In France, Socialists First Couple Are No More
description: PARIS, June 18  A day after President Nicolas Sarkozys conservative party captured a smaller majority in the French Parliament than expected, the Socialist Party was struggling to adjust to the awkward reality that its first couple  Sgolne Royal and Franois Hollande  had split up.

title: Another Attempt to Match Readers and Relevant News
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17  Ian Clarke was a 23-year-old computer scientist living in Scotland in 2000 when he started a global controversy by deploying an online system called Freenet. The system was intended to make it possible to share information anonymously, and to make it virtually impossible to remove from the Internet once it was placed there.

title: In Beginning, Even Jeter Doubted Jeter
description: This was before the 2,242 hits, before the four World Series rings, before he became the captain of the Yankees and before he attracted comparisons to Joe DiMaggio. This was Derek Jeter in Tampa, Fla., 15 years ago. This was Jeters first day playing professionally for the Yankees.

title: Things Going Right for Red Sox, but for All the Wrong Reasons
description: BOSTON, June 17  An hour before the Red Sox played the Giants in the middle game of their weekend series, Boston catcher Jason Varitek jumped up in front of his locker, knocked over his chair, kicked one of his shoes across the room and shouted as he dived on the floor of the Fenway Park clubhouse.

title: A British Channel and Its Two Faces
description: LONDON, June 17  First came Embarrassing Illnesses, in which doctors advised young Britons on how to deal with ailments like anal warts. That was followed by Big Brother, the reality television series in which misfits are locked into a house and prodded until their behavior turns embarrassing.

title: Not Everyone Wants Channel Thats All Big Ten, All the Time
description: One barometer for classic sports conflict in the Big Ten is Ohio State and Michigan at the Big House in Ann Arbor. But a percolating fight between the conference and Comcast is evolving into a battle that Keith Jackson, in his rumbling baritone, might call one between two big uglies.

title: The Supreme Courts Bonus Babies
description: Washington

title: Gianfranco Ferr, Italian Designer, Dies at 62
description: Gianfranco Ferr, the Italian fashion designer noted for a consistently singular vision in his signature ready-to-wear collection and for opening the doors of French haute couture to foreign-born designers, died Sunday night in Milan. He was 62.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Four Proves Bigger Than Thirteen

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guards commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral. (Go to Article)

title: Two Cheers on Global AIDS
description: Now that the Group of 8 industrialized nations has pledged to commit $60 billion to combat AIDS and other diseases around the world in coming years  a substantial sum by any reckoning  Congress and other national legislatures ought to look hard for additional funds to close a looming gap between the funds committed and the needs of desperate patients.

title: Postmodern Thoughts, Illuminated by the Practices of a Premodern Tribe
description: News of the death of the philosopher Richard Rorty on June 8 came as I was reading about a small Brazilian tribe that the French anthropologist Claude Lvi-Strauss studied in the 1930s. A strange accident, a haphazard juxtaposition  but for a moment this pragmatist philosopher and a fading tribal culture glanced against each other, revealing something unusual about the contemporary scene.

title: Lottery Numbers
Furyks Emotional Charge Up the Leader Board Fizzles on the 17th
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 17  A second United States Open title was in Jim Furyks grasp Sunday as he stood on the No. 17 tee, gripping his driver.

title: Showing Style With Black and Gold, or Giving Cause for Arrest?
description: Fashion has always been something of a uniform. Goths, hippies, preppies, Madison Avenue ladies who lunch: each group has its look.

title: In Ethiopia, Fear and Cries of Army Brutality
description: IN THE OGADEN DESERT, Ethiopia  The rebels march 300 strong across the crunchy earth, young men with dreadlocks and AK-47s slung over their shoulders.

title: Wind Helps Push Bonds Closer to Mark
description: BOSTON, June 17  On Friday night, on his first visit to Fenway Park, Barry Bonds hit a long fly ball that looked like a home run as it passed high above the foul pole in right field. But it was ruled foul.

title: New Lyrics for Israel
description: AS Israel prepares to celebrate its 60th birthday next year, its time to update its national anthem, Hatikvah (The Hope). Only a single phrase needs to be changed: nefesh Yehudi, which means a Jewish soul, should be replaced with nefesh Israeli, an Israeli soul. Why tamper with a beautiful, stirring hymn? To solve what we might call the Hatikvah contradiction.

title: Classic Qualities Have Role in Contemporary Sound
description: Few composers represent the shock of the new as convincingly as Iannis Xenakis, who transmuted the impersonal logic of higher mathematics into sounds of elemental power and daunting ferocity. Xenakis hardly reinvented music from scratch: the precision of Bach, the feeling of inevitability associated with Beethoven, Chopins poetry and Debussys painterly quality can all be heard in his 1980 piano work, Mists. But when Marc Ponthus opened the first concert of the Institute and Festival for Contemporary Performance on Friday night with an exhilarating account of that piece, it seemed to herald a radical break from convention, along with a compelling embrace of the new and unexpected.

title: End Looms for Iraq Arms Inspection Unit
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 16  The search for Saddam Husseins weapons of mass destruction appears close to an official conclusion, several years after their absence became a foregone one.

title: A Festival With More Than Just Jam-Bands
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn., June 17  Each year the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival insists its not just a hippie jam-band festival. This year two of Bonnaroos three headliners came from way off the jam-band circuit  Tool on Friday night and the Police on Saturday. Other performers on the three-and-a-half-day schedule spanned British rock, Canadian pop, soul, bluegrass, reggae, jazz and alternative hip-hop along with jam-band stalwarts like Sundays finale headliner, Widespread Panic.

title: Europeans Fear New U.S. Requirement Could Hurt Travelers
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Measures moving through Congress, including a requirement for travelers in some countries to register travel plans online 48 hours before departure, have raised fears in Europe of disruptions in the trans-Atlantic flow of business and leisure travel.

title: Air Force Hopes to Cut Oils Role in Fuel
description: The United States Air Force has decided to push development of a new type of fuel to power its bombers and fighters, mixing conventional jet fuel with fuels from nonpetroleum sources that could eventually limit military dependence on imported oil.

title: End Vietnams Air War
description: Sun Valley, Idaho

title: Editors Charge: His Lawyer Fell Short
description: People like to gripe about their lawyers after their cases go south. Listen, for instance, to Norman Pearlstine, who presided over the debacle that ended with Time Inc.s disclosure of the identity of a source to a special prosecutor two summers ago.

title: Wang, Baffling Mets, Extends Yankees June Push
description: For a team that is having trouble scoring, the most welcome sight is a grooved fastball or a hanging curve. The Mets are as good at pummeling those pitches as any team. But batters cannot hit those pitches if they do not exist. And last night they were few and far between.

title: Abbas Swears In Emergency Government
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, June 17  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, swore in an emergency government at his headquarters here on Sunday, reasserting his authority over the West Bank days after Fatahs rival, Hamas, routed his forces in Gaza and seized power there.

title: True Winner at Oakmont: The Course
description: Oakmont, Pa.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC This summer is the 10th anniversary of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and the usually reticent Princes William, 24, and Harry, 22, are speaking out. They discuss the tribute concert for their mother and their lives since her death, as well as their memories of her, with Matt Lauer (above right, with Princes Harry, left, and William).

title: Veterans Giselle, Full of Spontaneity, and No Apologies
description: NEW HAVEN, June 15  While glasnost was a buzzword, no ballerina exemplified it better than Nina Ananiashvili. When, after a long hiatus, the Bolshoi began again to tour Britain and America in 1986-7, she was its youngest star, marvelously fresh in the full-length Raymonda and Giselle. She soon began interleaving her Bolshoi career with engagements in the West. She has danced Balanchine with New York City Ballet, Ashton and MacMillan with the Royal Ballet of London, Bournonville with the Royal Danish Ballet, Petipa with the Kirov Ballet: That is, she, like no one else, has gone to all the main choreographic centers of ballet classicism to dance their home choreography, and she remains too a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater. (She dances Swan Lake there on June 28.)

title: Marvel Wants to Flex Its Own Heroic Muscles as a Moviemaker
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17  This month David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was discussing plot points in his Beverly Hills office with Edward Norton, the Academy Award-nominated actor whom he has cast as the star of a new version of The Incredible Hulk.

title: Taking On Big Donors, McCain Takes a Big Risk
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  A ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee like Senator John McCain could normally bank on a bonanza of campaign contributions from the defense industry, especially if he was under pressure to raise money fast.

title: Checking In With Glimmer Twins, Plato and Aristotle
description: Meet Aristotle sporting Doc Martens, and hear Plato interpreted by the light of a disco ball at the new kooky klassics double feature at the Kitchen.

title: Long Reviled, Merit Pay Gains Among Teachers
description: MINNEAPOLIS  For years, the unionized teaching profession opposed few ideas more vehemently than merit pay, but those objections appear to be eroding as school districts in dozens of states experiment with plans that compensate teachers partly based on classroom performance.

title: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up
description: Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce tomorrow that is will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to people close to the company.

title: After Bus Attack, Afghan Police Mourn Their Own
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 17  A mammoth explosion tore through a police bus in the heart of Kabul on Sunday morning, killing at least 24 people  22 of them police academy instructors on their way to work  in one of the deadliest insurgent attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

title: New CDs
description: BON JOVI Lost Highway (Island)

title: Tiny but Hungry, Moth May Peril California Crops
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 15  Full grown, the light brown apple moth is roughly the size of a nickel: a little dirt-colored insect with an adult life span shorter than the average summer vacation.

title: On the Campaign Trail With Elizabeth Edwards
description: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16  Elizabeth Edwards was holding court in the sweltering basement at the Cedar County Courthouse in Tipton, where local Democrats fanned themselves under fluorescent light. Her husband, John Edwards, making his second run for the presidency, watched and winced as she quizzed her audience about what they knew of his biography.

title: Cabrera Is Last Man Standing at U.S. Open
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 17  He took deep drags from a stubby cigarette and footlong divots from Oakmont Country Club until, at last, ngel Cabrera walked off the 18th green with the hopes of a nation and the burden of a lead in a major championship.

title: During Intermission, Cellphones Are Brandished in a Promotion
description: Typically you are told to turn off your cellphone before a performance. But at a recent Saturday matinee of Spring Awakening, the Broadway musical that garnered eight Tony Awards last week, the audience was told to do just the opposite.

title: The Best Judges Business Can Buy
description: The problem of wealthy interests trying to influence court decisions by pouring money into state judicial elections continues to escalate, according to a newly released report. So does the threat to the impartiality, independence and integrity of the nations courts. If the courts are going to pursue justice rather than advance special-interest agendas, states must either adopt public financing and strict fund-raising rules for judicial elections or switch to a nonelective merit selection system.

title: Restaurant Reservations Go Online
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17  Town Hall, one of the busiest restaurants in this food-crazed city, seems the very model of old-fashioned dining. Patrons who arrive to claim their reserved seats are greeted by a hostess who consults a piece of paper with the days reservations and leads her guests to the appointed table.

title: Fashion Writer Sentenced in Attack on Woman
description: Peter Braunstein, the former writer for Womens Wear Daily who was convicted on charges that on Halloween 2005, while dressed as a firefighter, he tied up, sexually molested and terrorized a former colleague, was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison today.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Rights for Car Passengers
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  A passenger as well as a driver has the right to challenge the legality of a police officers decision to stop a car, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Talks for Chip Software Maker Are Said to Bog Down on Price
description: Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, according to people close to the matter.

title: Vowing to Love, Cherish and Root for Brooklyn Cyclones
description: The rush begins in midwinter. The pantry needs stocking, credit cards are paid off and spring cleaning begins well before the last frost has thawed.

title: Justices Turn Back Antitrust Suits Against Wall St. Firms
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court ruled in favor of more than a dozen Wall Street investment banks today as it found that they could not be sued under antitrust law over losses in the crash of technology stocks seven years ago.

title: Short and Happy (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: 18-Month-Old Run Over in Driveway
description: An 18-month-old boy was killed when he was run over by a neighbors car in a Flatbush driveway yesterday shortly after 5 p.m., the police said. The boy was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The neighbor, who was backing the car out on East 26th Street near Avenue I, was unaware of the accident and drove away from the scene. It is unclear whether the toddler was being supervised when he was hit. No charges are expected to be filed against the neighbor, the police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about proposed new anti-terrorism regulations for small boats gave the wrong rank for the Coast Guards commandant, Thad W. Allen. He is an admiral, not a vice admiral.

title: Ex-Businessman Wins Runoff for Dallas Mayor
description: DALLAS, June 17 Voters here on Saturday chose a retired businessman as their next mayor, ending a bid by a three-term city councilman who if elected would have become the first openly gay elected leader of a major American city.

title: Robert Tracy, 52, Dance Writer, Is Dead
description: Robert Tracy, a prolific dance writer, died on June 7 in Manhattan. He was 52.

title: Iraqi Journalist Found Dead as Security Lags
description: BAGHDAD, June 17  The body of the political editor of a government-financed newspaper was found Sunday in the main Baghdad mortuary.

title: Sir Wally Herbert, Explorer of the Iciest Corners on Earth, Dies at 72
description: Sir Wally Herbert, the first man to walk across the icebound Arctic Ocean and, some contend, the first to reach the North Pole on foot, a feat long credited to Rear Adm. Robert E. Peary, died Tuesday in Scotland at 72.

title: Computer Cookies and How They Crumble
description: Tiny files called cookies are the lifeblood of online advertising. When a computer visits a site or sees an ad for the first time, the sites server slips a cookie onto the visitors hard drive, identifying the computer in future dealings with that site or ad network. Cookies let online hosts determine the number of unique visitors they reach, a key metric for advertisers.

title: Preppie Afro-Pop and Other Odd Blends
description: For a proactive indie-rock fan in 2007 a debut album is more like an end product than a starting point. By the time that first shrink-wrapped and bar-coded CD finds its way into shops, the band will probably be old news, having suffered through many online cycles of hype and backlash. In a world that wont wait patiently for an album release date, it probably makes more sense to talk about a debut MP3, a debut YouTube appearance, a debut MySpace page.

title: Conquering the Peak Test of Technology
description: AFTER weeks of climbing, Rod Baber recently reached the summit of Mount Everest, a dream fulfilled. At the top of the world, as dawn was breaking, he took off his oxygen mask and called his voice mailbox, leaving an exuberant, if weary, message.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Brooklyn: Two Killed in Crashes
description: Two men died and a third man was seriously injured in two motor vehicle accidents Saturday night and early yesterday, the police said. A 58-year-old man was killed when he drove a Mercedes-Benz through a fence and into a parked car at 3:45 a.m. yesterday at Pennsylvania Avenue near the Belt Parkway. In the other accident, a 27-year-old man was killed and his passenger, also a man in his 20s, suffered head and neck injuries when the motorcycle they were riding collided with a 1999 Ford Taurus at 10 p.m. Saturday at Rockaway Parkway and Church Avenue in Brownsville. The injured man was listed in stable condition at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. No charges were expected.

title: Gore to Bring Talk of Green to Ad Festival
description: The brightest lights in the advertising business are gathering in Cannes, France, this week for an annual celebration of the art of persuading consumers to part with their money. In the industrys biggest international get-together, awards will be given for the best ads for products like cars, clothing, food and air travel.

title: G.E. and Pearson Are Said to Study Bid for Dow Jones
description: The General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, and Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, are exploring a joint bid for Dow Jones & Company to rival an offer made by the News Corporation, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: New Capos Taut Smiles at HBO
description: The keening that followed the 11 seconds of inky blackness at the end of The Sopranos finale has finally begun to die down. But the executives at HBO could be forgiven for feeling like they are still staring into that dark place.

title: Democrats Press Plan to Channel Billions in Oil Subsidies to Renewable Fuels
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  Senate Democrats are seeking a major reversal of energy tax policies that would take billions of dollars in tax breaks and other benefits from the oil industry to underwrite renewable fuels.

title: Gunmen Kill Palestinian at Israeli-Gaza Border
description: JERUSALEM, June 18  A Palestinian man was killed Monday at the volatile and closed border between Israel and Gaza, after Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers, officials said. The incident took place near the area where several hundred people trying to flee Gaza have been camped out, and Israeli troops fired back.

title: 7 Afghan Children Killed in U.S.-Led Airstrike
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 18  Seven children were killed during an airstrike by the American-led coalition against a religious compound thought to be an Al Qaeda sanctuary in remote eastern Afghanistan, the coalition reported today.

title: Staking His Campaign on Iowa, Edwards Makes a Populist Pitch to the Left
description: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16  Four years ago  facing what seemed to be a certain defeat in the Iowa Democratic caucuses  John Edwards recast his presidential campaign with weeks to go before the vote, unveiling an emotionally powerful speech about poverty that he delivered relentlessly across the state. Mr. Edwards came within a few thousand votes of victory. To this day, he tells associates he would have won with another week.

title: Autism Debate Strains a Family and Its Charity
description: A year after their grandson Christian received a diagnosis of autism in 2004, Bob Wright, then chairman of NBC/Universal, and his wife, Suzanne, founded Autism Speaks, a mega-charity dedicated to curing the dreaded neurological disorder that affects one of every 150 children in America today.

title: Retail Giant Will Remake Private Bank
description: Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank's reputation in catering to the very rich.

title: Pigs With Cellphones, but No Condoms
description: IN a commercial for Trojan condoms that has its premiere tonight, women in a bar are surrounded by anthropomorphized, cellphone-toting pigs. One shuffles to the mens room, where, after procuring a condom from a vending machine, he is transformed into a head-turner in his 20s. When he returns to the bar, a fetching blond who had been indifferent now smiles at him invitingly.

title: In Defense, the Timing Is Everything
description: The most common defensive error is not counting. The diagramed deal features another common defensive card-play error. It arose during the HBL International Pairs, the opening event at the Peek Freans 14th Asia and Middle East Bridge Championships in Karachi, Pakistan, in May.

title: Matching Masterpieces With Historys Flash Points
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when popularizer was a derogatory term used by academics to dismiss the popularity of a more successful colleague.

title: Private Equity Deal Expected for Lexicon Pharmaceuticals
description: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, is expected to announce today that it has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

title: Dinner With a Warlord
description: A HILLTOP IN EASTERN CONGO

title: Police to Adopt Changes Following Fatal Shooting
description: The New York Police Department is moving to require officers to take breathalyzer tests whenever anyone is killed or wounded by police action, and to psychologically screen candidates for undercover work, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced today, accepting the recommendations of a panel formed after an unarmed man was fatally shot in Queens in a volley of 50 police bullets.

title: Muddy Waters
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers have finally issued guidelines about which streams and wetlands are subject to federal jurisdiction. Unfortunately, they are just as confusing as the Supreme Court decision they are supposed to carry out  guaranteeing endless litigation, while increasing the chances that valuable wetlands will be needlessly destroyed.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the way cancer doctors practice medicine misstated a title for Dr. Peter Eisenberg. He is a former director of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, not a current director. His term ended on June 4. The article also misstated the price of Avastin, a cancer drug. For an average lung cancer patient, it is $8,800 a month, not $8,800 a dose.

title: Coney Island Plan Is Scaled Back, but Critics Are Skeptical
description: The developer who wants to remake Coney Islands amusement district has a new plan and says that youre going to love it.

title: Queens: Man Shot by Police in Critical Condition
description: A man who was shot by police officers on Saturday night after the authorities said he refused to drop a pellet gun that looked like a handgun remained in critical but stable condition yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. The man was identified as Luis A. Dominguez, 49, of Rosedale. The shooting occurred near his home shortly before 9 p.m., when several officers surrounded him and repeatedly ordered him to drop the gun before firing several shots, witnesses and the police said. Mr. Dominguez was shot in the torso, the police said. A lieutenant suffered a minor shoulder injury, and the police said yesterday it was unclear whether the lieutenant had been grazed by a bullet from a fellow officer. An investigation is continuing, the police said. A neighbor said Mr. Dominguez was prone to hostility when he had been drinking. He kept going up the street, hiding behind a tree with the gun, said the neighbor, Zita Young, 43. I ran to the deli to get one of the guys to see if they could talk to him or help him. By that time we heard the gunshots go off. I wasnt counting, but it was a lot.

title: Doctor, Give Me the News, and Sew Me Up Pretty
description: The deglamorization that doctors have suffered with the rise of H.M.O.s in American life has had its corrective on television, where medical dramas seem to labor ever more aggressively to establish the physicians genius. It is an immensely long gurney ride from the era of St. Elsewhere in the 1980s to the current moment of House, on which Hugh Laurie represents medicine as a field not of workaday mechanics but of brash intellectualism and analytical skill. How could a mere M.D. suffice?

title: Journeys Song Gets a Bump From TV Once Again
description: The Sopranos is over, but the last song featured on the show, Dont Stop Believin,  which the band Journey released in 1981, keeps going as its lyrics say, on and on and on and on.

title: Envoy Sees North Korea Progress
description: BEIJING, June 18  North Korea could be ready to begin shutting its plutonium producing reactor within weeks as the first step toward disabling the unit by the end of this year, the top American negotiator on the Norths nuclear weapons program said here today.

title: For A-Rod and Critics, Its Now Wait and See
description: An hour after the Yankees defeated the Mets in the second game of a three-game series, Alex Rodriguez poked his head into Joe Torres office. Torre had finished his postgame interviews and most members of the news media had left when Rodriguez stopped by.

title: Hey, Giovanni, Put a Shirt on. Youll Catch Cold.
description: LONDON, June 17  The Royal Opera House in Covent Garden recently broadcast its production of Mozarts Don Giovanni on outdoor screens around this city, part of the BP Summer Big Screens initiative. The revival of this grippingly spare and psychologically probing 2002 staging by the director Francesca Zambello, shown on Friday evening, was especially suited to big-screen close-ups thanks to an exceptionally attractive and involving cast.

title: The half-century mortgage
description: How would you feel about paying off your mortgage over the next 50 years? This week, a specialist broker in Britain called The Mortgage Lender announced it was developing a mortgage spanning half a century. The idea is that monthly payments are reduced to a more manageable level.

title: A hidden treasure at the British Museum
description: Bristish Museum (AP)

title: Second Stages New Season
description: The New York premiere of Edward Albee's "Peter and Jerry" and the world premiere of "Farragut North," a dark political comedy by Beau Willimon, are among the offerings in Second Stage Theater's 2007-8 season, the company is to announce today.

title: Another Attempt to Match Readers and Relevant News
description: Ian Clarke, the computer scientist who sparked global controversy with his online system called Freenet, which was intended to make it possible to share information anonymously and to make it virtually impossible to be removed from the Internet once it was placed there, is at it again.

title: Lexicon Strikes Two Deals with Private Equity
description: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

title: Stock Exchanges Continue Game of Musical Chairs
description: Unconfirmed reports Friday that the New York Mercantile Exchange is seeking a buyer at the same time that the Chicago Board of Trade is in the throes of a merger agreement re-emphasized what a tumultuous period this is for the worlds financial markets, as they focus nearly as much on buying and selling each other as they do on trading products.

title: C.I.A.s Venture Fund Spends on Surveillance Software Firm
description: In-Q-Tel, a private investment firm launched by the Central Intelligence Agency to support domestic intelligence agencies, has invested in an image sensor maker Pixim, the company said last week. The investment was part of a $15 million funding round announced in March that included Tallwood Venture Capital, Ridgewood Capital and the Mayfield Fund.

title: Private Equity Firm Takes Majority Stake in Taiwan Bank
description: Consolidation in Taiwans banking sector continues as a private equity firm, The Longreach Group, announced at the end of last week that it would invest 23 billion New Taiwan dollars ($694 million) to acquire 51 percent of the EnTie Commercial Bank.

title: S.E.C. to Probe Hain Celestials Practices
description: The Hain Celestial Group said Friday it had been informed by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the agency is conducting an informal inquiry into the companys stock option practices. Hain, the American company that makes organic and natural foods and personal care items, said it would cooperate with the investigation.

title: Wachovia Named in Brokerage Lawsuit
description: Wachovia, which agreed last month to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, has been added to a federal lawsuit accusing large brokerages of moving customers idle cash into low-yielding accounts to boost profits.

title: Microsoft Takes Stake in Chinese Game Maker
description: Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said. Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.

title: Boutique Bank Said to Be Prepping Rival Bid for Sanctuary
description: The battle for the British music group Sanctuary may not be over yet, with a London-listed investment bank, Crosby Capital Partners, preparing a counterbid to trump Universal Music Groups 20 pence-per-share offer, according to The Guardian. Crosby, which has offices in Hong Kong and London, has appointed lawyers from SJ Berwin to help make its offer for the troubled music group, which manages Sir Elton John and James Blunt, the report said.

title: Frances Areva Bids $2.3 Billion for Uranium Producer
description: The French nuclear giant Areva has presented a cash bid worth 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) for UraMin, a South Africa-headquartered company interlisted on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Areva said Friday it is bidding 7.75 Canadian dollars per share for UraMin stock, which closed Thursday at 7.94 Canadian dollars.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Is Said to Lead Bidding for Air Canada Unit
description: Air Canada Technical Services will name a buyer as early as Monday, and signs point to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts edging out Lufthansa Technik Group of Germany in a close race, according to The Globe and Mail.

title: G.E. and Pearson Explore Bid for Dow Jones
description: After making an overture to Microsoft about a joint bid for Dow Jones, the General Electric Company, the parent of NBC, is now exploring that idea with Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, according to reports on Monday. The talks are still preliminary, and Rupert Murdochs $5 billion offer for Dow Jones represents a a very high threshold, The New York Times said. The Wall Street Journal quoted several sources describing the possibility of a deal as a long shot.

title: British Paint Maker Rejects $14 Billion Bid from Dutch Rival
description: Shares in Imperial Chemical Industries  of Britain, the maker of Dulux paints, rose 16 percent Monday after it rejected a 7.2 billion pound ($14.2 billion) takeover bid from Akzo Nobel, a Dutch rival and the maker of Crown paints.

title: Everquest Financial Linked to Troubled Bear Fund
description: As Bear Stearns struggles with big losses at one of its hedge funds, MarketWatch notes that the troubled fund has ties to Everquest Financial, a company that filed plans for an initial public offering last month.

title: Chadbourne & Parke in Merger Talks With U.K. Law Firm
description: The New York law firm Chadbourne & Parke is in preliminary merger discussions with the Watson, Farley & Williams law firm of London, Chadbournes managing partner, Charlie ONeill, told The American Lawyer magazine.

title: Backed By Merrill, Marvel Flexes Moviemaking Muscles
description: David Maisel, the newly minted chairman of Marvel Studios, was until recently a little-known deal maker trained by the former kingpin Michael S. Ovitz.

title: John Edwards in Iowa
description: On the campaign trail with John Edwards in Iowa, where he has made the state the place where his candidacy will rise or fall.

title: Finish Line Laces Up Deal With Genesco
description: Finish Line, the footwear retailer, said Monday it had agreed to buy Genesco, which owns the teenager-focused Journeys sneaker chain and the Johnston & Murphy brand of dress shoes, for $1.5 billion, or $54.50 a share. The deal, which the boards of directors at both companies are supporting, came after Genesco rejected two bids from Foot Locker, the second of which was for $51 a share.

title: Buyout Shops Prep I.P.O. for Hedge Fund Administrator
description: The hedge fund administrator GlobeOp is planning to make an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange. GlobeOp said it hoped to get $102 million for the 20.4-million-share offering. A Boston buyout specialist, TA Associates, and Mezzanine Management are offering the stock and will both retain a significant holding in GlobeOp after the shares are sold.

title: BHP Considers New $40 Billion Bid for Alcoa, Report Says
description: BHP Billiton, the worlds largest mining company, has revived plans for a $40 billion (20.2 billion) takeover of Alcoa, according to The Times of London. The newspaper, without citing any named sources, said BHP is in the early stages of evaluating the merits of a takeover. BHP, based in Melbourne, is not thought to have formally approached Alcoa, the Times reported.

title: Private Equity Mania Sours Plays for Short Sellers
description: Is private equity raining on short-sellers parade?

title: 2008: The Iowa Trail
