description: The campaign trail through Iowa was well-worn this weekend as many of the presidential candidates made stops in the state. Former Senator John Edwards is one of the hopefuls who have been crisscrossing Iowa in recent days, and as The Timess Adam Nagourney reports, for Mr. Edwards it is part of a strategy that reflects just how much he has settled on this state as the place where his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination will rise or fall. But Mr. Edwards is running a different kind of campaign this time around than in 2004 when he lost the Iowa caucuses to Senator John Kerry:

title: Morning Buzz: Coney Dreams, Broken Buses, Soup to Nuts
description: Is Coney Island  where a storied past and dilapidated present have been the stubborn reality for as long as anyone can remember  about to get its groove back?

title: Simons Antes Up for Buyout Fund
description: James Simons, founder of the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies and a top earner in his field, is putting some of his cash into a new leveraged buyout fund, according to Long Island Business News. Mr. Simons, who led Alpha Magazines list of the top 25 hedge fund earners, is the largest investor in a new $115 million leveraged buyout fund raised by Topspin Partners, the report said.

title: Bank of America to Remake Its Private Bank
description: The Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private banks reputation in catering to the very rich.

title: Talks for Chip Software Maker Are Said to Bog Down on Price
description: Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, The New York Times reported.

title: Immigration to Resurface in the Senate
description: The immigration bill is scheduled to make its reappearance in the Senate by the end of this week but the outlook for its future depends on who you ask.

title: On the Trail With Mrs. Edwards
description: In his Web column today, Adam Nagourney writes about the Edwards campaigns recent swing through Iowa:

title: Forget Boxes, Move the Whole House!
description: The Lede ended last week focused on digging up a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere in Tulsa, so why not start this one off with the relocation of an 1883 carriage house in Portland?

title: Investors Cool to Goldmans Hedge Funds
description: Goldman Sachss alternative investment funds, including its hedge funds, experienced net inflows of zero in the latest quarter for the first time since the bank began reporting such data in 2004, the Financial News said. Last year, by comparison, the bank reported net inflows of $32 billion.

title: The Human Cost of War
description: I saw my first patient in the Congo today. Her name is Yohanita Nyiahabimana. She is a 41-year old woman who lives in the village of Malehe, about an hour from Goma. She was carried out of her house by her neighbors when they heard that we were coming. There she lay on some tattered blankets, all 50 pounds of her under the unforgiving African sun.

title: Cadbury Expected to Sell Beverage Unit, Including 7-Up
description: Cadbury Schweppes is preparing to announce Tuesday that it will sell its American beverage business, which includes 7-Up, Dr Pepper and Snapple, according to The New York Times. Cadbury said in March that it would split its confectionary and soft drinks businesses, but had not determined whether it would sell the beverage business or spin it off.

title: Giving Blood but Getting Nothing
description: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused suspicions in Brazil. Joaquina Karitiana says researchers broke promises to her tribe.

title: Bonnaroo: An Afternoon of Death
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Sunday was for the Bonnaroo diehards. The big mainstream headliners, Tool and the Police, were gone, and so were some of their fans. Theafternoon lineup leaned toward roots and bluesand, for some reason, songs about death. I started my afternoon with Mavis Staples, who recently released, Well Never Turn Back (Anti), an album of songs from her days in the civil-rights movement. She sang some of them, along with her gospel-soul hit, Ill Take You There; then, since it was Fathers Day, she dedicated a song to her dad, Roebuck Staples, who led the Staple Singers. It was Will the Circle Be Unbrokena funeral songsung with gutsy rasps and the optimism of a gospel believer.

title: Bonnaroo:Ornette Coleman Collapses
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.The jazz composer, saxophonist, trumpeter and violinist Ornette Coleman, 77, collapsed during his Bonnaroo set. He was playing one of his tenderly quizzical ballad lines on alto saxophone when he toppled suddenly to the stage. A few minutes later, he was helped to his feet, sipped some water and was walked off the stage. Suffering from heat exhaustion and dehydration, he was given fluids, taken to a local hospital and released a few hours later.

title: Bill Targets Blackstone, But Who Really Gets Hurt?
description: It seems aimed squarely at the Blackstone Group, but last weeks bill proposing to raise taxes on publicly traded buyout funds, if it were to become law, would probably cause many other firms to reconsider the idea of getting ticker symbols of their own. That could mean less of the transparency that many lawmakers were hoping to see in the industry, and might even result in less taxes for Treasury coffers, not more, Andrew Ross Sorkin wrote in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times.

title: Bonnaroo: A Marriage Proposal During the White Stripes
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Now I get it. Years ago, when I saw the White Stripes in clubs, they struck me as a loud, unsubtle, monotonous remake of a remake: everything I had disliked about 1970s blues-rock, reincarnated in artsy red, black and white clothes. The wacky Get Behind Me Satan partly changed my mind, convincing me that the White Stripes wanted no part of blues-country-roots authenticity. And at Bonnaroo, where they played to tens of thousands of people at the outdoor Which Stage, they made even more sense.

title: Topps to Postpone Vote on Private Equity Buyout
description: Topps said Monday that it would postpone a vote on a $385 million buyout offer by two private equity firms, including one run by Michael D. Eisner, after a Delaware chancery court judge ruled that the baseball card maker must disclose more information about the deal. Topps said it would also allow a rival, Upper Deck, to make a tender offer to its shareholders, in accordance with the decision by Judge Leo Strine Jr.

title: Bonnaroo: Wilco Gets Noisy
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.Wilcos new album, Sky Blue Sky (Nonesuch), is relatively noise-free after the bands two previous studio albums, which were laced with electronics and noise. Onstage at Bonnaroo, songs that began as gently strummed or picked folk-rock sprouted episodes of noisefrenetic electric-guitar tremolos, two-fisted keyboard pummeling, volcanic drum crescendoeseven in older songs like Via Chicago, which had three giant eruptions while Jeff Tweedy kept singing its modest melody. Wilco wont be mistaken for mellow any time soon.

title: Bonnaroo: A Farewell to Jamming, With $2.50 Bottles of Water
description: MANCHESTER, TENN.The Southern rock jam band Widespread Panic, which has been a Bonnaroo regular from the beginning, closed out the festival with its built-in paradox. Many of its songs (and borrowed ones, like Vic Chesnutts Sewing Machine) are about feeling unsure, out of place, a little precarious. But the music is never less than confident, riding hefty blues-rock riffs with Jimmy Herrings breakneck, cascading guitar lines and Domingo (Sonny) Ortizs ebullient percussion. The fans came prepared. When the band began Chilly Water, a song about feeling out of place in the city, the audience waited until the chorusGimme some of that cool, cool waterand suddenly big splashes of water ($2.50 a bottle from the concessions, free from fountains) were flung across the field. Bonnaroo was almost over, and they could resupply back in the real world.

title: Hares Disrupt Milans Airport
description: In the sad club of dwindling wildlife populations, the birds and the bees are joined by the tortoise, but not the hare, apparently.

title: Anti-Socialist Film Critics Gone Wild
Giuliani Meets With Israels Olmert
description: Rudolph Giuliani, who has had close ties to Jewish leaders since he was mayor of New York City, met privately with Israels Prime Minister Ehud Olmert today.

title: Top Chef: Judging the Judging
description: I notice that in response to my post about the season opener of Top Chef, one of its judges, Tom Colicchio, wrote in to quibble with the implication that the Bravo network has a hand in determining which contestants are eliminated and which make it deep into the competition.

title: G.E., Dow Jones and the MSNBC Factor
description: As General Electric casts around for partners in a possible rival bid for Dow Jones, its chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, might want to keep five letters in the back of his mind: MSNBC.

title: Hotter Summers, Fewer Jobs
description: The arrival of summer on Thursday means hundreds of thousands of New York teenagers who dont attend camp or summer programs will soon have a lot of free time on their hands.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through this past Sundays book sections.

title: What Died When Rorty Died?
description: Screens plans to go broke overestimating everyones intelligence today, including its own.

title: Midnight Train to Freedom
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Q&A: Life in Iraq
description: Iraq is now the second most unstable country in the world, outranked in that category only by Sudan, according to an annual survey conducted by Foreign Policy magazine.

title: Court Shields Banks from I.P.O. Antitrust Suits
description: Private equity firms may be feeling unfriendly vibes from Washington these days, but the Supreme Court just gave Wall Streets investment banks a big hug. In a 7-1 ruling, the nations highest court ruled that banks including Credit Suisse, Citigroup and Morgan Stanley are immune from antitrust lawsuits that alleged they conspired to drive up prices of initial public offerings in the late 1990s.

title: Could An Underbid Win Dow Jones?
description: The news that Pearson and General Electric are thinking about making a counter-offer for Dow Jones raises the interesting question: Could an underbid succeed?

title: A Reader Asks: Wheres the Morgue?
description: Q. Good morning. I was just wondering  what happened to the morgue? Did it go with you to the new building or is it all digitized?  Arlene Herring on Your City, Your Room.

title: Fashion Writer Sentenced to 20 Years in Attack
description: Peter Braunstein, the former fashion writer, was just sentenced to 20 years to life in prison on charges he dressed up as a firefighter, kidnapped and sexually abused a co-worker. Anemona Hartocollis of The Times is in State Supreme Court in Manhattan reporting on the sentencing. NYTimes.com will have more shortly.

title: Have Analysts Gotten Better, or Just Lucky?
description: A lot has changed since 2003, when Eliot Spitzer, then New Yorks attorney general, reached a settlement with Wall Street firms intended to bring more independence to their equity research arms, whose reputations were tarnished by questions about conflicted loyalties.

title: Michael Moores Movie Leaks to the Web
description: UPDATE, June 19, 5:23 PM ET After a documentary leaked in a serious way over the weekend, the studio has decided to move up the opening. Michael Cieply tells it well.

title: The Rising Cost of Meat on a Stick
description: The cost of food and beverage rose by 3.9 percent in May from the same month a year earlier, about 1 percent higher than the inflation rate and the biggest jump in three years, according to the Labor Department.

title: In Hedge Fund Haven, a Golf Course Goes Begging
description: Presidential hopefuls have been traveling hat in hand to Greenwich, Conn., usually leaving with wads of hedge-fund money. But the towns own public golf course has been far less successful at prying cash out of the hands of Greenwichs well-heeled citizens.

title: For Some, Limited Access to Access NYC
description: Click on the Web site of Access NYC, a portal that the New York City government started last fall to make it easier for residents to fill out forms and apply for benefits, and you will see messages in English, Spanish, Chinese, Arabic, Haitian Creole, Korean and Russian.

title: McCain Cites Romney Stem Cell Shift
description: Senator John McCains presidential campaign stepped up its attacks on Republican rival Mitt Romney today, sending a March 2005 clip to this reporter that appears to highlight anew an apparent change in Mr. Romneys position today on taxpayer financing of embryonic stem cell cell research.

title: Tick, Tick, Tick in Albany
description: There are four working days left in the legislative session in Albany. (Well, three-and-a-half.) Which brings up an issue that irked good-government types when Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature were trying to get their budget passed. Under the state constitution, lawmakers are supposed to get three days to look over  and, presumably, debate or modify  the final version of any bills. In practice, as anyone who follows the capital knows, legislation is often crafted behind closed doors by governors and the leaders of the Senate and Assembly, presented to the rank-and-file as a fait accompli, and voted while the papers still warm from printing.

title: CIT Buys Midmarket M&A Advisory Firm
description: CIT Group, the New York-based financing firm, said Monday it would acquire Edgeview Partners, a mergers and acquisitions adviser whose clients include many buyout firms. CIT did not disclose the price it paid for Edgeview, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., but said in a press release that the deal was part of an effort to expand its offerings to the private equity industry.

title: Report on Stalled Buyout Talks Drag on Cadence Shares
description: Shares in Cadence Design Systems fell Monday following a report that buyout talks for the maker of chip design software have hit a wall. The stock was trading at $22.25 Monday afternoon, down 4.5 percent.

title: Hotel Chelsea Is Under New Management
description: Updated 6 p.m.  By some accounts, Stanley Bard, the managing partner, and the rest of the Bard family, have been forced out of running the hotel they have operated for about half a century, but the hotels board of managers put out a news release today saying the Bards would still have a role and that David Bard would remain on the board.

title: When Its Good to Be Endangered
description: When the National Trust for Historic Preservation last week named the Brooklyn industrial waterfront the most endangered place in America, much hand-wringing ensued. The wharves, warehouses and factories of the Brooklyn coastline, a legacy of the boroughs manufacturing past, are being demolished by developers anxious to cash in on the areas newly hip status, the trust glumly warned.

title: Darfurs Conflict and Global Warming
description: United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moons op-ed article tracing the vicious ethnic conflict in Darfur to a drought that was caused at least in part from climate change may have sounded surprising to some observers.

title: Could an Underbid Win Dow Jones?
description: As chatter rises over the prospect of a General ElectricPearson bid for Dow Jones, many have been wondering how that combination could possibly trump News Corporations $60-a-share offer. Most analysts and pundits see Rupert Murdochs bid, worth about $5 billion, as too rich to be beaten. The septuagenarian media mogul could also open his wallet even wider, according to common wisdom.

title: Former Enron Broadband C.E.O. Is Sentenced
description: The former chief of Enrons high-speed Internet unit, who turned government witness and testified in the trial of Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, was sentenced Monday to 27 months in prison. Nearly three years ago, Kenneth Rice, 48, pleaded guilty to securities fraud and agreed to help federal prosecutors on other cases related to the energy giants collapse. His sentencing was postponed as he cooperated with prosecutors.

title: For One Bidder, No Horsing Around
description: There is a fine line between publicly, gently lobbying a governor on something, and pushing so hard it boomerangs. And one of the groups bidding for New Yorks thoroughbred racing franchise is trying to walk it.

title: For Council Speaker, Its Easy Being Green
description: In just a year and a half as the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn has become a valued ally of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. She has broken with him on some minor issues (the ban on metal baseball bats comes to mind), but has sided with him on most major ones, like budget priorities.

title: Calpers Jumps on the Activism Bandwagon
description: As shareholder activists grab the spotlight more often  the most recent example being The Childrens Investment Funds pushing for a sale of ABN Amro  one of the largest institutional investors in the United States has decided to hitch itself to itself to their star.

title: Special Education Parents Offer Mixed Views
description: The five-page, 45-question parent survey by the Citywide Council on Special Education looked simple enough. But interpreting the results has been anything but.Betsy Gotbaum, the citys public advocate, released a report this morning, Left in the Dark. It reported results from the survey [pdf], which was conducted from Oct. 1 to Nov. 30 and involved 2,026 parents of students with moderate to severe disabilities in District 75, the citywide full-time special education district.

title: Obama Calls His Clinton Document Screw-Up
description: Senator Barack Obama disavowed the document his campaign aimed at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton last week, saying today that it was stupid and caustic.

title: Kobe Bryant, Messy Blogger
description: Add one more thing to Kobe Bryants long list of talents: he can send news coverage rippling across the Web with a simple change of a timestamp.

title: Taxing Matters
description: On the surface, the news coming out of Florida last week seemed so promising: The Florida Legislature passed the biggest property-tax cut in state history, one report began.

title: A Post-Powell Problem
description: A lot of liberals blame Colin Powell for persuading them to support the notion of getting into the Iraq war, but is Colin Powell also to blame for the Bush administrations inability to get the United States out of the Iraq war? In a roundabout way, yes, suggests Andrew J. Bacevich, a professor of history and international relations at Boston University, in The Boston Globes Ideas section.In a long essay arguing for the abolishment of the position of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Bacevich says Powell is indirectly to blame for the nations poor military leadership since he stepped down as chairman of the Joint Chiefs. Bacevich writes:

title: One Week Later: Sopranos Chatter
description: Got a minute? The Sopranos links got too heavy, and The Lede had to put them down next to the gabagool. Weve got fun clicks, new theories and some statistics about the finale that is still a matter of heavy debate, especially about whether Tony lived or died.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: In Formula One, Lewis Hamilton did it again.

title: 24 Hours and Ready for More
description: I survived 24 hours in the pits of the Corvette Racing team at the 24 Hours of Le Mans  and had a beer poured on my head to prove it!

title: Egalitarian Tall Tales
description: A few weeks back a puff piece in a New Zealand newspaper extolled a trucking company that has fostered an egalitarian culture  and does not believe in hierarchy, bureaucracy or superiority. The same article also noted that company headquarters features this saying in bold text on a lobby wall: The man on top of the mountain didnt fall there.

title: Americans in Paris
description: Forget about freedom fries. American businessmen have come to the Paris air show in full force.

title: Spitzer Nominates a New M.T.A. Chairman
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated H. Dale Hemmerdinger, a real estate executive, to be the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, succeeding Peter S. Kalikow.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Bill Leaves Committee
description: A bill to legalize same-sex marriage just passed the State Assemblys judiciary committee on a 16-5 vote, with the only nay votes being those of the committees five Republicans. It now goes to the rules committee, and from there, possibly, to a first-ever floor vote in the Assembly.

title: Semels Resignation, Deal Making and the Activists
description: As Yahoo announced that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as chief executive of the beleaguered Internet giant, two questions arose: Is Yahoo in play? What now for the shareholder activists?

title: Edwards Kicks Off Eventful Month
description: Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards and Eventful, the online site that lets users demand appearances by celebrities and candidates, kicked off a month-long contest today.

title: Mike Gravel: Behind the Music
description: While the Obama Girl video became a mini-rage on YouTube last week, another kind of rock video was silently racking up the page views.

title: Political Sites Drawing More Eyeballs
description: May was good for political Web sites. An Internet researcher, comScore Inc., reports that traffic to such sites jumped 17 percent to nine million unique visitors last month, the highest rate of increase among the 110 categories that the company studies.

title: Opting Out of Poll, but Not Out of Iowa
description: Two of the leading Republican candidates for president have said this month that they will not participate in the Ames, Iowa, straw poll, a ritual showing of political strength in that early caucus state. Their decisions raised doubts about whether Iowa would maintain its importance in selecting the partys nominee.

title: The Altruists Paradox: Should It Hurt to Be Nice?
description: In my Findings column, I report the possible sighting of a true altruist, a being that some have argued is even rarer than the one sought by Diogenes (the ancient Greek eccentric who went around with a lamp, fruitlessly searching for an honest man).

title: Yankees Get Boost From Loss of Giambi
description: It has been a long, lonely period for Jason Giambi. He has not played for the Yankees this month because of a foot injury, and he may not play again this season. In addition, Giambi must decide by Thursday if he plans to cooperate with baseballs investigation into steroid use.

title: Yahoos Chief Resigns, and a Founder Takes Over
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18  When Yahoo hired Terry S. Semel as its chief executive in the midst of the dot-com implosion in 2001, it became a bit of an oddity in Silicon Valley: a technology company run by a Hollywood executive.

title: Its (Not) Just a Bug
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Symptoms and Ovarian Cancer
description: Frustrated at the lack of a good screening test for ovarian cancer, advocacy groups have persuaded professional cancer organizations to endorse a list of persistent symptoms that might indicate the presence of the disease. The list could have a very beneficial effect in alerting patients  and doctors who have been dismissive of complaints of generalized discomfort  that ovarian cancer is present at an early stage when it is most treatable.

title: Duncan and Jeter: Fundamental Similarity
description: The reporter had a question and, as usual, Derek Jeter gave an answer, if not exactly the one being sought.

title: Airbus Secures Big Orders at Air Show
description: PARIS, June 18  Airlines gave a big lift to the order book for the next-generation Airbus A350 on Monday, announcing contracts for 114 of the planes on the first day of the Paris air show. The vote of confidence puts the program on more solid footing, although it is still well behind the Boeing Companys rival jet.

title: Change at the Chelsea, Shelter of the Arts
description: For six decades the Bard family has managed the Hotel Chelsea, overseeing a bohemian enclave that has been a long-term home for writers, artists and musicians including Mark Twain, O. Henry, Tennessee Williams, Dylan Thomas, Andy Warhol, and Sid Vicious and Nancy Spungen.

title: Ex-Enron Executive Sentenced to Prison
description: The former chief of the Internet unit at Enron has been sentenced to 27 months in prison for helping mislead investors in the fraud that sent Enron, the worlds largest energy trader, into bankruptcy.

title: Italy: Search for Immigrants Whose Vessel Sank
description: The Italian Coast Guard continued its search for bodies after a vessel carrying immigrants sank off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa over the weekend. So far 11 of the 14 bodies they saw have been recovered, according to a Coast Guard spokesman who said the nationality of the victims remained unknown. Lampedusa, south of Sicily, is one of the main destinations of immigrants seeking to enter Europe from across the Mediterranean.

title: Sweet Spark May Hold Clue to How Things Break
description: The Wint-O-Green Life Saver Effect, long of interest to children and adults chewing the candies in pitch-black closets to see the blue-white sparks shooting out of their mouths, could provide scientists a way to better understand how things break. At the atomic level, that is.

title: A Yankee Needs an Ambulance, to Help His Home Country
description: When Robinson Can, second baseman for the New York Yankees, went comparison shopping for a new vehicle recently, he wound up at a Bronx hospital.

title: As More Toys Are Recalled, Trail Ends in China
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  China manufactured every one of the 24 kinds of toys recalled for safety reasons in the United States so far this year, including the enormously popular Thomas & Friends wooden train sets, a record that is causing alarm among consumer advocates, parents and regulators.

title: For Twins Santana, Pitchings Fine Line Leads Straight to .500
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 15  The 2-2 fastball from Johan Santana in the sixth inning Thursday night crossed the plate low, not by much, but enough for Atlantas Matt Diaz to take it for ball three. Santanas next pitch, a slider, did not break down and away enough, and the right-handed-hitting Diaz flicked a ground ball inside the first-base line for a two-out double that drove in a run.

title: Utah: Bear Kills Boy on Family Camping Trip
description: A black bear pulled an 11-year-old boy from his familys tent and killed him in a remote wilderness area near Timpanogos Cave National Monument. The attack on Sunday night was the first fatal mauling by a black bear in Utah history, researchers and federal officials said. The boys mother, stepfather and 6-year-old brother were sleeping when the bear ripped a hole in the tent and carried off the boy, who was still in his sleeping bag. Utah County sheriffs deputies found the body about 400 yards from the tent. Wildlife officers killed the bear yesterday; an examination of the remains confirmed that it was the killer, The Associated Press reported.

title: Space Station Passes Test After Repairs to Computers
description: Russian computers on the International Space Station passed a crucial test yesterday and are back in operation following a weeklong glitch that might have led to the stations evacuation had it not been fixed.

title: Florida Is Slow to See the Need to Save Water
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 12  Even as a drought and unprecedented water restrictions strip many Florida lawns of their lushness, Mark Harding has few takers for the artificial grass he sells from a showroom here. Inquiries are up, he said, but swapping turf for less thirsty alternatives remains hard for Floridians to get their heads around.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Bostons 1-0 victory against San Francisco referred incorrectly to the history of the interleague series between the Red Sox and the Giants. This was their first meeting since June 2004  not since the World Series in 1912, the year they last played each other at Fenway Park.

title: New Chairman for Victoria and Albert
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday appointed John Tusa chairman of the Victoria and Albert Museum. Mr. Tusa, who will begin his four-year term on Nov. 1, is the managing director of the Barbican Center in London and was previously the managing director of the BBC World Service. He is the author of two books on the arts and has been the chairman of the advisory committee to the Government Art Collection, a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery and the Design Museum and deputy chairman of the English National Opera. He was knighted in 2003.

title: Memo Pad
description: GROWING AIR FLEET  As the global economy grows and diversifies, the number of commercial airliners in service is increasing sharply. In its annual forecast, Boeing said that 28,600 new commercial airplanes would be delivered in the next 20 years, when a total of 36,400 airliners would be flying the global skies. Over the next 20 years, the center of gravity of the world airline fleet will move substantially toward the Asia-Pacific region, Boeing said in a report issued before the Paris air show this week. More than a third of the aircraft will be delivered to Asia-Pacific airlines, compared with about a quarter for North America. Within 20 years, the domestic market in China alone will increase to more than half the size of the domestic United States market, from its current one-fifth of the United States market, Boeing said. The company has been outpacing its rival Airbus in selling wide-body and other long-haul jets, including the 787, which is scheduled for initial deliveries next year.

title: Central Islip, N.Y.: Man Charged in Auto Shop Fire
description: A Selden man has been charged with causing a fire last week that destroyed three cars and damaged a fourth at an auto repair shop on Sunrise Highway, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The police said the man, Randy Galluzi, 38, was attempting to steal gasoline by using a cordless power drill to cut a hole in the bottom of a vehicles gas tank at Sonrise Automotive about 9:20 p.m. last Wednesday. The gas ignited, and although Mr. Galluzi was able to escape without injury, the draining gas spread the fire to other vehicles, the police said. Mr. Galluzi was charged with criminal mischief and petit larceny, the police said. He pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, according to the Suffolk County district attorneys office.

title: Unwanted Result of Ballot Confusion: A Beerless Town
description: POTTER, N.Y., June 16 This sleepy Finger Lakes town, which does not lay claim to any actual lakefront, misses much of the tourism that helps support the picturesque region. Agriculture is the main industry here in this dot of a town of 1,800, where drivers have to yield to roosters that wander onto the road.

title: Big Part of OxyContin Profit Was Consumed by Penalties
description: The $634.5 million in penalties and fines that the maker of the painkiller OxyContin and some of its executives agreed to pay to resolve a false marketing charge represents 90 percent of the profits it initially made from the drug, according to court documents filed by federal prosecutors.

title: Taxes a Pleasure? Check the Brain Scan
description: The University of Oregon announced a new piece of research last week with a startling headline: Paying taxes, according to the brain, can bring satisfaction.

title: A Summer for Shooting a New S.L.R.
description: To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who dont have to be told to Smile!

title: Bloomberg Quits G.O.P., Stirring Talk About 08 Race
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced this evening that he was quitting the Republican Party and changing his political affiliation to independent.

title: Correction
description: A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its Beat the Street competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of cheating in the contest  including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest.

title: Owners Push New Arena, but Residents Fear Change
description: NEWARK, June 18  After all the years of hyperbolic talk, the failed promises and the false starts, the behemoth looming over downtown is a steel and glass affirmation that good things can happen to this star-crossed city.

title: The Netherlands: Milosevic Aide Faces Trial
description: Vlastimir Djordjevic, an aide to the former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic, will appear in court in The Hague today to face charges of murder and persecution. Mr. Djordjevic, who was unexpectedly handed over to the war crimes tribunal on Sunday, had been living in Russia. He was arrested in Montenegro, where the police said he had arrived under a false identity. Mr. Djordjevic led Serbias security police during the 1999 Kosovo war. Prosecutors say he had a major role in deporting Kosovo Albanians. His arrest leaves four others on the run.

title: Across the Borders, Across the Years (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: ICI Rejects Bid by Akzo Nobel
description: LONDON, June 18  Imperial Chemical Industries, Britains largest specialty chemical maker, said Monday that it had rejected a takeover bid from Akzo Nobel worth 7.2 billion ($14 billion), terming the offer too low.

title: Judge Says He Will Suspend Durham Prosecutor
description: The senior judge in Durham, N.C., said last night that he would file orders this morning to immediately suspend from office Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney at the center of the Duke lacrosse case.

title: Queens: Two Men Killed in Separate Shootings
description: Two men were fatally shot about a mile apart in Jamaica early yesterday, the police said. One man, Charles Williamson, 27, of Williamsburg, Va., was shot in the head at 127-05 176th Street about 12:20 a.m., the police said. A half-hour later, the police said, Germaine Persaud, 21, of Queens, was shot in front of his home at 119-46 192nd Street by a man wearing a red bandana.

title: Maine Is Back on Track, and So Are the Mets
description: John Maine had certainly been part of the problem of late for the Mets, who entered last night having lost seven of eight games. After a strong start to the season, Maine had won only once since May 9. But last night, he was the solution.

title: Maine Law Caps Carbon Dioxide Emissions
description: BOSTON, June 18  Gov. John Baldacci of Maine signed a bill on Monday establishing how the state will reduce pollution and cap power plant emissions in a regional effort to reduce carbon dioxide output.

title: Letters
description: The Visual Side of Science

title: Randolph Isnt Concerned With Beltrns Leg Woes
description: Manager Willie Randolph continued to play down the seriousness of Carlos Beltrns injured left quadriceps before last nights game against the Minnesota Twins, and he questioned why the leg problem seems to have developed into a major story.

title: Woods Faces Challenges, Being a Father Among Them
description: OAKMONT, Pa., June 18  When Tiger Woods tapped in for par Sunday on the final hole at Oakmont Country Club, his work in the 107th United States Open was not finished.

title: Colin Fletcher, 85, a Trailblazer of Modern Backpacking, Dies
description: Colin Fletcher, whose ornate prose and prosaic tips on subjects like choosing the right hiking boots helped start the modern backpacking movement, died June 12 in Monterey, Calif. He was 85.

title: Brothers to the Bitter End
description: SO the masked men of Fatah have the run of the West Bank while the masked men of Hamas have their dominion in Gaza. Some see this as a tolerable situation, maybe even an improvement, envisioning a secularist Fatah-run state living peacefully alongside Israel and a small, radical Gaza hemmed in by Israeli troops. Its always tempting to look for salvation in disaster, but in this case its sheer fantasy.

title: Climate-Change Scorecard Aims to Influence Consumers
description: Coke or Pepsi? McDonalds or Burger King? Amazon or Yahoo?

title: Imagining the Day After the Unimaginable (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline and article in Business Day last Tuesday about a decision by TheStreet.com not to award prize money in the first round of its Beat the Street competition referred incorrectly to the reason for its action. Although TheStreet.com did say that some players used trading strategies that compromised the integrity of the system, it did not identify any of them or accuse any individual of cheating in the contest  including J. McKeown, who was leading the contest. (Go to Article)

title: Mortgages Give Wall St. New Worries
description: After the first cracks in the subprime mortgage business appeared late last year, several large lenders were forced into bankruptcy.

title: Trying to Capture a Trick of Light, a Tug of Memory
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.  Without light, we couldnt see the world. If there were no sun, the world would be in constant darkness, and, despite our eyes, everything would be invisible. This obvious point is a crucial one for artists, scientists and philosophers exploring the limits of visual perception.

title: United Nations to Help Lebanon Investigation
description: The Security Council approved a request from Lebanons prime minister to have the United Nations commission investigating the 2005 assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, help investigate last weeks killing of a legislator, Walid Eido. Mr. Eido died in an attack similar to the one that had killed Mr. Hariri, when a vehicle parked along the same road in Beirut blew up as his car passed. Like Mr. Hariri, Mr. Eido was opposed to past Syrian domination of Lebanons politics. Preliminary findings of the commission have implicated Syrian intelligence services in Mr. Hariris murder.

title: The Citys New Motto: See You in Court
description: Manufacturing is all but gone from New York. The information technology industry, while on a roll, does not quite have the Silicon Alley 90s buzz. This city is in danger of falling behind London as a financial capital.

title: For the Angler, a Flash of Color Among the Freighters
description: PANAMA  There are several ways to experience the Panama Canal.

title: Second Stages New Season
description: The New York premiere of Edward Albees Peter and Jerry and the world premiere of Farragut North, a dark political comedy by Beau Willimon, are among the offerings in Second Stage Theaters 2007-8 season, the company is to announce today. The season is scheduled to begin on Oct. 19 with Mr. Albees play, which is two of his one-acts combined: his 1958 Zoo Story and a more recent prequel, Homelife. Pam MacKinnon, who directed the world premiere at Hartford Stage in 2004, will direct a cast featuring Bill Pullman, Johanna Day and Dallas Roberts. Next up will be Next to Normal, a new musical with book and lyrics by Brian Yorkey and music by Tom Kitt (High Fidelity). Michael Greif (Grey Gardens) is slated to direct. Mr. Willimons play, third on the schedule, will be followed by a revival of Richard Nelsons 1990 comedy, Some Americans Abroad, to be directed by Gordon Edelstein. Second Stage is busy between now and the start of the new season, its 29th, though. Sarah Ruhls Eurydice is running through July 21, and the annual Second Stage Theater Uptown series is presenting Marisa Wegrzyns Butcher of Baraboo through June 30, to be followed by Election Day, a comedy by Josh Tobiessen, directed by Jeremy Dobrish, which will run from July 16 through Aug. 18. The Uptown series is presented at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway at 76th Street.

title: Conservancy Buys Large Area of Adirondack Wilderness
description: The last big piece of privately owned timberland in the Adirondacks  a craggy 161,000-acre wilderness of hardwood forests, 80 mountain peaks, 70 crystal-clear lakes and ponds, undammed rivers, white water gorges and secluded bogs  has been sold for $110 million to the Nature Conservancy, in a move intended to protect the land from future development.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Now You See Sicko, Now You Dont

title: Loving Arizona, Even When It Sizzles (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lola Wasserstein, Playwrights Mother, Dies at 89
description: Lola S. Wasserstein, whose larger-than-life personality provided inspiration for sprightly maternal characters in the plays of her daughter Wendy, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Rags to Riches Will Probably Not Race Colts Again This Year
description: Although no firm plans have been made for the Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches beyond her next scheduled start, it appears she may not face colts in the Travers Stakes or at any time this year.

title: Report Faults Oversight by Smithsonian Regents
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  In a high-profile mea culpa the Smithsonian Institution issued a report on Monday saying that its Board of Regents had failed to provide the oversight that might have prevented extravagant spending by its former chief executive, Lawrence M. Small, who resigned in March, and other missteps by the organization.

title: Saving Young Skin From the Suns Perils
description: Dr. Michael L. Ramsey, a dermatologist at the Geisinger Medical Center in Danville, Pa., coaches his sons Little League team these summery days when hes not removing patients skin cancers.

title: Millions of Missing Birds, Vanishing in Plain Sight
description: Last week, the Audubon Society released a new report describing the sharp and startling population decline of some of the most familiar and common birds in America: several kinds of sparrows, the Northern bobwhite, the Eastern meadowlark, the common grackle and the common tern. The average decline of the 20 species in the Audubon Societys report is 68 percent.

title: 9 Firefighters Are Killed in South Carolina Blaze
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 19  Nine firefighters were killed when a blazing furniture-store building collapsed on them Monday night. It was the worst loss of life for American firefighters since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Senate Republicans Propose Changes to Congestion Plan
description: ALBANY, June 18  Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal received mixed political signals on Monday and appeared unlikely to be resolved in the last week of the legislative session.

title: With Rise in Radiation Exposure, Experts Urge Caution on Tests
description: Advances in radiology have radically transformed medical practice, with CT scans and nuclear medicine exams providing physicians with the ability to quickly pinpoint internal bleeding, diagnose kidney stones or confirm appendicitis, assess thyroid function and identify and open blockages in the blood vessels to the heart.

title: Obama Apologizes for Memo
description: Senator Barack Obama said his campaign made a mistake last week when it distributed a document criticizing the support Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has received from Indian-Americans and companies that do business in India. The memos caustic tone and its focus on contributions by Indian-Americans to the Clinton campaign was potentially hurtful, and as such, unacceptable, Mr. Obama said in a letter to Indian-Americans. The document, which referred to Mrs. Clinton as D-Punjab, caused a furor among Indian-American groups. Mr. Obama said he did not know about the memo, but added, I consider the entire campaign, and in particular myself, responsible for the mistake.

title: Airbus Seeks a Welcome in Alabama
description: PARIS, June 18  Louis Gallois, the co-chief executive of EADS, the parent company of Airbus, could have his pick of invitations among dozens of parties during the Paris air show, the giant industry gathering this week.

title: Ending a Climb, Shares Slip Amid Concern on Housing
description: Most stocks fell yesterday for the first time in four days after confidence in the home building industry dropped to a 16-year low, renewing concern that the housing slump was not over.

title: Crunch Time on Energy
description: The Senate will tell us this week whether it really wants to do something about oil dependency and global warming or if it is just fooling around.

title: French Socialists First Couple Disclose a Parting of Ways
description: PARIS, June 18  A day after President Nicolas Sarkozys conservative party captured a smaller majority in Parliament than expected, Frances Socialist Party was struggling to adjust to the awkward reality that its first couple  Sgolne Royal and Franois Hollande  had split up.

title: Trial Starts for Former Chief in Options-Backdating Case
description: Prosecutors pursuing executives for backdating stock options began the first courtroom test of their crackdown as the former chief executive of Brocade Communications went on trial in federal court in San Francisco.

title: When Dollars Trump Compassion
description: You wont see these stories on television, but Marian Wright Edelman and Dr. Irwin Redlener could talk to you all day and all night about children whose lives have been lost or ruined because they didnt have health insurance.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about a vote by the New Jersey General Assembly to allow voters to decide whether all proceeds from a 1-cent tax increase approved last year should go to property tax relief for local governments referred incorrectly at one point to the type of tax that was increased. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was the sales tax, not the property tax.

title: Monets Fetch Millions
description: Monets 1904 painting Waterloo Bridge, Temps Couvert, sold last night for $31.7 million, before commission, at Christies International in London, Bloomberg News reported. The price was twice the estimate, but another Monet, Les Arceaux des Roses, Giverny, painted in 1913, fetched only $15.9 million, short of the $17.8 million estimate. Waterloo Bride, once owned by the filmmaker Alexander Korda, was bought by a telephone bidder; Roses, from a New York collection, went to an unidentified buyer in the auction room. The Monet auction record is $39.2 million, including commission. The sale ushered in a week of London auctions.

title: States Face Decisions on Who Is Mentally Fit to Vote
Antibiotic Use in First Year May Increase Asthma Risk
description: The use of antibiotics in the first year of life is associated with an increased risk for asthma at age 7, a new study has found, and the reason may be that antibiotics destroy not only disease-causing microbes, but also those that are helpful to the developing immune system.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the unearthing of a 1957 Plymouth Belvedere and a time capsule, which had been buried in Tulsa., Okla, to commemorate 50 years of statehood, misidentified one of the items in the capsule. It was a 48-star flag, not a 46-star flag.

title: Handel Instead of Tchaikovsky With the Rockets Red Glare
description: Mimi has died, poor thing; cue the fireworks. Though a staple at Central Park concerts by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic, fireworks often sit oddly on a program. How often can the Met offer the exultant Fidelio, after all, and how often does it offer the star-crossed Bohme? And how often can the Philharmonic present Tchaikovskys 1812?

title: Lottery Numbers
Footnote
description: The Broadway revival of Eric Bogosians Talk Radio, starring Liev Schreiber, will close Sunday after 150 performances at the Longacre Theater.

title: New Focus on a Forlorn Cleveland Tower
description: CLEVELAND, June 17  Marcel Breuer, one of the fathers of modern architecture, built only one skyscraper, the 29-story Cleveland Trust Tower, which today stands abandoned on a forlorn block downtown.

title: Glossy Insert at Gannett, and Maybe Dow Jones
description: The Gannett Company plans to introduce a glossy magazine insert for USA Today later this year, and Dow Jones & Company is contemplating a similar move for The Wall Street Journal, as both companies seek to capture more of the high-end consumer advertising market.

title: Semel Steps Aside as Yahoo Chief
description: In the face of increasing unrest among investors, Yahoos chief executive, Terry S. Semel, said today that he was stepping down to assume a non-executive advisory role with the company. He will be replaced by Jerry Yang, a Yahoo co-founder.

title: For California Wines, Nothing Succeeds Like Secession
description: Decades ago, articles about how California was growing to become the biggest state in the union would invariably offer context by explaining how the state would rank globally if it were an independent country.

title: Sifting the Garbage for a Green Polymer
description: Carbon dioxide. Orange peels. Chicken feathers. Olive oil. Potato peels. E. coli bacteria. It is as if chemists have gone Dumpster diving in their hunt to make biodegradable, sustainable and renewable plastics. Most bioplastics are made from plants like corn, soy, sugar cane and switch grass, but scientists have recently turned to trash in an effort to make so-called green polymers, essentially plastics from garbage.

title: Is Boycotting Israelis an Anti-Semitic Act? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Leader of the L.I.R.R. Looks North for Inspiration
description: For years, the Long Island Rail Road has had to suffer the indignity of being compared unfavorably, and perhaps not always fairly, with its sister railroad, Metro-North, which routinely scores better on performance measures like customer satisfaction and the ability to make trains run on time.

title: Police May Face an Alcohol Test After Shootings
description: The New York City Police Department is moving to require officers to take breath tests for alcohol if they shoot someone and to undergo a psychological screening when they become candidates for undercover work, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday. Both measures are among the recommendations of a panel created after a Queens man was fatally shot in November in a volley of 50 bullets fired by officers.

title: Moores Sicko Will Be Released Ahead of Schedule
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19  Hyped in Cuba, unveiled in Cannes, pirated on YouTube, and rallied around last week in Sacramento, Calif., by nurses chanting for the health insurance systems demise, Michael Moores documentary Sicko is finally ready to meet its American audience  or at least some of it  a week ahead of schedule.

title: RC2s Train Wreck
description: In the toy business, RC2 was the little company that could.

title: A Literary Dynasty, Warts and All
description: In a letter to his 6-year-old son, which closes this volume, Alexander Waugh  son of the satirist Auberon Waugh and grandson of the novelist Evelyn Waugh  dispenses some advice: Beware of seriousness: it is a form of stupidity, Fear boredom, Never use the word ersatz,  and Bear the name of Waugh with pride. The Waugh name, he goes on, is not a satchel of rocks, or a blotchy birthmark, or a tuxedo with medals for you to swank about in: Do not let it browbeat you into thinking you have to become a writer, that it is your destiny or your duty to do so. It isnt. There is no point in writing unless you have something to say and are determined to say it well.

title: At 90, an Environmentalist From the 70s Still Has Hope
description: Before Al Gore became synonymous with global warming, Barry Commoner was warning the public about the delicate condition of planet Earth. Long associated with the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, Dr. Commoner has for decades been agitating to restore ecological balance to the biosphere, whether by outlawing nuclear testing or spreading the practice of recycling. Time magazine once nicknamed him the Paul Revere of the environmental movement.

title: Bob Barker Gives CBS a Good Goodbye
description: After five decades on network television, Bob Barker appeared on CBSs Price is Right Friday for the last time, ending 35 years as host of Americas longest-running game show. Nielsen estimated 8.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. to watch the prime-time encore of the farewell show, which CBS televised earlier Friday in its usual daytime slot. Following the sendoff, CBS broadcast the 34th Annual Daytime Emmy Awards, during which Mr. Barker was honored with his 19th trophy. The awards show drew 8.3 million viewers from 9 to 11, putting the network in first place for the night. CBS was also No. 1 on Sunday, getting a boost from back-to-back repeats of Cold Case at 8 (7.2 million) and at 9 (9 million) followed by Without a Trace at 10 (8.6 million). But NBC finished on top for the night among adults 18 to 49, benefiting from a 45-minute overrun of its U.S. Open golf coverage in the 7 p.m. hour. From 9 to 11 a repeat of NBCs Last Comic Standing led the time period in the demographic, while attracting only 4.9 million viewers.

title: Travels With Charlie, From Kansas to the Moon
description: Kenneth Branagh, who is Irish, was sensational as one of the last centurys most famous Americans, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, in the 2005 HBO film Warm Springs. Jonathan Rhys Meyers, who is Irish, was pretty good as another, Elvis Presley, in a CBS movie that same year. But foreigners who dare trifle with Americas cultural reference points had better make sure that they leave every iota of the accent at home and that they are doing more than just recycling stock imagery.

title: Albany: Nomination for M.T.A. Chairman
description: A real estate executive was nominated yesterday by Gov. Eliot Spitzer to become the next chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the governors office announced. The nominee, H. Dale Hemmerdinger, is a former chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and president of the Hemmerdinger Corporation, a real estate development company, the governors office said. Mr. Hemmerdinger is also president of Atco Properties and Management, a member of the board of Valley National Bank and a trustee of New York University. If confirmed by the State Senate, he will succeed Peter S. Kalikow, a Pataki administration appointee who said recently that it was time for him to move on.

title: The Stories of Refugees, Wrapped in Stereotypes
description: In its more unfortunate passages, Rain in a Dry Land, Anne Makepeaces film about two Somali refugee families being relocated to the United States, reinforces unpleasant stereotypes that some people still harbor about Africa: that everybody over there is so illiterate and backward that airplanes and staircases and telephones baffle them.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Magazine on Sunday about Dr. Ronald McIver, who is imprisoned for drug trafficking, gave an erroneous account of the trial testimony of one of his patients, Leslie Smith. And a correction in this space on Sunday again referred incorrectly to that testimony. The only point Mr. Smith made in his testimony was that he acknowledged injecting drugs prescribed by Dr. McIver. Mr. Smith never raised the issue of whether he himself sold any drugs that were left over to buy other drugs. And he never referred to Dr. McIver in the context of the leftover drugs  either that Dr. McIver sold them or did not sell them.

title: Desperation Rises at Closed Border Crossings Between Gaza Strip and Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 18  A Palestinian man was killed Monday at the volatile and closed border between Israel and Gaza after Palestinian gunmen opened fire on Israeli soldiers, officials said. The attack took place near the area where several hundred people trying to flee Gaza had been camped out and Israeli troops fired back.

title: Patterns: Aspirin Linked to Lower Risk of Cancer and Heart Disease
description: Regular aspirin use may significantly reduce the incidence of both cancer and heart disease, according to a large new study, but other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, have no effect.

title: Arrington Injured in a Motorcycle Accident
description: The former Giants and Washington Redskins linebacker LaVar Arrington was hospitalized yesterday with multiple injuries after crashing his motorcycle. His agent, Carl Poston, said Arrington sustained a broken arm, at least one broken rib and a leg contusion.

title: I.B.M. to Show Stream Computing System
description: I.B.M. is introducing a high-performance computer system that is intended to rapidly analyze data as it streams in from many sources, increasing the speed and accuracy of decision making in fields as diverse as security surveillance and Wall Street trading.

title: New Jersey Court Says Showing of Mental Retardation Can Block Execution
description: TRENTON, June 18  In another setback for the death penalty in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court established ground rules yesterday for how a defendant, after being convicted of a capital crime, could show mental retardation and secure a sentence of life imprisonment.

title: Savion Glovers Objections to Festivals Reflect a Schism in the Tap World
description: In three weeks many of the biggest names in tap will converge on New York City as Tony Waags American Tap Dance Foundation presents its annual Tap City festival at the Duke on 42nd Street. But the biggest name in tap today wont be found at any of its jams or samplers.

title: Endangered After-School Programs
description: It was just a few years ago that New York got serious about expanding high quality after-school programs that complement classroom learning with academic, arts, sports and other meaningful activities. Participation has risen steadily, and the programs have gotten high marks. Many school officials see a link between these after-school activities and improvements in test scores and attendance, reduced dropout rates and college enrollment.

title: A Tough Act I, but the Second Has Some Funny Bits
description: KIM CHAN, like many character actors, has a face that is more familiar than his name. His high cheekbones, the mischief in his eyes and his knack for both serious and comedic performances seemed to be what Hollywood always looked for when casting roles for Asians.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 2 about the expansion of Latin American companies into the United States misstated the relationship of one such company, Grupo Bimbo, with Wonder Bread. Grupo Bimbo makes and distributes Wonder Bread only in Mexico, where it has acquired the rights from Wonder Breads parent, the Interstate Brands Corporation. Grupo Bimbo does not own Wonder Bread. The error was pointed out by Grupo Bimbo shortly after the article appeared. This correction was delayed while another question about the article was researched.

title: Google and Utility to Test Hybrids That Sell Back Power
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 18  Google and Pacific Gas & Electric have unveiled their vision of a future in which cars and trucks are partly powered by the countrys electric grids, and vice versa.

title: Cockroaches Conditioned to Salivate at a Scent, Not Pavlovs Dinner Bell
description: More than a century ago, Ivan Pavlov first demonstrated classical conditioning in dogs. The animals learned to associate food with a stimulus  the sound of a bell  such that they would salivate upon hearing the sound even when no food was present.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,515 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Power Foods
description: Q. Is eating fortified foods (for example, orange juice enriched with calcium and vitamin D or flour with folic acid) any better than just taking the nutrients in pill form?

title: U.S. Unfreezes Millions in Aid to Palestinians
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The United States on Monday ended an economic and political embargo of the Palestinian Authority in a bid to bolster President Mahmoud Abbas and the new Fatah-led emergency government he has established in the West Bank as a counterweight to Hamas-controlled Gaza.

title: Amateur Video Is Latest in Bryant Drama
description: Kobe Bryant has not appeared on radio or television in three weeks. He is not even in the United States. But in the lull between a less-than-compelling N.B.A. finals and an intriguing draft, Bryant is again commandeering headlines, and the leagues attention, without saying a word.

title: Pennsylvania: Deportation Stay Is Extended
description: A federal judge has granted an indefinite stay of deportation to Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian Coptic Christian who faces repatriation for a murder charge in Egypt. Mr. Khouzam, 38, of Lancaster, had received a stay of deportation until June 18. Now, the stay has been extended until his case is concluded, court documents show. Mr. Khouzam fled to the United States nine years ago, claiming he had been detained and tortured because he refused to convert to Islam. He denies the murder accusation. After being freed from detention in 2006, Mr. Khouzam was detained again May 29, after the Egyptian government provided diplomatic assurances that he would not be tortured.

title: Scholars Race to Recover a Lost Kingdom on the Nile
description: On the periphery of history in antiquity, there was a land known as Kush. Overshadowed by Egypt, to the north, it was a place of uncharted breadth and depth far up the Nile, a mystery verging on myth. One thing the Egyptians did know and recorded  Kush had gold.

title: Ringo Starr Goes Digital
description: Ringo Starr is going online. Beginning on Aug. 28 his EMI Music albums, including Sentimental Journey (1970), Beaucoups of Blues (1970), Ringo (1973) and Goodnight Vienna (1974) will be available for downloading, along with six Ringo Starr ring tones and Photograph: The Very Best of Ringo Starr, a career- and label-spanning 20-track collection of his solo recordings. Photograph will be available in CD and CD/DVD form, as well as digitally. The CD/DVD collectors edition includes seven previously unreleased film and video clips.

title: Chinese Singer Wins BBC Prize
description: A 23-year-old bass-baritone from the Shanghai Conservatory of Music has won the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World competition, the BBC reported. Triumphing over four finalists remaining from the 25 singers chosen to audition, the winner, Shen Yang, was the youngest competitor in the weeklong contest, which once helped to start the international career of the bass-baritone Bryn Terfel. Mr. Shen received a trophy from Joan Sutherland, the patron of the competition, and $30,000 in prize money and engagements with the BBC and the Welsh National Opera. Afterward Mr. Shen said, I think the competition is not only a competition; its a big singing party in the world.

title: Schools Plan to Pay Cash for Marks
description: New York City students could earn as much as $500 a year for doing well on standardized tests and showing up for class in a new program to begin this fall, city officials announced yesterday. And the Harvard economist who created the program is joining the inner circle of Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, according to an official briefed on the hiring.

title: Some Lenders Are Setting Rates College by College
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, attorney general of New York, said yesterday in a letter to Congress that his investigation of the student loan business had found a significant number of lenders that determine eligibility for private loans and set interest rates based in large part on the colleges the students attend rather than the borrowers credit-worthiness.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Saturday about the planned national tour of the musical Spring Awakening misidentified the director. The production will be directed by Michael Mayer, who won a Tony this month for his direction of the musical, not by Carole Shorenstein Hays. (Ms. Hays is president of SHN, which is bringing Spring Awakening to the Curran Theater in San Francisco in the fall of 2008.)

title: A New Global Blueprint
description: A few weeks ago, the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia brought together some big thinkers to discuss the future of American foreign policy, and guess what? They couldnt agree.

title: Finding Passion at Work
description: THIS week Im introducing The Coaches Roundtable, in which a rotating panel of career coaches and advisers will answer reader questions. Career advice is a funny thing. Because advisers can give contrary advice, it can be helpful to collect ideas, try a few and see which ones work for you. At times, just the language can make the difference. My first coach told me that I shouldnt expect to have a single-track career, and I finally felt free to figure out my new direction liberated from the idea of a traditional job.

title: Question Time for Nominee Linked to Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  In the months after the Sept. 11 attacks, at a time when the Central Intelligence Agency had long been out of the interrogation business, senior C.I.A. officers scrambled to build a program to question terror suspects in secret jails abroad.

title: 7 Children Killed in Airstrike in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 18  Seven children were killed during an airstrike by the United States-led coalition against a religious compound thought to be a Qaeda sanctuary in remote eastern Afghanistan, the coalition said Monday.

title: Motion Picture Academy Seeks Fresh Faces
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences opened its rolls slightly yesterday, extending invitations to 115 prospective members. The additions would bring the film academys voting membership to just under 6,000, and fell short of the maximum of 150 new members authorized by academy rules for the year. Among actors 16 invitees include Jennifer Aniston, Steve Carell, Daniel Craig and Christopher Plummer. Six directors invited to join included Peter Berg, Antoine Fuqua and Paul Greengrass.

title: A Passion for Soccer and the Environment
description: BOULDER, Colo.  In marketing terms, last years slogan was a bit of a clunker. Boulder Countys Most Competitive Soccer Team, as advertised on a side of the van that shuttles the Colorado Rapids under-23 players to practice, might have been accurate. But it failed to attract more than a couple of hundred fans to any of the teams home games.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Christina Albee joined CondNet, New York, as associate publisher at Style.com and Men.style.com. She succeeds Jeff Lundwall, who left, the company said, to start a recruiting firm specializing in advertising sales positions. Ms. Albee had most recently been New York advertising director at InStyle and associate publisher at InStyle Weddings, both part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner. CondNet is part of the Cond Nast Publications division of Advance Publications.

title: Thommie Walsh, Dancer and Tony Winner, Dies at 57
description: Thommie Walsh, a Tony-winning choreographer who also created the role of Bobby in the original production of A Chorus Line, died Saturday at his mothers home in Auburn, N.Y. He was 57.

title: Bush Embraces Abbas at Meeting With Olmert
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush threw his weight behind President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority today, using an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to declare Mr. Abbas the president of all the Palestinians and praise him as a reasonable voice among the extremists in the Middle East.

title: Zimbabwe Opens First Talks With Opposition
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 18  Members of Zimbabwes government and its political opposition met in Pretoria over the weekend for their first face-to-face talks since South Africa was asked in March to mediate between them.

title: Despite Bushs Promises, Georgians Remain Skeptical About Immigration Bill
description: MARIETTA, Ga., June 18  If President Bush thought he could win support for a comprehensive immigration bill by promising to secure the border and step up law enforcement, he would be dismayed by the reaction here.

title: U.S. Says North Korea May Begin Shutting Reactor in Weeks
description: BEIJING, June 18  North Korea could be ready to begin shutting down its plutonium-producing reactor within weeks as the first step toward disabling it by the end of this year, the top United States negotiator on North Koreas nuclear weapons program said here on Monday.

title: Sperm Donors (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Test Driving an Air Taxi: Quiet, Quick but Not Cheap
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  I dont know if the air taxi model will work. But I do know that it flies.

title: Judge Dissolves Civil Union in Custody Fight
description: A family court judge in Vermont on Friday dissolved a civil union between two women whose fight over their daughter had attracted national attention and for a time put a judge in Virginia at odds with one in Vermont over whether a child can have two mothers.

title: Outcomes: Hospital Work-Hour Rules Seen as Better for Patients
description: Rules limiting the number of hours hospital interns and residents can work were intended to improve patient care, but there were fears that signing cases over to a new team at a specified time would be harmful. Those fears have not been realized, according to a new study, and the work-hour rules have resulted in better care for patients.

title: At Risk: Hostile Outlook May Affect Breathing, Research Shows
description: Having a hostile attitude may affect your breathing, a new study reports.

title: The Kingdom Gambles That Entertainment Can Trump Politics
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18  The Kingdom, a coming film about the F.B.I.s pursuit of Islamic bad guys in a not particularly hospitable Saudi Arabia, appears on the surface to tread on treacherous and polarized political ground. But after a test screening before a deliberately diversified audience in the London borough of Wandsworth earlier this year, the director Peter Berg began to suspect that his terror thriller might survive its birth into a contentious world, after all.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Black Trial
description: CHICAGO, June 18  With a few strokes of his pen, Conrad M. Black systematically stole $60 million from the company he ran and controlled, a federal prosecutor said Monday in her closing argument against the former press tycoon and three associates.

title: A Co-op on Sutton Place Sues to Keep Its Backyard
description: The owners of an exclusive co-op on Sutton Place South have taken to the barricades, or at least to State Supreme Court in Manhattan, in an attempt to block the city from seizing a swath of their emerald green backyard for a public park.

title: Kidnapping Trial of C.I.A. Agents Is Suspended by Judge in Italy
description: MILAN, June 18  An Italian judge on Monday suspended the kidnapping trial of 25 Central Intelligence Agency operatives, a United States military officer and some of Italys former top spies, to await a ruling on whether prosecutors overstepped their bounds and violated state secrecy laws as they gathered evidence.

title: New DVDs
description: THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN

title: Passengers Granted Same Right as Drivers
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The Supreme Court on Monday extended to automobile passengers the same right that drivers have: the right to challenge the validity of a decision by the police to stop the car.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about comments by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the United States would not alter its plans to deploy a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic, despite a proposal by Russia that the United States instead use a radar base in Azerbaijan, referred incorrectly to the former status of Poland and the Czech Republic. They were Soviet satellite states, not Soviet states.

title: Bridging Gaps Between Hospital and Home
description: Almost as soon as patients are admitted to 9 Silver, a general medicine floor at Beth Israel Medical Center in downtown Manhattan, Alicia Tennenbaum starts planning how to get them to leave.

title: Justices Back Underwriters on New Issues
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  The securities industry dodged a bullet on Monday when the Supreme Court threw out a private antitrust suit that accused 10 leading investment banks of conspiring to fix prices for the initial public offerings of hundreds of technology companies during the 1990s.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) ON DANGEROUS GROUND Ida Lupino, born into an Italian theater family, acted in films steadily from the age of 13 and in the 1950s was one of the few female directors working in Hollywood. Turner Classic Movies is paying tribute to this actress, director, writer and producer throughout June; tonight a series of her performances will be showcased, starting with this 1952 drama about a police detective (Robert Ryan) who helps a blind girl (Ms. Lupino, above with Mr. Ryan) whose brother has been murdered. Next, at 9:30 p.m., is While the City Sleeps (1956); at 11:15 p.m. Ms. Lupino plays a widow terrorized by a deranged handyman in Beware, My Lovely (1952); and at 12:45 a.m. comes Ladies in Retirement (1941), an understated thriller about women living on the moors.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Paris Air Show misstated Boeings manufacturing schedule for its 787. The plane will be rolled out at Boeings plant in Everett, Wash., on July 8; that is not the date for the inaugural flight.

title: Military Strikes Insurgents Base East of Baghdad
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, Tuesday, June 19  The American military began a major attack against Sunni insurgent positions here in the capital of Diyala Province overnight, part of a larger operation aimed at blunting the persistent car and suicide bombings that have terrorized Iraqis and thwarted political reconciliation.

title: A Beethoven Whos Happy but Fed Up With Niceties
description: The Emerson String Quartet ended its long and busy residency at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night fittingly, with Beethovens farewell to the medium but also with a new piece by Kaija Saariaho. In the last three weeks the Emerson has coached and presented young ensembles and itself gone through the Beethoven repertory onstage, adding other composers to its programs here and there.

title: Awareness: Enforcement of Hygiene Inconsistent at Petting Zoos
description: Along with lambs, ducks and rabbits, petting zoos may also feature E. coli, salmonella and other disease-causing microorganisms. But according to a new study, few zoos consistently enforce hygienic practices that would keep these germs from spreading to humans.

title: Thai Junta Orders Return of Ex-Prime Minister
description: BANGKOK, June 19  Ramping up their campaign against the man they ousted from power, the military government in Thailand today ordered the former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, to return to the country by the end of the month or face arrest on charges of concealing financial assets.

title: Running Guns to Gaza: A Living in the Desert
description: RAFAH, Egypt, June 17  The Hamas military takeover of Gaza last week was partly fueled by caches of weapons smuggled through tunnels below this gritty Sinai border town. Two days spent with smugglers here suggest that to stanch the flow of weapons, Egypt will have to address the economic and social concerns of the region, and not rely solely on its security forces.

title: Liberating Effects of Captive Conversation
description: Ive been in the business of designing broadcast and recording studios for about 30 years, and since the beginning Ive been traveling at least once a week. Ive learned that the captive conversation between me and my seatmate can have some unexpected business or personal consequences that are downright karmic.

title: The Power of Memory to Triumph Over Death
description: The most famous unheeded advice in the history of Western literature may be the admonition given by the ruler of the underworld to Orpheus, when that grieving youth went down to retrieve his wife, Eurydice, from the depths, and the lovers began their journey back upward.

title: Finish Line to Buy Genesco for $1.5 Billion
description: Genesco, the company behind footwear names like the teenager-focused Journeys chain of stores and the Johnston & Murphy brand of shoes, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell itself to a smaller retailer, Finish Line, for $1.5 billion.

title: On the Horizon, Personalized Depression Drugs
description: Imagine that you are depressed and see a psychiatrist who explains that you have clinical depression and would benefit from an antidepressant. So far, so good. But then the doctor tells you there is a 60 percent chance that youll feel better with this antidepressant and that it could take as long as four to six weeks to find out, during which time youll probably have some side effects from the drug.

title: Antitrust Complaints Prompt Changes to Vista
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said today.

title: Atlantis Disconnects From Space Station
description: The space shuttle Atlantis disconnected from the International Space Station this morning as the two spacecraft passed over New Guinea, a quiet end to a busy, tumultuous 10-day visit.

title: The Claim:  Hydrogen Peroxide Is a Good Treatment for Small Wounds
description: THE FACTS

title: A Staple of the News Media, but Is Rodriguez a YES Man?
