description: Except for a plaque or a retired number in Monument Park at Yankee Stadium, there appears to be no greater confirmation of greatness for a past or present Yankee than to be the subject of a Yankeeography on the YES Network.

title: A Veteran Umpire Isnt Ready to Toss Himself
description: Headlines in some newspapers last Friday said: Veteran umpire calling it quits, Froemming to retire at end of season or Froemming announces hell retire at end of season. The daily agate transactions said, Major League Baseball  announced that umpire Bruce Froemming will retire at end of season.

title: U.S. Is Really in Trouble, Says Bloomberg, Sounding Like a Candidate
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., June 18  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, sounding every inch the presidential candidate he insists he is not, brought his message of pragmatic, nonpartisan leadership to California on Monday, telling a crowd of Google employees that the nation was really in trouble.

title: A Militant Fights From a Basement on Emergency Street
description: AIN AL HILWE REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon  On a recent afternoon, with the smoke still rising from buildings burned in fierce fighting here between Islamist militants and the Lebanese Army, a man calling himself Abu Omar gave a tour of his squalid neighborhood.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review in Weekend on Friday about Paul McCartney, at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan, misidentified the instrument he played when he sang Here Today. It was an acoustic guitar, not a piano.

title: Getting Law Firms to Like Commercials
description: TELEVISION advertising has long been frowned on in the legal profession, as it can conjure images of ambulance-chasing personal injury lawyers and, in some cases, can run afoul of state laws. But a new partnership between a prominent legal directory and an Internet-based advertising agency is trying to overcome these negatives.

title: Truck Bombing Kills Scores at Shiite Mosque in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, June 19  A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.

title: Radiology Was Young, and So Was I
description: Some people are born with silver spoons in their mouths. I grew up in a lead cocoon.

title: Iowa Goes for Edwards (Elizabeth, at Least)
description: TIPTON, Iowa, June 16  Elizabeth Edwards was holding court in the sweltering basement at the Cedar County Courthouse in Tipton, where local Democrats fanned themselves under fluorescent light. Her husband, John Edwards, making his second run for the presidency, watched and winced as she quizzed her audience about what they knew of his biography.

title: New Jersey Civil Union Board Hears Bias Charge
description: TRENTON, June 18  The commission that monitors how well civil unions are working for New Jerseys same-sex couples met for the first time on Monday and heard about the first official discrimination complaint filed to the state.

title: Ornette Coleman Collapses
description: The jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman, 77, collapsed onstage from heat stroke at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., on Sunday and was given intravenous fluids in a nearby medical tent before he was taken to Coffey County Hospital, Reuters reported. He is next scheduled to perform with the Ornette Coleman Quartet in Kongsberg, Norway, on July 6.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day on June 13 about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the surname of an attorney for Mark S. Kipnis, a co-defendant. And a correction in this space on Friday also misspelled his surname. He is Michael Swartz  not Schwartz or Schwarz.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a Senate bill that would increase taxes on publicly traded equity firms and hedge funds gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a Democratic lawmaker from Montana who sponsored the legislation. He is Senator Max Baucus, not Bachus.

title: Now You See Sicko, Now You Dont
description: Michael Moores documentary about health care in the United States, Sicko, appeared then disappeared from the Internet as the weekend gave way to Monday, The Associated Press reported. First at least two YouTube users posted a pirated 124-minute, 14-video-clip version of the $9 million film, which is not scheduled for nationwide release until June 29. Each of the clips attracted 500 to 600 viewers to the video-sharing Web site over the weekend before YouTube pulled the links, citing a copyright claim by Lionsgate, which is distributing Sicko with the Weinstein Company. Sarah Rothman, a Weinstein spokeswoman, said in a statement that it was responding aggressively to protect our film. Mr. Moore, whose previous films include Roger & Me and Fahrenheit 9/11, has supported the downloading of pirated films as long as the pirates do not profit.

title: Writer Sentenced for Sexually Tormenting Former Colleague
description: Peter Braunstein, the former Womens Wear Daily writer convicted of terrorizing a former colleague for 13 hours in 2005 after dressing as a firefighter to gain access to her apartment, was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison yesterday.

title: Brooklyn: Sentencing for Womans Murder
description: A man who served as his own defense lawyer was sentenced yesterday to 32 years to life in prison for killing a companion. At his sentencing in State Supreme Court, the man, Gregory Zalevsky, 52, submitted a handwritten 29-page motion to vacate his conviction for the murder of Irina Ilyina, 31, a mother of two from New Jersey. Ms. Ilyina, who had been dating Mr. Zalevsky while seeking a divorce from her husband, was found smothered in Mr. Zalevskys Brighton Beach apartment in July 2004. In the courtroom, Justice Matthew J. DEmic denied Mr. Zalevskys motion. Ms. Ilyinas parents, sister and former husband asked for a long prison sentence, calling Mr. Zalevsky a monster. In a statement to the court, Mr. Zalevsky said he expected to be exonerated.

title: Not All Plane Beds Are Equally Restful
description: The latest dogfight in the highly competitive airline industry is for bragging rights to the best nights sleep in the sky.

title: Win a Trip: Paging Dr. Wen
description: Will Okun, who's traveling with Nick Kristof in Africa, reports on what happened when his fellow winner was confronted with a medical emergency.

title: Union Members and Activists Will Give Democrats a Listen
description: Democratic presidential candidates may come under scrutiny today and tomorrow from two important party constituencies: labor union members and liberal activists.

title: $30 Million Homes
description: A two-bedroom condominium in New York City, an eight-bedroom house Aspen, Colo. and a nine-bedroom house Bel Air, Calif.

title: 9 Firefighters Killed in Blaze
description: Fire swept through a warehouse in Charleston, S.C., collapsing the buildings roof.

title: Fashionable, Tommy?
description: I was walking on the rue Saint-Honor in Paris at dusk last night and couldnt help noticing the sheer volume of light pouring from the windows of fashionable stores like Brooks Brothers and Tumi. There were hardly any other strollers at that hour, and the shops were shut. But most looked open and ready to welcome customers.

title: Vague, Like the Ending
description: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about set dressing and a movie company and a sale. Those in the know had two words: The Sopranos.

title: Viva Las Vegas
description: Peebles

title: Glorious Cheese
description: From cow to plate: a camembert's journey.

title: Theater Briefs
description: The musical "Xanadu" has a new opening date: July 10. The show was to have opened at the Helen Hayes Theater on June 26, but a roller-skating injury suffered by its leading man, James Carpinello, led to a postponement. Mr. Carpinello has been replaced by Cheyenne Jackson.

title: A Lost Kingdom on the Nile
description: The kingdom of Kush flourished with the political and military prowess to maintain control over a wide territory in Africa.
From The Times archives, original coverage of the Charles Becker case and the Satan's Circus neighborhood in Manhattan. (In pdf format)

title: J.P. Morgan Names Credit Card Chief
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired Gordon A. Smith from American Express to head its credit card unit, succeeding Richard J. Srednicki, 59, who plans to retire next quarter. Mr. Smith, 48, has spent his entire career, more than 25 years, at American Express, including the last two as head of the global commercial card group.

title: Options-Backdating Trial Starts for Former Brocade Chief
description: Prosecutors pursuing executives for backdating stock options began the first courtroom test of their crackdown as the former chief executive of Brocade Communications went on trial in federal court in San Francisco.

title: Queen Elizabeth 2 Sold to Dubai-Owned Company
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2, the majestic ocean liner that carried millions of people across the Atlantic during its 40-year history, has been sold to a Dubai-owned company for $100 million, the company said Monday.

title: Parmalat Announces Settlement Agreements
description: Parmalat announced three settlement agreements Monday related to the dairy groups 2003 failure, with Merrill Lynch, ING Bank and Banca Monte Parma of Italy, for a total of 72 million euros ($96.5 million).

title: Blackstone Makes Its First Management Buyout in India
description: The private equity firm Blackstone Group said Monday that it had agreed to buy an Indian back-office company, Intelenet Global Services, for an undisclosed sum, in its first management buyout in India.

title: To Avoid Takeover, Akzo May Up Imperial Bid
description: The move by Akzo Nobel, the worlds largest maker of paints and coatings, to buy a British rival, Imperial Chemical Industries, may be a defensive play to avoid a hostile takeover of its own.

title: Holy Lands New Lure: Bikini Babes
description: During the conflict with Lebanon last year, Israeli tourism industry didnt disappear; it just went south, away from the fighting. Now, with a new set of life-or-death concerns emerging, the nations tourism industry again soldiers on.

title: Electronic Arts to Reorganize
description: Electronic Arts, the worlds biggest video game publisher, said on Friday it would reorganize into four units in an efficiency drive by its new chief executive, John Riccitiello. Under the plan, Electronic Arts will consist of units that focus on sports, casual games, the Sims franchise and other games.

title: For Wendys, a Sale May Be Its Most Palatable Option
description: Wendys International, which in April said it formed a special committee of directors to review options, seems to be leaning toward a sale of the company.

title: Troubled Bear Fund Gets Breathing Room from Creditors
description: Bear Stearns got a one-day reprieve from lenders to try to arrange a rescue plan for a troubled hedge fund, according to press reports. The fund, Bear Stearns High Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund, has experienced large losses and margin calls from creditors, as its bets on the subprime mortgage market went bad.

title: Closing Arguments Begin in Black Trial
description: With a few strokes of his pen, Conrad M. Black systematically stole $60 million from the company he ran and controlled, a federal prosecutor said Monday in her closing argument against the former press tycoon and three associates.

title: Warburg Pincus Set for Big Gain on Polypore I.P.O.
description: Polypore International set a price range for its upcoming initial public offering that would yield Warburg Pincus, which bought the company three years ago, a 120 percent to 135 percent gain on its equity investment of about $300 million.

title: Intel Gives K2 Network Capital to Play With
description: K2 Network, an online game publisher that has been bringing multiplayer Asian games to the United States market, said it won $16 million in a second round of funding led by Intels venture capital arm. The round included new investors Khosla Ventures , Greycroft Ventures and Novel TMT Ventures.

title: Cinven in $2.85 Billion British Hospital Deal
description: Cinven on Monday agreed to buy Britains third-largest network of private hospitals from the British United Provident Association for 1.44 billion pounds ($2.85 billion).

title: Friendly Sale Ends Not-So-Friendly Battle Within
description: Friendly Ice Creams decision to sell the Northeast chain, known for its Fribble milkshake, to a private equity firm has headed off a proxy battle showdown and ended a lawsuit filed by the companys cofounder that accused Friendlys chairman of mismanagement.

title: Sean Bell Shooting Leads to Overhaul in Police Undercover Work
description: The local news today is dominated by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kellys announcement yesterday of 19 changes in undercover procedures  including a new requirement that officers be tested for alcohol consumption in all cases where they have been involved in a shooting that results in injury or death.The recommendations, from a panel of top police commanders, are the broadest changes in official policy in years. They are a response to the police shooting in November of Sean Bell, an unarmed 23-year-old black man in Queens, which set off a wave of public protest and anger over police tactics. Two of the five officers involved in the shooting have been charged with manslaughter.

title: Citigroup Still Considering German Bank Deal
description: Citigroup on Tuesday reiterated its interest in buying a bank in Germany but played down recent talk that it was about to swoop on Commerzbank. We are not in any talks at all with Commerzbank, Sue Harnett, Citigroups German head, told Reuters at a news conference.

title: Cybersource Buys Electronic Payments Rival
description: The electronic payments company Authorize.Net Holdings will be acquired by a rival, CyberSource in a $565 million deal.

title: Saudi Prince to Offer His Kingdom to the Public
description: Kingdom Holding, the Saudi Arabian investment firm owned by billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, plans to sell a 3.15 billion-riyal ($840 million) stake in an initial public offering.

title: Are Online Pet Stores Gaining New Allure?
description: Break out that sock puppet. Investors are backing online pet stores again.

title: Private Equity Fund Back on Bidding List for Alitalia
description: Italy has allowed the American private equity firm MatlinPatterson to re-enter the auction for the national airline Alitalia  in what Reuters calls an apparent about-face amid fears that one of the two existing bidders may pull out.

title: Indian Metals Producer Raises $1.75 Billion in U.S. Share Sale
description: Sterlite Industries, the copper and zinc producer controlled by the billionaire Anil Agarwal, sold $1.75 billion of stock in the United States. Sterlite, based in Mumbai, sold 130.44 million American depositary receipts at $13.44 apiece, the unit of Vedanta Resources said in a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

title: ING Enters Turkey With Oyak Deal
description: ING, the Dutch banking and insurance group, on Tuesday moved into the Turkish banking sector with a $2.67 billion cash acquisition of Oyak Bank and said it would invest to rapidly extend market share by opening branches, improving marketing and expanding Internet banking.

title: Google Foundation to Invest in Give-and-Take Hybrid
description: Google and Pacific Gas & Electric have introduced their vision of a future in which cars and trucks are partly powered by the countrys electric grids, and vice versa.

title: Document: 19 Changes in Undercover Procedures
description: Following is the full text of the news release  issued late yesterday by the New York Police Department detailing the findings of a panel charged with reviewing undercover procedures. [Note: The release was incorrectly dated May 18.]Commissioner Kelly Announces Undercover Panel Recommendations: Mandatory Alcohol Testing in Shootings With Fatalities or InjuriesPolice Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced today 19 recommendations of a special panel that he appointed to review New York City Police Department undercover procedures in the wake of the Sean Bell shooting.

title: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, In His Own Words
description: ABORTION April 27, 2006; Fund-raiser for Naral Pro-Choice New York  "Reproductive choice is a fundamental human right, and we can never take it for granted."

title: Quadrangles Rattner: How the Credit Bubble Will Burst
description: When it comes to todays credit markets, the specter of a certain six-letter word seems to be haunting many observers including banks and the Federal Reserve. But perhaps most strikingly, a few of the debt booms biggest beneficiaries  private equity  have sounded notes of caution.

title: Cellphones for Kids
description: If you're going to issue your child a cellphone, it had better be ultra-simple, ultra-limited, ultra-rugged and ultra-parent-controlled.

title: Cadbury Says It Favors Sale of Beverages Unit
description: Cadbury Schweppes said Tuesday that it sees a sale of its American beverage unit, rather than a spinoff, as the most likely option as the worlds biggest confectioner also announced plans to cut 15 percent of its work force  some 7,500 jobs  in an efficiency drive.

title: Latest Poll Shows Approval of Spitzer Rising
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers approval rating has shot up to 60 percent from 48 percent in April, but only 22 percent think his hard-charging steamroller style is working, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning.

title: Yahoos C.E.O. Change Reignites Deal Chatter
description: As Yahoo announced late Monday that Terry S. Semel was stepping down as its chief executive, at least two big questions immediately arose: Is the Internet giant in play? And will shareholder activists jump into the game?

title: Pearson Shareholder Criticizes Potential Dow Jones Bid
description: Though Pearson is exploring the possibility of bidding alongside General Electric for Dow Jones, Pearsons third-largest shareholder, Schroders, an investment company, urged the company not to get into a bidding war with Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, The Telegraph reported Tuesday.

title: Hit Entertainment Statement
description: The following is a statement from Hit Entertainment released by Bender/Helper Impact, an outside public-relations agency:

title: 2008: Candidate Bloomberg?
description: Though he may look like a candidate for president and sound like a candidate for president, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg told an audience in California on Monday that  despite speculation to the contrary  he was not a candidate for president. During his speech to employees at the high-tech company, Google, the mayor did not rule out the possibility and instead delivered a serious message:

title: Bloomberg Courts the Power Brokers
description: As any student of New York politics knows, there is more than one way to put pressure on state or city legislators. One is to go to legislative leaders, like Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, or City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn. When they speak, people listen.

title: The Romney-Rockwell Video
description: A prominent part of Mitt Romneys pitch to conservative voters and others across America is his family photo album. He mentions his five sons, 10 grandchildren and one wife  his high school sweetheart no less  almost without fail on the campaign trail.

title: True Believers
Displaced
description: From the high vantage point of our trucks, we could see the long lines of people stretching through the towns center and masses more throbbing behind a barricade, pressing for the opportunity to just wait in line. I had seen a similar commotion once before in Chicago, at a record signing by singer R. Kelly. But this is Rutshuru in the eastern Congo: these people were fighting for food.

title: Blackstone I.P.O. to Price Thursday
description: One of the most anticipated initial public offerings of the year may arrive sooner than expected. The Blackstone Group will price its share offering on Thursday, The Associated Press reported citing one of the offerings underwriters, Morgan Stanley. The firm was originally expected to go public next week.

title: Ulurp: Is That the Sound of Columbia Absorbing Part of Harlem?
description: The acronym may sound amusing  it stands for Uniform Land Use Review Procedure  but to those opposed to the expansion of Columbia Universitys campus, it is the shot that signals the start of a metaphorical ground war.

title: Jim and Mario
description: Do you ever get the feeling there are great parties going on that you havent been invited to?

title: Manufacturers Seen as Potential Buyout Bait
description: Options traders are apparently not the only ones who see Illinois Tool Works as a possible candidate for a leveraged buyout. The company, whose products include industrial fasteners and commercial meat slicers, was one of the manufacturers that Victor Consoli, a credit strategist at Bear Stearns, flagged this week as potentially attractive to private equity firms.

title: The Best Time to Visit and Swim in Brittany
description: What is the best time to go to Brittany? What is the temperature of the ocean in August?

title: Freeing James Baldwin
description: The Times Literary Supplement, or TLS, that most venerable and high-minded of Englands weekly book sections  Virginia Woolf and Henry James were contributors  has had a makeover. Thankfully, not all that much has changed. A long list of contributing editors has been added up at the front. The editor, Peter Stothard, now writes a small introductory note to each issue. (Did you know Stothard has a blog?) And the brilliant N.B. column, written by James Campbell, has been moved to the back page, so you no longer have to go foraging for it.

title: On the Trail of the Dolphin Whackers
description: When the first dead dolphin washed ashore on May 29 in southern California, there was little cause for alarm. When four more followed, concern rose considerably. Evidence that four of the five had been shot in the head sent Michelle Zetwo, a special agent for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations Fisheries Office for Law Enforcement, on a murder investigation.

title: Debate Over Upper West Side Towers Livens Up
description: [Note: Jim Rasenberger wrote an article in The City on Sunday about the disagreement over two tall glass towers rising on Broadway at 99th Street. The article has generated several dozen reader comments. City Room asked Mr. Rasenberger, the author of High Steel: The Daring Men Who Built the Worlds Greatest Skyline (2004), to respond to the comments, in the context of broad public concern about the pace and scope of development in the city.]

title: Weill Says Big Is Beautiful; Hedge Fund Disagrees
description: Sanford Weill, the retired chairman of Citigroup, recently told Bloomberg News that the banks enormousness isnt a disadvantage. Being large and having a strong balance sheet enables a company to withstand the financial turmoil that happens every now and then in global markets, he said.

title: Redskins Owner to Buy Dick Clark Productions
description: The private equity firm owned by Daniel Snyder, owner of the Washington Redskins, agreed on Tuesday to buy Dick Clark Productions for $175 million, acquiring a library of live music shows including American Bandstand.

title: Lack of Growth Sets Us Back

description: New York City insists that six 19th-century houses on Duffield Street in Downtown Brooklyn were not, in fact, a way station for runaway slaves before the Civil War. A two-year, city-financed study of the matter found no persuasive evidence that the houses were ever part of the underground railroad, but skeptics are unconvinced.

title: Medical Marijuana Measure Falls With Connecticut Governors Veto
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 19  After struggling with what was described as one of the most difficult decisions in her three-year tenure, Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a measure today that would have legalized the use of marijuana for certain medical conditions.

title: Shuttle Detaches From Space Station
description: The space shuttle Atlantis undocked from the International Space Station. After backing away about 450 feet, the Atlantis flew around the space station, taking pictures of the stations new configuration, including a 17.2-ton truss installed during the shuttle astronauts nine-day visit. Later, the astronauts used a camera attached to the shuttles robotic arm to perform a final check for damage to the nose cone and the leading edges of the wings. The astronauts will test the orbiters flight systems today in preparation for a scheduled landing tomorrow at Cape Canaveral, Fla., weather permitting; otherwise, the shuttle will remain in orbit another day.

title: U.S. Seeks to Block Exits for Iraq Insurgents
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 19  In more than four years in Iraq, American forces have been confounded by insurgents who have often slipped away only to fight another day. The war in Iraq has been likened to the arcade game of whack-a-mole, where as soon as you knock down one mole another pops up.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coasts political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Flix Houphout-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque.

title: Mac Morgan, 89, Bass-Baritone Who Went on to Teach Voice, Dies
description: Mac Morgan, an American bass-baritone who sang on radio, television and the stage from the 1940s to the 1970s and who was later chairman of the voice department at Boston University, died on June 12 in Carrollton, Ga., where he lived. He was 89. He died of complications of an appendectomy, said his daughter Anne Morgan.

title: Yankees Offer Only a Wisp of Offense
description: DENVER, June 19  All of the seats at Coors Field are painted green, except for one row ringing most of the ballpark, 20 rows high in the third deck. That line of seats is purple, representing a mile above sea level. On Tuesday, though, you could not see it.

title: Home Depot Sells a Unit That Never Fit
description: Home Depot agreed yesterday to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion. Members of the consortium  Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice  will take an equal stake in the company.

title: White House Report Lauds Immigrants Positive Effects
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Hoping to influence Congressional debate, the White House issued a report on Tuesday saying, Immigration has a positive effect on the American economy as a whole and on the income of native-born American workers.

title: Smithsonian Report Due
description: A committee created to review the compensation and expenses paid to the former Smithsonian Secretary Lawrence M. Small is to post its report online this morning at 8, Eastern time. Mr. Small resigned in March after an audit showed that the Smithsonian had paid for his frequent use of personal luxuries like chauffeured cars and catered meals. The report, which will also address the Smithsonians governance issues, was prepared by an independent review committee composed of three people outside the Smithsonian: Charles A. Bowsher, a former comptroller general; A. W. Smith Jr., known as Pete, the former chief executive of the Private Sector Council, a nonprofit organization for improving the management of federal government; and Stephen D. Potts, chairman of the Ethics Resource Center. The report is separate from one issued on Monday by the Smithsonians Committee on Governance  also established in March  four of whose five members also sit on the Board of Regents, the Smithsonians governing body. The independent review committees report, along with a lengthy appendix, will be available at smithsonianirc.org.

title: Living in a Portuguese Wine Region
description: Following your dreams can be harder than you expect, as Jerry and Carolee Luper found when they moved to the Douro, Portugals best known wine region, to run their own small vineyard and winemaking business.

title: A Deal Worth Cheering
description: The steady march of major timber companies to new locations in the southern United States and overseas has exposed millions of acres to development, ratcheting up the already fierce pressures on the nations dwindling supply of open space. With most federal open-space programs cut to the bone, the task of preserving these lands for future generations has fallen increasingly to private groups.

title: Staking Out the Dead and Having a Lively Time of It
description: Jason Hawes, a jovial, bald hulk who resembles Vic Mackey of The Shield, runs his own vigilante team on Ghost Hunters. But unlike Mackeys fictional rogue cops, the TAPS gang on this Sci Fi reality show doesnt whack anyone: the quarry is already dead.

title: You May Call It a Daydream. She Just Calls It Her Life.
description: In One Thing I Like to Say Is, a sensitive new play by Amy Fox that is part of Clubbed Thumbs Summerworks series, the promising romance of Lina and James suffers a fairly major setback. I have some sad news about James, Lina (a wry Amy Staats) says with a doleful glance. He does not exist.

title: A Spotlight on African-Americans in Modern-Dance History
description: Dance in America: Dancing in the Light, the fourth and final program in the American Dance Festivals Emmy Award-winning Free to Dance, brings this documentary series to a rich and satisfying close tonight. The one-hour show, part of Great Performances on PBS, chronicles more than a half-century of American modern-dance history, from Asadata Daforas Ostrich to the first section of Bill T. Joness D-Man in the Waters.

title: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
description: Should Yahoo stop trying to beat Google at its own game? Should it step up the pace and grow even larger through mergers and acquisitions?

title: A Dish Whose Heart Longs for Spring
description: NEW YORK chefs have been flaunting peas, fava beans and ramps on their menus since March, but as every farmers market devotee knows, its all a great big spring vegetable charade. By the time the vernal equinox hits, were desperate to trade brussels sprouts for asparagus, but the really divine local produce is still months away.

title: Some Texans Fear Border Fence Will Sever Routine of Daily Life
description: McALLEN, Tex., June 15  Antonio N. Zavaleta, a vice president and professor of anthropology at the University of Texas branch in Brownsville, saw a slight problem in the route of a border fence that federal officials displayed at a community meeting earlier this month.

title: Brooklyn: Developer Charged With Bribery
description: The developer of a multifamily house on Maple Street near Kings County Hospital Center was charged with bribery yesterday after offering a building inspector $1,000 to overlook a safety violation, city investigators said. The man, Vauguens Michel, 49, was charged with bribery and rewarding official misconduct, according to the Department of Investigation. Rose Gill Hearn, the investigation commissioner, said that Mr. Michel offered the bribe to an inspector who had found shoring work on the site to be inadequate. The inspector reported the offer to the Department of Investigation, Ms. Gill Hearn said.

title: Corias Lawyers Look to Restore a Reputation
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19  Guillermo Coria, a tennis player from Argentina, took to an unfamiliar court Tuesday. The spectators included eight jurors, a judge and a major nutritional supplement manufacturer, which Coria is claiming is responsible for his positive steroid test six years ago.

title: Some Cities Will Get Early Look at Sicko
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19  Hyped in Cuba, unveiled in Cannes, pirated on YouTube and rallied around last week in Sacramento by nurses chanting for the demise of the current health insurance system, Michael Moores documentary Sicko is finally ready to meet its American audience  or at least some of it  a week ahead of schedule.

title: Smoothing the Way for Those Seeking a Day at the Beach
description: Milagros Franco was 8 the last time she was on a beach. That was 23 years ago. So Ms. Franco said she was elated yesterday to be spending a bright, balmy day at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn.

title: N.F.L. Program Gives New Meaning to a Set Formation
description: MOUNT LAUREL, N.J., June 19  Five N.F.L. players sat inside a dimly lit film-editing room at the sprawling headquarters of NFL Films, tucked deep in a South Jersey office park. They had traded their eye black for pancake makeup, their uniforms and helmets for smart suits and silk ties.

title: Baghdad Book Takes $60,000 Prize
description: Imperial Life in the Emerald City (Knopf), a vividly detailed portrait of the Green Zone in Baghdad and the Coalition Provisional Authority, which ran Iraqs government from April 2003 to June 2004, has won the $60,000 Samuel Johnson Prize, billed as the worlds richest award for nonfiction, Reuters reported. The book, written by Rajiv Chandrasekaran, the former Baghdad bureau chief of The Washington Post, was drawn from hundreds of interviews and documents. Helena Kennedy, chairwoman of the judges, said, The writing is cool, exact and never overstated and in many places very humorous as the jaw-dropping idiocy of the American action is revealed.

description: Fresh out of college, Michelle A. Rhee joined Teach for America, the fast-track teacher training program, landing at Harlem Park Community School in Baltimore. The public school ranked near the bottom in city reading and math scores, and as a new teacher, Ms. Rhee got a classroom of 35 children achieving the worst and behaving the worst.

description: After nearly two years of work, the Army Corps of Engineers revealed today which New Orleans neighborhoods and blocks were the most vulnerable to flooding and which were the best protected. The report shows that despite considerable improvement, large swaths of the city are still likely to be flooded in a major storm.

title: Nominee for C.I.A. Counsel Offers Few Details in His Senate Confirmation Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  As a 31-year veteran of the Central Intelligence Agency, John A. Rizzo is privy to some of the nations most closely held secrets. As the top lawyer at the agency for much of the last six years, he had a central role in C.I.A. detention and interrogation of prisoners in secret jails abroad.

title: Footnotes
description: The musical Xanadu has a new opening date: July 10. The show was to have opened at the Helen Hayes Theater on June 26, but a roller-skating injury suffered by its leading man, James Carpinello, led to a postponement. Mr. Carpinello has been replaced by Cheyenne Jackson. ... LoveMusik, starring Michael Cerveris and Donna Murphy as Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya, will end its limited engagement at the Biltmore Theater on Sunday. The Manhattan Theater Club production will have played 24 previews and 61 regular performances. ... The run of the romantic comedy The Irish Play, written by Tim McGuillicuddy and directed by Theodore Mann, artistic director of Circle in the Square, has been extended indefinitely at the Irish Arts Center. ... Tony Danza will don a black producers hat once more to reprise the role of the conniving Max Bialystock in the Las Vegas production of the Mel Brooks musical The Producers in Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Danza, one of many Maxes in the Broadway production, will enter the Las Vegas cast on Aug. 13 for an 18-week run of 126 shows. ... The concert promotion company the Bowery Presents announced yesterday that the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn will open on Sept. 4 with Patti Smith and Her Band.

title: Girardi Likely Front-Runner After Meeting With Orioles
description: Joe Girardi, a former Yankees player and coach, sounded enthusiastic yesterday after meeting with the Baltimore Orioles about their vacant managerial position. It would be surprising if he is not offered the opportunity to succeed Sam Perlozzo, who was fired Monday.

title: European Parliament: You Call That Vodka?
description: European Parliament legislators offended vodka purists by backing a proposed definition of vodka that says it must be made from grain or potatoes. But to the horror of traditionalists, they said vodka could also be made from ingredients like sugar beets, apples and raisins, as long as vodka bottles were properly labeled. Countries in the so-called vodka belt, which includes Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Sweden, wanted a definition that would allow vodka to be made only of grain, potatoes and molasses.

title: Comedy of Errors Is No Laughing Matter for the Mets
description: Even a defending Cy Young award winner like Minnesotas Johan Santana needs a little help, and he received plenty of it from both teams last night at Shea Stadium. His Twins supported him with 13 hits and the Mets made four errors as Santana won a four-hit shutout, 9-0.

title: Bush Will Pair Veto With New Cell Initiative
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush will issue an executive order intended to encourage scientific advances in regenerative medicine, according to senior White House officials who said Mr. Bush would announce the initiative on Wednesday, just as he vetoes a measure promoting embryonic stem cell research.

description: The parameters of Jason Giambis potential meeting with baseballs steroid investigators could leave the head detective George Mitchell with a strategic decision: Does he place the lug on the couch or in a hot seat?

description: BANGKOK, June 19  Thailands military government on Tuesday ordered Thaksin Shinawatra, the man it ousted from power, to return to the country by June 29 or face arrest on charges of concealing assets.

title: Former First Couple Mimics TVs Former First Couple
description: This untitled video, produced by Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign, introduces the winning song in her contest for a campaign theme. The viewer clicks on a separate link to find that Internet voters have chosen Celine Dions You and I. The video so precisely mimics the final scene of the final episode of The Sopranos broadcast two Sundays ago that in a few short hours on the Web it has become known as The Sopranos video.

description: Life in the great Pakistan bull market had been good to Ajaz Rahim. He had a big house in an affluent Karachi neighborhood, a swimming pool with a wave machine and a Yamaha motorcycle that people who know him say he liked to ride without a helmet.

description: Earlier this spring, in train stations and subway cars across the city, advertisements began appearing for a play that was to begin a limited engagement at Florence Gould Hall of the Alliance Franaise. This might easily pass without comment, were it not for the matter of the shows already quiet if substantial success. Platanos & Collard Greens was first produced in a tiny Midtown theater  70 seats  in 2003 and has moved gradually and intermittently to larger spaces since, with virtually nothing but conversation to endorse it.

title: Beneath the Bucolic Gurgling, Throbbing Electronica
description: Open the CD booklet of Person Pitch (Paw Tracks), the marvelous recent album from the Animal Collective member known as Panda Bear, who played the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, and you wont find any song lyrics. Instead, youll find collages and two pages of acknowledgments. On one page Panda Bear thanks Mom and Dad and lots of other people who know him by his real name, Noah Lennox. On the other he lists more than 100 musical acts.

description: Michael B. Nifong, the disbarred district attorney of Durham County, N.C., was served an order at his home yesterday that suspended him from office and was told to turn in his parking pass and office key.

Gone are the ham-fisted tariffs that lawmakers once threatened to impose if China did not raise the value of its currency, the yuan. In their place is a more gradual process for inflicting economic and political pain unless Beijing moves faster to lift the yuan.

title: Lottery Numbers
Some Things to Change, and Some to Leave the Same

One minute youre madly in love and then  snap!  youre not sure, the spell fracturing as the next course comes, as you readjust your gaze. You wish you could change half a dozen things. You wouldnt tinker at all with half a dozen others.

title: Police Say Fugitive Hunted for a Shooting on S.I. Was Heavily Armed
description: A woman who was arrested in Philadelphia on Monday on charges of shooting a co-founder of a Staten Island commune last year had apparently planned for the possibility of armed violence, the police said yesterday. The woman, Rebekah Johnson, had an AK-47 assault rifle and 1,000 rounds of ammunition in her apartment in North Philadelphia, the police said.

title: Bloomberg Severs G.O.P. Ties, Fueling Further Talk of 08 Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced Tuesday that he was dropping his Republican affiliation, a step that could clear the way for him to make an independent bid for the presidency.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the various factors that will offset New York Citys 7 percent across-the-board cut in property taxes referred incorrectly in some copies to a state law that limits the amount that the assessed value of a house can rise each year. It can rise no more than 6 percent in a year or 20 percent over five years  not over three years.

title: Karzai Cites Taliban Shift to Terror Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 19  Taliban insurgents have shifted their tactics to rely more on terrorist attacks, in part out of frustration with their flagging insurgent campaign, said President Hamid Karzai and the commander of American military forces in the Middle East.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on June 10 about a dispute between Vermont and a group of Civil War re-enactors over possession of a cannon referred incorrectly to a decision by former Gov. Mortimer Proctor about what to do with the cannon in the 1960s. He entrusted it to the re-enactors group itself, the Second Battery Vermont Light Artillery  not to James Dassatti or Richard Fifield, both of whom led the battery at different times. Also, the article misidentified the type of clothing that Ronald Crisman, who runs the Vermont Veterans Militia Museum and Library, wore to a legislative hearing on the current dispute. He wore contemporary clothing, not a Civil War uniform.

title: Not for Bean Counters
description: UNTIL not long ago, the term bean salad was rarely used without being preceded by the word three, and the three-bean salad was usually a staple of the bad salad bar. But the world of real bean salads can extend the range of your repertory.

title: Gazans Adjust to Power Shift as New Rulers Revel in Their Victory
description: GAZA, June 19  Muhammad al-Borniah, 23, shook a little on Tuesday as he showed off the tiny cell, No. 13, where he spent five days in January as a prisoner of the Palestinian Preventive Security, the elite Fatah force that dealt with subversion.

title: Army Provides a Sense of Unity in Fractured Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With the Lebanese government mired in political crisis, Parliament unable to meet, and sectarian tensions rising, many of this countrys institutions are slowly crumbling away.

title: Report Assails Pay of Ex-Chief of Smithsonian
description: Even though his supposed fund-raising acumen was used to justify his ballooning salary, the chief executive of the Smithsonian Institution raised less private money for the museum complex last year than his predecessor did in 1999, an independent committee said in a scathing report issued today.

title: Critic Leaves Newsday for New York Magazine
description: Justin Davidson, Newsdays music critic, will move to New York magazine and also take on the role of architecture critic, the magazine said yesterday. New Yorks previous music critic, Peter G. Davis, left earlier this month. The magazine has been without a staff architecture critic since 2004.

title: Grapes and Power: A Mondavi Melodrama
description: CALL it Greek tragedy or Shakespearean drama, Biblical strife, Freudian acting out or even soap opera. You wouldnt be exaggerating, and you wouldnt be wrong.

title: New Human Rights Council Brings Limited Change
description: The Human Rights Council, created to be an improvement on the discredited Human Rights Commission, which seldom exposed notorious rights violators, marked the end of what critics called a disappointing first year by abolishing independent rights monitors for Belarus and Cuba. The Geneva-based council did maintain monitors for 10 countries, including Cambodia, Myanmar North Korea and Sudan, and agreed to new rules obliging all 47 member states to have their rights records scrutinized.

title: Vilma Espn, Rebel and Wife of Ral Castro, Dies at 77
description: Vilma Espn, an idealistic socialite who fought alongside Fidel and Ral Castro in the mountains of Cuba and later, as Ral Castros wife, became a prominent advocate of womens rights and a powerful member of the Cuban Communist Party, died Monday in Havana. She was 77.

title: 6 Gaza Militants Killed in Clashes With Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 20  In a sudden escalation of Israeli-Palestinian violence today, at least six Palestinian militants were killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers in Gaza and the West Bank, according to army officials and Palestinian news reports, and the Israeli air force attacked two rocket launchers in northern Gaza after they had fired two rockets into Israel.

title: From a Japanese Chef, Chinese, but Not Takeout
description: NEXT month New Yorkers will get their first taste of a Chinese dish called fiery pepper hunt. The combined forces of every General Tso in town will be no match for it.

title: U.S. Open Has Higher Ratings
description: ngel Cabreras victory in the United States Open on Sunday attracted an average of 9.5 million viewers, 37 percent more than last year, and the most since Tiger Woodss victory in 2002. While the final round produced a 6.4 rating, the final half-hour, in which Cabrera watched from the clubhouse as Woods missed a birdie putt to tie the tournament, spiked to a 10.1.

title: Well, We Found 140,000
description: The post-Watergate law requiring the preservation of presidential records has proved to be no match for the Bush White Houses stealthy use of back-channel e-mail messages via the Republican National Committees computer system. Congressional investigators have discovered that while 88 White House staffers had accounts at the G.O.P. computer banks, there are no e-mail archives to be found for 51 of them.

title: The Fighting Business Brothers and Other Tales
description: WHEN a fistfight breaks out between two men in the office, you have to figure that the ill feeling between them runs deep.

title: New York Law to Expand by Staying Put
description: Expansions are rarely easy in space-challenged Manhattan, and sometimes its just easier to chuck an address and move elsewhere. But as officials at New York Law School in TriBeCa are demonstrating, it can pay to stay in place, if a real estate owner is able to think creatively to extract as much value as possible from a property and to make a move at exactly the right moment.

title: An Athlete Doing Battle With His Past
description: The term sports film doesnt do justice to the director Szabolcs Hajdus movie White Palms, a punishing, beautiful drama about a troubled 30-something Hungarian gymnast who gets a job as a coach training 2001 Calgary Olympic hopefuls. The film is shot and edited in an austere, quasi-documentary style reminiscent of that of films by the Dardenne brothers (The Son) and cast mainly with skilled gymnasts who perform their own routines.

title: Silver Wields Power by Keeping Albany Guessing
description: What will Shelly do?

title: 9 Firefighters Die in South Carolina Blaze
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 19  The early reports were bad enough: four firefighters had died as a fire in a furniture warehouse became an inferno of exploding windows, columns of flame and steel beams twisted from 1,000-degree heat.

title: Microsoft to Alter Windows Vista
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Microsoft has agreed to make changes to its Windows Vista operating system in response to a complaint by Google that a feature of Vista is anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the case said on Tuesday.

title: Into Middle America but Staying on the Fringe
description: DRIVING the back roads, you sometimes cross state borders unknowingly. Without the enormous Welcome to ...! signs you see on the Interstates, all you have to identify your new surroundings are subtle clues in the landscape  knobbier pine trees, say, or highways named for local heroes.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about a project in which the artist Eve S. Mosher is drawing a chalk line 10 feet above sea level in areas of New York City that could be threatened by flooding linked to global warming misstated the estimate of how often flooding at that level could occur, according to research by NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies at Columbia University. In a worst-case scenario, the 10-foot line could mark the zone for flooding that would occur every 19 years, on average, by the decade of the 2050s  not every eight years, on average, by the year 2050.

title: Robin Olds, 84, Fighter Ace and Hero of Big Vietnam Battle, Dies
description: Brig. Gen. Robin Olds, a World War II fighter ace who became an aviation legend by commanding the Air Force wing that shot down seven MIGs over North Vietnam in the biggest air battle of the Vietnam War, died last Thursday at his home in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He was 84.

title: Kids Eating Habits (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Appeal of a Chateau
description: Even on a gray and drizzly day, the appeal of the Chteau du Fe is immediately apparent. Behind the wrought-iron gate, a fountain plays in the courtyard and the rosy brick and pale stone facade of the long, low Louis XIII abode  one of Frances Monuments Historiques  is more welcoming than imperious.

title: Life Term for Killer of Buffalo-Area Abortion Provider
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., June 19  An avowed opponent of abortion rights already in prison for murdering an obstetrician in 1998 was sentenced again on Tuesday, this time in federal court, to spend the rest of his life behind bars.

title: Boeing Scores With Dreamliner Order
description: PARIS, June 19  International Lease Finance Corporation, the worlds largest commercial jet leasing company, signed an agreement Tuesday with Boeing for an order of 52 787 Dreamliners, raising the total number of orders for the hot-selling wide-body plane to 634.

title: Shakespeares Doomed Lovers, Acting and Dancing
description: A glowingly handsome evocation of the Italian Renaissance, Kenneth MacMillans Romeo and Juliet, created for the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden in 1965, long ago became the standard version of the ballet. It has proved itself a fluent mixture of dance and acting, absorbing in its response to both Shakespeares story and Prokofievs score.

title: Royal Visit Is an NBC Hit
description: The British royal offspring invaded American television on Monday, posting the nights highest ratings and giving NBC an easy victory over all. Nielsen estimated that 12.2 million viewers tuned in at 10 p.m. to watch NBCs Dateline interview with Matt Lauer and Princes William and Harry.  The taped conversation, pegged to the 10th anniversary of the death of the princes mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, drew NBCs best ratings in the time slot since Januarys Golden Globes. Earlier in the night NBCs Deal or No Deal earned 11.9 million viewers, dominating the 8 p.m. hour. Fox ranked second on Monday among adults 18 to 49, leading the 9 p.m. hour in that demographic with Hells Kitchen (7.3 million). Meanwhile, the premiere of NBCs Age of Love attracted 7 million viewers at 9 and a third-place finish in the 18-to-49 set. In the network news race, CBSs Evening News With Katie Couric averaged less than 6 million viewers last week in third place (5.9 million). ABCs World News With Charles Gibson finished first for the eighth consecutive week (7.5 million), ahead of NBCs Nightly News With Brian Williams (7.1 million).

title: Reader Responses
description: Following are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardts June 20 column on outsourcing and Thomas the Tank Engine:

title: Florham Park: Two Shooting Victims Found in House
description: A 40-year-old man and a 20-year-old woman were found dead of gunshot wounds in a single-family house on Riverside Drive on Monday afternoon, the Morris County prosecutors office said yesterday. There were no signs that anyone had broken into the house, the prosecutor, Michael M. Rubbinaccio, said. While the victims identities were withheld pending notification of next of kin, neighbors identified the man as Charles A. Kondakjian, a handyman whose wife died recently. Adam DeFalco, whose brother lives on the same block, said that Mr. Kondakjian had been keeping company with a young woman, and that the two would occasionally visit the neighborhood deli together. Investigators towed a silver Mountaineer sport utility vehicle, which neighbors said had been there all weekend, from the driveway yesterday.

title: Preserving the Land
description: Housing developments, subdivisions and strip malls are the antithesis of a setting for a vacation retreat. And to prevent this sort of growth, many second homeowners are taking an active role in ensuring that their refuge in the country stays sprawl free.

title: Some Lenders Dislike Plan to Save Bear Stearns Fund
description: An effort to save a troubled hedge fund at Bear Stearns hit a major hurdle yesterday when Merrill Lynch signaled that it would move forward with plans to auction $850 million in subprime securities that had been held as collateral.

title: After Meeting Israeli Leader, Bush Gives Support to Abbas
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush threw his weight behind President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Tuesday, using an Oval Office meeting with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel to declare Mr. Abbas the president of all the Palestinians and praise him as a reasonable voice among the extremists in the Middle East.

title: To Commit a Hate Crime, Must the Criminal Truly Hate the Victim?
description: In her courtroom on the 21st floor of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, Justice Jill Konviser-Levine sat and pondered the question of hate.

title: Microsoft Has Deal to Get Exclusive Episodes of Grand Theft Auto IV for Its Xbox Unit
description: It turns out that maybe crime does pay, at least if its in Grand Theft Auto.

title: More Than 20 Killed in Pakistani Tribal Region
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 19  What appears to have been a missile attack killed more than 20 people in the North Waziristan tribal region of Pakistan close to the Afghan border on Tuesday, Pakistani security officials said.

title: More Monet Millions
description: Monets 1904 water lily painting Nympheas sold last night for $32.8 million, before commission, at Sothebys in London, Bloomberg News reported. The painting was bought by an unidentified bidder from the family of a collector who bought it in the 1920s from Monets son, Michel. His 1904 painting Waterloo Bridge, Temps Couvert fetched $31.7 million, before commission, the previous night at Christies International in London.

title: Dining Briefs
description: NEW PLACES

title: U.S. Presses Blair to Become Mideast Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East representing the diplomatic quartet of world powers , Bush administration officials said today.

title: Senator Drops Objections to Corzine Court Nominee
description: NEWARK, June 19  Ending a weeklong silent protest, a New Jersey state senator withdrew her objection on Tuesday to Gov. Jon S. Corzines nominee for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

title: Truck Bomb Hits Baghdad Mosque, and 61 Are Killed
description: BAGHDAD, June 19  A suicide bomber barreled a truck filled with cooking gas and explosives into a square bordered by a large Shiite mosque in the heart of Baghdad on Tuesday, just as worshipers were finishing midday prayers. The Interior Ministry said at least 61 people were killed and 130 wounded.

title: Calendar
description: Solstice Celebrations

title: In a Quick Fix, the Yankees Put Phillips at First Base
description: DENVER, June 19  For strategic reasons, the Yankees recent surge came at the right time. They are back in the pennant race, not striving to enter it, and thus are not desperate for help as the July 31 trading deadline approaches.

title: Panel Supports Tax Breaks for Coal and Non-Oil Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  The Senate Finance Committee approved $28 billion in tax breaks on Tuesday to underwrite renewable fuels and clean coal technology, all at the expense of the oil industry.

title: Doctors Education (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Monday about Don Giovanni, at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden in London, referred incorrectly to Erwin Schrott, who portrayed the title role. He is a bass, not a baritone.

title: Industrial Chinas Ravaging of Nature, Made Disturbingly Sublime
description: At one point in the absorbing if unsettling documentary Manufactured Landscapes, about the work of the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky, a few unnamed voices try to assure a couple of Chinese officials not to worry. Mr. Burtynsky, these voices say, will make everything  meaning the mountains of coal that seem to stretch on forever behind them  beautiful. And so Mr. Burtynsky does. Whether in a coal distribution center or a garbage dump, he turns the grotesque into something beautiful, or at least something that looks good on a gallery wall.

title: Power to the People (and Some Pop Too)
description: During the last few moments of the True Colors Tour, which arrived at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night, the evenings sprawling cast delivered an affirmative anthem. Not surprisingly, it was True Colors, the Cyndi Lauper ballad that once felt a bit more intimate in tone. And the climax was visual as well as musical: Ms. Lauper and all the other performers each raised a fist in the air.

title: Blacks Lawyers Hammer Former Partners Testimony
description: CHICAGO, June 19  It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates  and not any act of criminal fraud  that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about a report from the Smithsonian Institution saying that its Board of Regents failed to provide proper oversight reversed the identities of two Smithsonian officials. Roger W. Sant, chairman of the Board of Regents executive committee, was second from the left, and Cristin Samper, the Smithsonians acting secretary, was third from the left.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A chart yesterday about the number of television appearances made by presidential candidates in 2006 and 2007 omitted the time frame during which the numbers were tracked. The data was through June 10 of each year.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Kurt Waldheim, the former diplomat and president of Austria, misstated the level of support he had in 1981 in his unsuccessful bid for a third term as secretary general of the United Nations. Although he retired from the United Nations after failing to win a unanimous vote of the five permanent members with veto power, his candidacy did indeed win some support, including that of the United States and the Soviet Union; it did not lack support entirely. Also, the obituary misidentified the chancellor of Austria whom Mr. Waldheim served under as foreign minister, from 1968 to 1970. He was Josef Klaus  not Bruno Kreisky, who became chancellor in 1970.

title: Cadbury to Cut Jobs and Sell Beverage Unit
description: LONDON, June 19  Cadbury Schweppes, the biggest candy maker in the world, said today that it planned to cut 7,500 jobs and sell the United States beverage unit that made Dr Pepper, Snapple and 7-Up to become more profitable.

title: Politics Forcing Detroit to Back New Fuel Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  For a quarter-century, American automakers and their allies argued that any legislation to increase fuel economy standards would rob them of profits, force them to lay off workers and deprive consumers of the vehicles they wanted to buy.

title: 007 Director Named
description: Marc Foster has been chosen to direct the 22nd James Bond screen adventure. Mr. Fosters credits include Stranger Than Fiction and the forthcoming Kite Runner, based on the best-selling novel by Khaled Hosseini. Filming is to begin at Pinewood Studios in London in December, and worldwide release is expected on Nov. 7, 2008.

title: Giuliani Left Group on Iraq After Warning, Article Says
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani quit the high-profile Iraq Study Group after failing to attend the groups meetings, and financial filings showed that he chose to give two lucrative speeches on days the panel was meeting.

title: Running Fast and Free, Elite Team Keeps It Simple
description: A dozen women with impressive college and high school running rsums are pushing one of New York Citys largest running clubs to pick up its pace. Mary Wittenberg, the chief executive of New York Road Runners, compares it to a battle between the all-stars and the walk-ons.

title: AIDS Research Gets a Home at Brooklyn Army Terminal
description: Late last year, the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, a global nonprofit company that hopes to speed the development of an H.I.V. vaccine, seemed on the verge of abandoning its plan to open a new laboratory in Brooklyn. The potential defection would have dealt a serious blow to the citys long-running efforts to attract more well-paying biotechnology research and manufacturing businesses.

title: Bush Again Vetoes Bill on Stem Cell Research
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  President Bush today issued his second veto of a measure lifting his restrictions on human embryonic stem cell experiments, a move that effectively pushed the contentious scientific and ethical debate surrounding the research into the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: PBSs Expos Is to Appear Online Before Being Broadcast
description: Expos: Americas Investigative Reports returns this weekend for its second season on PBS, with a 20-week run of episodes that highlight investigative reporting from news outlets nationwide. But this season viewers who cannot wait until the broadcast premiere on Friday night can watch each new episode beforehand in streaming Internet video.

title: Balanchines Square Dance Returns to Square One
description: Fifty years ago George Balanchine created Square Dance, a whimsical marriage of ballet set to music by Vivaldi and Corelli and the hoedown world, with an actual square-dance caller. He later scaled back the hoedown aspect and struck out the caller, but to mark the works anniversary the Vail International Dance Festival will open on July 29 with a performance of the original by the Pacific Northwest Ballet. The festivals executive director, Damian Woetzel, said on Monday that the caller would be Scott Wise, a Broadway actor and director. Works by Twyla Tharp and Jerome Robbins will also be on the program. Pacific Northwest will perform Square Dance the next night in the more familiar caller-free version, said Mr. Woetzel, a New York City Ballet dancer making his debut this summer as director of the festival.

title: Terry Hoeppner, 59, Who Coached Football at Two Universities, Dies
description: Terry Hoeppner, a college football coach who led Miami of Ohio to two consecutive bowl appearances before becoming the head coach at Indiana, died yesterday in Bloomington, Ind. He was 59.

title: State Dept. Expands Staffing to Handle Passport Backlog
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  The State Department will catch up with the increased demand for passports by this fall, a department official told a Senate committee on Tuesday, saying the department has hired more employees, opened a new processing center and expanded work hours.

title: Trash Station on West Side Creates Split in Assembly
description: ALBANY, June 19  A group of assemblymen from Upper Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn sharply criticized several colleagues on Tuesday for blocking a recycling station planned for the West Side of Manhattan, saying any delay would prolong the health risks their mostly low-income black and Hispanic constituents face.

title: Manhattan: Tiffany Support for Lower Manhattan
description: The Tiffany & Company Foundation announced yesterday that it would give $1 million to each of three nonprofit organizations working in Lower Manhattan: the National Parks of New York Harbor Conservancy, which promotes access to parks around New York Harbor; the Battery Conservancy, which is building an ocean-themed ride in the Battery; and Friends of the High Line, which supports a park that is set to open next year on an abandoned overhead train track that runs from Gansevoort Street to 20th Street. The gifts are connected with Tiffanys plan to open a store at 37 Wall Street in October. The main store is on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street.

title: Old MacDonald Now Has a Book Contract
description: JOHN PETERSON is not your typical farmer. He is prone to wearing feather boas while driving his tractor and to putting on a bumblebee suit and breaking into interpretive dance between rows of organic vegetables. And while some farmers hunker down with seed catalogs in the off-season, Mr. Peterson takes a sabbatical from his farm, Angelic Organics, in Caledonia, Ill., and spends the winter in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, writing as often as he can. Over the years he has written plays, short stories, a cookbook and a newsletter that he sends to his customers.

title: Heavy Fighting as Troops Pursue Iraqi Insurgents
description: BAGHDAD, June 20 American troops continued their aggressively push today in Baquba, the capital of Diyala Province, in an effort to rid it of extremists believed to be part of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: Some Colleges to Drop Out of U.S. News Rankings
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19  The presidents of dozens of liberal arts colleges have decided to stop participating in the annual college rankings by U.S. News and World Report.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some copies on June 10 with an article about Ivory Coasts political fragility misidentified a religious structure built in Yamoussoukro, the official capital, by Flix Houphout-Boigny, the longtime president, whose death in 1993 helped to precipitate events that led to a civil war. It is a basilica, not a mosque. (Go to Article)

title: For Julie Harris, a Stage to Call Her Own
description: WELLFLEET, Mass.  It doesnt have a name yet, the large, earth-tone building that since last summer has risen out of the sand next to the cedar-shingled post office here, but thats what you get when you ask Julie Harris if you can name a professional theater after her. Fortunately for the Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater, Ms. Harris was open to compromise.

title: For a Corrupt New York, a Lawman Who Fit In
description: Back when Times Square was young, the average New York policeman dealt with criminals in one of two ways. He applied his nightstick or held out his hand for a bribe. The nightstick work was often artistic, a subtle tap on the skull or the feet that sent a lightning bolt of pain straight through the system.

title: Recipe: Cornmeal-Herb Dumplings
description: Salt 1 cup all-purpose flour 1 cup cornmeal 1 teaspoon baking powder 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper 2 tablespoons chopped mint 2 tablespoons chopped chives  1/2 cup buttermilk, more if needed 2 large eggs, beaten.

title: Seeking a Souvenir of Those Mobsters You Hate to Love
description: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about set dressing and a movie company and a sale. Cash only.

title: Clash Nears in the Senate on Legislation Helping Unions Organize
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Senate Democratic leaders moved Tuesday to force a vote on organized labors top legislative priority, a bill that would make it far easier to organize workers. But Republican leaders vowed to kill the measure, voicing confidence that they could defeat a motion cutting off debate and bringing it to a vote this week.

title: Sarkozy Reshuffles Cabinet After an Election Setback
description: PARIS, June 19  President Nicolas Sarkozy hastily altered his month-old government on Tuesday, adding women, ethnic minorities and members of rival parties to his cabinet.

title: Beltrn Is Talking to Himself, but Is Still Muted at the Plate
description: Carlos Beltrn talked to himself in the batting cage yesterday, giving himself little reminders about what he should do. Stay back. See the ball. Hit the ball. Do not pull every pitch. He swung, then went back to talking to himself.

title: Blackstone to Set a Stock Offering Price Sooner Than Expected
description: The wait for one of the most eagerly awaited initial public stock offerings of the year got a couple of days shorter yesterday.

title: A Lesson That Thomas Could Teach
description: A typical Thomas the Tank Engine story is a little morality play about hubris. The stories take place on the fictional Island of Sodor, where train cars with faces and personalities go about their work.

title: YouTube to Be Available in 7 Additional Languages
description: PARIS, June 19  After laboriously converting PayPal, the Internet payment service, for use in China a few years ago, Steve Chen swore that he would never go through another localization of a Web company.

title: European Agency Backs In-Flight Calls
description: PARIS, June 19  European regulators have cleared the use of mobile phones and BlackBerry devices by airline passengers during flights, Airbus announced on Tuesday.

title: Between Teacher and Student: The Suspicions Are Growing
description: TEANECK, N.J., June 13  The accusation could not have been lodged against a more respected or popular educator: James Darden, an eighth-grade English teacher who was honored with a school assembly last year after winning a prestigious teaching award.

title: Avenel: Girl Killed on Train Tracks
description: A 12-year-old girl was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train yesterday afternoon, railroad officials said. Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, said the transit police thought the girl, who was not identified, was playing with four or five friends on the tracks east of the Avenel Station. Mr. Stessel said the spot was near an overpass where Route 1 and 9 cross the tracks, but was not near any ground-level crossings. The engineer sounded the horn and applied the emergency brakes, but was unable to stop in time, he said. The girl was struck just before 2:30 by a train on its way from Hoboken to Bayhead. None of the 250 passengers were injured when the brakes were applied, Mr. Stessel said.

title: Drunken Drivers May Face Two New Felony Charges
description: ALBANY, June 19  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and top lawmakers agreed Tuesday to toughen penalties for driving while intoxicated and to create a homicide charge aimed specifically at drunken drivers.

title: North Korea Talks Likely to Resume Next Month
description: TOKYO, June 20  The stalled six-nation talks over North Koreas nuclear program are likely to resume next month after international nuclear inspectors visit North Korea next week, the chief United States negotiator said here today.

title: A Graduate of Stanford by Way of a Transfer
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Viviana Alcazar hovered at her mothers hospital bed, feeling the alternating tugs of ambition and obligation, knowing which one would prevail. It was late 2002, and she was a year into community college and daring to think of transferring to a university. Meanwhile, her mother, Elisa, had stomach cancer and was scheduled for an operation and chemotherapy and given a prognosis full of question marks.

title: Tentative Budget Agreement Is Reached in Connecticut
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 19  Averting a possible government shutdown, Democratic legislative leaders in Connecticut have shaken hands with the states Republican governor, M. Jodi Rell, on a budget for the coming fiscal year that provides more state money for education and health care while not increasing taxes on wealthier residents.

title: Correction: A Rat With a Whisk and a Dream
description: An article last Wednesday about the animated film Ratatouille misstated the role of Brad Lewis. He is the producer, not the director.

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Enforcement of Calorie-Count Rule Is Delayed
description: In response to a federal lawsuit, New York City health officials said yesterday that they would wait three months before enforcing a new rule that requires most major fast-food and chain restaurants to prominently display calorie information on their menus.

title: Carmela Got Gold Jewelry. Hillary Wants a White House.
description: WASHINGTON

title: Tattoo Remorse: When the Thrill Is Gone (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastry Chefs, Refusing to Be Sweet
description: TWO decades ago a pastry chef might have dreamed of stocking the cake trolley that was pushed around the carpeted dining room of a stodgy restaurant uptown.

title: The Changing of the Guard at the Chelsea
description: Someone in the new management told Stanley Bard yesterday to stop hanging around the front desk of the Chelsea Hotel, which he has run for 50 years, more or less. He had come to work a bit later than his usual 5:30 a.m., but Mr. Bard, 73, does not have an actual job any more. He was shelved this week.

title: In the Amazon, Giving Blood but Getting Nothing
description: KYOW, Brazil  As the Karitiana Indians remember it, the first researchers to draw their blood came here in the late 1970s, shortly after the Amazon tribe began sustained contact with the outside world. In 1996, another team visited, promising medicine if the Karitiana would just give more blood, so they dutifully lined up again.

title: Earliest Gunshot Victim in New World Is Reported
description: Archaeologists in Peru have uncovered the human skeleton of what they conclude is the earliest known gunshot victim in the New World.

title: Player Silence on Concussions May Block N.F.L. Guidelines
description: CHICAGO, June 19  The National Football League gathered team medical personnel, members of its concussion research committee and several outside critics for a summit Tuesday that was roundly complimented as a candid discussion regarding brain injuries, specifically the decision on when a player who sustains a concussion may safely return to action.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) AFIS 100 YEARS ... 100 MOVIES: 10TH ANNIVERSARY EDITION For the 10th year, the American Film Institute counts down the top 100 movies of all time as selected from 400 candidates by 1,500 leaders in the film industry, and adds some films from 1996 through 2006 to the ballot. New this year: American Beauty, The Aviator, Brokeback Mountain, Lord of the Rings, The Matrix, Saving Private Ryan, Sideways (above), Traffic and Titanic. The winners will be announced by celebrities including Tim Allen, Halle Berry, Peter Bogdanovich, Jeff Bridges, Laurence Fishburne, Peter Fonda, Harrison Ford, Dennis Hopper, Spike Lee, Shirley MacLaine, Liza Minnelli, Sydney Pollack, Martin Scorsese and M. Night Shyamalan. Morgan Freeman is host.

title: Recipe: Bean Salads
description: 2 cups dried beans, split peas or lentils, sorted

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,517 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article Monday about tense negotiations over the Big Ten Networks placement on cable systems misstated the financial terms of a new 10-year contract that the Big Ten has with ESPN and ABC. It is worth $1 billion, or an average of $100 million a year  not a total of $100 million.

title: Behind the Masks
description: Every war has THE picture that captures its essence, and the Palestinian civil war in Gaza is no exception. My nominee would be the photograph of a Hamas fighter in Gaza, lounging in a senior Fatah officials office over which he had just taken control. The masked Hamas fighter in jeans is relaxing in an ornate chair, holding a rifle in one hand and speaking  through the opening in his mask  on a telephone in the other. It has the weird feel of a Gap ad for Halloween.

title: Food Stuff
description: Mushrooms, Tame and Wild David Falkowski grows several kinds of mushrooms in a barn on the northern edge of the farm fields in Bridgehampton, N.Y., on land his father and grandfather farmed before him. He is devoted to organic farming, and his shiitakes and blue and king oyster mushrooms (all $20 a pound), which sprout from bark and straw, are sold at the farmers markets in Sag Harbor on Saturday mornings and East Hampton on Wednesday mornings.

title: Police Sobriety Test Proposal Could Lead to a Showdown With Unions
description: The Police Department and leading police unions might be headed for a showdown over a proposal to administer sobriety tests to officers who shoot someone on or off duty.
