description: CAMEMBERT, France

title: Israel Lets Food and Medicine Enter Gaza to Avert Crisis
description: JERUSALEM, June 19  Israel allowed 12 trucks of food and medical supplies to enter the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, Israeli officials and international aid representatives said, in an effort to avert a looming humanitarian crisis now that Hamas is in control.

title: TODAY IN BUSINESS
description: DETROIT RETHINKS ITS POSITION American automakers have reversed years of stalwart opposition to any legislation to increase fuel economy standards, and are now willing to accept a modest increase in mileage standards in the hopes of silencing calls for even tougher targets.

title: New Rules for Undercover Cops
description: The fatal shooting of Sean Bell by undercover police officers on his wedding day last November revealed some serious problems with New Yorks undercover police procedures. Commissioner Ray Kelly has wisely agreed to heed the recommendations of a panel of law enforcement experts to make changes, including requiring a breathalyzer test if an undercover cop shoots anyone.

title: Barclays May Drop Symbol
description: LONDON, June 19  Barclays, the British bank that is bidding for ABN Amro, is considering dropping its eagle logo because of concerns by ABN Amro that it could remind some clients of the Nazi regime, two people close to both banks said.

title: Head of Budget Office Quits; Successor Is Chosen
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  President Bush accepted the resignation of Rob Portman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, on Tuesday, replacing him with Jim Nussle, a former Iowa congressman with a record of battling the Democrats on behalf of administration budget and tax priorities.

title: Court Upholds Plavix Patent
description: A federal district judge in Manhattan upheld the patent on the anti- clotting drug Plavix yesterday, removing a weighty uncertainty for Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, the companies that market the widely used product.

title: Court Upholds Patent on Plavix
description: A federal judge in Manhattan today upheld the patent on the anticlotting drug Plavix, good news for the companies that co-market the blockbuster product, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis.

title: Home Depot Agrees to Sell Supply Unit
description: Home Depot agreed today to sell its Home Depot Supply Unit to a group of private equity firms for more than $10.3 billion. Members of the consortium  Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice  will take an equal stake in the company.

title: Mike Wallace: The Grid, Yellow Fever and Real Estate
description: Here is the latest installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and author of Gotham, who took questions from readers this week. He will post more answers on Friday, but he is not accepting any new questions.

title: Attention Bangkok shoppers
description: Shopaholics in Asia never have to travel very far to reach a gleaming shopping mall. But nothing quite beats the mile-long strip of 6 large shopping centers in central Bangkok connected by an outdoor walkway. The skywalk as its called opened two years ago but is not publicized and few foreign visitors seem to know about it.The Skywalk is open from 6am to midnight

title: The Next Prince Fielder
description: I think I just met him. His name is Jackson Holliday and hes 3 years old.

title: 36 Hours in Paradise
description: A weekend in Bali, what could be the perfect tropical retreat.

title: The Wellcome Collection
description: Additional images from the Wellcome Collection in London.

title: Water and Wine in Portugal
description: A look inside the Quinta da Carolina and its vineyards in the Douro region of Portugal.

title: The skys the limit
description: The house may be a fixer-upper but Park Place outside London reportedly has been snapped up for a mere 42 million  or about $84 million.

title: Fishing and Fashion in Aveiro
description: Although it isnt the provincial place it once was, this Portuguese fishing town still has plenty of traditional charm.

title: Here, There and Everywhere
description: The hippie revival has little of the impetus that drove the first wave, if you can remember those times.

title: An Emotional Debate Before the Passage of a Marriage Bill
description: Members of the State Assembly debated a bill legalizing same-sex marriage on Tuesday night in speeches that were emotional but not angry. The bill eventually passed, 85-61, and now goes to the State Senate, where the Republican leadership vows it will die.

title: Barclays May Drop Eagle Symbol if ABN Deal Goes Through
description: Barclays, the British bank that is bidding for ABN Amro, is considering dropping its eagle logo because of concerns by ABN Amro that it could remind some clients of the Nazi regime, The New York Times reported.

title: Royal Philips Turns On $688 Million Light Deal
description: Royal Philips Electronics said Tuesday it was offering about $688 million for Color Kinetics, a lighting company based in Boston, with the support of the companys management. Philips, based in Amsterdam, is the worlds largest lighting company, while Color Kinetics makes light-emitting diode systems for professionals.

title: With Zenter Deal, Google Makes Its Own PowerPoint
description: Google has acquired an online slide presentation company, Zenter, filling out its web-based office software portfolio with an application similar to Microsofts popular PowerPoint.

title: Digital Single-Lens Reflex Cameras Are Put to the Test
description: David Pogue tests a few of the latest digital S.L.R.s.

title: Blacks Lawyers Hammer Former Partners Testimony
description: It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates  and not any act of criminal fraud  that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.

title: V.C.s Shower Advent Solar With Cash
description: A solar cell and module maker Advent Solar, said on Tuesday it had secured more than $70 million in a series D funding to ramp up production at its four-month old production facility.

title: Visage Gets Cash to Help Start-Ups Avoid Ampd Pitfalls
description: Despite some high-profile setbacks in its target market of mobile virtual network operators, Visage Mobile closed a $10 million fifth round of venture capital, bringing total investment in the six-year-old company to more than $80 million to enhance boost its subscriber management services.

title: Candover Hunts the Netherlands Stork
description: The Dutch conglomerate Stork is in talks with London buyout shop Candover regarding a possible takeover worth about 1.45 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

title: Investcorp Closes New Private Equity Fund
description: Investcorp said Tuesday it had held the first closing of a new private equity pool at $620 million. Officials from Investcorp declined to comment beyond the firms announcement about the vehicle, Investcorp Private Equity 2007 Fund LP, but The Deal.com reported that the pool has a $1 billion target.

title: Lehman Plans $500 Million Private Equity I.P.O.
description: Lehman Brothers said on Wednesday it plans to raise $500 million in an initial public offering of a fund that will invest in a pool of private equity funds. Lehman Brothers Private Equity Partners is set to launch on the Euronext in Amsterdam in late July.

title: Petrochina Seeks $6 Billion in Shanghai Share Sale
description: PetroChina is planning the nations biggest share sale this year to raise as much as $6 billion in Shanghai for overseas acquisitions, increased oil drilling and refinery construction.

title: Bailout for Bear Stearns Fund Said to Lose Support
description: An effort to save a troubled hedge fund at Bear Stearns hit a major hurdle Tuesday when Merrill Lynch signaled that it would move forward with plans to auction $850 million in subprime securities that had been held as collateral, The New York Times reported.

title: Symbion Says Yes to Buyout Firms
description: Symbion Health, an Australian health care company, accepted a new, higher bids for its vitamins and pharmacy businesses, paving the way for a buyout of the company for 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion). Ironbridge Capital and Archer Capital matched a rival bid by Sigma Pharmaceuticals to clinch the Melbourne-based companys recommendation, according to a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Wednesday.

title: Ousted Fannie Mae Chief Accuses Regulator of Hiding Inquiry Details
description: Franklin Raines, the ousted chief executive of Fannie Mae, said regulators are withholding documents that may show a deliberate attempt to drive down the mortgage-finance companys stock.

title: In Managing Money for the Rich, UBS Comes Out on Top
description: UBS, the biggest money manager for the wealthy, widened its lead over Citigroup and Merrill Lynch last year as rising stock markets attracted new funds, according to consulting firm Scorpio Partnership.

title: Whole Foods Chiefs Memo Ignites War of the Words
description: When the Federal Trade Commission announced its decision this month to try to block the $565 million merger of Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets, the move left some analysts and industry observers scratching their heads.

title: BofA Chief Says Flood of Easy Credit to Continue, for Now
description: As Bank of Americas chief executive, Kenneth Lewis, sees it, private-equity firms will enjoy unprecedented access to financing for at least a few more years before a deal goes bad  but that his own firm has begun to reconsider private-euity loans.

title: Behind Blackstones Rush to Market
description: The wait for one of the most eagerly awaited initial public stock offerings of the year got a couple of days shorter Tuesday. The Blackstone Group will price its initial offering Thursday night, according to the Web site of Morgan Stanley, one of the underwriters. The offering was originally scheduled to begin sometime next week.

title: BofAs Former Finance Chief to Join Cerberus
description: As financial services becomes a hot sector for leveraged buyouts, Cerberus Capital Management has hired a longtime bank executive to run the division in charge of those businesses. Alvaro de Molina, formerly Bank of Americas chief financial officer, will run that unit, a Cerberus spokesman confirmed to Financial News.

title: Morgan Stanleys Profits Rise, Defying Subprime Slump
description: Morgan Stanley, appearing to rise above the mortgage-related woes that have hurt some of its rivals, said Wednesday that its net income increased 40 percent in the latest quarter.

title: Hes No Longer a Lame Duck, but Will He Fly?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs announcement last night that he was leaving the Republican Party and becoming a political independent made headlines across the country and was a front-page article in The Washington Post, The Boston Globe and other national and regional newspapers.

title: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
description: As industry watchers tried to divine whether Yahoo would be put in play following the the resignation of Terry S. Semel as the Internet giants chief executive, The New York Times suggested that another radical proposition is being whispered inside and outside the company: stop trying to beat Google at its own game.

title: Insider Trading Goes Global
description: The story of Ajaz Rahim, a former executive at Faysal Bank in Pakistan, and his friend Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Credit Suisse banker who American prosecutors allege provided Mr. Rahim with insider information for stock trades, is a timeless tale of hubris and aspiration.

title: L.A. Police Chief Wins 2nd Term
description: Commissioner William J. Bratton has received a new vote of confidence at the Los Angeles Police Department as investigations simmer away concerning his officers harsh tactics at an immigration protest.

title: New York, New York (and New York)
description: A Quinnipiac University poll taken days ago  before Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs announcement last night that he was leaving the Republican Party  found that in a three-way race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would win 43 percent of voters statewide, followed by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with 29 percent and Mayor Bloomberg with 16 percent.

title: Madison Dearborn to Buy Nuveen for $5.75 Billion
description: Nuveen Investments, a money manager catering to wealthy investors, agreed on Wednesday to be acquired by a group led by Madison Dearborn Partners for about $5.75 billion, as private equity finds itself plunging deeper into financial-services deals.

title: 2008: Its Bloombergs Day
description: With a trip through California this week that has resembled a political campaign swing and an announcement late Tuesday that he is leaving the Republican party, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has managed to fuel rumors that he is edging closer to a run for president even as he reiterates that he has no plans to do so.

title: The Revolution Will Be Monopolized
description: This is still CNN: Joshua Levy, co-founder of the blog techPresident, which tracks the role of the Web in the 2008 campaign, is disappointed by the rules for the two presidential debates co-sponsored by CNN and YouTube (the first one will feature the Democratic candidates next month in Charleston, S.C.). Because all of the questions will come from YouTube videos created by Internet users, the debate is being advertised as a revolution in citizen participation in presidential politics, Levy notes.

title: Ex-Poet Laureate on Guantnamo Poetry
description: The imminent publication of a book of poetry gets front page treatment in The Wall Street Journal today. Poems From Guantnamo: The Detainees Speak gives readers an unusual glimpse into the emotional lives of the largely nameless and faceless prisoners there, the paper explains.

title: Rybka Wins World Computer Championship. Bring on Deep Junior?
description: Rybka ran away from the field to win the 15th World Computer Chess Championship in Amsterdam from June 11 to 18. The championship was organized by the International Computer Games Association. Final standings and games can be found here at the ICGAs Web site.

title: Kerkorian Drops Pursuit of MGM Casinos
description: The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has withdrawn his efforts to acquire two of MGM Mirages top Las Vegas properties, the casino operator said on Wednesday. Mr. Kerkorian, MGMs largest shareholder, had been pursuing the Bellagio (where he likes to stay when hes in town) and the City Center, but told the companys board Tuesday that his Tracinda vehicle was pulling its offer.

title: Clinton Gets Better Reception on Iraq
description: Heres a totally unscientific but not unimportant measure of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons evolution from Iraq war supporter to antiwar partisan in the last year: She was booed more lightly and gently at this mornings Take Back America gathering of liberal activists than she was a year ago.

title: A Less Tragic Ending to Romeo and Juliet
description: The thunderstorm that swept the metropolitan area on Tuesday night brought airports to a grinding halt, but it saved the lives of Romeo and Juliet. Flights at La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark-Liberty Airports were delayed for three to five hours starting in the early evening. At the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, it began pouring at the end of the fourth act of Romeo and Juliet at Shakespeare in the Park, right after Juliet drank the fake poison. Camryn Manheim, who plays the nurse, said in an interview, I thought well keep going, expecting to finish the play even if lightning strikes us.

title: Domestic Violence Spending: Reactive, Not Preventive?
description: In 2005, New York Citys domestic violence hot line took almost 125,000 calls; the police recorded more than 226,000 domestic violence situations (about 620 per day); and 68 people were killed by family members  accounting for almost 13 percent of all homicides.Those facts come from a new report [pdf] by the citys Independent Budget Office. The human toll of domestic violence is readily apparent; the purpose of the report is to estimate the financial impact of domestic violence on the city.

title:
Living with Music:
A Playlist by Darcey Steinke
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the celebrity playlists on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

title: I am listening with all I am
description: Christian Wiman  an occasional contributor to The Book Review, and a poet, critic, essayist and the recently-married editor of Poetry magazine  writes about his battle with incurable cancer of the blood in the new issue of The American Scholar. Its a devastating essay about poetry, about falling in love, about grief and about faith.

description: Last weeks surprise out of Washington  a bill that could jack up the tax rate for publicly traded private equity firms  does not seem to be much of a concern for the Blackstone Groups underwriters. Or Fortress Investment Groups shareholders, for that matter.

title: Morgan Stanley Raises $8 Billion Real Estate Fund
description: Morgan Stanley has added to its real estate ambitions, announcing Wednesday that it has raised $8 billion to invest in the field and intending to spend almost half of that in Japan. With those funds, the investment bank has now raised the worlds largest global real estate fund, according to Bloomberg News  topping rivals like the Blackstone Group, which took private Equity Office Properties, the nations largest office landlord.

description: While the Gold Cup semifinal between the United States and Canada is virtually devoid of controversy or sensation, Thursday night's other semifinal at Soldier Field, Mexico vs. Guadeloupe, is positively overflowing with commotion.

While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an "anti-gay agenda."

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a federal court decision that upheld the patent on Plavix, a blood thinner marketed by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Sanofi-Aventis, misstated the potential financial damages that the Canadian drug maker Apotex might have to pay the companies for selling a generic version last year. description: For at least a generation, press critics have complained bitterly about the news media's obsession with polls and the horse race aspect of the presidential campaign. title: Win a Lifetime in Congo
description: This win-a-trip journey is supposed to take weeks, but Ive been a bit concerned that we might end up stuck here in our Congo hotel washing dishes for weeks. The problem is that you cant use credit cards in Congo, of course, and so everything revolves around cash. I brought my supply of $100 bills, well secreted, but it turns out that nobody here takes U.S. currency from 1999 or earlier.

title: Credit Suisse Adds to Investment Banking Team
description: There are two new managing directors in Credit Suisses investment banking group. The firm said in an internal memo that Tom Delbrook, previously the vice president of finance at the shipping giant UPS, would join the firms general industrial and services group, covering the transportation, shipping and logistics industries out of New York.

title: Darfur and Congo
description: Ive often been asked why I write so much more about Darfur than Congo, since far more people have been killed in Congo. After all, fewer than half a million have probably died in Darfur, compared to 4 million in Congo.

title: Your Comments on my Congo Column
description: My Thursday column is about a woman in an eastern Congo village whom we found, starving to death  a war casualty as much as any other. You can also find video about the case, and Will and Leanas blogs about it, at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. Please post your comments here.

title: McClatchy Considers Parting with CareerBuilder Stake
description: Beset by shrinking advertising revenues, newspaper companies have been flailing to find solutions to prop up their income. One solution that McClatchy, the company that bought Knight Ridder last year, is now entertaining: selling its stake in CareerBuilder, the job search Web site. McClatchy, one of the nations largest publishers, co-owns the site along with Tribune and Gannett.

description: Rachel Louise Carson was born 100 years ago, in 1907, and her classic Silent Spring (1962) turns 45 this year. Tributes have been popping up everywere.

description: When the package arrived in the mail, it seemed like an unexpected present.Inside was something wonderful: The large-format renderings of our dream home from Allison Ramsey Architects. description: Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Figuring the Bloomberg Factor
description: Bloomberg, good for the Democrats? First Read, the blog of the NBC News political unit, speculates that a Michael Bloomberg presidential candidacy would help the Democratic nominee in November 2008: Why? Its simple  the South. The irony of a Bloomberg candidacy is that it could make the Democrats more competitive in the South because their 35 percent base vote in the South is made up of die-hard Democrats.

title: Nintendo Deals With Good Versus Wiivil
description: The familiar lines of debate over video games and violence are front and center again after Britains banning of Manhunt 2, but Nintendos Wii may be changing the landscape.

title: How to Succeed in New York
description: Wikipedia lists more than 1,200 people in the line of succession to the British throne. The line of succession to the United States presidency includes 18 titles, from the vice president to the secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, the most recently created Cabinet-level department.

title: Update on Yohanita
description: We went back to HEAL Africa to visit Yohanita, the 41-year old woman we had found in the village of Malehe to be suffering from infection and severe malnutrition. I was relieved to see that she was lying in bed, fully conscious, and able to speak in full sentences. Feza, the girl who came down from the village, was at her bedside and feeding her some porridge and potatoes, which Yohanita was eating in big spoonfuls.

title: Report Says E.P.A. Misled Public About Indoor Air Hazards of 9/11
description: Federal environmental officials misled Lower Manhattan residents about the extent of contamination in their condominiums and apartments after the collapse of the World Trade Center, according to a preliminary report released today by the Government Accountability Office.According to the report, which was made public during a Senate subcommittee hearing in Washington, the Environmental Protection Agency did not accurately report the results of a residential cleanup program in 2002 and 2003. More than 4,000 apartments in Lower Manhattan were professionally decontaminated in that program, and the agency reported that only a very small number of air samples taken in those residences showed unsafe levels of asbestos.

title: McCain Plays Down the Money Chase
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Senator John McCain acknowledged here today that fundraising has been very tough, but said that his brand of retail politics does not demand huge sums of money this early in the campaign.

title: Dow Jones Board Takes Lead in News Corp. Talks
description: In the latest twists in the Dow Jones saga, the company said on Wednesday that its board of directors has taken the lead in negotiating with Rupert Murdochs News Corporation. The move may push the publisher of The Wall Street Journal closer and faster to a sale.

title: Blogtalk: All About Bloomberg
description: When it comes to New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and whether hell actually make a bid for the White House, the only point of agreement among some prominent bloggers is that the billionaire mayor has the resources to mount a serious campaign.

title: Fear
description: I can hear the music pulsating in the thick Congo night, inviting me. Come over, dance, drink, have a good time, enjoy life. But I am scared to leave the hotel at night.

title: Merrill Kicks Off Auction for Assets in Bear Stearns Fund
description: The fate of Bear Stearns beleaguered subprime-securities hedge fund was up in the air Wednesday afternoon, as at least one major lender has begun auctioning off its collateral.

title: The Rule of the Decent Interval
description: Call me shallow, but I am fond of those little extemporaneous rules, like Murphys Law or the Peter Principle, that allow us to recognize and ridicule familiar patterns of social behavior. And Id like to propose one of my own.

title: One Year Later: My Real Fathers Day
description: I have never cried much. In fact, I could probably count on one hand how many times I had really cried, as an adult, up until the time I came home from Iraq. During my tour, I couldnt even shed a tear at my moms memorial service. I felt cold and numb because of everything going on around me. Not callous, just gifted at compartmentalizing emotions. Ive cried more in the last year than I have in a lifetime. But heres the catch. They have all been tears of joy, in moments where I am simply overwhelmed and feel so very lucky to be home with my kids.

title: Yahoo Good, Google Better (a Lot Better)
description: Its become a monthly ritual with few surprises. Web audience measuring firms report numbers for Web search traffic in the United States. Yahoo does well. Google does a lot better. Microsoft and others barely hold on, or worse.

title: I Do Not Wish to Enroll in a Party
The Only Reason to Run for President Is to Win
description: This evening, the NewsHour with Jim Lehrer broadcast excerpts from an interview Judy Woodruff conducted on Tuesday in Los Angeles with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles. The interview occurred before Mr. Bloombergs surprise announcement that he was leaving the Republican Party.In the interview, Ms. Woodruff asked the mayor why he would not run for president as an independent, and he replied, You dont have to run for president to get the issues out there. The only reason to run for president is to win and be president and to try to affect not just dialogue, but try to change things.

title: Remember to Stay Home
description: Just a travel advisory:This years E3, the annual garish neon-drenched video game industry trade show, is a shadow of its former self. And youre not invited.The show used to take place at the Los Angeles Convention Center in May and was a take-all-comers, lavish show with lots of booth babes and millions spent by the major video game companies to promote their latest technology and products.

title: Q & A: Sarah Jessica Parker
description: A few years ago you could dismiss an actor for attempting to put his or her name on anything other than a movie or a TV show. Two bullet-proof exceptions were Paul Newman (spaghetti sauce) and Elizabeth Taylor (perfume). They had, in addition to talent and looks, a massive store of goodwill with the American people that exempted them from scorn. Now, all the roles have been if not quite reversed then shuffled: average Joes get to become divas (thanks to American Idol), musicians are statesmen (Bono), designers are artists (Hedi Slimane), bloggers are the new tastemakers, and actors are making jeans. Actors have a hard time winning our approval as designers, in part because the new tastemakers can so readily make them the object of our contempt (I cite the catalog of red-carpet disasters on Go Fug Yourself), and in part because we suspect that the mastery of one craft doesnt presume an ability to master another without demeaning both.

title: They Both Start With P
description: Oliver Perez is not much of a basketball fan. But he was sitting alone on a clubhouse couch at about 5:30, watching on ESPN Classic the replay of Game 6 of the 1993 N.B.A. Finals. The Chicago Bulls clinched their third consecutive championship that night in Phoenix, and the big shot, a three-pointer by John Paxson, came with 3.9 seconds left. Perez looked as if he had never seen it before, and he said, Wow over and over and over again.

title: Six Degrees of Mike Gallego
description: When Derek Jeter joined the Yankees, he was given No. 2  probably, he guesses, because he was skinny and it was the smallest jersey size. The last player to wear it before him was infielder Mike Gallego.

title: Win a Trip: Photos of Hope
description: Will Okun, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, discussed his photographic style.

title: Congressmans Brother Is Said to Have Bribed School Official
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 20  The former president of the Orleans Parish School Board pleaded guilty in federal court on Wednesday to taking $140,000 in bribes from a political operative thought to be the older brother of Representative William J. Jefferson, who has been indicted on bribery charges.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the bombing of a Sunni Arab mosque near the southern Iraqi city of Basra misstated the name of the mosque. (The error was repeated in an article on Sunday about violence in Iraq.) It is the Talha Bin Obeidallah Mosque, not Talha Bin al-Zubair.

title: Bronx: Woman Guilty in Sons Death
description: A Bronx mother has pleaded guilty to manslaughter for failing to obtain medical attention for her 4-year-old son after he was beaten by her live-in boyfriend, prosecutors said yesterday. The mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, admitted in State Supreme Court on Tuesday that she had recklessly caused the death of her son, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006 by not immediately seeking medical help, the Bronx district attorneys office said. Ms. Smith will be sentenced to 2  to 7  years in prison in July, prosecutors said. The boyfriend, Jose Calderon, 19, has pleaded not guilty to murder charges. Prosecutors said Mr. Calderon beat the child over a period of several days because he had broken a television set.

title: General Strike Over Rising Fuel Price Takes Hold in Nigerian Cities
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, June 20  Shop shutters stayed bolted and young men played soccer on roads that were usually choked with traffic as the first day of an indefinite general strike and fuel shortages brought cities across Nigeria to a hush on Wednesday.

title: Democratizing the Nations Capital
description: Just in time for next months rockets red glare, a measure to give the residents of Washington D.C. their long-denied right to a full vote in the House of Representatives is making headway in the Senate. The legislation, already passed by the House, is gaining unexpected support from Senate Republicans finally struck by the injustice of the meeting place of democracy being denied its democratic right.

title: U.S. Is Urging Blair to Be Lead Mideast Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, representing the diplomatic quartet of world powers, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Health Coverage for All Americans (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: London Weighs In on Rings
description: Mixed reviews greeted The Lord of the Rings,  a $25 million musical, after it opened on Tuesday at the Theater Royal in London, The Associated Press reported. Billed as the most expensive production in West End history, the show, revised from a version that drew a mixed response in Toronto in 2006, received enthusiastic notices from The Times of London (a wonder) and The Guardian, but The Financial Times said it could not muster a single memorable tune, and Charles Spencer of The Daily Telegraph said, Its run, I fear, will be nasty, brutish and short.

title: Space Shuttle to Stay in Orbit Another Day
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., June 21  The space shuttle Atlantis will stay in orbit another day. Mission managers called off both landing opportunities this afternoon because of rain showers within 35 miles of the landing runway here.

title: Bronx: Man Dies as He Flees Police
description: A Bronx man fell to his death on Tuesday night as he tried to escape through a window when police officers arrived at his door with an arrest warrant, the police said yesterday. The man, James Harris, 42, of 1900 Grand Concourse, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said that Mr. Harris was being sought on charges of trademark counterfeiting and that he tried to escape when officers knocked on the door of his fourth-floor apartment.

title: Up to 5 Are Missing in Flooded Catskill Town
description: Rescue workers searched frantically yesterday for as many as five people reported missing in the southern Catskill town of Colchester after flash floods washed away several homes, a dozen vehicles and a bridge, state and local officials said.

title: How the U.S. Has Kept the Productivity Playing Field Tilted to Its Advantage
description: Americans anxiety level over competitiveness with other nations has grown in recent years. A large number of Americans appear to believe that the United States will not be able to succeed in an open world market, and they argue in favor of reducing our exposure to the outside.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column, about the success of famous players at the United States Open, included incorrect information from The Associated Press about the golfer shown hitting out of sand at the 1953 Open. It was an unidentified golfer; it was not Ben Hogan, who won the tournament. (Research by The Times and by The A.P. failed to produce an identification.)

title: Brooklyn: Ex-Judge Ordered to Prison
description: An appeals court judge yesterday denied a stay of sentence for a former State Supreme Court justice convicted of corruption charges and ordered him to begin serving his 3-to-10-year prison term. The former judge, Gerald Garson, was convicted in April of accepting bribes to manipulate the outcome of matrimonial cases in his Brooklyn court. At his sentencing on June 5, Mr. Garsons $15,000 bail was revoked, but his lawyers won a temporary reprieve that afternoon. They argued that Mr. Garson, 74 and ailing, should remain free while he appealed the verdict on the grounds that the evidence was insufficient. In documents filed with the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, Second Department, prosecutors argued that the verdict was supported by overwhelming evidence, and yesterday, in a one-page decision, Associate Justice Edward D. Carni revoked the temporary stay.

title: Bell Canada Discussing a Merger With Western Provinces Carrier
description: OTTAWA, June 20  Bell Canada, the target of at least three possible privatization bids, said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada.

title: Antonio Aguilar, 88, Ranchera Singer, Dies
description: MEXICO CITY, June 20  Antonio Aguilar, the film star and ranchera singer who was considered the undisputed master of his genre for decades, died here on Tuesday. He was 88.

title: T.G.I. Fridays Finds Smaller Portions Add to Customer Traffic
description: Four months after it introduced smaller portions to its menu, T.G.I. Fridays is finding that less food translates into more customers and, perhaps, bigger profits.

title: William LeMessurier, 81, Structural Engineer, Dies
description: William J. LeMessurier, a structural engineer who became a hero to other structural engineers when he detected and repaired a potentially catastrophic flaw in the Citicorp building in Manhattan, died on June 14 in Casco, Me. He was 81.

title: Senate Approves Stricter Fuel Standards for Autos
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Senate voted this evening to raise fuel-economy requirements for cars and sport utility vehicles, demanding that they get 35 miles per gallon by 2020.

title: Injured Schilling to Miss Two Starts
description: ATLANTA, June 20  The Red Sox have carved out a large lead in the American League East largely because of a starting rotation that has for the most part stayed healthy. Aside from a blister that cost Josh Beckett two starts, the starters have hummed along and the team has received sensational late-inning relief from the rookie Hideki Okajima.

title: Lack of References Subverts Browns Glowing Rsum
description: There were seven empty seats on the N.B.A. coaching carousel when it reached maximum velocity in late May. The whirling has nearly stopped, and six coaches have settled into place  one reliable old hand, two less-proven retreads and three virtual rookies.

title: Pension Relief for Airlines Faulted by Some Legislators
description: A pension measure tucked into last months Iraq war spending bill is causing some leading members of Congress to complain that American Airlines got a break worth almost $2 billion without proper scrutiny.

title: Japanese Company Donates Funds to Restore Munch Paintings
description: A Japanese company operating in Norway has pledged $670,000 toward the restoration of the Edvard Munch paintings The Scream and Madonna, above, damaged during a brazen daylight armed theft from the Munch Museum in Oslo in 2004, Agence France-Presse reported. The Oslo city authorities said the donation by Idemitsu Petroleum of Japan to the Munch Museum would be applied to restoration of, and research into, the two paintings, which were chipped, scratched, punctured and harmed by humidity, and are now undergoing repair. Three men suspected of participating in the robbery have been sentenced to prison and fined.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Confused Bleeding Heart

title: Mets Defensive Lapses Few and Far Between
description: Tom Glavines 8-year-old son, Peyton, was watching the Mets game Tuesday night and did not like what he saw. He asked his father why David Wright, after making his second error of the game, threw his glove in the dugout.

title: Out of a Packing Box, Not Stuff, but Souls
description: I WAS initiated young into the cult of clutter. Opening a drawer in my childhood kitchen meant finding birthday cards sticky from a leaking pen, a recipe for moussaka never made, bits of yarn and a Hot Wheels car missing a door. Occasionally, my mother attempted organization by topic (Vacation Ideas, Childrens Vaccinations, Restaurants to Try), but she never got hanging files, so the folders slipped and slid over one another. Dad had a secretary at work to organize his papers, and at home he directed seasonal weekend purges that inevitably threw Barbies out with the bath water.

title: An MP3 Player That Is Designed to Shake Up Music Listening
description: Music and food have always been compatible, which may be why a salt-shaker-shaped MP3 player sounds like fun. After all, the idea of shaking something to mix up the contents  in this case a music playlist  is something even a baby can understand. The $40 Sansa Shaker from SanDisk also comes with an onboard speaker, making it possible to share audio files with everyone at the table. Its like a micro-size jukebox.

title: Shiite Rivalries Slash at a Once Calm Iraqi City
description: DIWANIYA, Iraq  The Shiite heartland of southern Iraq has generally been an oasis of calm in contrast to Baghdad and the central part of the country, but now violence is convulsing this city. Shiites are killing and kidnapping other Shiites, the police force is made up of competing militias and the inner city is a web of impoverished streets where idealized portraits of young men, killed in recent gun battles with Iraqi and American troops, hang from signposts above empty lots.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on May 26 about Rochesters economic decline referred imprecisely to the number of universities there and misstated the percentage change in population over the past three decades. There is one university, the University of Rochester, within the city limits, not six. (The other five are in suburban Rochester). The population decline was 26 percent, not 40 percent.

title: China: Investment Fund Plans Bond Issue
description: The Chinese legislature plans a review next week of the Finance Ministrys plans for a bond issue to raise money for a new state-run foreign investment fund, the government said. The fund agreed last month to acquire a nonvoting stake of nearly 10 percent in the Blackstone Group. By selling yuan-denominated bonds to buy foreign currency for overseas investments, the fund would be partly replacing similar bond sales and currency purchases conducted until now by the central bank. While Chinese officials have said that it is not their intention to drive down the value of the dollar, economists are waiting to see whether the new investment fund will allocate as much of its bond proceeds to dollar-denominated purchases as the central bank has; more than two-thirds of the $1.2 trillion in reserves managed by the central bank are thought to be in dollars.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,524 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.What is the most economical way to wallpaper a room?

title: Britains Private Equity Firms Try to Make the Case for Their Low Taxes
description: LONDON, June 20  Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament on Tuesday and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

title: A Prime Minister Cool to Culture Will Leave Behind a Hot Arts Scene
description: LONDON, June 20  Over the past 10 years, while cultural innovation has seemingly been sparse in traditional creative breeding grounds like the United States and France, the arts have been flourishing in Britain. Never before have museums been so popular; not since the 1960s have artists, composers, playwrights, designers and the like enjoyed such prestige.

title: Tricks Get Trickier, Raising Questions of Safety
description: Jeremy Stenberg has not competed in a freestyle motocross event since falling out of the sky during the Dew Tour last June in Louisville, Ky.

title: Song That Comes From the Words of Friends
description: The composer David Del Tredici has written of three times during his career when he felt compelled to reject all he had been taught and rely on instincts  three times he had to, in a sense, come out.

title: Another Step Toward Invisibility for the Cellphone Headset
description: Determining whether someone speaking into the air is on the phone or just a little odd is becoming harder.

title: Justices Tighten Rules on Shareholder Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Supreme Court dealt a new blow today to investors suing companies over accusations of fraud when it set a higher standard to prevent the lawsuits from being dismissed.

title: Egypt Arranges Peace Summit in Support of Abbas
description: GAZA, June 21  In a gesture of support for Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, Egypt has organized a summit meeting for him and the leaders of Jordan and Israel that is to take place on Monday, Israel announced today.

title: Mini-Series Revisits the Yankees Melodrama During the Summer of 77
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J., June 20  Joe Grifasi was at the Yogi Berra Museum here Wednesday explaining his approach to portraying Berra in The Bronx Is Burning, the eight-part miniseries on ESPN that begins July 9.

title: Report Warns of Risks in Federal Liens Notices
description: Federal government agencies have risked exposing millions of Social Security numbers to identity thieves by including the numbers in federal liens notices that are sent to local governments and are often made available over the Internet, federal investigators said in a report expected to be released today.

title: Airport Tries to Rein In Greeters Generosity Toward Troops
description: BOSTON, June 20  For several years, the Maine Troop Greeters have welcomed soldiers from every military transport plane that has landed at Bangor International Airport with hugs, handshakes, cookies and homemade goodies.

title: Report Says U.S. Misled City on Dust From Ground Zero
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Federal environmental officials misled Lower Manhattan residents about the extent of contamination in their condominiums and apartments after the collapse of the World Trade Center, according to a preliminary report released on Wednesday by the Government Accountability Office.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on May 30 by The Associated Press about Barbara Cox Anthony, an heir to the Cox media fortune, incorrectly described her inheritance. And a correction in this space on Friday misattributed the error. Ms. Anthony and her sister, Anne Cox Chambers, and their older brother, James M. Cox Jr., all held equal interests in the company before the death of Mr. Cox in 1974, at which time the sisters received his share; they did not inherit the entire company from Mr. Cox. The error was introduced by an editor, not by The A.P.

title: Around the Campfire, Global Ghost Stories
description: UNLIKE many parents, Maria Valero does not mind that her son Enrique spends hours on the Internet talking with friends. That is because Enrique, 12, and his family live in Caracas, Venezuela, and by sending instant messages to the American children he befriended during his summers at Mountain Camp, near Lake Tahoe in California, he keeps his English skills sharp.

title: Republicans Losing the West
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: Gay Marriage, a Touchy Issue, Touches Legislators Emotions
description: ALBANY, June 20  Teresa R. Sayward did not hesitate when she rose from her seat on Tuesday night to address her colleagues in the State Assembly. An observant Catholic from a small, conservative upstate town, she had rarely shared the story of her son, Glenn, 42, and his struggle to come to terms with his gay identity decades ago.

title: Napoleons Toothbrush Finally Has a Home
description: LONDON, June 20  Self-made millionaires (or billionaires today) often acquire respectability by investing in great art. Then, at the appropriate time, they donate or bequeath it to museums willing to give their names to a gallery or wing.

title: Next Week
description: Next week, Will Leitch of Deadspin.com makes his debut as a regular contributor to the PLAY e-mail newsletter, spinning his distinct brand of commentary on the oddities and follies of the sports world.

title: New Delay for Passports Along Borders
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The Bush administration on Wednesday postponed rules that would require passports for United States citizens re-entering the country by land or sea from Canada, Mexico, Bermuda or Caribbean countries.

title: Fast, Dazzling, Large and Deluxe
description: PARIS, June 20  The Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass is not the kind of guy who flies commercial. If his latest venture takes to the skies, he will not be the kind who flies subsonic either.

title: Anger at Coach Fuels Racial Divide in Rural Colorado
description: LA JARA, Colo.  The photograph, of four popular high school students standing side by side, each clutching a gun in one hand and giving a stiff-armed Nazi salute with the other, terrified many people in La Jara and the surrounding poor farming communities of the San Luis Valley. Its discovery further intensified a bitter racial divide between supporters of a longtime coach, who is black, and a largely white group of students and their parents.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Corrections: Kitchen Tales
description: An article last Thursday about six home kitchens misstated the age for Simone Leigh, an artist whose kitchen is decorated with found objects. She is 39, not 46. The article also misstated the location for Jills, a restaurant owned by Jill Pettijohn, whose home kitchen was featured. It is in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, not Red Hook.

title: U.S. Holds Direct Talks in North Korea on Arms
description: TOKYO, June 21  The United States chief nuclear negotiator began a surprise two-day visit to North Korea today, saying he wanted to speed up six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Koreas nuclear program.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on June 11 about the dedication of Cole Porters childhood home in Peru, Ind., as a bed and breakfast and museum, referred imprecisely to the financing of the restoration of the house. It was financed by tax-deductible funds accepted by the Ole Olsen Memorial Theater in Peru, not by the theaters own funds.

title: Toby Keiths Big Dog Is No. 1
description: Toby Keith is No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with Big Dog Daddy (Show Dog Nashville), though in what has become a familiar pattern for the music industry, record sales were low across the board. Big Dog Daddy sold 204,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The Brooklyn rapper Fabolous reached No. 2 this week with his new From Nothin to Somethin  (Def Jam), selling 159,000 copies. Paul McCartneys Memory Almost Full (Hear Music) remained at No. 3 with 107,000, a decline of 34 percent from last week. DJ Khaleds new We the Best (Koch) reached No. 8, and The Traveling Wilburys Collection (Rhino) opened at No. 9.

title: City Mourns Firefighters and 9 Lost on the Job: Fathers, Mentors, Friends
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., June 20  Technically, Art Wittner had the day off. But as the last surviving member of the Monday night shift from his firehouse, Station 16, he could not think of staying away from work.

title: Hail to the Teacher (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lilly, Matriarch of U.S. Team, Refuses to Fade to Gray
description: CLEVELAND, June 15  The other day, a visitor suggested to Kristine Lilly that she might have a pair of jeans older than some of her teammates on the United States womens soccer team.

title: Coria Settles With Company He Claims Made a Bad Pill
description: Guillermo Coria, a professional tennis player from Argentina, reached a settlement in a New Brunswick, N.J., court yesterday with the supplement manufacturer that he said made a contaminated multivitamin that led to a positive steroid test six years ago.

title: PGA Tour Moves Closer to Adopting Drug Policy
description: Tim Finchem, the commissioner of the PGA Tour, said yesterday that the organization may institute a policy on performance-enhancing drugs, including testing, by the end of the year.

title: Grown-Up Films Vie for Viewers in Summer
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19  When Gary Palmucci, the general manager of a small New York film distributor, was picking a date to release Lady Chatterley, a buzzed-about French retelling of the steamy D. H. Lawrence story, he knew he wanted to open the movie in the summer.

title: No, Despite the Polls, Its Not Really a Horse Race (Not Yet, Anyway)
description: For at least a generation, press critics have complained bitterly about the news medias obsession with polls and the horse-race aspect of the presidential campaign. The constant focus on who is ahead is a pointless distraction, those critics argue, from what should be the real substance of the campaign, like what the candidates would do as president.

title: As National Candidate, Bloomberg Would Have to Multitask
description: It seemed to be no coincidence that the day after he announced his formal departure from the Republican Party and left open the door to an independent presidential campaign, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg mundanely announced yesterday that the citys 311 customer service telephone line had received its 50 millionth call.

title: Congress Weighs End to Private Equity Tax Break
description: Leaders of the tax-writing committees in Congress are considering a new proposal to end a little-known tax break that has allowed wealthy financiers who run private equity firms and hedge funds to cut their total income tax bills by billions of dollars, aides to lawmakers say.

title: Jones Faces Felony Charges in Las Vegas
description: Already serving a one-year suspension from the National Football League, Pacman Jones will face two felony charges stemming from a strip club disturbance in February that led to three people being shot.

title: Trenton: Lesbians File Discrimination Complaint
description: Two lesbians from Ocean Grove have filed a complaint with the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights, claiming that the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, a Methodist organization, illegally discriminated against them when it denied their request to rent the boardwalk pavilion for their civil union ceremony in September. In the complaint, filed on Tuesday, the women, Harriet Bernstein and Luisa Paster, note that the pavilion is regularly used for weddings of heterosexual couples. The division will investigate to see if there is sufficient evidence of discrimination; if so, the case will be referred to an administrative law judge. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Once Again, Yankees Bats Are Stifled by Rockies
description: DENVER, June 20  The Yankees came here as the hottest team in the American League. With their rollicking offense in the thin air of Colorado against a traditional also-ran, the Yankees had reason to believe they would thrive at Coors Field.

title: Giambi Is Likely to Meet With Mitchell
description: Jason Giambi of the Yankees is expected to announce today that he will cooperate with former Senator George J. Mitchells investigation into the use of performance-enhancing substances in Major League Baseball.

title: Late-Session Measures Stir Scrutiny and Skepticism
description: ALBANY, June 20  A torrent of bills and amendments are swirling through the halls of the Capitol as the legislative session here comes to a close. Some are big bills, like campaign finance or same-sex marriage legislation, loudly debated and widely pondered. Some are small bills, often championed by a lone and lonely lawmaker, like a proposal to name the Concord the official state grape.

title: Oxfam Suggests Benefit in Africa if U.S. Cuts Cotton Subsidies
description: Eliminating billions of dollars in federal subsidies to American cotton growers each year would reduce American cotton production and exports, raise world prices by about 10 percent and modestly improve the incomes of millions of poor cotton farmers in Africa, according to a new study by Oxfam, the aid group.

title: 50 Years of Heavy Reading, and Looking for More
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y., June 15  The longest-running book club in this Long Island beach community may be one of the longest-lived book clubs on the planet, for all anyone knows. But, irony of ironies  as any irony-invoking book club member might appreciate  the members are having a hard time remembering just how old their club really is.

title: Zeev Schiff, 74, Author and Dean of Israel Military Correspondents, Dies
description: JERUSALEM, June 20  Zeev Schiff, the dean of Israeli military correspondents, defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz and author of numerous books, died Tuesday in Tel Aviv. He was 74.

title: Academic Boycotts (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Smithsonian Ex-Chief Criticized in Report
description: Though his talent for fund-raising was cited to justify his ballooning salary, private donations to the Smithsonian Institution actually declined under its former chief executive, Lawrence M. Small, an independent committee said in a scathing report issued yesterday.

title: For the Fashion-Conscious, a Laptop With Substance and Style
description: For some, customizing a laptop involves a few Blink-182 stickers and a black marker. Sony is kicking things up a notch with its Vaio CR series of fashion-forward, customizable laptops in five colors.

title: Digital S.L.R.s That Let You Shoot Like a Pro
description: To an ordinary person, the summer might mean barbecues, baseball games and trips to the beach. To a photography nut, however, it means longer days of sunlight, brighter subject colors (beach balls, bathing suits) and more people who dont have to be told to Smile!

title: Serving Some Gumbo From Old New Orleans
description: Even before Hurricane Katrina the Preservation Hall Jazz Band had been reviving. Now, touring heavily, making new records and collaborations, and perhaps carrying a sharper mandate of cultural preservation  because the New Orleans we knew really is gone  the band has become worth another hearing.

title: Brooklyn: Suspect Sought in Sex Attack
description: Officers conducted a widespread manhunt in Brooklyn last night after a woman, identified by an official as a police officer, was sexually assaulted in Bay Ridge, the police said. The assault occurred near 95 Bay Ridge Avenue around 7 p.m., they said.

title: Whole Foods Deal
description: Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Dining section yesterday about restaurants run by pastry chefs misstated the dates that ChikaLicious (203 East 10th Street), one of the first such restaurants in New York, will close for renovations. It will be closed from July 2-5; it is not closed now. The article also misspelled the name of a new place the restaurants owners will be opening. It is ChikaLicious Puddin, not Pudding.

title: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills 3 Canadians
description: Three Canadian soldiers were killed when a roadside bomb tore through their vehicle in southern Afghanistan, according to NATO officials and the Canadian government. Additionally, two Afghan drivers died when their convoy was attacked by the Taliban, said Ghulam Jalani, deputy police chief of Zabul Province.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about eBays fight against fraudulent auctions misstated the name of a trade group that provided information about illegal software sales on the site. The group is the Software and Information Industry Association, not the Software Industry Association of America.

title: Wal-Mart to Expand Banking Services
description: Wal-Mart Stores said today that it would rapidly expand the financial services offered in its stores, extending the reach of its retailing empire into the bank accounts of its shoppers.

title: Suggested Reading
description: Wimbledon starts on Monday, and once again John McEnroe will provide television commentary. McEnroe won Wimbledon three times, alternately displaying exquisite shotmaking and tantrums so demonstrative that the London tabloids labeled him Superbrat.

title: Science Panel Finds Fault With Estimates of Coal Supply
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The United States may not have nearly as much coal as is popularly believed, and mining the remaining resources may be more dangerous for workers and the environment than current operations, the National Academy of Sciences said in a report Wednesday.

title: For 2 Years, Bloomberg Aides Prepared for Bid
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  The announcement by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York that he was leaving the Republican Party to become an independent was made after nearly two years in which his aides had laid the groundwork for a potential independent run for president.

title: Corrections: Behind the Glass Wall
description: An article on June 7 about Philip Johnsons Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., misspelled the surname of the archivist of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, who was a visitor to the house. He is David Vaughan, not Vaughn.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A dance review yesterday about the American Ballet Theaters production of Romeo and Juliet, at the Metropolitan Opera House, misidentified the dancer who portrays Paris. He is Gennadi Saveliev  not Jared Matthews, who is Benvolio.

title: Big Money for Little E
description: So youve been hearing about Dale Earnhardt Jr. changing race teams, effective at the end of this Nascar season, but you dont know what the fuss is about? The main reason this is such a big deal, as always, is money.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Morgan Stanleys Profits Rise, Defying Subprime Slump
description: Morgan Stanley, driven by its trading and investment banking divisions, reported a robust second quarter yesterday with a 41 percent increase in net earnings.

title: Putting on Lip Gloss, and a Show, for YouTube Viewers
description: MANY women slap on their makeup in front of the mirror before they dash out the door: a quick coat of foundation, a dusting of blush, a brush of eye shadow, a twirl of the mascara wand and a quick smear of lip gloss. The beauty ritual hardly varies, and audiences generally arent invited.

title: Not Buying It
description: ON a Friday evening last month, the day after New York Universitys class of 2007 graduated, about 15 men and women assembled in front of Third Avenue North, an N.Y.U. dormitory on Third Avenue and 12th Street. They had come to take advantage of the universitys end-of-the-year move-out, when students discarded items are loaded into big green trash bins by the curb.

title: At Wal-Mart, a Back Door Into Banking
description: Wal-Mart failed to get approval for a bank. But the giant discount chain is effectively building one anyway.

title: Yahoo Buying a High School and College Sports Network
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20  Just one day after the management shake-up at Yahoo, the companys board was called on to make a decision that had nothing to do with the resignation of Terry S. Semel as chief executive or the appointment of the co-founder Jerry Yang to succeed him.

title: Really, Really Rosie
description: Watched Rosie this morning. You know, Rosie ODonnell. Shes that homebody who lives with her wife and kids and hangs out with her good-time girlfriends and says whatever she wants.

title: In Colorado, Matsuis Problems Have Vanished Into Thin Air
description: DENVER, June 20  Kazuo Matsui stood on his tiptoes by his locker at Coors Field on Tuesday, smiling easily as he rubbed his feet along the raised dimples on a curved slab of wood. He was giving his feet a massage, and he eagerly showed a visitor a chart displaying various pressure points. Stimulating the nerve endings, it said, can have powerful effects on overall circulation.

title: United Nations: Russia Rejects Kosovo Plan
description: The United States and European countries on the Security Council circulated a new resolution calling for independence for Kosovo, the breakaway province of Serbia, and delaying carrying out the plan for four months, but Russia, whose objections to a previous version led to the revision, rejected it. Kosovo has welcomed the plan and has threatened to declare independence on its own if the United Nations does not act, but Vitaly I. Churkin, Russias ambassador, called it unacceptable.

title: Lawsuit Casts Doubt on TV Reality
description: The celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay has been accused of falsifying scenes in a new Fox television reality show that gives him a weeks time to make over failing restaurants and records his confrontations with staff, The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, brought by Martin R. Hyde, a former general manager at Dillons in Manhattan, said Mr. Ramsay falsely claimed that meat was spoiled, used a defective chair to imply that the restaurants furniture was shoddy and hired actors to pose as customers to make the restaurant appear busy by the end of the week. Asking for millions in damages and a court order to stop the show from being broadcast as scheduled in the fall, Mr. Hyde also maintained that Mr. Ramsay humiliated him and drove him to quit to avoid further abuse. James Curich, a spokesman for Mr. Ramsay, said he could not comment on the lawsuit because he had not seen it. Jennifer Sprague, a Fox spokeswoman in Los Angeles, said she could not comment, and Andrew Blackmore, a manager at Dillons, said he had signed a release stating that he could not discuss the show with the news media. A year ago Mr. Ramsay won $138,000 and an apology in a libel suit in London against the publishers of The Evening Standard, which had accused him of faking scenes in his reality show Kitchen Nightmares, also about a restaurant makeover. I wont let people write anything they want about me, he said.

title: A Plea to Let a Punishment Fit the Prank
description: MONTROSE, N.Y.

title: Talent Beats the Competition
description: Americas Got Talent has got America watching. Nielsen estimated that an average of 12.4 million viewers tuned in on Tuesday to watch this two-hour competition, from NBC, earn its second-best ratings ever among adults 18 to 49, more than doubling those of its closest competitor at both 8 and 9 p.m. NBC easily won the night, leading the 10 oclock hour as well with a repeat of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (9.4 million). CBS ranked second with reruns of NCIS at 8 (9.3 million), The Unit at 9 (5.9 million), and 48 Hours at 10 (6.8 million). Fox finished ahead of ABC in third, as its repeat of House at 9 (6.6 million) compensated for its low-performing On the Lot at 8 (2.4 million).

title: The Empire Slate
description: Hamden, Conn.

title: Kazakhstan Ballot Called 2 Years Early
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, June 20  Kazakhstans lower house of Parliament was dissolved Wednesday in preparation for early elections.

title: 14 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq in 2 Days
description: BAGHDAD, June 21  Fourteen Americans were killed in combat in five incidents, most in Baghdad, in a 48-hour period ending Thursday, the military announced.

title: Joggers Know His Sculptures; Meet the Artist Behind Them
description: This falls into the now-you-know category: The artist who has been intriguing bikers and joggers with driftwood sculptures along the Hudson River in Manhattan has been identified as Tom Loback.

title: Rival Hunters on the Run in a Cat-and-Mouse Game
description: Theres a scene in Thomas Perrys Silence in which a powerful male executive from the entertainment world, naked, is tended to by two young female assistants. Since Silence technically qualifies as a thriller, and since so many thrillers have strong sleaze components, its easy to imagine where this setup might lead.

title: His Charge: Find a Key to Students Success
description: Roland G. Fryer, who was hired by Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein to advise him on how to narrow the racial gap in achievement in the citys schools, made his professional name in economics by applying complex algorithms to document how black students fall behind their white peers. But his life story challenges his own calculations.

title: Central Islip: Bank Robbery Charges
description: A Suffolk County man accused of robbing five banks on Long Island in the last three months pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in First District Court, the Suffolk County district attorneys office said. The man, Steven P. Bertuglia, 34, was arrested on Tuesday night as he sat in his car in Mount Sinai, the Suffolk police said. In addition to being charged with robbing five banks, he is suspected of robbing others on Long Island and in New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey, the police said.

title: The Number 61
description: Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 63 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61, Roger Maris's record before Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa surpassed it in 1998, again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?

title: Citizen Kane Wins an Election
description: Citizen Kane has held onto its title in a once-a-decade poll as the best of all American films, winning the top spot for the second time in a row in a poll of film critics, historians and others conducted by the American Film Institute, Reuters reported. The Godfather moved up a notch to take second place, dropping Casablanca into third in the ranking of the 100 best films. Raging Bull moved up 20 places, to No. 4, followed by Singin in the Rain, Gone With the Wind, Lawrence of Arabia, Schindlers List, Vertigo and The Wizard of Oz. D. W. Griffiths Intolerance (1916) was voted into the Top 100, but his Birth of a Nation (1915) was voted out, despite its technical innovations. Of 43 newly eligible films, released from 1966 to 2006, Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring appeared (50th place), as did Saving Private Ryan (71), Titanic (83) and The Sixth Sense (89). The results were disclosed on the CBS special 100 Years, 100 movies, 10th Anniversary Edition.

title: Mr. Bushs Stem Cell Diversion
description: The executive order on stem cells issued by President Bush yesterday seeks to reorient research in new directions that may or may not pay off. But make no mistake, it is no substitute for the bill expanding embryonic stem cell research that Mr. Bush vetoed at the same time because it would involve the destruction of microscopic entities  smaller than the period at the end of this sentence  that the president deems a nascent form of life.

title: Truth in Cereal (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens: Man Charged in Fatal Shooting
description: A Queens man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting a man in the street after an argument in a nearby bodega, prosecutors said. The man, Sherwin Thompson, 20, of 119th Avenue in South Jamaica, was charged with murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Thompson repeatedly shot Germaine Persaud, 21, about 1 a.m. on Monday as Mr. Persaud stood in front of his house on 192nd Street.

title: For Some Things, Its O.K. to Be Sticky (Yoga Mats)
description: WHICH one of these is not like the others: urdhva mukha svanasana, chaturanga dandasana, polyvinyl chloride. The first two are Sanskrit names for yoga poses, the third, a toxic plastic often used in sticky yoga mats.

title: Woods Chases Nicklaus as a Father
description: The world has seen the evolution of Tiger Woods from prodigy to wunderkind to amateur champion to winner of multi Masters, Opens and P.G.A. Championships to multi-multimillionaire to husband and now to father. And a few days before his wife, Elin, delivered their daughter, Sam Alexis, the morning after he tied for second at the United States Open, he was asked how being a parent would change his golf life.

title: Lottery Numbers
Dark Work in a Sunny Spot
description: WARREN BEATTY, for whom the novelist Susanna Moore once worked, found her voice so hilarious that he cast her in his film Shampoo, Ms. Moore was saying at her Brooklyn apartment the other day. It is an odd voice, high-pitched, and, as even she points out, over-enunciated; the voice of a schoolmistress who taught less privileged youth a century or so back. It is not the voice one would expect, given that the book that brought her notoriety a dozen years ago was the erotic thriller In the Cut, and that her latest novel, The Big Girls, set in a womens prison, has again stirred the critics into a lather of moral indignation.

title: Zoellick Obtains Board Support to Lead World Bank, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Robert B. Zoellick, President Bushs nominee for president of the World Bank, secured the support of the banks board of directors on Wednesday after reporting to them about his recent meetings with bank representatives around the world, bank officials said.

title: North Dakota Is Sued in Church-State Case
description: A group that advocates strict separation of church and state has sued North Dakota to bar public financing of an association that provides therapeutic and rehabilitative services for troubled youth by steeping them in Christian teachings, Bible readings, religious services and rituals.

title: Bringing Home Lessons Learned on the Battlefield
description: AT 38, Thomas J. Deierlein had carved out a busy, fulfilling Madison Avenue career, working as chief operating officer for Dynamic Logic, a market research company that gauges the effectiveness of advertising. After more than a decade in the business, his days as an elite Army Ranger were far behind him  or so he thought until October 2005.

title: The Bloomberg Question
description: We probably should know better, but for now were going to take a politician at face value and believe Michael Bloomberg when he says he is not running for president. His line yesterday about running only if he was the last person on earth was Shermanesque by todays standards. And were not ready to weigh in on whether New Yorks billionaire mayor should be Americas billionaire president.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about International Lease Finance Corporations order for Boeing 787 Dreamliners misstated the size of the companys provisional order for Airbus A350s before the planes 2006 redesign. The order was for 16 planes, not 12.

title: Trying to Unite Europe, Again
description: Jos Manuel Barroso, the president of the European Commission, spoke good sense this week when he declared that negotiations on reorganizing the European Union cant start from scratch every time a member state has a change of government.

title: Plenty of Love Up North
description: The unlikely hotspot for tennis this summer is Vermont, better known for ski racing than pros acing. But Stowes 360 tennis courts (in a Sound of Music setting) easily outnumber ski trails, and on July 14 and 15, the Topnotch Resort and Spa in Stowe hosts the Fed Cup semifinal between the United States and Russia. The womens tournament is expected to draw Serena Williams, Venus Williams and Maria Sharapova. Tickets are scarce, but guests staying at the Topnotch can still buy passes at prices from $75 to$225; lower-priced rooms are sold out, but villas starting at $1,100 per night are available. Finally, those craving strawberries and cream at Wimbledon, June 25 to July 8, can catch courtside seats through the Stowe-based Grand Slam Tennis Tours. Last-minute packages including hotels, admission, meals and more start at $3,625 for four nights.

title: New Rules Expected on Safety of Nanotechnology Products
description: DuPont and Environmental Defense, one of the nations largest environmental groups, plan to release jointly developed guidelines today for evaluating the safety and environmental risks of nanotechnology products.

title: Calendar
description: Thinking Design

title: If You Like the Safari Browser for the iPhone, Youll Love Opera Mini for Cellphones
description: Apples iPhone, which goes on sale June 29, gets oohs and ahhs for a number of reasons, a big one being the way its Safari Web browser displays pages just like the desktop version, then lets you run your fingers over the screen to zoom in and out.

title: They Take the Bounce Out of Bowser
description: FILLED with trepidation about being tied down, Mary Turner and her husband, Richard Shein, decided to put off parenthood awhile and see how they did with a dog. Ms. Turner, a lawyer, found Bingo, a darling cinnamon-colored puppy, trembling in a cage at an animal shelter near their home in San Bernardino, Calif.

title: A Student, a Teacher and a Glimpse of War
description: MALEHE, Congo

title: Bush Vetoes Measure on Stem Cell Research
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  President Bush on Wednesday issued his second veto of a measure lifting his restrictions on human embryonic stem cell experiments. The move effectively pushed the contentious scientific and ethical debate surrounding the research into the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Albany: New Head of Ethics Commission
description: John D. Feerick, chairman of the State Ethics Commission, said yesterday that he had selected Herbert Teitelbaum, a New York lawyer, as executive director of the commission. He also said he would recommend Mr. Teitelbaum for the same post at a soon-to-be-created public integrity commission combining the existing ethics and lobbying commissions. When the merger takes place, David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, will probably be out of a job. I met with John Feerick about a month and a half ago, once, and it was very clear to me that he was intent on choosing someone other than me, Mr. Grandeau said. Mr. Teitelbaum is a senior partner in the New York office of Bryan Cave. His wife, Ruth J. Abram, founded the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which has lobbied extensively in Albany. Mr. Feerick said that he was enormously impressed by Mr. Teitelbaum and that a spouses work should not be held against a candidate.

title: Germany: Labor Deal at Deutsche Telekom
description: Deutsche Telekom agreed with the Ver.di union on terms to transfer 50,000 workers to jobs that pay less, paving the way to end five weeks of strikes at the company. The employees will take a 6.5 percent pay cut and lengthen the workweek by four hours, Deutsche Telekoms personnel chief, Thomas Sattelberger, said at a news conference with Ver.di in Bad Neuenahr, Germany. The deal allows Deutsche Telekom to set up T-Service, a customer service unit that is part of a cost-cutting program aimed at saving 900 million euros ($1.2 billion). As many as 16,000 workers a day have gone on strike across Germany since May 11 to protest Deutsche Telekoms initial plan to cut pay by 9 percent. As part of the agreement, Deutsche Telekom would raise the variable portion of workers salary and promised it would not sell the service unit before 2010.

title: Starting the Day Together (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Orleans Still at Risk, Army Data Show
description: After nearly two years of work, the Army Corps of Engineers revealed yesterday which New Orleans neighborhoods and blocks were the most vulnerable to flooding, and which were the best protected. The report shows that despite considerable improvement, large swaths of the city are still likely to be flooded in a major storm.

title: Spitzer Pushes for a Last-Minute Deal on 3 Disputed Issues
description: ALBANY, June 20  Gov. Eliot Spitzer was trying to reach a broad deal Wednesday to end the legislative session by linking together three contentious issues, people with knowledge of the negotiations said. The issues included his own campaign finance reform plan, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal and a measure to grant pay raises to lawmakers.

title: Precedents Begin to Fall for Roberts Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  No Supreme Court nominee could be confirmed these days without paying homage to the judicial doctrine of stare decisis, Latin for to stand by things decided. Yet experienced listeners have learned to take these professions of devotion to precedent cum grano salis, Latin for with a grain of salt.

title: Mexico Moves to Cut Back Tax Loopholes for Businesses
