description: MEXICO CITY, June 20  Hoping to raise Mexicos tax collection rate to offset future declines in oil revenue, President Felipe Caldern presented a tax package to Congress Wednesday that seeks to close many of the loopholes that businesses have used to avoid paying taxes.

title: Small Companies That Try to Bring Innovative Technology to Teaching
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  There is a growing cluster of companies in the Northwest looking to capitalize on educational needs.

title: Northwest Ingenuity, Many Ways
description: LANGLEY, Wash.

title: Quilter Sues Art Dealer
description: The great-granddaughter of a woman who belonged to a group of quiltmakers in Gees Bend, Ala., whose work has become celebrated in the art world, has filed suit against three Atlanta art dealers claiming that they have illegally taken two century-old quilts made by her great-grandmother. The woman, Lucinda Pettway Franklin, contends that one of the dealers, Matt Arnett, asked two years ago to borrow the quilts to have them examined and photographed for a book. But the quilts, along with another made by her mother and an aunt, have not been returned, despite requests, according to the lawsuit, which was filed on Tuesday in Alabama. Newer quilts of their kind sell for tens of thousands of dollars; the value of older ones is much higher. The suit is the third filed recently against Mr. Arnett; his brother, Paul; and his father, William, who have long represented and promoted the quilters in Gees Bend, an isolated, historically black community. Two earlier suits say that the Arnetts have defrauded Gees Bend quilters. Gregory H. Hawley, a lawyer representing the Arnetts, was unavailable for comment yesterday, his law firm said. In previous interviews he has denied the claims in the first two lawsuits.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (A&E) STREET THIEF (2006) Are we watching a real thief as he successfully plans and carries out his break-ins? Or is this just an extremely realistic portrayal of a fictional character named Kaspar Carr? The director Malik Bader (playing Kaspar, above) has fielded such questions since this filmed record of a Chicago burglar amazed audiences at the 2006 Tribeca Film Festival. (Shortly before the event one of the films producers was arrested on charges of armed robbery and kidnapping in connection with a truck hijacking.) Tonight the film, fictional or otherwise, makes its television debut.

title: Letters Show Deep Value Giuliani Puts on Loyalty
description: Loyalty is a word that has long defined Rudolph W. Giulianis leadership style. But rarely has there been as documented an outpouring of that support as the 92 letters Mr. Giuliani wrote for Dennis E. Szybala during four months in 1981.

title: The Times Is Raising Newspaper Prices
description: The New York Times Company will increase the newsstand and home-delivery prices for the newspaper next month, the companys chief executive said at an investor conference yesterday.

title: Now Playing in the U.S., Soccers Garage Band
description: A year after the world's best soccer teams convened in Germany to crown a World Cup champion, 12 teams from North and Central America and the Caribbean came to the United States this month to determine the top team in the fourth-best footballing region of the world. This is the world's most popular sport dialed down a few notches. The tournament, called the Concacaf Gold Cup, is the red-headed stepchild of regional soccer tournaments. It lags behind the glamorous European Championship, the more prestigious Copa America (which starts June 26 in Venezuela) and it may even trail the African Cup of Nations in terms of excitement and talent.

title: College Lists? No Thanks (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Jeter Is Concerned, Rockie Shortstop Is Just a Fan
description: DENVER, June 20  Troy Tulowitzki is only 22 years old, which means he was 11 during the 1996 season, when Derek Jeter was the American League rookie of the year. Tulowitzki was born in Santa Clara, Calif., and grew up near San Francisco. But Jeter was his hero.

title: Poised to Be New Jerseys Attorney General
description: TRENTON, June 20  Some years ago, when assistants to District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan were debating the merits of law school graduates who had applied to work in the office, the conversation turned to pastry.

title: Recalling the Princess They Called Mother
description: MONACO

title: Trying on Enlightenment for Size
description: IT says size 2, but its so-o-o huge! New stock had just arrived at Diane Von Furstenbergs newly opened store in the meatpacking district, and staff members were trying things on, their conversation carrying into the dressing room where a red and white floral wrap dress ($325) was presenting me with troubles of my own.

title: U.S. Courting a Somewhat Skittish Friend in Central Asia
description: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan, June 20  The president of reclusive and authoritarian Turkmenistan said Wednesday that he was willing to expand his relations with Washington and with American businesses and that he would continue to cooperate with efforts to stabilize neighboring Afghanistan.

title: A Leader of Hamas Warns of West Bank Peril for Fatah
description: GAZA, June 20  Mahmoud Zahar, perhaps the most influential Hamas leader in Gaza, warned Wednesday that Fatahs effort to repress Hamas in the West Bank could lead to Fatahs downfall there as well.

title: Music Genres, as You See Fit
description: Q. I have music in my MP3 collection that doesnt fall into the standard categories that iTunes provides. Is there a way to make my own music genres within the program?

title: Embracing Many Mediums to Focus on the Message
description: Linder is the nom dart for Linder Sterling, a British artist, musician and performer who was born Linda Mulvey in Liverpool in 1954. A compact exhibition of drawings, photomontages, video and ephemera devoted to her has been organized at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center by Neville Wakefield, a senior curatorial adviser at the museum. Linder is an intriguing exploration of the overlapping worlds of art and music, but walking through the show tends to call to mind a roster of more memorable women.

title: U.S. to Hold Direct Talks in North Korea on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  In a sharp reversal of strategy, the Bush administration on Wednesday secretly dispatched its top North Korea negotiator to the countrys capital, Pyongyang, for one-on-one talks about the North Koreans giving up their nuclear arsenal.

title: Economics, Religion and Politics, in Bite Size
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater is in such a remote location  walk west on 52nd Street and just keep going  that by the time you arrive at its door, you feel as if you have discovered a hidden cultural treasure. At its best the Marathon  the theaters annual one-act festival that has showcased new work by everyone from David Mamet to Tennessee Williams, and which this year is divided into two five-play series  offers a similar sensation.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 11 about the reaction of Mormons to the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, who is a Mormon, referred imprecisely to Mr. Romneys position on gay rights. While he opposes gay marriage and civil unions, the article should not have said he has embraced an anti-gay agenda. (Go to Article)

title: All the Films You Want to See, but When?
description: THE DVD became the most popular way to view movies for good reasons. The discs are sturdy, and the crisp images do not degrade with repeated showings. They take up little space. Some DVD players are cheaper than buying a DVD movie.

title: Fast-Growing China Says Little of Child Slaverys Role
description: SHANGHAI, June 20  There is a certain ritualistic aspect to stories in China like the one this past week about the hundreds of people, many of them teenagers or even younger, who were forced to work under slavelike conditions in the brick kilns of Shanxi Province. First, Chinese readers are horrified by a picture of their country that many say they hardly recognize, then a villain is rounded up, and finally, after a torrent of unusually blunt and emotionally charged news reports and editorials, the matter drops from view, ensuring that the larger issue goes unresolved.

title: Kenneth Franklin, Astronomer, Dies at 84
description: Kenneth L. Franklin, long the Hayden Planetariums top astronomer, whose accomplishments included helping pinpoint the first noise known to have come from another planet and inventing a watch for use on the moon, died in Boulder, Colo., on Monday when the sun rose in New York at 5:07 a.m. He was 84, and had for years provided astronomical information to this newspaper, including the hour of sunrise.

title: Beauty Tips and Clips
description: WATCHING dozens of beauty videos on YouTube, I learned makeup and hair tricks that Im embarrassed to admit I didnt know.

title: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
description: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company  Rupert Murdochs News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson  some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between trash or slash. And they are wondering which might be worse.

title: As the Mets Flounder, Gmez Could Be a Catch
description: Carlos Gmez has few friends in New York, so he has been surprised when strangers have stopped him, acted as if they had known him forever and talked about the catch. Five weeks into his major league career, Gmez already has a tremendous defensive play attached to him like a tattoo.

title: Study Says Eldest Children Have Higher I.Q.s
description: The eldest children in families tend to develop higher I.Q.s than their siblings, researchers are reporting today, in a large study that could settle more than a half-century of scientific debate about the relationship between I.Q. and birth order.

title: A Band Minds Its Manners, but Is Coy About Its Suits
description: Carlos Dengler, better known as Carlos D., the bassist and keyboardist for the moody New York band Interpol, is out of his self-described hedonist phase.

title: At Trial, Writer Recalls an Alter Ego That Took Over
description: The case of Laura Albert  professionally known as JT Leroy  could be read as a literary cautionary tale, the story of a writer who hid behind her own assumed identity and lost herself while reaching for the truth.

title: Unusual Court Case at Center of Pakistans Political Fight
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 20  The case is simply called The Chief Justice v. The President. It plays out daily in plush Supreme Court chambers before a bench of 13 men who could well decide the outcome of Pakistans political crisis.

title: Bear Stearns Staves Off Collapse of 2 Hedge Funds
description: The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of two hedge funds.

title: Heavy Fighting as U.S. Troops Squeeze Insurgents in Iraq City
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 20  Fighting was heavy in parts of Baquba on Wednesday as American troops continued to squeeze a large section of the city in an effort to rid it of insurgents believed to be part of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

title: A Week Since She Vanished, and Still Little Light Is Shed
description: CANTON, Ohio, June 20  From the moment her mother entered her home last Friday and found her missing, the circumstances surrounding the disappearance of Jessie Davis were most unsettling.

title: Another Summer of Love
description: JANIS JOPLIN looms large in Kim Matulovas consciousness  not least Ms. Joplins free-form hair, flounced frocks and fingers choked with rings. My style is, like, gypsy, Ms. Matulova said last week, something like a ghetto hippie.

title: National Education Board Reviews Election Procedures
description: The officers of the National Association of State Boards of Education are reviewing their election procedures, after a nominees withdrawal left them with only one candidate for the office of president-elect: a member of the Kansas school board who supported its efforts against the teaching of evolution.

title: Libyans Weigh a Deal to Free Medical Workers in H.I.V. Case
description: ROME, June 20  The European Union and hundreds of Libyan families whose children are infected with the virus that causes AIDS are expected to announce an agreement on Friday in Brussels to remove an important obstacle in the case of six foreign medical workers whom Libya accuses of intentionally infecting the children, an official connected to the negotiations said Wednesday.

title: Red Carpet or Rehab, It All Sells
description: THE image of Lindsay Lohan passed out in a car over Memorial Day weekend may have stalled her acting career, but it has done wonders for hoodie sales at American Apparel.

title: Giuliani May See a Rival in Successor
description: Seven weeks after the 2001 terror attacks, Rudolph W. Giuliani gave a last-minute electoral nod to a billionaire media mogul running for mayor.

title: Not Just Another Day at the Board of Elections
description: On a typical day, Troy Johnson, chief clerk of the New York County Board of Elections, busies himself making sure voters are registered, absentee ballot requests are answered and the copious records inside the boards 10th-floor office downtown on Varick Street are scrupulously maintained.

title: Indian Tycoon Spreads His Wings in Aviation
description: Vijay Mallya, an Indian liquor and airline magnate who revels in the tycoon lifestyle, wants to bring his good times to the rest of the world.

title: June Has Been Anything but Fun So Far for Mets
description: Offering a diversion from the ugliness unfolding on the field, the out-of-town scoreboard at Shea Stadium last night showed highlights from the Red Sox-Braves game from Atlanta. Some fans hollered when the score, very much in Bostons favor, was announced. As long as the Braves continue to lose, the first-place Mets, no matter how poorly they play, would not lose any ground.

title: On the Waterfront: A Matter of Preservation (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying Connected via Cellphone (and Cellphone Bill)
description: MY daughter graduated from high school last week. As she heads to college, my husband warned me that we face four years of a crushing financial burden, with enormous regular payments that he fears could lead to bankruptcy.

title: Firefighter Falls to Death in  Blaze in Brooklyn
description: A firefighter was killed this evening after falling at a burning building in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Newly Released
description: June is beach-read month, and a number of this months new releases would do nicely under a beach umbrella. Much of Ann Brasharess new book takes place on Fire Island, and will undoubtedly be spotted there as well. Other novels take place in 17th-century Persia, in World War I-era France and among a very smart herd of sheep.

title: Queens: Man Fatally Stabbed
description: A 24-year-old man was stabbed to death shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday outside a strip club on Steinway Street in Astoria, the police said. The man, who was identified as Jason Brown of Bay Shore, in Suffolk County, was pronounced dead on arrival at Elmhurst General Hospital, the police said. He had been stabbed several times in the torso by another man during a dispute outside the strip club, Club Riviera, the police said. The assailant escaped, the police said, and no weapon was recovered.

title: An iPod Rival Can Browse the Net and Download Audio and Video
description: Archos has always been the underdog in the portable media player race. While it manufactured some of the first real MP3 players, its products have been overshadowed by the iPod. With its new 605 Wi-Fi, this wallflower is hoping to be the belle of the ball.

title: Hamas Conquest of Gaza Disturbs Arab World With Echoes of Recent Splits and Alliances
description: CAIRO, June 20  The conquest of the Gaza Strip by Hamas has frightened Arab leaders because it was characterized by the same dynamics that have been agitating the region.

title: Words, Actions and Hamas (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Disposable Trump Is Promoted to Giant Killer
description: First look at only the West hand in the diagramed deal. You are on lead against six spades. Declarer showed four spades, five diamonds and two key cards (one ace and the trump king, or two aces) but no trump queen. Dummy revealed five or more clubs, four spades and sufficient strength to drive to slam opposite a minimum opening bid. What would you lead?

title: And Finally, Sleep
description: What does it take to win the ultra-cycling competition Race Across America? Try 8 days, 19 hours, and 33 minutes. Try 3,043 miles on a bike, with little or no sleep, day after pedal-cranking day. Thats what Jure Robic, a 42-year-old Slovene competitor, endured to win the solo division in this years race, which started in Oceanside, Calif., on June 10; Robic reached the finish line in Atlantic City Tuesday morning, and the race as a whole wraps up tomorrow. Thirty solo competitors and several teams with up to eight riders switching off signed up for this years race, which ran through vast stretches of desert, mountains, Great Plains, and endless American roadways. As of this morning, 13 solo competitors in the men's race (all five women missed time cutoffs) were battling saddle sores and exhaustion while trying to make the final time cut at the finish line tomorrow night.

title: Your Questions About the IPhone
description: Hmmm, lets see what shall I cover in my column next week?

title: Pettitte Says He Quit on Himself
description: Sometimes, you watch a game and go talk to the pitcher, and you cant believe hes describing what you just saw. Esteban Loaiza was like that; he would give up 6 runs in 5 innings and talk about how he actually pitched pretty well.

title: Immortal Syria
description: The Old City of Damascus, the Silk Road bazaars of Aleppo and the ruins of ancient Palmyra attest to Syria's Bronze Age, classical, biblical and Islamic history.

title: Closing Shop
description: Images from the Heritage Book Shop in Los Angeles, which is set to close.

title: An Unlucky Number
description: A troubled writer, a haunted hotel room  who else but Stephen King? In "1408," adapted from a 2002 short story by Mr. King, John Cusack is the hack who drags his emotional baggage to Room 1408 of the Dolphin Hotel in Manhattan, accommodations whose history of grisly deaths demands investigation. Once there, he learns that checking out might not be an option.

title: A Jumbled Real World
description: The domestic drama "Longing" ("Sehnsucht)" tells of a rural firefighter named Markus (Andreas Mller) who visits another town with his colleagues and ends up getting drunk and falling into bed with a kindly waitress named Rose (Anett Dornbusch). Marcus can't stop seeing Rose; unfortunately, he's already happily married to a wonderful woman named Ella (Ilka Welz).

title: A Look at Loss and Reinvention
description: "What do you do when nothing is left?" is the question that drives "The Real Dirt on Farmer John," Taggart Siegel's fascinating documentary about loss and reinvention. If you're John Peterson, the progressive Illinois farmer whom Mr. Siegel filmed through 25 years of friendship and multiple crises, you pick yourself up and start again  with the camera running, of course.

title: U.S. Is Urging Blair to Be Lead Mideast Envoy
description: The United States is pressing Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to become a special envoy to the Middle East, working on behalf of the diplomatic quartet of world powers to help the Palestinian president build the institutions and apparatus necessary for a viable state.

title: Munich, No. 1 even where it (maybe) hurts.
description: English Garden, Munich (AP)

title: A Global Array
description: Images from Documenta 12, an international art show in Kassel, Germany.

title: Day Trip: Trailing Van Gogh
description: Auvers sur Oise

title: Hospital Death Rates
description: The following are the hospitals with the lowest and highest mortality rates for patients treated for heart attacks or heart failure, according to an analysis of about 5,000 hospitals by the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Whole Foods to Unload Wild Oats Stake to Apollo
description: Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.

title: Allied Capital Settles With S.E.C., Giving Greenlight More Ammo
description: Allied Capital, a business development company, said Wednesday that it had settled a four-year investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into its valuation practices. Allied, which provides debt and equity financing for middle-market companies, settled the S.E.C.s informal investigation without admitting or denying agency allegations, according to Allied and the S.E.C.

title: In Suit, Ex-A.I.G. Chief Says Others Are Liable for Restatement
description: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, sued 16 current and former executives and directors Wednesday, seeking to hold them liable for a results restatement and a $1.64 billion regulatory settlement he considered unnecessary.

title: Watchdog Group Is Given a Name
description: The merger of the United States brokerage industrys two major watchdogs finally has a name: the Securities Industry Regulatory Authority, or SIRA.

title: Accounting Rule Is Eased for Foreign Companies
description: Federal regulators tentatively agreed Wednesday to ease an accounting requirement for foreign companies that trade on United States exchanges. The move comes amid concerns that U.S. stock markets are losing out to overseas competitors due, in part, to what critics see as a overly-burdensome regulatory environment.

title: Bell Canada Discussing a Merger With Western Provinces Carrier
description: Bell Canada, the target of at least three possible privatization bids, said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada. If combined, Bell, which is based in Montreal, and Telus, based in Vancouver, would have a market capitalization of C$53.2 billion ($50 billion) based on Wednesdays stock prices.

title: Britains Private Equity Chiefs Defend Their Tax Breaks
description: Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament on Tuesday and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

title: Man Group Prices Brokerage I.P.O.
description: Man Group, Europes largest publicly traded hedge fund, said Thursday it expects its United States brokerage to price its shares at $36 to $39 each when they list on the New York Stock Exchange. The price range values the entire business at as much as $5 billion.

title: Yahoo Buying a High School and College Sports Network
description: Just one day after the management shake-up at Yahoo, the companys board was called on to make a decision that had nothing to do with the resignation of Terry S. Semel as chief executive or the appointment of the co-founder Jerry Yang to succeed him.

title: Gannett Takes the Lead on 4Info
description: Newspaper and broadcasting giant Gannett led a $10 million fourth round of venture funding in mobile advertising company 4Info. 4Info, based in Palo Alto, lets people get news and other information via text messaging on their mobile phones.

title: Nuveen Deal GetsThumbs Down from Debt Analysts
description: Private equity player Madison Dearborn Partners $6.3 billion deal for municipal bond fund Nuveen Investments may gladden the hearts of investors, but it doesnt have debt analysts cheering, BusinessWeek noted.

title: Lone Star to Sell Korea Exchange Shares
description: Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm whose attempt to sell Korea Exchange Bank last year was blocked by a legal dispute, offered an 11.3 percent stake in the company for as much as $1.1 billion.

title: Deutsche Bank, 4 Hedge Funds Fined in Vivendi Inquiry
description: Deutsche Bank and four hedge funds including GLG Partners were fined a combined 6.25 million euros ($8.4 million) by Frances market regulator after an insider trading investigation into a Vivendi Universal securities sale in 2002.

title: Alcan Opens Books to BHP and Rio Tinto, Report Says
description: Alcan, seeking to fend off a $27.7 billion hostile bid from Alcoa, has given BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Group access to its financial data, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

title: Luxottica Tries Oakley On for Size
description: The Luxottica Group, the worlds biggest eyewear maker, said Wednesday that it would buy the American sunglasses maker Oakley Inc. in an all-cash deal worth about $2.1 billion.

title: Congress May Challenge Private Equitys Big Tax Break
description: For private equity chiefs, the other shoe  and a much bigger one  may be about to drop in Washington.

title: U.S. Said to Investigate Kickbacks in Stock Lending
description: Federal prosecutors are close to bringing criminal charges against as many as a dozen current and former Wall Street employees in connection with a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to hedge funds and short sellers, BusinessWeek reported. So far, federal prosecutors have reportedly secured guilty pleas from three confidential witnesses in the case.

title: Atticus Phones In Opposition to Barclays ABN Bid
description: Atticus Capital, the hedge fund manager with more than $14 billion in assets, reiterated its opposition to Barclays proposed $68.2 billion euros ($91.4 billion) deal to buy Dutch bank ABN Amro.

title: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
description: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company  Rupert Murdochs News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson  some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between trash or slash. And they are wondering which might be worse.

title: Bear Stearns Staves Off Collapse of 2 Hedge Funds
description: The high-stakes game of brinksmanship began early yesterday on Wall Street, and continued throughout the day. Bankers traded telephone calls, frenetically negotiating the fate of Bear Stearns two hedge funds.

title: BlackBerrys: A Spy Tale of Three Cities
description: As Wall Street workers consider new guidelines on how and when to use their BlackBerrys, Paris has taken the issue a bit further, deciding that the ubiquitous hand-held devices may pose a threat to French national security.

title: L.S.E. May Offer $2 Billion for Italian Rival, Report Says
description: The London Stock Exchange is planning to offer about 1.5 billion euros ($2.01 billion) for Borsa Italiana, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source. The deal would value the Borsa, which is privately-owned by Italian banks, above the 1.2 billion to 1.4 billion euros valuation placed on it last year when the Milan-based bourse planned for an initial public offering.

title: The Headliner Takes the Stage, but It Proves Anticlimactic
description: If Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs announcement on Tuesday night that he was leaving the Republican Party amounted to a political earthquake  or at least a tremor?  there were no real aftershocks on Wednesday, judging by this mornings papers. Indeed, the big political news of the day  Mayor Bloombergs insistence that he was not planning to run for president  seemed almost anticlimactic as speculation about his ambitions swirled around him. But he still got his headlines.

title: I.S.S. Recommends Vote Against Icahns Offer for Lear
description: Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended that shareholders of Lear reject Carl C. Icahns proposed $36-a-share offer for the auto parts supplier, lending serious opposition to the shareholder activists bid.

title: Mary McCarthy at 95
description: Mary McCarthy, were she alive, would be 95 today  she was born on June 21, 1912.

title: Corzine: Bloombergs Move No Surprise
description: For Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg never seemed to be a good fit with the Republican Party.

title: 2008: A Closer Look At Bloomberg
description: Need help making sense of the strange week that has unfolded around New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg? Fortunately, a set of stories gets beneath the surface of the mayors unexpected announcement and cryptic statements of recent days.

title: Podcast: The Switch Is On
description: Following is the draft script of the weekly Only in New York audio podcast. Listen at left or download  it to a portable player.

title: Austin Reels After Man Is Beaten to Death
description: Even with the chain of events pieced together by the police so far, its hard to comprehend the flash violence that broke out in an East Austin, Tex., parking lot on Tuesday. Even the police chief was shocked, and his expression of that  This is an anomaly for Austin  couldve applied to the nation as well.

title: On the Move
description: Tony Blair: British prime minister was considered a World Bank chief candidate, and now hes up for the job of Mideast envoy?

title: A New Vision for the East River
description: This morning, with a four-borough boat tour leaving from South Street Seaport in Manhattan and ending at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn, more than 50 community groups are announcing the East River Agenda, a plan to make riverfront neighborhoods a centerpiece of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs PlaNYC vision for improving the citys environment over the next 30 years.

title: Giuliani Prefers His Godfather Imitation
description: DES MOINES  Years before he became known as the squeegee-busting mayor of New York and ages before his name became forever linked with Sept. 11, Rudy Giuliani made his reputation fighting the mafia.

title: The Number 61
description: Alex Rodriguez is on pace to hit 65 home runs, the most since steroid testing began in 2003, and the most by any player not associated with the steriod scandal. At PLAY, that got us thinking: Will 61, Roger Mariss record before Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa surpassed it in 1998, again become a benchmark (albeit unofficial) for home runs in a season? Should it?

title: What to See and Do in Slovenia in and Around the Capital
description: This is my first time traveling to Slovenia. Can you give me tips for sightseeing and attractions? And what do you suggest I see in Ljubljana?

title: Even Less Confidence in Congress
JT and Me
description: I was born in West Virginia  my grandfather, Archie Garner, was a coal miner  and throughout my life Ive followed West Virginia writers as closely as Ive followed the fortunes of the nearby Pittsburgh, Pa. sports teams.

title: Finding a Hassle-Free Way to Transfer Files
description: Readers seem to love it when they hear about tech "experts" like me getting trapped in technical hell. Seems to be a form of schadenfreude, that delicious German word meaning, "taking pleasure in other people's misfortune."

title: Sample Platter
description: As Screens has pointed out before, you can learn much from the sloppy comments section on YouTube. Consider, for example, the notes that follow one version of Senator Hillary Clintons take-off on the last scene of The Sopranos.

title: Yoga at the Crossroads of the World
description: About 80 men and women  some from as far as California and Honduras  woke up extra early to visit one of the worlds busiest intersections in search for serenity.

title: LVMH Enters Talks to Buy Les Echos
description: A wealthy businessman proposes buying a major provider of business news, setting off fears among its employees that their editorial integrity would be compromised.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Daydream designs for the lazy afternoon ahead.

title: Currents
description: A flea-market-style restaurant, carefully curated and more.

title: UBS Paves the Way for More Infrastructure Deals
description: As state governments consider selling toll roads, airports and bridges to close budget gaps, UBS is bolstering its team of investment bankers that advise on such deals. The Swiss firm said Wednesday it hired three bankers for its infrastructure group ahead of what it expects to be a rise in privatizations in the United States.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Behind the Lid" and "Radio."

title: Finding a Hassle-Free Way to Send Files
description: Readers seem to love it when they hear about tech experts like me getting trapped in technical hell. Seems to be a form of schadenfreude, that delicious German word meaning, taking pleasure in other peoples misfortune.

title: Romeo and Juliet in the Park
description: Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the Public Theater's party for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Mauer Roots for Posada, One Catcher for Another
description: Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins became the first catcher to win the American Leagues batting title when he hit .347 in 2006. Mauer edged Derek Jeter of the Yankees, who hit .343.

title: Public Land
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Justices Tighten Rules on Shareholder Suits
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday imposed a strict standard that investors must meet to keep alive their lawsuits alleging securities fraud. In an 8-1 decision, the justices said that courts must weigh possible innocent explanations for defendants conduct at the very start of a securities fraud case. Doing so can lead to early dismissal of investors lawsuits.

title: Report Says Citys Smoking Rate Has Plummeted
description: New York Citys smoking rate fell by 20 percent from 2002 to 2006, with 240,000 fewer smokers, according to a new report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Campaign Cash: Reporters as Donors
description: Bill Dedman, an investigative reporter with MSNBC.com, posted a set of articles online today about journalists who have contributed to candidates, political parties and political groups. He combed through federal filings of contributions to campaigns and organizations, and here are his findings:

title: K.K.R. Hires Bankers for a Potential I.P.O.
description: Even as the Blackstone Group prepared to price its initial public offering Thursday night amid heightened scrutiny from Washington, one of its major rivals was considering stepping into the limelight. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired Morgan Stanley and Citigroup to prepare a possible I.P.O. later this year, people familiar with the matter told DealBook. The news was first reported by CNBCs Charles Gasparino.

title: Assembly to Microsoft: Reboot
description: We reported today on several disputable and under-the-radar bills or proposals circulating through the Assembly, including language apparently being circulated by lobbyists for Microsoft that critics say would gut the states voting-machine integrity law.

title: Edwards Starts Texting for Dollars
description: Many of us have come to rely on cell phone text messaging to ask and answer all sorts of everyday questions  things like: Want 2 meet 4 coffee? or U going 2 the pty @ 8?

title: Rupert Murdochs $12 Billion Trial Balloon
description: There is a lot of skepticism surrounding the idea that News Corporation will trade MySpace for a 25 percent stake in Yahoo. Reports of the talks, which the Tech Confidential blog describes as having the distinct smell of a well-timed leak, are said to be very preliminary, and Yahoo may decide that its not interested.

title: Secret Societies: Yale and Disneyland
description: Skull and Bones spent what must have been an excruciating day or so on news sites across the Web this week when The Associated Press put out a story about the Apache quest to retrieve Geronimos remains, a legend fortified with a few pieces of evidence.

title: Silver Gives Green Light to Bill for H.I.V. Testing of Rape Suspects
description: A bill that would require H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges appears likely to become law.

title: G.E. and Pearson End Talks on Dow Jones Bid
description: One potential white knight for Dow Jones has ridden into the sunset.

title: Turf War Over a Brooklyn Patronage Prize
description: It seems as if there is always some political battle within the boroughs of New York City where, on center stage, is either race and ethnicity. Or a turf war waged by one political club or another, or the party organization seeking to flex its muscles.

title: The War at Home: Feuding Democrats
description: As the Senate prepares to open another major debate over Iraq next month, a dispute is percolating in an unlikely corner: two Democrats who both voted against going to war.

title: Island Hopping
description: After an unusual spike in news about islands, The Lede takes a tour from Japan to New York.

title: A Special Break for Atlantic Yards
description: The State Assembly passed a significant expansion of New York Citys 421a tax-incentive program this afternoon, and Senate approval is expected shortly in Albany. The current program provides property tax abatements to developers in certain neighborhoods of the city if 20 percent of the units in any building are priced for lower-income residents, making 80 percent of the area median income.

title: Summer Begins  Now
description: Today is the day. At 2:06 p.m.  right now  the sun is at its highest point. Or something like that.

title: Anatomy of a Scene
description: Director Michael Winterbottom dissects a scene from "A Mighty Heart," starring Angelina Jolie.

title: Two More Politicians Line Up to Blast Blackstone I.P.O.
description: Yet more politicians have taken aim at the Blackstone Groups forthcoming initial public offering on the eve of its pricing. In a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday, Henry A. Waxman, the Democratic chairman of the House Oversight Committee, and Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic congressman from Ohio and a presidential hopeful, warned that the I.P.O. may present new and undisclosed risks.

title: Carefully Headed Racing Buffs Attend Ascot
description: The annual spectacle let's racegoers find creative diversions with hat-styles from elegant to outlandish.

title: Deal Is Near on Congestion Pricing Panel
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer emerged briefly from end-of-session legislative negotiations today to say that a deal is near on a commission to examine Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan in Albany.

title: Evercore Hires Energy Banker from Citi
description: Stephen P. Schaible, formerly a managing director and head of global energy banking at Citigroup, will join Evercore Partners in September as a senior managing director, where he cover the energy and chemicals sectors out of New York, Evercore said Thursday.

title: With Bonds Closing In, Torre Feels for Aaron
description: The Yankees travel to San Francisco after todays game in Denver, and there they will face Barry Bonds, who needs eight home runs to break Hank Aarons record of 755.

title: Killing in the Name of God
description: The most bizarre experience on this trip so far has been the visit to General Laurent Nkunda. Its hardly an everyday occurrence to go to the military camp of an actual warlord who is accused of raping and massacring thousands. (He prefers to be referred to as liberator of the people, and denies all allegations against him.) That a journalist well known for opposing him had just been assassinated in the Congo, and that General Nkunda made several references to our security, made us apprehensive during the interview and cautious in subsequent reporting.

title: New Head for State Art Collection
description: Agnes Gund, 68, a longtime arts patron and president emerita of the Museum of Modern Art, has been named chairwoman of the Empire State Plaza Art Commission. The Empire State Plaza Art Collection began in the late 1960s under the patronage of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and  like the Rockefeller family  has had longstanding ties to the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Prognosis Excellent
description: The instant reviews of Sicko, Michael Moores new movie, are beginning to trickle onto the Web. Eric Alterman, who has taken his Altercation blog from MSBNC.com to Media Matters, calls it by far Moores best film: good humored, compelling, and, amazingly, its actually fun.

title: Fleet-Footed Lehman Women Trounce Rivals
description: Lehman Brothers consistently ranks high in Wall Streets investment-banking league tables, but it was the sisters at Lehman who dominated day one of this years J.P. Morgan Corporate Challenge. The annual footrace in New Yorks Central Park is historically so crowded with Wall Streeters that Bankers Ball dubs it the Bankerthon.

title: Mike Wallace: Gotham, Public Health, the Meaning of Manhattan
description: Here is the latest installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and author of Gotham, who has been taking questions from readers this week. He will post more answers on Friday, but he is not accepting any new questions.

title: Q & A:  Nicole Kaplan
description: Nicole Kaplan has been the executive pastry chef at the Italian restaurant Del Posto since January. She made her reputation with the work she did before then at Eleven Madison Park, where she spent seven years and where her desserts were one of the restaurants standout attractions.

title: Peltz Takes a Stake in Kraft
description: Billionaire investor Nelson Peltz bought a 3 percent stake in Kraft Foods, a person with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News, confirming a report by CNBC. The companys shares jumped 6.6 percent, the most in 11 months.

title: The Nature of F1s green effort
description: Formula One made the cover story of Nature magazine today, as the highly respected science journal investigates Max Mosleys green future for the sport. The cover has the headline: HOW GREEN IS THIS? with a photo of a McLaren and a Ferrari racing. Inside, the headline reads: Formula 1 racing: Power games

title: Staten Island: The Exception to the Decline in Smoking
description: Always ready to buck a citywide trend, Staten Island was the one borough where the smoking rate did not decline dramatically over the past four years, according to statistics the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene released today. The borough remains the citys smokingest, by an increasingly wide margin.

title: Supreme Court Takes A Middle Course
description: The Supreme Court decision in Tellabs today drew praise from trade groups for banks and trial lawyers. That alone should be an indication that it is anything but definitive in its effect. Even the Tellabs case may yet survive and go to trial, depending on how lower courts assess the facts in light of todays opinion.

title: Beware of Being Swallowed by Sand
description: Just when you thought it was safe to go back on the beach.  Now comes a report about the dangers of sand holes. Never mind the jellyfish  you probably know how to spot them in the water. This year, youre also going to have to look down at the sand to avoid falling into a potentially dangerous hole. It could collapse around you. The Star Ledgers Belmar Benny, a blogger, writes about the latest beach menace.

title: Blackstone Prices at $31 a Unit in $4.13 Billion I.P.O.
description: They did it.

title: America is Catching Up
description: Often, the best way to know what will be in the stores next year is to look at what the chip makers are doing now.

title: Harry Potter Spoiler Spreads
description: Can you believe that someone posted the ending of Harry Potter on the the Web?

title: Virginity, Lost
description: Do you suppose its possible today, somewhere in America, to graduate from high school with ones virginity intact? Everything would seem to point away from the possibility.

title: Nader Weighs a Run
description: Hes baaaack.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Lady Chatterley'
description: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lady Chatterley," a French take on D. H. Lawrence's racy novel.

title: The Veil of French Politics
description: Sgolne Royal was the first woman from a major political party to run for President of France. She was the first French cabinet minister to give birth while in office. And now she has become the first French political figure to break up with her boyfriend  Socialist party head Francois Hollande, her concubin, according to French law, and the father of her four children  on the public airwaves.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Sicko'
description: The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Sicko," Michael Moore's documentary on the American health insurance industry.

title: Win a Trip: Starfish in Congo
description: Leana Wen, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, followed up on the care of Yohanita.

title: Immigration Hovers Over Bush-Sessions Event
description: ATHENS, Ala.,  Senator Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican, is one of President Bushs staunchest opponents on legislation to overhaul the nations immigration laws. But that didnt stop Mr. Bush from traveling to Mobile today to raise money for Mr. Sessions reelection campaign.

title: Buy My Eyeballs
description: For decades, media companies have struck an implicit bargain with consumers: put up with our advertisements, and well give you content for free or on the cheap. But, lately, people have become a bit spoiled. Lots of content on the Internet is free without ads or it runs with ads that can easily be clicked shut. And more and more households have TiVos and other digital video recorders that allow people to zap past commercials.

title: Ask the Transportation Commissioner
description: Update: Read answers.

title: A Look at the Air Show
description: Highlights of the Paris air show, including Lockheed Martin's Joint Strike Fighter.

title: June Blooms in the Bronx
description: The Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden re-opens after a $2.5 million renovation. The one-acre garden is in the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Readers Questions: Birth Order and Intelligence
description: In a recent study on birth order and intelligence, Norwegian researchers report that eldest children have higher I.Q.s than their younger siblings. Why would that be? There are as many guesses as there are scientists. Virtually anyone who has a sibling is a birth-order theorist, says Dr. Frank Sulloway, an expert on family dynamics at the University of California, Berkeley. Dr. Sulloway answered readers questions about the study and its implications; his answers appear below. [Editors note: questions are no longer being accepted.]

title: Giuliani on Citgo, Cuba  and, Um, Gays and Hollywood
description: HIALEAH, Fla.  Rudolph Giuliani often talks about how dictators, bullies and tyrants need to be confronted and challenged.

title: Slicing The Impact of Apples iPhone
description: I am intrigued by a theory proffered by John Hodulik, a telecommunications industry analyst with UBS Warburg. He believes that Nokia and Motorola could actually indirectly benefit from the sale of Apples competing iPhone. The reason has to do with the economics of handset subsidies  yknow, the few dollars to few hundred dollars that carriers give you to get you to buy a new handset and sign up for a two-year contract.

title: Edwards Revisits Two Americas
description: Riffing off his Two Americas campaign theme, John Edwards took aim at the financial services industry in a speech tonight in New York, where he blamed a lack of industry regulation for the demise of the American Dream.

title: Who Buys This Stock?
description: In my Friday column, I discuss Universal Express, a penny stock that is issuing billions of shares of stock each quarter. Those shares are evidently being sold in the market, and the cash enables the company to stay in business. A federal judge has ruled that those sales are illegal, but that has not stopped them.

title: Did the United States Get a Gift?
description: Referee Benito Archundias decision to disallow a last-ditch Canadian equalizer helped send the United States advance to the Gold Cup final but left the Canadians fuming. Did Archundia get it right, or did he blow the call? Who are the best and worst referees at this years tournament, and why?

title: Spy Director Ends Program on Satellites
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The nations top intelligence official has decided to terminate a multibillion-dollar spy satellite program beset by spiraling costs and opposition from powerful lawmakers.

title: Rosewood Residences at Mayakob & Jubilee, Florida
description: Rosewood Residences at Mayakob

title: C.I.A. to Release Documents on Decades-Old Misdeeds
description: The Central Intelligence Agency will make public next week a collection of long-secret documents compiled in 1974 that detail domestic spying, assassination plots and other C.I.A. misdeeds in the 1960s and early 1970s, the agencys director, Gen. Michael V. Hayden, said yesterday.

title: Honk? No, Pray if You Hear a Loud Crack
description: O.K., we agree that Deadliest Catch has no peer. That landmark Discovery Channel series, which chronicles the derring-do of commercial crab-fishing boats off the Alaskan coast, ended Tuesday, with its highest-rated episode ever.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on May 9 about a new course at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on how to be an informed consumer of print, broadcast and Internet journalism misspelled the surname of a vice president of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, which helps finance the course. He is Eric Newton, not Newtown. The error was pointed out by Mr. Newton in an e-mail message this week.

title: The Principle of 2nd Home, 2nd Vote
description: MOST people who buy a second home are seeking refuge, a place to recharge their psychic batteries, to leave the worries and trivia of their jobs and hometowns behind. The last thing on their minds, generally, is to get sucked into the whirlpool of local politics.

title: Soup With Everything: A Freaky All-American Party in California
description: WHERE is this place? We tilted the handmade map every which way, reread the directions a fourth time and made yet another U-turn on a gorgeous dirt road lined with craggy oaks and broken fences. Wed driven four hours from San Francisco into the golden hills of Northern California with a sack of jalapeo peppers, and were nervous we wouldnt make it before the welcome gate closed.

title: High Goals for Reducing Emissions in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Legislature passed a bill yesterday that set ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases from power plants, refineries, motor vehicles and other sources that contribute to global warming.

title: Family Behind Foxwoods Loses Hold in Tribe
description: MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT INDIAN RESERVATION, Conn.  Things are different now for the Hayward family, who took this tiny tribal nation on a dizzying odyssey two decades ago from virtual dust to startling wealth and power.

title: Japan: Abe Delays National Election
description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe delayed the critical upper house election by a week, to July 29 from July 22, by extending Parliaments current session by 12 days, in what was seen as a desperate move to regain popular support and dampen widespread anger over the governments admission that it had misplaced payment information for millions of pensioners. Polls show that support for Mr. Abe and his Liberal Democratic Party has fallen dangerously low among potential voters, with the main opposition Democratic Party scoring higher in some polls. A significant defeat could put pressure on Mr. Abe to step down as party leader and prime minister, though his party would keep the prime ministers post through its control over the lower house.

title: U.S. Troops Find Buried Dangers at Outpost
description: ARAB JABOUR, Iraq, June 21  The troops who settled into this jungle of tall grasses and sunburned palms five days ago fast discovered a new feature of an area that the military had neglected for more than a year: dozens of huge bombs buried beneath the road, some big enough to destroy a 130,000-pound Abrams tank.

title: Girardi Rejects Shot at Managing the Orioles
description: Joe Girardi has turned down an opportunity to become the next manager of the Baltimore Orioles. Girardi told the team that accepting the position would not be conducive with his family situation.

title: Dinner With Dad (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Man Is Convicted in Nantucket Stabbing Death
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., June 21  A New York man was convicted on Thursday of stabbing to death a Manhattan woman three years ago on this affluent island two days after she ended their relationship.

title: Court Rules Coachs Violations Are Not a Form of Free Speech
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Supreme Court on Thursday rejected the claim by a high school football powerhouse in Tennessee that its coachs recruiting violations were a form of free speech that could not be penalized by the state athletic association.

title: N.J. Man Kills 2 Daughters and Himself
description: A man apparently drowned his two young daughters in a bathtub and then hanged himself from the rafters of the attic in his home in Montclair, N.J., the Montclair police said yesterday.

title: Queens: Hate Crimes Alleged in Assault on Elderly Women
description: A Long Island City man has been indicted on hate crimes charges in connection with the mugging of two elderly women in March, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Jack Rhodes, 44, of Vernon Boulevard, was indicted on charges of burglary, robbery and assault as hate crimes, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, adding that prosecutors believe that Mr. Rhodes chose his victims because of their advanced age. Mr. Brown said Mr. Rhodes repeatedly punched a 101-year-old woman while mugging her in the vestibule of her building on Highland Avenue in Jamaica Hills on March 4. She suffered a broken cheekbone. He also repeatedly punched an 85-year-old woman during a robbery in her 170th Street building about half an hour later, Mr. Brown said. She was cut and bruised by the attack. Mr. Rhodes pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: London Exchange May Bid $2 Billion for Borsa Italiana
description: The London Stock Exchange was considering making a bid of $2 billion to acquire Borsa Italiana, the operator of the stock exchange in Milan, two people close to the companies said. The two exchanges discussed a potential merger and were set to continue discussions today, a spokesman for Borsa Italiana said. The spokesman, Alessandro Pavesi, said the proposal from the London exchange is the only one being considered. Both exchanges have fended off takeover approaches in the last year, and a merger might help them avoid a takeover in the future, said Rupak Ghose, an analyst at Credit Suisse in London. It is not surprising that the L.S.E. is looking at different alternatives to become larger and hence avoid becoming acquired, Mr. Ghose said in a note to investors.

title: Stop-Time and Symmetry, Punch Lines and Pathos
description: Branford Marsalis and Joshua Redman are in good places. By the end of their JVC Jazz Festival concert on Wednesday at Town Hall  Mr. Redmans trio went first, Mr. Marsaliss quartet second  they had put the crowd into happy exhaustion. It had been pummeled with hard stuff, engaged by delicate stuff, and there had been remarkably little glibness going around.

title: Firefighters Fatal Fall Cut Short a Lifelong Pursuit
description: Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak fell to his death yesterday while trying to save an artists loft less than two miles from the three-story aluminum-sided house in Greenpoint where he was raised.

title: Kazakhstan: Unicredit Unit Bids for Bank
description: Bank Austria Creditanstalt, a unit of UniCredit, bid $2.2 billion to acquire AO ATF Bank of Kazakhstan to tap an oil-related boom in the former Soviet Union. Bank Austria said that it had agreed to buy at least 85 percent of the bank, which is based in Almaty and has corporate and retail operations, and that it hopes to acquire the remaining shares. ATF Bank has 110 branches and assets valued at 6.3 billion euros ($8.4 billion) and a market share of 11.8 percent. Austria Creditanstalt is based in Vienna, and UniCredit is based in Milan.

title: G.M. to Alter Tiger Woodss Role in Its Ads
description: DETROIT, June 21  After eight years as the face of Buick, Tiger Woods is still less than half the age of an average Buick owner.

title: Old bin Laden Interview Is Allowed Into Padillas Trial
description: MIAMI, June 21  Over strong objections from the defense, the judge in the terrorism case against Jose Padilla ruled on Thursday that prosecutors could play parts of an old television interview with Osama bin Laden to bolster their case against Mr. Padilla and two co-defendants.

title: New Wharton Dean
description: Thomas S. Robertson, a professor of marketing, has been named dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, university officials announced. Dr. Robertson, left, is currently the executive faculty director of the Institute for Developing Nations at Emory University in Atlanta. Dr. Robertson taught from 1971 to 1994 at Wharton. He will succeed Patrick Harker, who will become president of the University of Delaware.

title: Tapping Out Fusion: Is That One Tutu Too Many?
description: No one has ever mistaken Savion Glover for Fred Astaire, and therein lies his appeal. With his signature dreadlocks, baggy clothes and rambunctious virtuosity, Mr. Glover, 33, is often credited with single-handedly reviving tap dance from genteel movie entertainment to a vibrant American art form with the street cred and youthful appeal of hip-hop.

title: Without ODonnell, View Keeps Its Viewers
description: Maybe they dont miss Rosie so much after all.

title: Surveillance Program Debated
description: The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said that former Attorney General John Ashcroft told the panel in a closed session that the Bush administration was sharply split over the legality of the domestic eavesdropping program. Representative Silvestre Reyes, a Texas Democrat who leads the panel, said that it was clear to him that there was enormous debate in the administration about the legal basis for the program. Also, the Senate Judiciary Committee authorized, but did not issue, subpoenas to Mr. Gonzales and to the custodian of records for the presidents office to turn over all documents related to the eavesdropping program.

title: Fixing the College Loan Mess
description: Congress has reacted to the college loan scandal with several strong proposals that would go a long way toward ending corruption while making loans more affordable for students and taxpayers. The House has passed a bill that would make it a crime for lenders to solicit business by offering college officials anything of value and force lenders to disclose any existing deals. And both houses are on the verge of approving legislation that would cut some $19 billion in wasteful subsidies to the Federal Family Education Loan Program.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on April 8 about Michigan States 3-1 victory over Boston College to capture the N.C.A.A. mens ice hockey championship misidentified the player who scored the only goal for the Eagles. It was Brian Boyle  not Brock Bradford, who had the assist. The reporter pointed out the error this week.

title: Painting a Rosy Picture of a Costly Fighter Jet
description: LE BOURGET, France, June 21  With jets screaming overhead, macho often mixes with Mach 1 here at the Paris air show. But the Lockheed Martin Corporation chose a softer approach to show the might of its next-generation radar-evading, supersonic fighter jet.

title: Home Depot Amendment
description: Squatting beside the bulk of the Senate immigration bill  a once-in-a-generation attempt to change millions of lives and the direction of the nation  you will find a squalid little amendment. It was placed there by Senator Johnny Isakson of Georgia to benefit an Atlanta-based corporate constituent, Home Depot.

title: Art in Review
description: DAVID LAMELAS Maccarone 630 Greenwich Street, at Morton Street, West Village Through July 28

title: Land of Lincoln
description: How do Americans love Abraham Lincoln? Andrew Ferguson counts the ways in Land of Lincoln, his hilarious, offbeat tour of Lincoln shrines, statues, cabins and museums. The 16th president comes in many forms, and every one, it seems, has a following, right down to Lincoln the chief executive officer, dispenser of corporate leadership tips.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Fleeting Structures and Nomadic Art
description: LONDON, June 21  A futuristic structure rising about 18 feet will soon appear on an open field just south of the Serpentine Gallery in Kensington Gardens here. The work of the London architect Zaha Hadid and her partner, Patrik Schumacher, the creation will exist for only a week, timed to coincide with the annual Serpentine summer party on July 11.

title: After One Objection, Senate Confirms Corzines Choice for Chief Justice
description: TRENTON, June 21  Despite an unexpected objection from a lone legislator that surfaced a week ago, the New Jersey Senate on Thursday confirmed Gov. Jon S. Corzines choice for chief justice of the State Supreme Court.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Friday about declining populations of once common birds misidentified one shorebird in decline. It is the common tern, not the greater tern.

title: Justices Support Guidelines for Sentencing
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Defendants may find it more difficult to challenge a sentence that is within the guidelines issued by the United States Sentencing Commission, under a ruling by the Supreme Court on Thursday.

title: Louise Bourgeois, Evoking Heart and Libido
description: Such is the fame of the 95-year-old sculptor Louise Bourgeois that you never have to hunt very hard for a show of her work. Even as we speak, a glimpse of her prodigious production is on view at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on June 13 about Don Herbert, who appeared on television in the 1950s and 60s as Mr. Wizard, misstated the name of the institution in Princeton, N.J., with which the physicist Frank Wilczek was affiliated in 1990, when he was interviewed about informal approaches to teaching science and praised Mr. Herbert. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not Studies.

title: Outdoors Is the Way Up in Ogden, Utah
description: WEDGED between old stockyards and a boarded-up packing plant on the western edge of town, the kayak park is not easy to find. But it is just the kind of thing that draws outdoor enthusiasts to Ogden, Utah.

title: Upbeat Economic News Helps Lift Shares
description: Stocks rebounded yesterday from their worst day in two weeks after Merrill Lynch assuaged concern of a looming credit crisis and the latest government report on the economy showed growth was accelerating.

title: Once Again, Trade Effort Stumbles on Subsidies
description: FRANKFURT, June 21  A high-level meeting aimed at salvaging global trade talks collapsed Thursday when the United States and the European Union fell out with India and Brazil over plans to cut agricultural subsidies and tariffs.

title: Sudden Power Show Sets Up Rematch for North Carolina
description: OMAHA, June 21  The setup was perfect. Rice and North Carolina, who met in Thursday nights bracket final at the College World Series, had been stunned and eliminated last year by Oregon State, the surprise champion.

title: New Community Center Gets Youths Off Streets and in the Ring
description: NEWARK, June 21  The fight was brief. The mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, floated like a butterfly, bouncing around a bit in oversized gloves. But it was 14-year-old Shakor Jackson who stung like a bee.

title: Research Finds Firstborns Gain the Higher I.Q.
description: The eldest children in families tend to develop higher I.Q.s than their siblings, researchers are reporting today, in a large study that could settle more than a half-century of scientific debate about the relationship between I.Q. and birth order.

title: Climbing Out on a Limb and Then Crawling Back
description: The low-key comedy Broken English, about a romance-scarred professional woman named Nora Wilder (Parker Posey) who invigorates her life with help from a handsome, sensitive, fedora-clad Frenchman (Melvil Poupaud), is a textbook example of an Indiewood film: a Hollywood fantasy wrapped in plain brown paper.

title: The Little Engine That Could Poison
description: FOR decades, Thomas the Tank Engine and his fellow trains have been teaching children important life lessons. Now the plucky locomotives  especially the haughty and sometimes naughty James the Red Engine  are serving up important lessons about regulating environmental poisons in the global economy.

title: The China Puzzle
description: The Chinese miracle has been the biggest economic story for several years now, a tale of a nation rising from the ashes of a Stalinist command economy to become the worlds premier trading partner. But China reminds us with distressing regularity that the progress has been selective.

title: Renewed to Keep the Bloom on the Rose
description: Rose Month events at the New York Botanical Garden conclude this weekend with free tours of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden and question-and-answer sessions with experts.

title: Brooklyn: Second Reprieve on Judges Sentence
description: A former judge was given a second reprieve on his prison sentence yesterday and allowed to enter an alcohol detoxification program. The former judge, Gerald P. Garson, 74, was convicted of accepting bribes to manipulate matrimonial cases in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. This month, Justice Jeffrey Berry of State Supreme Court sentenced Mr. Garson to 3 to 10 years, but after the hearing, an appellate court judge gave Mr. Garson a temporary stay to file an appeal. This week, the appellate court judge ordered Mr. Garson to begin his sentence and revoked the stay. But yesterday, Justice Berry, responding to defense arguments that Mr. Garson would probably die in prison without treatment for alcoholism, allowed Mr. Garson to attend a detoxification program until July 5 before beginning his sentence.

title: Afghans Say NATO Bombs Kill 25 Civilians
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 22  At least 25 civilians, including nine women, three babies and an elderly village mullah, were killed in an air strike early this morning when they were caught in a battle between Taliban and NATO forces in southern Afghanistan, said the police chief of Helmand province.

title: Pakistan: Like Rushdie, a Lofty Title for bin Laden
description: A group of clerics, the Pakistan Ulema Council, said they had given Osama bin Laden the title Saifullah, or sword of Allah, in response to the British governments decision to give Salman Rushdie, the author of The Satanic Verses, a knighthood. The chairman of the council, Tahir Ashrafi, said that since Mr. Rushdie, who is considered a blasphemer by many Muslims in Pakistan, had been given the title Sir, then Mr. bin Laden, a holy warrior in the eyes of the council, should be given a parallel title. The gesture was a more lighthearted reaction to the honor for Mr. Rushdie than the noisy protests of demonstrators in some cities of Pakistan. On Monday, Pakistans Parliament passed a resolution condemning the knighthood and said it should be withdrawn.

title: Might Drink Your Blood, but Otherwise Not Bad Guys
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20  These days Charity Bokindo, the district commissioner of Nairobi North, is taking no chances.

title: A Successful Cultural Exchange With No High-Fives
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 21  So how do you take two proud Americans like Terry Hutchinson and Kevin Hall and turn them each into someone who could pass for a Kiwi?

title: Manhattan: Marketing Officer Resigns
description: New York Citys chief marketing officer, Maureen J. Reidy, resigned yesterday to become chief operating officer of IMG Fashion, which puts on Fashion Week shows. Ms. Reidy had been responsible for sponsorship deals for the city and attracting major events, like the 2004 Republican National Convention and the 2008 Major League Baseball All-Star Game. George A. Fertitta, chief executive of NYC & Company, the citys marketing and tourism promotion agency, has not decided how to replace Ms. Reidy, a spokeswoman said.

title: British Girl Sues  for Right to Wear Chastity Ring
description: LONDON, June 22  At a time of passionate debate over religious clothing and emblems, a 16-year-old British Christian sued her school in court today for the right to wear a so-called purity ring symbolizing her commitment to pre-marital chastity.

title: Oh, Dolly! When Sheep Go Bad, Forget the Peace in the Valley
description: Its an exciting time to be involved in agricultural science. The achievement of Black Sheep, a pastoral horror-comedy from New Zealand, can be measured in its ability to make that sentence sound both sinister and hilarious. The movie is essentially a silly, grisly elaboration of a simple idea: What if sheep started running amok, feasting on human flesh and turning their victims into huge ovine zombies?

title: Nine Days Ahead of Schedule, New Jersey Legislature Passes a Budget
description: TRENTON, June 21  It was like the Legislatures version of speed-dating.

title: Open Wide and Say Shame
description: It has become a journalistic clich and therefore an inevitable part of the prerelease discussion of Sicko to refer to Michael Moore as a controversial, polarizing figure. While that description is not necessarily wrong, it strikes me as self-fulfilling (since the controversy usually originates in media reports on how controversial Mr. Moore is) and trivial. Any filmmaker, politically outspoken or not, whose work is worth discussing will be argued about. But in Mr. Moores case the arguments are more often about him than about the subjects of his movies.

title: Israel: Gay Parade Draws 2,500
description: A parade in Jerusalem in favor of gay rights passed off largely peacefully despite vocal opposition and protests by ultra-Orthodox citizens. The police arrested a man they said was carrying a homemade bomb he said he intended to put along the route. Some 2,500 people marched, according to the police, half the 5,000 that had been expected.

He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he appears to have run out of employers to disappoint with his statistically below-average pitching. title: New U.N. Plan Commits $2.15 Billion to Fight Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis
description: The World Health Organization yesterday released a plan intended to prevent hundreds of thousands of cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis and save up to 134,000 lives by 2008.

title: When Preaching Flops
description: A little while ago, a national study authorized by Congress found that abstinence education programs dont work. That gave liberals a chance to feel superior because it turns out that preaching traditional morality to students doesnt change behavior.

title: Agency Is Target in Cheney Fight on Secrecy Data
description: For four years, Vice President Dick Cheney has resisted routine oversight of his offices handling of classified information, and when the National Archives unit that monitors classification in the executive branch objected, the vice presidents office suggested abolishing the oversight unit, according to documents released yesterday by a Democratic congressman.

title: In Surprise Move, U.S. Envoy Visits North Korea
description: TOKYO, June 21  The United States chief nuclear negotiator on Thursday began a surprise two-day visit to North Korea, saying he wanted to speed up six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Koreas nuclear program.

title: Senate Adopts Energy Bill Raising Mileage for Cars
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Senate passed a broad energy bill late Thursday that would, among other things, require the first big increase in fuel mileage requirements for passenger cars in more than two decades.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the defense editor of the newspaper Haaretz who was considered the dean of Israeli military correspondents misstated his surname at one point. As the article noted, he was Zeev Schiff and in subsequent references he should have been identified as Mr. Schiff, not Mr. Haaretz.

title: A Yoga Classs Path to Serenity Leads Through Times Square
description: Its fame and its claim to being the crossroads of the world make Times Square a prime spot for a variety of events, from protests to race-car demonstrations. But it would seem a poor setting for something meant to produce serenity.

description: JT Leroy, the authorial other whom the writer Laura Albert employed as her alter ego and self-protective proxy in the world, was found yesterday by a jury in Manhattan to be not just a fictional creation but a fraud.

title: Survivors Recount Fatal Catskill Flood as Missing Are Sought
description: COLCHESTER, N.Y., June 22  It was not the first flood for Josephine Banks, whose property sits amid the fabled trout streams of the western Catskill Mountains. And so when the water started rising on Tuesday night, she had a strategy: Throw open the doors of the barn where she has a second-floor apartment and let the roiling creek flow through.
