title: Firefighter Falls to His Death in Brooklyn Fire
description: A 23-year-old firefighter was killed in Brooklyn yesterday when he fell four stories while fighting a small blaze ignited by a cigarette that had been left on a windowsill, officials said.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the disbarment of Michael B. Nifong, the district attorney in Durham County, N.C., misstated the surname of a North Carolina State Bar lawyer who made closing arguments in the ethics trial of Mr. Nifong. He is Doug Brocker, not Doug Brock.

title: Shaken and Stirred: For Liquor Campaigns, the Webs the Thing
description: TO introduce Reyka, an Icelandic vodka, William Grant & Sons is running a quirky campaign with a wit as dry as a well-made martini. There are erupting volcanoes, enigmatic puffins, fun facts about Iceland and comely women dressed for the cold rather than as they typically appear in liquor ads.

title: Dog Day at Christies
description: Bowing to a dog-crazed public, Christies is holding its first New York sale today dedicated to dogs in art: 95 paintings and sculptures dating from the 17th century to the present.

title: Rain and Clouds Make NASA Cancel Shuttle Landing
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla., June 21  Rain and clouds forced NASA to wave off two landing opportunities for the space shuttle Atlantis Thursday afternoon.

title: 14 Americans Are Killed in Combat in 2 Days
description: BAGHDAD, June 21  Fourteen Americans were killed in combat in five attacks, most in Baghdad, in a 48-hour period ending Thursday, the military announced.

title: Shuttle Lands Safely in California
description: The space shuttle Atlantis set down safely at Edwards Air Force Base in California today at 3:49 p.m. Eastern time, ending its 5.8-million-mile, 14-day mission.

title: One Day (and Dead Body) at a Time
description: With its shadows and gallows humor, You Kill Me goes about as dark as a comedy can go before turning into tragedy or self-parody. Its ethnic stereotypes are Polish mobsters from Buffalo, which just means that they eat kielbasa instead of Italian sausage and traffic in real snow. They dont have much juice, only a chunk of the city, but they speak the same patois as the usual players, doing shakedowns and takedowns between analyzing this and that. Theyre not especially wise, these guys; if anything, theyre kind of sad.

title: In Colorado, Yankees Take a Turn for the Worse
description: DENVER, June 21  As Roger Clemens threw his warm-up pitches before the bottom of the first inning, a fan in the front row at Coors Field held up a sign chiding the Yankees for paying $28 million for a dinosaur.

title: CBS Leads in Ad Commitments for Fall Season
description: The sale of commercial time before the start of the 2007-8 broadcast television season is winding up as three big networks garner commitments from advertisers.

title: Bush Advisers Weigh Closing Guantnamo Prison Sooner
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  President Bushs top advisers have reopened an internal debate over how quickly to close the American detention unit for suspected terrorists at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, according to administration officials familiar with the deliberations.

title: Trails, Trains and a Syrup House in Woodstock, Vt.
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., is an old-fashioned town that's not stuck in the past. Mixed in with vintage grocery stores, antique farms and a covered bridge is a comfortable assortment of coffee shops, art stores and fun boutiques with an upscale but rural tinge, like the Vermont Flannel Company (20 Central Street, 802-476-5226; www.vermontflannel.com), which sells everything from nightshirts to red and green tartan flannel underwear.

title: In Sweep of Iraqi Town, Sectarian Fears Percolate
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 21  After two days of clawing their way toward insurgent strongholds in western Baquba, American troops on Thursday began one of the most delicate phases of the operation: reintroducing the citys residents to their own army.

title: Making Waves in Dairyland
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Ron Kind, a Democratic representative from Wisconsin dairyland, is making a name for himself as a crusader for big changes in farm policy. Its making many of his colleagues nervous.

title: Mexico Moves to Send Ex-Governor to U.S. on Drug Charges
description: MEXICO CITY, June 21  Mexico took the first steps on Thursday toward extraditing the former governor of Quintana Roo to the United States, where he is wanted in New York City on charges of drug trafficking, money laundering and racketeering.

title: Ed Friendly, 85, a Producer of Little House, Dies
description: Ed Friendly, co-producer of hit television shows including the rambunctious Rowan & Martins Laugh-In and the frontier saga Little House on the Prairie, died Sunday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 85.

title: A Time to Reflect, as Some Orchestra Members Bid Goodbye
description: Certain places on the calendar, arbitrarily chosen though they are, invite people to contemplate the trajectories of their lives, their present positions and what brought them there. The last subscription series of the New York Philharmonics season began on Wednesday night. New hirings were announced from the stage, and five retiring members were given public goodbyes.

title: Spitzer and Legislature Sprint to Finish Line
description: ALBANY, June 21  Gov. Eliot Spitzers first legislative session was coming to a fractious close on Thursday night, as he and top lawmakers failed to reach agreement on a wide range of issues as they rushed to finish business for the summer.

description: Washington

title: ABC Says It Was Outbid for Paris Hilton Interview
description: How much is an interview with Paris Hilton worth? Representatives of ABC News said yesterday that they had lost to NBC for the first interview with Paris Hilton after her release from jail next week because ABC was unwilling to make a high six-figure deal with Ms. Hiltons family.

title: New Jersey Man Kills 2 Daughters and Self
description: A man apparently drowned his two young daughters in a bathtub and then hanged himself from the rafters of the attic in his home in Montclair, N.J., the Montclair police said yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about a lawsuit by the tennis player Guillermo Coria against a nutritional supplement company that he blames for his positive steroid test referred incorrectly to an arrangement in professional basketball designed to ensure safe and pure supplements for athletes. The N.B.A. players union, not the league itself, has such a deal with a supplement maker.

title: Bosnia: Study Puts War Dead at 97,207
description: A total of 97,207 people were killed or disappeared in the 1992-1995 war in Bosnia, according to a three-year study by the Sarajevo-based Research and Documentation Center. The center, which describes itself as independent and nonpartisan, said it had names for all the dead cited in its study. It said that close to two-thirds of the casualties, 64,036, were Bosnian Muslims, followed by Serbs, 24,905, and Croats, 7,788, while 478 were of other nationalities. Almost half of the casualties died in the first year of the war. Of the total dead, 57,523 were directly involved in the war and 39,684 were civilians.

title: For Schumer, the Double-Edged Sword of Cozying Up to Hedge Funds
description: They are not normally a shy group, the hedge fund managers, private equity titans and Wall Street executives whose net worth has suddenly become a national issue. But last spring, when a group of them gathered at the Regency in New York for a Democratic fund-raiser, they were downright bashful.

title: School Crossing Guard Is Charged With 1,000 Counts of Child Molesting
description: BERWICK, Pa., June 21  Michele Andreas says she is never going to trust anyone to watch her three boys again.

title: Seen on the Street: Photographers Everyday Epiphanies
description: When artists talk about training the eye, they generally dont mean doing exercises to maintain 20/20 vision. They mean honing a set of instincts, learning to see relationships among colors or objects or spaces. The title of this small but potent collection of contemporary photographs from the Metropolitan Museums collection describes this kind of vision another way: seeing what is Hidden in Plain Sight. The show focuses mostly on versions of street, rather than studio, photography.

title: Backing Fatah and Abbas, Egypt Organizes Summit Meeting for Palestinian Leader
description: GAZA, June 21  In a gesture of support for the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, Egypt has organized a summit meeting in which he will meet with President Hosni Mubarak and the Jordanian and Israeli leaders.

title: With ABN Amro in Play, Chief of Barclays Capital Savors a New Test
description: LONDON, June 21  Robert E. Diamond Jr., the 55-year-old president of Barclays, grinned, rubbed his palms together, and then hopped up and down in his office chair like a 5-year-old.

title: Budget Nominee Knows Thing or Two About Spending
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  Former Representative Jim Nussle of Iowa, President Bushs new choice for budget director, is no stranger to the ways in which members of Congress can drive federal spending higher.

title: Brooklyn: Attack on Officer Investigated
description: The police yesterday continued their investigation of the sexual assault of an off-duty police officer who was attacked at knifepoint by a masked man in her Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday night. The woman, whose name, age and rank were not released, had just gotten off work when, shortly after 6:30 p.m., she was attacked by a man who investigators believe broke into her Bay Ridge apartment through a rear window where an air-conditioner had been installed, the police said. The man grabbed her from behind, sexually assaulted her and then fled, possibly through the same window, the police said. The woman called another officer from her precinct to report the attack. It was not known if she knew her attacker or if he knew she was an officer.

title: Mets and Glavine Backing Into a Corner
description: Andy Van Slyke batted .354 in 65 career at-bats, including the postseason, against Tom Glavine. But he says he believes he had only one hit off him, a home run in the 1991 National League Championship Series.

title: Bob Evans, 89, Restaurateur With Chain Built on Sausage, Dies
description: Bob Evans, who turned a 12-stool restaurant into a nationwide chain and food empire with the help of his homemade sausage, died yesterday, Bob Evans Farm Inc. said. He was 89.

title: Niceness Counts in Ark-Building, Too
description: Evan Almighty, in which Steve Carell, playing a newly elected congressman from Buffalo, is commanded by God (Morgan Freeman) to build an ark, is a movie far less interesting than its premise. It is also slightly less interesting than its hugely popular predecessor, Bruce Almighty, which starred Jim Carrey. But there is nonetheless a fruitful franchise in the making here, a potentially endless series of movies with popular, sometimes naughty comedians acting out wholesome modern-day versions of well-known Bible stories.

description: General Electric Company said today that it and Pearson, the British publisher, had decided against making an offer for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, leaving Rupert Murdochs News Corporation as the sole bidder.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column in the Dining section on Wednesday, about the opening of the restaurant Muse in Water Mill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number. It is (631) 726-2606.

title: Foundation With Real Money Ventures Into Virtual World
description: For the first time, one of the nations largest foundations is venturing into virtual worlds to play host to activities and discussions and explore the role that philanthropy might play there.

title: Peltz Is Said to Be Pressing for Sale of Some Kraft Brands
description: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor, does not like Fruity Pebbles cereal or Maxwell House coffee.

title: In Aiding Poor, Edwards Built Bridge to 2008
description: John Edwards ended 2004 with a problem: how to keep alive his public profile without the benefit of a presidential campaign that could finance his travels and pay for his political staff.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Investors Suits Face Higher Bar, Justices Rule
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The Supreme Court on Thursday dealt a blow to investors who want to sue companies and executives because of suspected fraud, setting a higher standard for class-action lawsuits to go forward.

title: This Time, Its Personal: Mayor Blasts U.S. Envoy on London Toll
description: LONDON, June 21  Diplomatic it was not. In a feud with the American ambassador here, Londons mayor notched up the vitriol on Thursday to the point of wishing harm, even terminal harm, to Washingtons envoy.

title: In Writers Trial, a Conflict Over Roles of Art and Money
description: Florenz Ziegfelds notion of arts subservience to commerce is an old idea in the entertainment field. In another form, it might be rendered that art is there only to make a buck.

title: Blackstone Rival Plans Own I.P.O.
description: Now that the Blackstone Group is off and running, it needs to start looking over its shoulder.

title: Killings Surge in Oakland, and Officials Are Unable to Explain Why
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 15  The names of friends and family members killed in this city over the last two years come easily to Rob Wilson, a rangy, dreadlocked 17-year-old gang member.

title: People
description: People

title: Speaking Simply of War and the True Courage of Heroes
description: In Beyond Glory, a solo show about war veterans that opened last night at the Laura Pels Theater, Stephen Lang portrays a series of former servicemen recollecting their combat experiences and the acts of courage that won them the United States militarys highest laurel, the Medal of Honor.

title: South Korea: Lone Star May Sell Part of Bank
description: Lone Star Funds, the buyout firm founded by John Grayken, plans to sell a stake in Korea Exchange Bank for as much as $1.1 billion after its move to divest entirely was derailed last year by a legal dispute. Lone Star is offering 73.1 million shares, or 11.3 percent of Korea Exchange, for 13,150 to 13.750 won ($14.19 to $14.84) a share, according to an e-mail message sent to fund managers by the Credit Suisse Group, the investment bank arranging the sale. Shares in Korea Exchange fell 1.7 percent, to 14,600 won, up 14 percent this year. Lone Star, based in Dallas, has struggled for two years to sell the controlling stake it bought in 2003 as Korean prosecutors contend that the firm purchased the shares at an artificially low price. The sale of part of the Seoul-based bank would allow Lone Star to return money to investors while the case is pending and retain a majority stake.

title: Cheney in Dispute on Oversight of His Office
description: For four years, Vice President Dick Cheney has resisted routine oversight of his offices handling of classified information, and when the office in charge of overseeing classification in the executive branch objected, the vice presidents office suggested that the oversight office be shut down, according to documents released today by a Democratic congressman.

title: Still Building a Ladder to the Stars
description: Robert Roane escorted Gretta Cohen to the senior prom on Thursday night.

title: City Smokers Ranks Drop 19%, Study Says
description: The citys department of health, citing a combination of high taxes, workplace limits and $10 million in grim television advertising, said yesterday that the number of smokers in New York City had declined by 240,000 in the last five years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a sports article in some copies on Wednesday about the Rockies 3-1 victory against the Yankees misstated the score after Kaz Matsui crossed the plate for Colorado in the fifth inning. It was 2-1, not 2-0.

title: Voucher Use in Washington Wins Praise of Parents
description: Students who participated in the first year of the District of Columbias federally financed school voucher program did not show significantly higher math or reading achievement, but their parents were satisfied anyway, viewing the private schools they attended at taxpayer expense as safer and better than public schools, according to an Education Department study released yesterday.

title: Spain: Explosives Found in Car in South
description: The Civil Guard said it had found a car loaded with explosives in southern Spain. A spokesman said in a telephone interview that the car was found in Ayamonte, a popular tourist area close to the border with Portugal, and that the explosives were apparently in the process of being transported and were not rigged to a detonator. The radio station Cadena Ser put the amount at 220 pounds. The paramilitary Basque group ETA formally ended a 15-month cease-fire on June 5 and put Spain on the alert for possible terrorist attacks, particularly in southern areas frequented by tourists.

title: Theater Listings
description: POTOMAC THEATER PROJECT After 20 years of producing theater in and around Washington, the Potomac Theater Project is hoping to call New York City home again. An earlier incarnation of the group, the New York Theater Studio, was active here from 1977 to 1985.

title: Track Workers Reminded: Always Look Both Ways
description: Each year Bob Wills teaches hundreds of people who work on the subway tracks how to do their jobs without getting hit by a train  and he likes to tell them that they are going to fail his class.

title: EBay Is Preparing to Re-enter the China Auction Business
description: STRASBOURG, France, June 21  EBay is on track to rejoin the online auction business in China this summer, with tight restrictions on sellers to clamp down on sales of counterfeit goods, the companys chief executive said this week.

title: From Cuba, With a Dream of the Majors
description: Geikel Conyedo may one day play professional baseball. Or he may merely be another high school star whose career stalls in college. Whatever happens, he has already overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles on his journey to New Jersey from Cuba.

title: Doping Scandal Puts Dark Cloud Over Coverage of Tour de France
description: The end of the Lance Armstrong era was not fated to be easy for Versus.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Correction: Where It All Started
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Independence Day celebrations misstated the given name of the British general who surrendered to American forces at Yorktown, Va. He was Charles Cornwallis, not George.

title: Asking Serious Questions in a Very Quiet Voice
description: KASSEL, Germany, June 16  Once every five summers the charismatic exhibition called Documenta transforms this ashen industrial city smack in the middle of the country into an international culture center. And even when the show bumps up against other big-deal events  the Venice Biennale and the Mnster Sculpture Project both recently opened  it has a mystique of its own.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: U.S. Envoy Finishes North Korea Talks
description: TOKYO, June 22  The United States chief nuclear negotiator left North Korea today after a surprise visit with assurances that Pyongyang would slow down its main nuclear reactor, a move that would fulfill a commitment made in February and help speed six-nation talks aimed at dismantling North Koreas nuclear program.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) STARGATE SG-1 Over and out: Sci Fis longest-running original series comes to an end after 10 seasons, leaving the SG-1s (played by Beau Bridges, Ben Browder, Lou Gossett Jr. and Amanda Tapping, among others) to explore galaxies we earthlings can only imagine. For mourning viewers, two Stargate SG-1 films are reportedly in the works. Tonight, the Asgard, facing extinction, decide to hand over all their knowledge and technology to the team. But will there be time enough to stop the Ori?

title: Officials Find Lapses by Trooper Who Drove Corzine in Parkway Accident
description: Law enforcement officials have concluded that the state trooper who was driving Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey during a devastating car accident two months ago was violating policy by speeding and using emergency lights, was not adequately aware of the situation and could have prevented the accident. As a result, the state police superintendent has disciplined the trooper, Robert J. Rasinski, though he declined to specify the punishment.

title: A Trumpeter in His 80s Feeds the Fires of His Revolution
description: The new thing, the third great revolution in jazz, has suddenly found its audience. Whitney Balliett wrote those words in 1965, bestowing a serious subculture with a modicum of approval. By his estimation, jazzs first two revolutions had been spearheaded respectively by Louis Armstrong and Charlie Parker. The new thing, a looser but better term than the avant-garde, seemed a bit more surprising in its appeal.

title: Quartet to Meet on Palestinian Turmoil
description: JERUSALEM, June 22  Diplomats from the United States, European Union, Russia and the United Nations plan to meet on Tuesday in Jerusalem, a day after the Israeli and Palestinian leaders meet with the leaders of Egypt and Jordan in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, said Israeli, Russian and U.N. officials.

title: Water, Waves, Action
description: DURING the dog days of summer and into early autumn, the competitors and organizers of surfing competitions on the Atlantic and Pacific coasts gaze hopefully toward the south.

title: Brooklyn: Evidence Turned Over in Case Against Bouncer
description: In their case against a bouncer accused of killing a 24-year-old graduate student, prosecutors yesterday gave defense lawyers four boxes of evidence described as medical reports and hair and fiber analyses. The defendant, Darryl Littlejohn, 42, has been charged with the murder of Imette St. Guillen, a student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Ms. St. Guillens body was found bound and strangled in a remote part of Brooklyn in February 2006, a day after she had visited a bar in SoHo where Mr. Littlejohn worked. No trial date has been scheduled. Prosecutors in Brooklyn are waiting for their counterparts in Queens to try Mr. Littlejohn first, on separate and unrelated kidnapping charges.

title: Great Lakes Pollution Suit
description: Eight conservation groups led by the National Wildlife Federation announced plans to sue several shipping companies that operate in the Great Lakes, accusing them of discharging polluted water without the permit required under the federal Clean Water Act. The release of untreated ballast water, water held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, introduces nonnative species that could harm the lakes ecosystem, the groups contend.

title: Nader Weighs Another Run for President
description: Ralph Nader, whose run for president infuriated Democrats in 2000 and made him the object of disdain when he ran again in 2004, said today that he might get into the 2008 race.

title: Reflections on Baryshnikovs Latest (Not Last) Legs
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV. Ballet superstar, company director, commissioner of choreography, collaborator, photographer, actor, childrens book author, artistic director of his own cultural center, Carrie Bradshaws perfidious boyfriend. But most of all, and most simply, dancer.

title: Jim Shoulders, a Tenacious Rodeo Champion, Dies at 79
description: Jim Shoulders, a city boy who gained renown as the Babe Ruth of professional rodeo, riding bucking broncos and snorting bulls to a record 16 world-championship titles, died Wednesday in Henryetta, Okla. He was 79.

title: Giambi Will Cooperate With M.L.B.s Probe
description: Jason Giambi of the Yankees agreed yesterday to cooperate with George J. Mitchells investigation into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball, apparently becoming the first active player who has consented to speak with Mitchell, the former United States Senator. Mitchells investigation is almost 15 months old.

title: 3 Drug Makers Are Convicted in Reimbursement Overcharges
description: A federal judge ruled yesterday that AstraZeneca, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Schering-Plough must pay damages for overcharging on certain drugs paid for by Medicare, pension funds, insurers and patients.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about the success of the New York Athletic Clubs elite womens running team misstated a team members collegiate achievements. Julia Stamps Mallon was named an all-American at Stanford six times, not twice.

title: A New Commissioner Enters the Fray Against Gridlock
description: IT sounds like a tall order, being asked by a reporter to dumb down the hellacious  or is it heaven-sent  concept of congestion pricing and its potentially redemptive role in releasing New York Citys midsection from the pain of gridlock. Congestion pricing is, after all, a very smart product. Ingenious, actually, if Janette Sadik-Khan, the tall (5-foot-8 in her svelte suede kitten heels) new commissioner of the citys Department of Transportation, is consulted.

title: Report Rates Hospitals on Their Heart Treatment
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The federal government has gingerly stepped back into rating the care delivered by the nations hospitals, releasing for the first time in nearly two decades a list of hospitals where heart patients are most likely to die.

title: Port Authority Tentatively Approves Changes Aimed at Increasing Public Scrutiny
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, long a cloistered and opaque agency, took a big step yesterday toward opening itself to greater public scrutiny by tentatively approving changes to overhaul the way it awards contracts, works with lobbyists and makes decisions affecting the airports, bridges, ports and tunnels it operates.

title: In Virginia, a Blue Ridge Retreat Thats a Little Undiscovered
description: JOSEPH RADA had been a New Jersey boy his whole life  born in Perth Amboy, grew up in Holmdel, worked in Elizabeth, raised a family in Lincroft. Virginias Blue Ridge Mountains were hardly on his mind.

title: Romney Policy Speech
description: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential hopeful, called for a new course in the battle against global terrorism in a speech to the American Enterprise Institutes World Forum in Colorado. Mr. Romney urged what he described as a new type of Marshall Plan that would deliver economic aid, public health aid and other assistance to Islamic states struggling to resist violent extremists. He also called for the creation of a special military unit that would work with other governments to combat terrorists.

title: Romancing the Rose in Its Infinite Splendor
description: AS they always have  and absolutely must  during Rose Month at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, fanciers of the queen of flowers will stop, stoop and smell the roses, inhaling the splendor of the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden throughout the month of June. But this year visitors will discover a 1.04-acre garden that has been redefined. After undergoing a comprehensive, six-month, $2.5 million refurbishing, the rose garden is presenting its largest and most varied collection ever: 3,373 plants in 621 varieties.

title: Mike 08? Better Dust Off Citys Charter
description: How does Mayor Gotbaum strike your ear? You never know. You just might have to get used to the sound of that.

title: Jones Is Said to Be Close to a Sale of Barneys
description: The Jones Apparel Group was near a deal late last night to sell Barneys New York, the high-fashion chain, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, people involved in the talks said.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: 2 Companies Drop Pursuit of Dow Jones
description: The General Electric Company and Pearson, the British publisher, have decided not to make an offer for Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, G.E. said yesterday, leaving Rupert Murdochs News Corporation as the only bidder.

title: Yankees Cast in Place, as Sequel Awaits a Finish
description: The Bronx Zoo observed through the impressionable eyes of a teenage bat boy. Such was the original narrative for an eight-part television series on the 1977 Yankees set against the backdrop of New York City in the Summer of Billy, Reggie, George and Sam.

title: Muslims Veils Test Limits of Britains Tolerance
description: LONDON, June 16  Increasingly, Muslim women in Britain take their children to school and run errands covered head to toe in flowing black gowns that allow only a slit for their eyes. On a Sunday afternoon in Hyde Park, groups of black-clad Muslim women relaxed on the green baize lawn among the in-line skaters and badminton players.

title: Dont Veto, Dont Obey
description: President Bush is notorious for issuing statements taking exception to hundreds of bills as he signs them. This week, we learned that in a shocking number of cases, the Bush administration has refused to enact those laws. Congress should use its powers to insist that its laws are obeyed.

title: Official Says He Told Truth on Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  The No. 2 official in the Justice Department said Thursday that he told the truth in February when he testified at a Senate hearing that the White House had limited involvement in the dismissal of federal prosecutors, an assertion that proved incorrect.

title: As Japan Ages, Universities Struggle to Fill Classrooms
description: DAZAIFU, Japan  When Yasunori Iwanaga was choosing universities three years ago, it was not the academic program, the strong team in judo, his favorite sport, or even the study abroad program in England that swayed him to choose Fukuoka University of Economics.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: CELEBRATING THE FOURTH

title: A Sad Tale of Fictional S.E.C. Filings
description: When it comes to disclosures, Universal Express is not exactly a model company.

title: A Course Is Added to the Police Academy Curriculum: How to Become Good Neighbors
description: Concluding that police officers are sometimes too detached from the communities they serve, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday the start of a new program of intense training in community relations for cadets at the Police Academy.

title: $4 Billion Price on Bigger Plan for Expansion of Javits Center
description: After a six-month review of the expansion plan for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the Spitzer administration is seriously considering a revamped proposal that would include additional exhibition space but cost $4 billion, more than twice the previous estimate.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,526 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Playing in Peoria, Former Top Pick of Padres Hopes to Salvage Career
description: PEORIA, Ariz., June 20  For a professional baseball player of any acclaim and experience to be in Peoria at this time of year, something has to have gone wrong.

title: Correction
description: The Keeping Score column on Sunday, about new baseball research into hitting and fielding trends that can help assess the impact of pitchers, referred incorrectly to the status of the journeyman Glendon Rusch. He is recovering from a blood-clot scare last season, and is not pitching now; he is not out of the game because he "appears to have run out of employers to disappoint" with his statistically below-average pitching.

title: True West
description: Images from the life of a bareback rider.

title: Lake Living
description: A look at Smith Mountain Lake, a Virginia vacation area with 500 miles of shoreline.

title: Predictable Gold Cup Final Could Be Anything But
description: In the end, we have the Gold Cup final that everyone expected, those old rivals the United States and Mexico at Soldier Field in Chicago on Sunday.

title: Rats and Buildings
description: Images from David Macaulay's new exhibition at the National Museum Building in Washington.

title: The Vatican Library
description: Images from the Vatican Library, which is set to close in July for a three-year renovation.

title: Browsing at the Renegade Craft Fair
description: More than 200 vendors set up booths in McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn, peddling their handmade wares to people for whom do-it-yourself is the only label that matters.

title: A Walk in the Clouds
description: Images from Hiram Bingham's 1911 expedition to Machu Picchu.

title: A Weekend at War
description: For Dark Angel, a scenario paintball game, 400 players took sides for a 26-hour game of humans against mutant supersoldiers.

title: How High (or Low) Will Blackstone Go?
description: Just how immune is the Blackstone Group to the slings and arrows of Congress? The next test comes later this morning when its shares begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker BX. The $4.1 billion offering generated a flood of interest from all over the world, despite a series of last-minute challenges from United States lawmakers, leading to predictions that the stock would quickly surge about the $31 offer price set late Thursday.

title: Lets (Not) Make a Deal
description: Monty Hall would probably be ashamed. Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Legislative leaders were close to agreements on a wide range of issues as the legislative session came to a fractious close on Thursday night. But then it all fell apart, and Mr. Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the states top Republican, took to their respective corners of the capitol to assail each other for the failures.

title: Nimby heartthrob
description: George Clooney has gone from Hollywood heartthrob to neighborhood Nimby. The movie star is protesting a $16 million development that he says will ruin the beauty and serenity of his favorite retreat  Lake Como  where he owns a lakeside villa.

title: Jefferies Gobbles Up Yet Another Advisory Group
description: The Jefferies Group said it had acquired the Putnam Lovell investment banking business, a provider of merger advice to asset managers and broker dealers, from National Bank Financial Group of Canada. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Wachovia Fined $2 Million for Excessive Fees
description: Wachovia Securities has been fined $2 million and ordered to pay restitution to more than 1,300 customers for charging excessive fees in its fee-based brokerage accounts, regulators said Thursday.

title: Bell Canadas Talks With Telus May Spoil Private Equitys Party
description: Private equity suitors for Bell Canada may soon be headed for the exits as the arrival of Telus creates a clear front-runner in the race for control of Canadas largest phone company, The Globe and Mail suggested. Bell Canada said Wednesday that it was discussing a possible merger with Telus, the leading phone company in western Canada.

title: In Battle for CBOT, Tub-Thumping Continues
description: IntercontinentalExchange stepped up its efforts Thursday to acquire the Chicago Board of Trade, appealing to shareholders as the vote nears on a bid from Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings.

title: Peltz Is Said to Push for Sale of Kraft Brands
description: Nelson Peltz, the activist investor, does not like Fruity Pebbles cereal or Maxwell House coffee. That is what he is preparing to tell Kraft Foods, having quietly acquired a 3 percent stake in the company, according to The New York Times.

title: How Many Memories Fit In Your Brain?
description: If you were to walk into an unfamiliar room, look around briefly and then close your eyes, how much could you could remember of what you saw? Well give you a chance to find out how your visual memory compares with other peoples, but be warned: your memory is probably worse than you imagine.

title: Plane Freed From a Glacier Sets Out for Britain Again
description: A week ago, the eyes of an anxious world were fixed on Tulsa, Okla., straining for a glimpse of a time-capsule car being unearthed after 50 years under the courthouse lawn  which, despite all the precautions that circa-1957 civic hucksterism thought to take in prepping the car, dashed many a fond hope when it emerged from its vault as only a Plymouth Belvedere-shaped lump of rust. Sniff.

title: K.K.R. Wins Bidding for Air Canada Division, Report Says
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has won the auction for Air Canada Technical Services in a deal valued at around C$900 million ($840 million), The Globe and Mail reported. In buying the controlling stake in the Air Canada maintenance division, the buyout shop aiming to create a leading Canadian-based aircraft maintenance firm that services airlines around the world

title: Is Zells Tribune Deal Hitting the Rocks?
description: Is Samuel Zells complex deal to buy Tribune in trouble?

title: NYSE Euronext Enters Bidding for Italian Exchange, Report Says
description: NYSE Euronext has joined the bidding fray for Italian markets operator Borsa Italiana, which is currently considering an offer from the London Stock Exchange Group reportedly worth $2 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Madison Dearborn Plans $13 Billion Buyout Fund, Report Says
description: In yet another example of the unprecedented amount of cash flooding the private equity industry, buyout shop Madison Dearborn Partners is planning a sixth fund that could be twice as large as the $6.5 billion to buyout fund it closed last year, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Global Migration
With ABN Amro in Play, Chief of Barclays Capital Savors a New Test
description: Whether Barclays $91 billion bid for ABN Amro succeeds or fails, one of the areas where the impact will be felt most strongly is at the British banks investment banking unit. And Robert E. Diamond Jr., head of Barclays Capital, would be crucial to making a merger work, noted The New York Times.

title: Investors Tune in to Border Media
description: Spanish-language radio station operator Border Media Partners has raised $111 million from a private equity consortium, that includes Vestar Capital Partners, Goldman Sachs Urban Investment Group and Darby Overseas Investments.

title: Bear Stearns Is Said to Plan $3.2 Billion Bailout of Hedge Fund
description: Seeking to stave off disaster, Bear Stearns plans to take on $3.2 billion of loans to stop creditors from seizing assets of one of its money-losing hedge funds in the biggest fund bailout since 1998, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Mobile Payment Firm Rings Up $9 Million in Funding
description: Danal said Thursday it received $9.5 million in new venture financing. San Jose-based Danal is the U.S. subsidiary of South Koreas Danal Company, a mobile payment service company. The round was led by Morgenthaler Ventures and the South Korean parent company also contributed to the funding.

title: For Schumer, New Tax Legislation Demands a Balancing Act
description: Hedge fund managers and private equity titans are not the only ones who find themselves in an awkward position as Congress contemplates legislation that would raise taxes on publicly traded private equity firms.

title: Alert: Terminal Changes at Rome Airport
description: I did not think Romes main airport, Leonardo Da Vinci (a.k.a. Fiumicino) could get more frustrating or disorganised. But it has achieved that feat today: Suddenly, unannounced, as of yesterday, check-in for flights to Paris, Brussels (and a few other Europen cities) are leaving from the Domestic Departures Terminal, Terminal A. Oh, but its not that simple: Only flights on Alitalia, KLM and Air France have moved. The rest remain in the European International Departures Terminal, Terminal B.

title: Jones Is Said to Be Close to a Sale of Barneys
description: The Jones Apparel Group was near a deal late Thursday night to sell Barneys New York, the high-fashion chain, for about $825 million to the investment arm of the Dubai government, The New York Times reported.

title: Goldman Chief Urges Caution on Buyout Tax Increases
description: Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein warned Thursday that raising taxes on private equity firms could be very dangerous, telling The Financial Times that it might encourage the industry to move to more favorable tax regimes. But Mr. Blankfein, whose firm is extremely active in the buyout business through its private equity arm, also said the issue of private equity taxation deserved a closer look.

title: A Firefighters Death; Bigger Javits; Albany Breakdown; JT Leroy
description: The local headlines today are dominated by the death of Firefighter Daniel F. Pujdak, who fell from the fourth floor of a warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon while fighting a fire that began with a lighted cigarette left on a windowsill.

title: K.K.R. Wants an I.P.O. of Its Own
description: Reports that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is preparing its own initial public offering is the latest chapter in the saga of the private equity firms rivalry with arch-nemesis the Blackstone Group.

title: Green Banking
description: This week Friends of the Earth in the Netherlands initiated a campaign called Not with My Money in which people were urged not to bank at banks that invest in oil or coal energy.This morning dozens of people cut up their ATM cards in front of one bank and vowed to switch to other institutions.

title: A Death in the Line of Duty
description: Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who was killed Thursday in a fall at a fire in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was the first firefighter to die in the line of duty since last August.

title: Web Aggregator Daylife Raises $8.3 Million
description: Daylife, a news aggregation Web site, raised about $8.3 million in a Series B round of venture funding from investors including the New York Times Company, according to a regulatory filing cited by peHUB.com.

title: Bear Stearns Said to Withdraw Everquest I.P.O.
description: Everquest Financial, a firm with ties to a troubled hedge fund run by Bear Stearns, has called off its proposed initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

title: Blackstone Moves Higher in NYSE Debut
description: Just how immune is the Blackstone Group to the slings and arrows of Congress?

title: 2008: Obama, Edwards on Government Reforms
description: In New Hampshire this morning, Senator Barack Obama is set to give a speech on trying to reform Washington. His campaign released excerpts of the speech, planned for an audience at New Hampshire Community Technical College in Manchester. The reform package, which Mr. Obama pledges to enact on his first day in office, includes a strict provision barring political appointees who leave their position from lobbying the executive branch for the remainder of the administration.

title: Liberals, Divas and Abusers
Saving Blood Cells from Umbilical Cords
description: Among the more unusual pieces of legislation enacted by the Legislature in the waning days of the session is a law establishing a public and private umbilical cord blood banking program in the State Health Department.

title: Remarks of Senator Barack Obama
description: The following is the prepared text of Senator Obamas speech on government reform, as provided by his campaign.

title: A Favorite Swimming Spot in Berlin
description: In Berlin, one good way to beat the heat is by jumping into Ploetzensee, one of the citys many fine lakes. Ploetzensee is small, understated and central  set back in woods from the busy Seestrasse thoroughfare in Berlin-Wedding about 7 kilometers (4.2 miles) northwest of the Brandenburg Gate. Named after a red-eyed carp called a Ploetze, the lake has been a popular bathing spot with beach and snack bar for more than 150 years.

title: Two Ritchie Funds File for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Ritchie Capital put two of its Ireland-based funds into bankruptcy protection Thursday, marking the latest setback for the hedge-fund firm founded by A.R. Thane Ritchie, a former college football star. The funds lost more than $700 million investing in life-insurance policies covering wealthy individuals, and Ritchie has sued Coventry First, which sold it some of the policies, over the losses.

title: 9/11 Simulation Taxes Purdue Servers
description: Its unusual for an academic computer-science department to brag about its prowess on YouTube, but thats exactly what happened this month after Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., released a study into the causes of the collapse of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Learning to Walk the Tracks
description: After a series of fatal accidents in the New York City subway, the transit authority has stepped up its safety training. William Neuman of The Times went into an active subway tunnel.

title: Bloomberg: Im Not Going to Be President
description: How many times and ways can the man say it?

title: Wharton Picks Marketing Man for Deans Post
description: The Wharton School has a new dean, and he is well-versed in the art of the pitch.

title: Live and Let Di
description: I once read a novel  at least I think I did, I cant recall the title  in which, after a date, a guy returns with a young woman to her apartment. All is well until he gets a look at his dates bookshelves: they are overflowing with what appears to be Joyce Carol Oates novels and only Joyce Carol Oates novels. Dozens and dozens of them. I forget what his exact response is. But its something like: Aiieee!

title:
Stray Questions For:
Chris Abani
description: Chris Abanis novels include GraceLand and, most recently, The Virgin of Flames.What are you working on?
