description: Sewell Chan at our sib-blog, City Room, has New York Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs latest denial:

title: Picking Up Where Dean Left Off
description: Hungry for dinner with Senator Barack Obama? A minimum contribution of $5 to his presidential campaign  and, of course, a little dash of luck  was all it took to play along in the latest political gimmick of the 2008 race for the White House.

title: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
description: Why is Wall Street so alarmed that a bunch of mortgage securities might be sold?

title: Freak Amusement Park Accident Severs Girls Feet
description: Your stomach falls out at the thought of it: a 13-year-old girl is happily enjoying an amusement-park ride one minute, and is grotesquely injured the next.

title: Controversy Follows United States Into Gold Cup Final
description: The Unites States men's national team remained on course Thursday to retain the Concacaf Gold Cup with a hard-fought 2-1 win over Canada in their semifinal at Soldier Field in Chicago. The Americans will meet archrival Mexico on Sunday afternoon.

title: Picking Up Where Dean Left Off
description: In his web column today, Jeff Zeleny writes:

title: The End of Tom Sawyer-ware
description: Plaxo, which offers a web-based address book service, was an early dot-com high flyer. There was just one wrinkle. The premise of the original service was to persuade your friends to do the heavy lifting and fill in your address book for you. However, by the time most people received their fifth (or tenth) request from Plaxo, they were ready hunt the designers of the service down like rats on the tundra.

title: Learning to Walk the Tracks
description: After a series of fatal accidents in the New York City subway, the transit authority has stepped up its safety training.

title: For One Analyst, Facebook Is a Screaming Buy
description: The main thing about Facebook, Pali Research analyst Richard Greenfield wants to make clear, is that it is not just for college students  if you have not signed up or have not used it lately, you should. And if you are a big media company, he has another piece of advice: Buy the company.

title: Petitioners Urge the Mayor to Run
description: A Draft Michael Bloomberg rally on the steps of City Hall this morning drew more journalists than the dozen or so volunteers who are hitting the streets today to collect signatures on unofficial petitions to urge the mayor to run for president. The event started just as Mr. Bloomberg wrapped up his weekly radio call-in program on WABC-AM, in which he told the host, John Gambling, Im not going to be president. (Interestingly, the statewide organizer of the petition drive is a WABC producer, Frank Morano).

title: 500 Tons of Subway Cars, One Foot Away
description: After two New York City Transit workers were killed in April in separate incidents, the agencys new president, Howard H. Roberts Jr., on April 29 ordered an immediate suspension of track work. The suspension was lifted on May 4; less than two weeks later, on May 17, the agency announced a series of safety initiatives. Investigations are still continuing.

title: Bear Stearns Sets $3.2 Billion Rescue for Hedge Fund
description: Moving to placate lenders and stabilize what has become an embarrassing situation for the investment bank, Bear Stearns said Friday that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds. Bloomberg News described the loan as the biggest bailout since 1998; The New York Times said it was a tacit acknowledgment that Bears portfolio managers made brash bets on a mortgage market that has been jarred by a rising delinquencies and foreclosures.

title: Karjakin, the Youngest Player, Leads Super Strong Tournament
description: A tournament in Foros, Ukraine, a town not far away from Yalta on the Crimean Peninsula, has attracted some of the worlds best players. The tournament, sponsored by Aerosvit Ukrainian Airlines, began June 17 and runs through the end of the month. Among the participants are Peter Svidler of Russia, ranked No. 9 in the world, Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine, No. 12, Dmitry Jakovenko of Russia, No. 18, and Alexander Onischuk, tied for 39, who is originally from Ukraine but is now a United States citizen and was the 2006 U.S. champion.

title: Backing Obama, Without a Blessing
description: Supporters of Senator Barack Obamas Democratic presidential primary campaign have formed one of the first independent organizations dedicated to supporting a 2008 presidential hopeful, overlooking their candidates past criticisms of the legal status of such groups.

title: Bill Would Raise Taxes on Carried Interest
description: Congress challenged the private equity industry on a major new front Friday afternoon, when 14 Democrats from the U.S. House of Representatives introduced a bill that would raise taxes on carried interest.

title: Winning the Gingerbread Wars
description: Alison was absolutely right when she identified the three big questions we still needed to answer before we could move forward: How much would this dream home cost? Were there logistical hurdles (like unavailable contractors)? Would our notoriously picky town approve what we wanted to do?

title: Whose Red Room Is It Anyway?
description: The acrimony between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno  with each saying the other is to blame for the many failed deals in the waning days of the legislative session  has taken a new turn.

title: Blackstones First-Day Poplet
description: After months of hype, hoopla and controversy, reviews of Blackstone Groups actual market debut appear to be a little like that Peggy Lee song, Is That All There Is? While the offering was clearly a success by most measures  it priced at the high end of the expected range at $31, opened 18 percent higher at $36.55 and recently traded at $35.95  the relatively modest jump seemed to leave many observers underwhelmed. The stock closed the day at $35.06.

title: SJP Follow-up: Labor and Costs
description: Of all the topics raised by the Sarah Jessica Parker interview, the one that stirred the most debate was how Steve & Barrys can deliver Bitten at such low prices, and does this mean the company employs sweat shops and other unethical manufacturing practices. The subject came up during my conversation with SJP at the store  and, according to Parker, she asked similar questions of Steve & Barrys during her due diligence. But since a lot of people on the blog are concerned about this issue, I decided to explore it further with Howard Schacter, the companys chief partnership officer, and we spoke this morning.

title: End of the road for Universal boss?
description: The S.E.C. has asked a federal judge to appoint a receiver to take control of Universal Express, the subject of my column today.

title: Leaving the Congo
description: I never thought I would be so happy to leave the Congo. Goma never felt right to me; in fact, the more days I spent walking along the dark gray lava-covered ground, being stared at by suspicious and glaring eyes, the more tense and anxious I became. Like Will, I was relieved to return to the oasis of our hotel every night.

title: Perceivers, Not Deciders
description: Readers respond to David Brookss June 22 column, When Preaching Flops.

title: Indias $2,500 Car
description: Lets talk cheap cars. Very cheap cars. Nissan announced yesterday that its thinking of building a $3,000 car for India  which might have sounded inexpensive, if only Tata Motors, an Indian automaker, hadnt announced plans for a $2,000 car earlier this month.

title: Wyoming Senator Appointed
description: A Republican state legislator, John Barrasso, is the new United States Senator from Wyoming. The states governor, Dave Freudenthal, appointed him to the post today, filling a vacancy created by the death of Senator Craig Thomas earlier this month.

title: Reports From the Police Shack
description: Since the early 1990s, New York City has experienced a remarkable overall decline in crime, such that many New Yorkers take public safety almost for granted, pausing, perhaps, only when a particularly gruesome crime grabs newspaper headlines or airtime on the television news. But every day, the New York Police Department issues terse news releases, including reports of homicides; descriptions of suspects wanted for questioning; names and descriptions of missing individuals; and notifications when city employees have been arrested  among other things. We thought wed share some from the week.These notices  the sheets in cop shop jargon  are provided to journalists, including reporters at 1 Police Plaza, the headquarters of the Police Department, who work out of a set of offices known by tradition as The Shack.

title: The Lesser-Known Islands of New York
description: Answers Revealed, noon, June 28

title: My Boss
description: sent me the link to this video today. I like it.

title: A Victim of Equity Stripping
description: A Chicago woman who fell behind on her mortgage payments became a victim of a common fraud known as equity stripping.

title: Win a Trip: A Boat Out of Congo
description: Will Okun, who is traveling with Nicholas D. Kristof in Africa, takes a high-speed ferry as part of his journey to Burundi.

title: Cinderella Motel
description: Collier Schorr goes inside the arena with rodeo cowboys.

title: Cheney Rules
Simplicity
description: Im sitting on a curb along the edge of the parking lot next to the gym with two duffle bags, a ruck sack, the M249 and a 9mm strapped to my leg. It is hard to believe that all of my personal possessions for the next year can be hand carried.

title: Vows: Hildy and Jarrod
description: For Hildy Kuryk and Jarrod Bernstein, teasing at a political fund-raiser and a shared love of New York City led to romance.

title: As American as Nachos, Maple Syrup and Sushi
description: What does Made in America mean, especially in todays automobile industry?

title: Bobby Richardsons Capper to the 62 Series
description: Bobby Richardson saw his picture in The New York Times yesterday, and he had to tell the story behind it.

title: Freedom? Were Talking Money Here
description: When governments around the world censor the Internet  by which we mean restricting the sites their citizens can visit and the content they can see  it clearly has an impact on freedom of speech and of information.

title: For Candidates, Fund-Raising Drives the Weekend
description: Most of the leading candidates for president are staying out of the heavily traveled primary states of Iowa and New Hampshire this weekend, and fanning out across the country to court voters and donors.

title: Baby Hawks Distinguished Ancestry Is Now Acknowledged
description: So it turns out that Ziggy, the 7-week-old baby red-tailed hawk that fell from its Seventh Avenue nest and crashed near the Ziegfeld Theater on West 55th Street last week, might be related to Pale Male  one of New York Citys most famous avian residents  after all.

title: A Wii Bit of Violence in Manhunt 2
description: Its all very nice that you can use the nifty wireless remote control of Nintendos Wii machine to swing a gulf club or a tennis racket. But what do you thing gamers really want to wave around?

title: Friends Again, Sort of . . .
description: The Boston standoff between Google and eBay appears to be over. The result of the confrontation: only minor scrapes and bruises for Google.

title: Mules
description: Alice Walker observed, Black women are the mules of the world. Traveling across the poor African country of Burundi, we see women doing the majority of the hard fieldwork and, of course, all of the labor in the home.

title: Waiting for the Punchline
description: See if you spot the humor in all this.

title: Weekend Project: Build a TV-Lift Cabinet
description: The weekend is about to begin. Get out your power saw and tool belt.

title: Obama's Volunteer Push
description: Brooklyn supporters of Senator Barack Obama took their enthusiasm to the streets as part of a nationwide effort by the campaign.

title: Adjust Your Volume
description: I do television so I can get to New York the English chef Gordon Ramsay told Bill Buford of The New Yorker last fall as he was about to open Gordon Ramsay at the London, his first restaurant in the States. I prostitute myself so I can have a restaurant here.

title: Mike Wallace: Potters Fields, Grand Central, Overlooked Sites
description: Here is the last installment from Mike Wallace, the historian and co-author of Gotham, who answered reader questions this week. We would like to extend our thanks to Dr. Wallace for his patience in helping us start up this new feature and also to all the readers who participated. The next person taking questions will be Janette Sadik-Khan, the new city transportation commissioner.

title: Enterprise 2.0 Agnostic
description: The Enterprise 2.0 bandwagon seems well underway, with the latest sign being a well-sponsored and well-attended three-day conference in Boston this week.

title: Popular But Poor on Facebook
description: Its been just a month since Facebook started letting outside programmers add new applications to its service, but its already hard to imagine the site without them. Thousands of developers have jumped in, lured by the prospect of fun, fame and fortune.

title: A Long Line for a Shorter Wait
description: For its first stores in Manhattan, Whole Foods, the gourmet supermarket, directs customers to form serpentine single lines that feed into a passel of cash registers.

title: Chirac Refuses to Testify in French Dirty Tricks Case
description: PARIS, June 23  Having lost the immunity that protected him from prosecution while in office, Jacques Chirac, the former French president, has refused to testify in a political dirty tricks scandal that sought to discredit Nicolas Sarkozy, the current president.

title: The Low-Profile Westport River Offers a High Yield of Fish
description: The darkening sky and the damp wind blowing upriver showed no signs of abating. The forecast from the night before promised clearing skies and temperatures in the mid-60s, but the day dawned with mist, fog and a fine, cold drizzle. For an angler in coastal New England, sometimes May and June can be the cruelest months.

title: Safety Group Proposes 3rd Stairwell in High Rises
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Skyscraper safety requirements proposed after the World Trade Center attacks on Sept. 11 have been adopted by the pre-eminent building code group. That means tall buildings nationwide could soon be required to be designed with an extra emergency stairwell and more robust fireproofing.

title: Day of Grief in New Jersey After Violence Claims 3 Lives
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 22  It was hardly a new path that Thomas Reilly traced from his native Ireland to northern New Jersey, where after two decades of hope and hard work his immigrant aspirations had seemingly been fulfilled. He was a successful business owner. He had married. He had two adorable daughters.

title: Water Woes in Irish City Are Downside of Growth
description: GALWAY, Ireland  For Breda and Mike Guilfoyle, surveying the containers of boiled water on the kitchen tops of their bed and breakfast inn here, the jokes about polluted drinking water have worn thin. They worry that visitors will stay away from Galway, western Irelands premier tourist city, this summer.

title: C.I.A. Chief Tries Preaching a Culture of More Openness
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  William E. Colby faced an uneasy decision in late 1973 when he took over the Central Intelligence Agency: whether to make public the agencys internal accounting, then being compiled, of its domestic spying, assassination plots and other misdeeds since its founding nearly three decades earlier.

title: Baseballs Japanese Roots Survive Test of Time and Will
description: Chitoshi Akizuki wasnt sure whether he would travel from San Jose to San Francisco this weekend to watch Hideki Matsui and the Yankees play the San Francisco Giants. But he will be there in spirit.

title: With Extra Rest, Glavine Breaks His Slump
description: The fans rose in unison as Tom Glavine walked toward the Mets dugout. He had thrown 110 pitches through eight brilliant innings, and it was time, they undoubtedly assumed, to salute him for a job well done. Glavine was looking at the ground. He did not acknowledge the applause because he knew something the fans did not. He was not finished yet.

title: Militants Said to Flee Before U.S. Offensive
description: BAGHDAD, June 22  The operational commander of troops battling to drive fighters with Al Qaeda from Baquba said Friday that 80 percent of the top Qaeda leaders in the city fled before the American-led offensive began earlier this week. He compared their flight with the escape of Qaeda leaders from Falluja ahead of an American offensive that recaptured that city in 2004.

title: Rockets Kill 9 in Pakistan Tribal Area
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 23  Nine people were killed in what officials here described as overnight rocket attacks from across the Afghan border in the Shawal area of the North Waziristan tribal region of Pakistan.

title: Homes Sell. Homes Dont Sell. Builders Still Build.
description: THE American housing market, as measured by home-building activity, is falling at the most rapid rate in decades, underscoring the pain felt by builders who were far too optimistic about the state of the market.

title: A Former Prospect on the Court Is Now Much Better at the Table
description: Back in 1979, I coached juniors  teenagers  at a European Bridge League training camp in Ghent, Belgium. Along with bridge, we held sporting events, including a tennis tournament. I was paired with a 14-year-old Dutch boy named Louk Verhees. He was a marvelous player and carried us singlehandedly to victory.

title: Tugboat Industry Is Experiencing a Revival
description: CLEVELAND, June 22  The latest sign of Americas tugboat building boom sits on a bank of the Cuyahoga River here. Shaped like a curved silver tongue, the steel hull of the Great Lakes Towing Companys first tugboat lies upside down in a brand-new factory.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend on June 15 about a deal between the Menier Chocolate Factory theater company in London and the producer Bob Boyett that gives Mr. Boyett first rights to transfer the companys shows to Broadway referred incompletely to the transfer of the companys revival of Sunday in the Park With George next winter. The Broadway revival will be a Roundabout Theater Company production. Boyett Ostar Productions, Mr. Boyetts producing partnership, will be an associate producer; it is not bringing over the revival by itself.

title: Is Made in China a Warning Label? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Truck Kills Cyclist in Bronx
description: A bicyclist was killed yesterday in the Baychester section of the Bronx by a truck that fled the scene, the police said.

title: North Korea Prepared to Shut Down Reactor, U.S. Envoy Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 22  The chief American nuclear envoy, returning from the first visit to North Korea by a ranking United States official in five years, said here Friday that Pyongyang had assured him it was ready to shut down its main nuclear reactor and would ultimately disable it.

title: Space Shuttle Lands in California Desert
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 22  The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a smooth landing on a dry desert lake bed here Friday, ending a two-week mission to the International Space Station that had turned somewhat dramatic after key computers broke down.

title: Breaking From Tradition in the Americas Cup
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 22  It has been an Americas Cup for breaking with convention. For the first time, yachtings premier competition is being staged in the Mediterranean. For the first time, there is no home team: The defender, Alinghi, picked Valencia as the site because Geneva, its base, was next to a lovely lake, but much too far from the requisite salt water.

title: A Liberal Explains His Rejection of Same-Sex Marriage
description: Could legalizing same-sex marriage actually strengthen marriage as a social institution? If I could believe this, writes David Blankenhorn, I would support gay marriage without reservation.

title: Mr. Spitzers First Round
description: New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer marched into the state Capitol in January like a new sheriff ready to clean out the saloon. Six months later, he has emerged from his first legislative session a bit tattered, a bit wiser, but with his high poll numbers intact. Mr. Spitzer may not have won the toughest battles he fought, but he has charted a clear path for where he wants to take the state. There is every reason to believe that if he sticks to it, he will eventually make significant improvements in how the publics business is done in New York State.

title: At White House, Renewed Debate on Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  The Bush administration acknowledged Friday that its top officials were once again actively debating recommendations about how and when to close the detention facilities at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, but officials said they thought it could be weeks or months before a decision was made.

title: A Need to Reach Out (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lifeline of Sorts to Newspapers
description: So I went to Chicago this week to see Sam Zell, the billionaire real estate mogul who not all that long ago sold one of his major holdings, Equity Office Properties Trust, to the Blackstone Group for $39 billion.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (Disney) THE SUITE LIFE OF ZACK & CODY The mischievous twins who live in a high-class hotel in Boston with their lounge-singing mother are graduating from middle school in this season premiere. Or perhaps only Cody (Cole Sprouse, above right), will receive a diploma, since Zack (Dylan Sprouse, above left) hears some bad news: summer school. But theres always the game room, swimming pool, room service and, of course, the candy counter run by Maddie (Ashley Tisdale) to help distract Zack from his troubles.

title: Its Anger, Not Nostalgia, at This Antioch Reunion
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 22  The messages have been flying through alumni chat rooms, sometimes 10 a minute, ever since Antioch University announced that it was closing, at least for now, the undergraduate college that once seemed the very symbol of the 1960s.

title: British High Court Wrestles With Symbol of Premarital Purity
description: LONDON, June 22  At a time of passionate debate over religious clothing and emblems, a 16-year-old member of an evangelical Christian movement protested in court on Friday because her school has refused to allow her to wear a so-called purity ring, symbolizing her commitment to premarital chastity.

title: A Homeless Mans Story (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brechts Take on Chicago: God Among Meatpackers
description: There are costly Manhattan kitchens that have not been designed with a quarter of the efficiency of Lear deBessonets production of St. Joan of the Stockyards. This infrequently seen Brecht play, now at Performance Space 122, imagines in this incarnation the fights between Christian principles and capitalism, labor and management, rich and poor as back-alley brawls from which there are no easy exits.

title: In His Memory, the Melodies Linger On
description: There were no fireworks on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse, where the JVC Jazz Festival presented We Remember Ruby, a tribute to the trumpeter and cornetist Ruby Braff. They werent needed.

title: Bravura Moves for an Old Crowd Pleaser
description: BECKET, Mass., June 21  Some ballets, alas, are fragile. Others, alack, are indestructible. I have often wished Petipas tutu-Spanish Don Quixote were more frail than it is: Its the kind of ballet-as-circus event that seldom turns into art, but its virtuosity and its musics razzmatazz are such that you can eliminate the title character and the plot, interleave individual dances from earlier acts into the grand pas de deux from Act III, cram it all onto a small stage to taped music, and still its Don Q, that whiz-bang crowd-pleaser.

title: Two Giants, but They Arent Twins
description: IT takes more than great technology to make a great technology company. Years after the millennium bubble burst, the lesson is still being learned  the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.

title: Damons Season Raises Questions and a Few Eyebrows
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22  When the Yankees signed Johnny Damon to a four-year, $52 million contract after the 2005 season, they did not consider it a risky deal. Damon had never been on the disabled list, and he had recently turned 32 years old.

title: New Ways to Do It Make Giving Away Books a Bit Less Painful
description: IT has been a long, sometimes painful process, but over the years, Ive learned to separate from my books.

title: The Streets Where the Average Age of a Prostitute Is 14
description: For her second documentary under the Who Cares About Girls? banner, the globetrotting journalist Lisa Ling takes on child prostitution. Slave Girls of India, to be shown on the Oxygen channel tomorrow night, has all the elements you might expect from the combustible combination of Ms. Ling and a story about suffering and injustice: hidden cameras, horrifying statistics and emotional close-ups, many of Ms. Ling herself.

title: Quartet Meeting Set for Jerusalem
description: Diplomats from the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations  what is known as the quartet  will meet Tuesday in Jerusalem, a day after Israeli and Palestinian leaders meet with leaders of Egypt and Jordan at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheik, Russian, Israeli and United Nations officials said. Both meetings are being held to discuss the impact of the seizure of power in the Gaza Strip by Hamas on the region and on the Israeli-Palestinian relationship. At the meeting in Egypt, Israel is expected to offer to release to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and his new Fatah-led emergency government much of the Palestinian tax money it refused to pass on to a Hamas-led government.

title: Illegal Lofts Get New Scrutiny After a Firefighters Death
description: The former sewing factory at 83 Meserole Street in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is like hundreds of other buildings in the industrial precincts of Brooklyn  a hulking, century-old brick box lined with big windows, its insides turned into lofts inhabited by designers, musicians and other practitioners of the hipster professions. That the apartment conversions are illegal is usually of little consequence to anyone, including the authorities.

title: Champions Take Different Path to Finals
description: OMAHA, June 22  The noonday sun in eastern Nebraska bakes the grass and the people this time of year, but Oregon State catcher Mitch Canham walked around Rosenblatt Stadium with a bounce in his step.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the new Wellcome Collection museum in London referred imprecisely to the work of the Nobel Prize winner James D. Watson, who led the inaugural ceremony. He was a discoverer of the structure of DNA, not of DNA itself.

title: Sorkin to Broadway
description: Aaron Sorkin, who created the television shows The West Wing and Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip, will return to Broadway this fall with The Farnsworth Invention, Playbill reported. Citing a casting notice, Playbill said that Dodger Theatricals would produce the play, tentatively scheduled to open on Nov. 18, and Des McAnuff would direct. The Farnsworth Invention concerns the battle over patent rights to the television set, which pitted the inventor Philo T. Farnsworth against David Sarnoff, who ran the Radio Corporation of America. The play was given a workshop production at the La Jolla Playhouse, in San Diego in February and March. Mr. Sorkins play A Few Good Men opened on Broadway at the Music Box Theater Nov. 15, 1989.

title: For Women, a Recipe to Create a Successful Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One morning in May, Veronica Salazar stuffed refried beans into sandal-shaped masa cakes, concentrating to block the commotion in a cavernous kitchen here in the Mission District. The chopping of vegetables added to the din as the clang of metal pans against stainless steel equipment competed with background music from a local Spanish-language radio station.

title: The Fall of Mr. Smalls Empire
description: This week we have gotten a deeply troubling glimpse into the reign of Lawrence Small, who headed up the Smithsonian Institution from 2000 until resigning in March. A stinging new report by an independent review committee concludes that the Smithsonian is in a governance crisis largely caused by Mr. Smalls self-isolating and secretive management style. The problem does not stop with Mr. Small. The Smithsonian, it says, also suffers from antiquated methods of governance and a Board of Regents that appears to have played a largely ceremonial  and lackadaisical  role.

title: China Tries to Contain Scandal Over Slave Labor With Arrests and Apology
description: BEIJING, June 22  Chinese authorities moved to contain a widening slave labor scandal with an apology from a provincial governor for abuses that have shocked the country, and the arrest of two labor officials, state news media said Friday.

title: ABC and NBC End Race to Interview Paris Hilton
description: After a flurry of accounts this week about financial offers to land the first postprison interview with Paris Hilton, both ABC and NBC said yesterday that they no longer had any interest in securing the interview.

title: Yoga, Cocoons and Pots, but No Kitchen Sink
description: Perhaps others will be quicker off the mark, but I had to read the title of Donna Scro Gentile Freespace Dances ConTainMeiNiT, which opened on Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop, two or three times before I caught on. The simultaneous mawkish cuteness and vagueness of this sentiment were a warning sign.

title: Stuffing Tortillas and Parkgoers, Dawn to Dusk
description: On the concrete floor of a garage turned kitchen, behind a curtain stamped in lavender and green, was a freezer as tall as a man, as long as a car and as wide as a love seat. Inside was a pile of cardboard boxes stuffed with lettuce, tomatoes and cactus leaf nopales, a Mexican delicacy. The coolers on the opposite end were packed with raw meat: 40 pounds of chicken, 60 pounds of chorizo, 300 pounds of pork, 1,000 pounds of beef.

title: Delphi and U.A.W. Reach Tentative Deal
description: DETROIT, June 22  The Delphi Corporation and its largest union reached a tentative wage-cutting agreement on Friday that the auto supplier called a significant milestone toward its emergence from bankruptcy protection.

title: Kindred Spirits, in Country and Beyond
description: Among other things, the current tour by Lyle Lovett and K. D. Lang presents a treatise on the nature of hunger. At Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, there were songs of lonesome discontent and insatiable desire, along with a cold, straightforward yearning. They came in many forms: as covers and originals, joke songs and deadly serious ones. At one point Mr. Lovett sang Keep It in Your Pantry, a lighthearted ode to more than one sort of appetite; Ms. Lang offered Constant Craving, one of her biggest hits.

title: Bonds Belts No. 749, but Yankees Prevail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22  Before Scott Proctor stared him down in the eighth inning on Friday, 441 pitchers had allowed home runs to Barry Bonds. Proctor, a small right-hander with a big fastball, thrives on a challenge. With a four-run lead on Friday night, this was the perfect time.

title: Tempers Flare as Discussions on Big Ten Network Heat Up
description: The Big Ten is angry at Comcast. And Comcast is angry at the Big Ten.

title: S.E.C. Requests Receiver for Universal Express
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, stating that Universal Express appears to exist primarily as a vehicle for fraud, has asked a federal judge to appoint a receiver to take control of it. Universal Express is a penny stock company that has sold billions of unregistered shares to the public.

title: Marshall D. Shulman, 91, Dies; Expert on Soviet Union
description: Marshall D. Shulman, who devoted his life to understanding the Soviet Union as a leading scholar, a policymaker and a principal builder of Columbia Universitys Russian studies program, died on Thursday at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 91, meaning that he was born before the Soviet Union and outlived it.

title: Mileage Vote Reveals New Configuration in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Automakers had to know they were in serious trouble when Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat with deep blue-collar roots, announced that she had lost patience with their annual objections to higher gas mileage rules.

title: Chavez Backs Giambis Decision
description: Eric Chavez revered Jason Giambi when they were teammates on the Oakland Athletics. Chavez loved how Giambi respected people, whether he was interacting with an All-Star or a bat boy. Chavez loved how Giambi prepared for games, a dose of intensity mixed with a dash of playfulness.

title: The Fight Against Malaria (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture, Taken Apart With Pen and Ink
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  David Macaulay could be called the Mr. Wizard of architectural history. In 23 books over three decades, his arresting pen-and-ink illustrations have explored everything from the construction of ancient pyramids to the subterranean systems that support a modern metropolis.

title: $3.2 Billion Move by Bear Stearns to Rescue Fund
description: Bear Stearns Companies, the investment bank, pledged up to $3.2 billion in loans yesterday to bail out one of its hedge funds that was collapsing because of bad bets on subprime mortgages.

title: These Tour Guides Know the History Not Found on Plaques
description: Jennifer Nugent Duffy stood in the middle of Central Park, clutching a clipboard, and talked about what was no longer there.

title: Footnotes
description: The British band The Cure, featuring the singer Robert Smith, below, announced plans for an American tour, starting on Sept. 13 in Tampa, Fla. The band is finishing work on its first album of new music since 2004, which is to be released this fall. ... With Hollywood in the hunt for the next Harry Potter-style franchise, DreamWorks Studios has bought the film rights to the childrens book series Children of the Lamp, by P. B. Kerr. The popular series, whose fourth title is due out in September, follows the adventures of a family who pass for human but have the power to grant wishes. ... The New York Philharmonic has received a gift of $5 million from Didi and Oscar S. Schafer in support of the orchestras Concerts in the Parks, which take place each July in the metropolitan area. The gift provides $1 million annually over the next five years, with the series to be known as the New York Philharmonic Concerts in the Parks, presented by Didi and Oscar Schafer.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a warehouse fire that killed nine firefighters in Charleston, S.C., misspelled the surname of a man who was rescued from the building. He is Jonathan Tyrrell III, not Tyrell. (Go to Article)

title: Masked Man for As? Why, Its Mike Piazza
description: Mike Piazza signed with the Oakland Athletics in the off-season expecting a diminished workload. He was expecting to march to the plate about four times a game, hit the ball and sit down to watch someone else strap on the shin guards and chest protector.

title: World View Podcast
description: Greg Winter and Jeffrey Gettleman discuss Ethiopia.

title: Kentucky: Amusement Park Ride Cuts Off Girls Feet
description: The Superman Tower of Power ride at Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom outside Louisville malfunctioned Thursday, severing both feet of a 13-year-old girl, state safety officials and a park spokeswoman said. As patrons of the ride hurtled toward the ground at more than 50 miles per hour, a frayed cable snapped and cut off the girls feet, said Bill Clary, a spokesman for the Kentucky Division of Regulation and Inspection. The ride was immediately shut down, as were similar rides at three other Six Flags parks, said the Six Flags spokeswoman, Wendy Goldberg. Mr. Clary said inspectors would remain on the scene until they understood what had happened and how to ensure that it not happen again.

title: Manhunt 2 Too Violent
description: Take-Two Interactive Software said late Thursday that it had suspended plans to release its game Manhunt 2 next month. Earlier this week the British Board of Film Classification refused to issue a rating for the game, citing its extreme violence. That decision made it illegal to sell the game in Britain. In the United States, the Electronic Software Rating Board, an independent industry group, has informed Take-Two that it intends to give the game an Adults Only rating. The game was to be released for Nintendos Wii and Sonys PlayStation 2, but those companies have said that they will not allow Adults Only-rated games on their systems. Major retailers, including Wal-Mart, also refuse to sell games with that rating. Take-Two now must choose whether to scrap the game or to remove some violent content in the hopes of securing a rating of M for Mature. SETH SCHIESEL

title: Once More With Feeling: A Really Senior Prom
description: Robert Roane escorted Gretta Cohen to the senior prom on Thursday night.

title: Finding Inspiration in an Unlikely Place
description: A couple of decades ago, opera composers began finding inspiration in newspaper headlines, a trend that opera fans and critics have debated vigorously. It brought the immediacy of current issues to the opera stage, but the transformation into opera sometimes trivialized those issues.

title: Obama Says New Rules Would Guide His Administration
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Senator Barack Obama said on Friday that if elected president, he would impose new lobbying restrictions on members of his administration and seek to end a system of no-bid contracts that he says is riddled by abuse.

title: New Jersey Decides Its Toll Road Plan Still Needs Time
description: For the better part of a year, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has promised to produce a plan to solve some of New Jerseys fiscal difficulties by raising billions of dollars through the leasing of the states biggest toll roads.

title: Is This the End of Harry, on the Web?
description: A self-proclaimed hacker says that he broke into the computers of the British publisher of the hugely successful Harry Potter series and discovered the feverishly awaited climax to the coming seventh and final installment. But his disclosures were met with skepticism this week.

title: Wyoming: Senator Named to Fill Vacancy
description: John Barrasso, a Republican state legislator and an orthopedic surgeon, was appointed by Gov. Dave Freudenthal to replace Senator Craig Thomas, who died June 4. Mr. Barrasso, 54, a two-term state senator, was one of three contenders whose names had been submitted to the governor by the Wyoming Republican Party. The governor, a Democrat, was required under Wyoming law to select a candidate from the same party as Mr. Thomas, a Republican. Mr. Barrassos appointment takes effect immediately. Although Mr. Thomass term was set to end in 2012, Mr. Barrasso will face a special election in 2008 to keep the interim Senate seat. He has indicated that he intends to run.

title: A Concert for King
description: Stevie Wonder, Aretha Franklin and Carlos Santana said on Thursday that they would participate in a concert to raise money to build a memorial to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the National Mall in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Quincy Jones, Russell Simmons and Tommy Hilfiger are organizing the so-called Dream Concert, set for Sept. 18 at Radio City Music Hall. Other scheduled performers include Robin Thicke, Bebe Winans, Cece Winans and Jessye Norman, with Al Roker to appear as a presenter. The foundation working to build the memorial has raised $79.5 million of the $100 million needed to complete and maintain it. The memorial will occupy a space on the Tidal Basin between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials.

title: Grass to Read in New York
description: Gnter Grass, the Nobel Prize-winning German writer, will give his first reading in the United States of his memoir, Peeling the Onion, at the 92nd Street Y Unterberg Poetry Center on Monday evening at 8. Mr. Grass, 79, will read passages in German, and the actor Michael Stuhlbarg will read them in English. Afterward, the Israeli writer and journalist Amos Elon will interview Mr. Grass, who came under fire last year for his belated admission that he had served in Hitlers elite Waffen-SS, despite having long claimed to have been an ordinary soldier. Some critics accused Mr. Grass of making the revelation at that time in hopes that it would increase the sales of his memoir. The English translation of the book is being published in the United States this month.

title: France: Immigration Ministry Draws Fire
description: More than 3,000 people, among them French and American intellectuals, anthropologists and social scholars, have signed an online petition protesting Frances new Ministry of Immigration, Integration, National Identity and Co-development. The petition, from the Internet-based research center terra.rezo.net, which focuses on issues related to migration, objects to the very idea of the ministry, saying that even its name could foster governmental xenophobia leading to stigmatize the foreigner as a problem, a risk, and possibly a threat to integrity or national identity.

title: Athena Comes Home
description: Athena Comes Home

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The TV Sports column yesterday, about coverage of the Tour de France by the cable network Versus amid the doping scandals in cycling, misstated the surname of a race commentator in some copies. He is Paul Sherwen, not Sherwood.

title: Signs of Energy
description: The Senate passed an energy bill on Thursday night that could make a constructive, if modest, contribution toward reducing this countrys greenhouse gas emissions and its dependence on foreign oil. Given the resistance of industry and the troubled history of previous energy bills, that is encouraging news. But its still only a start.

title: All-Day Festival of Sounds, From African to Operatic
description: An unsuspecting passerby wandering down Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village on Thursday evening would have been surprised to hear pulsating waves of sound from a large, eclectic orchestra massed in the middle of the street.

title: Lottery Numbers
Tech Missionary Shifts Focus
description: HIS ideas and opinions aside, nobody has done more than Lawrence Lessig to help people understand the profound effects of technology on the laws governing intellectual property. He is, as Wired magazine called him in 2002, the Elvis of cyberlaw (wired.com).

title: Bear Stearns to Bail Out Troubled Fund
description: Bear Stearns, the investment bank, said today that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds operated by its asset-management business, in an effort to placate lenders and investors.

title: Delphi and U.A.W. Reach Tentative Accord
description: DETROIT, June 22  The Delphi Corporation, the big auto supplier, reached a tentative agreement today with its unionized workers that will help it emerge from bankruptcy protection by cutting wages and benefits.

title: Norman Hackerman, 95, Chemist and Former University President, Is Dead
description: Norman Hackerman, a noted chemist and a former president of both the University of Texas at Austin and Rice University, died June 16 in Temple, Tex. He was 95 and lived in Austin.

title: Second Victim of Flash Flood Is Found in the Catskills
description: COLCHESTER, N.Y., June 22  Emergency workers on Friday found the body of an elderly woman killed in Tuesdays flash flood, and are still scouring the ravaged banks of a brook that overflowed for two other missing women, the authorities said.

title: Wimbledon Field Falls Into Place
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 22  Witnessing the draw at Wimbledon feels like an hour at the bingo parlor. Blank grids are distributed. Coins with numbers, each representing a player in the field, are drawn from a basket. A man at a microphone calls out the results, and onlookers quietly fill in the blank spots. A screen on the wall tracks it all.

description: After months of hype, hoopla and controversy, the Blackstone Group went public yesterday, and with it, lost its private equity moniker.

description: The Associated Press has become the second news organization in a month to file a motion asking a federal judge to make public the names of baseball players linked to performance-enhancing drugs in government documents.

title: AT&T Hoping the iPhone Has Coattails
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22  When the iPhone goes on sale next Friday, people are likely to flood AT&T Wireless and Apple stores to check out the new device. But will the curiosity translate into big business for AT&T?

description: David E. I. Pyott, 53, became president and chief executive of Allergan in 1998 after spending his earlier management career in the nutrition subsidiaries of Novartis and Sandoz. The stock stood at $15.74 and the company was best known for its contact lens care solutions.

description: NEW HAVEN, June 22  It seems entirely blasphemous to open a review of Americas oldest dance company by commenting on something other than the choreography. But thank heavens for the Yale School of Music.

description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 22  The space shuttle Atlantis glided to a smooth landing on a desert dry lake bed here Friday, ending a two-week mission to the International Space Station that had turned somewhat dramatic after key computers broke down.

title: Lowering Flag for Wars Dead Brings a New Rift
description: IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., June 19  The Stars and Stripes in front of the Veterans of Foreign Wars lodge here flies at half-staff because Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm issued a statewide order to lower the flag for 24 hours to honor a Michigan soldier killed in Iraq.

description: Classical music no longer relevant? Tell it to the families, comrades and friends of the nine firefighters who died in a blaze that swept through a furniture warehouse in Charleston, S.C., on Monday evening. Or, for that matter, to the hundreds of thousands who saw the opening of the memorial service held yesterday in the North Charleston Coliseum on CNN.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about a decision by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to quit the Republican Party  an announcement that further fueled speculation about his plans for a presidential run in 2008  referred imprecisely in some copies to a constitutional requirement for presidential candidates. The Constitution says only that the president must be a natural-born citizen, not that the president must have been born in the United States. The provision is generally regarded as barring naturalized citizens, not those born elsewhere to American parents.

title: Guy Vander Jagt, 75, Long a Leader Within House G.O.P., Dies
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Guy Vander Jagt, a former congressman from Michigan and prolific fund-raiser and campaigner in nearly two decades as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, died Friday. He was 75 and lived in Great Falls, Va., outside Washington.

title: Yet Another Plan for Bell Canada, This One a Recapitalization
description: OTTAWA, June 22  A Toronto-based investment banking firm proposed recapitalizing Bell Canada on Friday as an alternative to the three competing privatization offers and one takeover bid for the company.

title: From Tibet to New York, a Youth Now Faces a Long Journey to Recovery
description: Gonpo Dorjee, 16, arrived in America on May 26. But he has seen little of his new home, New York City. The sights he sees most often are a small swath of the East River and part of the industrial skyline of Greenpoint, Brooklyn  the view from the window of his room at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan.

title: At Talks on Europes Charter, a Crisis Averted, for Now
description: BRUSSELS, Saturday, June 23  Europes leaders averted a crisis on Saturday after Poland stepped back from a dramatic threat to veto a treaty to replace the European Unions defunct constitution.

title: German Officials Report Increased Threat of Terrorist Attacks
description: FRANKFURT, June 22  Germany faces a heightened threat of terrorist attacks because of its military involvement in Afghanistan, government security officials here said Friday. The danger level, they warned, was comparable to the months before the 9/11 attacks in the United States.

title: Afghans Say NATO Airstrike Killed at Least 25 Civilians in the South
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 22  At least 25 civilians, including nine women, three infants and an elderly village mullah, were killed in an airstrike early Friday morning when they were caught in a battle between Taliban and NATO forces in southern Afghanistan, the police chief of Helmand Province said.

title: Moscow Presses BP to Sell a Big Gas Field to Gazprom
description: MOSCOW, June 22  Under pressure from the Russian government, BP agreed on Friday to sell one of the worlds largest natural gas fields to Gazprom, the natural gas monopoly, in the latest apparently forced sale that benefited a Russian state company.

title: Latest Plan From Dow Jones Is Said to Frustrate Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch was surprised and frustrated yesterday upon seeing a Dow Jones & Company plan to keep him from controlling the content of The Wall Street Journal if the company accepts his $5 billion takeover offer, according to people close to him.

title: A Mayor Often Ill at Ease, and Usually Muted on Iraq
description: The mayors lips are pursed. The tuxedo-and-gown dinner crowd in the Pierre hotel ballroom has fallen still, just a few spoons rattling along the rims of dessert plates. At the very front of the room, the spotlight has settled on Michael R. Bloomberg. Someone is reading an award citation for his work as mayor. Mr. Bloomberg oscillates. He bounces on his toes, nods his head. His eyes appear to be pinned open. Though he has not uttered a word, Mr. Bloombergs body seems to all but scream: Get me out of here.

title: Clooney Protests
description: George Clooney, who owns a villa in the small town of Laglio, on the shores of Lake Como, below, is urging his neighbors to sign a petition against further development there, BBC News reported yesterday. Laglios mayor wants to spend $15 million to build a large parking facility and a pontoon bridge that would pass in front of Mr. Clooneys home. Mr. Clooney is threatening to leave the town, whose population is about 900, if the plans proceed. He came to Laglio in 2002, and since then his presence has attracted an increasing number of tourists to the area. I dont want my presence here affecting the local population, Mr. Clooney said at a meeting of the Laglio protest committee last week. The building work is only being done because I live here. And unless it stops Im going to have to move.

title: Bill Is Offered to Increase Tax on Private Equity
description: Interest on Capitol Hill in raising taxes on private equity and hedge fund managers reached a peak yesterday as leading Democrats introduced a bill that would more than double taxes on most of the income earned by partnerships, including private equity managers, venture capitalists and some hedge funds.

description: It was just an organizational meeting for Senator Barack Obamas New York volunteers, but the gathering this month jammed every pew of a church in the East Village, and the crowd spilled over into not one but two overflow rooms.

title: U.S. Group Says Pakistan Is Building New Reactor
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 22  Pakistan is building a third plutonium production reactor at a major nuclear weapons center, a sign of plans to increase the nations nuclear arsenal significantly, a Washington group specializing in nuclear issues said Friday.

title: Reserve Officer Criticizes Process of Identifying Enemy Combatants at Guantnamo
description: The military hearings used to decide whether to hold Guantnamo detainees relied on incomplete and outdated information, screened by officers who were under intense pressure from their commanders to conclude that the detainees should be held, a reserve military intelligence officer and lawyer who had a role in the process said in an affidavit filed yesterday in a federal appeals court.

title: At Odds With Suffolk Leader, Lawmakers Block a Tax Bill
description: ALBANY, June 22  In a rare legislative rebellion on the floor of the State Assembly, a group of black and Hispanic Democratic lawmakers have blocked a sales tax bill that would have provided millions of dollars in revenue to Suffolk County. They called the move a statement against the stringent immigration policies held by the county executive, Steve Levy.

title: Singing, Dancing, Stamina: The Work of Pop Stardom
description: Would you love me if I didnt work out, or I didnt change my natural hair? It was Thursday night at Roseland Ballroom, and Stacy Ferguson  the pop star better known as Fergie  was singing those questions to the tune of Zoom, the old Commodores slow jam.

title: Influx From Zimbabwe to South Africa Tests Both
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 22  As Zimbabwes disintegration gathers potentially unstoppable momentum, a swelling tide of migrants is moving into neighboring South Africa, driven into exile by oppression, unemployment and inflation so relentless that many goods now double in price weekly.

title: Expensive Art
description: Damien Hirst became, for the moment, the worlds most expensive living artist on Thursday, when Sothebys sold his Lullaby Spring pill cabinet for 9.6 million ($19.3 million) in London, Reuters reported. The sale came just 24 hours after Lucian Freud had taken the title when his portrait Bruce Bernard sold at Christies for 7.9 million. The London auctions, which ended yesterday, took in a total expected to be near $1 billion. Christies said its auctions set records for 23 artists, including Joan Mir and Mr. Freud. Sothebys said it set records for artists including Henri Matisse, Tracey Emin and Frank Auerbach.

title: Library Repair Causes a Plea to the Pope
description: ROME, June 21  Normally a sanctuary of scholarly meditation, the Vatican Library has been the scene of unusually hectic activity lately, as word has spread that it will close in July for a three-year renovation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing in Weekend yesterday, about two musicals being performed this weekend by the Our Time Theater Company, misidentified the site. It is the Cherry Lane Theater, at 38 Commerce Street in the West Village  not the Theater Studio on East 24th Street in Manhattan, where the company was originally scheduled to perform.

title: Leaders in Deal on Europes Charter
description: BRUSSELS, Saturday, June 23  In a deal reached at 4:30 in the morning here, the leaders of the 27 members of the European Union agreed today to negotiate a treaty by the end of this year to replace the defunct constitution.

title: 8 U.S. Troops Killed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, June 23  Eight American servicemen and one British soldier were reported today to have been killed in Iraq, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 25 as insurgents continue to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles.

description: Lets be honest: Weve all done it. When no ones looking, in the privacy of our own home, vanity or curiosity (or a mix of the two) compels us to google ourselves.

description: After a flurry of accounts this week about financial offers to land the first post-prison interview with Paris Hilton, both ABC and NBC said today that they no longer had any interest in securing the interview.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22  The alliance between Barry Bonds and Alex Rodriguez was forged through shared experiences  home run trots, front-page controversies and lots and lots of booing.

He is Steve Chesney, not Hecht, and he is the fire chief of Roscoe, N.Y., not an assistant fire chief.

title: France: Eiffel Ticket Sellers Stole $940,000
description: Fifteen former ticket takers at the Eiffel Tower were given suspended prison sentences and fines for embezzling $940,000 from ticket sales. The company that manages the Eiffel Tower discovered the scam in February 2002 after receiving an anonymous letter from one of 27 employees at the ticket office.

title: A Group That Lives for Understatement
description: The huge catalog of jazz standards is a cozy, private place for the Keith Jarrett Trio, which returned to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. Mr. Jarrett on piano, Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums have been playing together for 24 years, Mr. Jarrett proudly announced onstage. In the concerts only overstated moment, he added, Every time we play is a historical event for me, and it should be for you, too.

title: Romney Aide Who Is Focus of Inquiries Goes on Leave
description: BOSTON, June 22  The director of operations of Mitt Romneys presidential campaign will be on a paid leave of absence while the authorities investigate accusations that he impersonated a state trooper in Massachusetts and told a reporter in New Hampshire that he had run the reporters license plate, the campaign said Friday.

title: Recanted Testimony Fails to Overturn Conviction in a 1991 Murder
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has denied the appeal of a man convicted of murder in 1992 on the strength of testimony from five eyewitnesses who later recanted under oath.

title: Dubai Government Buys Barneys for $825 Million
description: The clothing retailer Barneys New York, a temple to fashion that introduced Americans to Armani and $300 T-shirts, was sold yesterday to the investment arm of the Dubai government for $825 million.

title: Britain: Biggest Union Backs Israel Boycott
description: Britains largest labor union urged concerted and sustained pressure upon Israel, including an economic, cultural, academic and sporting boycott, to force its withdrawal from Palestinian areas. The union, called Unison and grouping 1.3 million public service employees, also called on the British government to oppose the sale of arms to Israel. The calls were made in a motion approved at Unisons annual conference in Brighton demanding the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza with its capital in Jerusalem The resolution followed similar calls for pressure on Israel from British labor unions representing journalists and college teachers. British and American Jewish organizations condemned the latest boycott call.

title: How Facebooks Mark Zuckerberg Shames Terry Semel
description: Terry Semel failed as Yahoos chief executive more than any other reason, of course, because he didnt respond properly to the challenge of Google. Mr. Semel passed on many opportunities simply to buy Google. And he was slow to understand Googles key business strategiesthe power of search, the money from search advertising, the enormous value in creating a network that sells ads on other Web sites, and the improbable power of running a big company like a collection of dorm room startups. Whats galling, of course, is that Yahoo was a leader in offering Web search and online advertising years before Google started.

When such places disappear, the culprit is often the turbulent cycles of the real estate market, which have a way of mercilessly washing away links to summers past. But for all the condos and McBeach Houses popping up along the coast, there are still plenty of spots to indulge in nostalgia at the Shore. Here are a few from a recent trip.

title: Lets Get Lost
description: Theres a moment in The Motel Life, Willy Vlautins downcast first novel, when the protagonist, dead drunk, is helping his dying brother use the toilet. This is the greatest feeling Ive ever had, the dying brother sighs, and by that point in the story, you believe him. The book is an unapologetic ode to self-defeat, a loose collection of deadpan cataclysms in which the most heartening episode revolves around the rescue of an undernourished dog. Its charm is unassuming, and a little clumsy at the outset, but Vlautins novel rewards the patient. At times its appeal is irresistible.

title: Fears That Nature Performed a Coup de Grce on Kansas Town
description: GREENSBURG, Kan.

title: The Mosquito Coast
description: Drive up to Crab Meadow Beach in Northport and you will pass a lovely little salt marsh. It looks pristine, particularly because it lacks phragmites reeds, the common, brutally invasive species whose presence is always a sign of corrupted terrain.

description: ALUM BAY, England  The fog is rolling in at the Needles, and so are the phantoms.

description: JERUSALEM, June 23  In the land of milk and honey, it is time for peanuts and hot dogs  the Israel Baseball League makes its debut Sunday night when the Petach Tikva Pioneers play host to the Modiin Miracle. A high demand for tickets has moved organizers to double the seating capacity at the Yarkon Sports Complex to accommodate a projected 2,000 spectators expected to attend.

title: Hussein Cousin Gets Death Sentence for Mass Killings
description: BAGHDAD, June 24  As the judge pronounced five death sentences on him on Sunday, the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali seemed a shadow of the merciless enforcer who oversaw poison gas attacks that killed thousands of Kurdish villagers in Iraqs northern uplands nearly 20 years ago.

title: With Jake Peavy
description: Jake Peavy (9-1), a 26-year-old right-hander for the San Diego Padres, leads the National League with 110 strikeouts and a 1.98 earned run average, and is tied with the Los Angeles Dodgers Brad Penny and Philadelphias Cole Hamels for the most victories. Peavy, Penny and Hamels are scheduled to pitch today.

title: A Brave New World for TV? Virtually
description: IF you can find him, Vincent Tibbett is precisely the sort of well-connected cultural liaison any emerging filmmaker should want to know. An employee of the Sundance Channel, he is as easily recognizable for his shaggy haircut and assertively casual attire as he is for the crowds of aspiring artists who follow him around, hoping to chat him up about cinematic trends, get him to evaluate their movies or simply score his e-mail address.

title: President? Or Kingmaker?
description: MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG of New York insisted yet again last week that he did not intend to run for president in 2008, even as he left the Republican Party to become an independent. Then, on Friday, he tweaked his language somewhat, simply saying, Im not going to be president.

title: 1949: Strawberry Tapioca Flamingo
description: In 1951, 1.5 million pounds of tapioca spilled into the East River when a pier holding a shipment from Brazil collapsed in the early morning hours. (The headline in The Times: Tapioca  la East River.)

title: Saving Coral Reefs Becomes a Tourism Priority
description: GREEN sea turtles, cascades of glittering reef fish, blooming coral pillars  countless travelers have come nose to nose with a thriving undersea universe while on vacation. But increasingly, divers and snorkelers are swimming over bleached hunks of coral devastated by shore runoff or overfishing.

title: Woody Allens Universe, Still Expanding, Is as Absurd as Ever
description: I keep wondering if there is an afterlife, and if there is will they be able to break a twenty? Woody Allen memorably wrote in Without Feathers. In the same collection, he lamented, Today I saw a red-and-yellow sunset and thought, How insignificant I am! Of course, I thought that yesterday, too, and it rained.

description: NEWARK, June 23  It started with a kiss.

title: When Computers Attack
description: ANYONE who follows technology or military affairs has heard the predictions for more than a decade. Cyberwar is coming. Although the long-announced, long-awaited computer-based conflict has yet to occur, the forecast grows more ominous with every telling: an onslaught is brought by a warring nation, backed by its brains and computing resources; banks and other businesses in the enemy states are destroyed; governments grind to a halt; telephones disconnect; the microchip-controlled Tickle Me Elmos will be transformed into unstoppable killing machines.

title: All the Race Data Sits in Your Hand
description: IN the last two decades, television coverage of auto racing has developed into a finely tuned presentation. Broadcasts routinely feature multiple camera angles, timing and pit stop information, interviews and even team-to-driver communications.

title: Dont Count on Running Into the Neighbors
description: THE gambrel-roofed Alstedes Country Market, set alongside rolling farmland on Morris County Route 513 in Chester Township, is more reminiscent of a toy barn than a working farm building. Kurt Alstede, who grows 200 crops on the 500 acres he farms here, ascribes his success to parents and grandparents who want to give children the experience of picking their own fruits and vegetables.

title: The Ordinary Reader
description: When I was 7, my grandfather recited the first poem I remember hearing, The Face on the Barroom Floor. He performed it with verve, winking a little at the figure he cut, his bald forehead gleaming as he circled around the kitchen, doing what he called the bear dance: his own brand of performance poetry. He also knew Casey at the Bat and many other popular poems. Until I read Joan Shelley Rubins Songs of Ourselves, Id always assumed this was a personal quirk, some inborn instinct to literature that belied his orphaned, hardscrabble youth spent working as an itinerant farm laborer and barber in the high plains of western Kansas.

title: Israel to Transfer Millions to Abbas to Bolster Him
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  Israel agreed today to transfer of hundreds of millions of dollars of Palestinian tax revenues to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, in an effort to support his new emergency government after the Muslim militants of Hamas seized control of Gaza 10 days ago.

description: BOSTON, June 23  Voice of the Faithful, the lay group formed in response to the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, is calling for the Vatican to review the requirement that priests be celibate, saying the policy may have played a role in the scandal.

title: Weddings/Celebrations; Nimet Habachy, Hussein Amin-Salem

Batts of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York will officiate in her chambers in Manhattan.

title: Sexy, Scary and Often Naked: Thats Acting!
description: WITHIN the hothouse atmosphere of last months Cannes Film Festival, the Italian actress Asia Argento was a weather system unto herself, creating pockets of turbulence wherever she went. Ms. Argento, whose first name is pronounced AH-zee-ah, is one of those rare actors whose mere presence instantly makes a movie less predictable. She had three films in the festival, and in each one, handily conquered scenes that would reduce most performers to nervous wrecks or laughingstocks.

title: Kathryn Orr, Austin Busbey
description: Kathryn Mary Orr, a daughter of Laurie Orr and Dennis P. Orr of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Austin Charles Busbey, a son of Frances Busbey and Maj. description: THIS story of police corruption begins in an unusual way, the anonymous narrator of Triple Homicide explains. It begins with a murder.

title: This Summer, Its Rock Around the Bloc
description: DESPITE recent events hinting at its resuscitation, the Cold War pretty much conked out for good 18 years ago. For music fans in the former Eastern bloc, the demise of the old regime brought about an unexpected benefit: the arrival of rock and techno music festivals on a huge scale previously reserved for May Day celebrations. More recently, Western festivalgoers have begun to take notice of these concerts, drawn not only by the acts, but also by the alluring ticket prices and the unfettered enthusiasm of the audience.

title: In a Rush Not to Hurry
description: ON an evening in early June, Emmy Rossum, the 20-year-old Hollywood actress, gathered a few friends in a recording studio near Times Square for an advance listen of her coming debut album.

title: Wright Caps a Perfect Day at the Ballpark
description: Last nights tense 1-0 Mets victory over the Oakland Athletics at Shea Stadium included the untimely ejection of Paul Lo Duca in a ferocious temper tantrum, excellent pitching by both starters and a game-winning double by David Wright in the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: It Takes a Tough Man to Tell a Bad Joke
description: IN the last few months Brad Paisley and Toby Keith, two of country musics biggest stars, have returned (if they ever left) to the place they call home: country radio. They have millions of fans and two very different reputations: Mr. Paisley excels at sweet love songs, while Mr. Keith is still best known as a pro-troop rabble-rouser. But neither one can resist a good joke  or, for that matter, a bad one. And this spring both of them came out cracking.

title: Open Space Rescue
description: Supporters of saving at least some of New Jerseys dwindling supply of open space and undeveloped land have won an important, but regrettably short-term, victory.

title: Sonorities of a Tenor Tuba and a Symphonic Saw
description: ODD things come out of the woodwork when you move offices, as The New York Times did recently. Among the items unearthed were a number of unusual, even bizarre CDs: a testament to humankinds ability to master the unlikeliest of instruments and to carve the classical music audience into the tiniest of niches. Hearing these CDs provided the thrill of listening to fantastically accomplished practitioners of the esoteric. Some are great musicians to boot. Here is a dogs breakfast of recordings saved from the movers purgatory.

title: Lee Urges Young Players to Carve Out a Niche on the Court
description: As a high school senior, David Lee was a high flyer who, like any teenager, loved the thrill and the theatrics of making highlight-reel dunks. He is now a burgeoning star for the Knicks because of a far more basic skill  rebounding.

title: A New Culture Takes Hold in an Old Fishing Town
description: IT is midday in Aveiro, a surprisingly cosmopolitan fishing town on northern Portugal's Rota da Luz, the Route of Light. The spring afternoon is sunny and warm, and the canals are filled with bobbing moliceiros, their bright prows upturned like jester's shoes. Tied up to docks for lunch, they are empty of fishermen and tourists; nearby, shopkeepers are itching to close up for siesta. Lining the canals, gorgeous Art Nouveau homes are sleepy in the sun, their half-closed shutters indicating lunch is on the table.

title: Alinghis Crew Begins Where It Left Off
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 23  For all those New Zealand fans who partied through the night in Port Americas Cup, then woke up hoping that Alinghis crew might suffer from rust or the jitters, it turned out to be a disappointing afternoon.

title: Weddings/Celebrations; Mindy Spire, Dana Spiegel
description: Mindy Spire and Dana Spiegel were married last evening at the Bacara Resort and Spa in Santa Barbara, Calif. Cantor Chayim Frenkel officiated.

description: A MOSQUITO in the bedroom is usually just a nuisance, but other insects can cause serious damage to the house itself. Termites are the first thing that comes to mind when you think of wood-destroying bugs, said Michael F. Potter, a professor of urban entomology at the University of Kentucky.

description: Le Mans, France

title: The Crowd Is Restless, but Maybe Thats a Good Sign
description: INVESTMENT newsletter editors are markedly less optimistic about the stock market now than they were late last year, when the Dow Jones industrial average was a thousand points lower. This suggests that the bull market may run a while longer, according to the market timing theory known as contrarian analysis.

title: The Stage Shifts to Federers Turf in the Battle for Supremacy
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23  It is Roger Federers tournament to lose, the expectation that comes with winning Wimbledon four times in a row. A fifth consecutive victory would match Bjorn Borgs modern mens record for consistency and put Federer two Wimbledon championships behind the career leaders, including Pete Sampras. It would also give Federer 11 Grand Slam titles, the same as Borg and three short of Samprass mark.

title: The U.S. Attorney Who Roared
description: TRENTON

title: Whose Orders?
description: In 1997, Saul Friedlnder published The Years of Persecution, 1933-1939, the first of his projected two-volume history of Nazi Germany and the Jews. In the introduction to that volume, he announced his intention of establishing a historical account of the Holocaust in which the policies of the perpetrators, the attitudes of surrounding society and the world of the victims could be addressed within an integrated framework. Such a framework has indeed been missing from most historical accounts of this most difficult and challenging of subjects. They have focused either on the processes of decision-making and their implementation or on the world of suffering and death experienced by the victims. Friedlnders first volume stood out from most other work in this field because it successfully combined both of these aspects. And his second volume does so as well. It now establishes itself as the standard historical work on Nazi Germanys mass murder of Europes Jews.

title: Subprime Fallout Could Hit Shares
description: THE long-scheduled meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers is a highlight of the calendar this week, but with no change in rates expected, investors may focus instead on subprime mortgages, where rates have been changing for the worse.

description: Sometimes the sun has smiled on New York Citys Young Republicans, an organization which helped elect the first Republican president, Abraham Lincoln, in 1860 and which was formally organized as a club in 1911.

title: Eight U.S. Soldiers Are Killed in Iraq Violence
description: BAGHDAD, June 23  Eight American servicemen were reported to have died in Iraq on Saturday, bringing the four-day death toll to at least 23 as insurgents continued to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles.

title: Schools Nearly Out, and Mr. Chips Is Thirsty
description: JUST after 4:30 p.m. on a sunny Friday, Matt Barnes and his friends were impatiently waiting for someone to let them into Moes, a neighborhood bar at Lafayette and Portland Avenues in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Up Front
description: The novelist Thomas McGuane, the author of this weeks cover review, is a talented but reluctant book critic. His last review in these pages appeared way back in 1993, when he assessed Thom Joness story collection The Pugilist at Rest. (That review began with these two sentences: Writers as good as Thom Jones appear but rarely. The original poetry of his fictional world is irresistible, and the sense that he knows this world absolutely has cleansed his prose and produced an affectless sheen.) So why doesnt McGuane review more often? I am aware of my responsibility to the author who deserves a fair report, and to the reader who is trying to make up his mind, he told us in an e-mail message. The divided mission can make reviewing painful and is probably why I dont do it more.

title: 36 Hours in Bali
description: SAY Bali and most people think paradise. There are stunning sunsets, sculpted rice terraces and a temple on almost every corner. And for less-spiritual seekers, this steamy Indonesian island also has great surfing and a rollicking nightlife. Sure, it's gotten pretty touristy, especially on the pub crawl along Kuta Beach, where beer-swilling Australians rule. And while recent terrorist bombings have rattled Bali's blissful pace (it is a Hindu-majority island in a Muslim-majority nation), they have done little to temper its popularity or discourage super-chic resorts from being built. Paradise, after all, is as close as the nearest temple, finding yourself on your knees with a blue flower pressed between your fingertips, asking for blessings from Brahma or one of the other gods.

title: Segue From Gigi to Geek-Chic Indie Rock
description: WHEN the piano rocker Ben Folds was invited to play the opening night of the Boston Pops this spring, the orchestra managers laid down a few ground rules: No swearing; avoid songs with risqu subject matter; dont comment on politics. This was supposed to be a gala evening of Champagne and hors doeuvres, not beer and groupies. They warned Mr. Folds that he would not be playing to his typical audience. But then, he said with a laugh, I get up there, and theres a fistfight.

title: Weddings/Celebrations; Sabrina Tanenbaum, Jonathan Strauss
description: Sabrina Gabrielle Tanenbaum, the daughter of Claudie Tanenbaum and Edward Tanenbaum of New York, is to be married this evening to Jonathan Aaron Strauss, the son of Elise I. Strauss and David Strauss, both of New York. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the Pierre in New York, with Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler taking part.

title: Correction: Ancient Road, Timeless Trip
