title: Yet Another Plan for Bell Canada; This Time, a Recapitalization
description: A Toronto-based investment banking firm proposed recapitalizing Bell Canada on Friday as an alternative to the three competing privatization offers and one takeover bid for the company.

title: Lear Delays Vote on Icahn Deal
description: Lear, the auto parts maker, has delayed a shareholder vote on a $2.9 billion buyout offer from Carl Icahn. The vote was rescheduled to July 12 from June 27 in response to criticism of the bid from shareholders and proxy advisory services. Mr. Icahn made the bid, valued at $36 a share, through his American Real Estate Partners.

title: A Buyout Fund by Any Other Name
description: As the private equity industry gets a lot less private, The Financial Timess Thorold Barker suggests it should be thinking about finding a new name for itself. He brings up one possibility that describes what buyout funds do  long-term capital management  but notes that a certain ill-fated hedge fund seems to have ruined that one for everybody. DealBook visited this question in a column in The New York Times in March, and readers responded with plenty of suggestions, including adaptive equity, enterprise capital and constructive finance.

title: Barclays Reveals Exposure to Troubled Hedge Fund
description: The British banking giant Barclays said Friday it has some exposure to troubled hedge funds that invested in the subprime mortgage market, but any loss from the exposure would not be material to its overall performance.

title: Report on Amaranth Collapse Is to Be Made Public
description: After a nine-month investigation, a bipartisan Senate subcommittee is expected to issue a report Monday detailing how a single hedge fund, Amaranth Advisors, dominated the North American natural gas market last year, causing high prices and extreme volatility that ultimately led to the companys stunning collapse.

title: In Blackstone I.P.O., Shades of Milken?
description: For some Wall Street veterans, the Blackstone Groups debut on the New York Stock Exchange Friday may have sparked flashbacks to the 1980s, notes USA Today. The publicity is creating a dj vu all over again, John C. Coffee, an expert in securities law at Columbia University, told USA Today. To anyone who was around Wall Street in the 80s, Blackstone reminds them of the powerful role of Drexel Burnham. They were also masters of the universe.

title: Shaw Hooks Up With Alinda for Venture Projects
description: Shaw Group, an engineering services provider, said Friday its Shaw Capital unit and an investment company, Alinda Capital Partners, had agreed to create a joint venture to pursue a variety of projects. The venture, called Shaw Infrastructure Investments, will pursue energy, transportation, infrastructure, water, wastewater and related projects.

title: F.B.I. Monitoring; a Nazi Artifact; the Weak Dollar; and More
description: And you thought the police surveillance before the 2004 Republican National Convention was intense.

title: London Hedge Fund GLG to Go Public in U.S.
description: GLG Partners, one of Europes largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, according to The New York Times.

title: Renewable Energy Panel Named
description: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson announced the appointment on Sunday of 16 members to the states new Renewable Energy Task Force, which by Dec. 1 is supposed to recommend ways to expand the states use of alternative fuels and other forms of renewable energy. The task force is scheduled to meet for the first time on Tuesday in Albany.The members are:

title: A Frothy Magazine Merger
description: This week, Jason Binns Niche Media, whose titles include Gotham and Los Angeles Confidential, is expected to announce a merger with Greenspun Media Group of Las Vegas  which publishes Vegas, Wynn and Venetian Style, among other magazines  and the Ocean Drive Media Group, which publishes Ocean Drive and Ocean Drive Espaol and several other magazines, The New York Times David Carr reported.

title: Theyre Partners. Theyre Rivals. Theyre Both.
description: General Electrics NBC Universal with Pearson and Hearst until recently considering partnering for Dow Jones. News Corporation-MySpace-Yahoo. News Corp.-NBC. Universal.

title: Murdoch Said to Be Close to Integrity Terms on Journal
description: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and advisers for Dow Jones and its controlling Bancroft family were close Sunday night to agreeing on terms designed to protect The Wall Street Journals newsroom independence if the company accepts a takeover bid from Mr. Murdoch, according to The New York Times.

title: Evolution Is ...
description: "Everybody is interested in pigeons. The book would be reviewed in every journal in the kingdom and would soon be on every library table."- An adviser to Darwin's publisher explaining why Darwin should publish a book on pigeons instead of "The Origin of Species"

title: Sharing Your Intimate Information Online
description: As people take the idea of user-generated content to ridiculous extremes, an intriguing notion is emerging for applications of user contributed data.

title: 2008: Giuliani Confronts The Faith Factor
description: In a reprise of the 2004 flap between Senator John F. Kerry and the handful of American bishops who sought to deny him communion because of his support for abortion rights, church leaders are now setting their sights on a 2008 Republican presidential hopeful and lifetime Catholic, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Battle Looms on Immigration Bill
description: It is do or die  again  for the immigration legislation in the Senate as Congress heads into its final days before the Fourth of July break.

title: Quarter Pounders of the Soul
description: During the summer of 1999, Stephen King  then recuperating from being hit by a van  read the second and third Harry Potter books and they became, he wrote, a kind of lifeline for me.

title: Life as We Know It
description: NATURAL SELECTION 1858

title: Congestion Pricing: Has David Bested Goliath?
description: The answer might depend on who you think is the giant.

title: Will Hedge Fund Bailout Put Bear in Play?
description: Bear Stearnss recent hedge-fund troubles could affect more than just the investment banks reputation. They could jeopardize its independence as well.

title: Back to Work for Tony Blair?
description: Over the weekend, signs grew that Prime Minister Tony Blair was getting closer to securing his next job offer, and so did opinions about whether he should get it.

title: In Search of the Health Care Candidate
Now Its Spam on Stationery
description: No one is better at using the most obscure features of computer programs than spammers.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through this past Sundays book sections.

title: A Hypothetical Poll for an Improbable Race
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer just took office in January. And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has shown no interest whatsoever in running for governor.

title: Blackstone Shares Struggle as Barrons Sees a Top
description: Though some suggested its opening-day jump wasnt big enough, especially considering the Hollywood-like atmosphere around the event, the Blackstone Groups $4.1 billion initial public offering on Friday was generally seen as a success.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports
description: In Nascar, Juan Pablo Montoya recovered from an awful qualifying session and gambled on fuel in the closing laps at Infineon Speedway to win his first Nextel Cup (soon to be Sprint Cup) race.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Digital News Editor Jim Roberts
description: Jim Roberts, editor of digital news, answered reader questions June 25 through 29, 2007.

title: Reviewing the Raters of Manhunt 2
description: Echoing concerns among some veteran game journalists flagged by Game Politics, a great blog about the video game industry, The New York Timess reviewer, Seth Schiesel, found the adult rating of Manhunt 2 entirely reasonable.

title: M.T.A. Starts Live Webcasts of Meetings
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority  a bureaucracy long known for being big, opaque and not especially responsive to ordinary people  is letting some sunshine in. Today, the authority began making live Webcasts available of its boards meetings. The boards New York City Transit committee is meeting at this moment at the authoritys headquarters, 347 Madison Avenue.In a statement, the authority said it had begun the broadcasts  which include closed captioning for the hearing-impaired  to comply with Gov. Eliot Spitzers Executive Order No. 3, which requires all public agencies to broadcast their meetings by July 1.

title: How to Get on the City Room Blogroll
description: Send your suggested links to jeremyz@nytimes.com and put City Room Blogroll in the subject line.

title: Suffolk Leader, in Immigration Maelstrom, Strikes Back
description: Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, is hitting back. Mr. Levy, a Democrat who has gained national attention for his stands in opposition to illegal immigration, has scheduled a noon news conference at the H. Lee Dennison Building in Hauppauge.

title: Doral to Accept Bear Stearns Groups Buyout Offer
description: Doral Financial, the Puerto Rico-based bank that is facing bankruptcy, said that it will turn to a buyout offer led by Bear Stearns, after a rival offer from its second-largest shareholder was withdrawn.

title: Where Are the Doctors?
description: Can you take me back to the U.S. with you?

title: Sea Lions and Bobcats and Bears, Oh My
description: The weekend was rich with news about battles between humankind and various creatures of the wild.

title: Private Equity Lobby Girds for Tax Fight
description: The private equity industry is not just sitting back and waiting for Congress to raise their taxes. The Private Equity Council, a less-than-year-old trade group representing many large buyout firms in the United States, has hired big guns from the lobbying world to defend their interests in Washington.

title: C.I.A. Arrest Warrants Strain U.S.-German Ties
description: The arrest warrants German authorities have issued against 10 CIA agents have strained German-American relations. Now, prosecutors in Munich want the agents extradited to Germany so they can stand trial for their alleged roles in the illegal kidnapping of terror suspects.

title: Theater Briefs
description: The final curtain will fall on the Broadway production of the Disney musical "Tarzan" on July 8 at the Richard Rodgers Theater. At its closing, the show will have played 486 regular performances and 35 previews.

title: Wild Racing Weekend Outside F1
description: Is wild the word? How can yesterdays races in Champ Car and Nascar be defined? I did not see the Nascar race, but the race at the Infineon Raceway road course in Sonoma, California does give some food for thought, and I wrote a few words about Juan Pablo Montoyas first Nascar victory elsewhere.

title: Postcard from Todd Thomson
description: Todd Thomson, the former head of wealth management at Citigroup and onetime heir apparent to former Citi chief Sandy Weill, is still being a bit secretive about his next move on Wall Street.

title: Whose Bright Idea? $1 Off a Light Bulb
description: Attention Consolidated Edison customers: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced this morning that all Con Ed customers in the city will receive a $1 coupon in their home electricity bills in August toward the purchase of a GE Energy Smart compact fluorescent light bulb.

title: The Big Chill
description: Weve had a run of gorgeous early summer days here in New York  bright, crisp and uncharacteristically dry. It seems like an ideal time for a seasonal warning about drinking white wines too cold.

title: Prospect Park Scofflaws Caught on Tape
description: Streetsblog and StreetFilms have posted this video by an irate parkgoer in Brooklyn who says drivers routinely enter Prospect Park illegally after the 7 p.m. ban on vehicles goes into effect:

title: Nano-Sizing Risk
description: Along with creating new strands of DNA, a related strand of engineering also has unknowable, but potentially frightening consequences: nanotechnologybuilding materials out of very small particles.

title: Building a Hedge Fund, With No Manager Required
description: The New Yorkers John Cassidy this week takes a close look at the mystique of hedge funds, and, in a way, sees an industry that would rather not let you look behind its curtain.

title: Bad Audits And Government Grants
description: An obscure government study of audit quality  in audits that are not regulated by much of anybody  has found that most audits conducted in 2002-03 were not of sufficient quality to be relied upon.

title: An Uncanny Avian Resemblance
description: At City Hall this morning, the buzz among reporters  at least those of a certain generation  was, for a change, not about whether Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs presidential aspirations were real, but about how the little cartoon bird (top right) animating the citys new environmental consumer-education campaign, GreeNYC, had an uncanny resemblance to the logo from The Partridge Family (bottom right). It is unclear whether the reference was intentional, since that Mondrian-style school bus the fictional 1970s singing family drove to their pop performances certainly wasnt a hybrid-electric vehicle.

title: Hmmm, How Does Senator Bloomberg Sound?
description: One might assume that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is getting a bit tired of fending off questions about a possible presidential bid (though its also possible hes loving every second).

title: Whitman Defends E.P.A.s 9/11 Work
description: Minutes ago, in forceful and at times emotionally wrought language, Christie Whitman, who was administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency on 9/11, told a House committee that the agency did the best it could to inform rescue workers after environmental hazards in Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center attack. Ms. Whitman  responding to years of criticism by 9/11 health advocates  adamantly denied that the agency withheld information from the public.

title: A Familiar Silence After Austin Killing
description: Following a crime in Austin that shocked the nation is a familiar, deafening silence for murder investigators from Toronto to Newark.

title: Figuring Out Fortresss Tax Bill
description: Just how much would Congresss proposed tax increase cost Fortress Investment Group?

title: Stunning Views, and Safe for Bikes, Too
description: Shore Parkway, which runs along the southern edge of Brooklyn, offers some of the most stunning views of the New York Harbor to be found. Unfortunately, until recently, it was a bumpy, erratic and even dangerous pathway for bicyclists and pedestrians. So deteriorated was the parkway  with a crumbling seawall and open cavities in the bike path  that the city gave the road emergency status. Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican who represents Staten Island and part of Brooklyn, recalled, There were craters 15 feet in diameter at certain points where you could literally hide a small vehicle.

title: Are the (All) Stars Aligned?
description: One of my first memories of baseball was watching the 1984 All-Star Game at Candlestick Park. I was 3 years old at the time and naturally didnt remember much from it. But my dad taped it, as he did most baseball All-Star Games when I wasnt old enough to stay up late to watch them, and a few years later, I would pop the tape into the VCR and watch the player introductions over and over and over. Occasionally, Id watch a few innings before I got bored and went off to play with Legos or something.

title: But Can You Insure Against a Wii Injury
description: Firemans Fund Insurance Company last week announced it has begun selling insurance for developers of video games. The policies, which mimic those offered in the movie business, are being marketed by Firemans as a way to manage the downside risk of expensive productions and costly potential eventualities.

title: In Suffolk, Warnings of Cuts and Tax Increases
description: The feud between Hispanic Democrats in the State Assembly and the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, intensified today as he warned that their actions could force what he called draconian program cuts, property tax increases and the firing of 4,700 workers, more than a third of the county workforce.Mr. Levy said at a news conference in Hauppauge, on Long Island, that he would be forced to impose such measures if the Assembly fails to renew the countys sales tax, which he said would create a $350 million budget gap.

title: Aide at Elite School Is Charged in Rape
description: A 25-year-old school aide at the elite Hunter College High School in Manhattan was arrested and charged with third-degree rape today for having a sexual relationship with a 15-year-old student at his home on Staten Island, city investigators said.

title: Naked shorting, redux
description: The number of companies affected by naked short selling keeps growing  at least in the minds of some.

title: You Are So Facebook
description: If the friend requests pouring into my email inbox lately are any guide, social networking upstart Facebook is trouncing leader MySpace.

title: Said Time Inc., Who Needs Google?
description: For the last few years, publishers have seen text ads on their Web sites as found money, as they struck deals with Google and later Yahoo to place ads that relate (more or less) to the topics of their pages. Now they are starting to see those ads, small as they are, as so important they want to sell them themselves.

title: Mayor Keeps Making Nice to Silver
description: The quarrel over congestion pricing between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who proposed the plan, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who helped scuttle the bill in the State Legislature, is marked by two distinct styles of oratory: Mr. Silver suggests the mayor is an arrogant autocrat, and Mr. Bloomberg smiles sanguinely and says he hopes for the best.

title: City Puts Retro Bird on YouTube
A Weakened McCain-Feingold
description: The Supreme Court dealt a huge blow to the McCain-Feingold campaign finance act today, loosening the restrictions on what companies and unions can spend on television advertisements just before elections. The Republican co-sponsor of the act, John McCain, wasnt pleased, saying, It is regrettable that a split Supreme Court has carved out a narrow exception by which some corporate and labor expenditures can be used to target a federal candidate in the days and weeks before an election.

title: Modifying the Top Floor
description: Our builder, Johnny, had pledged to work up an estimate. In the meantime, my biggest concern was refining the plan for the top floor. Like readers of this blog, I thought this floor needed modifications.

title: A Campaign for Big Ideas
description: In his Web column today, Patrick Healy catches up with former New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has his own newsletter and has started a series of issue-related forums pegged to the 2008 campaign cycle.

title: Brilliant 2-Year-Old Pokes Tiny Hole in Study
description: A study that has dominated most e-mailed lists since Friday, when eldest siblings found proof that they had a slight but significant edge in I.Q., was punctured with one tiny, microscopic hole today in Britain. Georgia Brown, a two-year-old with an I.Q. of 152, is the youngest of five children, a British newspaper reported.

title: XLIV for Romney Coming Next?
description: Holy Caesar!

title: Following Urban Bees on Their Daily Rounds
description: The mysterious and alarming collapse of honeybee populations throughout the United States has prompted a new local study of the phenomenon.

title: Alessandra Ferri's Farewell
description: Alessandra Ferri's farewell performance of Romeo & Juliet with  Roberto Bolle. Videography by Nan Melville.

title: Bending the Knee
description: Editors note: An earlier version of this article included a paraphrase of President Bushs remarks at a 2004 press conference. That passage has been replaced by a direct quote from the White House transcript.

title: Whos Cooking Dinner Now?
description: Ten months ago, Jeff Jordan, then president of eBays PayPal unit, announced he was leaving eBay to spend more time with his family, especially his 12-year-old twins. But as earnestly as Mr. Jordan made his case at the time, there were just too many signs pointing to other another reason for his leave-taking. At age 47, he was still young, and he was known to be ambitious. He had been considered the successor-in-waiting to eBays CEO, Meg Whitman.

title: Answers From the Transportation Commissioner, Part 1
description: The citys new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, was taking questions from City Room readers through the week. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

title: Stuck on Flight 5637
description: Passengers mill in the aisles and fan themselves aboard a 50-seat Comair jet that was stranded on a ramp at Kennedy International Airport for four hours, while David Ollila, whose company makes miniature video cameras, talks to his office in Michigan and films from the scene. Video courtesy of V.I.O. Inc.

title: The Science of Evolution
description: Sean B. Carroll discusses the science of evolution and the field of evo-devo.

title: One Mans All-Stars
description: With the Cardinals playing the Mets tonight at Shea Stadium, and in the spirit of Tony La Russa, the man entrusted with managing the National League team on July 10  and remember, this year it counts  here is one mans guess as to how the 32-man roster will shake out. There are no requirements as to how many pitchers, infielders, outfielders, etc.  must be on a roster, so the manager often picks more players from a particularly strong position and fewer from a weaker one. For instance, I could see La Russa picking two additional shortstops but only one more second baseman.

title: Christie Whitman Testifies
description: Clips from Christie Whitman's testimony before a House subcommittee.

title: Readers Questions: The Science of  Evolution
description: The public discourse about evolution has been so dominated by politics and religion that it can seem as if the science behind it has been frozen since the time of Darwin.

title: Digging Into Cheney
description: Barton Gellman, one of the best reporters around, has a superb and illuminating series in The Washington Post about Dick Cheney. While Cheney himself didnt talk, lots of people around him did  underscoring Cheneys central role in the Bush administrations most demented policies. The series shows that Bush is still the boss  its not as if Cheney is secretly pulling the strings  but that Bush tends to operate at a level of general goals. Cheney is a master of operations, and uses that role to translate general aims into specific (and usually horrifying) policies.

title: YouTube Changes Rile Users
description: For some loyal denizens of YouTube.com  including the politically attuned  the sites recent redesign that replaced users picks for the most viewed or highly rated videos with editors choices in subject categories like news and politics, is akin to dictatorship.

title: Welcome to My Civilian Life
description: For my final post here, Id like to give you a little tour of the last year and half of my life. It covers a lot of ground, so hang on.

title: On Fringe of Forests, Homes and Fires Meet
description: COLEVILLE, Calif.  Lori and Don Morris had just started unpacking the boxes this month in their new dream house  four acres, national forest view, wide open land at their doorstep  when a wildfire raced down the stark bluffs over this high-desert town near the Nevada border.

title: Britain: Vacation Service in Merger With Auto Group
description: The Saga Group, a British provider of insurance and vacations to the consumers 50 and older, agreed to merge with the Automobile Association in a transaction that values the two closely held companies at 6.2 billion ($12.4 billion). The deal would enable Saga to offer policies and cruises to the Automobile Associations older customers and the association to sell roadside assistance to Sagas 2.5 million clients, the companies said. About 15 million British motorists rely on the association when their cars break down. Sagas chief executive, Andrew Goodsell, will head the company, and the automobile associations chief executive, Tim Parker, will quit.

title: Ex-E.P.A. Chief Defends Role in 9/11 Response
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Testifying at a Congressional hearing on Monday about the governments environmental response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, Christie Whitman staunchly defended her statements assuring the public that the air in Lower Manhattan was safe in the days immediately after the attack.

title: Lottery Numbers
Cold-War Era Abuses Invite Contemporary Comparisons
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  When the Central Intelligence Agency took a nervous look at its past in 1973, one potential illegal act officials identified was the treatment of a Soviet K.G.B. officer named Yuri Nosenko. After fleeing to the United States in 1964, he had been held in a makeshift jail for three years and subjected to tough questioning to determine whether he was a genuine defector or a plant.

title: A Contest for the World, Led by South Koreans
description: South Korean dancers dominated the field at the New York International Ballet Competitions closing gala, winning or sharing a majority of the medals and other honors awarded on Sunday night at the Rose Theater. But the programming made it hard to get a clear picture of the skills of any of the contestants in the biennial competition, which this year drew dancers from 19 nations.

title: One Dead as Bus Carrying Family Leaves Roadway
description: NASHVILLE, June 25  A chartered bus carrying an extended family home from a reunion in Niagara Falls, N.Y., crashed early Monday in southern Kentucky, killing one passenger and injuring the driver and dozens more passengers, the Kentucky State Police said.

title: Letters
description: Archaeology and the Nile

title: Romney to Tap Own Money for Campaign
description: Mitt Romney said yesterday he had once more turned to his personal fortune to help finance his presidential campaign and might do so again, suggesting that his fund-raising has fallen off since the first three months of the year.

title: An Easy Target, but Does That Mean Hatred?
description: Hate-crime laws have long had their skeptics, and the one enacted by New York State in 2000 is no exception.

title: Shakespeares Splashy Side
description: Hark! Shakespeare in the Parks water-laden Romeo and Juliet is terrifically exciting," says Ben Brantley, and Lauren Ambrose is a Juliet to die for. The action is centered around a pool that the actors splash through, but it doesnt slow them down: this show  which shares a director with Rent  has "what most productions of Romeo and Juliet fatally lack, Mr. Brantley says: a sense of infectious, instinctive urgency. So hurry to get your tickets; bring a friend to get take-out while you wait in line.

title: Open Sesame Just Wont Do: Hoboken Tries to Unlock Its Cave
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., June 21  The Cave of the Sibyl, where Virgils prophetess received Aeneas before leading him to the underworld, was a vast cavern in southern Italy with a hundred mouths. When the Sibyl spoke, her words came in a hundred voices.

title: Peace Talks Simple Compared With Steroids
description: The time has come to wrap it up, Senator Mitchell. More than scoring a sit-down with Barry Bonds, closure is your calling. With all due appreciation and respect, investigating steroid use in baseball should not be taking anywhere near as much of your time as  for comparisons sake  brokering peace in Northern Ireland.

title: A Campaign for Big Ideas
description: Every week or so, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York prepares a private political memo, called the Update, and e-mails it to friends and allies in hopes of provoking thought and debate. The Updates central thesis is that there are Great Issues at stake in the 2008 presidential election, and that the candidates should be judged on their ability to discuss them in detail, in a way that measures more than glibness, memory and theatricality.

title: China: HSBC to Buy Part of Tower in Shanghai
description: HSBC Holdings, the European bank, said it would buy part of an office tower in Shanghai to house its China headquarters as it speeds up expansion in China. HSBC agreed to buy naming rights and occupy 20 floors of one of the twin towers of the Shanghai International Finance Center, to be completed by 2010, from Sun Hung Kai Properties, HSBC said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The tower, a few blocks from the banks current headquarters, would be renamed HSBC Building-Shanghai IFC. Stephen K. Green, the chairman of HSBC, disclosed the deal at a news conference in Shanghai, but he declined to say how much the bank had agreed to pay.

title: Delphi Workers May Give Up Their Layoff-Pay Benefit
description: DETROIT, June 25  Unionized workers at Delphi, the big auto parts supplier, could vote this week to throw out the jobs bank, a longtime program that lets them continue receiving most of their pay after being laid off.

title: Staten Island: New President for S.I. College
description: The next president of the College of Staten Island will be Toms D. Morales, left, the provost and vice president for academic affairs at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, and a professor of education there. Dr. Morales, 53, whose appointment was approved yesterday by the trustees of the City University of New York, earned a bachelors degree from the State University of New York at New Paltz and a masters degree and Ph.D. in educational administration and policy from SUNY Albany. Before moving to Cal Poly, he was vice president for student affairs and dean of students at CUNYs City College campus from 1994 to 2001. Dr. Morales, whose presidency begins on Aug. 1, will succeed Marlene Springer, who is retiring as president after 13 years.

title: Hancock Case Is Settled for $21.3 Million
description: The Manulife Financial Corporation will pay $21.3 million to settle claims that its John Hancock investment units secretly diverted client funds to pay for marketing, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: One Swing Is Difference vs. Cardinals Again
description: The teams were the same. So was the site. The Mets pitcher of record was the same, and the game was again decided by a home run.

title: Brooklyn: Case Advances in Infant Death
description: Justice Neil J. Firetog of State Supreme Court denied a motion yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to review the disclosure by the district attorneys office of grand jury testimony in a case involving the disposal of a newborn. His decision allows prosecutors to continue their case against Andria Sergio, 27, of Bay Ridge, who has been charged with hindering prosecution and improperly disposing of a body in the death of a girl delivered by her sister Laura, 25, in April. The baby was found on the back porch of the family home. The cause of death was found to be asphyxiation and hypothermia, and Laura Sergio has been charged with murder. After prosecutors, in a court filing, disclosed a summary of grand jury testimony by Andria Sergio, defense lawyers asked Justice Firetog to dismiss the charges, arguing that the disclosure was improper. Prosecutors successfully argued that the disclosure was meant to ensure that the testimony would be accepted as evidence at trial.

title: Defenders of Secrets, Unite!
description: They have waited two long years, and now they have only 24 days to go. As the diehard fans of Harry Potter count the minutes until they can get their hands on Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the seventh and final installment in the monumentally successful series by J. K. Rowling, they are engaging in a frenzy of speculation and rumor-mongering about what will happen to their beloved characters.

title: J.B. Handelsman, 85, New Yorker Cartoonist, Is Dead
description: J. B. Handelsman, a noted cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker over the course of four and a half decades, died on Wednesday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Foundation Lets Public Help Award Money
description: In a first, a major foundation is offering the public a direct role in deciding who should receive some of its money, a process typically shrouded in mystery.

title: Science of the Soul? I Think, Therefore I Am Is Losing Force
description: In 1950, in a letter to bishops, Pope Pius XII took up the issue of evolution. The Roman Catholic Church does not necessarily object to the study of evolution as far as it relates to physical traits, he wrote in the encyclical, Humani Generis. But he added, Catholic faith obliges us to hold that souls are immediately created by God.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on June 17 about a redevelopment project in Baltimore that has displaced some longtime residents misstated the amount of space Johns Hopkins University will occupy in the projects research park. It has agreed to lease about a third of the space in the parks first building, not a majority of space in the park. The article also misstated the lowest price for new housing in the development. While the bulk of the housing will indeed start at $250,000, some one-bedroom units are expected to be available for about $200,000, although prices have not been set.

description: To the Editor:

title: For G.I.s in Iraq, a Harrowing Day Facing a Trap
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 25  The enemy was a phantom who never showed his face but transformed a neighborhood into a network of houses rigged to explode.

title: Nice Night for 60 Minutes
description: On a summer night of typically tiny television audiences, three networks shared the top spot on Sunday in the ratings among adults 18 to 49, while CBS posted an advantage over all in total viewers. Nielsen estimated that CBSs 60 Minutes earned the nights most viewers, as 8.3 million tuned in to that news magazine at 7. And CBS remained the most-watched network the rest of the night with repeats of Without a Trace at 8 (6.7 million) and again at 10 (6.7 million), along with a rerun of Cold Case in between at 9 (7.8 million). In the 18 to 49 demographic, CBS finished about even with NBC and Fox. NBCs two-hour Dateline, about a rescue mission in Afghanistan, ranked No. 2 from 7 to 9 with 4.5 million viewers, while a repeat of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (5.8 million) led the 10 oclock hour among adults 18 to 49. Fox boasted the nights highest-rated show in the demographic, a rerun of Family Guy at 9 (4.5 million).

title: Manhattan: Arrest in Beating Death
description: A 23-year-old Washington Heights man was arrested and charged with manslaughter after a 78-year-old man he was accused of attacking died, the police said yesterday. The man, Tarz Youngblood, had been fighting with the victim, Hazen Moorer, at 156th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue about 10:30 p.m. on June 16. The police found Mr. Moorer on the ground with a head injury. He was taken to Harlem Hospital Center, where he died on Sunday, the police said.

title: Private Equity Investors Hint at Cool Down
description: The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.

title: Lugar Urges Quick Shift in Iraq War Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  After offering a bleak assessment of the Bush administrations strategy in Iraq, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he was urging lawmakers and President Bush to change course quickly to protect a further erosion of Americas standing in the world.

title: Doubting the Police
description: The woman was reluctant to let her name be used. She said she had a teenage son and was afraid that he might be harassed by the police. But her desire to have the truth come out overcame her fears.

title: U.N. Inspectors Invited to Iran for Talks on Nuclear Program
description: FRANKFURT, June 25  A team of inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency will travel to Tehran in the coming weeks at the invitation of the Iranian government to try to clear up longstanding questions about Irans nuclear program, the agency said Monday.

description: A picture caption with a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdochs management of his media company, the News Corporation, misidentified the owner of the British newspaper The Independent. It is owned by Independent News & Media, not by Mr. Murdochs company.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,544 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following service members yesterday:

description: General managers give personality tests. They hold individual workouts and measure players. But there is no comparison between watching a player and competing against him.
