title: Darwin Still Rules, but Some Biologists Dream of a Paradigm Shift
description: Is Darwin due for an upgrade? There are growing calls among some evolutionary biologists for just such a revision, although they differ about what form this might take. But those calls could also be exaggerated. There is nothing scientists enjoy more than the prospect of a good paradigm shift.

title: Video and Film Producers, at Home in the Bronx
description: THE advertising campaign to promote Bronx tourism and business began this week. Its called Were Talking the Bronx.

title: Investors React to New Worries Over State of Hedge Funds
description: Financial shares tumbled yesterday on concern that losses tied to subprime mortgages would deepen, extending the stock markets worst weekly decline since March.

title: Polished Young Choristers Evoking Eternal Mysteries
description: The Brooklyn Youth Chorus is regularly heard alongside prestigious ensembles in major works at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In March it helped Elton John celebrate his 60th birthday at Madison Square Garden; other collaborators have included Andrea Bocelli and Lou Reed. It can sometimes be hard to think of this group, founded by Dianne Berkun in 1992, as anything but a polished ensemble of miniature professionals.

title: Humans Have Spread Globally, and Evolved Locally
description: Historians often assume that they need pay no attention to human evolution because the process ground to a halt in the distant past. That assumption is looking less and less secure in light of new findings based on decoding human DNA.

title: Egypt: Engineer Gets Life on Israeli Spy Charge
description: A court in Cairo convicted Muhammad Sayyid Saber Ali, an Egyptian nuclear engineer, of spying for Israel and sentenced him to life in prison. Mr. Ali, who worked for Egypts atomic agency, was charged with delivering information about the agency and one of two nuclear reactors to Israeli intelligence agents in exchange for about $17,000. He admitted that he had delivered reports that he took from the agency but said the information was general, available online and not a secret. In Egypt, a sentence of life is equivalent to 25 years in prison; a pardon for good conduct is possible after two-thirds of the time has been served.

title: Slump Brings the Yankees Weaknesses Into Focus
description: The best thing that has happened to the Yankees this season, besides the revitalization of Alex Rodriguez, has probably been the development of their pitching in the lower minor leagues. Despite many needs on the major league side, the Yankees have no plans to dismantle their farm system.

title: Before a New Roof, the Top Is Down at Center Court
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25  Center Court was not made for days like this. Not yet, anyway.

title: Rules on All-Star Picks Leaving La Russa Little Choice
description: As the manager of last years National League champion, Tony La Russa of the Cardinals has the privilege of filling out his team for the All-Star Game this year. La Russa, however, calls it more of a challenge.

title: U.S. Is Creating 3 Centers for Research on Biofuels
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Energy Department is creating three bioenergy research centers to find new ways to turn plants into fuel.

title: Murdochs Dealings in China: Its Business, and Its Personal
description: BEIJING, June 25  Many big companies have sought to break into the Chinese market over the past two decades, but few of them have been as ardent and unrelenting as Rupert Murdochs News Corporation.

title: Early Warning of Disease (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fast-Reproducing Microbes Provide a Window on Natural Selection
description: In the corner of a laboratory at Michigan State University, one of the longest-running experiments in evolution is quietly unfolding. A dozen flasks of sugary broth swirl on a gently rocking table. Each is home to hundreds of millions of Escherichia coli, the common gut microbe. These 12 lines of bacteria have been reproducing since 1989, when the biologist Richard E. Lenski bred them from a single E. coli. I originally thought it might go a couple thousand generations, but its kept going and stayed interesting, Dr. Lenski said. He is up to 40,000 generations now, and counting.

title: U.S. Plan to Capture and Kill Insurgents in Baquba Fell Far Short of Goal, Officer Says
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, June 25  One week after American forces mounted their assault on insurgent strongholds in western Baquba, at least half of the estimated 300 to 500 fighters who were there have escaped or are still at large, the colonel who is leading the attack said Monday.

title: (Sort of) Rating Hospitals
description: The federal government deserves a modest pat on the back for identifying hospitals that have the very best  and very worst  mortality rates for cardiac patients. One can only hope that the information will goad underachieving hospitals into improving their performance. Unfortunately, the ratings are too broad to help most patients decide which institution they can entrust with their lives.

title: Rules for Getting Married
description: There are Eight Simple Rules for Dating My Teenage Daughter, rules of the road, The Rules of the Game, rules of engagement and The Cider House Rules, among others. Now comes a campaign for a leading department-store chain, which promulgates rules for prospective brides and grooms that are intended to bring a new, less stuffy attitude to the process of registering for wedding gifts.

title: African Refugees, Transported by Song
description: From 1991 to 2002 a civil war wracked the West African nation of Sierra Leone. The death, mayhem and destruction forced hundreds of thousands of residents to flee, many to the north, to refugee camps in Guinea.

title: Tom Sizemore Sentenced
description: Tom Sizemore, below, the actor whose credits include Saving Private Ryan and Black Hawk Down, was sentenced yesterday in Los Angeles to 16 months in state prison for violating his probation in a drug case. Judge Cynthia Rayvis of Superior Court issued the order after authorities said they found methamphetamine in Mr. Sizemores car last month in Bakersfield, Calif., when he was on probation for a previous drug conviction. If convicted on all charges in the Bakersfield case, he faces up to six years in prison. He has been in jail without bail since June 5.

title: At the Bowery Mission, Songs of Faith and Redemption
description: Inside an empty chapel in Lower Manhattan, Dwight Walker stood with his back facing the empty rows of pews. His voice began to rise with songs that included words like faith, found and lost. Five other men joined him.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on June 17 about slowing growth in online retail sales referred incorrectly to plans by the bookseller Borders to revamp its Web site so customers can reserve books online, then pick them up in the store. That service will be offered in the next version of the companys primary Web site, borders.com; it is not available now.

title: Honoring Rushdie
description: Salman Rushdies knighthood is causing a furor  especially in Pakistan and Iran  among Islamic extremists, who see it as an official state endorsement of a writer who has been anathema to them ever since the publication of The Satanic Verses. And it has caused a few ripples of conscience in the West, too, a part of the world where writers are not routinely threatened with death but where we do try, often perplexedly, to respect the validity and the intensity of other peoples feelings.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about Wired magazines personalizing its cover art with photographs uploaded to its Web site, Wired.com, misstated the name of the company that sold the Web site to Cond Nast, publisher of Wired. It is Daum Communications, not Baum.

title: Delphi Deal Is Blow to Jobs Bank
description: DETROIT, June 25  Unionized workers at the Delphi Corporation, the big auto parts supplier, could vote this week to throw out the jobs bank, the longtime program that lets them continue receiving most of their pay after being laid off.

title: 9 Statues Uprooted From Africa Head Home
description: For some two decades the nine carved statues were displayed in the Park Avenue apartment of the producer Lewis M. Allen and the screenwriter Jay Presson Allen. Tall and slender with rounded heads, the postlike figures seemed more like exotic conversation pieces than relics with a religious purpose, the Allens daughter, the writer Brooke Allen, recalls.

title: Day Laborers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about Wired magazines personalizing its cover art with photographs uploaded to its Web site, Wired.com, misstated the name of the company that sold the Web site to Cond Nast, publisher of Wired. It is Daum Communications, not Baum.

title: Bernd Becher, 75, Photographer of German Industrial Landscape, Dies
description: Bernd Becher, known with his wife, Hilla, for photographing relics of industry in the changing urban landscapes of late-20th-century Europe and the United States, died on Friday in Rostock, Germany. He was 75.

title: Vatican City: French Cardinal to Head Interreligious Council
description: Pope Benedict XVI appointed a French cardinal, Jean-Louis Tauran, to lead the Vaticans newly restored Council for Interreligious Dialogue, which oversees dialogue with Muslims and other faiths. Cardinal Tauran, 64, was the Vaticans foreign minister under Pope John Paul II.

title: New York Pitches Congestion Pricing to Federal Officials
description: Federal transportation officials studying New York Citys plan to charge drivers who enter the most congested parts of Manhattan on weekdays heard new financial details about the proposal during a meeting yesterday in Washington.

title: Little Visible Progress on Darfur at International Conference
description: PARIS, June 25  They came, they met, they agreed that more must be done, but a gathering here aimed at solving the crisis in Sudans Darfur region ended Monday with little visible progress.

title: Projects Sought for Space Laboratory
description: NASA is looking to share unused space aboard the International Space Station for science experiments, officials said. The agency has cut back on its own science plans for the station as it moved toward the next generation of spacecraft. Congress has called for NASA to operate the station as a national laboratory and open the door to other agencies and businesses once the orbiting facility is complete in 2010. William Gerstenmaier, NASAs associate administrator, said that several agencies had already shown general interest, including the departments of Energy and Defense.

title: Abortion Politics: The Third Rail (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Tuesday about a change in management at the Chelsea Hotel, long known as a haven for artists, writers and musicians, attributed two erroneous distinctions to it. Along with the Rembrandt and the Gramercy Park, the Chelsea Hotel was one of New York Citys first cooperative apartment buildings, but not the first. Also, the 12-story Chelsea was among the tallest buildings in the city when it was built, in 1883, but it was not the tallest in 1902; the tallest that year was the 29-story 15 Park Row, built in 1899.

title: Georgia: Supporters Offer Bond for Prisoner
description: Eleven businessmen have offered to post a $1 million cash bond to secure release of a man serving 10 years in prison for having consensual oral sex with 15-year-old girl when he was 17. One of the potential donors is Whitney Tilson, a hedge fund manager; the others have remained anonymous. The offer is meant to pressure David McDade, the Douglas County district attorney, into granting bond for Genarlow Wilson, who was ordered released from prison earlier this month after a Superior Court judge ruled that his sentence was a grave miscarriage of justice. That decision was appealed by the Georgia attorney general, which is keeping Mr. Wilson in prison until at least October when the State Supreme Court is set to hear arguments in his habeas corpus appeal. Mr. McDade has declined to set bond, saying Georgia law forbids it; Mr. Wilsons lawyer disputes that.

title: A Power in Albany (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Billionaire Thinks in Trillions for His Computer Designs
description: Twenty-six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student and a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Andreas Bechtolsheim designed a simple but powerful personal computer workstation that would help define the modern technology era.

title: Hefner Greenlights His Life
description: Hugh Hefner, below, has given his approval to a film about his life, Variety reported. Mr. Hefner, 81, the founder of Playboy, gave his O.K. at a meeting last week at his Playboy Mansion. Brett Ratner, whose credits include Rush Hour, Rush Hour 2, X-Men: The Last Stand and the forthcoming Rush Hour 3, will direct. Hef came from a puritanical background and reinvented himself to be the godfather of the sexual revolution, Mr. Ratner said. He broke all kinds of taboos, especially in sexuality. I want to show it all, from the First Amendment struggles to his first orgy to the stroke in the 1980s that almost killed him.

title: Collecting Antiquities, Cautiously, at the Getty
description: The title of antiquities curator at a major museum has always had a glamorous ring to it, an air of elegant erudition, pith helmets and globe-trotting. But as battles over so-called cultural patrimony have grown more intense in recent years, the post has also become a hot seat, with countries aggressively seeking the return of treasures they say were looted from their soil and then sold.

title: Some Subways Found Packed Past Capacity
description: They are just lines on a graph, but for many subway riders they will provide unique insight into one of the great aggravations of life underground: why trains on some lines are so often both crowded and late, while on other lines the trains seem to cruise along on schedule with almost no one on board.

title: Closing the Justice Gap
description: Heres another way the rich are different from the poor: They have lawyers. Poor people can count on free legal aid in criminal cases, but in civil proceedings  battles with landlords, employers, government bureaucracies  justice costs money, which means lots of people have to do without it.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Long Beach Journal on Thursday, about the Friday Workshop, a book club in the Long Island beach community that has been in continuous existence for about 50 years, misstated part of the title of a Shakespeare play that the group recently read. It is The Winters Tale, not A Winters Tale.

title: New York Review of Books Plans a Fiction Issue
description: For the first time in its 44 years, The New York Review of Books will publish a special fiction issue, including an excerpt from Diary of a Bad Year, a novel in progress by J. M. Coetzee. Robert Silvers, the reviews editor, said, Its a new step weve long wanted to take. Reviews of fiction in the issue, dated July 19 but on sale on July 5, will include Hilary Mantel on Mischa Berlinskis first novel, Tim Parks on the Nobel Prize winner Elfriede Jelinek and Nathaniel Rich on the writing and films of Pier Paolo Pasolini. The issue will also include essays, among them one by Colm Toibin on The Portrait of a Lady.

title: Memo Pad
description: REGISTERED TRAVELER PROGRAM  While skeptics point to the sluggish pace of the nationwide rollout of the Registered Travel Program, a second competitor, Unisys, said it opened its first program, called rtGO, at Reno-Tahoe International Airport. Membership in rtGO is $100 a year. Under the program, participants cleared in a background security check receive an identification card encoded with biometric data like iris scans and fingerprints. The card provides access to a special security lane. Several other competitors are planning to enter the business but the main operator is Verified Identity Pass, whose Clear program has about 48,000 members and locations at Terminals 1, 4 and 7 at Kennedy International Airport, as well as at airports in Orlando, Fla.; Cincinnati; San Jose, Calif.; and Indianapolis. Verified Identity plans to open a lane soon at Terminal B in Newark. While members get a special lane, so far other planned benefits of the program, like the ability to pass throughout without removing shoes, laptops or outer garments, have lagged behind, pending Transportation Security Administration approval of new technologies.

title: The Bears Release Tank Johnson After His Latest Legal Trouble
description: Defensive tackle Tank Johnson, one of the players punished this off-season under the N.F.L.s new personal-conduct policy, was waived by the Chicago Bears yesterday, three days after he was pulled over by the police in Arizona for speeding and arrested on suspicion of driving while impaired.

title: Harry Potter: Good Kisser
description: The review is in. A Harry Potter kiss is pure enchantment. Who says so? None other than Katie Leung, who plays the boy wizards Hogwarts classmate Cho Chang, speaking at a news conference in London to promote the premiere on July 3 of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, Agence France-Presse reported. He was great, Ms. Leung, 19, said of locking lips with Daniel Radcliffe, who portrays Harry. Im sure everyone wants to know if he was a good kisser; he definitely was. Mr. Radcliffe, who turns 18 on July 23, said he was initially nervous while filming the scene, above, but said, After the first few takes, it was fine, and we finally started enjoying ourselves. David Heyman, a producer of the film, the fifth in the series, said: Many of us have known Daniel since he was 10 years old, have seen him grow up before our eyes, care for him so, and are protective of him. It was so strange. I kept thinking, I shouldnt be watching this.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a front-page article yesterday about Rupert Murdochs management of his media company, the News Corporation, misidentified the owner of the British newspaper The Independent. It is owned by Independent News & Media, not by Mr. Murdochs company. (Go to Article)

title: Immigration Dispute May Force Tax Increase in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., June 25  The game of chicken between the State Legislatures black and Hispanic caucus and the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, who has crusaded against illegal immigration, intensified on Monday when he warned of mass layoffs, tax increases and cuts in county programs unless they can resolve an impasse over immigration and sales taxes.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Friday about the murder conviction of a New York man, Thomas Toolan III, who killed his former companion, Elizabeth Lochtefeld, in Nantucket, Mass., in 2004, misidentified Ms. Lochtefelds place of residence and referred incorrectly to Brian Glenny, who prosecuted the case. Ms. Lochtefeld lived in Nantucket at the time, not Manhattan, and Mr. Glenny is an assistant district attorney with the Cape and Islands District Attorneys Office; there is no Nantucket district attorney.

title: In Parasite Survival, Ploys to Get Help From a Host
description: Not long ago, my daughter proposed a way she could earn some extra cash beyond her weekly allowance. Would I give her a quarter, she wanted to know, every time she cleaned the cat box?

title: Father of Captive Israeli Sought Word on His Fate
description: JERUSALEM, June 26  Two weeks before Mondays release of an audiotape of a captured Israeli soldier in Gaza, his father set in motion a request to Hamas, the Islamic militant group holding the soldier, for some sign that the young man was alive.

title: Iraq Raids Home of Culture Minister, Seeking His Arrest
description: BAGHDAD, June 26  Iraqi forces raided the home of Culture Minister Asad al-Hashimi today after an arrest warrant accused him of masterminding the 2005 assassination attempt of a secular Sunni politician who was once a top aide to Ahmed Chalabi.

title: Special Ed Students in City Lag in Entering Mainstream
description: New York City lags behind the rest of the state in placing special education students into mainstream classrooms, the state said yesterday.

title: The Human Family Tree Has Become a Bush With Many Branches
description: Time was, fossils and a few stone artifacts were about the only means scientists had of tracing the lines of early human evolution. And gaps in such material evidence were frustratingly wide.

title: New Scrutiny as Immigrants Die in Custody
description: Sandra M. Kenley was returning home from her native Barbados in 2005 when she was swept into the United States fastest-growing form of incarceration, immigration detention.

title: The Height of Avarice
description: Hartford

title: He Sings the Borough Forgotten
description: Brooklyn has Walt Whitman to sing praises of its ample hills. Manhattan has Woody Allen to capture its outsize style and neuroses. And Staten Island? Well, Staten Island has Thomas W. Matteo for a borough historian to chronicle its glories, its goofs and, yes, its landfill.

title: From a Few Genes, Lifes Myriad Shapes
description: Since its humble beginnings as a single cell, life has evolved into a spectacular array of shapes and sizes, from tiny fleas to towering Tyrannosaurus rex, from slow-soaring vultures to fast-swimming swordfish, and from modest ferns to alluring orchids. But just how such diversity of form could arise out of evolutions mess of random genetic mutations  how a functional wing could sprout where none had grown before, or how flowers could blossom in what had been a flowerless world  has remained one of the most fascinating and intractable questions in evolutionary biology.

title: North Korea Receives Funds and Says It Will Shut Down Its Main Nuclear Reactor
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25  North Korea said Monday that its dispute with the United States over $25 million frozen in a bank in Macao had been resolved, and that it would begin to carry out its much-delayed promise to shut down its main nuclear plant.

title: The Frankenstein Family
description: Frankensteins castle has its occupants. Full casting has been announced for The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein. The lineup: Roger Bart (Dr. Frederick Frankenstein), Megan Mullally (Elizabeth), Sutton Foster (Inga), Shuler Hensley (The Monster), Andrea Martin (Frau Blucher), Fred Applegate (Kemp) and Christopher Fitzgerald (Igor). Previews begin on Oct. 11 at the Hilton Theater. The show opens on Nov. 8.

title: Immigration Bill Clears Test Vote in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A bill to overhaul the immigration system, all but given up for dead two weeks ago, cleared a crucial test vote in the Senate today, bolstering its chances for passage by the Senate within days.

title: Hollingers Former Lawyer Described as Trustworthy
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (Bloomberg News)  Hollinger Internationals former chief lawyer, on trial for fraud with its ex-chairman, Conrad M. Black, is an honest and trustworthy man and should be acquitted of all charges, his lawyer told jurors Monday in closing arguments.

title: The Glory of France, Restored to Louis XIVs Glittering Ideal
description: VERSAILLES, France, June 25  For much of the last three years visitors to the Chteau de Versailles have had good reason to feel disappointed: The Hall of Mirrors, the palaces most glittering jewel, has been undergoing extensive restoration, with only about half of its 220-foot-long gallery visible at any one time.

title: Man Jailed 2 Years Sues Over Queens Prosecutions
description: A Queens man who was released after spending more than two years in jail has filed a $50 million lawsuit against the district attorney, Richard A. Brown, and other city officials, saying the boroughs prosecutors have a frightening history of appellate reversals for prosecutorial misconduct.

title: Income Tax Steady in Connecticut Budget
description: HARTFORD, June 25  The State Senate approved a two-year, $36 billion state budget on Monday that increases spending for education and health care and raises the tax on cigarettes but not on income.

title: Brooklyn: Infants Death Deemed Homicide
description: The death of a 3-month-old Brooklyn girl in April has been reclassified as a homicide by the medical examiner, the police said yesterday. The girl, Shavannah Pearson, was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center on March 25 because of breathing difficulty. The doctors discovered several fractured ribs, and the infant was transferred to New York University Medical Center. She died on April 3. On Sunday, the medical examiner determined the death was a homicide.

title: No Takeoff, but 2 Visits by the Police
description: For nearly four hours last Thursday night, Flight 5637, a 50-seat regional jet, was stuck on the ground by bad weather at Kennedy International Airport. The air-conditioning wasnt working, and no one seemed to have a clue about when the plane would take off.

title: Maine: Troop Greeters Resume Offering Treats
description: Bangor International Airport is again allowing a group that greets soldiers who pass through the airport to serve them treats: packaged cookies and candies. Concerned about liability and the prospect of food borne illness, the airport last month had asked the group, the Maine Troop Greeters, to stop serving treats, which had expanded from cake and cookies to sandwiches and pizza. Bill Knight, who founded the greeters in 2003, said the group was pleased with the compromise. They treat us good, he said of the airport, which has allowed the group free use of a room free since 2004.

title: The Hague: Taylor Resumes Trial Boycott
description: Liberias former president, Charles Taylor, refused for the second time to attend his war-crimes trial in The Hague, instead continuing to bicker with the United Nations-backed court from his jail cell over the size and financing of his defense team. The presiding judge at the Special Court for Sierra Leone, which is trying him, chided court administrators for not dealing promptly with the defense issue, aggravated since Mr. Taylor fired his lead lawyer this month.

title: Billion-Dollar Deal to Be a Partner in Some Warner Films
description: In a sign that the flood of private money in Hollywood only continues to rise, Legendary, the production company of the venture capitalist Thomas Tull, will invest $1 billion in a portfolio of films co-produced by Warner Brothers Pictures.

title: Mideast Leaders Show Support for Abbas as Hamas Releases Tape of Israeli
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 25  The leaders of Egypt, Jordan, Israel and the Palestinian Authority gathered at this Red Sea resort on Monday in a show of support for the emergency government formed by the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah.

title: Racing Wildfire Destroys 165 Homes Near Lake Tahoe
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 25  Lower temperatures and light winds helped firefighters calm a fast-moving wildfire near here on Monday, but not before it destroyed more than 160 homes.

title: Finding Adventure and Trying to Save It
description: I have been lucky enough to convert my passion for travel into a successful travel business. For me, business travel is not misery  it is pleasure. And in the 30 years that Ive been doing my work, I hope that I have made a difference in the way that travelers view the world.

title: Justices Reject Suit on Federal Money for Faith-Based Office
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court on Monday closed the courthouse door on a lawsuit challenging the Bush administrations use of taxpayer money to support its Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Norddeutsche Affineries agreement to buy the Belgian copper smelter Cumerio misstated the price in dollars. It was $1.05 billion in cash, not $105 billion.

title: Mastic: Father Charged With Beating Child
description: A man who reported that his infant daughter was having trouble breathing has been charged with beating and kicking her, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Joshua Cohen, 20, pleaded not guilty yesterday in First District Court in Central Islip at his arraignment on charges of assault and endangering the welfare of a child, prosecutors said. The police said Mr. Cohen became angry on Sunday evening while watching the girl, whose name and age were not released by the police, and knocked her off a bed and kicked her in the head several times. The child was taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center, and was in critical condition yesterday, the police said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Friday about the Senates passage of an energy bill referred incorrectly at one point to the estimated fuel savings that could result from a mandatory increase in the efficiency of passenger vehicles. Consumption could possibly decrease by more than one million barrels a day, not one million gallons a day. (In the petroleum industry, a barrel is equal to 42 gallons.)

title: Staten Island: Boy Drowns in Pool
description: A 2-year-old boy drowned yesterday in an above-ground pool belonging to his relatives, the police said. The boy, identified as James Paccione of Liberty Avenue, Dongan Hills, was taken from the house he had been visiting, on Lovelace Avenue in Great Kills, to Staten Island North Hospital and was pronounced dead on arrival.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: David Arnold joined CurtCo Media, New York, in a new post, senior vice president and group publisher at the Robb Report Magazine Group. He had most recently been publisher at House Beautiful magazine, New York, part of the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Inmate Kills Guard Watching Him at Hospital
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 25  A white supremacist prisoner who was taken to the hospital complaining of lower back pain stole a correctional officers gun on Monday and killed him, the authorities said.

title: When It Comes to Knicks, Draft May Not Be Much Help
description: In an alternate universe, this might have been a momentous week, even a historic week, for New York and its beleaguered N.B.A. franchise. Had the Knicks stripped their payroll a few years back and suffered through some rough seasons, they might be stitching a uniform for Greg Oden or Kevin Durant, the two franchise-changing talents who headline Thursdays draft.

title: Lighten Up, Overeaters. This 7-Foot Giant Is in Touch With His Inner Child.
description: Like the JonBenet Ramsey murder case or Sudoku, the American obesity epidemic presents an absorbing challenge for active minds. Come on, lets just figure it out: Why are we all so fat?

title: Hungary: Interest Rate Is Lowered Unexpectedly
description: Hungarys central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark interest rate, the European Unions highest, for the first time since 2005 after inflation slowed. Policy makers, led by the central banks governor, Andras Simor, left, cut the two-week deposit rate a quarter-point, to 7.75 percent, after holding it since October. A leveling of wage growth also persuaded rate setters to lower borrowing costs, Mr. Simor said. Hungarys annual inflation rate has quadrupled in the last year as Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsanys government raised taxes and utility bills. Inflation excluding food and energy prices slowed for a second month in May, and an easing of pressures in the labor market reduced concern that prices would rise faster than the inflation target in the medium term.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday of Guy Vander Jagt, a former congressman from Michigan, misstated the circumstances under which he filled an unexpired term in the House of Representatives in 1966. He won the seat in a special election; he was not appointed to the position. (Representatives, unlike senators, cannot be appointed to fill seats.)

title: Labor Coalitions Divided on Immigration Overhaul
description: Now that President Bush has rallied Republicans to try again to reshape the immigration laws, supporters of the effort have a new worry. When the bill returns to the Senate floor, probably next week, opposition from labor unions could doom the bills prospects by putting pressure on many Democrats to vote against it.

title: Major Archive Goes to the Anne Frank House
description: Commemorating the 60th anniversary of the first publication of Anne Franks Diary of a Young Girl, a cousin donated thousands of letters, photographs and documents, some shown above, to the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam. Although the archive has little new information about the 25 months that the Frank family and four other Jews hid from the Nazis during the occupation of the Netherlands in World War II, its value lies in illuminating the familys cultured background in Germany and the wellsprings of Franks talent for writing. They spoke four languages, said the cousin, Bernard Elias, 82, who kept the materials in his attic in Switzerland for decades before providing them on permanent loan to the Anne Frank House, the museum incorporating the tiny apartment where the family hid. They were interested in art, theater. When they went to a concert or play, they wrote about it. Thats all in these letters. The donation includes a 1945 letter from Otto Frank informing his mother in Switzerland that his daughters, Anne and Margot, and his wife, Edith, had died in Nazi concentration camps; the letter his mother wrote in response to diary excerpts sent by Otto Frank; and photos from the late 1890s of the Frank family in their native Frankfurt. With Mr. Eliass collection, the museum now holds nearly all known historical material about the family.

title: New Zealand Wins Again in Americas Cup Race
description: VALENCIA, Spain  With the light, shifting winds proving unreliable, the crews on Alinghi and Emirates Team New Zealand had to wait and stew for just about two hours before the third race of this Americas Cup was finally able to begin Tuesday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday about opposition to a planned Wal-Mart in the predominantly Hasidic community of Monsey, N.Y., misidentified the man behind the counter of a discount store whose owners are among the opposition. He is Samuel Spitz, the brother of Mirel Kizelnik, an owner  not her husband, Joseph Kizelnik, co-owner of the store.

title: Obama, in New TV Ads, Focuses on His Pre-Senate Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  In the first television commercials of his presidential campaign, Senator Barack Obama will begin introducing himself to Iowa voters on Tuesday through a pair of biographical advertisements designed to tell the story of his career before he arrived in the United States Senate.

title: Attacker Kills 4 Sunni Sheiks Who Aided U.S.
description: BAGHDAD, Tuesday, June 26  A suicide bomber on Monday assassinated four Sunni sheiks who were cooperating with Americans to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province. Witnesses said the bomber sneaked through security checkpoints, strode into a large Baghdad hotel and detonated an explosive belt just before lunchtime, killing 12 people including the sheiks.

title: Manhattan: Coupons for Light Bulbs
description: New Yorkers will receive a $1 coupon for General Electric fluorescent light bulbs with their Con Edison bills this August as part of GreeNYC, a $3.4 million consumer education campaign in ecology. The effort, which is being provided to the city at no cost, includes posted advertisements and a broadcast and print media campaign, and suggests 10 ways to save energy, like turning off air-conditioners in empty rooms and using public transportation. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg noted at a news conference introducing the campaign that he would start unplugging the charger for his BlackBerry when it is not in use. He said he had always thought that when the charger was plugged in but not charging the BlackBerry, no electricity was being used. Turns out that is wrong, he said.

title: Taking Composing Cues From the Number of Gods
description: Among the holdings of the Rubin Museum of Art is a 16th-century Tibetan mandala painting, about two feet square. On Friday night the alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa played a new piece that he had written, based on that mandala. He performed it with the pianist Vijay Iyer, his partner in the duo Raw Materials; the concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, was in the small, beautiful theater of the Rubin, in the Flatiron district.

title: Companies Not Chasing Bondss Home Run Chase
description: You might have noticed that corporate America has taken a pass on Barry Bonds, that major companies have exhibited little interest in linking their brands to the near-certainty of Bonds hitting his 756th home run this year.

title: School Aide Is Accused of Raping a Student
description: A 25-year-old aide at the elite Hunter College High School in Manhattan was arrested yesterday on charges that he had sex on several occasions with a 15-year-old student at the aides Staten Island home, the authorities said.

title: A Stock Filing Gone Awry for Bear Stearns
description: Early in May, as Bear Stearns executives scrambled to meet redemption requests from clients in two troubled hedge funds, a money management company affiliated with the Wall Street firm filed its intention to sell $100 million worth of shares to public investors.

title: School Official Apologizes for Removing Photo of Kiss
description: His high school apologized for blacking him out, but Andre Jackson, a graduating senior whose kissing summoned the censors, remained unsatisfied.

title: First Round Complete at Ike
description: Two college golfers and a Long Islander in his mid-20s led after the first round of the Metropolitan Golf Associations Ike Championship at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale. Larry Haertel Jr. of Greenwich, the 2006 Ivy League champion from Brown; John Murphy of Brooklawn, who plays at Old Dominion; and Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club, the 2007 Long Island Amateur runner-up, had scores of two-over 72 to lead the field of 104 players. The four-time champion George Zahringer III was a stroke back at 73. Andrew Giuliani, the 2005 champion, shot a 76.

title: Complaints About Schedule Arrive on Time
description: Earlier this month, Boston Red Sox fans were angry. All right, Red Sox fans can often get angry when anyone says anything they construe as negative about their team or positive about their teams archrival, the Yankees.

title: Manhattan: Two Dead in Car Crashes
description: Two drivers were killed in crashes in Manhattan early yesterday, the police said. One, Francis Acosta, 24, of Webster Avenue in the Bronx, was headed north on the Henry Hudson Parkway at a high speed about 3:30 a.m. when his car hit the center divider, the police said. The car flew through the air and crashed onto the southbound West 95th Street exit ramp, the police said. The other driver, Angelo Corpas, 45, of West 138th Street, was killed about 2:30 a.m. when his Cadillac Escalade crashed into a taxi stopped at a red light at East 135th Street and Madison Avenue, the police said. The cabdriver, whose identity was not released, suffered minor injuries, the police said.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Thursday about voting rights for the District of Columbia misstated the number of votes needed to override a presidential veto. It requires two-thirds of those voting in each house.

title: Scientology Cited in Ban of Cruise Film in Germany
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25  United Artists, the mini-studio now controlled by Tom Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, ran into a snag over Mr. Cruises religion Monday in Germany. Officials banned the company from shooting a film at German military sites because of Mr. Cruises adherence to Scientology.

title: Dance Theater of Harlem Reminisces and Looks to the Future
description: There were squeals of recognition, hugs and tears. There was a soire, as the invitation put it, on Saturday night and a picnic on Sunday afternoon in Riverbank State Park in Hamilton Heights. But one theme persisted, beneath the laughing memories and the hopeful chatter at the Gathering, a weekend reunion of performers from Dance Theater of Harlem. How lucky they were, attendees told one another repeatedly in different ways, to have found a place where classically trained African-American dancers could perform.

title: 28-Mile Virtual Fence Is Rising Along the Border
description: SASABE, Ariz., June 21  If the effort to catch people illegally crossing the border here in the southern Arizona desert is a cat-and-mouse struggle, the Homeland Security Department says it has a smarter cat.

title: The Guantnamo I Know
description: Arlington, Va.

title: Supreme Court to Weigh Limits on Cases Involving Medical Devices
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Setting the stage for a confrontation between the states and manufacturers, the Supreme Court said on Monday that it would hear an appeal raising the issue of whether the makers of medical equipment approved by the federal government may be sued under state law by patients injured by those devices.

title: Its Getting Better All the Time for Oregon States Standouts
description: OMAHA, June 25  The long postgame celebration on the field was winding down at Rosenblatt Stadium on Sunday night when Oregon States junior shortstop, Darwin Barney, who minutes before joined with Mitch Canham to raise the Beavers second consecutive College World Series championship trophy, offered a mischievous smile.

title: Mending Fences at World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  For years, rumors of corruption surrounded an ambitious World Bank project for a system of reservoirs and water tunnels in the mountains of Lesotho in southern Africa. In 2002, the project director was convicted of graft and sent to jail.

title: Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, 84, Seen as Hero in Vietnam, Dies
description: Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, a popular and flamboyant South Vietnamese senior officer whose firing in the spring of 1966 set off civil warfare within his own country at the same time it was fighting the Communist north, died Saturday in Lancaster, Pa. He was 84.

title: Word of Mouth, and How to Get It
description: CROCS, those funny looking plastic shoes. In-N-Out Burger. Google, back before it became a verb.

description: A new patient comes into a doctors office weighing 204 pounds. Hes six feet tall. The following conversation ensues:

title: Senate Republicans Block Labor Bill
description: Senate Republicans today blocked the labor movements top legislative priority, a bill that would have made it easier for unions to organize workers.

title: Spaniards Had Help in Conquering the Incas
description: Can a single 500-year-old skull change the way we think of the Spanish conquest? Can a TV show make us care? Yes and yes. In The Great Inca Rebellion tonight, the estimable PBS documentary series Nova revisits the 16th-century siege of Lima, in which the Incas were decimated by Spanish conquistadors.

title: Brooklyn: Man Acquitted of Murder
description: A man was acquitted yesterday in State Supreme Court of charges that he murdered his half-brother. The defendant, Rannik Williams, 23, had been charged with second-degree murder after his half-brother, Michael, 17, was fatally shot in October 2005 in front of the building in East New York where both men lived. Prosecutors said he survived long enough to identify his killer for the police. Rannik Williams was ordered released from jail after his acquittal.

title: The Forces of Neatness Hope to Fill a Niche
description: WITH the popularity of the Internet, blogs and other online communication, you might think that independent magazine publishing is starting to wither. A new magazine called Organize, which makes its debut today, wants to prove that independent magazines are alive and well.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Norddeutsche Affineries agreement to buy the Belgian copper smelter Cumerio misstated the price in dollars. It was $1.05 billion in cash, not $105 billion.

title: Vote Against Banner Shows Divide on Speech in Schools
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Alaska high school student who unfurled a 14-foot banner with the odd message Bong Hits 4 Jesus insisted that it was a banner about nothing, a prank designed to get him and his friends on television as the Olympic torch parade went through Juneau en route to the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City.

title: Human DNA, the Ultimate Spot for Secret Messages (Are Some There Now?)
description: In Douglas Adamss science fiction classic, The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy, there is a character by the name of Slartibartfast, who designed the fjords of Norway and left his signature in a glacier.

title: Three Bad Rulings
description: The Supreme Court hit the trifecta yesterday: Three cases involving the First Amendment. Three dismaying decisions by Chief Justice John Robertss new conservative majority.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (IFC) DOUBLE HAPPINESS (1994) In her first feature film, Sandra Oh of Greys Anatomy (left, in curlers, with Claudette Carracedo) starred as a Chinese-Canadian woman with family issues. The movie is directed by Mina Shum.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Global Drug Use and Production Slowing, U.N. Finds
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 25  The once-predicted global epidemic of drug abuse is being brought under control, though opium production is up in Afghanistan, cocaine consumption is rising in Europe and trafficking is growing in Africa, the United Nations reported Monday.

description: Q. Who are you?

title: Enjoy Your Green Stay
description: Remember when all a hotel had to do to show its concern for the environment was to ask its guests to reuse their towels?

title: Mexico Purges 284 Police Commanders in Antidrug Effort
description: MEXICO CITY, June 25  Mexico purged 284 commanders from the top ranks of its federal police forces on Monday as part of the governments effort to contain corruption and halt an underworld war between drug traffickers.

title: Walking With Presidents and (Hollywoods) Kings
description: The first time I heard Jack Valenti speak, I noted that he was dapper, unexpectedly handsome and short. He had arrived at a meeting of the trustees of the American Film Institute to nominate his friend Kirk Douglas for the annual Life Achievement Award. When he had finished and whirled out, he was still dapper and unexpectedly handsome, but he had grown very big in stature.

title: Poll Shows Liberal Ideas Gaining With Young People
description: Young Americans are more likely than the general public to favor a government-run universal health care insurance system, an open-door policy on immigration and the legalization of gay marriage, according to a New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll. The poll also found that they are more likely to say the war in Iraq is heading to a successful conclusion.

title: Rome Welcomes Tourism Con Brio, but Not Too Much
description: ROME, June 25  There is a struggle under way, taking place in plain view, for the soul of Romes historic center: in one corner sit the forces of restraint, etiquette and cultural preservation, in the other the unswerving desire for just one more round of drinks.

title: Justices Loosen Ad Restrictions in Campaign Finance Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court on Monday took a sharp turn away from campaign finance regulation, opening a wide exception to the advertising restrictions that it upheld when the McCain-Feingold law first came before it four years ago.

title: Back From a Layoff, Hingis Avoids an Upset
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25  Court 2, known as the graveyard of champions, nearly nabbed another victim. The 1997 champion, ninth-seeded Martina Hingis, fought off two match points before beating Naomi Cavaday, an 18-year-old from England ranked 232nd in the world, 6-7 (1), 7-5, 6-0.

title: Team New Zealand and Its Quiet Leader Start to Come of Age
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 25  Sitting on the big stage, Dean Barker can still look like a Kiwi trapped in the headlights as he remains stiff in his chair and fixes his eyes on the large audience gathered before him for an Americas Cup news conference.

title: Prosecutors Invite a Dismissal in KPMG Tax-Shelter Case, Burdened by Technicalities
description: Federal prosecutors trying to bolster their faltering tax-shelter investigation have essentially dared a federal judge to dismiss charges against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG so that they can appeal the ruling and get the case moving again.

title: Chinese Tires Are Ordered Recalled
description: Federal officials have told a small New Jersey importer to recall 450,000 radial tires for pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and vans after the company disclosed that its Chinese manufacturer had stopped including a safety feature that prevented the tires from separating.

title: In Case of Missing Trousers, Aggrieved Party Loses Again
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  A District of Columbia administrative law judge who filed a $54 million lawsuit against his neighborhood dry cleaner over a pair of missing pants will not get a penny, a court here ruled Monday.

description: U.S. and Iraqi soldiers moved house to house in Baquba, Iraq, searching for insurgents, and finding many buildings rigged with explosives.

description: I wont presume to say whether or not readers were acting altruistically  only you know why you took the time to write  but you provided plenty of ideas in response to last weeks column and post about an experiment scanning the brains of people as their money went to charity. As the diehard fans of Harry Potter count the minutes until they can get their hands on Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the seventh and final installment in the monumentally successful series by J. K. Rowling, they are engaging in a frenzy of speculation and rumor-mongering about what will happen to their beloved characters.

description: Frankenstein's castle has its occupants. Full casting has been announced for "The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein."

title: Hop on the bus
description: Visitors to Paris often rave about how convenient and easy to use the Metro is. Its inexpensive, goes everywhere, and is relatively clean and quick. But the big, obvious, drawback is, well, most of it is underground. If youre not in a huge hurry and you want a cheap way to see the city ABOVE ground, hop on a bus.

description: One of the toughest aspects of Darfur to report has been Chinas involvement in Sudan  I know, Ive tried. title: Withdrawn I.P.O. Linked to Bear Fund Raises Questions
description: Everquest Financial, a money management firm with ties to two troubled Bear Stearns hedge funds, on Monday withdrew its proposed $100 million initial public offering.

title: Treehouse Buys Private Food Manufacturer
description: The E. D. Smith Income Fund, a trust that owns a variety of private-label food manufacturing operations, said it planned to sell all of its assets to TreeHouse Foods of the United States in a deal valued at about C$217 million ($203 million).

title: Roche Fires Up Tender Offer for Ventana
description: The Swiss drug maker Roche said Monday that it would start a tender offer to acquire Ventana Medical Systems for about $3 billion, or $75 a share, after its efforts to negotiate a merger were rebuffed.

title: Diller Plans to Keep Control of Expedia
description: Expedia Chairman Barry Diller said Monday he has no plans to cede control of the company to Liberty Media, the travel Web sites other large shareholder. Separately, Breakingviews argued that Mr. Dillers IAC/Interactive should consider streamlining itself by shedding the Home Shopping Network.

title: Spains Iberdrola Fires Up Deal for Energy East
description: The Spanish power company Iberdrola plans to buy the regional utility owner Energy East Corporation for $4.5 billion in cash, the companies announced Monday. The boards of the utilities, meeting in New York and Madrid, agreed to the deal, which would give Energy East shareholders $28.50 a share, representing a 27 percent premium over the closing stock price Friday of $22.37.

title: I.B.M. to Pay Settlement in Dollar General Probe
description: I.B.M. said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $7 million as part of a settlement of a federal regulatory investigation involving Dollar Generals 2000 financial statements.

title: Ex-Chief of Cendant Denied Bid for Release
description: A federal appeals court has denied a request by the former Cendant chairman, Walter A. Forbes, to be released pending an appeal of his conviction in a case over one of corporate Americas biggest accounting scandals.

title: John Hancock Case Is Settled for $21.3 Million
description: The Manulife Financial Corporation will pay $21.3 million to settle claims that its John Hancock investment units secretly diverted client funds to pay for marketing, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

title: Hollingers Former Lawyer Described as Trustworthy
description: Hollinger Internationals former chief lawyer, on trial for fraud with its ex-chairman, Conrad M. Black, is an honest and trustworthy man and should be acquitted of all charges, his lawyer told jurors Monday in closing arguments.

title: Google Seeks Ruling on Microsoft Oversight
description: Google is pressing for an extension to the Justice Departments oversight of Microsofts business practices, which for the most part is set to expire in November, according to a court filing Monday.

title: Investors React to New Worries Over State of Hedge Funds
description: Financial shares tumbled Monday on concern that hedge fund losses tied to subprime mortgages would deepen, extending the stock markets worst weekly decline since March, Bloomberg News reported. Bear Stearns, the second-biggest United States underwriter of mortgage bonds, slid to its lowest level in nine months after a Merrill Lynch analyst said it might have to salvage another hedge fund.

title: Digg Founders Score Funding for Online TV Venture
description: Revision3, an online television network created by Digg founders Jay Adelson and Kevin Rose, pulled in $8 million in second-round venture funding, led by Greylock Partners.

title: U.S. Starts Up 3 Centers for Research on Biofuels
description: The Energy Department is creating three bioenergy research centers to find new ways to turn plants into fuel.

title: Legendary Signs Billion-Dollar Deal to Finance Warner Films
description: In a sign that the flood of private money in Hollywood only continues to rise, Legendary, the production company of the venture capitalist Thomas Tull, will invest $1 billion in a portfolio of films co-produced by Warner Brothers Pictures.

title: Yukos Shareholders Accuse Auditor of Bowing to Kremlin Pressure
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers has withdrawn all its audit reports on the bankrupt Yukos oil company amid a tax-evasion investigation into the accounting firm, a decision that some of the oil producers shareholders said Monday was spineless. The auditor said that it had withdrawn its audits of Yukos from 1995 to 2004 because of new information that could have influenced those reports had it come to light earlier.

title: Prosecutors Invite a Dismissal in KPMG Case
description: Federal prosecutors trying to bolster their faltering tax-shelter investigation have essentially dared a federal judge to dismiss charges against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG so that they can appeal the ruling and get the case moving again.

title: Billionaire Thinks in Trillions for His Computer Designs
description: Twenty-six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student and a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, Andreas Bechtolsheim designed a simple but powerful personal computer workstation that would help define the modern technology era.

title: Upper Deck Goes Hostile in Topps Bid
description: Unable to work out a merger agreement with Topps, its rival baseball card maker, Upper Deck has decided to take its offer directly to shareholders. Upper Deck said late Monday that it would make a tender offer to acquire its rival trading card manufacturer in a deal that values the company at $425 million.

title: Going Public, SPAC-Style
description: Freedom Acquisition Holdings deal to buy the hedge fund GLG Partners shows how special-purpose acquisition companies can offer a useful way to go public through the backdoor. The Financial Timess Lex column notes that these kinds of companies, known as SPACs, have become extremely popular lately, raising $4 billion in the United States so far this year.

title: ICE Steps Up Battle Ahead of Exchange Merger Vote
description: IntercontinentalExchange on Monday commenced its proxy battle to block the merger of Chicago Board of Trade Holdings with Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, urging C.B.O.T. shareholders to vote against the deal.

title: K.K.R. Applies for Broker-Dealer License, Report Says
description: In a move that would enable it to branch into new businesses and possibly bolster its value should it go public, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to obtain a securities broker-dealer license, according to The Deal.com.

title: Wall Street Fetes Clinton Amid Tax Debate
description: Hillary Clinton is set to get a cash injection from Wall Street for her presidential campaign coffers Tuesday night at a fundraising event hosted by Warren Buffett and organized by Morgan Stanleys chief executive, John J. Mack, as well as a slew of other bankers, private equity executives and hedge fund managers, The Financial Times reported.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Open Inquiry into Bear Stearns Fund
description: Bear Stearns may have a lot of explaining to do about a big restatement of losses at one of its troubled hedge funds-and not just to its investors. According to BusinessWeek, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently opened a preliminary inquiry into the near-collapse of Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund.

title: Bell Canada Bidding Group Said to Lose Members
description: Caisse de dpt et placement de Qubec and the Canadian buyout firm Onex have pulled out of a group bidding for Bell Canada, the Globe and Mail reported. Their withdrawal from the consortium, which is led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, throws into question the groups ability to muster an offer for Bell Canada.

title: Barclays Bid Gets Boost from Court Adviser
description: Barclays got a big boost in its takeover battle for ABN Amro when an adviser to the Dutch Supreme Court said that it should allow the Dutch Bank to sell its Chicago-based LaSalle unit to Bank of America.

title: BlackRock to Buy Fund of Funds for $1.7 Billion
description: The asset management firm BlackRock said it had agreed to acquire the fund of funds business of the Quellos Groupfor up to $1.7 billion to expand its alternative investment operations. Following the acquisition, BlackRock said it would combine its hedge and private equity fund of funds activities to form a business that is expected to have more than $25.4 billion in assets under management.

description: The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.

title: S.E.C. to Face Questions in House Committee
description: All five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission will appear before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday, where they are expected to be asked to defend their agency against accusations that it might favor business interests at the expense of protecting investors. The hearing will mark the first time in more than a decade that all S.E.C. commissioners have been called to testify together, the Associated Press reported.

description: Officially, Dell today unveils its hope for the future. At an event this morning in New York, it plans to show off its new line of laptop computers. They are slim, colorful machines that have a lot riding on them given Dells struggles to compete in the consumer market.

description: Despite the frantic arm-waving involved, its hard to get too cutthroat while playing tennis on the Nintendo Wii, the phenomenally popular video game console. After all, you are represented on screen by a little cartoon character with a huge head.

description: The founder of Biovail, the Canadian pharmaceutical company, has filed a $1 million slander suit against a former Banc of America Securities analyst, claiming he was defamed when the analyst called him a criminal, The New York Post reported Tuesday. description: The Bloomberg administration has gained a powerful ally, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, in its long-running effort to open a waterfront recycling station on the Gansevoort pier, just south of West 14th Street. The plan is the last major element of the Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan, a multiyear program that is intended to make each borough handle its fair share of trash and waste.

title: Fred Thompson Makes the Rounds
description: Although he has not officially declared his presidential intentions, Fred D. Thompson, former senator of Tennessee, kicks off what looks a lot like a campaign in Nashville today, with stops this week in South Carolina and New Hampshire.

title: Basell to Buy Rival Huntsman for $5.6 Billion
description: Basell, a division of the billionaire investor Leonard Blavatniks Access Industries, said Tuesday it would acquire a rival chemical company, Huntsman for $5.6 billion, or $9.6 billion including debt. The announcement sent Huntsman shares up $5.40, or 29 percent, to $24.30 at the open of trading Tuesday.

title: They Arent on the Take
description: Few things get a journalists back up as quickly as the suggestion that he or she is somehow on the take, being paid by an interested party to influence what appears in the newspaper. So when Gregory Todd, a New York attorney, wrote to ask how New York Times columnists are compensated and whether Nicholas Kristof is receiving money from an African charity or David Brooks is getting paid by Rupert Murdoch, I forwarded the message to Andy Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, with the thought that his response could be quite interesting, as in pyrotechnic. After all, The Times editorial pages under his leadership are aggressive, to say the least.

description: The showdown anticipated by The Lede and other observers of competitive eating may not happen after all.

description: Ive heard the iPhone referred to both ways: the Jesusphone and the Godphone. Both reflect the miraculous qualities conferred unto this electronic device by the fervent Apple acolytes.

title: Lugar Breaks With Bush on Iraq
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican, is far from a publicity seeker. He rarely speaks on the Senate floor, at least in speeches specifically designed to garner big headlines. But when he does, its surely worth taking a listen.
