title: Arms Flowing Into Lebanon, U.N. Finds
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 26  The present state of border control is inadequate for preventing the smuggling of arms from Syria into Lebanon, according to a report that a United Nations assessment team submitted to the Security Council on Tuesday.

title: Calendar
description: Tasting Wine Before the 6:55

title: The Whole World Is Watching
description: Three years ago, I was catching a plane at Bostons Logan airport and went to buy some magazines for the flight. As I approached the cash register, a woman coming from another direction got there just behind me  I thought. But when I put my money down to pay, the woman said in a very loud voice: Excuse me! I was here first! And then she fixed me with a piercing stare that said: I know who you are. I said I was very sorry, but I was clearly there first.

title: Live Earth Concerts Struggle
description: Less than three weeks after Al Gore, the environmental campaigner and former vice president, visited Istanbul to announce its participation in the round-the-world Live Earth concerts on July 7, organizers announced yesterday that the city had been dropped from the roster of nine sites because of a lack of interest coupled with security concerns in advance of general elections on July 22, Reuters reported. ... In South Africa, organizers seeking to stimulate lagging ticket sales moved the Live Earth concert to the 18,000-seat Coca-Cola Dome in Johannesburg from a site 45 minutes by car from the city, Reuters reported.

title: Lawmakers Criticize Spitzer on Upstate Restoration Plan
description: BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 26  Gov. Eliot Spitzer, born and raised in New York City, made restoring upstate a central campaign theme last year

title: Scant Drug Benefits Called Costly to Employers
description: Health penny wise, medical pound foolish?

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday about an autism court case said incorrectly that the vaccine for mumps, measles and rubella contained a mercury preservative. The preservative, thimerasol, was in other vaccines involved in the hearings.

title: France: Alstom Buys a Wind Energy Company
description: Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotcnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotcnia, which also makes solar panels, it said. The purchase will help Alstom, which is based in Paris, expand in the United States and Asia, it said. Buying Ecotcnia strengthens Alstoms presence in renewable energy as governments seek alternatives to coal, gas and oil. Alstom also sells hydroelectric equipment and worked with Russias state nuclear agency in April to develop atomic plants.

title: W. Learns From Students
description: WASHINGTON

title: George Kovacs, Innovator in Lighting Fixtures, Dies at 80
description: George Kovacs, a designer, manufacturer and importer of innovative and stylish modern lighting fixtures who introduced the ubiquitous halogen torchiere to the United States, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

title: Outcome of an Ad Contest Starts an Uproar on YouTube
description: Some YouTube users cried foul this week when they saw the winning video in a Malibu Caribbean Rum user-generated advertising contest.

title: Reflections in an Ice Cube: The Drinks of Memory
description: ON the most bruising summer days its hard to imagine ever staring down a stove again. Those are the times when stirring sugar into cold tea feels like all the cooking anyone can handle  and that sweetened drink seems like all the nourishment anyone will ever need. After all, the body can burn spare fat cells for days, but it hits real trouble after a few hours without liquid.

title: A Taste of Freedom
description: ONCE when I was about 13 years old, my best friend, Renee, and I did that thing where you each tell your parents that you are sleeping over at the others house, and they dont even check. With relative ease, we found ourselves distinctly unchaperoned and hitchhiking the 20 miles to the Trenton, N.J., train station and catching a train to New York City.

title: Zimbabwe Seeks Indigenous Control of Companies
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 26  Zimbabwes government has put forward legislation that would require virtually all publicly traded companies to cede controlling interests to indigenous citizens, raising the possibility of a sizable redistribution of the countrys remaining wealth at a time when its economy is collapsing.

title: Baghdad Christians Find New Life in Kurdish North
description: KARA-ULA, Iraq  The 70 houses of this tiny village spring from the treeless, arid plain here in the northern tip of Iraq with the uniformity of an army camp.

title: Canadas Policy on Immigrants Brings Backlog
description: TORONTO, June 26  With an advanced degree in business management from a university in India and impeccable English, Salman Kureishy is precisely the type of foreigner that Canadas merit-based immigration system was designed to attract.

title: Ex-Governor Says Conviction Was Political
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 26  The convicted former governor of Alabama, Don E. Siegelman, faced prosecutors who urged a long prison sentence here on Tuesday in a federal corruption case that has unexpectedly transcended the confines of this sleepy state capital.

title: Lindsay Lohan Prolongs Rehab
description: Lindsay Lohan is staying put. Ms. Lohan, who turns 21 on Monday, is going to be doing extended care at the Promises rehabilitation center in Malibu, Calif., according to her mother, Dina Lohan, The Associated Press reported. It was her choice, Ms. Lohan told The Daily News when she appeared on Monday for a hearing in Nassau Family Court in Mineola, N.Y., where Judge Stacy Bennett ordered her and her estranged husband, Michael Lohan, to attend family therapy to reunite him gradually with his two youngest children. Mr. Lohan left prison recently after serving time for drunken driving and attempted assault. Lindsay Lohan checked into the rehabilitation center after she was arrested on May 26 on suspicion of driving under the influence in Beverly Hills. Shes doing great, her mother said.

title: Ex-Interior Aide Is Sentenced in Lobbying Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A federal judge on Tuesday sentenced the former second-ranking official of the Interior Department to 10 months in prison for lying to a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the crooked lobbyist who is now in prison.

title: Russian Says Britains MI6 Tried to Recruit Him
description: A Russian citizen has accused Britains MI6 foreign intelligence service of trying to recruit him while he was abroad. The accusation was made by the authorities and broadcast on national television. The man was not identified but was described as being in fear of his life. Russian television, which is under tight Kremlin control, has repeatedly accused Britain of spying. The campaign intensified last month when a man accused by British prosecutors of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin, said British intelligence had committed the murder.

title: Thousands Gather in Brooklyn for Firefighters Funeral
description: Bagpipes wailed and drums rattled yesterday as thousands of firefighters in dress blues flooded the streets of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, to pay final respects to Daniel F. Pujdak, the 23-year-old firefighter who fell four stories to his death while battling a fire in Brooklyn last Thursday.

title: Hollywood Scrambles as Strike Looms
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26  In Hollywoods upper reaches this week, few are bothering to count past two. As in Adam Sandler has already booked his two pre-strike pictures, so lets try Vince Vaughn.

title: Recipe: Griddled Butterflied Leg of Lamb With Lemon, Herbs and Garlic
description: Time: About 45 minutes plus 30 minutes for marinating

title: G.O.P. Senator Splits With Bush Over Iraq Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee and a steadfast supporter of the president, has conspicuously broken ranks with him on the Iraq war, warning that the United States standing in the world could be irreparably eroded if the White House does not change strategy soon.

title: Study Criticizes Parks Dept. Management
description: The quality of the typical New York City park is determined largely by whether it is in a wealthy or poor neighborhood, according to a study to be released by a private nonprofit group today. The report also indicated that despite budget increases in recent years, the Parks Department is not doing enough strategic planning to manage its parkland properly.

title: Ex-Senator Returns Home but Is Quiet on Candidacy
description: NASHVILLE, June 26  Dozens of self-proclaimed Fred Heads gathered at the airport here Tuesday to welcome home former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee, and to nudge him to seek the Republican Partys nomination for the presidency.

title: Saudi Arabia: Mobile Phone Assets Acquired in Malaysia
description: The Saudi Telecom Company, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the countrys largest mobile phone operator. Maxis has 14 million subscribers in Malaysia and India. Under the agreement, Saudi Telecom will also acquire 51 percent stake in PT Natrindo Telepon Selular, the Maxis subsidiary in Indonesia, the company said.

title: Spike Lee to Try Broadway as Director of Stalag 17
description: The first revival of Stalag 17, the 1951 comedy-drama about American prisoners of war written by two former P.O.W.s, Donald Bevan and Edmund Trzcinski, is scheduled to arrive on Broadway in late spring next year. And in one of the more surprising combinations in recent Broadway history, the director of the new production will be Spike Lee.

title: Pope Tightens Voting Rules for Election of Successors
description: ROME, June 26  Pope Benedict XVI has changed the rules for electing a pope by reinstituting the traditional requirement that two-thirds of the cardinals in the conclave agree on a candidate, no matter how long the process takes.

title: Accord Seen on Oversight of Journal
description: Negotiators reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, an important step toward a purchase by the News Corporation of The Journals owner, Dow Jones & Company, people briefed on the talks said.

title: Recipe: Sour Cherry Syrup
description: Adapted from Najmieh Batmanglij

title: Canada: Manulife Acquires a Fund Sales Group
description: The Manulife Financial Corporation, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Groups mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business. The deal is part of a plan by Manulife of Toronto to expand its mutual funds unit. The takeover creates a sales force of 1,500 independent advisers and a business with about 19 billion Canadian dollars ($17.7 billion) in assets under administration. The price was not disclosed.

title: Pointing to Stability, Kurds in Iraq Lure Investors
description: ERBIL, Iraq  It is a measure of soaring Kurdish optimism that government officials here talk seriously about one day challenging Dubai as the Middle Easts main transportation and business hub.

title: MySpace, Chasing YouTube, Upgrades Its Offerings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26  Two years ago, millions of MySpace users began adding video clips to their profile pages, helping to give rise to YouTube, which Google bought last October for $1.65 billion.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/CBS News/MTV Poll of young adults is based on telephone interviews conducted June 15 through June 23 with 659 people ages 17 through 29 living in households throughout the United States.

title: Delay in Buyout Bond Sale
description: US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the units equity buyout, people involved in the transition said yesterday.

title: A Lark Amid the Peacocks
description: YOU can look at the new Landmarc in the Time Warner Center as just another meat-mad, wined-up refueling station for New Yorks sputtering masses, a place willing to surrender any intimacy and many niceties in the interests of accommodating serious traffic. With 300 seats, its three times the size of the original Landmarc in TriBeCa, whose menu and competent cooking it replicates but whose warmth it largely lacks.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A theater review on Monday about Romeo and Juliet, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliets age in the play. She is 13, not 14.

title: Grasss Fact and Fiction, Fighting to a Draw
description: In 1945, with the Wehrmacht on the run, a 17-year-old private by the name of Gnter Grass cowered in a cellar in eastern Germany. As house-to-house fighting raged in the village outside, his platoon was ordered to mount some bicycles hanging from the ceiling and make a dash for it. Mr. Grass, who had never learned to ride, stayed behind to provide covering fire, then watched as Russian machine guns turned his comrades into a twitching pile of corpses.

title: U.S. Investigates Saudi Deal for British Arms, Company Says
description: LONDON, June 26  The United States Justice Department has started a formal corruption investigation into business conducted by BAE Systems, Europes biggest weapons maker and a supplier to the Pentagon, the company announced Tuesday.

title: The End of an Era at Bellevue and a Nearby Church
description: For 17 years, his feet have hit the sidewalk at 5 a.m., always ahead of the first dash of daylight. Then Philip Marani walks the few blocks from his home on East 28th Street to First Avenue, into Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Recipe: White Sangria
description: 2 small white nectarines or white peaches

title: Tentative Accord Reached on Dow Jones Control
description: Negotiators reached an agreement in principle today for guarding the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal if its parent, Dow Jones & Company, is sold to the News Corporation, people briefed on the talks said.

title: A.F.I. Appoints New Leader
description: The American Film Institute, the countrys leading organization for film history and preservation, yesterday named Bob Gazzale, a film historian and television producer, to be its president and chief executive. He will succeed Jean Picker Firstenberg, who is retiring in the fall after 27 years of heading the institute, which is based in Los Angeles. Mr. Gazzale, 42, becomes just the third person to lead the organization since its creation in 1967. The institutes board, including its chairman, Howard Stringer, chairman of the Sony Corporation, unanimously voted him in yesterday. He has been with the institute since 1992, mainly serving as the director of A.F.I. Productions. In a statement, Mr. Stringer said, As we say in the movies, we searched for brain, heart and courage, and found it all in our own backyard.

title: The Evolution of Sauvignon Blanc
description: THE sauvignon blanc grape owes a lot to New Zealand. Thirty years or so ago nobody knew much about it at all. Sure, it was a component of white Bordeaux, and yes, it was part of the blend in the great sweet wines of Sauternes. It made wonderful white wines in the Loire Valley, particularly in Sancerre and Pouilly-Fum, as it still does.

title: Correction: If Rules Change, Will Camembert Stay the Same?
description: An article last Wednesday about French cheese makers who have stopped making Camembert with raw milk and have withdrawn from the government program that certifies that they use traditional methods misstated some of the standards for that certification, called an Appellation dOrigine Contrle. To have an A.O.C., a Camembert from Normandy must be made with unfiltered raw milk, and have a fat content of 38 percent. It is not the milk that has to have a fat content of 38 percent.

title: BlackRock Spending $1.7 Billion to Get Fund of Funds Operation
description: BlackRock, the rapidly growing asset management company, said yesterday that it had acquired the fund of funds business of the Quellos Group, a boutique investment firm in Seattle.

title: Comparing Todays Tactics With Those Used in the Past
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  When the Central Intelligence Agency took a nervous look at its past in 1973, one potential illegal act officials identified was the treatment of a K.G.B. officer named Yuri Nosenko. After fleeing to the United States in 1964, Mr. Nosenko was held in a makeshift jail for three years and subjected to tough questioning to determine whether he was a genuine defector or a plant.

title: Worthy Goal of Flawed Bill: Aiding Unions
description: In the spring of 1949, the men who ran the steelworkers union decided to pick a fight over health insurance and pensions.

title: Renovating Stables in Poland
description: Levis Minford has never bought a house that was finished. Building and renovating have become almost a habit for Mr. Minford, a native of Idaho, and he always has some kind of construction project going on. So it was no surprise that, when he was looking for a house outside Warsaw, he settled on an 18th-century stable that had to be turned into a house.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Monday about Romeo and Juliet, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misstated Juliets age in the play. She is 13, not 14.

title: Workers Split With Bosses on Leave Act, Survey Finds
description: After soliciting 15,000 comments about the Family and Medical Leave Act, the Labor Department will issue a report today concluding that the public likes the law, but corporate America has big problems with it.

title: Harry Potter Makes Money
description: A first edition of the first Harry Potter adventure worked financial magic yesterday when it was sold at auction in London for $18,000, the BBC reported. The J. K. Rowling novel, issued in Britain in 1997 under the title Harry Potter and the Philosophers Stone, above (the title in the United States is Harry Potter and the Sorcerers Stone), is a rarity, according to the auction house, Bonhams. The publisher, Bloomsbury, gave it an initial press run of 500 copies. Bonhams sold the book to an anonymous buyer. The seller was an unidentified woman who had bought it originally with book tokens that she had been given as a school prize.

title: In the Backyard, Fireplaces
description: Steve and Terri Tucker have three fireplaces in their vacation home, but it is the fireplace on the deck that gets the most attention. Even in the summer months, when evening temperatures rarely fall below 60 degrees in the mountain town of Blue Ridge, Ga., Mr. Tucker said, the outdoor fireplace definitely gets used. In fact, he said they light it every single day.

title: Tu, at Peak of Career, Moves Into 2nd Round at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

title: Trooper in Near-Fatal Crash Is Driving Corzine Again
description: TRENTON, June 26  He was criticized by a police review panel for not being alert enough to prevent a car accident that almost killed the governor. And he is on the verge of being suspended for several days after violating police procedures for excessive speeding and the use of emergency lights.

title: Recipe: Long Island Iced Tea
description: Adapted from Gabrielle Hamilton

title: Senate Issues Subpoenas in Eavesdropping Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Senate Judiciary Committee today issued subpoenas to the White House, Vice President Dick Cheneys office and the Justice Department after what the panels chairman called "stonewalling of the worst kind" of efforts to investigate the National Security Agencys policy of wiretapping without warrants.

title: Brooklyn: Pizzeria Reopens
description: A popular Brooklyn pizzeria reopened on Saturday nearly three weeks after it was cited by the city health department for unsanitary conditions. Di Fara Pizza, at East 15th Street and Avenue J in Midwood, was closed after it failed an inspection on June 4, when inspectors found flies, a mouse infestation and bare-hand contact with food. That was the second time since March that the shop had been closed this year. After a visit last week, Di Faras reopened. We passed the inspection, Dominick DeMarco, the son of the owner, said last night. Its just all bureaucracy. You have to go through the paperwork.

title: Family of a Captured Israeli Soldier Gets Word to Hamas, via Norway
description: JERUSALEM, June 26  Two weeks before Mondays release of an audiotape of a captured Israeli soldier in Gaza, his father set in motion a request to Hamas, the Islamic militant group holding the soldier, for some sign that the young man was alive.

title: Oracles Revenue Climbs 20%, Helped by Acquisitions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26  Fourth-quarter revenue at the Oracle Corporation, the software company, beat Wall Streets projections on Tuesday as it continued to ride its three-year buying spree, leading its executives to claim substantial gains over its competitors.

title: Evaluating the Evaluators (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: 29 Are Accused of Smuggling Fake Goods Into the U.S.
description: Twenty-nine people were charged yesterday in three federal complaints that described a network of international plots to smuggle nearly $700 million in real and counterfeit goods from China through Kennedy International Airport and seaports in Newark, Houston, Staten Island and Long Beach, Calif.

title: Files on Illegal Spying Show C.I.A. Skeletons From Cold War
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Long-secret documents released Tuesday provide new details about how the Central Intelligence Agency illegally spied on Americans decades ago, including trying to bug a Las Vegas hotel room for evidence of infidelity and tracking down an expert lock-picker for a Watergate conspirator.

title: The Cherries of Persia
description: THE ruby-colored iced drink came in a tall glass set on a painted tray. There were other offerings: ice water, hot tea. But the bright color beckoned.

title: After Two Days and Four-Plus Hours, Henman Advances
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26  Tim Henman arrived Tuesday at Center Court, again, carrying a bag of rackets and the anxiety of a nation. He came to put an end, good or bad, on the most riveting match in Wimbledons first 24 hours. Fans and television cameras unblinkingly tracked his every move.

title: Chinese Company Denies Tire Defect
description: SHANGHAI, June 26  The Chinese manufacturer of 450,000 tires that United States regulators have ordered to be recalled denied Tuesday that they were defective, saying the accusations might be fabricated.

title: The Queen Got It Wrong: No Hands Are Kissed
description: LONDON, June 27  It had been so often foretold as to seem an anticlimax. But finally  and not quite as in the movie starring Helen Mirren  Gordon Brown got his Queen moment today when he took over from Tony Blair as prime minister of Britain.

title: Half the World Soon to Be in Cities
description: By next year, more than half the worlds population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, a number expected to swell to almost 5 billion by 2030, according to a United Nations Population Fund report released today.

title: Spain: 3 Suspected Qaeda Recruiters Arrested
description: The police arrested three Moroccan men in Barcelona on suspicion that they had links to the North African terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, and belonged to a terrorist cell that recruits and equips militants. They were detained at the request of the Moroccan authorities.

title: Japan: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in a Bottler in Tokyo
description: The Coca-Cola Company will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed. The Takanashi family, which founded the bottler 50 years ago, will retain control of about 65 percent of the company, Charlie Sutlive, a Coca-Cola spokesman, said.

title: With Eye on Future, U.S. Takes Youngsters on Trip to Venezuela
description: Talk about a quick turnaround. Only hours after defeating Mexico in the final of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Sunday in Chicago, Coach Bob Bradley and an ersatz United States national team were preparing to leave for Venezuela. The inexperienced American team, which includes 11 players who have made fewer than five appearances for the senior national team, opens play in Copa Amrica tomorrow against Argentina.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the Hayward clan of the Mashantucket Pequots of Connecticut, which led the tribe into the casino era but now feels rejected by its current leaders, misstated a comment by John L. Holder, executive assistant to the tribal chairman, about Richard A. Hayward, the tribes former leader. He said Mr. Hayward had become rude and undiplomatic as chairman  not undemocratic.

title: Brown Assumes Power in Britain
description: LONDON, June 27  On a day of poignant farewells and sober new promises, Gordon Brown took over Wednesday from Tony Blair as prime minister, offering Britain a pledge to try my utmost and declaring, Now, let the work of change begin.

title: Zahringer Wins Fifth Ike Championship
description: George Zahringer III of Deepdale Golf Club won the 52nd Metropolitan Golf Association Ike Championship yesterday at Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale by four strokes over Andreas Huber of Garden City Golf Club. Zahringer, 54, won his fifth Ike title and became the oldest champion in tournament history. He shot 75-71 yesterday for a 219 total.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the refurbished Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden at the New York Botanical Garden referred incorrectly to David Rockefellers donation in the 1980s for the renovation of an earlier rose garden at the same site. It was in honor of his wife, Peggy, not in memory of her. (She died in 1996.) The article also misstated the name of one kind of rose on display and erroneously listed part of the name as a variety. It is the Rita Levi Montalcini (named after the Nobel Prize winner Rita Levi-Montalcini), not the Rita Levi, and there is no rose called simply the Montalcini.

title: Senate Republicans Block Bill on Unionizing
description: Senate Republicans yesterday blocked the labor movements top legislative priority, a bill that would have made it easier for unions to organize workers.

title: Con Eds Rate Increase a Hard Sell in Council
description: With frustration from last summers Queens blackout hanging over the proceedings, City Council members grilled a Consolidated Edison official yesterday over the utilitys proposed electricity rate increase.

title: Six of the Best and Brightest, Poised to Take the Next Step on the Long Road
description: They are the children of immigrants, or the latest in a long line of siblings to graduate from public schools. These are the valedictorians of New York City. Some will enroll at the City University of New York, others are off to colleges in California and Texas and Maine. They are violin players, dancers, singers and student government leaders. They aspire to be engineers or writers or architects. Many are the first in their family to graduate from high school.

title: Cheneys Theory of Government (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Asked for Apology, Japan Plays for Time in Sex Slavery Standoff
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, June 27  Even before a United States Congressional panel overwhelmingly passed a resolution on Tuesday urging Japan to apologize for its wartime sex slavery, the Japanese government said it would have no comment.

title: Wrestler Killed Wife and Son, Then Himself
description: ATLANTA, June 26  Chris Benoit, a professional wrestler known as the Canadian Crippler, killed his wife and 7-year-old son in their house in Fayetteville, Ga., over the weekend before taking his own life by hanging himself with a cable from a weight machine in his home gym, investigators said Tuesday.

title: Carrier From Western Provinces Ends Bell Canada Bid
description: OTTAWA, June 26  Telus, the Western Canadian telephone company, unexpectedly withdrew its bid for its larger rival, Bell Canada, on Tuesday while some partners in one of three separate bids to take the company private also walked away.

title: Same-Sex Marriage: Parsing the Arguments (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Slaying Suspect Is Questioned in Second Killing
description: A Bronx man who was arrested last week on charges that he killed a man during a botched burglary two years ago is being questioned in the 2003 shooting death of a Hunter College student who was killed after leaving a meeting of peace activists in Harlem.

title: France: Chirac Faces Corruption Inquiry
description: Former President Jacques Chirac will very probably be questioned in the coming months about a corruption scandal involving political no-show jobs when he was mayor of Paris, his lawyer, Jean Veil, told Europe-1 radio. Two years ago, his ally and former prime minister, Alain Jupp, was convicted in the case, which investigators say helped finance Mr. Chiracs party as it drained millions of dollars from the citys coffers. Mr. Chirac has refused to testify in two other cases that involve events during his years as president: a political dirty tricks campaign and the mysterious death of a French judge in Djibouti in 1995.

title: Doubts Emerge About Passage of Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Senate immigration bills chances of passage seemed in doubt late this afternoon as several lawmakers signaled that they were undecided about supporting the legislation.

title: Manhattan: New Labor Council President
description: The New York City Central Labor Council announced yesterday that Gary La Barbera was elected president at a delegates meeting on Monday night. Mr. La Barbera, 47, is president of a Teamsters local representing 4,000 construction industry drivers and heads the Teamsters district council for the New York metropolitan region, representing 100,000 Teamsters. He succeeds Brian M. McLaughlin, who headed the labor council for 11 years before he was indicted in October on charges of obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribery. The delegates approved a new constitution that gives Mr. La Barbera less power than Mr. McLaughlin had. The councils board will have more powers; the president will serve as chairman of the board, sharing responsibilities with an executive director who runs operations day to day.

title: Mets Prefer Lo Duca Not Delay Suspension
description: There is no way, no how, Paul Lo Duca said, that he intends to miss any of the Mets four games this weekend in Philadelphia. But he may not have a choice.

title: Young Americans Are Leaning Left, New Poll Finds
description: Young Americans are more likely than the general public to favor a government-run universal health care insurance system, an open-door policy on immigration and the legalization of gay marriage, according to a New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll. The poll also found that they are more likely to say the war in Iraq is heading to a successful conclusion.

title: Bill Giving Illegal Residents Connecticut Tuition Rates Is Vetoed by the Governor
description: HARTFORD, June 26  Gov. M. Jodi Rell vetoed a bill on Tuesday that would have provided state tuition rates for illegal immigrants at state colleges and universities in Connecticut, saying she did not want to encourage the flouting of federal immigration laws.

title: Europeans Critical of Romania and Bulgaria
description: Bulgaria and Romania will receive stern rebukes from the European Commission today for failing to root out corruption and organized crime, officials said, adding to concerns that the nations, which became members of the European Union on Jan. 1, were admitted prematurely. According to a draft report on Bulgaria, contract killings remain a concern.

title: Film Portrays Stifling of Speech, but One Colleges Struggle Reflects a Nuanced Reality
Expressing Unsteadiness in Lyrics, but a Clear Focus in Delivery
description: I have no idea how this happens, Jeff Tweedy sang at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night. All of my maps have been overthrown. As his band Wilco chugged soulfully behind him, he continued: Happenstance has changed my plans/So many times my heart has been outgrown.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on June 13 about a more hospitable approach to day laborers taken by the village of Mamaroneck, N.Y., referred imprecisely to the number of hiring sites in the country. According to the National Day Labor Organizing Network, there are approximately 65 formal sites, like the one at the Strait Gate Church in Mamaroneck. But there are hundreds more informal gathering places for day laborers, including street corners and parking lots. (The first nationwide study of day laborers, released in 2006, counted more than 500 sites.)

title: Our Family Hostage Crisis
description: Fairfax, Va.

title: Senate Takes Up a Revised Immigration Bill, but Obstacles Remain
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  By a vote of 64 to 35, the Senate decided on Tuesday to take up a revised version of a comprehensive immigration bill that was pulled from the Senate floor nearly three weeks ago.

title: Food Stuff
description: New in the Village, the Spices of India

title: Liz Claiborne, Designer, Dies at 78
description: Liz Claiborne, the designer of indefatigable career clothes for professional women entering the workforce en masse beginning in the 1970s, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Not the Elusive Bluefin, but Just Fine for the Fire
description: BY now, everyone is well convinced that tuna is a fine replacement for steak. And by now, many people have realized that the absolute best tuna  bluefin  has been overfished. The result is that its scarce, hard to find, practically unaffordable when available and largely reserved for the classiest Japanese restaurants for use in sushi.

title: May Your Grill Always Be Smokin
description: I LEFT the suburbs 24 years ago and never looked back. The one thing I didnt count on missing was the barbecue, which is what we called it in the olden days, when it was still a tub full of charcoal briquettes topped by a wobbly grate. These days its known as the grill, and it can resemble a stainless steel spaceship, a birdhouse or a bungalow.

title: Ad Forecaster Lowers Estimates
description: A leading forecaster of advertising spending has again reduced his estimate for growth in the United States this year, joining other experts who have also trimmed their predictions.

title: Welcome at the Border: Thai Fruits, Once Banned
description: FRESH mangosteens and mangoes from Thailand will soon be available in the United States, the Agriculture Department has decided. Those fruits  as well as fresh pineapples, rambutans, litchis and longans  had been barred as imports from Thailand because they could harbor harmful insects, but will be allowed in when irradiated at low doses to kill or sterilize the pests.

title: Mosquitoes Have the Edge in Singapores Dengue War
description: SINGAPORE, June 26  Under the sink, behind the cleaning detergents, Thurainadan Govindarajoo shined his flashlight into the shadows, searching for telltale signs of the enemy.

title: General Motors to Change Ad Agencies
description: General Motors, once famously loath to change advertising agencies, did so today for the second time in five months  and the third time in a year  by shifting the national creative assignments for the Buick and GMC brands to the agency that creates national campaigns for Pontiac.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A headline on an article in Business Day on Saturday about the efforts of some companies to provide health insurance for retirees too young for Medicare overstated the number of retirees the program might help. Although about 800,000 early retirees are said to be without health insurance, the programs organizers say the plan would probably help only a fraction of them, not all.

title: Nascar Continues to Be Strict on Illegal Modifications of Cars
description: Five Nascar teams were severely penalized before the season-opening Daytona 500 to send a message through the Nextel Cup garage. Apparently, that has not stopped other teams from tinkering with racecars and breaking the rules.

title: Art Critic or Vandal? The Splasher Leaves Clues
description: Street artists have speculated for months about the identity of a mysterious figure who has become known as the Splasher because he or she hurled colorful blobs of paint at prominent pieces of art on exterior walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.

title: Get Out the Lederhosen and Prepare to Oompah
description: BEER + sun + sausage = joy.

title: Strength in America Is Not Just in the Oval Office, Edwards Says
description: This 30-second television advertisement for John Edwards is his campaigns first big media buy. It will run only in New Hampshire, the first primary state and one where polls show him running behind a number of other Democrats. At the moment, the campaign has no plans to run the advertisement in Iowa, where Mr. Edwards has invested considerable campaigning time and has shown strength in polls.

title: Letters
description: The Future of a Famous Cheese

title: Theyre More Evolved That Way
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Night Is Steamy, Yankees Are Steamed
description: BALTIMORE, June 26  Andy Pettitte was bothered by his performance Tuesday night, when he walked five Baltimore Orioles and mostly got away with it. But Pettitte sees what is happening around him, and it is almost too much to take.

title: 2 Oil Firms Are Defiant in Venezuela
description: HOUSTON, June 26  ConocoPhillips and Exxon Mobil refused on Tuesday to meet Venezuelas deadline to reach an agreement on ceding control of their major oil production ventures, in what could be their imminent separation from billions of dollars in investments.

title: How Could There Be Ballet Before the Swans Learned to Dance?
description: Its hard to imagine what the art of ballet was before Swan Lake came along. It classically encapsulates so very much about the whole romance of ballet: the Age of Chivalry; the destiny-laden call to the lakeside and the quest to save the enchanted maiden; the swan-

title: Chinas Leader Vows to Uphold One-Party Rule
description: BEIJING, June 26  President Hu Jintao said attempts to modernize Chinas political system must not jeopardize one-party rule, setting a conservative tone before an important Communist Party conclave in the fall.

title: Oden Is Solid on and Off the Court
description: Greg Oden held a tissue in his left hand, coughed like a truck rumbling through Times Square and graciously extended his right hand.

title: For a Future Thats Always Rosy
description: HIDDEN within our current tastes and penchants are the persistent and often ignoble residues of our former selves. I call it the Holly Golightly-Lula Mae Principle. Allow me to demonstrate how it works.

title: Pick Your Poison: Fists or Fireballs
description: The gasping, grunting and oozing hard-body slab that muscles, and sometimes crawls, through "Live Free or Die Hard" sure looks like John McClane. Older if apparently no wiser, the blue-collar super-cop from the "Die Hard" franchise has lost his hair, his foul mouth and apparently his nicotine itch, but he still has the same knack for trouble, the adrenaline-pumping, cheerfully anarchic kind that causes cars to ignite, bodies to fly, eardrums to pop and hearts to race and gladden. He's also lost his sneer, but sneering is cheap, and movies are expensive, especially when your star has pushed past 50 and slid off the power lists.

title: Differences Remain at Nato-Russia Meeting
description: Russian and NATO leaders meeting in Moscow mitigated confrontational statements but failed to resolve disagreements on a range of issues, including a European arms-reduction treaty and American missile-defense plans, ahead of President Vladimir V. Putins meeting with President Bush in Maine next week. Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, the NATO secretary general, advised all sides to lower the volume.

title: Frump-Free Cooking: The Look That Sizzles
description: FLIP through the channels or scan the bookstores and the look is there in all its glory: sort of tight, sort of low-cut, definitely sexy. Its the new uniform of women who work with food.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about reaction at a reunion of Antioch College alumni to a decision to close the college misstated the number of students who enrolled in 2006. It was 130  not 63, which was the number of new students in 2005.

title: Styrofoam, Food and Public Schools
description: Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.

title: Frugal Traveler: South Dakota & Nebraska
description: The Frugal Traveler visits a cave in South Dakota, then heads to Nebraska to see Carhenge, a replica of Stonehenge made with cars.

title: Independent Label, Partisan Vote
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, once a Democrat and then a Republican, rattled the presidential campaign last week with his announcement that he now considers himself to be a political independent. People wondered if it was just the latest calculated step by the billionaire mayor in a quest for the White House.

title: 36 Hours in Savannah
description: New ideas join the old in the heart of the gracious South.

title: Asymptote Manhattan
description: Images from the architects' new condo project on Perry Street.

title: A Brief History of Wooden Sawhorses
description: For decades, wooden sawhorse barriers have been a mainstay at parades and demonstrations in New York City, from the arrival of the Beatles in 1964 to the New Years Eve celebrations in Times Square each year.

title: Bottles, Bottles Everywhere but Nowhere to Recycle
description: Check out the picture of Rome on the front page of Tuesdays IHT It tells two stories: 1. As the article notes, there is too much drinking on the streets of Romes historic center. 2. (And this is more important from our blogs point of view) There are way too few garbage cans in Romes center city and no recycling bins whatsoever. Soin this blistering hot town, people who drink bottled water, soda, beer, booze, whatever, are more or less forced to put bottles and cans into general garbage, or (often) just leave them somewhere street side. There is no way to recycle.

title: Saudi Telecom Phones In Malaysia Deal
description: Saudi Telecom, the largest phone company in Saudi Arabia, bought a 25 percent stake in Maxis Communications of Malaysia for 11.4 billion riyals ($3 billion) to tap growth in developing markets like India. Saudi Telecom bought the shares from a Malaysian billionaire, T. Ananda Krishnan, who last month offered to buy the 40 percent that he did not already control in Maxis, which is based in Kuala Lumpur and is the countrys largest mobile phone operator.

title: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in a Bottler in Tokyo
description: Coca-Cola will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Manulife Inks Deal to Boost Wealth Management Business
description: Manulife Financial, a Canadian life insurance company, said it would buy the Berkshire-TWC Financial Groups mutual fund and securities dealerships to bolster its Canadian wealth management business. Manulife said the deal would double its number of Canadian wealth management advisers and triple its assets under administration in that business.

title: Alstom Powers Up Deal for Spanish Wind Company
description: Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotcnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotcnia, which also makes solar panels, it said.

title: U.S. Sues Merrill on Treatment of Muslim Analyst
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Merrill Lynch on Tuesday over its treatment of an Iranian Muslim, who the commission says was an analyst in the banks global markets and investment banking model development group.

title: 3 Ex-Officers at Countrywide Admit Insider Trading
description: Three former executives of Countrywide Financial, a mortgage lender, have agreed to plead guilty to insider trading in the week prior to the release of a disappointing earnings report, federal prosecutors have said.

title: An Entrepreneur Makes Death a Business
description: J. Robert Hillier has spent the last 41 years spreading architectural gems across the United States. Now, he is into death and destruction. Why not? Entrepreneurs get to do whatever they want.

title: Hong Kongs $2 million dinner backdrop
description: Lisa Lam and Joyce Lau from the IHTs Hong Kong office weigh in on dining with a view:

title: Regulators to Examine C.D.O. Investments
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has a string of potentially overzealous hedge funds in its sights.

title: Not Yet Legal for the Street, but a Whiz on a Tractor
description: Nicole Snyder doesn't have a drivers license, but she is in control when it comes to piloting a 7,000-horsepower jet tractor.

title: The  16-Page Splasher Manifesto
Jurors Are Expected to Get Conrad Blacks Case Today
description: After nearly 15 weeks in court, lawyers in the trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black neared the end of their arguments Tuesday, with the jury expected to begin poring over 100 pages of instructions starting Wednesday.

title: The Cyclone's 80th Birthday
description: Stilt walkers entertained crowds, a brass band played, Miss Cyclone made an appearance and a few octogenarians took a ride, all in honor of the Cyclone at Coney Island.

title: In Silicon Valley Real Estate, Steady but Cautious Growth Returns
description: Silicon Valleys economy, notorious for its booms and busts as it rode each new wave of technology, is on the upswing again. Led by a variety of industries, including clean energy, biotechnology and new media, the regional economy, this time more sober than speculative, is adding jobs. And Thomson Financial says venture capital investments in Silicon Valley rose to $10.5 billion last year, the highest level since 2001.

title: Nordstrom to Sell Faonnable to Lebanese Investment Firm, Report Says
description: Nordstrom appears to have reached a deal to sell its Faonnable chain to a Lebanese private equity firm for about $200 million, The New York Post reported. The report said that Faonnable employees received word of the impending sale on Tuesday, along with the potential for some job cuts.

title: Citigroup in Talks to Buy Automated Trading Desk, Report Says
description: Citigroup is in advanced talks to buy Automated Trading Desk, an electronic trading firm, for about $700 million, The Wall Street Journal reported. The report noted that the deal marks the latest push by the banking giant into the trading of stocks by computerized programs rather than by people.

title: Blackstone Said to Quit Coles Bidding Group
description: The Blackstone Group has become the latest to pull out of a consortium bidding for the Coles Group, the Australian retailer, Reuters reported, improving the prospects of a rival suitor, Wesfarmers.

title: Cash in Hand, Hedge Funds Bail on Big Lots
description: Big Lots, the nations largest seller of overstocked and discontinued items and whose fare includes organic plant food made from chicken droppings, is losing its novelty for its hedge fund investors, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Quayle Joins in Offering a $500 Million Blank Check
description: Former Vice President Dan Quayle and the ex-Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz are joining with the chief executive of the sporting goods maker K2 in a bid to raise as much as $500 million in the second-largest initial public offering of a blank check shell company on record.

title: Londons Candover Lands Stork
description: A London buyout shop, Candover has made an offer valuing Stork, a Dutch conglomerate, at 1.5 billion euros ($2 billion). The companies said Tuesday that Candover will offer 47 euros per share, an 11 percent premium to Storks closing price June 18, the day before talks were announced a week ago.

title: Solar Cell Start-Up Raises $15 Million
description: As solar start-ups continue to attract the eye of venture capital investors, a solar cell developer Stion said it had raised $15 million in a second round of venture capital led by Lightspeed Venture Partners to advance ongoing work in thin-film materials science.

title: French Directors Production Company Prices I.P.O.
description: EuropaCorp, the film production company founded by the French director Luc Besson, set a price range on Tuesday for a stock market listing, which it said would raise more than 70 million euros ($94.2 million).

title: Spitzer Weighs In on Suffolk Dispute  and Aqueducts Future
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Tuesday, after a speech to the state broadcasters association, that he had talked to the principal players in the dispute between the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, and the State Assembly. Things are at a boiling point; perhaps things can calm down and we can reduce it at best to, at least to a simmer and probably below that, the governor said.

title: Carlyle Says Going Public Is an Option
description: The Carlyle Group is apparently evaluating an option to go public, despite speculation  that the private equity industrys boom may be close to hitting a wall and the news that the Blackstone Groups stock closed below its offering price Tuesday.

title: Youngest Player Wins Old-Timers Tournament
description: Alexander Khalifman, 41, has won a tournament in Bazna, Romania, that ran from June 15 to 26. What made the tournament unusual was that the field was made up almost entirely of great players from the 1970s and 1980s. What Khalifman, who won the World Chess Federation championship in 1999, was doing in the field is anybodys guess, but he took advantage of his invitation. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the tournament by scrolling down to where it says Vizualizare.

title: Ex-Comverse Chief Relied On Counsel, Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the fugitive founder and former chief executive of Comverse Technology who faces 35 criminal counts in the United Sates stemming from backdated options, said Tuesday that he relied on lawyers and accountants when dealing with the securities.

title: Two Billion-Plus Deals for Bain Capital
description: Bain Capital agreed to buy the Guitar Center, a retailer of musical instruments, for about $1.9 billion in cash. In a separate deal, Bain said it would acquire Germanys biggest yacht maker, Bavaria Yachtbau, for about 1.3 billion euros ($1.75 billion).

title: More Buyout Jitters: Bond Offering Is Postponed
description: Investors looking for signs that the buyout boom of the past two years may be hitting a wall have two new ones to ponder. US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the units equity buyout. Before the decision, US Foodservice had twice scaled back its debt offering to help finance its $7.1 billion buyout by the equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

title: A Restaurant War, Rising Rents and the Last Day of School
description: Can a restaurants distinctive themes  the shade of paint, the selection of chairs and stools, the layout and materials of the bar, not to mention the recipes and choice of salad dressing  be considered intellectual property?

title: Campaign Cash: Clintons Expectations
description: Is Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign about to beat its own fundraising expectations? Or, perhaps, has it been low-balling them?

title: CommScope to Buy Cable Maker for $2.6 Billion
description: CommScope, a maker of communications equipment, said Wednesday it would buy the Andrew Corporation for $15 per share, or about $2.6 billion. Last year, CommScope offered to buy Andrew, which sells cables and antennas, but quickly withdrew its bid.

title: Dow Jones Accord In Place, But Incomplete
description: Despite reports that the board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation had reached an agreement in principle yesterday on protecting the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal, a firm accord between the two parties that would help pave the way for a takeover is not yet a reality, The New York Times noted.

title: Slide Show: The Cyclones 80th Birthday

title: Tip of the Week: Search Engines
description: TIP OF THE WEEK: Search engines have shortcuts to all kinds of information, like stock quotes and gasoline prices, even song lyrics. In Google or Yahoo, for example, type in phrases like "teaspoons in a pint" and hit the Search button to get unit and measuring information. Both sites can also give you basic currency conversions: Type in "1 USD in GBP" to get a rough idea of the dollar's strength against the British pound sterling. There's more information for using these features at www.google.com/help/features.html and at tools.search.yahoo.com/shortcuts.

title: Once Upon a Radical Time on the Lower East Side
description: Clayton Patterson  ex-teacher, artist, photojournalist, documentarian, as he describes himself  is a man obsessed. His first anthology, Captured: A Lower East Side Film/Video History, published in 2005, took up 586 pages. His latest anthology, Resistance: A Radical Social and Political History of the Lower East Side, weighs in at 624 pages.

The iPhone Challenge: Keep It Quiet
description: David Pogue looks at the features of the new iPhone, as furtively as possible.

title: Pretty in Portugal
description: Exterior

title: More Than Just Squatting (on Domain Names)
description: UPDATE: My editing on this post added language about the various types of businesses built on domains that does not match the way the industry refers to these practices. I wrote a post to correct and explain here.Saul Hansell, Bits Editor

title: 2008: Mrs. Edwards vs. Ann Coulter
description: Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards, keeps making headlines.

title: No More Money from Murdoch?
description: In Rupert Murdochs attempt to buy Dow Jones, the question of price has been on the back burner of late, overshadowed by negotiations over a framework for protecting the editorial independence of the companys flagship publication, The Wall Street Journal.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Kevin Young
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the celebrity playlists on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

title: Poison Ivy, Now With Stronger Poison
description: Summer is back, and so is poison ivy, stronger than ever. The weed is flourishing this year, growing faster and more toxic, and a pair of studies flagged by The Wall Street Journal say an upswing in greenhouse gases is to blame.

title: Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko
description: A Russian defector held in a secret CIA prison in the U.S. to determine whether he was a legitimate defector or a Russian intelligence plant. Nothing new. The tale has been told in numerous books and articles over the years.

title: Beyond the Jewels, Unfinished Business
description: Releasing the family jewels is a big step forward for the C.I.A. But dont revel in the glasnost just yet. There are still troves upon troves of documents that the C.I.A., F.B.I., and other intelligence agencies are keeping locked away. Dirty tricks from the 1960s and 70s make for interesting reading. But understanding what went wrong before 9/11 makes for better intelligence.

title: At AOL, the Worlds News Is One Big Blog
description: Blogging and news is in the air here at Bits, so we were interested to note that AOL has restructured its entire news site as a blog.

title: A Business Opportunity
description: How would you like a business where you have to sell expensive items at low margins in a fast changing business to fickle consumers? And oh yes, Wal-Mart is coming on strong as a competitor.

title: Whos at the Copa? (Group C)
description: The third and final quartet features the monsters of the tournament, Argentina, along with a very experimental United States side. Paraguay and Colombia complete Group C, making it very difficult for the American to advance.

title: Go-Shopping Like Paris Hilton
description: Her name is everywhere.

title: IRAN GAS RATION
description: Two gas stations were torched early Wednesday in Tehran as angry Iranians protested fuel rationing measures suddenly enforced by the government, while many other Iranians lined up to fill their tanks.

title: Gas Rationing Prompts Riots in Iran
description: Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin.

title: Lanvin, Soup to Nuts
description: In between packing my party dresses for couture  isnt that a hoot?  I stopped by to see Alber Elbazs early spring clothes for Lanvin. You can never be too early in fashion these days. Elbaz has been broadening Lanvins concept, thinking more along the lines of a supermarket spree, something here, something there, and has come out with pajamas (Carole Lombardish), prt--porter wedding dresses (throw on and go to the alter or justice of the peace), T-shirts, travel clothes and mainstay looks that will remain in stock. I especially loved a creamy white shirtdress in double-layered silk inspired by a mans dress shirt, with a triple-layer navy chiffon minicoat. A super-simple dress made from two asymmetrical squares of black silk showed how Elbaz is such a pragmatic innovator. His other accomplishment is to bring clear design integrity to shapes that appear simple, in fabrics like polyester (yes!), washed silk and organdy, so that the clothes are hard to copy.

title: They Dont Make Gallows Humor Like They Used To
description: Patrick Knight, sentenced to death for a double murder in Texas, promised to tell a joke as part of his last words at his execution. After soliciting jokes in a Web campaign dubbed Dead Man Laughing and also on CNN, he received over 1,300 submissions. But when the time came last night, his plan crashed and burned, yielding no laughs from what was perhaps the toughest crowd ever.

title: Of Trabants and a Belvedere
description: If you havent read Mark Landlers article on the Trabant, I recommend checking it out.

title: Its Never Too Early to Line Up for That Phone
description: Or is it?

description: The first reviews of the iPhone are in. And I didnt notice the line in front of the Apple store getting shorter.

description: As iPhone Week continues here on Pogues Posts, heres a bunch of cool info about the virtual keyboard that nobodyI mean, not Apple, not the bloggers, not the reviewershas said anything about. [Update: DOH!! Apple JUST posted a video about the keyboard. Hmph. Well, its still not as detailed as what follows.]

title: Now on the Clock  Tedium
description: The National Basketball Association draft at Madison Square Garden tonight is unlikely to have anything that surpasses Brady Quinn's totem act two months ago. Quinn holds the career record for touchdowns at Notre Dame, won the Sammy Baugh Trophy as college football's best quarterback and is even second cousins with one of the bratty kids from "Home Improvement." But, to this point, the most enduring image of his career involved him sitting at a table and doing nothing.

title: New Yorks Parks: A Tale of Two Cities?
description: Parks in poorer neighborhoods are more likely to be in worse condition than parks in wealthier neighborhoods.

title: Jarring
description: My lasting image of Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi will be the children and the jarring contrast between their poverty and their beauty.

title: What We Can Do to Help
description: One of the most common comments we get goes: What can I do to help? You guys talk so much about the problems, and now I want to do something. I dont like to bring up problems without proposing solutions. In this second-to-last entry, I propose concrete action steps to channel passion and idealism into activism and action.

title: Paper View
description: Paper View was a film Id wanted to make for a long time, and July 4th provided me with the perfect excuse.

title: Blackstone Flipping
description: Shares in Blackstone, the private equity company that went public last week in what looked like a successful initial public offering, declined again this morning. But this is one company that knows how to time an investment.

title: Making Podcast Ads More Nimble
description: Fans of Wired, Epicurious and other Conde Nast outlets download nearly 500,000 podcasts from those titles per month, and Conde Nast says it has just found a way to better make money from those clips.

title: The Family Jewels
description: The Times's Tim Weiner discusses the importance of the newly declassified C.I.A. documents known as the "family jewels."

title: Ode to Jersey
description: Almost all states have an official state song. New York, of course, has I Love New York. Some states have more than one state song. Connecticut has a state song (Yankee Doodle) as well as a state cantata (the ever-catchy The Nutmeg). Massachusetts has  and were not kidding here  a state song, a state ceremonial march, a state patriotic march, a state glee club song, a state polka, a state ode, as well as a state folk song (Arlo Guthries Massachusetts). Only New Jersey has none.

title: Cuauhtmoc Blanco: Comic Muse
description: There really is no equivalent for Cuauhtmoc Blanco, not anywhere. He is the clown king of Mexican soccer, but with fire, guile, deadly effectiveness and an enormous ego all part of the mix as well. He was left off the 2006 World Cup team  too much of a jerk, supposedly. But now that the national team is run by Hugooolllll Sanchez (no slouch in the ego department himself), Cuauhtmoc is back with El Tri. Which means greater entertainment value for us all.

title: Toulouse, the Trek
description: In Moulin Rouge, John Hustons 1952 biopic of the French painter and absinthe-bucket Henri Toulouse-Lautrec, Jose Ferrer played the lead  entirely on his knees. The action begins in a Parisian bar, Toulouse-Lautrec sits supping his deathly-green mouthwash  the barman polishes the glasses. Then the painter clambers down off his stool. Suddenly were in his point of view, looking up at the great zinc-topped escarpment of the counter; the barman leans over, peers down at us, and speaks the first line of the movie: So long, Toulouse!

title: Things That Go Boom
description: The 4th of July is one week away. Time to start thinking about blowing things up.

title: WWE Scrambles After Double Murder-Suicide
description: Following a grisly murder scene created by a former champion, World Wrestling Entertainment is trying mightily to cut ties with a deed that echoes a sport that stages brawls between feuding, well-built men.

title: For Blackstone Co-Founder, YouTube Clip Hits Home
description: Most parents would be elated if their childs debut novel got a mention in The New Yorker. But Pete Peterson, senior chairman of the Blackstone Group, seems less than thrilled about it.

description: Democratic Party leaders in New York City tend to be well-known, at least in political circles.

description: The bump on the planned new J.P. Morgan Chase tower near the World Trade Center site is not  as US Magazine might put it if the subject were a pregnant movie star  a fashionable one, according to some critics. The architect has said he might change the design, but only slightly.

title: Hot-Dog Champ Is Coming to Coney Island, Manager Insists
description: Takeru Kobayashis debilitating jaw pain has generated widespread speculation in the world of competitive eating that he might not be able to take part in the Nathans Famous July 4 International Hot-Dog Eating Contest next week  a competition he has won every year since 2001.

title: New Wells Chief Charts Stay-at-Home Deal Strategy
description: John Stumpf, the new chief of Wells Fargo, said Wednesday that it is highly unlikely that the bank will make any big acquisitions outside its existing geographical markets. He did not rule it out, though, telling Reuters that, while we dont want to be big for bigs sake, Wells Fargo would nevertheless look at a larger transaction out of market.

title: After 3 Years, Adelphias Rigases Receive Prison Date
description: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered Adelphias founder and his son to report to prison on Aug. 13, nearly three years after they were convicted in one of the largest corporate frauds in the nations history.

description: And The Lede swings from global warming to one unlikely city breaking out the sleds and parkas.

title: Sheryl and Sheryle

title: The Darfur Infection
description: For the last year it has become increasingly clear that the Darfur virus has been infecting and destabilizing Central African Republic to the southwest. Last years win-a-trip went there, and since then the situation has gotten worse. In addition, a 27-year-old French woman was just killed there, while working for Doctors Without Borders, and so humanitarian groups are going to have to pull back. Now Amnesty International has a new report on the situation:

description: He led Britain for 10 long years, and on his retirement day  he got a new job.

description: In todays paper I wrote about MySpace TV, the social networks challenge to YouTube, a company it inadvertently helped emerge from the nursery when MySpace members began posting YouTube videos to their profile pages. After the jump is a first look at the new MySpace TV home page, which should go live later this week.

title: Tonight: Mexico vs. Brazil
description: Tonight at 845 Eastern time, well bring you our live play-by-play account of the Mexico-Brazil match. Victor Mather will provide the commentary for this marquee first-round matchup.

title: Doing It First, Over and Over and Over
description: Some stories you can pretty much write before they happen. But we write them and people read them in a collective act of mutual reassurance that at least some parts of our crazy world is still predictable.

title: Video: 4 Million Styrofoam Trays a Week
description: Or 850,000 a day. Thats how many pass through the lunch rooms of New York City public schools when classes are in session.

title: Refining the Kitchen
description: Paul and I thought the main floor was working well  except for the kitchen.

title: Fidelity National Rings Up $1.8 Billion for eFunds
description: Fidelity National Information Services said Wednesday that it would acquire EFD/eFunds, a processor of electronic fund transfers and prepaid card transactions, for $1.8 billion, linking two of the nations major financial processors.

title: Spying on Reporters: Part II
description: The Family Jewel documents show in fine detail how the C.I.A., at the direction of high level officials in the Kennedy and Nixon administration, spied on journalists. Top government leaders were infuriated by leaks of classified information to reporters  a view shared by subsequent presidents, including George W. Bush  and instructed the C.I.A. to employ its full arsenal of spy techniques to hunt down the leakers. In some cases, reporters phones were wiretapped, journalists were tailed and observation posts were set up near their offices to track their comings and goings and their visitors. All this was done despite a legal ban on C.I.A. domestic spying.

title: Young Voters on 2008
description: A recent New York Times/CBS News/MTV poll asked young voters about their political views and their opinion, so far, of the candidates and key issues in the 2008 election. The nationwide telephone poll was conducted June 15-23 with 659 young adults ages 17-29. Here are follow-up interviews with some of the respondents.

title: New Center Has Lots of Clinton Ties
description: A coterie of national security and defense experts from the last Clinton administration have formed a new Washington think tank, the Center for a New American Security, that looks an awful lot like a shadow policy apparatus for Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign.

title: Styrofoam, Food and Public Schools
description: Public school parents in Brooklyn have started a movement to dump styrofoam tableware in 1,400 city schools.

title: Sidelined by Inspectors, a Pizza Place Reopens
description: After two weeks on the edge of their seats, pizza lovers have a reason to rejoice. Di Fara Pizza, the much-praised Brooklyn pizzeria, reopened on Saturday after satisfying the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, which has shut the restaurant down twice this year, once on March 15 and again on June 4, for health-code violations.

title: Bear Stearns Asset Management Chief Takes Charge in Fund Crisis
description: The chief executive of Bear Stearnss asset management division, Richard Marin, is taking a stronger role in managing its two troubled hedge funds and appointed the head of the investment banks mortgage unit head to save one of the funds, two sources familiar with the decision told Reuters.

title: Bill Bryson, Neat Freak
description: The Times of London today has a long and amusing article about how Bill Bryson, the bestselling travel writer, has become the agitating new president of an anti-litter organization called the Campaign to Protect Rural England (CPRE). Bryson may have been born in Des Moines, but hes out to save England from its sloppy tendencies. The articles author, Stefanie March, has a nice dry style:

title: A Win in the War on the War on Drugs
description: Finding a silver lining in the cloud created by Bong Hits 4 Jesus: Writing on The Agitator, his personal blog, Reason senior editor Radley Balko makes the case that Morse v. Frederick was actually a victory for drug reform advocates, not a setback.

description: Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival celebrates its 75th anniversary. Video by The Video Production Team at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival: Nel Shelby, Ashley Meeder, and Kyle Frederick. Edited by Erica Berenstein.

title: Argentina: Life Goes Vern
description: It seemed to be a mighty fall from grace for the Argentine midfielder Juan Sebastin Vern, 32, who in 2004 was named to the FIFA 100, a list of the 125 greatest living soccer players as selected by Pel. After that came his banishment from the Argentine national team and from some of the top clubs in Europe.

description: The citys new transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, took questions from City Room readers through the week. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

title: Perspective on the Jewels From the C.I.A.s Chief Historian
description: For more than 30 years, the Family Jewels have clouded the C.I.A.s reputation, even though most of their contents have long been known from official reports and ad hoc disclosures. William Colby  who oversaw the compilation of the Jewels while serving as the agencys operations chief and director-designate  is the source of some durable misconceptions about them. In his memoir, Honorable Men (p. 340), Colby says that the Jewels consist of 693 pages of possible violations of, or at least questionable activities in regard to, the C.I.A.s legislative charter; that among the contents are bizarre and tragic cases wherein the Agency experimented with mind-control drugs; and that accompanying them was a separate and even more secret annex that summarized a 1967 survey of C.I.A.s involvement in assassination attempts or plans against Castro, Lumumba and Trujillo.

title: The Winning Hand
description: How Peter Homer, an amateur inventor from Maine, bested NASA technology and built a better space glove.

title: Paulson Criticizes Bills Raising Buyout Taxes
description: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that raising taxes on hedge funds and buyout firms may have unintended consequences and said Congress shouldnt target firms that go public, such as the Blackstone Group, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Our New Look
description: You probably noticed the blogs new banner. Its designed by the always funny and far-ranging Gordon Hull. Aside from presiding over his own burger club, Gordie is a founder of Surface to Air, a New York-based company with branches in Paris and Tokyo that provides creative direction for folks like Marc Jacobs, Adidas and Nike. Surface to Air is a little hard to quantify  it also produces books and has its own clothing line and a store in Paris, on rue Charlot. Gordies banner looks, I think, suitably couture.

title: Nested Tug-of-Wars
description: The other day in an interview in The New York Times Magazine, Al Gores daughter Kristin revealed that when she was a child, she couldnt stand to think about wrists. All those veins and tendons. Probably didnt like to gnaw chicken bones either. Too squeamish.

title: Edwards-Coulter P.S.
description: During MSNBCs Hardball exchange between Elizabeth Edwards and Ann Coulter yesterday (see earlier post today), Ms. Coulter echoed an audience question: Yeah, why isnt John Edwards making this call?

title: On YouTube, Candidates Get an Eyeful
description: Bjorn, an imposing figure in a two-horned Viking helmet and a thick, black beard  the stick-on kind  wonders how the candidates plan to deal with illegal immigration. Someone else has a very, very serious question  about aliens: Will the candidates agree to Congressional hearings on the existence of extraterrestrials?

title: DealBook: Is LinkedIn Getting Ready for an I.P.O.?
description: Our savvy friends over at DealBook take stock of the reports, including one by VentureBeat, that LinkedIn, the professionals social networking site, is about to go public.

title: Politics, Soccer  or Death!
description: CARACAS  After enjoying last nights opening ceremonies with Bolivian president Evo Morales and addled Argentine soccer deity Diego Maradona, Venezuelan president Hugo Chvez left the country today for Russia, Belarus and Iran. Chvez may be on a shopping trip for more Russian military equipment, including a couple of submarines, but the main effect will be to switch everyones focus from Chavista politics to the Copa Amrica.

title: The Selling of Coney Island
description: The selling of Coney Island's Astroland Park to developers leaves one last park in the amusement district: Deno's Wonder Wheel Park.

title: The A.M.A. Gets Under Your Skin
description: On Monday, the delegates to the annual meeting in Chicago of the American Medical Association endorsed what could only be described as a cautious committee report on the role of implanted radio identification tags in patient care. The three recommendations were that doctors make sure that they get informed consent from patients before using such tags, they they not program any medical information into them without making sure it would be as secure as normal medical records, and that they support research into uses of the devices.

title: FINAL: Mexico 2, Brazil 0
description: Final! Mexican football gets a big shot in the arm with a great win over a Brazilian squad filled with stars. El Tri looked poor in nearly all their Concacaf matches, but this game shows theyre still not far off the worlds elite teams. Lets see if they can keep it up throughout the tournament! (And I hope some of you bet them to win at 6-1.)

title: Building a Winner
description: At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?

title: The Other Side of the Desk
description: I will always remember that day in 2004 when I sat on the business side of a Lieutenant Colonels desk as he invited me to go to Iraq with his battalion. Now, as a company commander in the Utah National Guard, one of my duties has been to send others to fight the war in Iraq.

title: Cinema Days
description: Editors note: An earlier version of this column misquoted a phrase from an episode of Monty Pythons Flying Circus; it has since been corrected.

description: My Thursday column is about climate change and its impact on Africa. Please post your comments below.

title: Answers Are Within, and That May Be the Problem
description: I was sitting here at sweltering Camden Yards on Wednesday night, trying to come up with fresh verbs to describe what were watching every night. Slumping, sliding, stumbling, sputtering. They all apply, and many more. The remaining 87 games could test anyones vocabulary.

title: White House Rebuffs Congress in Firings Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Bush moved one step closer to a constitutional showdown with Democrats today, as the White House asserted executive privilege in refusing to comply with Congressional subpoenas for documents related to the dismissal of federal prosecutors.

title: Citigroup Unit in Australia Cleared of Insider Trading
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, June 28 (Bloomberg News)  Citigroup, the worlds largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.
