description: Over the weekend of June 17, executives at Bear Stearns scrambled to avert the collapse of two hedge funds.

title: Glavine Wins No. 297 in Game With Rain, but Little Thunder
description: Rain delayed the start of last nights game at Shea Stadium by 54 minutes. The game was called after the top of the sixth inning after a second rain delay of 91 minutes. In between, the Mets squeezed in a 2-0 victory against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: The Beerman Goes Flat
description: Things are not exactly in a groove for Mark Johnson, the happy-go-lucky Champions Tour player known as Beerman. He has played unevenly, often plagued by a string of bogeys during rounds that raise his anxiety level and take him out of contention. If he doesnt turn around his game, he risks losing easy entry into tournaments in 2008.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (NBC) STUDIO 60 ON THE SUNSET STRIP Since a penultimate three-part, three-week episode wasnt enough for Aaron Sorkin to wrap up the loose ends, this series finale should finally resolve the hostage crisis and let us know whether Jordan (Amanda Peet, above with Bradley Whitford) survives childbirth.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the ability to encode information in a genome referred incorrectly to the number of bases, or letters, in the genetic code of a bacterium in which researchers wrote the E=mc2 formula. The bacteriums genome has about 4.2 million bases, not 400 million.

title: Learning to Mix Tennis Career and Motherhood
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  There are times when trying to be both a mother to a 5-year-old and one of the worlds best tennis players does not seem a good match.

title: Blair to Tackle Economics but Not Peace Efforts, a Task Reserved for Rice
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  In his new role as envoy to the Middle East, Tony Blair will be charged with shoring up Palestinian institutions, but not with trying to nail down a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians because Condoleezza Rice, the secretary of state, is handling that job herself, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Our Gas Guzzlers, Their Lives
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi

title: This Is Not la Belle France, but Merrie Olde England?
description: PARIS, June 27  My poor mans Pastoral Symphony,  Frederick Ashton said of his Fille Mal Garde, which the Paris Opera Ballet is performing for the first time, proving once again that this choreographer was entirely too modest. In its enchanting vision of bucolic pleasures and the sensual joys of romantic love; its beautiful Ferdinand Hrold score (adapted and considerably expanded upon by John Lanchbery); and its charming countryside designs by Osbert Lancaster, Ashtons work is a masterpiece with the lightest of touches. It is as capable of delighting audiences now as it must have been at its Royal Ballet premiere in London in 1960.

title: 20 Decapitated Bodies Found in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, June 28  Twenty decapitated bodies were found today in a predominantly Sunni village southeast of Baghdad, Iraqi police said.

title: A Vanishing Tribe, but Well Dressed for Extinction
description: IT is a transitional time for Valentino  both the man and the institution.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline and a report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday about the cancellation of a concert planned for Istanbul, and an effort to stimulate ticket sales for a concert in Johannesburg, misidentified the event whose organizers planned the concerts. It is Live Earth, not Live Aid.

title: Movie Association Sues 2 Internet Sites
description: The Motion Picture Association of America, a trade organization for Hollywoods largest film studios, sued two Internet sites, claiming they illegally post copyrighted material.

title: Israelis Kill 11 Militants Inside Gaza; 2 Civilians Die
description: JERUSALEM, June 27  At least 11 Palestinian militants and 2 civilians were killed Wednesday during Israeli raids in Gaza in the deadliest day of fighting since the Islamic militant group Hamas took control there nearly two weeks ago.

title: Senators to Push for Registry of Drug Makers Gifts to Doctors
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  In the midst of a Senate hearing about the money and gifts that drug makers routinely provide to doctors, Senator Claire McCaskill mentioned that she had a brother who runs a restaurant.

title: Pentagon Splits War-Support Contract 3 Ways
description: The Army announced yesterday that it had awarded contracts to feed, fuel and house American troops in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, breaking the job into three $5 billion deals to separate companies rather than just one.

title: That Time Again: Make Way for Tomatoes
description: IVE got a tomato farm growing down in Maryland. About 20 different heirloom varieties, maybe 50 plants and still counting.

title: Red State Welfare
description: Drive across the empty reaches of the Great Plains, from the lost promise of Valentine, Neb., to the shadowless side roads into Sunray, Tex., and what you see is a land that has lost its purpose. Many of the towns set in this infinity of flat have a listless look, with shuttered main streets and schools given over to the grave.

title: Building a Winner
description: At least a couple of N.B.A. teams hope their pick tonight carries the franchise to a championship. Play general manager: How would you build a winning team, by focusing on the draft or on trades and free agency?

title: The N.B.A.s Dropouts
description: Cincinnati

title: Abreu Gives It His All, but His All Is Nothing
description: BALTIMORE, June 27  Bobby Abreu slapped Erik Bedards last pitch of the game to first base, then sprinted as if he had a chance to beat out the throw. He did not, but at least he hustled. It was all Abreu had, all the Yankees had on another exasperating evening. It was hardly enough against Bedard.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a Senate committee hearing on problems at the Smithsonian Institution misstated a finding of two reports on the institution last week. They said that the Smithsonians Board of Regents had failed to provide adequate oversight, not inadequate oversight. Because of another editing error, the article misstated one of the titles of Sheila P. Burke, a Smithsonian official. In addition to deputy secretary, she is chief operating officer, not chief financial officer.

title: Congress Considers Action to Help Former N.F.L. Players
description: A House of Representatives subcommittee hearing on the N.F.L.s divisive player-disability plan in Washington on Tuesday afternoon included one particularly ominous exchange.

title: An iPod Has Global Value. Ask the (Many) Countries That Make It.
description: Who makes the Apple iPod? Heres a hint: It is not Apple. The company outsources the entire manufacture of the device to a number of Asian enterprises, among them Asustek, Inventec Appliances and Foxconn.

title: School Ruling Leaves Unanswered Questions
description: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary plans to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky., left hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change their policies using race as a factor in school assignments.

title: The Sights,  the Sounds,  the Smells of Springtime in the U.S.
description: What do Americans do for sports in the spring? I asked this question, somewhat facetiously, when it worked out that I wouldnt go overseas this year.

title: Brief Power Failure Is Long Enough to Unsettle
description: It lasted less than an hour, but a power failure that left big sections of the Upper East Side and the Bronx without electricity yesterday afternoon stirred fears that there may be more dark days ahead this summer for Con Edison and its customers.

title: A New Low for Clemens and the Yankees
description: BALTIMORE, June 27  It feels like falling off a cliff, Joe Torre said Wednesday night after another loss, and the metaphor is appropriate. The Yankees had reached a high point before this trip, but suddenly they are plunging to depths never experienced in Torres 12 years as manager.

title: Justices Reject Diversity Plans in Two Districts
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  With competing blocs of justices claiming the mantle of Brown v. Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared today that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a students race.

title: Union to Help Charter Firm Start School in the Bronx
description: Green Dot Public Schools, a charter school operator from Los Angeles, is seeking to expand into New York with the cooperation of the teachers union.

title: Transcript of the Third Democratic Primary Presidential Debate
description: The following is a transcript of the Democratic primary presidential debate on PBS. The participants were Senator Joseph Biden, Jr. (D-Del.); Senator Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.); Senator Christopher Dodd (D-Conn.); Former Senator John Edwards (D-S.C.); Former Senator Mike Gravel (D-Ak); Representative Dennis Kucinich (D-Ohio); Senator Barack Obama (D-Ill.); and Gov. Bill Richardson (D-N.M.). The moderator was Tavis Smiley, host of Tavis Smiley on PBS. The panelists were Michel Martin, journalist and NPR host; Ruben Navarrette, Jr., nationally syndicated columnist; Dewayne Wickham, USA Today and Gannett News Service columnist. The debate took place at Howard University on Thursday, June 28, 2007. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: The Spy Who Loved His Mother, Barely
description: The lighter side of espionage has pretty much fallen by the wayside. Something about 9/11, secret C.I.A. prisons and the poisoning of former K.G.B. agents in Europe has cast a pall on spy spoofs.

title: Updating a House of Tomorrow
description: ATLANTA

title: As Street Art Goes Commercial, a Resistance Raises a Real Stink
description: The covert campaign targeting street art began about seven months ago, with blobs of paint that appeared overnight, obscuring murals and wheat-pasted art on walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan. Arcane messages were pasted at the sites, but it was difficult to ask for an explanation. The author was never identified.

title: Brooklyn: Detective Testifies in Killing
description: Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police had failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobels co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, who is overseeing the case, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio was properly obtained.

title: Study Lauds Police Effort; Commissioner Criticizes Low Starting Pay
description: A police initiative in which narrowly drawn high-crime areas are flooded with rookie officers has played a major role in reducing New York City crime rates since 2003, even as a decade of declines in other large cities have shown signs of reversing, according to a statistical analysis released yesterday.

title: In Quest for Passport, Patience, Time and Contacts Count
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  A first-time United States passport applicant is required to pay a $97 fee. But some applicants can testify that the real cost is much higher.

title: From a Risk of Down Two, a Big Reward
description: In the World Wide Bridge Contest played on June 1, the top finishers from Manhattan were R. Jay Becker and Scott Levine. Playing at Honors Bridge Club, 133 East 58th Street, Manhattan, they finished 8th in the United States and 43rd in the world. (Full details can be found at www.ecatsbridge.com.)

title: Manhattan: Commuter Train Cocktails
description: Sales of alcohol on the trains and at the stations of the Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Railroad will continue. As expected, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority declined yesterday to act on a proposal to ban alcoholic beverages on the commuter lines. A board committee that studied the issue said it could not find a correlation between alcohol sales and accidents or arrests involving drunken commuters. The authoritys chairman, Peter S. Kalikow, said the board would not take any action on the proposal, made last year by Mitchell H. Pally, a board member from Long Island. Mr. Pally said he would continue to press for a ban. It is as if we were giving people a license to drink and drive, and that is unacceptable, he said. The railroads sell beer, wine and hard liquor in some trains and stations.

title: Giuliani and Abortion (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: Judge Blocks Public Access
description: A judge has declined to make public a motion to dismiss murder charges against a Brooklyn man accused of beating his stepdaughter to death. The motion was submitted on Tuesday to Justice L. Priscilla Hall in State Supreme Court by lawyers for the man, Cesar Rodriguez, 28, who has been charged with killing his stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, 7, in January 2006. In court, defense lawyers said that the motion was based on improper grand jury testimony by the victims 11-year-old sibling. Clerks for Justice Hall have denied repeated requests by reporters and a lawyer for The New York Times to view the document. The court attorney for Justice Hall, Machelle Sweeting, said she was reviewing the motion to determine whether portions that include or refer to grand jury testimony can be disclosed publicly. Prosecutors are scheduled to respond to the motion by July 6. Ms. Sweeting said she would determine whether to release the motion most expeditiously as possible.

title: Wider Use of Latin Mass Likely, Vatican Officials Say
description: Pope Benedict XVI has signed a document that would allow more churches to adopt the old Latin Mass that largely faded from use during the 1960s, when the groundbreaking Second Vatican Council opened the door to worship in the local vernacular, Vatican officials say.

title: Nielsen Adds to Cellphone Tracking
description: CELLPHONES are rapidly becoming ubiquitous and the Nielsen Company, the longtime monitor of television consumption, wants in.

title: The Lobbyists Behind the Curtain
description: Senate Republicans need to be reminded of that breast-beating moment last January when they joined in the overwhelming 96-to-2 approval of stringent requirements for sunlight to be shed on the money ties between Congress and the lobbying industry. That worthy bill, and another strong measure the House approved in May, are suddenly hung up by the G.O.P.s refusal to cooperate in the naming of Senate negotiators to a committee charged with reconciling the two versions of the legislation.

title: Say Thanks, and Smile (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: As Pakistans Chief Looks Ahead, Army Holds the Cards
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Speculation has been rife in political circles recently that Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, may not survive his wrangle with the chief justice and hold on to power, but a great silence emanates from the one place that may count the most: the barracks and the mess halls of the armed forces, the other great part of Pakistans ruling equation.

title: A Keyboard Made for Those in Need of a Kill Aliens Command
description: Any athlete will tell you that the difference between winning the silver and the gold is often raw talent, but good equipment can give anyone that extra push. That is what Microsoft is hoping to prove with its new Reclusa keyboard, created in collaboration with the gaming company Razer.

title: Correction: Who, Me Take Running Class?
description: An article last week about dog owners who hire runners to exercise their pets misstated the surname of an owner in one reference and misstated the age of a runner. As noted elsewhere in the article, the dog owner is Richard Shein, not Stein, and Roy Scranton is 30, not 26.

title: Housing and Hedge Funds
description: There may be a silver lining in the recent hedge fund debacle at Bear Stearns.

title: China: Playboy to Open Entertainment Complex in Macao
description: Playboy Enterprises will open a 40,000-square-foot entertainment complex, the Playboy Mansion Macao, with dining, entertainment and retail shops, in Macao in late 2009, the chief executive, Christie Hefner, said. The complex will be part of the Macao Studio City complex, with the gambling operations run by a casino operator, Melco International Development, Ms. Hefner, left, said in an interview in Macao. Macao Studio City, a $2 billion joint venture between the Hong Kong-listed ESun Holdings and partners including Silver Point Capital, is next to the Lotus Bridge, which will link Macao and the mainland Chinese city of Zhuhai. It will include a film studio, a million-square-foot shopping mall, and gambling and convention sites.

title: Reader Responses
description: The following are excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardts June 27 column on labor unions:

title: Treasury Secretary Announces Broad Review of U.S. Markets
description: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. announced yesterday that the Bush administration would start a formal review of how the United States regulates financial markets and hedge funds amid concerns over competition from overseas trading capitals.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: New York Festival Chooses Opening-Night Film

title: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
description: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

title: Young Hopes to Show Others How to Learn From Mistakes
description: ATLANTA, June 27  When someone mentioned to Dmitri Young of the Washington Nationals that he had changed a lot of things about himself lately, his face turned serious and his answer was succinct. Kind of had to, he said in a deep voice. Either that or die.

title: A Summers Day, Made in the Shade
description: MOST people love sitting in the sun, but they also know the dangers of too much exposure (and leathery, wrinkled skin is the least of them). There are all types of umbrellas, pavilions and tents to provide the necessary shade. Some are portable and sized for an individual; others will cover a crowd.

title: California Driving
description: Around Pebble Beach, big driving events usually involve Titleists and oversized clubheads. Not so in August, when the Monterey peninsula, California's golf mecca, turns its attention from pars to cars. Classic Car Week, a five-day celebration of vintage and exotic autos, held at various locations in and around Monterey, gets rolling Aug. 16. It's a major show that attracts car lovers from around the world, and PLAY newsletter readers who count themselves among the aficionados might do well to make plans now. It starts with vintage cars making a scenic tour of the peninsula, then picks up speed with races at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, featuring historic automobiles. Along the way, there will be vintage car auctions -- Steve McQueen's 1963 Ferrari GT250 will be among the items on the blocks -- and a splashy bash at the Quail Lodge in Carmel Valley, highlighted by Land Rover off-road test-drives and helicopter rides to catch the races at Laguna Seca. Tickets to each happening are sold separately.

title: Russian Freed From Guantnamo Is Killed by Police Near Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, June 27  A Russian man who had been captured by American forces in Afghanistan and released from the detention center at Guantnamo Bay was killed Wednesday in a police raid near Chechnya, Russias intelligence service said.

title: Flooding Sweeps Central Texas After Record-Breaking Rains
description: DALLAS, June 27  More than a foot and a half of rain flooded broad swaths of Central Texas on Tuesday and Wednesday, and a 13-year-old boy drowned in a Dallas suburb after he was swept away in a creek.

title: A Latin American Fortune Is Assembled
description: CARLOS SLIMS EMPIRE

title: Dozens of Shiites Killed in Baghdad Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, June 28  A spate of grisly attacks believed carried out by Sunni extremists killed dozens of Shiites around Baghdad over the past two days, just ahead of a planned huge march of devout Shiites through Sunni Arab heartlands to the remnants of a revered Shiite shrine.

title: Antidepressants Rated Low Risk in Pregnancy
description: Taking an antidepressant like Prozac may increase a pregnant womans risk of having a baby with a birth defect, but the chances appear remote and confined to a few rare defects, researchers are reporting today.

title: Ann Coulters Pointed Remarks Draw Edwardses Pointed Reply
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Never mind Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Some days, it seems as if the presidential campaign of John Edwards considers his main rival to be Ann Coulter, the conservative writer.

title: New Film Studio Planned
description: Two Hollywood veterans announced plans yesterday to form a new independent film company with $200 million in financing secured from a consortium of private investors.

title: Manhattan: Khat Smuggling Convictions
description: Three men were convicted in Federal District Court on Tuesday of charges related to the large-scale smuggling of khat, an African plant chewed as a stimulant. Prosecutors said that two of the men, Ali Awad, 43, and Abdi Emil Moge, 33, both of Minneapolis, were convicted of conspiracy to import khat, and the third, Abdullahi Hussein, 37, of Portland, Me., was convicted of conspiracy to distribute it. A fourth defendant, Abdi Nur Dahir, 32, of Minneapolis, was acquitted. The prosecutors said Mr. Awad and Mr. Moge were among the leaders of a smuggling group operating in the Horn of Africa, Western Europe and the United States. Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said the group used express mail and couriers to smuggle tons of khat into this country. He said that couriers frequently carried the leaves in suitcases on commercial flights.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlees ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime ministers surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee.

title: Lottery Numbers
White House Drops Vice Presidents Dual-Role Argument as Moot
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The White House has dropped the argument that Vice President Dick Cheneys dual role as president of the Senate meant that he could deny access to national archivists who oversee the handling of classified data in the executive branch.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered  not just state flags.

title: Draft Picks Caught in Fast Break of Trade Talks
description: When Georgetowns Jeff Green was called to Phoenix for a last-minute workout with the Suns on Tuesday, he shrugged, packed a suit for tonights N.B.A. draft and prepared for every situation.

title: 5 Charged in Planting of Devices at School
description: TOTOWA, N.J., June 27  Five teenagers who graduated last week from Wayne Valley High School have been arrested in connection with the discovery of 16 devices with fuses in lockers at the school, forcing the evacuation of 1,400 students on the last full day of classes.

title: CommScope to Buy Andrew Corporation
description: CommScope, a maker of cable for communications companies, has agreed to buy the Andrew Corporation for about $2.6 billion to bolster sales to mobile phone and wireless Internet companies.

title: New Campaign Finance Rules Skip Unions
description: The new law would crack down on donations from lobbyists, strictly limit contributions from contractors who do business with the city, and allow developers to give only a fraction of what they once could.

title: Next Week
description: David Cay Johnston of The Times business desk looks at the practice (often foolish) of using public subsidies for private sports ventures. Also, sailing camps that get right to the tough stuff.

title: Suggested Reading
description: Last weekend, Ken Griffey Jr. played in Seattle for the first time as a Cincinnati Red, receiving a rousing reception and then delighting the fans with two home runs on Sunday. A spate of injuries in recent years sidetracked him, but this 1994 profile of Griffey reminds us that in the mid-90s, the question was when, not if, he would break baseballs home run records (while wearing his trademark grin). From PLAYs suggested reading list:

title: Unwilling to Retire, a Veteran Looks to Make a Late Statement
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

title: Bird Lives in the Adulation of a Young Saxophonist
description: The Charlie Parker tribute being held this week at Birdland, the club that bears his nickname, isnt meant for anyone harboring resentment about the commodification of Parkers art. Nor is it for anyone who insists that jazz belongs strictly to the Americans, or that it glances backward at its own peril. Presented by the Umbria Jazz Festival, with the help of various Italian cultural organizations, the engagement traffics in nostalgia even as it revels in new talent.

title: 2 Lawsuits Against Maker of Toy Trains
description: The RC2 Corporation, maker of the Thomas & Friends Wooden Railway toys, was named yesterday as a defendant in two complaints demanding the company provide medical monitoring to children who may have ingested lead paint from its products.

title: Likely Spread of Deserts to Fertile Land Requires Quick Response, U.N. Report Says
description: ROME, June 27  Enough fertile land could turn into desert within the next generation to create an environmental crisis of global proportions, large-scale migrations and political instability in parts of Africa and Central Asia unless current trends are quickly stemmed, a new United Nations report concludes.

title: After Decade as Premier, Blair Yields to Brown
description: LONDON, June 27  On a day of poignant farewells and sober new promises, Gordon Brown took over Wednesday from Tony Blair as prime minister, offering Britain a pledge to try my utmost and declaring, Now, let the work of change begin.

title: Mommy Is Truly Dearest
description: I TELL her everything.

title: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon
description: MEXICO CITY, June 27  Carlos Slim Hel may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

title: Democrats Stress Domestic Programs in Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  For 90 minutes Thursday night, eight Democratic candidates debated before an audience made up largely of one of their partys most reliable and liberal constituencies  African-American voters  and used the stage to urge a revitalization of domestic programs that they said had faltered under President George W. Bush.

title: Sex Education (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Protest Raised Over Lowering a Sail, as Alinghi Ties Series
description: VALENCIA, Spain, June 27  After a wild, wacky ride in Race 3, the Americas Cup, sports oldest major competition, returned to more familiar ways and means Wednesday.

title: In the Berkshires, a Dance Destination Marks an Anniversary by Stretching
description: When Ted Shawn happened upon Jacobs Pillow in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts in 1930, he didnt have a grand scheme in mind. He simply pined for a retreat or, as Norton Owen, the Pillows director of preservation, put it, a place to get away from it all.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,560 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Not Quite Liz and Gordie, but Palace Protocol Is Looser
description: LONDON, June 27  It had been so oft foretold as to seem an anticlimax but, finally  and not quite as in the movie starring Helen Mirren  Gordon Brown got his queen moment on Wednesday when he took over from Tony Blair as prime minister.

title: An African Tragedy, Ignored by the World (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Toxic Waste Fire Linked to Oxygen Generators
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  A fire in October at a toxic waste transfer station in North Carolina was fueled by the same type of oxygen-generating devices that ignited and brought down a jetliner in the Everglades in 1996, federal investigators reported on Wednesday.

title: Ms. Boldens Black Mark
description: Discrimination is disturbing wherever it shows its face. But it is especially deplorable in public schools, which are supposed to uphold the values of tolerance and basic fairness. Marion Bolden, superintendent of Newarks schools, seemed to forget that recently when she ordered one high school to blot out a yearbook picture of a gay student and his boyfriend kissing. Ms. Bolden said she thought the picture  which was covered over with black marker  was suggestive and looked fairly illicit. Photos of heterosexual couples kissing were left untouched.

title: Poland: Central Bank Raises Benchmark Interest Rate
description: Polands central bank unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate, for a second time this year, on concern that wage growth will force companies to increase prices. The Monetary Policy Council, which is led by the central bank, lifted the seven-day reference rate a quarter-point, to 4.5 percent. It is possible that wage pressure will continue to grow, strengthening inflation pressure, the council said after the meeting. It said inflation might temporarily slow in the third quarter, helped by the healthy financial standing of companies and growing competition among service providers and goods producers. The inflation rate, at 2.3 percent in May, is nearing the central banks mid-range target rate of 2.5 percent.

title: Israeli President to Resign in Plea Bargain on Sex Charges
description: JERUSALEM, June 28  The Israeli government has dropped rape charges against President Moshe Katsav in exchange for his agreement to step down and to plead guilty to lesser charges, the attorney general, Menachem Mazuz, announced Thursday.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Black Trial
description: CHICAGO, June 27  A federal jury began deliberations in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul, on Wednesday after more than an hour of instructions from Judge Amy J. St. Eve.

title: Talks Under Way Over Sunni Official Named in Warrant
description: BAGHDAD, June 27  The arrest warrant issued for the Iraqi culture minister, Asad al-Hashimi, continued to draw fire from some Sunni Arab leaders on Wednesday, and negotiations with the government were under way to review the investigation.

title: A State Questions UBS Ties to Hedge Funds
description: UBS, Europes largest bank by assets, was accused yesterday by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge fund advisers.

title: Gobbling Up Garbage, and Looking Good Doing It
description: YONKERS

title: A Portable Battery-Powered Charger for Cellphones, Music or Games Can Avert an Energy Crisis
description: Cellphones and other hand-held gadgets always seem to fail near the end of a day that has drained the energy from batteries (and owners).

title: 2 Iranian Gas Stations Burned Over Rationing
description: TEHRAN, June 27  Angry drivers set fire to at least two gas stations overnight in Tehran after the government announced that gasoline rationing would begin Wednesday just after midnight.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a dance review of the New York International Ballet Competition reversed the identities of the two dancers shown performing Black Swan. Kwi Sub Park was on the left and Eun Ji Ha was on the right.

title: Liz Claiborne, Clothing Designer, Dies at 78
description: Liz Claiborne, the designer of indefatigable career clothes for professional women entering the work force en masse beginning in the 1970s, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Manhattan: Writer Charged With Fraud
description: Three women, including the author of several financial advice books, were indicted on charges of fraud yesterday after prosecutors said they stole $1.6 million from New York area investors. The women  Carla Zimbalist, 62, of Beverly Hills, Calif.; Pam Chanla, 33, of Alhambra, Calif.; and the writer, Jennifer Wilkov, 38, of Brooklyn  were charged with fraud and securities violations, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Ms. Wilkov, whose books include Dating Your Money, for Couples, pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday in State Supreme Court, prosecutors said. Ms. Zimbalist was in custody in California and Ms. Chanla had not yet been arrested, prosecutors said. Mr. Morgenthau said that the three told 23 investors that Ms. Zimbalist and Ms. Chanla would use the investors money to renovate homes in Southern California, but that they did not actually own many of the properties and used much of the money for personal expenses.

title: Biggest Urban Growth Is in South and West
description: Newark, for four decades a symbol of Americas urban decay, is growing faster than any major city in the Northeast, according to census figures released yesterday.

title: Switzerland: Massachusetts Challenges U.S. Unit of UBS
description: UBS Securities, the investment-banking division of the Swiss-based UBS, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge-fund advisers. The subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., gave hedge-fund managers below-market rent, low-interest personal loans and other benefits to retain and increase business, according to a complaint from the office of William Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth and its top securities regulator. The complaint also accuses UBS of failing to supervise gifts and gratuities. The action, filed with the states Securities Division, seeks a cease-and-desist order, a censure and an undisclosed administrative fine, the statement said. Doug Morris, a UBS spokesman in New York, declined to comment.

title: New Senators Resist Overhaul of Immigration
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  In narrowly winning her seat last year, Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri ran hard against what she saw as a flawed approach in Congress to dealing with illegal immigration. Ms. McCaskill, a Democratic newcomer, says she is not about to change her view now.

title: Opera With Attitude, Guitars, and a Dose of Mayhem
description: PARIS, June 27  It is no longer thought daring for moviemakers to direct opera. Roman Polanski and William Friedkin first did so some years ago. Anthony Minghella and Michael Haneke tried their hand more recently, and Woody Allen and David Cronenberg will soon have a go. Invariably the idea of opera house managers is to add some screen buzz (and, they hope, draw new audiences) to their standard repertory.

title: Georgia: No Bond in Habeas Corpus Appeal
description: A judge ruled that a man serving a 10-year prison sentence for having consensual sex with a 15-year-old girl at a party when he was 17 is not eligible for bond while his habeas corpus case is being appealed. The judge, David Emerson, of Superior Court in Douglas County, ruled that Genarlow Wilson, 21, is not eligible for bail because he was convicted of aggravated child molestation, a crime that is considered one of the seven deadly sins under Georgia law. The ruling means that Mr. Wilson will probably spend several more months in prison.

title: U.S. Open Is Looking Younger Than Ever
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., June 27  Alexis Thompson learned to play golf from the seat of a baby stroller, a twist on the Tiger Woods upbringing that included lessons from a high chair.

title: Teenager Killed on Subway
description: A 19-year-old was fatally shot last night on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Second Company Bids for Canadian Newspapers
description: OTTAWA, June 27  A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Blacks Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday.

title: Long Climb for New President of Health Care Workers Union
description: George Gresham, the new president of 1199, New York Citys largest labor union, which represents 300,000 health care workers, has not forgotten what life is like at the bottom.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday with sports articles about the top two college players expected to be selected in todays N.B.A. draft misspelled the surname of one player. As the articles noted, he is Kevin Durant, not Durrant, of Texas. (Greg Oden of Ohio State is the other top player.)

title: Pakistani Underdog Wins Crowd, if Not Game, at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28  From the balcony overlooking Court No. 18, family and friends, and people he did not know, shouted encouragement in Urdu, his native language.

title: Immigration Bill Fails to Survive Senate Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Bushs effort to overhaul the nations immigration policy, a cornerstone of his domestic agenda, collapsed in the Senate today, with little hope that it can be revived before Mr. Bush leaves office in January 2009.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the withdrawal from an initial public offering by a company that owned assets of a troubled hedge fund misidentified that fund. It is the Bear Stearns High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies fund  not another fund with a similar name, the High-Grade Structured Credit Enhanced Strategies fund.

title: Scottish Panel Challenges Lockerbie Conviction
description: LONDON, June 28  An independent judicial review body ruled Thursday that a former Libyan intelligence official jailed for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing might have been wrongfully convicted and was entitled to appeal the verdict against him.

title: U.S. Faces More Distrust From World, Poll Shows
description: PARIS, June 27  Distrust of the United States has intensified across the world, but overall views of America remain very or somewhat favorable among majorities in 25 of 46 countries and the Palestinian territories surveyed in an international poll conducted by the Pew Research Center, in results reported Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about deaths in immigration detention misstated the year that one immigrant detainee died, and the amount of time that elapsed between then and an announcement this month of a federal investigation into her death. Young Sook Kim, who was detained at a privately run center in Albuquerque, died in 2006, not in 2005; the announcement of the investigation came nearly a year after her death, not nearly two years.

title: Just Dont Call Them Inexpensive
description: AS much as I like the word cheap and its variations  cheap-jack, cheapskate, el cheapo and the effervescent cheap and cheerful  I seem to have a hard time actually getting the word into a fashion article. Use inexpensive,  Im told.

title: Tentative Dow Jones Sale Pact Said to Give Murdoch Power to Hire and Fire at The Journal
description: A tentative accord on the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal would leave Rupert Murdochs News Corporation with the sole power to hire and fire The Journals top editors if it succeeds in buying the newspapers owner, Dow Jones & Company, people who have been briefed on the agreement said yesterday.

title: Calendar
description: Furniture Large and Small

title: Southern Wildfires (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching Army Wives Watching Army Wives
description: FORT DRUM, N.Y.  Poor Denise Sherwood. Her nasty son smacks her around. And she just learned that the Blackhawk helicopter carrying her husband, Maj. Frank Sherwood, was shot down in Iraq. So maybe the real Army wives at this post near Syracuse, watching Denise on TV in the hit Lifetime drama, Army Wives, would show her some love, or at least cut her some slack?

title: The Steamfitters Escape
description: THERE are 11,232 parquet-floored apartments in Peter Cooper Village and its sister complex, Stuyvesant Town, east of First Avenue, all built in the 1940s as affordable housing for middle-income tenants, and all remarkably similar in style and layout. Or almost all, anyway: one stands out for its stained-glass windows, its wall of vines and its spiral staircase to nowhere. Step inside, and youll never think of mirrors on the ceiling the same way again.

title: Hot Dog Champ and Upstart Set for July Fourth Face-Off
description: In the world of competitive eating, heads  if not stomachs  were spinning yesterday. In a last-minute development, what observers were expecting to be the Bite of the Century seemed off, then on again.

title: Study Sees Climate Change Impact on Alaska
description: Many of Alaskas roads, runways, railroads and water and sewer systems will wear out more quickly and cost more to repair or replace because of climate change, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Japan: Industrial Production Dropped in May
description: Japans industrial production unexpectedly dropped in May for a third month, the longest losing streak in almost two years. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent from a month earlier, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said. Slower production diminishes hopes that economic growth will accelerate, in contrast with other reports released in the last week, which said that export growth almost doubled to 15.1 percent in May and retail sales gained for the first time in eight months. The Bank of Japans governor, Toshihiko Fukui, said this month that the bank needed more evidence of the economys strength before it raises the key interest rate from 0.5 percent.

title: Randolph Will Have Surgery Instead of Coaching in the All-Star Game
description: As a second baseman, Willie Randolph made countless throws to first base. As manager of the Mets, he has made countless calls to the bullpen. All the wear and tear on his right shoulder has taken a toll. Randolph said yesterday that he would have rotator-cuff surgery next month instead of coaching in the All-Star Game.

title: Church Dissidents Lose Property Appeal
description: Three congregations that broke away from the Episcopal Church over the appointment of a gay bishop are not entitled to property claimed by the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, a California appeals court has ruled.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about government ratings for hospitals misstated the number of hospitals where heart patients are most and least likely to die. The report lists 41 hospitals, not 42, whose death rates are worse than the national average, and 52 hospitals, not 55, whose deaths rates are better than average. A list of the hospitals can be found at www.nytimes.com/health.

title: The Nets Hope to Keep Triumvirate Together
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 27  The wall above the front desk at the Nets practice facility is bare, except for three signed jerseys with names that, for three years, have represented the backbone of the franchise: Jefferson, Kidd, Carter.

title: Better Protecting the Vulnerable
description: With time running out on the legislative clock, the State of New York is close to enacting three new laws that would set welcome national examples for criminal justice reform. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly and the Senate need to work quickly to iron out any differences and ensure these vital reforms are signed into law.

title: N.B.A. Renews TV Pacts, Adding Links to Digital Use
description: ESPN, ABC and TNT will continue to carry the N.B.A. through the 2015-16 season under eight-year contracts worth $7.4 billion that will let the networks exploit the leagues digital rights more extensively than in the past.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Strawberry Lawn

title: Study Finds Many Injuries to Surgeons Go Unreported
description: Nearly all surgeons accidentally stick themselves with needles and sharp instruments while in training. But most fail to report the injuries, risking their health and that of their families and patients to the threat of diseases including AIDS, hepatitis and many other blood-borne illnesses, according to a survey being published today.

title: Scientists Find Earliest Sign of Cultivated Crops in Americas
description: Scientists exploring the western slopes of the Andes in northern Peru have found seeds of domesticated squash from almost 10,000 years ago, about twice the age of previously discovered cultivated crops in the region.

title: A Calm, Serene Presence From Islands of Nostalgia
description: In an uptempo song near the end of Cesria voras set on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, her saxophonist, Totinho, swaggered toward her with arms outstretched, as if inviting her to dance. She gave him one dismissive glance, and he returned to his microphone. Ms. vora was maintaining the core of her music: a serene, pensive stillness.

title: Manhattan: Building Code Changes
description: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the citys building code since 1968, greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings. The updated code, which is to be reviewed for possible revision every three years, was approved in a 47-to-0 vote, with one abstention, and will go into effect on July 1, 2008. It adds sprinkler requirements for smaller buildings, raises standards for smoke detectors, strengthens safety regulations for high-rise residential buildings and provides for rebates on permit fees if buildings meet higher environmental design standards and undertake more environmentally friendly practices.

title: Asias Long Road to Recovery
description: BANGKOK, June 23  As the founder of a petrochemicals business empire that aggressively expanded in refining, plastics, steel and cement, Prachai Leophairatana once ranked among Asias wealthiest men.

title: U.N. Predicts Urban Population Explosion
description: By next year, more than half the worlds population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, and the number is expected to swell to almost five billion by 2030, according to a United Nations Population Fund report released yesterday.

title: Proposals From Both Sides Fail in Immigration Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Senate on Wednesday killed proposals from the left and the right for major changes in a comprehensive immigration bill, but the outlook for the bill remained in doubt as senators prepared for a crucial vote on whether to end debate and move to final passage.

title: European Regulator Blocks Ryanair Bid for Aer Lingus
description: BRUSSELS, June 27  A bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Irelands national carrier, was blocked Wednesday as the top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.

title: Manhattan: Storms Snarl L.I.R.R.
description: Severe storms caused delays of about two hours last night on the Long Island Rail Road after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m., affecting service after 8 p.m. to and from Jamaica, according to a railroad spokeswoman. Pennsylvania Station became so crowded at one point that the Long Island Rail Roads section was shut to new passengers between 8 and 10 p.m., leaving hundreds of passengers stranded outside. As of 10 p.m., service was restored at all but three stations, where trees had fallen on the tracks. Service was expected to be normal this morning.

title: A Gifted Player Comes Up Short in the Draft
description: Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year. He is an All-American. And some draft analysts project him to go to the Blazers. But not with the first pick, as an old school fan might guess. Hes projected to go to the Blazers in the second round, with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that hes a little small to play on the perimeter, and doesnt shoot well. Thus, one of the top five players in college basketball slips to the second round of the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Day of Campaigning for a G.O.P. Noncandidate
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 27  Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee delivered a pep talk to his fellow Republicans here Wednesday, reminding voters in this early primary state about what he called the virtue of conservative ideals.

title: Judge Rejects Hospitals Suit Against Chain in New Jersey
description: A judge in Newark has dismissed a lawsuit claiming that the St. Barnabas Health Care System, which overbilled Medicare by hundreds of millions of dollars, defrauded the federal government so badly that other hospitals were deprived of their fair share of reimbursement.

title: Edwards on Poverty (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Penalty for Delusional Murderer Blocked
description: HOUSTON, June 28  Enforcing its edict against execution of the insane, a split United States Supreme Court today overturned the death sentence of a delusional Texas murderer who insisted he was being punished for preaching the gospel.

title: Tu, at Peak of Career, Seeks Last Burst at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  People would ask, with increasing frequency, when Meilen Tu would quit playing tennis. It seemed obvious that her best years were past.

title: A Slipshod Harry Potter and a Challenging Racer
description: Hollywood knows that a movie based on a Harry Potter book must be meticulously made to satisfy the series legions of fans. And the video-game industry knows that any game based on a popular movie can make money, no matter how many corners are cut, simply by riding a successful films coattails.

title: U.N. Official Is Expected to Become Chief Prosecutor for War Crimes Tribunal
description: THE HAGUE, June 27  The chief prosecutor at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Carla Del Ponte, is expected to be succeeded by the United Nations official leading the inquiry into the killing in 2005 of Rafik Hariri, former prime minister of Lebanon, United Nations officials in The Hague and in New York said Wednesday.

title: Beauty Regimens Reach for the Gold Standard
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: A Luxury Condo by Arty Architects From the Fringe
description: With so many developers relying on celebrity architects to market condominiums these days, its become routine to see names like Richard Meier and Jean Nouvel emblazoned across real estate ads and billboards. But Asymptote? Isnt that the firm that designed that steel cloud, a highly conceptual (read: unbuilt) elevated memorial and park for downtown Los Angeles two decades ago?

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about Tony Blair, misstated the circumstances of Prime Minister Clement Attlees ouster from office. His party did not lose control of Parliament in the 1950 election; it held on until a second election, in 1951. The article also misspelled the prime ministers surname. It was Attlee, not Atlee.

title: Discovery Team Decides on Leader for Tour
description: The Discovery Channel cycling team will start the Tour de France next week with the goal of placing Levi Leipheimer, the winner of the Tour of California this year, among the top three finishers in the three-week race, team officials said yesterday.

title: Vatican City: Pope Backs Adult Stem Cell Research
description: Speaking at the end of his weekly general audience, Pope Benedict XVI endorsed research using so-called adult stem cells, which are isolated from tissue samples taken from adults rather than derived from human embryos, a technique the Vatican still condemns. Scientific research must be encouraged and promoted, so long as it does not harm other human beings, whose dignity is inviolable from the very first stages of existence, the pope said, according to the Italian news service ANSA. Adult stem cells can grow into a very limited range of body tissues, replenishing dying cells and regenerating damaged tissues; embryonic stem cells can grow into a wide range of body tissues.

title: Your Briefcase Just Ran Over My Toe
description: DAN RAWLINGS  a sales executive, former football player and guys guy  loves his briefcase.

title: Fidelity National, a Payment Processor, Is Buying eFunds
description: Fidelity National Information Services, the electronic-payment processor, agreed to buy a rival, the eFunds Corporation, for about $1.8 billion in cash to bolster its debit card business.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about presidential elections involving candidates from the same state, inaccurately described the circumstances involving the selection of Warren Harding as the Republican nominee in 1920. Hardings nomination was not a direct response to the Democrats selection of another Ohioan, James Cox; Cox was a compromise nominee who was not chosen until after Hardings nomination.

title: Food-Safety Crackdown in China
description: SHANGHAI, June 27  After weeks of insisting that food here is largely safe, regulators in China said Tuesday that they had recently closed 180 food plants and that inspectors had uncovered more than 23,000 food safety violations.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 2 of Huang Ju, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, the elite group of nine senior officials who rule China, misidentified the committee member responsible for presiding over reforms to the banking and financial systems. It was Mr. Huang  not Jiang Zemin, the former president with whom Mr. Huang was allied.

title: Earnings Up 4.2% at Bed Bath & Beyond
description: Bed Bath & Beyond Inc., the home-furnishings retailer, said yesterday that first-quarter profit rose 4.2 percent after customers bought less bedding and curtains as home sales slowed.

title: Alitalia Seeks Another Suitor After Aeroflot Withdraws
description: MILAN, June 27  The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nations flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

title: Building Companies the Womens Way
description: Karla Lightfoot, 40, a yoga instructor and freelance writer, was meditating one day when the name compassion couture just came to her.

title: While You Were Out, the Post-it Went Home
description: THE romance between Shirley M. Knappe, 83, and Frank Sterling Long, 88, began electronically, with poetic early-morning e-mail messages from Mr. Long to Ms. Knappe, who live in an assisted-living facility in Coral Springs, Fla. But now that they have been married for three years, their day-to-day affairs are tracked on Post-it notes, which Ms. Knappe corrals onto the kitchen cabinets above the toaster oven: her activities in yellow, his in blue.

title: A Favorite Tune? A Wake-Up Call? A Wireless Alarm Will Blend the Two
description: If you love the music collection stored on your cellphone or computer, why let a little thing like sleep prevent you from hearing it? The iHC5 alarm clock from iHome (www.ihomeaudio.com) can connect wirelessly with any digital device that features Bluetooth technology and stream an audio file to the bedroom.

title: Looking Like a Billion Bucks
description: MILAN

title: White House Is Subpoenaed on Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday issued subpoenas to the White House, Vice President Dick Cheneys office and the Justice Department after what the panels chairman called stonewalling of the worst kind of efforts to investigate the National Security Agencys policy of wiretapping without warrants.

title: Wells Fargo and Ex-Analyst Are Fined
description: The NASD said yesterday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.

description: The Wells Fargo stagecoach has a new driver.

title: Storms Delay L.I.R.R. and Shut Down Power
description: Severe storms last night delayed service on the Long Island Rail Road for more than two hours after floods caused signal problems at the Jamaica station about 7:30 p.m. Service to and from Jamaica was affected after 8 p.m., a railroad spokeswoman said.

title: Italy: Changing of the Guard on the Left
description: Walter Veltroni, the popular mayor of Rome, announced that he would seek the leadership of the new Democratic Party, to be formed in the fall by merging the centrist Christian Democrats and the former communist Democrats of the Left, two main parties in the governing center-left coalition of Prime Minister Romano Prodi. The widely expected announcement officially makes the 51-year old Mr. Veltroni, a former Communist, the new leading figure of Italian center-left politics and a possible future candidate for prime minister.

title: A Designer Is Virtually Back
description: SOME women, like Natalie Massenet, cant wait to get a piece of RM.

title: Even in Agreement, Scalia Puts Roberts to Lash
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Its not every day that one Supreme Court justice, even one as rhetorically unrestrained as Justice Antonin Scalia, characterizes another justice, let alone the chief justice of the United States, as a wimp and a hypocrite.

title: Wider Sale Is Seen for Toothpaste Tainted in China
description: After federal health officials discovered last month that tainted Chinese toothpaste had entered the United States, they warned that it would most likely be found in discount stores.

title: Tina Brozman, 54, Former Judge and Bankruptcy Law Innovator, Dies
description: Tina L. Brozman, a former chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, whose work helped change international bankruptcy law, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 54.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Scientists Link Housecats to Wildcat Subspecies
description: Some 10,000 years ago, somewhere in the Near East, an audacious wild cat crept into one of the crude villages of early human settlers, the first to domesticate wheat and barley. There she felt safe from her many predators in the region, such as hyenas and larger cats, and the rodents that infested the settlers homes and granaries were sufficient prey for her.

title: For Education and Fun, Its Never Too Early to Give a Preschool Child a Starter Computer
description: ClickStart: My First Computer, from Leapfrog, is intended to transform your TV into a computing center for preschoolers. It consists of a wireless keyboard with mouse that can sit in a childs lap, and an infrared receiving base that plugs into your TVs audio-video jacks.

title: Web Browsing Without Windows
description: Q. How do I get the video and animation to work on Web sites when I am not using a computer running Windows or Microsofts Internet Explorer browser?

title: Wells Fargo Fined in Disclosure Case
description: The NASD said today that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending.

title: Patrons Sway Leads to Friction in Charter School
description: The Beginning With Children Charter School, housed in a former factory in Brooklyn, landed on the states list of high-performing schools this year, thanks to rising English and math test scores among black and Hispanic students.

title: Bald Eagles No Longer Endangered, U.S. Says
description: SEMINOLE COUNTY, Fla., June 28  Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled to historic lows in the early 1960s, are once again flourishing and no longer need the protections of the Endangered Species Act, Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne announced today.

title: Friends and Graduates, Now Victims in a Fiery Crash
description: Their exams, their prom, their graduation ceremony  all the rituals of high school were behind them. So were all the football and basketball games at which they had yelled and jumped from the sidelines as cheerleaders. Now they were on their way to spend a few carefree days in the Finger Lakes before one last round of post-graduation parties.

title: Not Yet Legal for the Street, but a Whiz on a Tractor
description: TOMAH, Wis., June 24  It was not just Nicole Snyders age, 17, that made her such a hit at the Dairyland Super National Truck and Tractor Pull here Saturday night. And it was more than the fact that her tractors two jet engines together produced 7,000 horsepower, enough to fly a troop-carrying helicopter.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of a transmission error, a film review yesterday about Live Free or Die Hard misstated the critics description of the plot. It should have been described as logic-defying, not logic-defined.

title: Paris Hilton Says She Is a Changed Woman
description: Paris Hilton read aloud her prison writings as if she had spent a lifetime on Robben Island, and that was surely the highlight of the heiress/actresss first television interview since her release from jail.

title: Bloomberg Had Surgery in 2000
description: Before he was elected mayor in 2001, Michael R. Bloomberg had surgery to have two stents implanted in a coronary artery because of blockage in his heart, a person with knowledge of Mr. Bloombergs health said last night.

title: Free Speech: The Justices Speak (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: Detective Testifies in Killing
description: Testifying yesterday in a murder trial, a retired detective said that the police failed to build a case against a suspect for 17 years, despite having his name, address and Social Security number. The detective, William Powell, cited his own notes describing the defendant, Craig Sobel, 39, who was charged last year with killing Dominick Masseria, 17, in 1989 on the steps of a church in Dyker Heights. Mr. Sobels co-defendant is R. Lindley DeVecchio, a retired F.B.I. supervisor who has been charged with helping a prized informant commit murders on behalf of the mob. The judge overseeing the case, Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court, has told prosecutors to show good cause for delaying prosecution of the case, and has already dismissed the charges against another man, John Sinagra, because of the delay. Prosecutors said they planned to call 11 witnesses to show that their evidence against Mr. DeVecchio had been properly obtained.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about conflict over whether to lower flags in honor of soldiers who die in combat misstated the policy of New Mexico. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, orders both the state and federal flags lowered  not just state flags. (Go to Article)

title: Editor Reveals the Sources of His Unease
description: Back in the summer of 2005 it was no fun being Norman Pearlstine. As editor in chief of Time Inc., he had been battling Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the tenacious special prosecutor investigating the Valerie Wilson case. Mr. Fitzgerald had issued subpoenas to a number of Washington journalists, among them the Time magazine reporter Matthew Cooper, seeking information about their contacts with administration officials who might have been involved in leaking Ms. Wilsons identity as an undercover intelligence agent. When they refused to comply, both Mr. Cooper and Time Inc. were held in contempt.

title: Lake Tahoe Fire Hits Year-Round Residents
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 27  When word came to evacuate his 12-foot-square shack on Tuesday afternoon, Scott Weise did not have a great deal to pack. He grabbed a few books, some canned goods and his one prized collection: about $1,300 worth of fishing gear, equipment Mr. Weise said he had planned to use  before his evacuation  to take as many crappie and blue gill out of Lake Tahoe as he could.

title: What kinds of rugs are good for high-traffic areas?
description: Q.  What kinds of rugs are good for high-traffic areas?

title: In West Bank, Hamas Is Silent but Never Ignored
description: HAWARA, West Bank, June 26  A new code was born here overnight. No one, it seems, belongs to Hamas in the West Bank anymore. Everyone now is an Islamist, a word that neatly, and maybe more safely, shears the religious from party affiliation amid the uncertainty of a Palestinian people newly divided.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A subheading on Monday with a dance review of Alessandra Ferris farewell performance with American Ballet Theater misstated the number of years she was with the company. As the review noted, she joined in 1985 and thus was with it for 22 years, not 12.

title: A Situation Is Brewing, Acoustic and Fierce
description: When the bassist Christian McBride feels good about a groove, he savors it, exults in it. Flashing a million-watt smile, he tosses off frolicsome micro-elaborations: a downward-tumbling triplet run, a jaunt of springy quarter notes on the fifth degree of the scale. This sort of thing happens a lot, especially on his bandstand. It certainly happened on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, where hes headlining this week.

description: Alando Tucker was the Big Ten player of the year last season. He was an all-American. Some draft analysts project him to go to the Portland Trail Blazers. Not with the first pick  as his credentials may suggest  but with the 42nd pick. The rap on him is that he is a little small to play on the perimeter and does not shoot well.

description: WASHINGTON, June 27  The threat came in the weekend mail.

title: The iPhone Arrives
description: Apples iPhone goes on sale Friday. Early reviews of the phone have been mostly positive. The Timess David Pogue wrote: Even in version 1.0, the iPhone is still the most sophisticated, outlook-changing piece of electronics to come along in years. It does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.

title: The Tortured Path for the Immigration Bill
description: May 17, 2007 Senate negotiators from both parties announce an agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill, which would offer legal status to millions of illegal immigrants. Deal follows months of negotiations behind closed doors.

description: New shows in New York include "Old Acquiantance" and "Gone Missing."

description: Wheeled briefcases are exploding in number.

description: Images from "Encompassing the Globe: Portugal and the World in the 16th and 17th Centuries" at the Smithsonian's Sackler Gallery in Washington.

description: Citigroup, the worlds largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.
