title: The Farmer Needs a Wife
description: The bachelors of La Viuela, Spain, welcome "women's caravans" to their rural  mostly male  village.

title: The Keys to Success
description: This film about a brilliant boy pianist fighting to shape his destiny was Switzerlands entry for the 2006 Oscars, and you can see why. Like most award-seeking crowd-pleasers, it places uncomfortable impulses in opposition  in this case parents desire to develop a childs latent genius, versus the childs desire to have a normal childhood and find his own way  then dramatizes them in the most unchallenging way imaginable.

title: Sexy Tableaus
description: The notion that French cinema consists mainly of pretentious soft-core pornography is an ignorant clich, but "One to Another" does little to disprove it. This drama from the directors Jean-Marc Barr and Pascal Arnold aims to be a disturbing account of young love, friendship and murder. But it plays like a remake of Larry Clark's muckraking thriller about youths, "Bully," as directed by Diane Chambers, the intellectual barmaid on "Cheers."

title: European Regulator Blocks Ryanair Bid for Aer Lingus
description: A bid by the low-cost airline Ryanair to buy Aer Lingus, Irelands national carrier, was blocked Wednesday as the top European regulator showed a willingness to intervene despite the overturning of past merger prohibitions in court.

title: Wells Fargo and Ex-Analyst Are Fined
description: The NASD said Wednesday that it had fined Wells Fargo and its former director of research for failing to disclose in a research report that an analyst had taken a job with the company she was recommending. The analyst, Jennifer Jordan, who is now a corporate vice president in charge of investor relations at the company, Cadence Design Systems, refused to settle the NASD case and will fight it, her lawyer said.

title: Will Blogging Software Firms Attract Buyers?
description: For the social software side of Enterprise 2.0, there may be a short window of opportunity for M&A, according to the analyst firm The 451 Group, which takes a look at the potential buyers and sellers in the market for wiki and blogging software. Among the potential acquisition targets named in the report are Six Apart and Atlassian Software Systems; 451 Group analyst Kathleen Reidy considers the software giant Oracle to be the most logical buyer of such assets.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Black Trial
description: A federal jury began deliberations in the criminal trial of Conrad M. Black, the former media mogul, on Wednesday after more than an hour of instructions from Judge Amy J. St. Eve. The jury of six women and six men deliberated for about two and a half hours before recessing for the day.

title: Alitalia Seeks Another Suitor After Aeroflot Withdraws
description: The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nations flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

title: New Commitment to Charity by Mexican Phone Tycoon
description: Carlos Slim Hel may be the richest man in the world. And in Mexico, where tens of millions of people live in seemingly intractable poverty, that distinction has been drawing some heat.

title: In S.E.C.s Hedge Fund Suit, a Family Affair
description: Federal regulators filed charges against a hedge fund manager, Simpson Capital Management, for allegedly defrauding mutual fund investors of millions of dollars in a late-trading scheme lasting more than three years. And in a twist, the chief of the hedge fund in question had family ties to a fund manager whose alleged market abuses set off an industry-wide investigation in the earlier part of the decade.

title: Terra Firma Extends EMI Offer
description: Terra Firma Capital Partners, the private equity firm that has offered 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion) for the British music firm EMI Group, extended its takeover bid on Thursday until July 4. As of June 27, Terra Firma had received acceptances representing 3.5 percent of the music company.

title: Equinix in $482 Million Data Deal
description: A data center services provider, Equinix, said Thursday it is buying IXEurope, a European data center operator, for about $482 million in cash. IXEuropes shareholders will receive $2.50 for each share held. IXEuropes operations include 14 data centers throughout Europe, which Equinix plans to fold into its brand.

title: A Baguette Fit for A President?
description: France has a new president, and a new presidential baguette. This year, Nicolas Sarkozy and his guests at lyse Palace will have a Renaissance with their meals  the baguette made by Arnaud Delmontel. He won this years prize for the best baguette in Paris, awarded by the mayors office, which means hell be the official supplier to the president.

title: Fund to Close Doors Following Subprime Losses
description: Fallout from the subprime mortgage market meltdown continued as Caliber Global Investment, a $908 million fund based in Britain and managed by Cambridge Place Investment Management, said it would close after losses on subprime-mortgage debt in the United States.

title: Sierra Shareholders Approve UnitedHealth Merger
description: Sierra Health Services said Wednesday evening that 99 percent of its shareholders had approved the companys merger with UnitedHealth Group.

title: Nuveen Shareholders Sue to Block Madison Dearborn Deal
description: Nuveen Investments, an asset management firm, said in a regulatory filing late Tuesday that two separate lawsuits have been filed by shareholders seeking to block a $5.75 billion buyout of the company.

title: Texas Pacific Still Interested in Coles Despite Losing Partners
description: The Coles Group, the Australian retailer, said on Thursday that a consortium led by the Texas Pacific Group would not submit a takeover offer for the company by the Sunday deadline but was still interested in making a bid.

title: Buyout Shops Get Bridge Loan for U.S. Foodservice Deal
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice have decided to finance their $7.1 billion buyout of U.S. Foodservice with a bridge loan after canceling a $650 million bond offering, as investors appeared reluctant to back the financing.

title: Carlyle Postpones I.P.O. of Mortage Fund
description: The Carlyle Group postponed a $415 million initial public offering of a fund that invests in bonds backed by mortgages after a slump in the subprime market. The buyout shop is preparing a supplemental offering memorandum that will contain a revised timetable for the global offering, the Washington-based firm said. The firm had offered investors 18.9 million shares for $20 to $22 each.

title: Peoples United Inks $1.9 Billion Deal for Chittenden
description: Peoples United Financial has agreed to buy Chittenden for $1.9 billion in cash and stock, in a deal that will create the largest locally owned bank in New England, with $21 billion in assets and more than 210 branches.

title: ProSieben to Acquire SBS Broadcasting
description: The German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media agreed Wednesday to buy SBS Broadcasting of Luxembourg, creating a pan-European broadcaster that can take on Bertelsmanns RTL Group. ProSieben, based in Munich, will pay 3.3 billion euros ($4.4 billion) for SBS and expects a smooth closing next month because the deal does not require the approval of either competition or media watchdogs.

title: Insight Closes $1.25 Billion Fund
description: Insight Venture Partners wrapped up its latest investment vehicle, Insight Venture Partners VI, with $1.25 billion, a closing that gives the New York firm about $3 billion under management. Founded in 1995, Insight Venture focuses on software and Internet services investments that cover the entire range of private capital investment  from early-stage venture capital deals to buyouts.

title: Chinese Bloggers on Darfur
description: The campaign to brand the Beijing Olympics as the Genocide Olympics, unless China distances itself from Sudan, is unfortunately creating something of a backlash within China. It would be so important to get Chinese bloggers to scold their government for underwriting the Darfur genocide, but in fact the opposite is happening. Nationalist sentiment and a certain defensiveness is leading Chinese netizens to claim that the Darfur movement is just an effort to prevent Chinese oil companies from exploiting Sudanese oil. Heres a translation of a Chinese blog posting.

title: PregLem Raises $26 Million in New Funding
description: PregLem, a pharmaceutical company based in Geneva, Switzerland, announced Wednesday that it had raised $26 million in series A funding. The funds will help develop and commercialize compounds for women suffering from infertility.

title: Former Cendant Unit Affinion Files for I.P.O.
description: Affinion Group Holdings, a marketing-services business that the private equity firm Apollo Management bought from Cendant in 2005, filed to raise as much as $600 million in an initial public offering.

title: Wells Fargos New C.E.O. on Deals and Buffett
description: Analysts said that the sudden promotion of John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargos chief operating officer, to chief executive, signaled that the bank would probably continue to focus on increasing sales in its core markets in the West rather than merging with an East Coast partner like Wachovia or SunTrust, as many on Wall Street have advocated for years.

title: A Bear Stearns Executives Bailout Blog
More Debt Offerings Are Delayed
description: MISC, the worlds biggest owner of liquefied gas tankers, postponed a $750 million bond offering, in the latest sign of the turbulence in the debt markets. The Financial Timess Lex column suggests the increased resistance could be the beginning of a serious bondholder revolt. Separately, an analyst at CreditSights suggested that troubles at two Bear Stearns hedge funds could spread in unexpected ways.

title: Bloombergs Heart; Charter School Control; Blackout Woes; and More
description: A parenthetical sentence in the next issue of Newsweek magazine has become the political talk of the town. In the article, Newsweek notes:

title: Newark Rises, but Not Like Phoenix
description: Newark, for four decades Americas poster child for urban decay, is growing faster than any major city in the Northeast, according to census figures released this morning. Its population, which has been declining for 50 years, increased by 3.3 percent since 2000, including 0.5 percent in the fiscal year ending last July 1. (New York City, though still the most populous, recorded virtually no growth in the same time period, though city officials dispute that. See below.)

title: Podcast: Post No Bills
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: World Chess Federation Changes Championship Rules, Again
description: Just when it seemed that the World Chess Federation had finally settled on a system for selecting the world champion that had some widespread support, it has rewritten the rules again. In a press release earlier this week that can be found here the federation said that the winner of a grand prix series of tournaments held over a two-year period would play a match against the winner of a mega-tournament called the World Cup. The winner of that match would then play a match against the world champion. The grand prix would begin in 2008.

title: 2008: The Immigration Debate
description: Senators, who have been arguing for weeks over provisions of the compromise immigration bill, are set to decide today whether to close debate and vote on passage. Whatever happens, the fate of the immigration bill is likely to have consequences for both parties in the 2008 presidential election.

title: Two Buyout Firms to Buy G.M. Unit for $5.6 Billion
description: After 78 years as part of General Motors, Allison Transmission is switching gears. In a sign of the times, that switch involves some big buyout shops.

title: The Bouncing Egg
description: Lyndsay and Patrick Mikanowskis new cookbook, Egg, is one Ill probably never cook out of. Its crazily conceptual (have a look at the cover, below) and its as much an art-thing, a dream book, as a food-thing. Most of the recipes are from avant-gardish, well-known chefs  Ferran Adria, Wylie Dufresne, et al.  and most look like theyd require 8 hours and a battery of sous-chefs to duplicate.

title: Currents
description: A water purification factory reborn as a hotel and more.

title: Flout of Office Reply
description: If you cant defund him, just impeach him: Some opponents of the idea of impeaching President Bush (such as Washington Post columnist Eugene Robinson) base their opposition on the frightening notion of President Dick Cheney. Writing in Slate, conservative heretic Bruce Fein proposes a solution for that problem: Impeach Cheney. Fein, who was associate deputy attorney general and general counsel of the Federal Communications Commission under President Reagan, writes:

title: Milans Latest Trend: Hedge-Fund Chic
description: As menswear designers showcased their latest creations on the runways of Milan this week, many of the shows seemed to have something in common, an animating spirit that reflected todays culture, todays time. That phenomenon, according to The New York Times, was best encapsulated by the editor of Departures, American Express magazine for the jet set:

title: When the Workout Brings Out the Crowd
description: EVERYONE loves a free ride, which explains why there are so many gratis sports gatherings during the summertime. Some events in or near Manhattan are well known, such as the Downtown Boathouses free access to kayaks and Niketowns group training runs in Central Park. We scoured the city to cull this insiders list of 10 lesser-known free (or nearly free) sports happenings. Each regular get-together has added value that puts it over the top compared with similar free events, whether its sag wagon support on a 50-mile bike ride or a volleyball court complete with scorekeepers and balls for riverside play. Not to mention that many of the gatherings have regulars whose enthusiasm makes them a riot to row, run and skate with.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Umbrellas, tents and pavilions guard against too much sun.

title: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
description: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

title: Russian Scientists Say the Arctic Is Theirs
description: Toss another stick or two on to that smoldering Cold War fire: Theres renewed talk of expanding the Russian Empire.

title: A Reclusive Math Star Spotted in Russia
description: A sighting of a celebrated mathematician may not quite be the stuff of Page Six, but it seems perfect for us.

title: The Hewlett-Packard Nine
description: I dont know Bryan C. Wagner, but last week the Justice Department contacted me to let me know that I have been designated as a victim in his criminal prosecution. Mr. Wagner, an independent private investigator, has the unfortunate distinction of being the person taking the blame in the Hewlett-Packard pretexting scandal.

title: Often-Asked iPhone Questions
description: With its new iPhone, Apple pulled off two masterful feats: creating the machine and creating the buzz around it.

title: Video: Outside Two Tents, Looking In
description: The Politicker points to a WNYC video (posted below) of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg at the Crains breakfast on Wednesday. Under questioning by Brian Lehrer of the radio station, Mr. Bloomberg provided a sound bite:

title: A Bill to Help 9/11 Private Paramedics
description: Maybe the third time will be a charm.

title: Snorkeling Options on Saba
description: How is the snorkeling in the immediate area of Saba? Is there a fairly easy access to the ocean, given the altitude of the living areas? I dont mind a trek. I would just like the opportunity to take the occasional dip or snorkel without a lengthy boat ride.

title: Rating the U.S. Players
description: After each US match, Sams Army  the fan club/hinchada/torcida that follows the national team  rates the US players on a 1-to-10 scale. Sixty or more fans give their ratings, which are then averaged on the Sams Army web site. A consensus then emerges, and under the principle of the wisdom of the market, it provides a quite accurate gauge of how the players really did.

title: Immigration Bill Blocked
description: Senate supporters of the far-reaching immigration bill failed to muster the 60 votes needed to close off debate today. It was a procedural vote required to move the bill on to final debate and a vote; 46 senators voted to move it on while 53 voted against the motion.

title: Is the Sun Setting on Investment Bankers?
description: As hedge fund managers inspire fashion trends and TV series, investment bankers have inspired an obituary of sorts from one former member of that profession.

title: Clintons Camp Projects $27M in 2nd Quarter
description: In a memo sent to major donors and supporters this morning, Howard Wolfson, the campaign communications director for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, predicted that the Clinton camp would raise in the range of $27 million for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night.

title: The Micro-Mini Startup
description: Internet startups seem to be getting smaller and smaller. In the late 1990s, it wasnt uncommon for companies to raise tens of millions of dollars and hire many dozens of people, growing to hundreds very quickly. By the time entrepreneurs started rallying around the Web 2.0 banner, the trend was toward companies with less than 10 employees.

title: Police Recover Stolen Church Reliquary
description: Detectives in Queens have cracked the case of a stolen church reliquary, the police said.

title: Messi vs. Maradona
description: Most soccer fans must have seen these by now, but with Argentina playing the Americans tonight, its work another look anyway.

title: Drop That iPhone and Wish an A.T.M. Happy Birthday
description: It seems fitting that a ubiquitous piece of technology that everyone takes for granted celebrated its 40th birthday as people line up for the iPhone, the very height of the mania.

title: LIVE Tonight: USA vs. Argentina!
description: Group C play at the Copa Amrica begins tonight with two games. First, Paraguay meets Colombia, followed by the match between the United States and the tournament favorites, Argentina. Well have the play-by-play of USA-Argentina, Duncan Irving doing the live commentary. Kickoff at the Estadio Jos Pachencho Romero in Maracaibo is scheduled for 8:45 p.m., Eastern time.

title: Google Earth Makes Some Officials Nervous
description: The race to map every last square inch of New York City seems well underway, as we noted in a blog post last month. Googles Street View and Microsofts Live Search Maps, which both started in the same week last month, give users birds-eye, street-level, 360-degree views of many streets and intersections in Manhattan and in parts of the other boroughs.

title: Venture Capital Group Hires Lobbyist on Carried Interest
description: The army of lobbying firms hired to battle the effort to increase federal taxes for private-equity managers and venture capitalists continues to grow: A filing made public on Wednesday shows that the law firm Proskauer Rose has signed on to represent the National Venture Capital Association on the matter.

title: F1 press conference levity continues
description: I think this is the third time I have brought this topic up this year, but its a wonderful sign of a change in Formula One, somewhere. The press conference today at Magny-Cours was again an occasion for a little levity, smiles and outright fun laughter.

title: Oracles Deal Spree May Be Paying Off
description: Oracle has its binge of acquisitions to thank for its better-than-expected quarterly profits and sales, according to the software company and some of the analysts who cover it.

title: Universal Fiction
description: Universal Express, a company that can pay its bills only by illegally selling unregistered shares, has taken out a full-page ad on page C11 of todays Times. It bills the ad as a response to the undeveloped articles I wrote about the company last week. (Here are the column and a follow-up article.)

title: Dwight, More in Anger than Sorrow
description: Dwight Macdonalds letters, collected in Michael Wreszins anthology, A Moral Temper, are blistering reading  rude, funny, alive. You didnt want to be on the wrong end of a Macdonald thrashing.

title: Spitzer Says We Need Answers From Con Ed
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer declined to criticize Consolidated Edison today when he was asked about the brief power failure that cut electricity to parts of the Bronx and Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Q&A: Ask About iPod Pricing
description: Weve had quite a bit of discussion on our post about how much to expect Apple to cut the price of the iPhone. And we were very interested to see Hal Varians Economic Scene  column today about a study that tries to figure out the source, and cost, of the parts that go into an iPod. (There is a fascinating graph from the study after the jump.) The whole study is here.

title: Once Bitten, Twice Introduced
description: On May 7, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Representative John Hall held a series of news conferences in the Hudson Valley on dam safety. Sometime during the day, Mr. Schumer felt a sting on his left leg, just above the sock. A couple of days later, he noticed a red bulls-eye mark in the same spot on his leg  the telltale sign that he had been bitten by a tick carrying Lyme disease. The senators spokesman, Joshua Vlasto, says that Mr. Schumer consulted with a doctor who works for Congress and took antibiotics as a precaution, and that the senator did not develop the disease.The tick bite was widely reported, and today, Mr. Schumers office announced that he had reintroduced a bill, co-sponsored with Senators Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, that would provide $100 million over five years for studying, preventing and treating tick-borne illnesses and creating an advisory committee on the matter. Lyme disease cases are up 35 percent in New York City, to 307 known cases in 2006 from 224 in 2003; the record was 399 cases, in 2005.

title: Google v. Microsoft: Whats the Better Workplace?
description: The perks at Google have long been the talk of Silicon Valley and beyond. But when all is said and done, how do they stack up against the perks at Microsoft? And which is the better workplace?

title: Family Honor on Smith Point; Animal Houses of Belmar; Other Seaside News
description: Jim Dooleys father was a lifeguard. His fathers uncle was a lifeguard, too. Now Mr. Dooley himself is chief of the Smith Point lifeguard crew in Long Island.

title: A Nation of Scaredy-Cats?
description: Digital rudeness is alive and well. More people than ever are yelling into their cell phones, sending text messages in movie houses and reading e-mail on their BlackBerry while you try to talk to them. In one recent indication that etiquette had reached a new low, I was on a tightly packed Bay Area Rapid Transit train during rush hour, and was forced to listen to a fellow passenger conduct a lengthy cell phone conversation with the speaker phone turned on.

title: Tip: Finding That iPhone
description: Apple is trying to be helpful with a Web page that will tell you what Apple stores have iPhones. Its binary, yes or no, not how many are left at the store.

title: Debt Watch: Dollar General, Servicemaster Face Tougher Terms for Offerings
description: In perhaps another sign that buyout boom is slowing down, Dollar General, the national discount chain, has lopped off a potentially risky form of debt from its proposed bond offering, Bloomberg News and Reuters reported Thursday. The retailer has removed $725 million so-called pay-in-kind toggles, or bonds that can be repaid in cash or by the issuing of more debt.

title: Celebrating the Bridge
description: Joseph Bertolozzi is using a bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., as an instrument and is composing a suite for it.

title: Accelerade Commercial
description: An ad for Accelerade.

title: Circle Line Loses Liberty-Ellis Ferry Contract
description: The Circle Line, which has held the contract to run the ferries to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island from Lower Manhattan since the 1950s, has lost the contract for that service to a company that runs ferries between San Francisco and Alcatraz.The National Park Service announced today that it had selected Hornblower Cruises and Events to run the ferry service to Liberty and Ellis Islands under a 10-year concession. The contract still needs to be signed by Hornblower and pass a 60-day mandatory Congressional review. Hornblower is expected to take over the ferry service in October.

title: A List With Personality
description: Im always on the lookout for great wine lists and Im thrilled when I find one. Last week I wrote about one kind of great list, at Landmarc in the Time Warner Center, where the prices are extraordinarily low even if the wines are not terribly exciting. Yesterday I found a great list of entirely different sort, at Trestle on Tenth in Chelsea, a lovely little neighborhood restaurant with Swiss and French influences. Here, the wines themselves are exciting and the prices are more than fair. Ive eaten there enjoyably several times, and heres a review from my colleague Frank Bruni. But while Ive always liked the wine list, I think it has improved tremendously in the last few months.

title: Inside the Mind of Murdoch
description: Todays unusually late start for reporters was the latest attempt by The Wall Street Journals newsroom to protest the expected sale of the paper and Dow Jones, its parent company, to Rupert Murdochs media empire, the News Corporation. A passage from this weeks New Yorker may give an indication of just how effective they are likely to be in influencing Mr. Murdoch.

title: Will Bush Get Saved Again?
Hasidic Village Has Led New York State in Growth Since 2000
description: Kiryas Joel, an Orthodox Jewish enclave in southern Orange County, grew faster than any other community in New York State between 2000 and 2006, according to an analysis by The New York Times of Census Bureau data released this morning.Kiryas Joel grew by 51 percent, to 20,071 residents from 13,273, over the six-period period. The village was incorporated in 1977 as an offshoot of a Satmar Hasidic sect in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. As Fernanda Santos reported last August, the community has had a high rate of natural growth, in part because under their religious beliefs, birth control is banned and women get married young and stay in the village.

title: The Singles Vote
description: The so-called marriage gap, in which single people vote differently from married people, has been evident in the last three presidential campaigns, with married voters tending to support the Republican and unmarrieds supporting the Democrat.

title: FIFAs Altitude Ban: Is Sepp Blatter High?
description: Yesterday FIFA announced that it has decided to roll back its proposed ban against international matches played at high altitude from 2,500 meters to 3,000 meters. (For you Americans reading this, thats from about 8,200 feet to 9,850 feet.) Youll find FIFAs announcement buried in the fourth paragraph of this press release.

title: YouTube Answers Its Critics
description: In response to a deluge of complaints from users, YouTube.com has reinstated features that allow visitors to its site to sort videos by the number of views, rating and other measures in each of its topical categories  News and Politics, being one of our favorites.

title: Council Aide Suspended Over Threats
description: A City Council aide who used the word assassination in criticizing a councilman, Leroy G. Comrie Jr., has been suspended without pay for six weeks, the Councils speaker, Christine C. Quinn, announced this afternoon.

title: 9,045 Phone Calls During an Hourlong Blackout
description: Consolidated Edison added 50 customer service representatives, for a total of 280, within 30 minutes after the start of the brief power failure on Wednesday that cut power to 385,000 people and disrupted subway and train service and traffic lights.

title: Get Two, They Last Longer
description: This nugget from an interview with Steve Jobs of Apple and Randall Stephenson of AT&T:

title: Movie Minutes: 'Ratatouille'
description: The New York Times Co-chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Ratatouille," the latest offering from Pixar about a gastronomically inclined rat.

title: Dude, Youre Getting an iPhone
description: Steve Jobs addressed Apple employees this morning and various blogs have an account, which included the promise of an iPhone to each employee.

title: Movie Minutes: 'In Between Days'
description: The New York Times Co-chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "In Between Days," about a young Korean immigrant in an unnamed American city.

title: Competition Is Sometimes Good for You
description: Verizon sent me an e-mail last night to let me know about a price adjustment on my DSL service. The price is going up, of course, but I had to check my last bill to see how much: was $29.95, now $31.99.

title: Now Batting for the YankeesJoe Torre?
description: Yankees Manager Joe Torre is not the type to bark at his players or flip over a table in the clubhouse to try to motivate them. But Torre admitted he recently thought about taking batting practice with the Yankees to lighten the mood.

title: Readers Questions: The Beginnings of Synthetic Life?
description: Are scientists on the brink of creating entirely new forms of life? In a study published this week by the journal Science, a research team led by Dr. J. Craig Venter and Dr. John I. Glass reported that they had managed to replace the genes of one species of bacteria entirely with the genes of another. Dr. Venter and Dr. Glass will be taking readers questions about their research and its implications on Friday, and their answers will be posted here. Submit your question below; they will not be able to answer all questions and only those selected will be published. (Editors note: questions are no longer being accepted.)

title: Reading the Ink Blot
description: Well, it took me two weeks to work up the nerve, but I finally read all your comments about my last Hillary Clinton column and see that we have had a pretty major misunderstanding.

title: FINAL: Argentina 4, United States 1
description: For Duncan Irvings live updates of tonights Group C match between the United States and Argentina from Maracaibo, click and use the refresh or F5 buttons on your browser. Kickoff is at 8:45 p.m. eastern.

title: Kramnik Leads Dortmund With 3 Rounds to Go
description: Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, leads the annual super strong tournament in Dortmund, Germany, with 3 out of 4 points. Called the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting (which almost sounds like a tea social), the tournament is one of the four elite tournaments on the chess calendar (along with Linares, Corus and the M-Tel Masters). The official Web site for the tournament can be found here.

description: Id say this is one unpleasant job description:

title: Democratic Debate at Howard U.
description: Senator Chris Dodd is not Paris Hilton. Tavis Smiley is not Alex Trebek. And both Michelle and Senator Barack Obama are HIV-free.

title: 5 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq Attack
description: BAGHDAD, June 29  Five American soldiers were killed and seven more wounded when their patrol in a southern neighborhood of Baghdad was hit by a roadside bomb, the American military said today.

title: Exploring Vibrant Latin American Sounds
description: When we think of Argentine composers we think of Piazzolla and now Osvaldo Golijov, said Michael Barrett, the general director of the Caramoor International Music Festival. But thats the tip of one iceberg in one country. Mr. Barrett and the festival are probing deeper into Latin American music with Sonidos Latinos, a two-year series of concerts that opens tonight.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday of Tina L. Brozman, a former New York bankruptcy judge, misstated a holding of Maxwell Communication, on whose 1991 bankruptcy case she worked. It was the parent of The Daily News of New York, not The New York Post.

title: Stoic Londoners Shrug at Latest Threat
description: LONDON, June 29  The headline of Londons Evening Standard newspaper today said 1,700 people could have died at ladies night in the Tiger Tiger night spot. The police gauged the potential death toll as significant if the car had exploded.

title: Even Before Rain, Mets Would Rather Be in Philadelphia
description: Willie Randolph and the Mets were not happy that they were scheduled to play the finale of their four-game series with Cardinals last night. They would have preferred an afternoon game, so they could leisurely make their way to Philadelphia for todays day-night doubleheader against the Phillies.

title: Footnotes
description: Prosecutors in Australia withdrew charges yesterday against Jamie Fawcett, a photographer accused of planting a listening device in 2005 outside the Sydney home of Nicole Kidman, The Associated Press reported. ... The main building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, normally closed on Mondays, will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. on Monday in connection with the Independence Day holiday later that week. Other Monday openings will take place on Sept. 3 (Labor Day) and Oct. 8 (Columbus Day). ... Mary Louise Wilson, who won a Tony Award this month for best featured actress for her portrayal of the elderly Big Edie Beale in Grey Gardens, will leave the show on July 29. There was no immediate word on a replacement.

title: Justices Limit the Use of Race in School Plans for Integration
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  With competing blocs of justices claiming the mantle of Brown v. Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared Thursday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a students race.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the dearth of university students in Japan misstated the reason that the numbers of college-age children of baby boom parents there peaked in 1992, years earlier than the American peak. It was because Japans baby boom was concentrated in the years immediately following World War II, while the American boom lasted until 1962. It was not because Japans boom started earlier; both started in 1946.

title: Salvaging a Prudent Name
description: James E. Cayne has a bellyache.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday of the fashion designer Liz Claiborne misstated the duration of her working relationship with Arthur Ortenberg, her husband, before the founding of Liz Claiborne Inc. in 1976. Mr. Ortenberg was Ms. Claibornes boss for two years, beginning in 1954, not for two decades. The obituary also misidentified the object of the couples wildlife conservation efforts in Madagascar. Their foundation sought to rescue the fish-eagle, an endangered bird there; they were not trying to save fish and eagles.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: New Yorks second-home owners have broader voting rights than your June 22 article The Principle of 2nd Home, 2nd Vote may lead readers to infer.

title: A Friendly Interstate Battle of Online One-Upmanship
description: BOSTON, June 28  Sure, they share a river border, but New Hampshire and Vermont have long been the inverse of one another, from politics to shape (flip one upside down and you get the other).

title: Monster Prices for Frankenstein
description: Given that the Mel Brooks musical The Producers introduced the $480 ticket to Broadway, its no wonder that rumors are already spreading about the ticket pricing for The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein, opening on Nov. 8 at the 1,821-seat Hilton Theater. Well, heres the official word: On Friday and Saturday evenings and at weekend matinees, you will be able to buy something called a premier seat  roughly, one of the best 100 seats in the theater  for $450. Premium seats, the next-best 120 or so seats, will go for $375. The remaining orchestra and dress circle tickets will be priced at $120 each, and the balcony will be divided between $80 and $60 tickets. Both premium and premier seats will cost $100 less for other performances, and prices for balcony seats will be slightly lower as well. A production spokesman said $25 orchestra seats would be available for most performances, though there are no specific details about those tickets yet. One more thing: Young Frankenstein is allotting fewer tickets than normal to groups  50 at most per weekend performance  to allow greater single-buyer access, the spokesman wrote in an e-mail message.

title: Fund-Raising for Clinton and Obama Nears Records
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign announced yesterday that it would raise in the range of $27 million for the second quarter of 2007, which ends Saturday night, and also warned supporters to prepare for a similarly dazzling result by a leading Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama.

title: 'E PLURIBUS VENOM'
description: E PLURIBUS VENOM The paradox of well-heeled and wealthy art collectors fawning over rebellious street art is apparent everywhere in the art world. The graffiti artist known as Banksy is the toast of London, while Shepard Fairey is approaching cult status in Los Angeles for his posters and stickers of the face of the professional wrestler Andre the Giant with the word obey emblazoned across them. Mr. Fairey, 37, is now having his first major New York gallery exhibition, split between the Jonathan LeVine Gallery in Chelsea and a rented 6,600-square-foot warehouse exhibition space in Brooklyn for huge graffiti installations and murals. (Last weeks opening in Brooklyn was disrupted by a man trying to set off an incendiary device.) There are about 80 works between the two sites, together forming a comprehensive, 20-year survey of his artwork in various mediums: screen prints, stencils, stickers, album covers, collage, spray paint and more. Despite the range of mediums and styles, the imagery comes off as generic, combining decorative elements with political metaphors, like an image of a couple cuddling a bomb. (Right is War for Sale.) Its Norman Rockwell crossed with the Dead Kennedys crossed with Communist-era propaganda. References to capitalism and war predominate, especially in the Chelsea show, where many works are neatly framed and ready for sale. It is tempting to see this stuff as just another luxury commodity. (Jonathan LeVine Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, ninth floor, 212-243-3822, jonathanlevinegallery.com, through July 21; 81 Front Street, at Washington Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, through July 6.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

title: The Spice Girls, Together Again
description: Like many other disbanded pop groups before them, the Spice Girls have decided to reunite, The Associated Press reported. In London yesterday, the five-member Girl Power group of the 1990s announced plans for their first concerts since breaking up in 2001 and the first with all the members of the original ensemble since Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice) left to pursue a solo career in 1998. She was on hand with Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice), Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice) to say that they had agreed on 11 concerts around the world in December and January. Obviously its nostalgic, Ms. Halliwell said. But equally, if new fans want to come along, thats fantastic. The tour will take them to Los Angeles (Dec. 7); Las Vegas (Dec. 8); New York (Dec. 11); London (Dec. 15); Cologne, Germany (Dec. 20); Madrid (Dec. 23); Beijing (Jan. 10); Hong Kong (Jan. 12); Sydney, Australia (Jan. 17); Cape Town (Jan. 20); and Buenos Aires (Jan. 24). Mrs. Beckham, a mother of three sons, said the tour would be arranged to accommodate the members children.

title: Resegregation Now
description: The Supreme Court ruled 53 years ago in Brown v. Board of Education that segregated education is inherently unequal, and it ordered the nations schools to integrate. Yesterday, the court switched sides and told two cities that they cannot take modest steps to bring public school students of different races together. It was a sad day for the court and for the ideal of racial equality.

title: Season of Sounds That Span the Globe
description: The worlds music comes to New York during the summer months. Here is an annotated sampler, in chronological order, of the vast array of such events taking place around town in coming weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about evolution and the soul misstated the views that Nancey Murphy, a philosopher at Fuller Theological Seminary, expresses in her book Bodies and Souls, or Spirited Bodies? Dr. Murphy argues that neither humans nor animals have souls, not that both have souls. She cited the ideas of Thomas Aquinas on animal and human souls to contrast with her view, not to support it.

title: Bondholders Scream Foul as Tyco Splits
description: Bondholders can be the forgotten investors in corporate America. Nobody ever promises to maximize bondholder value. Nor should they. Bond investors do not own the company, as shareholders do. They merely have a contractual relationship with it.

title: 'LE DOULOS'
description: LE DOULOS Jean-Pierre Melvilles brutal and subtly brilliant policier Le Doulos (shot in 1962, released in 1963) underscores why the French put the name to film noir. Based on the Pierre Lesou novel published by Gallimard in its celebrated Srie Noire line, the film follows the parallel fates of two criminals  Jean-Paul Belmondo as Silien, Serge Reggiani as Maurice  bound by an almost mystical sense of masculine loyalty. Mr. Belmondo, below, who had recently worn a priests collar for Melville in Lon Morin, Prtre (1961), enters Le Doulos in a more familiar Melvillian costume of a belted trench coat and fedora. A stated friend to Maurice as well as to the police, he first appears masked by an enveloping shadow, his silhouette framed in a doorway. He remains a darkly obscured figure for much of the rest of the story, a disturbing question mark for both Maurice (who believes in him) and the audience (who may not). The story eases and lurches, at times mechanistically, but what sticks and sticks hard is the way Melville fashions an entire world out of a threadbare room, a light swinging as if from a gallows, an ominous hat-check number, filigrees of cool jazz, an hourglass figure that melts into the image of a yapping dog and a masterly sense of cinematic space, exemplified by a lengthy interrogation scene. In Le Doulos the camera and the actors move in a silent conspiracy, revealing more about the true nature of a man far in advance of any line of dialogue. Le Doulos will be shown in a new 35-millimeter print, making it even easier to swoon into its darkness. (Through July 12, Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110, filmforum.org; $10.50) MANOHLA DARGIS

title: For Acadians, History Speaks in Accents Disconsolate
description: DRIVE past the potato fields of the St. John Valley in northernmost Maine, walk into Rosettes, and a four-inch-high mound of fries hand-cut from regional tubers awaits. So does some half-and-half of a linguistic variety.

Corzine during a thunderous crash in April told police officers investigating the accident that he was unaware the vehicle had its emergency lights flashing and was traveling far above the posted speed limit of 65 miles per hour, according to a report released on Thursday by the state police.

But residents dont expect to encounter George Washington and Benjamin Franklin, unless those famous faces happen to be in their wallets.

title: Sustained in Death by the Memory of One Great Love
description: At first, second and final glance, Susan Minots Evening, a claustrophobic 1998 novel about a woman in her 60s remembering the days and few torrid nights of her life while slowly, very slowly dying, doesnt seem as if it would translate easily to the big screen. It hasnt. Stuffed with actors of variable talent, burdened with false, labored dialogue and distinguished by a florid visual style better suited to fairy tales and greeting cards, this miscalculation underlines what can happen when certain literary works meet the bottom line of the movies. It also proves that not every book deserves its own film.

title: Two Car Bombs Are Found in London
description: LONDON, June 29  Two days after a new government took office under Gordon Brown, London was thrust into a new terrorism alert today when police found two Mercedes Benz cars filled with gasoline, nails and gas canisters parked close together in an area known for packed night-clubs and late-night bars.

title: DIY Art: Walk on It, Write on It, Stroke It
description: Rudolf Stingels show at Daniel Newburgs SoHo gallery in 1991 has always stuck with me. Mr. Stingel was 35 and newly arrived from Italy, and his American debut pulled no punches. He simply covered the gallerys entire floor with plush carpet so deeply orange that the white walls acquired a pinkish glow. The effect was profoundly, disturbingly, subversively optical, a Duchampian ready-made in blatant disregard of Duchamps injunction against the retinal aspect of art.

title: If It Quacks, It Could Be Your Tour Bus

The commander wears khaki fatigues and displays a knowledge of Beacon Hill, the Common and other landmarks that is nearly as impressive as his driving skills. He also turns social director, leading a chorus of his passengers in a quack quack at waving pedestrians on Newbury Street.

description: Long ago, the JVC Jazz Festival started programming its concerts by formula. Perhaps for that reason, Wednesday nights show at Carnegie Hall, built around the bassist Ron Carter, felt familiar. It was a quadruple-decker, with some of Mr. Carters old friends of high repute, as well as his two current bands, and the straw occasion for it was his 70th birthday last month.

It found that 60 percent of Americans believed at least one of the following: clear evidence had been found of links between Iraq and Al Qaeda; W.M.D. had been found in Iraq; world public opinion favored the U.S. going to war with Iraq.

Thats been clear since the last round of fighting ended nine months ago and the job of monitoring the border went to the Lebanese Army, backed up by an expanded United Nations force.

Mr. Burke, who received, and later gave up, a trademark for the term swordfish chop, also applied for a trademark on the term salmon pastrami, according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office. He did not receive a trademark on the term salmon pastrami.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on June 15, about the Japanese artist and curator Takashi Murakami, misspelled the name of the art show he runs. It is Geisai, not Gesai. It also misstated the policy of his company, Kaikai Kiki, on taking a 10 percent agents fee for works sold at the show. It does not always take a fee, and in Miami in December it plans to waive it for young artists.

title: Barriers Held Against Beatlemania, but Not March of Progress
description: They were there when the Beatles came to America, keeping screaming teenage girls from spilling into the street, and when the astronauts of Apollo 11 got a ticker-tape parade up Broadway. Same thing at the Yankees championship parades; they kept crowds to the side as the heroes glided by.

title: NIK BARTSCH'S RONIN
description: NIK BRTSCHS RONIN Zen-funk is the term that Nik Brtsch, a Swiss pianist, uses to describe the music of his five-piece band, Ronin, above. Its an eminently printable phrase, but it cleanly misses the mark. True, Mr. Brtsch composed the pieces for his recent album, Stoa (ECM), during a six-month residency in Japan. And, yes, at times those pieces do flirt with funkiness, though to draw allusions to James Brown, as some reviewers have, following Mr. Brtschs lead, is a rather dubious stretch. The problem with the term is its connotation of mind-clearing tranquillity, when Ronin proposes something much more heady and premeditated. Stoa, for instance, relies on a precision movement of interlocking parts in a manner suggestive of a timepiece. (The Swiss and the Japanese have long had this expertise in common, after all.) Minimalism is a useful frame of reference, in the same way that it is for some hard-to-classify American bands. One track on the album, Modul 35, could be considered an acoustic corollary to the music of Battles; elsewhere theres a vague resemblance to Tortoise. And videotape of Mr. Brtsch and his colleagues performing Modul 33 last fall (find it on YouTube, or at nikbaertsch.com) brings to mind the contemporary chamber group So Percussion. Next weeks showcase, which comes on the heels of festival appearances in Vancouver and Montreal, will mark Ronins United States debut. If all goes according to plan, Mr. Brtsch will engage the drummer Kaspar Rast, the percussionist Andi Pupato, the bassist Bjrn Meyer and the clarinetist Stefan Haslebacher in a tricky yet ethereal interaction thats more vivid in performance than on record. Maybe it will be meditative, and maybe it will get funky. Whatever the case, the crowd response will surely outdo the sound of one hand clapping. (Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Joes Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, 212-539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $18, with a two-drink minimum.) NATE CHINEN

title: A Big, Wide World of Music
description: Music from all over the world floods into New York City year round, but especially in summertime. Thats when outdoor stages supplement clubs and theaters, and free concert series can introduce audiences to music with lower commercial profiles.

title: Majoring in Snob Studies at Rich Kid U
description: The Best Years, a new series on the N network, immerses itself so deeply in the pits of class warfare that its characters might as well be carrying cans of mace.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) WITNESS FOR THE PROSECUTION (1957) Billy Wilders popular whodunit, an adaptation of the Agatha Christie murder mystery, was nominated for six Oscars and boasts a starry cast that includes Marlene Dietrich, Elsa Lanchester, Henry Daniell, Tyrone Power and Charles Laughton, above.

title: In Texas, Assessing Flood Damage and Preparing for More
description: GRANBURY, Tex., June 28  The sun emerged Thursday afternoon amid the thunderclouds that have soaked much of Texas in recent weeks, giving residents hope that the floodwaters will continue to recede.

title: Fed Leaves a Key Rate Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The Federal Reserve, saying that inflation remains its predominant policy concern, left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 5.25 percent on Thursday and signaled that it would keep it at that level for some time.

title: Summer Rentals: Its Not Too Late
description: EACH year, Stephen Duffy and a bunch of his friends rent a house in Provincetown, Mass., where they compete in a Labor Day tennis tournament. Finding a rental to accommodate the group in this popular beach town at the tip of Cape Cod usually involves many calls to brokers, vetting of multiple properties, and often simply settling for whatever is available.

title: William Hutt, Actor, Dies at 87
description: William Hutt, one of the foremost Canadian stage actors of his generation and a founding member of the Stratford Festival of Canada in Ontario, where he appeared in or directed 130 productions, died on Wednesday in a Stratford hospital. He was 87.

title: Thomas Hits 500th, and the Ball Is Returned
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 28  Home run balls hit by the opposition at the Metrodome usually end up thrown back on the field before the player finishes circling the bases. But when the ball Frank Thomas of Toronto hit in the first inning Thursday afternoon for his 500th career home run landed in the stands in left-center field and stayed there, Thomas figured it was bound for eBay or an auction house.

title: Messier and Stevens Lead 4 Inductees to Hall of Fame
description: Mark Messier was on a cruise with his parents and Scott Stevens was about to clean his kitchen floor yesterday when they received the news that they had been elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: Jupp Derwall,  Former Coach of West German Soccer Team, Dies at 80
description: Jupp Derwall, who coached the West German soccer team to victory in the 1980 European Championship and a second-place finish in the 1982 World Cup after a controversy-laden run to the title game, died Tuesday in St. Ingbert, Germany. He was 80.

title: Revisiting Old Friends Who Write and Fight
description: Two very different roads to the past are being traveled by two very different actresses in the Roundabout Theater Companys mildly entertaining, maddeningly disjunctive revival of Old Acquaintance, John Van Drutens 1940 comedy of high-heeled and round-heeled sexual mores in literary Manhattan.

title: Russia: Top Court Backs Ban on Terrorist Remains
description: The Constitutional Court lent its support to a government policy of withholding remains of suspected terrorists, a practice causing anguish among families in the Caucasus. Under the policy, bodies are either secretly buried or cremated. Muslim relatives have complained, saying that withholding the dead punishes families, not terrorists, and that no due process determines whether the dead were terrorists at all. Russia calls the practice an effective deterrent. The authorities have withheld remains in several prominent cases, including of leaders in the Chechen separatist movement. After militants briefly besieged the city of Nalchik in 2005, the authorities stacked more than 100 bodies in an unrefrigerated container. It later cremated them all, as relatives begged for their return.

title: Bald Eagles, Thriving, Settle Into Suburban Life
description: OCALA, Fla., June 28  Bald eagles, whose numbers dwindled to historic lows in the early 1960s, are again flourishing and no longer need the protections of the Endangered Species Act, Interior Secretary Dirk Kempthorne announced Thursday.

title: Growing in the Caribbean, Inspiring Artists Over the Centuries
description: If plants and politics seem to be entwined lately, what with genetically modified food, the payment of coffee-bean pickers, deforestation and drugs, a stroll through Paradise in Print at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is a reminder that plants have long played a major role in the human story. This is particularly true in the Caribbean, where, as an exhibition handout puts it, plants grow at such a quick pace that the gardeners most useful tool can be a machete.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday of J. B. Handelsman, a cartoonist whose work appeared in The New Yorker, included incorrect information from the Web site of The New Yorker for the caption of one of his cartoons for the magazine. The original caption, with a cartoon showing a maitre dhotel speaking by telephone to a would-be diner, read: Certainly. A party of four at seven-thirty in the name of Dr. Jennings. May I ask whether that is an actual medical degree or merely a Ph.D.? The caption in the Web sites tribute to Mr. Handelsman, which was quoted in the obituary, omitted the word merely.

title: Britain: House Prices Show a Surge
description: British house prices advanced this month at the fastest pace since December, bolstering the case for an interest rate increase by the Bank of England next week. The average cost of a home rose 1.1 percent from May, to 184,070 ($368,000), according to the Nationwide Building Society, the biggest mortgage lender in Britain. The bounce-back in June is a bit stronger than expected, said Fionnuala Earley, chief economist at Nationwide. It looks like the bank will bring forward the decision to increase interest rates, and increase the risk that rates get to 6 percent this year.

title: Russia: Gazproms Profit Doubled in 2006
description: Gazprom, Russias natural gas export monopoly, said 2006 profit doubled, to a record $22.6 billion, beating estimates, as it sold more fuel at higher prices. Net income surged 97 percent, to 613.3 billion rubles, from 311.1 billion rubles a year earlier, the state-run company said. The profit equals $22.6 billion at the average ruble rate for the period and is 8.2 percent higher than the median estimate of six analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Rising prices in Europe, where Gazprom has a quarter of the market, and increased shipments to former Soviet nations drove the gain in earnings, the highest ever reported by a Russian company. Gazprom, based in Moscow, relies entirely on exports for profit because it loses money on sales in Russia, where prices are capped.

title: Giambi Agrees to Cooperate; So Should Selig
description: Whether or not his lawyers have portrayed his circumstances to him this way, Jason Giambi has entered a plea bargain with Commissioner Bud Selig. Unlike a typical plea bargain, Selig serves as prosecutor and judge, and thats where Giambi faces a perilous problem with his decision to speak with George J. Mitchell.

title: Norman Mailer and Gnter Grass: Remembrance of Things Past
description: Norman Mailer speaking on Wednesday night at the New York Public Library with the Nobel Prize-winner Gnter Grass, said, This may well be one of the very last times I appear in public; old age is catching up with me. Still, despite walking with two canes and complaining that he couldnt hear or see well, Mr. Mailer, 84, was as feisty and funny as ever. He defended Mr. Grass, who has been attacked for what critics say is the belated acknowledgment in his new memoir, Peeling the Onion, that he served for a few months in the Waffen-SS as a teenager. Mr. Grass, best known for his novel The Tin Drum, has unflinchingly demanded that Germans account for Nazi atrocities. Mr. Mailer said he searched his own life to figure out why Mr. Grass didnt speak about his experience earlier. What have I held onto for so long? he asked, and then answered: stabbing his second wife, Adele, in 1960. Its something Ill probably never write about, he said. Ive never felt ready to write about it. Unless you can write something thats brilliant, he added, youre better off not writing about it at all. Mr. Grass, who said his SS experience was publicized in the 1960s, added that he always knew he would write about this period but that I was going to write about it when I was ready. PATRICIA COHEN

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Friday about nonprofit organizations created by John Edwards that helped keep his political profile alive after the 2004 election referred imprecisely to a donation made to an Edwards campaign committee. Although an individual donor was not identified, the donation was credited to Oak Spring Farms LLC, which listed a New York hotel as its address. The donation was not anonymous. The article also misstated the title of one of Mr. Edwardss campaign advisers. David Ginsberg is a senior adviser for communications; he is not the campaigns deputy campaign manager, a post currently held by Jonathan Prince.

description: CORNING, N.Y.  They must have been single-minded, to put it conservatively, said David Whitehouse, executive director of the Corning Museum of Glass here.

Editor Steps Down in Los Angeles
description: Douglas Frantz said yesterday that he would leave The Los Angeles Times after less than two years as managing editor, a turbulent period of transition and conflict between the newspaper and its corporate parent, the Tribune Company.

title: F.D.A. Issues Alert on Chinese Seafood
description: The Food and Drug Administration today issued an alert challenging imports of five major types of farm-raised seafood from China, including shrimp and catfish, because testing found recurrent contamination from carcinogens and antibiotics.

title: Iraqi Shiite Parties Agree to Try to Unite Moderates
description: BAGHDAD, June 28  In a tacit admission of the troubles between Iraqs two largest Shiite political parties, their respective leaders signed an agreement this week to work together and back appointments to the cabinet and other posts based on professional experience rather than party allegiances, officials said.

description: During an interview on a Boston radio station earlier this month, in anticipation of the San Francisco Giants coming to town, Boston Red Sox pitcher Curt Schilling was asked if Barry Bonds was at home run No. 754 and Schilling was pitching, would he give Bonds a pitch to hit.

description: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary programs to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky., left hundreds of school districts struggling yesterday to assess whether they must change policies that use race as a factor in school assignments.

title: 62 City Women Agree: The Farmer Needs a Wife
description: LA VIUELA, Spain  Ramn Snchez is not a great believer in the powers of Cupid. But when Mr. Snchez, a wiry 54-year-old bachelor, heard that dozens of women would be coming to this quiet village for a blind date with the local men, he happily signed up.

title: Fox Wins Wednesday Ratings Race
description: Foxs So You Think You Can Dance danced circles around its competition on Wednesday, earning the network its 24th consecutive ratings victory on Wednesdays. From 8 to 10 p.m., Foxs two-hour dance-off attracted 9.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. ABC and NBC fought a close race for second over all in the 18-to- 49 demographic. At 8 ABCs Next Best Thing finished solidly No. 2 in the hour (7.2 million), while NBCs Last Comic Standing (5.8 million) edged ahead of ABCs American Inventor (6.6 million) and CBSs Criminal Minds repeat (6.6 million) to lead the 9 oclock hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which ranked second for the night in total viewers, finished fourth in that demographic. At 10 CBSs CSI: NY (8.1 million) shared the lead in the 18-to-49 set with NBCs Dateline (6.2 million). BENJAMIN TOFF

title: Central Islip: Arson Charge Is Denied
description: A Long Island bar owner pleaded not guilty yesterday to federal arson charges that accuse him of ordering a stationery store on the same block as his bar firebombed. An indictment alleges that the bar owner, Carmine Graziano, 45, hired two men to set fire to the shop, Roseannes Cards Galore in New Hyde Park, in August 2003 in retaliation for complaints the owners made about noise and under-age drinking at his bar, Copperfields Pub. Mr. Graziano was ordered held without bail yesterday after his arraignment in Federal District Court in Central Islip. Surveillance tapes show two men throwing a rock and then a Molotov cocktail through the stores front window, prosecutors said. The fire forced the evacuation of several apartments above the store, which was destroyed; there were no serious injuries.

title: SEUN KUTI & THE EGYPT 80
description: SEUN KUTI & THE EGYPT 80 Competing with a famous father is tough enough, particularly when that father is Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the Nigerian titan of Afrobeat music who before his death from AIDS 10 years ago was one of the worlds most outrageous and electrifying musical figures. But when Seun Kuti (above), 24, Felas youngest son, began performing with his fathers band, the Egypt 80, he faced another formidable contender: his older half-brother Femi, who since the late 80s has earned the respect of critics and Afrobeat fans  not a crowd easily impressed  for his saxophone populism. Luckily or unluckily for both, their father is truly inimitable, and in addition to his music  a deliriously warped reflection of James Browns funk  Fela left a tradition of fearless political dissidence. As Seun Kuti told The Observer, the British newspaper, three years ago when graduating from the Liverpool Institute for Performing Arts, his fathers music is a mission that lives on, with room for plenty of inheritors. Things in Nigeria are even worse now, he said, and however hard it is to live up to his legacy, we have to carry on the fight for liberation and consciousness. He brings his saxophone and his fight to S.O.B.s on Sunday for his New York debut, and Femi Kuti and his band Positive Force appear at Central Park SummerStage on July 11. (9 p.m., 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, 212-243-4940, sobs.com; $30.) BEN SISARIO

title: Ecuador: U.N. Declares Galpagos Endangered
description: The Galpagos Islands have been added to a list of endangered World Heritage sites maintained by the United Nations. The archipelago, home to a array of species that inspired Charles Darwin to form his theory of natural selection, has seen annual tourist visits grow to 120,000 from 40,000 in 1996. Introduced plants now outnumber native plants, according to a report prepared by naturalists for a United Nations committee that keeps track of cultural and natural sites of international significance. Altogether 29 out of 830 heritage sites are listed as in danger, a spur to greater conservation efforts, The full list is at whc.unesco.org.

title: Manhattan: Workers Charged in Gun Sale
description: Three workers for the citys Bureau of Water Supply have been charged with participating in an illegal gun sale on city property, the Department of Investigation said yesterday. Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation, said a supervisor and two subordinates were charged in connection with the supervisors purchase of a .45-caliber pistol in the parking lot of a city water facility in the Delaware County hamlet of Grand Gorge. Ms. Gill Hearn said the supervisor, Thomas Ganz, 36 of Grahamsville, N.Y., was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, a misdemeanor. The subordinates, James Geraghty, 38, of Stamford, N.Y., and George Pennell Jr., 39, of Liberty, N.Y., were charged with falsifying business records, the department said. Dianne Struzzi, a department spokeswoman, said Mr. Geraghty, who sold the weapon, and Mr. Pennell falsely claimed that Mr. Pennell, who has a pistol permit, was the buyer. Mr. Ganz does not have a valid permit, she said.

title: David Cleans Up
description: Already naked, Donatellos David is going to be bathed in public. An 18-month, $270,000 restoration of the 15th-century bronze statue, a landmark of Renaissance sculpture, will be conducted before the eyes of visitors to the National Museum of the Bargello in Florence, Italy, The Guardian of London reported. The statue will not be moved to a laboratory for its first major restoration; instead the restorers have taken lights, cleaning equipment and lasers into the room where the statue is displayed. Television cameras and monitors will furnish spectators with close-ups of the work. The laser will be used to clean and render visible the gold leaf which we know is in the hair but also probably decorates Davids boots, said Ludovica Nicolai of the restoration team.

title: Bronx: Man Is Killed on Bridge
description: Three men were shot, one fatally, yesterday afternoon around the Willis Avenue Bridge in Mott Haven, the police said. According to the police, the victims were chased by an unknown number of young men starting at East 131st Street and Willis Avenue before they were shot. The police said they did not have a motive for the shooting and had not been able to identify the assailants. One victim, a 22-year-old man, was shot in the head on the bridge around 4:15 p.m., and pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The other two men, a 19-year-old who was shot in the buttocks and the leg and a 17-year-old who was shot in the hip, were taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and were reported in stable condition. The police did not identify the victims, but at the hospital last night, a family member, Janis Mackey, said the 17-year-old was Edward Steele of Harlem, her grandson.
