description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Giant Sees Some Strains in the System
description: As chairman and chief executive of ConocoPhillips, James J. Mulva is steering the third-largest American integrated energy company at a time of great profit but also growing concern over global warming and rising gasoline prices and questions as to whether Big Oil is doing enough to cope with either challenge.

title: Mets Fans Find Their Usual Seats in Philadelphia
description: Philadelphia

title: Immigrants Work On as Bill Dies and Views Divide
description: SAN DIEGO, June 29  Ediberto Perez pedaled his bicycle out of a canyon shantytown in this border citys northern outskirts where he and other migrant workers scratch out a living.

title: Lebanese Troops Kill 2 Palestinian Protesters and Wound 30
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29  Lebanese Army troops opened fire on Friday at Palestinian demonstrators trying to march back to their besieged refugee camp in northern Lebanon, killing two and wounding at least 30 others, Palestinian officials and witnesses said.

title: Mr. Bush Gets Another Look Into Mr. Putins Eyes
description: President Bushs June 2001 declaration that he had looked Russias Vladimir Putin in the eye and was able to get a sense of his soul was greeted with bemusement and also relief. The cowboy president wasnt, after all, going to start another cold war. But that sudden effusiveness wasnt as sudden as it appeared.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a presentation of New York Citys congestion pricing proposal to federal transportation officials in Washington gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the amount of federal money being sought to finance the proposal. It is $536.9 million, not $539 million.

title: U.S. Account of Afghan Deaths at Odds With Head of Rights Group
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 29  Four civilians were killed early Friday by American and Afghan forces in eastern Afghanistan, according to the leader of a small human rights group who gave an account of the deaths entirely at odds with that of the United States-led coalition.

title: Small Schools Are Ahead in Graduation
description: Graduation rates at 47 new small public high schools that have opened since 2002 are substantially higher than the citywide average, an indication that the Bloomberg administrations decision to break up many large failing high schools has achieved some early success.

title: Little Odessa? Maybe Not, but Bush-Putin Talks Lend This Resort a Russian Flavor
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., June 29  For the first time in its 39-year history, the Clam Shack has translated its menu of fried clams and lobster rolls into Russian.

title: Delphi Workers Accept Pay Cuts
description: DETROIT, June 29  A year ago, members of the United Automobile Workers union who gathered in Las Vegas brashly reaffirmed their fortitude with Bruce Springsteens rebellious lyrics, No retreat, baby, no surrender.

title: Backers of the Buyout Boom Seem to Be Backing Out
description: THE private equity business hit bumps. A deal was struck for a possible Dow Jones sale, and the Supreme Court struck down a longstanding rule on product pricing.

title: Taking the Earnest and Chatty Approach to Strauss and Liszt
description: Not for nothing has the New York Philharmonic placed its Summertime Classics series  now in its fourth year  in Bramwell Toveys hands. Part M.C., all enthusiasm, he talks about the music, then plunges into it with the genuine excitement of a small boy attacking a tray of fingerpaints. The orchestra seems vaguely charmed. Much sound and fury results.

title: Free Agents Top Skill: Moving Big Names
description: More than 130 players will spill into the N.B.A.s free-agent market after the clock strikes midnight tonight. That makes at least 130 new pawns in the N.B.A.s real off-season game: the hunt for Kevin Garnett.

title: How a Fan of Comic Books Transformed Himself Into a Hollywood Player
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29  Drink in hand, attaboys coming at him from every direction, Tom DeSanto was living the fanboy dream.

title: Red, White and Blue Celebration for an American Born in Berlin
description: Lukas Foss, who turns 85 in August, has in him a little of both the American dream and the American reality. He lived until 15 as a German in Berlin but has since been just about as American as an American can be. Mr. Foss was recognized at the Rose Theater at Lincoln Center on Thursday night. The music was mostly his, with Aaron Coplands Old American Songs added in.

title: Vanishing of Diamonds and Dealer Roils District
description: A diamond dealer accused by dozens of other dealers in Manhattans wholesale diamond district of swindling them out of $3 million worth of stones has fled the country, apparently to Israel, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Staten Island Man Is Charged in Home Storage of Chemicals
description: A Staten Island man with a conviction for wire fraud was charged yesterday with reckless endangerment after law enforcement authorities found more than 2,000 pounds of chemicals in his home and in a nearby storage locker during a nighttime raid, officials said.

title: M.T.A. Web Site Went Dark, Too
description: When the power went out in a broad swath of the Upper East Side and the Bronx on Wednesday, a record number of commuters turned to the Internet to learn if their subway lines or commuter trains were running. But the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys Web site provided no help.

title: Ready or Not (for Many, Its Not), New Noise Code Is Taking Effect
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has called it the first comprehensive overhaul of the New York City Noise Code in 30 years. But for all the fanfare, it is sneaking up quietly, on a city largely unprepared.

title: Courage Without the Uniform
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: Israels Deal Over Rape Charges Is Criticized as President Resigns
description: JERUSALEM, June 29  Israels disgraced president, Moshe Katsav, submitted his resignation to Parliament on Friday morning amid fierce public criticism over the deal by which rape charges against him were dropped in exchange for an admission of guilt for lesser offenses.

title: Jankovic Stays Around, but Not Without a Fight
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29  Jelena Jankovic, ranked No. 3 in the world, carries little of the distant coolness of the top-ranked Justine Henin and none of the socialite aura of No. 2 Maria Sharapova. She seems perfectly minted as a fan-friendly star, with a humble Serbian background and a smile-first personality.

title: Knicks Add Randolph and Hope for the Best
description: Zach Randolph will pull on a Knicks jersey, No. 50, on Monday, and will spend every day thereafter getting fitted for a new image under the bright lights of the big city.

title: Heaven Is Above Manhattan, and the Dress Code Is Relaxed
description: MY flight to the rooftops of Manhattan began on a summery evening when I was denied admission to Hell. Like its Biblical namesake, the place I call Hell is below ground level: you have to take three steps down from the sidewalk to enter. Appointed with red walls and staffed by waitresses in red dresses, the joint literally brims with smoke, fire, alcohol, dance music and other manifestations of sin.

title: Jeter Sees Its Time That He Speaks Up
description: Derek Jeter of the Yankees adheres strictly to the baseball code that anything that is said or seen in the clubhouse should stay in the clubhouse. Jeter stresses that he sees no merit in discussing what the Yankees say or do after reporters leave the clubhouse and the doors close.

title: U.S. Tightens Rules on Subprime Mortgages
description: Federal banking regulators set final rules on subprime mortgages yesterday, turning aside banking industry efforts to weaken them.

title: Web Space Where Religion and Social Networking Meet
description: Caitlin Todd enjoys making friends on social networking Web sites, but is turned off by content that she believes is inappropriate on a number of popular pages.

title: Another Argentine Hopes to Win a U.S. Open Title
description: EAST MEADOW, N.Y., June 29  Eduardo Romero stood ready with his driver on the first tee box Friday morning, wearing a smile and bobbing his head to the music coming from a nearby tent.

title: Commission on Veterans Care Recommends Measures to Improve Treatment at Home
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The presidential commission investigating problems in health care for military personnel wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan held its final hearing Friday, and focused on problems with moving patients through various stages of aid, from Defense Department hospitals to those run by the Veterans Administration or private health care, to home care and to jobs.

title: Grand Jury Indicts 4 Accused of Plotting to Blow Up Fuel Tanks at Kennedy
description: A federal grand jury indicted four men yesterday on charges that they plotted to ignite jet fuel tanks and pipelines at Kennedy International Airport.

title: A World of Scissors and Paper Thats Captured in Photographs
description: Daniel Gordons large color photographs, the subject of a solo exhibition at Zach Feuer Gallery in Chelsea, have several things going for them. They operate in the gap between collage and set-up photography, which is a lively place to be at the moment. They benefit from an impressive if not entirely original way with scissors that involves creating figurative tableaus from cut paper and cut-out images that Mr. Gordon then photographs.

title: As Unrest Rises, China Broadens Workers Rights
description: BEIJING, June 29  Chinas legislature passed a sweeping new labor law on Friday that strengthens protections for workers across the booming economy, a response to increasing signs of restiveness among tens of millions of migrant laborers.

title: Far Beyond Flamenco, a Zest for Rhythms (and Politics)
description: Resistance with joy. Thats how Marina Abad described the song Piedras vs. Tanques (Stones Against Tanks) when Ojos de Brujo played on Thursday at the Highline Ballroom, and the phrase could be this Spanish bands watchword.

title: Many Wishes, Many Splashes, and the Fountains at the Met Fill Up
description: Dionysos, standing there in his sandals with his arm over that woman, knows. He spends his days watching everyone in the room and everything they do.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the trial of the former media executive Conrad M. Black misidentified the London paper that Mr. Blacks former company, Hollinger International, once owned. It is The Daily Telegraph, not The Times of London.

title: Teammates Dont Mind When Lo Duca Talks the Talk
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29  The door to Manager Willie Randolphs office opened at 10:30 a.m., and out stepped catcher Paul Lo Duca, who had just spent nearly 30 minutes speaking about his exasperated outburst the night before.

title: World View Podcast
description: Greg Winter and Michael Wines discuss Zimbabwe.

title: Frog-Jumping and Other Ordered Disruptions
description: Andrew Palermo and Taye Diggs became childhood friends at the School of the Arts in Rochester. Mr. Palermo became a modern-dance choreographer and composer; Mr. Diggs went on to act on Broadway and in films and television though he continued to dance. In addition to forming a company, dre.dance, in 2004, the two also teach dance and acting. This is apparently no passing fancy for Mr. Diggs, though he has not given up that other day job.

title: For Poor Families, an Added Burden of Too Many Pets
description: SELMER, Tenn.  Phillip Swetman is an accidental owner of 13 dogs. Most, Mr. Swetman said, came from drive-bys.

title: Burial of Suicide Bombers
description: In Afghanistan, a bomber's end comes in a flash of terror and a humble grave.

title: At Dortmund, Draws All Around, so Kramnik Maintains Lead
description: Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the world champion, drew his fifth round game against Peter Leko of Hungary and maintained his half-point lead at the Dortmund super tournament with two rounds to play. Trailing him a half-point behind were Viswanathan Anand of India, the worlds top-ranked player, and Evgeny Alekseev of Russia. The official Web site for the tournament is here.

title: Bell Canada Agrees to Ontario Teachers-Led Buyout
description: Bell Canadas directors endorsed a privatization offer worth 35 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) from the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners early Saturday, The New York Times reported.

title: 2008: McCains Campaign Faces Tough Obstacles
description: With this weeks failure of the immigration bill, loathed by many G.O.P. voters and championed by Senator John McCain, talk of trouble for his campaign is picking up volume. Michael Finnegan of The Los Angeles Times examines what one Republican strategist calls a confluence of forces working against Mr. McCain:

title: A worthy cause, and an unsual press conference at Magny-Cours
description: Jean Todt, the Ferrari director, Michael Schumacher, Max Mosley and others have been supporting an interesting medical project for the past several years. Called the Institute for Cerebral and Medullary Disorders, it was founded out of the collaboration of three medical men, Professor Grard Saillant, an orthopedist and traumatologist and Yves Agid and Olivier Lyon-Caen, neurologists. Saillant has helped heal injured F1 drivers for years, including Schumacher when he broke his leg in 1999 at the British Grand Prix.

title: Another racing miracle
description: Just three weeks after the most horrendous accident in Formula One in years, when Robert Kubica, escaped injury at the Canadian Grand Prix, the GP2 series support race had its version of a miracle at Magny-Cours on Saturday. On the first lap of the race Ernesto Viso went flying through the air and hit a concrete wall in the car upside down and then spun along the top of the wall for what seemed like forever, before the car landed hard on the other side of the wall and continued its tumble. The race was stopped for an hour as the driver was extracted from his car and sent to hospital. He is reported to be in stable condition, and basically unhurt. Like the accident in Canada, this was another of the kind where it seemed nearly impossible for the driver to have survived. Twice lucky. But it is impossible not to think of Alain Prosts words before the death of Ayrton Senna in Imola, after Rubens Barrichello had a serious accident on the Friday and Roland Ratzenberger was killed on the Saturday. Prost spoke of his belief in the law of series. Thank goodness the sport has never ceased its driver for safety since then.

title: New Orleans East
description: New York Times reporter Susan Saulny visits the East New Orleans street that her parents hope to come back to by Thanksgiving.

title: IPhone: Waiting for Ma Bell
description: We are in the first day of the AiP (After iPhone) era. It turns out that Apple had so many iPhones in stock  that there was no reason to wait in line. AT&T stores were not so well stocked, at least according to some accounts.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 1
description: In her news analysis, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, a White House correspondent for The Times, wrote that a string of Republican defections this week put the president in danger of losing control over a party that once marched in lockstep with him. Each of the defections  on Iraq, immigration and domestic eavesdropping  is featured on this weeks Sunday breakfast menu.

title: Sad Scenes at an AT&T Wireless Store
description: After spending six hours in line, then another 90 minutes inside the Apple Store in Corte Madera, north of San Francisco, I decided to check out the action at the AT&T Wireless store in nearby San Rafael.

title: IPhone Good News and Bad News
description: The following video may not be suitable for all viewers. In it, PC Worlds correspondent attempts to damage a shiny new iPhone by shaking it in a Ziplock bag full of keys; by keying it deliberately; by dropping it repeatedly onto concrete; and more. Even I was surprised by the results.

title: A Battery of Questions
description: Joe Nocera, the Saturday columnist for the Times, took Apple to task for designing a cell phone with a battery that cannot be replaced by the consumer.
